site_title: China cuts down payment requirements to boost property sector
summary: China has cut the minimum down payment level for first-time home buyers to 25% in cities without restrictions, aiming to boost the sluggish property market and support economic growth. The move, part of a two-day series of measures, follows the halving of tax on small car sales. The property sector accounts for 15% of China's GDP, and the relaxed rule is expected to stimulate demand and relieve pressure on the economy, which is expected to expand at its slowest pace in a quarter of a century this year.

site_title: Hoteliers seeing unexpected boost from migrant influx
summary: German hoteliers are experiencing an unexpected boom due to the influx of migrant asylum seekers, with many hotels filling rooms that would otherwise remain empty. The government is paying states 670 euros per month for each asylum seeker they house, leading to a surge in bookings. Hoteliers are mixing humanitarian concerns with business sense, with some leasing hotels for years to accommodate refugees. The arrangement has generated significant revenue for hotels, with some reporting costs of up to 50 euros per night per migrant.

site_title: German unemployment inches up in September
summary: German unemployment rose seasonally by 2,000 to 2.795 million in September, but the unemployment rate remained at 6.4%, a post-reunification low. This suggests consumer spending in Europe's largest economy remains positive. The unadjusted unemployment total fell to 2.708 million, the lowest level since 1991.

site_title: Senate passes US spending bill hours before shutdown
summary: The US Senate passed a spending bill hours before a government shutdown, sending it to the House for a vote. The measure funds Planned Parenthood and passed 78-20 in the Senate. President Barack Obama's administration supports the bill, and Speaker John Boehner has promised a vote. Conservative Republicans object to the bill, citing undercover videos of Planned Parenthood officials discussing fetal tissue. The House has set up a procedure for a vote, and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell plans to discuss a two-year spending limit with Boehner and Obama.

images.alt_text: The Senate passed a US government spending plan hours before a shutdown deadline, sending the bill to the House where Speaker John Boehner promised a vote over objections from fellow Republicans who wanted to use it to defund Planned Parenthood.

site_title: Bank Indonesia to intervene in forwards market from October
summary: Bank Indonesia plans to intervene in the currency forwards market from October to stabilize the rupiah, which has dropped 9% this quarter. The central bank aims to signal its policy stance and address the gap between supply and demand in the markets. The rupiah's three-month implied yield rose to a two-year high, and Bank Indonesia will offer foreign-exchange bills before the end of October to boost dollar supply locally. The move aims to mitigate the impact of the currency's weakness on inflation and foreign-currency debt.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific to buy freehold residential site near Marine Parade for S$21.5 million
summary: Roxy-Pacific has agreed to acquire a freehold residential site near Marine Parade in Singapore for S$21.5 million. The 19,474 sq ft site has an existing plot ratio of 1.4 and will be financed by internal funds and bank borrowings. The acquisition is not expected to impact the group's earnings or net tangible assets per share for the current financial year. The purchase price works out to S$789 per sq ft per plot ratio.

site_title: Airbus A320neo suffers setback as Pratt engine damaged in tests
summary: Airbus A320neo jet suffered a setback after a Pratt engine was damaged during flight trials in hot weather conditions. The damage was discovered in one of the test plane's two powerplants, raising questions about the Pratt & Whitney-manufactured turbine. Despite this, Airbus stated that deliveries of the A320neo should still begin as scheduled later this year. The incident occurred on a test plane powered by the PW1100G engine, which is set to be used on the first A320neo for Qatar Airways.

site_title: Bobby Chin appointed HDB deputy chairman (Amended)
summary: Bobby Chin, former managing partner of KPMG Singapore, has been appointed as the new deputy chairman of the Housing and Development Board (HDB) of Singapore, effective October 1, 2015. The new HDB Board term will run until September 30, 2018. Other new members include Lily Kong, Heng Chye Kiang, Sudha Nair, and Teoh Zsin Woon. James Koh Cher Siang has been re-appointed as chairman, and six other members have also been re-appointed.

site_title: Hong Leong Asia warns of net loss for Q3
summary: Hong Leong Asia, the trade and industrial arm of Hong Leong Group, has warned of a net loss for its Q3 ended Sept 30, mainly due to higher losses in its consumer products unit. The firm expects a loss for the nine months ended Sept 30, citing lower unit sales and insufficient profits from other segments to offset the losses. The company will announce its Q3 results in November, with its shares falling 2.2% to S$0.89 on Wednesday.

site_title: Ralph Lauren hands over helm at iconic fashion brand
summary: Ralph Lauren, 75, is stepping down as CEO of the iconic fashion brand in November, handing over the top executive post to 41-year-old Stefan Larsson, global president of Old Navy. Larsson, who will remain as chief creative officer, brings a fresh global perspective to the company, which has been a leader in the industry for nearly 50 years. The transition comes after the company's disappointing financial results, with its share price down 43% over the past 12 months.

site_title: STI narrowly avoids sixth day of loss
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended the day with a gain of 2.95 points, avoiding a sixth consecutive loss. The index fell to an intraday low of 2,772 before rebounding due to gains in Hong Kong and China indices, as well as US futures. For the quarter, the STI shed 527 points, or 16%, while for the year, it has lost 17%. Turnover on Wednesday was boosted by active trading in commodity stocks, with Noble and Golden Agri contributing to the index's record volume of S$1.07 billion.

site_title: EU steel industry warns China of complaint on hot-rolled coil
summary: The European Union steel industry warns China of a complaint on hot-rolled coil imports, citing prices below production costs. Chinese shipments to the EU doubled to 660,000 metric tons last year, with the first half of 2015 reaching over 700,000 tons. The European Steel Association, Eurofer, is seeking to file a complaint to the European Commission, alleging dumping, which could lead to EU tariffs on Chinese producers. This move highlights concerns over excess capacity in China's steel market and the impact on European steel producers.

site_title: Glencore recoups most of Monday's 29% plunge
summary: Glencore shares jumped 11% to 88.83 pence, recouping most of Monday's 29% plunge, as investors saw a bargain and metals prices rose. The company, facing criticism over its debt load, is raising over $1 billion by selling future production of gold and silver. CEO Glasenberg is working on a debt-cutting plan, including asset sales and a $2.5 billion share sale. Despite a "quasi-Lehman moment" of rumors about its viability, Glencore says it has good liquidity and strong credit lines, reassuring investors.

site_title: Investors pull US$40b from emerging market assets in Q3 - IIF
summary: Global investors pulled an estimated US$40 billion from emerging market assets in Q3, the worst quarter since 2008, according to the Institute of International Finance. This was largely due to dovish signals from the US Federal Reserve, which cited concerns about slower global growth and market turbulence. The Fed held off raising interest rates for the first time since 2006, providing only a short-lived boost to emerging market flows.

site_title: Virgin Active to become anchor tenant at Tanjong Pagar Centre
summary: GuocoLand has signed a multi-year contract with Virgin Active to become the anchor tenant at the Tanjong Pagar Centre mixed-use development. The 31,000 sq ft fitness centre will open by mid-2016, featuring a high-altitude training studio and a 200 sq m exercise studio. This is Virgin Active's second outlet in Singapore, with the largest studios in Asia. The integrated development will also include retail and residential components.

site_title: Australian capital to regulate ride-sharing app Uber
summary: The Australian Capital Territory (ACT) government announced it will regulate ride-sharing services like Uber, becoming the first capital in the world to do so. Starting October 30, drivers and vehicles must undergo accreditation and registration. The move aims to reduce fares for commuters and encourage innovation in the transport industry. The ACT also plans to halve fees for taxis and hire cars from 2016 and 2017, respectively. This decision comes after similar regulations were introduced in the Philippines and France, and amid ongoing legal challenges to ride-sharing services in other cities.

site_title: Rocket Internet startups see revenue jump, losses grow
summary: Rocket Internet's top startups saw a 6% increase in average operating margin in the first half, despite making hefty losses. Revenue grew strongly across several companies, including Global Fashion Group (63% increase), Home24 (98% increase), and Westwing (48% increase). The company's portfolio value increased to 3.4 billion euros, driven by a recent financing round. Despite strong revenue growth, Rocket Internet's shares have slumped since its listing in Frankfurt last year. The company's losses remain significant, despite the improvement in operating margins.

site_title: QT Vascular wins patent infringement case
summary: QT Vascular successfully defended itself against a patent infringement lawsuit filed by AngioScore. After a seven-day trial in California, a jury unanimously decided that QT Vascular's "Chocolate PTA" balloon catheter does not infringe AngioScore's '119 Patent. The verdict confirms that Chocolate is substantially different from the design disclosed in the patent. As a result, QT Vascular does not expect to incur any liability on the patent claim, allowing it to continue selling the product without impediment.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end 17 points higher
summary: Malaysian shares rose 17.72 points to 1,621.040 on Wednesday, driven by gains of 573 to 277 lots traded, valued at RM2.48 billion.

site_title: Australia: Shares end worst quarter since 2011
summary: Australian shares ended their worst quarter since 2011, with the S&P/ASX 200 index falling 8.0% for the quarter, its biggest three-month drop since 2011. The benchmark rose 2.1% on the final day but failed to offset previous losses. New Zealand's benchmark also fell 2.3% for the quarter, its biggest decline since 2012. The decline follows months of volatility and is attributed to a recovery bounce from the previous day's heavy selling.

images.alt_text: Australian shares bucked a poor performance by Wall Street to edge 0.6 per cent higher on Thursday, aided by a hunt for dividend yield and more merger action.

site_title: German retail sales slip in August: data
summary: German retail sales slipped 0.4% in August, down from a 1.6% increase in July, amid potential signs of waning consumer confidence. This marks a reversal from the 2.4% increase in retail sales on a 12-month basis in August. The decline in retail sales follows a leading consumer sentiment survey that found consumers are worried about the economic consequences of the European refugee crisis.

site_title: Eurozone inflation turns negative, putting pressure on ECB
summary: Eurozone inflation turned negative in September, falling 0.1% on an annual basis, as oil prices tumbled. This marks the first time inflation has dipped below zero since March, raising pressure on the European Central Bank to boost asset purchases. Analysts expect the ECB to increase or extend its quantitative easing scheme, citing long-term inflation expectations at their lowest level since February. The ECB has flexibility to act, but some economists warn that easing its commitment to meeting its target could damage credibility.

images.alt_text: The European Central Bank plans to tighten rules on meetings by Executive Board members with investors and ensure the immediate release of the content of closed-door presentations, people familiar with the matter said.

site_title: China: Stocks finish the day higher
summary: China's stocks rose, paring the biggest quarterly loss since 2008, as the government cut a tax on vehicle purchases, leading to gains for automakers. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.5% to 3,052.78, after plummeting 29% since June. The government has taken measures to shore up stocks, including banning major shareholders from selling and curbing index futures trading, but President Xi Jinping signaled that policy makers will pare back support as volatility subsides.

site_title: Singapore's non-resident population grew at slower pace this year: report
summary: Singapore's non-resident population grew at a slower pace of 2.1% this year, down from 2.9% last year, due to easing growth in the foreign workforce. The country's total population grew 1.2% to 5.54 million, with a higher proportion of citizen marriages and births. However, the population continues to age, with the proportion of citizens aged 65 and above increasing to 13.1% from 12.4% last year. The government plans to support businesses to shift towards skills- and capital-intensive growth to create quality jobs for Singaporeans.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Bobby Chin appointed HDB's deputy chairman
summary: Bobby Chin, former managing partner of KPMG Singapore, has been appointed as the new deputy chairman of the Housing and Development Board (HDB) starting October 1, 2015. The new HDB Board term will run until September 30, 2018. Chin's appointment was announced by the Ministry of National Development. Other new members include Lily Kong, Heng Chye Kiang, Sudha Nair, and Teoh Zsin Woon. James Koh Cher Siang has been re-appointed as chairman.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Heathrow chief wants carbon cuts, clean fuel research
summary: Heathrow Airport CEO John Holland-Kaye is urging world leaders to accelerate greenhouse gas reductions and implement a mandatory carbon-offset program for the aviation industry to combat climate change. He also called for research into cleaner fuels and more efficient technology. The airport aims to reduce its emissions by 34% by 2020 and is phasing in electric vehicles. Holland-Kaye's proposal comes as the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) considers a new carbon offset market, which would start in 2020 and cover all nations.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end bruising third quarter with a solid gain
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the third quarter with a 1.4% gain, but the benchmark Hang Seng Index still plummeted 20.6% for the quarter due to global growth worries and US monetary policy uncertainty. Analysts predict further decline, with some predicting a drop to 18,000 points. A surge in Chinese auto shares and energy sector rebounded helped lift market sentiment, with Hong Kong-listed automakers and energy companies surging over 10% and 4.5% respectively. Despite the short-term gain, many investors remain pessimistic about the market's bearish trend.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks ended barely changed on Thursday, as most Asian markets stabilised after jitters over Turkey's downing of a Russian fighter jet abated.

site_title: 7-Eleven Australia chiefs resign over wage fraud claims
summary: 7-Eleven Australia's chairman and CEO, Warren Wilmot, and chairman Russell Withers, have resigned following allegations of wage fraud. Franchisees allegedly underpaid workers, with some even doctoring pay slips to cover up underpayments. A Senate inquiry found evidence of exploitation, particularly affecting international students. The company has appointed an interim CEO, Michael Smith, to lead a search for a permanent replacement, and will work to uncover the extent of underpayments and implement remedies.

site_title: China to improve management of FX reserves: SAFE
summary: China will continue to see a current account surplus but face capital and financial account deficits in the second half of 2015, according to the State Administration of Foreign Exchange (SAFE). The country aims to maintain a stable yuan while improving foreign exchange reserve management and monitoring cross-border capital flows to ensure safety.

site_title: Europe: Shares rebound from 2015 lows at end of bruising quarter
summary: European shares rose at the end of a bruising quarter, rebounding from 2015 lows. The FTSEurofirst 300 index advanced 2.45% and the Euro STOXX 50 index rose 2.48%. A Chinese tax cut boosted automakers and miner Glencore, while a stronger dollar also contributed to the rebound. The market was squeezed, but a stronger dollar is helping risk appetite return, according to fund manager Roberto Lottici. European inflation turned negative again, increasing pressure on the European Central Bank to boost asset purchases.

images.alt_text: European shares rose on Wednesday after reaching 2015 lows as a bruising quarter ended, with a Chinese tax cut boosting automakers while miner Glencore rallied after saying it had no solvency issues.

site_title: Asian currencies rise as global equity rout jitters ease
summary: Asian currencies rose against the dollar on Wednesday, with the yen and other currencies gaining ground as global equity markets rebounded from a recent rout. The Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hike is expected to have a short-lived impact, with analysts predicting losses for Asian currencies versus the US dollar. The yen weakened against peers, while the euro and other currencies strengthened. The Fed's decision on interest rates is expected to influence emerging economies, with improving labor market data in the US adding pressure for a rate hike.

site_title: Europe: Stocks up as investors assess value in volatile quarter
summary: European stocks rose 1.8% to 345.43, rebounding from Tuesday's decline, amid concerns over a slowdown in Asia and uncertainty over the Federal Reserve's actions. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index has fallen 9.4% in the third quarter, its worst performance since 2011. Investors will also monitor economic reports, including unchanged Euro-area unemployment and a 0.9% rise in consumer prices. Stocks like Rio Tinto and J Sainsbury Plc rose after positive corporate news, while investors await US-EU trade talks and further guidance from the Federal Reserve.

site_title: JTC net surplus up 7% to S$1.4b
summary: JTC Corporation reported a 7% increase in its group net surplus to S$1.4 billion for the 2014 financial year, driven by higher land and building rental income and gains from industrial government land sales. Operating revenue rose 7% to S$1.85 billion, while capital expenditure increased 31% to S$2.3 billion. Total borrowings fell 80% to S$494 million, and total equity rose 9% to S$18.3 billion. The company's investment properties decreased 15% to S$12.1 billion.

site_title: UK house price growth picks up in September: Nationwide
summary: The UK's annual house price growth accelerated to 3.8% in September, up from 3.2% in August, according to Nationwide. This represents a 0.5% month-on-month increase, exceeding expectations. The housing market appears to be rebounding, with house prices rising for the first time in five months.

site_title: WTO cuts trade forecasts
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) has revised down its forecasts for global goods trade, cutting growth projections to 2.8% this year and 3.9% in 2016. The downgrade, announced on September 30, 2015, follows quarterly growth turning negative, with trade shrinking by an average of 0.7% in the first two quarters of the year. The WTO attributes the downward revision to risks such as a potential US interest rate rise and slowing in developing economies.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei rebounds as financials soar, ends quarter down 14.1 per cent
summary: Japanese stocks rebounded 2.7% on Wednesday, closing at 17,388.15, after a 14.1% decline in the quarter. Despite factory output falling for the second straight month, analysts attributed the rebound to bargain-hunting on Tuesday's slump and hopes of fresh stimulus to boost growth. Financial sectors outperformed, with banking and insurance indices rising 3.9% and 4%, respectively. The broader Topix index gained 2.6% to 1,411.16, but lost 13.5% for the quarter.

site_title: Temasek's Ho Ching returns in October as president takes bigger role
summary: Temasek Holdings CEO Ho Ching is set to return from a six-month sabbatical in October as one of the company's three presidents. Ho will remain CEO and executive director, while taking on the role of chairman for Temasek International. Lee Theng Kiat, who led Temasek during Ho's absence, will become CEO of Temasek International, overseeing commercial strategies and portfolio management. The changes take effect from October 1, allowing Ho to focus on her stewardship role, protecting the company's past reserves.

site_title: Singapore's central bank set to ease again in October policy meet: Credit Suisse
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), is expected to ease its monetary policy in October, shifting to a neutral policy stance or zero appreciation. This move aims to counter the economic slowdown, particularly due to weak industrial production and deteriorating growth outlook in China and Asia. Employment growth has also slowed, with the unemployment rate inching up to 2.8% in Q2 2015. The expected impact on GDP is expected to be small, with MAS keeping its forecast at 1.7% for 2015.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Toshiba adds US$3.3 billion credit line after accounting probe
summary: Toshiba Corp added a 400 billion yen (S$4.7 billion) credit line with banks amid uncertainty about accounting costs related to a scandal that has led to over $1.3 billion in profit cuts. The two-year credit line brings the total loan facility to 762 billion yen, supplementing cash reserves. Toshiba's shares gained 3.3% after the announcement, paring this year's decline to 41%. The company faces further costs related to fines and investor lawsuits.

site_title: UOB rolls out brand campaign in line with its 80th anniversary
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) is launching a brand campaign as part of its 80th anniversary celebrations, focusing on its commitment to customers and employees. The campaign, "Right by you," highlights the bank's timeless values of being honourable, enterprising, united, and committed. Based on research, UOB found that customers perceive the bank as dependable, and staff training reinforces these values. The campaign will be rolled out globally, starting in Singapore, and aims to position UOB for long-term success.

images.alt_text: UNITED Overseas Bank (UOB) is rolling out a brand campaign as part of its 80th anniversary celebrations.

site_title: China aircraft carrier launch by end-2015 credible, experts say
summary: China is reportedly ready to launch its first domestically made aircraft carrier, the type 001A, by the end of 2015, according to a Hong Kong-based newspaper. The non-nuclear-powered carrier is expected to take several years to enter service, with a potential launch date of December 26 and a service date of October 1, 2019. Experts say China's growing naval might and ability to test the US Navy's dominance are major concerns. However, analysts also note that China's carrier program may be less important in the future due to the development of sophisticated anti-ship capabilities.

site_title: URA releases residential sites in Redhill, Sembawang for sale
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has released two residential sites for sale in Singapore. The first site, located near Redhill MRT, can yield 400 units and has a first-storey commercial component, with a site area of 8,400 sq m. The second site is in Sembawang, but the article does not provide further details about this site. The tender for the Redhill site will close on November 12, 2015.

site_title: ANZ to open first Myanmar branch on Oct 2
summary: ANZ Banking Group announced it will open its first branch in Myanmar on October 2 after receiving final regulatory approval. The Yangon branch will be among the nine lenders to receive preliminary approval, with limited licences to one branch per bank and foreign currency loans only to foreign companies. The bank will also lend to domestic banks.

site_title: Multinational China executives feel chill wind, not hot growth
summary: China's economy is officially growing at 7% annually, but many multinational executives report a slowdown in their businesses, with some sectors experiencing flat or declining sales growth. Executives from various industries, including banking, consumer goods, and heavy machinery, say they feel the economy is growing between 3-5%. This gap between official growth figures and on-the-ground performance is a challenge for local executives, who often rely on GDP data to set revenue and profit targets.

site_title: Seoul: Shares reverse early loss to close up 1 per cent; won gains
summary: South Korean shares reversed an early loss to close up 1% on Wednesday, as investors caught up after a long weekend and foreigners turned net buyers, purchasing 148 billion won worth of shares. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) ended the session at 1,962.91 points, up 1% for the day, after falling 1.4% early in the session. This marks the end of a four-straight-month losing streak for the KOSPI, which slid 5.4% quarterly. The South Korean won also broke a five-day losing streak, closing up 0.8% to 1,185.3 per dollar.

site_title: Rio Tinto sells Australian coal mine stake
summary: Rio Tinto sells its 40% stake in the Australian Bengalla coal mine to New Hope Group for US$606 million, part of US$4.5 billion in asset divestments since 2013. The sale is expected to be completed by early 2016, amid slowing demand from China and a downward spiral in commodity prices. Rio Tinto aims to focus on its core portfolio, while New Hope sees the purchase as a positive long-term outlook in the global export market.

site_title: Indonesia rewards China's "courage" with high-profile rail contract
summary: Indonesia awarded a $5 billion rail contract to China, beating Japan, due to China's willingness to provide loans without guarantees. The 150km Jakarta-Bandung railway will be built at a medium speed, not the initially planned high speed. Indonesia prefers China's proposal due to its lower financial burden and promise of technology transfer. This win is seen as a victory for China's "One Belt One Road" initiative, and analysts expect Indonesia to be a front-runner for future regional rail projects. Japan expressed disappointment and hopes for more transparency in the future.

site_title: Ringgit's slide spurs worst quarterly bond losses in six years
summary: Malaysia's ringgit currency declined 15% from June 30, the steepest drop since 1997, leading to the nation's worst quarterly bond losses in six years. This decline, combined with slowing Chinese growth and a looming US interest-rate increase, prompted global investors to pull funds from Malaysian stocks and bonds. The 10-year government bond yield climbed 29 basis points to 4.30%, pushing up borrowing costs for the country's US$444 billion development programme. The nation's stocks were the only bright spot, falling 5.8% this quarter.

site_title: China steel futures hit record low as export lifeline shrinks
summary: China's steel rebar futures hit a record low of 1,820 yuan (S$408.1) a tonne in the final session before the National Day holiday, amid a slowing economy and declining export volumes. The decline in demand has exacerbated overcapacity problems in the steel sector, leading to prices not seen in over two decades. Chinese steel exports have risen 26.5% in the first eight months of the year, but are now under threat due to weak demand and lower overseas prices.

images.alt_text: Chinese steel rebar futures fell to a fresh record low in the final morning session before the National Day holiday, with few anticipating any big upturn in demand over the rest of the year, especially as export volumes decline.

site_title: China cuts tax on small-engine cars to revive market
summary: China has cut sales tax on small-engine cars to boost its stagnant car market. The tax cut, effective until the end of 2016, applies to cars with 1.6-litre engines or smaller, accounting for 70% of total sales. The move lifted shares of major Chinese automakers, including Great Wall Motor, BYD, and BAIC Motor. However, analysts predict the market may not see a significant turnaround, with flat sales in the first eight months of 2015 and potential contraction in 2015.

site_title: Seoul: Shares fall, won edges up in catch-up trade after long weekend
summary: Seoul shares fell 0.4% to 1,934.50 points, with 27 losers outweighing 10 gainers, as investors played catch-up after a long weekend amid concerns over China's slowing economy. Pharmaceutical shares underperformed, falling 3.6%, and foreigners were set to be net sellers for a sixth consecutive session. The South Korean won edged up 0.2% to 1,192.9 per dollar, reversing a five-day losing streak.

site_title: Update: China sees capital account deficit, volatile fund flows in H2
summary: China is expected to continue a deficit on its capital and financial account in the second half of 2015 due to global market volatility, particularly concerns over the US Federal Reserve's interest rate rise and emerging market currency volatility. China posted a $125.6 billion deficit in the first half, including a $40.6 billion deficit in the March-June quarter. The country's central bank has intervened to keep the yuan stable, and authorities will strengthen monitoring of cross-border capital flows to curb outflows. China's current account surplus in the first half was 3.1% of its GDP.

images.alt_text: China's central bank has intervened heavily to keep the yuan steady after it shocked global markets by devaluing the yuan by nearly 2 per cent on Aug 11, running down its foreign exchange reserves by a record amount that month.

site_title: Asia: Markets rebound, Glencore surges after crash
summary: Asian markets rebounded slightly on Wednesday after a mass sell-off in the previous session, with Glencore rising 15% after reassuring investors about its business. Emerging currencies ended a tough quarter on a high, but analysts warned of further volatility ahead, citing weak commodity prices and China's slowdown. The Federal Reserve's Janet Yellen is set to speak later, with hopes for clarity on US interest rate plans.

site_title: Traders flee emerging markets at fastest pace since 2008
summary: Investors have pulled $40 billion out of developing economies in the third quarter, the fastest pace since 2008, amid faltering Chinese economic growth, slumping commodity prices, and a strong US dollar. This outflow was the first since 2009 and the largest since 2008, with $19 billion in equities and $21 billion in debt. The MSCI Emerging Markets stocks benchmark has declined 20% in the past three months, and local-currency developing-nation bonds have lost 6.6% in dollar terms.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rebound from losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks rebounded 1.16% on Wednesday after a sharp decline the previous day, driven by bargain-buying. The Hang Seng Index rose to 20,795.93, while Glencore, which fell 30% on Tuesday, jumped 12%. Shanghai and Shenzhen indices also gained, with the Shanghai Composite Index up 0.48% and the Shenzhen Composite Index up 0.44%. The rebound follows a global stocks rally and comes as investors brush off new Trump threats.

site_title: More auto tech could curb road accidents: researchers
summary: Researchers from Boston Consulting Group say new automotive safety technologies can reduce road accidents in the US by 28% and save thousands of lives. These technologies, such as automatic braking and lane control assistance, could lead to a 90% reduction in accidents over time. The study found that adopting these technologies would save 9,900 lives and $251 billion in societal costs annually. However, slow adoption due to high costs is a significant missed opportunity, with experts calling for increased consumer education and federal incentives to promote their use.

images.alt_text: Nvidia's senior director of automotive business Danny Shapiro displays the electronic dashboard of an Audi automobile in Santa Clara, California, in this February 11, 2015 file photo.

site_title: China: Stocks rise, paring world's worst quarterly performance
summary: China's stocks rose 0.6% on Wednesday, paring their worst quarterly loss since 2008, as the government struggled to halt a $5 trillion rout. The Shanghai Composite Index tumbled 29% since June, with the value of shares traded on mainland bourses plummeting 87% from the June record. The government has taken unprecedented measures to shore up stocks, including banning major shareholders from selling and curbing index futures trading. Despite efforts to support shares, investors remain cautious due to weak economic data and concerns about the outlook for corporate earnings.

site_title: Growth in bank lending in Singapore eases again to 0.5% in August: MAS
summary: Bank lending in Singapore rose 0.5% in August to S$613 billion, slower than the 0.6% gain in July. Business loans increased 0.8% to S$373 billion, while consumer lending remained flat at S$240 billion. This marks a weaker growth pace compared to the 2.2% year-on-year gain in July.

site_title: Little progress on dairy, autos in Atlanta TPP trade talks: New Zealand official
summary: New Zealand's agricultural trade envoy Mike Petersen stated that Trans-Pacific Partnership talks have made no progress on key areas such as dairy and automobiles. Trade ministers from 12 countries are set to meet in Atlanta, with negotiations on improved access for New Zealand's dairy exports to the US, Canada, and Japan. Trade Minister Tim Groser previously deemed the deal "inadequate" for New Zealand's dairy market access. Officials are awaiting ministers to make key decisions on these areas, with the deal potentially setting common standards for 40% of the world economy.

site_title: G7, Gulf states pledge US$1.8 billion for UN refugee aid
summary: The G7 group, European countries, and Gulf states pledged $1.8 billion in funding for UN refugee aid, addressing the worst refugee crisis in 70 years. The commitment was made after UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon warned of UN humanitarian agencies being "broke." The funding will primarily support the UN refugee agency and the World Food Program. The pledge was announced following a meeting of G7 foreign ministers with their Gulf counterparts.

site_title: Shophouses in Geylang up for sale at S$1,350 psf
summary: A row of five adjoining shophouses on 236-244 Geylang Road has been put up for sale by JLL for S$28.8 million, or around S$1,350 psf. The property, held under a single title, features a Chinese restaurant, provision shop, office, and association spaces. The sale price is indicative and follows recent sales of shophouses in the area, including an OCBC property that sold for S$5.1 million and a strata-titled shophouse that sold for S$4 million in 2014.

site_title: New moneylending rules to kick in on Thursday in Singapore
summary: New moneylending rules in Singapore will take effect on October 1, 2015, capping upfront fees at 10% of the loan principal, monthly interest at 4%, late interest and fees at 4% and $60 respectively, and total borrowing costs at 100% of the principal. These caps do not apply to business loans granted to registered businesses. The move aims to protect borrowers from exorbitant interest rates and fees while preserving access to credit for the industry.

site_title: Thai rate cut was likely to have minimal impact: central bank minutes
summary: Thailand's central bank kept interest rates unchanged at 1.50% for a third consecutive meeting, citing minimal impact from further easing on the economy while maintaining financial stability risks. The decision was made despite efforts to boost the economy after the 2014 army coup. The bank's monetary policy committee agreed that overall monetary conditions remain conducive to economic recovery, with the exchange rate also seen as supportive.

site_title: India talks tough on black money in hunt for hidden billions
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi is set to crack down on black money, with a three-month deadline ending on September 30 for tax evaders to declare hidden assets and pay a softer penalty. Those who comply will face immunity from prosecution, while those who don't risk up to 10 years in jail. Modi's government aims to bring billions of rupees into the light, following a pledge to tackle the "menace" of black money. The move is part of a broader effort to increase tax revenue and curb corruption.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise 0.7 per cent led by banks, miners
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% on Wednesday, led by gains in banks and miners, after hitting a two-year low the previous day. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 35.6 points to 4,954, despite concerns about global growth and China. Major banks ANZ and NAB led the gains, while miner Rio Tinto surged 2.4% after selling a coal mine stake. Energy provider AGL slipped 4% after releasing profit expectations. The market is expected to end 2015 roughly 6% above Tuesday's close, despite year-end expectations being slashed by most strategists.

site_title: Apple launches Apple Music in China
summary: Apple launched Apple Music in China, offering a 10 yuan ($2.24) monthly subscription for a vast music library, as part of its efforts to expand its business in the country. The service will initially be available on iPhones and iPads, with Android phone compatibility planned for this fall. This move comes as Apple seeks to reassure shareholders about its business in China, where the company has been facing challenges.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks down on return from holiday; chip shares outperform
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.3% on Wednesday, despite gains in local chip makers, due to concerns over the local economy. The TAIEX index closed at 8,106.16. Last Thursday, the central bank cut benchmark rates for the first time in six years to stimulate economic growth. Chip shares, particularly TSMC, outperformed, while the financials subindex lost 1.7%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$0.342 to T$32.950 per US dollar.

site_title: Pacific trade ministers aim to seal TPP trade pact
summary: Pacific trade ministers from 12 countries, including the US, Canada, and Japan, are set to finalize the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) agreement in Atlanta after stalled talks in Hawaii. The deal aims to create the world's largest free trade region, lowering trade barriers and strengthening intellectual property protections. Despite vocal opposition, 90% of issues have been settled, with negotiators aiming to present a final agreement for ratification to governments. The US hopes to lock in rules that China would eventually have to follow, while critics argue the pact favors industry groups over environmental and labor standards.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Wednesday, down 1.53 points to 1602.52, amid a 69.3 million lots traded worth RM23.9 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 95 to 62.

site_title: China's cabinet promotes online-offline business links
summary: China's State Council has issued guidelines promoting online-offline business links to spur consumption and economic activity amid slowing growth. The guidelines encourage partnerships between internet companies and physical stores, mobile Internet adoption, and e-commerce development in rural areas. The government will also unveil financial support for the sector, aiming to cut red tape and promote tax and financial incentives. This move is seen as a way to drive innovation and development in the flow of commerce, and to transform physical stores through business model innovation and entrepreneurship.

site_title: US gathers great Asian democracies to its side
summary: US President Barack Obama gathered senior officials from the US, Japan, and South Korea to reaffirm their ties and show a united front against North Korean threats and China's assertive stance in the region. The meeting, held on the sidelines of the UN General Assembly, aimed to deepen economic ties through the Trans-Pacific Partnership and maintain maritime security through trilateral cooperation. The US camp expressed concern over North Korea's potential long-range rocket test and China's growing maritime territorial ambitions, while Beijing remains a key partner in countering the North Korean threat.

site_title: NZ business sentiment improves, but still pessimistic: survey
summary: New Zealand business sentiment improved in September, with a net 18.9% of respondents expecting the economy to deteriorate over the year ahead, down from 29.1% in the previous poll. A net 16.7% of respondents expected their businesses to grow, up from 12.2% last month. Inflation expectations remained steady at 1.69%. Despite the improvement, the overall sentiment remains pessimistic, reflecting concerns over the dairy sector.

site_title: Bank of England head warns of 'catastrophic' climate change
summary: Bank of England head Mark Carney warns that climate change poses a "catastrophic" threat to global financial stability and long-term prosperity unless urgent action is taken to limit its effects. He notes that the world is on track for a 3.5 degree temperature rise, which would lead to "a world we cannot adapt to." Carney's comments come as world leaders scramble to reach a deal to limit climate change at the upcoming Paris talks, with scientists warning that the window of opportunity is finite and shrinking.

images.alt_text: Climate change threatens global financial crises and long-term declines in wealth unless world leaders urgently seal a deal to limit it, the head of the Bank of England said on Tuesday.

site_title: Toshiba obtains new 2-year commitment line from banks worth US$3.3b
summary: Toshiba secured a 400 billion yen (S$4.7 billion) 2-year commitment line from its main banks, nearly doubling the available funds, to prepare for market downturns. The new line comes after the company faced a debilitating accounting scandal, which led to the resignation of its CEO and several board members. Toshiba aims to improve corporate governance and return to profit under new CEO Masashi Muromachi, who plans to overhaul weaker operations. The company also announced plans to divest part of its Chinese white-goods manufacturing units.

site_title: China Aug services trade deficit US$22.8b: FX regulator
summary: China's services trade deficit widened to US$22.8 billion in August, from US$17.6 billion in July, with a January to August deficit of US$135.5 billion. The deficit was led by a US$20.9 billion gap in tourist spending. Meanwhile, China had a US$58.6 billion surplus on trade of goods in August.

site_title: Asia share slide halts but weak commodity outlook weighs
summary: Asian stock markets steadied on Wednesday after hitting 3-year lows, but a weak commodity outlook and concerns about China's economy discouraged buyers. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index was little changed, tracking a 19% loss for the quarter, its worst in four years. Japan's Nikkei gained 1.6%, while South Korea's Kospi dropped 1%. Investors felt relief after shares of Glencore rose 10% overnight, and benchmark copper prices rose 0.1% to a six-year low.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open 1.55% higher
summary: Tokyo shares opened 1.55% higher on Wednesday, following a mixed lead from US equity markets. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index gained 263.0 points to 17,193.84. The move recovers some losses from the previous day. Investors await the Bank of Japan business confidence survey this week.

site_title: Seoul: Won set for worst quarterly loss since 2011 on stocks selloff
summary: The South Korean won is set for its worst quarterly loss since 2011, with a 6.6% drop from June 30 to 1,194.71 a dollar, amid a worsening economic slowdown in China and a military standoff with North Korea. Global investors sold a net $7 billion of local shares in the third quarter, with the won expected to retreat for the fifth quarter, its longest run of declines since 2009. The Bank of Korea cut its 2015 growth forecast to 2.8% in July, citing a dimmer economic outlook.

site_title: Axel Springer paying US$343m for 88% of Business Insider
summary: German media company Axel Springer SE agreed to purchase 88% of Business Insider Inc for $343 million, boosting its stake to 97%. Amazon founder Jeff Bezos will own the remaining 3%. Business Insider has 76 million monthly unique visitors. This deal follows Axel Springer's failed bid for the Financial Times.

site_title: Oil falls after US inventories show buildup
summary: US crude oil inventories rose 4.6 million barrels to 457.8 million barrels in the week to Sept 25, exceeding analyst expectations. Crude oil futures fell 1% to $44.76 a barrel, while Brent crude dropped 1.9% to $47.88 a barrel. Analysts predict US crude will decline 9% this month and Brent crude will drop 12% in September, with prices unlikely to move substantially higher due to easing demand growth. Supplies are expected to swing into a year-on-year decline, but prices need to be low for at least six months.

site_title: Global banking sector hits record profits in 2014, but sees margins erode: McKinsey
summary: The global banking sector achieved a record $1 trillion in profits in 2014, primarily driven by Chinese lenders. However, margins eroded by 185 basis points due to low interest rates, competition, and fintech disruption. Despite this, revenue growth is expected to continue at 3% annually, with return on equity tracking 8-10% over the next few years. Banks will focus on improving operating costs to balance margin erosion, and the industry is poised for a new reality characterized by stable returns and slow growth. Digitization will be a key factor in the next 10 years.

site_title: Foreigners pull record US$5 billion as Southeast Asia stocks sink
summary: Foreign investors sold a record US$5.1 billion in Indonesian, Thai, and Philippine shares in the third quarter, causing the MSCI Southeast Asia index to sink 21% due to a worsening economic outlook and US interest rate hikes. This is the largest outflow since Bloomberg began tracking data in 1999. The region's economic woes are linked to China's slowdown and a commodity rout.

site_title: Jousting, but no insurrection at UK Labour conference
summary: The UK Labour Party conference, led by Jeremy Corbyn, began with dark warnings of a civil war, but no major insurrection occurred. Corbyn's leftist agenda won over 60% of party members, but centrist senior parliamentarians oppose his policies. Despite internal tensions, Corbyn emphasized the importance of debate and unity, and hinted at a potential showdown on the nuclear deterrent system. Other rifts emerged over issues like the air campaign against ISIS and the European Union.

site_title: Japan Aug industrial output unexpectedly falls 0.5% on month
summary: Japan's industrial output unexpectedly fell 0.5% in August, marking the second consecutive month of decline. The data contradicts economists' median forecast of a 1.0% increase. Manufacturers predict a 0.1% rise in September and a 4.4% growth in October.

site_title: Philippine central bank to use interest rate corridor system from Q2 2016
summary: The Philippine central bank plans to introduce an interest rate corridor system starting from the second quarter of 2016, aiming to guide market interest rates towards its main policy rate. The system will use an overnight lending rate of 6% as the ceiling and a special deposit account rate of 2.5% as the floor. The Monetary Board also approved a new auction facility to reinforce the influence of the policy rate, which will allow banks to deposit money with the monetary authority for a short term. This move is expected to help manage inflation and financial market volatility.

images.alt_text: The Philippine central bank will start using an interest rate corridor from the second quarter of next year, its governor said on Tuesday, and use a new auction facility to try to guide market interest rates towards its main policy rate.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Lifebrandz, Cacola Furniture
summary: Micro-penny stocks Lifebrandz and Cacola Furniture are expected to see trading on Wednesday following disclosures. Lifebrandz posted a S$7.63 million loss for 2015, while Cacola Furniture terminated a reverse takeover that would have seen it enter the agri-food business. Asian stocks are expected to do better following a late rally in US shares.

site_title: Trading in the spotlight as Glencore seeks way out of crisis
summary: Glencore, a commodities trading company, is facing a crisis as it struggles to pay its debts despite a surge in trading earnings. The company, led by CEO Ivan Glasenberg, has bet big on fuel oil and ship refuelling markets, but analysts question the viability of this strategy. Glencore's reliance on trading is set to rise in the second half of the year, but concerns over debt and market volatility have led to a decline in the company's stock price. The company's debt stands at $30 billion, and analysts warn that it may struggle to service its debt if commodity prices remain low.

images.alt_text: As Glencore's stock went into free fall in August in the face of heavy debts and shrinking earnings, its chief Ivan Glasenberg had a defiant message - traders can beat weak commodity prices during market downturns.

site_title: Asian futures rise amid late US rally while yen holds advance
summary: Asian stock futures rose, signaling a 1.7% rebound in the Nikkei 225, after a late US rally amid concerns over China's slowdown. The worst quarter for global equities since 2011 is nearing its end, with a five-day Chinese holiday providing a reprieve. Copper futures rallied while crude oil fell, as traders awaited data on US supplies. Risk sentiment stabilized, but remains tentative, with investors wary of further deterioration due to funding costs in China ahead of the holiday.

site_title: Singapore shares open slightly lower after Wall Street stabilises
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened flat at 2,786.63 points, down 0.05% from the previous day. US stocks stabilized after opening higher and dropping during the day. In local trading, 87.7 million shares worth S$210.3 million were traded, with gainers and losers evenly matched. Top stocks included Singtel, OCBC, and DBS.

site_title: Rio de Janeiro mayor bans Uber, open to debating regulation
summary: Rio de Janeiro's mayor, Eduardo Paes, has banned the use of ride-hailing app Uber in the city, effective immediately. Unlicensed drivers will face fines of up to 2000 reais (S$704). The decision comes amid concerns over the impact of Uber on local taxi drivers. Paes left the door open for possible regulation of the service in the future, but has taken the first step by banning the app.

site_title: Brokers' Take: Singtel upgraded to 'buy'
summary: Citi Research upgraded Singtel to "buy" with a target price of S$3.92, citing attractive valuations and a strong free cash flow yield. Despite being vulnerable to broader market sell-downs and competitive dynamics in Australia, the firm sees Singtel's yield as second-best among large-cap Singapore stocks and most sustainable. The stock closed at S$3.55 a share on Tuesday, up three cents from the previous day.

site_title: Japan's Abe says a bit more effort needed to beat deflation
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe stated that more effort is needed to combat deflation in the country's economy, which is the world's third-largest. Abe's economic policies, known as "Abenomics," have improved jobs and incomes, but reversing nearly two decades of falling prices requires additional measures. He aims to raise Japan's GDP by nearly a quarter to 600 trillion yen and refocus on the economy after the passage of security bills that eroded his popularity. Abe's policies include monetary easing, fiscal stimulus, and structural reform to boost growth.

site_title: Fortescue seeking to cut debt amid commodity market turmoil
summary: Fortescue Metals Group Ltd, an iron ore miner, is confident it can weather commodity market turmoil despite larger competitors facing debt struggles. The company has generated over $2 billion in cash and has $2.4 billion in reserve funds, allowing it to withstand volatility. Fortescue cut its cash costs by 21% in fiscal 2015, and its share price rose 1.8% to A$1.70 after the announcement, trimming its year-to-date decline to 38%.

site_title: Switzerland beats Singapore, US to top competitiveness ranking
summary: Switzerland has topped the World Economic Forum's competitiveness ranking for the seventh consecutive year, followed by Singapore and the US. The report attributes Switzerland's success to "nurturing innovation and talent." The US is at risk of losing its top spot due to concerns over education reform, high health and social security costs, and slow productivity growth. The report warns that the global economy faces a "grave threat" from slow productivity growth, which could exacerbate unemployment and income inequality.

site_title: Dollar drifts lower as market awaits Yellen rate comments
summary: The US dollar drifted lower against major currencies as investors awaited Federal Reserve Chair Yellen's comments on monetary policy. The dollar fell to 1.1254 against the euro and 119.75 yen, but edged up against the British pound. Analysts expect the Fed to raise interest rates at the mid-December policy meeting, citing hawkish comments from FOMC members. The market will also be watching the US jobs report for September, set for release on Friday, which could influence the Fed's decision.

site_title: Google counters Apple with Nexus phones, new tablet
summary: Google unveiled two new Nexus smartphones, the Nexus 5X and Nexus 6P, along with a convertible tablet called Pixel C, ahead of the holiday shopping season. The devices feature the new Android Marshmallow operating system, fingerprint sensors, and improved cameras. The phones are priced below those of Apple and Samsung, starting at $379 and $499 respectively. The Pixel C tablet starts at $499 and features a keyboard that doubles as a cover. Google also introduced upgraded Chromecast devices and announced a partnership with Spotify to stream music wirelessly through home sound systems.

site_title: UK consumer confidence dips, hit by China, migrant crisis: GfK
summary: British consumer confidence dropped to +3 in September, lower than expected, due to concerns over China's economic slowdown and the migrant crisis in Europe. The decline was attributed to a "depressed back-to-school mood" and perceptions of a weak economy. This dip comes after signs of slower economic growth in Britain and follows a survey showing retail sales beating expectations.

site_title: Dutch investigators raid Uber office in Amsterdam
summary: Dutch investigators raided Uber's Amsterdam office, seizing documents related to its low-cost service UberPOP, which operates without a permit. Prosecutors have fined Uber 450,000 euros for running UberPOP and believe it continues to operate despite the ban. UberPOP offers taxi rides at lower prices than traditional taxis, sparking a fierce debate over regulation. Uber plans to cooperate with authorities and push for a revised law to modernize the legislation, aiming to create more jobs and give consumers a choice.

site_title: China's 'One Belt, One Road' holds economic promise
summary: China's "One Belt, One Road" initiative aims to create a global network of transportation links and infrastructure to promote trade and economic growth. Analysts have identified potential projects in major Asian countries, including India, Indonesia, Malaysia, and Pakistan, which could benefit from the initiative. China has also committed to financing infrastructure projects in its neighboring countries and has set a domestic initiative with a budget of 2% of its GDP. The initiative is expected to have a significant impact on global trade and investment, but faces competition for funding and challenges in implementation.

site_title: US regulators say Fiat Chrysler under-reported vehicle deaths
summary: US regulators say Fiat Chrysler significantly under-reported vehicle deaths, with the company agreeing to a record $105 million fine for failing to properly handle defects in 11 million vehicles. The under-reporting was attributed to a "number of problems" with Fiat Chrysler's data submission system. The automaker has committed to a thorough investigation and remediation, and will also buy back over half a million vehicles with defective suspension parts. This incident is part of a series of scandals in the auto industry, raising questions about safety and reliability.

images.alt_text: Close up of the calender and logo of the new Fiat 500, constructed by Italian-US multinational automobile manufacturer Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) displayed in front of Arco della Pace in Milan, on July 4, 2015. Fiat Chrysler significantly under-reported the number of deaths and injuries which occurred in its vehicles, US safety regulators said Tuesday.

site_title: LifeBrandz loss worsens to S$7.63m in FY15
summary: LifeBrandz, a Singapore-based nightspot operator, reported a loss of S$7.63 million for FY15, worse than the S$5.75 million loss in FY14. Revenue grew 8% year-on-year to S$1.26 million, despite a 25% decline in shares. The company has a reverse takeover deal with Healthtrends Medical Investments and plans to update on further development. The net asset value per share was 0.03 cents, down from 0.08 cents in FY14.

site_title: Oil prices rise as equities stabilise
summary: Oil prices rose on Tuesday, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate advancing 80 cents to $45.23 a barrel and European benchmark Brent oil adding 89 cents to $48.23 a barrel. The price increase followed a more benign outlook for commodities, as shares of mining giant Glencore rose and equity markets stabilized after a dismal Chinese industrial data report on Monday. Analysts attributed the price increase to a narrowing imbalance in the market, with expectations of lower US oil supplies and a stabilization of the Glencore situation.

site_title: US: Dow ends up, Nasdaq lower after choppy session
summary: US stocks ended the day higher, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 47.24 points (0.30%) to 16,049.13, while the S&P 500 rose 2.32 (0.12%) to 1,884.09. However, the Nasdaq Composite Index fell 26.65 (0.59%) to 4,517.32, marking its sixth consecutive decline. The tech-rich Nasdaq fell despite a boost from biotech stocks, while bond prices rose, with the 10-year Treasury yield falling to 2.06%.

site_title: Volkswagen draws up refit plan for cars in pollution scam
summary: Volkswagen has unveiled a plan to refit millions of vehicles affected by a worldwide pollution-cheating scandal, with CEO Matthias Mueller vowing to act ruthlessly to overcome the crisis. The German government has given VW until October 7 to explain how it will resolve the issue, which has caused a 38% loss in VW's market value. Up to 11 million diesel cars worldwide are fitted with devices that can switch off pollution controls, allowing them to emit harmful levels of emissions. Mueller has promised technical solutions will be submitted in October, with owners to be notified in the coming weeks and months.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen on Tuesday revealed a plan to refit millions of vehicles affected by a worldwide pollution-cheating scam, as its new chief vowed to act ruthlessly to overcome the "severest test" in the car giant's history.

site_title: Market liquidity could evaporate in response to shocks, IMF warns
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned that market liquidity could "evaporate in response to shocks" due to growing corporate debt in emerging-market economies, particularly in China and Turkey. The IMF reports that corporate debt has quadrupled in the past decade, with low interest rates and investor risk-taking contributing to this increase. The organization cautions that a sharp rise in interest rates could lead to a decline in liquidity, threatening financial stability and potentially triggering a global financial crisis. Policymakers are advised to monitor risks and prepare for the normalization of monetary policy.

site_title: Ringgit in free-fall puts 5.00 mark within sight
summary: The Malaysian ringgit has plummeted, reaching 4.472 to the US dollar and 3.122 to the Singapore dollar, its largest quarterly loss since the 1997 Asian financial crisis. Experts predict the currency could reach 5.00 to the USD, with a "macro financial risk contagion" possible if the spiral continues. The government has not taken sufficient measures to stabilize the market, and interest rate cuts are seen as a necessary but potentially damaging response. The currency's decline is attributed to domestic issues, including the 1MDB scandal and allegations against Prime Minister Najib Razak.

site_title: US payment industry switching to chip-enabled cards
summary: The US payment industry is transitioning to chip-enabled cards, a shift intended to make in-person purchases safer. Starting Thursday, merchants who cannot process chip-enabled cards could become liable for fraudulent transactions, with MasterCard and Visa setting the deadline. However, consumers will not be directly affected, as federal law requires banks to reimburse consumers for various types of fraud. Chip-enabled cards will continue to work until they expire or are activated, and new machines will prompt users to dip the card instead of swiping it.

site_title: The perils of forcing a sale of illiquid assets
summary: A lawsuit against hedge fund manager Boaz Weinstein alleges he manipulated the values of illiquid assets to artificially depress prices, resulting in a $500 million loss for the Public Sector Pension Investment Board of Canada. Weinstein's strategy was to conduct an auction for corporate bonds, but only three dealers bid, leading to significantly lower valuations. The case highlights the potential for a liquidity panic to lead to a financial crisis, with experts warning that a rush for liquidity could trigger a market collapse.

site_title: Ezra shares up 4.31% on news of joint venture with Japan's Chiyoda
summary: Ezra Holdings shares rose 4.31% on news of a joint-venture agreement with Japanese engineering giant Chiyoda. Under the deal, Chiyoda will buy a 50% stake in Emas AMC's subsea services business for $180 million. This restructuring will put the business under a joint-venture company, with Ezra retaining a 50% stake. The deal is valued at 78% of Ezra's market capitalization and reflects the market's undervaluation of the counter.

site_title: S&P may downgrade banks with lax cyber security
summary: Standard & Poor's may downgrade banks with weak cybersecurity controls, even if they haven't been attacked. The ratings company considers a bank's preparedness to withstand a data breach and reputational harm as key factors. Cyberattacks have become a growing threat for banks, with hostile nation-states, terrorist organizations, and criminal groups behind most attacks. Few banks have disclosed their cybersecurity spending, but any cuts to technology units would be "disconcerting". Large banks have taken steps to mitigate the danger, but smaller ones are more vulnerable due to their revenue base.

site_title: Canadian dairy farmers in tractors protest trade deal
summary: Canadian dairy farmers protested outside parliament in Ottawa, blocking road access in a tractor convoy to object to agricultural concessions in the Trans-Pacific Partnership. The farmers, representing 12,234 family farms, fear that opening up the Canadian market to foreign milk imports will harm their supply-managed industry. They argue that most Canadian dairies are too small to compete globally, and that reciprocal access to foreign markets will not balance out milk sales. The protest comes ahead of final negotiations over the trade pact, which Canadian dairy representatives will press trade officials to oppose.

images.alt_text: A cow and hundreds of dairy farmers driving tractors blocked road access to Canada's parliament on Tuesday to protest agricultural concessions in trade talks with other Pacific Rim countries.

site_title: S$ falls to fresh six-year low against US$ on global growth concerns
summary: The Singapore dollar (SGD) has fallen to a fresh six-year low against the US dollar (USD), breaking through the S$1.43 handle, amid concerns over global growth. The SGD has declined by 7.4% year-to-date and has been down for seven consecutive days. Analysts expect the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to hold monetary policy steady for now, but DBS Bank economists predict an easing of policy in October via a recentring of the S$NEER exchange rate.

site_title: China's bond market is 'overheating': Bloomberg poll
summary: China's bond market is "overheating" due to scattered capital from the bursting stock market bubble, according to a Bloomberg poll of 21 financial experts. 60% forecast a widening of corporate bond yield premiums in the fourth quarter, with some warning of a potential bubble. The credit market is also experiencing a surge in capital outflows, driven by China's yuan devaluation, with an estimated $141.66 billion exiting China in August. Experts express concerns over the risks of inflation and further capital outflows, citing worsening credit profiles of Chinese companies.

site_title: Shipping shows surprising optimism
summary: Shipping industry confidence levels have reached their highest point this year, with a 5.9 average confidence level reported in the latest Shipping Confidence Survey by Moore Stephens. Despite concerns over low freight rates, overtonnaging, and private-equity funding, respondents expressed optimism about the industry's future, driven by growing world population and global trade forecasts. The survey found that charterers were particularly bullish, and investing in shipping is expected to increase, with respondents citing the long-term outlook for the industry as positive, particularly with emerging economies increasing demand for seaborne goods.

site_title: Consumer confidence rises in Sept; property values up 5%
summary: US consumer confidence rose to 103.0 in September, the highest since January, surpassing economists' expectations of 96.1. The consumer present situation index reached 121.1, its highest level since 2007, while consumer expectations for inflation rose to 5.2% from 4.9%. Meanwhile, US single-family home prices rose 5% year-over-year in July, with cities like San Francisco and Denver experiencing the highest year-over-year home appreciation.

site_title: S-E Asian currencies hammered in wobbly quarter, woes persist
summary: S-E Asian currencies, including the ringgit, rupiah, and baht, experienced significant losses in the past quarter due to global economic concerns, including China's slowdown and a commodity slump. The International Monetary Fund warned that falling commodity prices could shave off 1-2.25 percentage points of growth from commodity exporters and energy-exporting nations. Economists predict that the current woes may persist into the next quarter, with a looming US rate hike and structural factors such as debt and credit contributing to the softening global growth.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Putian cashes in on healthcare
summary: Lin Yuming, a Putian entrepreneur, has built a chain of women's hospitals in China, focusing on obstetrics and gynaecology, and is now expanding through an initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong. Putian has emerged as a hub for healthcare investment, with 15 other companies considering IPOs, as the Chinese government encourages private investment to curb healthcare costs. The industry is expected to triple to $90 billion by 2019, with international rivals like Harvard-affiliated Brigham and Women's Hospital also eyeing opportunities in China.

site_title: Chinese embrace America's culture - but not its policies
summary: Chinese citizens, particularly young people, admire aspects of American culture such as free speech and individuality, but remain wary of the US government's foreign intentions, especially regarding China's territorial claims. Despite American cultural influence, studies show that many Chinese citizens view the US with distrust, with 67% of respondents believing their country will replace the US as the world's leading superpower. This contrast highlights the gap between cultural attraction and political distrust in China-US relations.

site_title: Airbnb expects to double bookings to 80m this year, say investors
summary: Airbnb is expected to double its nightly bookings to 80 million this year, according to investors, despite ongoing battles with regulators. The company's growth rate is expected to continue, with a global presence in over 190 countries and more than 1.5 million listings. Airbnb's push in Europe and efforts to win over business travelers are succeeding, with 50% of its revenue coming from Europe. The company's valuation has reached $25.5 billion, making it the third most valuable venture capital-backed company in the world.

site_title: Germany launches criminal probe against VW ex-CEO
summary: German prosecutors have launched a criminal probe against Volkswagen's former CEO Martin Winterkorn, amid the company's diesel emissions scandal. The probe follows allegations that Winterkorn was not aware of the fraud, but prosecutors are seeking to establish the chain of responsibility. Over 11 million Volkswagen vehicles worldwide are equipped with software designed to deceive emission tests, with Audi and Skoda affected vehicles totaling over 3 million. VW faces potential fines of up to $18 billion and significant recall costs, threatening to tarnish Germany's engineering reputation.

site_title: Glencore gloom envelops rivals as Asia commodity shares fall
summary: Glencore's stock plummeted 29.4% in London, with Asian commodity shares also falling, as the company's debt woes worsened amid China's economic slowdown. The collapse in raw materials prices, the lowest since 1999, has hit miners such as BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto, with PetroChina and Noble Group also experiencing significant losses. The Bloomberg World Mining Index fell 1.7% and is now down 34% for the year, as excess supplies and a sluggish world economy contribute to the downturn.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Huationg Global secured S$81.3 million in new civil engineering contracts, including Changi Airport Terminal 5 and Sengkang's integrated regional hospital. SinoCloud established a new division to manage its China data centre business, while Biosensors International will sell a drug-eluting stent system in Japan starting October 1. Kingsmen Creatives' associate set up a Myanmar unit for creative services. STATS ChipPAC's 2016 and 2018 notes saw high tender rates, with 76.09% and 83.07% of principal amounts validly tendered, respectively.

site_title: Pressure mounts on Glencore's euro debt
summary: Glencore's euro-denominated debt faced pressure, with its 1.25 billion March 2017 bonds selling off by up to 11 points, pushing the yield to over 16.5%. Analysts warned of potential restructuring if the company's debt continues to rise, citing a US$29.55 billion net debt burden. However, some analysts, such as UBS, remain positive on Glencore's short-term liquidity, citing a well-structured balance sheet and good liquidity.

site_title: Building global asian leaders
summary: Asia's growing economic influence has created a need for Asian leaders in global companies, with organisations investing in developing this talent pool. However, Asian leaders are in short supply, with only 2% of top 200 global employees in emerging Asian markets. Forward-thinking companies are investing time and effort to develop global Asian leaders, who must embody local knowledge with a global perspective and networks. Regional HR teams must play four critical roles: trusted adviser, passionate advocate, innovative marketer, and astute facilitator of global skills development to address this talent gap.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: US stocks opened lower amid a fresh tariff salvo by President Trump on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in the second half. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Singapore stocks notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. CGSI downgraded Grab to 'hold' citing slowing earnings growth in the second half.

site_title: South African clothes sellers eye fast local supply as rivals land
summary: South African retailers are urged to work more closely with the domestic textile industry to counter global fashion giants, such as Inditex's Zara and H&M, expanding in the country's lucrative market. Despite government investment in upgraded production lines, most local clothing is still sourced from Asia. Local brands, like The Foschini Group, aim to increase domestic production, with some factories able to get garments to market within 32 days. The sector's value has grown to over 200 billion rand, with consumers spending an average of 5.3% of their income on clothing and footwear.

site_title: STI sheds just 4 points after late rebound
summary: The Straits Times Index fell 3.98 points to a 38-month low of 2,787.94, its fifth consecutive decline, amid global market concerns over a weak China economy, commodity price volatility, and uncertainty over US interest rate hikes. However, a rebound in Dow futures late in the afternoon lifted the index 47 points from its intraday low of 2,740. Other regional markets also declined, with the Hang Seng Index down 3% and the Shanghai Composite Index falling 2%.

site_title: Indian PM woos US technology giants with his 'Digital India' push
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's US visit focused on business and economic ties during the UN General Assembly session. The "Digital India" initiative, aiming to make government services accessible online, was a central point of discussion with US technology giants. Modi met with President Barack Obama and engaged with business leaders, emphasizing the changes his government is making to India's economy. The visit highlighted India's efforts to modernize its economy and increase its global presence.

site_title: Singapore bonds resilient amid equity, currency jitters
summary: Singapore's bond market has remained resilient despite a sell-off in the stock market and currency fluctuations, with the Singapore Fixed Income index (SFI) rising 0.31 to 120.06. The SFI outperforms the Straits Times Index by 17.48% year-to-date. Corporate bonds gained 0.08% and government bonds 0.05%, with two tranches of Land Transport Authority bonds selling well. The decline of the Singapore dollar has not deterred investors, with SGD corporate bonds proving resilient. Experts attribute the resilience to the small supply of new bonds and the long-term buy-and-hold investor base.

site_title: Noble takes a hit from Glencore's meltdown
summary: Noble Group's shares plummeted to a seven-year low of 40 Singapore cents, down 10.1% from the previous day, following Glencore's overnight stock decline. Other mining companies, such as Indika Energy and BHP Billiton, also fell. Analysts attribute the sell-off to "panic selling" and overestimating the potential impact of Glencore's struggles, with some suggesting it may be an overreaction. Olam International, a soft commodity trader, remained relatively stable, with its shares closing flat.

site_title: Congress, Fed helped save Goldman Sachs from Glencore fate
summary: Congress and the Federal Reserve intervened to save Goldman Sachs' commodities business from potential collapse in 2011, following a review of Wall Street banks' physical commodities units. Revenue was down, competition was high, and employee attrition was at an all-time high. Glencore, a commodities company with no banking rules, posed a threat to Goldman Sachs' business. The Fed and Congress helped Goldman Sachs navigate the situation, ultimately saving its commodities unit from a potential Glencore-style fate. The intervention prevented a significant loss of assets and helped maintain the company's position in the market.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs executives had told their board in 2011 that the combination of commodity production and trading was proving attractive to investors.

site_title: Managing the risk of BYOD
summary: NICE Systems, a software solutions provider, adopted a three-pronged strategy for managing the risk of Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) in January 2013. The company's approach involves identifying, assessing, and mitigating risks associated with BYOD. However, the article does not provide further details on the company's specific strategies or outcomes.

site_title: No contact from foreign investigators, says 1MDB
summary: Malaysia's 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB) has not been contacted by foreign investigators over allegations of mismanagement and corruption, its president Arul Kanda said. Despite Swiss and Singaporean investigations, 1MDB has denied all allegations and has not been contacted by the FBI. The fund's debt has surpassed $11 billion, and Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak is facing criticism over his involvement. Some media reports are seen as politically motivated to undermine Najib, and 1MDB plans to sell assets to cut debt, aiming to be in a positive cash position by early 2016.

site_title: The retreat of German rigour
summary: Volkswagen's emissions scandal has exposed the "law" formulated by economist Charles Goodhart, which states that any statistical regularity will collapse when pressure is placed on it for control purposes. The German car giant's use of engineering and software to evade emissions controls is a striking example of this phenomenon. This echoes the 1990s, when Germany's willingness to compromise on monetary targets led to a loss of trust in the country's economic discipline. The implications of this retreat from "German rigour" are far-reaching, with potential repercussions for monetary union and discussions about austerity in Europe.

site_title: Amazon to grow its Detroit office into a new tech hub
summary: Amazon plans to expand its Detroit office, adding more full-time jobs to create a technology hub. The company, which already has hundreds of employees in Michigan, will lease additional space to accommodate more software developers and engineers.
