The party's shadow cabinet is split on Trident, with Corbyn's deputy leader Tom Watson opposing renewal. Corbyn played down fears of a rift and hinted at finding an accommodation, but critics see the non-vote as a severe embarrassment.

site_title: Asia: Shares held back by insipid Wall St, dollar consolidates
summary: Asian stocks remained flat on Monday, following a lackluster performance on Wall Street, while the dollar consolidated its gains against the yen and euro. Despite strong US GDP data and Fed Chair Janet Yellen's hints of a potential interest rate hike, the markets remain cautious ahead of Friday's non-farm payrolls data, which will determine the Fed's next move. The dollar edged up to a two-week high against the yen, while gold and platinum prices were steady.

site_title: India PM Modi makes rock star appearance at Facebook
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi made a high-profile appearance at Facebook, advocating for the power of social media to influence governments. During a town hall-style Q&A session, Modi emphasized the importance of real-time information and the potential for social media to correct governments' mistakes. He also promoted his country's Digital India drive and encouraged entrepreneurs to invest in India. Modi's visit was part of a Silicon Valley tour, marking the first time a prime minister of India has visited the US West Coast since 1982.

site_title: Dreams of a Digital India turning into a nightmare
summary: India's mobile phone network is facing a crisis due to rapidly rising growth and inadequate infrastructure, resulting in widespread dropped calls and poor mobile quality. The issue has become a major concern for the government's Digital India initiative, which aims to connect the country's cities and villages to the internet. The Telecom Regulatory Authority of India has reported that telephone companies will have to compensate consumers for dropped calls, and the government has called for the industry to address the issue. Experts blame the telecom industry for the problem, citing a lack of investment in infrastructure and technology.

site_title: Responding to financial reporting surveillance reviews
summary: Directors in Singapore are facing increased scrutiny from the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA) due to the expanded Financial Reporting Surveillance Programme (FRSP). The programme, launched in 2014, now reviews the financial statements of companies with "clean" audit reports, directly engaging with directors on compliance with prescribed Accounting Standards. Directors are responsible for ensuring financial statements are accurate and transparent, and failure to comply can result in warnings, fines, or prosecution. To avoid responding to ACRA queries, companies should ensure their finance teams are competent and external auditors adhere to Singapore Financial Reporting Standards.

site_title: Vietnam scraps ceiling rate on corporate dollar deposits
summary: Vietnam's central bank scrapped the interest rate ceiling on corporate dollar deposits, previously set at 0.25%, to prevent dollar hoarding. The ceiling for individual dollar deposits will be cut to 0.25% from 0.75%. The new policy, effective Monday, aims to develop the country's money and foreign exchange markets. The move follows a directive signed on Friday and is seen as an effort to promote economic growth and reduce currency hoarding.

site_title: Pope wraps up historic US tour in Philadelphia
summary: Pope Francis concluded his six-day US tour in Philadelphia, wrapping up a historic visit that electrified Americans with a message of respecting immigrants, protecting the environment, and sharing wealth. The 78-year-old head of the Catholic Church met with victims of the sex abuse scandal, but the meeting was not confirmed. During his tour, Pope Francis called on politicians to take responsibility for crafting a fairer economic system and urged Americans to welcome others to share in the American dream. He also condemned violence in the name of religion and preached inter-faith tolerance, receiving widespread applause from crowds.

site_title: Junior bankers risk being fired by wary bosses, UK law firm warns
summary: UK law firm GQ Employment Law warns that junior bankers may face unfair dismissal due to new regulations holding managers accountable for regulatory lapses caused by junior colleagues. From March 2016, managers at UK banks will be responsible for lapses on their watch, potentially leading to hasty terminations. This could result in increased employment lawsuits, particularly from former traders dismissed during benchmark rigging probes, and create tension between senior managers and HR teams.

site_title: Feted in China, Xi's US profile dims in shadow of Pope
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping's first state visit to the US was overshadowed by Pope Francis' historic US visit, with US media giving more attention to the Pope's every word and step. Xi's US trip, which included a 21-gun salute and a visit to a high school, was largely ignored by US media, with data showing that tweets and online articles about the Pope far outnumbered those about Xi. The contrast highlights Xi's struggling US image and low US-China relations, with officials playing down the Pope's visit as not eclipsing Xi's.

site_title: US state regulators push to simplify brokerage fee disclosures
summary: US state securities regulators unveiled a new model fee disclosure to standardize how brokerage firms present information about various fees, aiming to promote better understanding and comparison. The voluntary disclosure format, developed by the North American Securities Administrators Association, will provide investors with easy-to-read information on service and maintenance fees, and their frequencies. The goal is to address confusion caused by inconsistent fee disclosures among companies, with nearly 30% of surveyed investors unaware of their firm's fees and 25% unsure if they were being charged.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: TLV Holdings has appointed billionaire investor Jim Rogers as a strategic adviser for 12 months, starting September 26. Meanwhile, Vard Holdings secured over $100 million in contracts for two offshore subsea construction vessels for Topaz Energy and Marine. US stocks opened lower amid fresh tariff salvo on Canada, while Creative Technology warned of below-target H2 revenue and operating loss similar to H1. Singapore stocks rallied for the fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data, and MAS and PBOC are set to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Indonesia banks on syariah finance boom
summary: Indonesia is launching a plan to grow its syariah finance sector, which currently accounts for less than 5% of banking assets. The government aims to educate the public and establish an Islamic finance committee to better manage the sector. Regulators believe the sector has potential, given Indonesia's large Muslim population and increasing trend towards piety. The plan includes a five-year roadmap and a National Islamic Finance Committee to oversee the sector, with the goal of increasing the sector's share of banking assets.

site_title: Thousands evacuated from Taiwan islands as typhoon nears
summary: Thousands of tourists were evacuated from Taiwan's Green Island and Orchid Island as super typhoon Dujuan approached the island, with heavy rains and high tides forecast. The typhoon, upgraded to a "strong typhoon" by Taiwan's weather bureau, is expected to make landfall in eastern Taiwan on Monday night, threatening long-weekend plans for many. Over 24,000 troops are on standby for disaster relief and evacuations, with emergency response centres set up and 100 shelters available. The storm is also expected to hit Japan and mainland China, with warnings of possible landslides, high waves, and heavy rain.

site_title: Bulky problem for FedEx as online purchases of furniture rise
summary: FedEx is facing logistical challenges as online purchases of bulky items, such as furniture and car parts, surge. The company is experiencing higher costs due to increased human handling and fuel use, with operating expenses rising 36% last quarter. FedEx and United Parcel Service are adapting to the growing demand for e-commerce purchases, with the latter adding a new surcharge for retailers shipping large numbers of oversized packages during peak holiday season. Despite the challenges, consumers are willing to pay more for the convenience of online purchases, with 23% agreeing that they would buy anything online regardless of bulkiness.

site_title: Weak A$ drawing more S'pore interest in hotel assets Down Under
summary: Singapore investors are increasingly drawn to hotel assets in Australia due to the country's weak Australian dollar. Acquisitions in the past year include the Rydges Darwin Airport Hotel and Resort, Diamant Hotel, and Four Points by Sheraton. Singaporeans traditionally favor corporate hotels in markets like Sydney, Melbourne, and Perth, and the lower Australian dollar makes it an attractive market for investors. The Australian tourism sector is also expected to remain positive, driven by robust domestic demand and the influx of Chinese tourists.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: China champions women at UN but record criticised
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping hosted a special session at the UN to mark 20 years since the Beijing conference on women's rights, pledging $10 million to the UN agency for women and plans to build 100 health centers and school start-ups for girls in the developing world. However, his efforts were marred by China's detention of five young feminists earlier this year, sparking criticism from US President Barack Obama and former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton. Despite this, leaders such as German Chancellor Angela Merkel and Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff spoke in support of women's rights, emphasizing the need for protection in war zones and crisis regions.

site_title: Xi pledges US$2b for new development fund for poor countries
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping pledged US$2 billion for a new development fund for poor countries during his first address to the UN, aiming to promote global development and alleviate poverty. The fund is part of China's efforts to step up investment in the least developed countries by at least US$12 billion by 2030. Xi also promised to relieve debts owed by these countries and urged developed countries to remain the main channel for assistance. The move follows criticism from the US and other developed countries that China has not taken sufficient responsibility in its growing global role.

site_title: Rents plunge on HK street that was world's priciest strip
summary: Hong Kong's Russell Street, once the world's most expensive shopping strip, has lost its title to New York's Fifth Avenue. Rents on the street have plummeted 40% due to China's economic slowdown, with some retailers paying up to 43% less than their former tenants. The decline is part of a broader slump in Hong Kong's retail property market, with prices expected to drop 15-20% this year. The Hong Kong government is monitoring the market and will make policy changes if necessary, amid a global economic slowdown.

site_title: Greek finance minister confident of returning to growth
summary: Greek finance minister Euclid Tsakalotos expressed confidence in returning to growth, citing a formal review of economic reforms by end-November and potential debt relief negotiations by Christmas. The EU estimates a banking sector recapitalization of 10-25 billion euros, which the new government aims to implement by October to unlock a 3 billion euro bailout funds tranche. Tsakalotos also vowed to crack down on tax evasion, a key policy for the government's success. However, analysts warn that unpopularity among voters and Syriza members may hinder full implementation of the bailout reforms.

images.alt_text: Greece's new finance minister, Euclid Tsakalotos, while speaking to the Financial Times, said he"didn't see any reason" why growth wouldn't return to the beleaguered European nation, a week after it re-elected the left-wing Syriza party with 145 of 300 parliamentary seats to form a new government.

site_title: Middle-income expats priced out of Dubai luxury
summary: Middle-income expats in Dubai are being priced out of luxury lifestyles due to a shortage of affordable homes and reduced overseas allowances. With annual rents exceeding 72,000 dirhams or property prices reaching 790,000 dirhams, many are moving to less glamorous areas or neighboring Sharjah. The emirate's real estate sector remains volatile, with property prices 50% higher than two years ago and expected to rise again by 2017. To address the issue, some experts suggest developers should prioritize build-to-lease projects to keep rents affordable, but the focus on high-margin luxury projects has driven up prices.

site_title: Exit poll gives Catalan separatists election win
summary: Catalan separatists are on track to win an absolute majority of parliamentary seats in a regional election, with a pro-independence alliance securing between 74 and 79 seats out of 135, according to an exit poll. The main pro-independence group, "Together For Yes", won 49.8% of the vote, with the region's president Artur Mas hailing the election as a "great victory for democracy". If the results are confirmed, separatist parties will need to strike an accord, with a declaration of independence by 2017 possible.

images.alt_text: Separatists pushing to make Catalonia independent from Spain were on track to win an absolute majority of parliamentary seats in a regional election on Sunday, an exit poll showed.

site_title: Compensation of top Oracle execs lower in FY2015
summary: Oracle's top executives saw lower compensation in fiscal 2015, with billionaire founder Larry Ellison's pay falling to $62.1 million, down from $100 million the previous year. Ellison's co-replacements Mark Hurd and Safra Catz received $56.9 million each. The lower pay was due to performance-based stock awards contingent on revenue and operating cash flow growth, which were introduced after Ellison stepped down as CEO. Oracle investors had previously disapproved the company's compensation plan in advisory say-on-pay votes.

site_title: Further New Zealand rate cuts still a possibility
summary: The Royal Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) cut its official cash rates for the third time in four months, lowering them from 3.25% to 2.75%. This decision aims to stimulate the economy amid falling dairy prices and a weakening economic outlook. The New Zealand dollar (NZD) has plummeted 21% against the Singapore dollar (SGD) since the cut. Historically, similar rate cuts in 2008 led to a 38% decline in the NZD against the SGD, suggesting further rate cuts may be possible, potentially weakening the NZD further.

site_title: As car buyers dally, rental firms get a boost
summary: Car rental companies in Singapore are experiencing a surge in business as motorists delay buying new cars due to high Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums. Demand for longer-term rentals, typically 3-6 months, has increased by 15% at Komoco Car Rental and 30% at Kah Motor. Some customers are even taking on driving jobs to offset rental costs, with some renting cars for six months or a year. The trend is expected to continue as long as COE premiums remain firm, with some companies seeing a 100% increase in long-term rentals.

images.alt_text: Car rental companies are enjoying a surge in business as motorists who are putting off buying a new car raise demand for longer-term rentals, with some customers even taking on driving jobs to offset the cost of renting.

site_title: Platinum skids to new low on Volkswagen scandal
summary: Volkswagen's pollution scandal has led to a sharp decline in platinum prices, reaching a 6.5-year low of $926.35 per ounce. The precious metal, used in catalytic converters for diesel cars, has been weakened by reduced demand due to the scandal, which has damaged consumer confidence in diesel engines. Platinum prices have plunged by 23% since the start of the year, with palladium prices rising instead. Analysts predict further divergence between platinum and palladium prices as more details about the scandal are released.

site_title: China to promote equity crowdfunding to support startups
summary: China's government plans to promote equity crowdfunding for startups to encourage entrepreneurship, aiming to stimulate employment and economic growth. The move is seen as a response to the slowing economy, with most Chinese banks unwilling to fund startups. Equity crowdfunding has grown rapidly, with e-commerce giants like JD.com setting up platforms, but there are concerns about unregulated risks. The government aims to address these risks by cutting red tape, developing third-party credit rating services, and standardizing credit information. China is forecast to account for half of the developing world's crowdfunding by 2025.

site_title: Introducing the Hang Seng Index
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index, a benchmark for the city's stock market, has appreciated in the short term, but its long-term prospects are uncertain due to the financial crisis and China's liberalization of financial markets. The index is seen as a gateway to China, but concerns over Hong Kong's political future, a potential property market crash, and currency risk threaten its stability. Investors can access the index through a broker in Singapore, but must consider foreign exchange risk, tax implications, and regulatory environment. A diversified exposure to Hong Kong can be achieved through exchange-traded funds (ETFs), but requires a 20-question online quiz to qualify.

site_title: If not now, when?
summary: The US Federal Reserve is considering raising interest rates for the first time in 11 years, with a possible 0.25% increase over the next four meetings. Analysts weigh the pros and cons, with some arguing it's necessary to combat overspending and inflation, while others believe it could exacerbate uncertainty and volatility. The decision will impact businesses, industries, and investors, with some expecting a signal of confidence in the US economy and others concerned about the potential impact on emerging markets and the global economy.

site_title: New CEO aims to get Rickmers Maritime ship-shape
summary: Rickmers Maritime, a shipping trust, has appointed new CEO Soeren Andersen to focus on the regional container shipping market, which he believes will benefit from the growing dominance of mega vessels. Andersen aims to target intra-Asia shipping, utilizing the trust's existing fleet of smaller vessels, which can accommodate 2,500-4,250 TEU. He plans to lower debt levels, increase charter rates, and eventually expand the fleet, with a focus on steady revenue and organic growth. Andersen is optimistic about the market, despite the current depressed global shipping markets, and has already started negotiating charter contract extensions.

site_title: Microsoft leads fast-growing move by companies on carbon pricing
summary: Microsoft is leading a growing trend among companies to adopt carbon pricing, with its business units charged an internal tax based on their energy usage. The revenue generated from this tax is invested in environmental sustainability projects. This move reflects the increasing pressure to address climate change, with tougher laws and moral convictions driving companies to calculate their carbon footprint and take action.

site_title: Perception, not profit, dictates market mood
summary: US stocks retreated last week due to a crisis of confidence in the Federal Reserve, sparked by mixed signals and assurances from Fed Chairwoman Janet Yellen that interest-rate hikes would proceed this year. Market volatility is expected to continue this week as traders await inflation and jobs data, which could influence the timing of interest-rate hikes. The shift in perception was also fueled by a tweet from Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton, which led to a decline in biotech stocks and shares of German car makers, such as Volkswagen and BMW, despite no apparent change in profit margins.

site_title: Mueller starts damage control as new VW CEO
summary: Volkswagen's new CEO, Matthias Mueller, is facing significant damage control efforts amid a pollution test rigging scandal. Mueller, former Porsche chief, has pledged an "unsparing investigation and maximum transparency" to restore confidence in the company. The scandal, which involves 11 million diesel cars equipped with defeat devices, could lead to fines worth over $18 billion. The US and Switzerland have halted the sale of new diesel cars, and several countries, including France, Britain, and India, have launched investigations into the matter. Mueller must navigate the financial and judicial consequences of the scandal, which has wiped billions of euros off the company's stocks.

site_title: Subscription food box firms popping up in the US
summary: Subscription food box firms, Naturebox and Graze, are popping up in the US, capitalizing on the nation's appetite for novelty, convenience, and healthy snacking options. Entrepreneurs are launching these services, aiming to provide customers with a variety of healthy snacks delivered to their doorstep. Consumers like Matt Feit are embracing these services, using them to change their eating habits and incorporate healthier snacking into their daily routines.

site_title: Face masks a common sight in Jakarta as pollution takes its toll
summary: Jakarta, Indonesia, faces severe air pollution issues, with 70% of the city's air pollution attributed to vehicle emissions. The city's rapid economic growth has led to a surge in vehicle numbers, resulting in worsening air quality and health problems, including asthma, bronchitis, and cardiovascular disease. Experts estimate that air pollution causes 6,500 premature deaths annually in Indonesia. The government has begun to address the issue by mandating improved emission standards for new vehicles and investing in mass transit systems and green spaces.

site_title: US Airways readies for integration
summary: US Airways will cease operations on October 17, marking the end of the airline as a brand. The integration with American Airlines, a $11 billion deal, will bring together 655 planes and tens of thousands of employees. Officials at American have prepared for nearly two years, tweaking nearly 500 US Airways policies and combining frequent flyer programs. The transition will be most pronounced at US Airways hubs, including Charlotte, where 90% of passengers fly the airline. Despite potential technical issues, the merger is seen as a necessary step to create a stronger rival to United and Delta, with American Airlines' senior vice-president stating that the merger made sense and helped turn the airline around.

images.alt_text: Over the past year US Airways has handed off bits and parts of its operation to American Airlines' headquarters, but the airlines are still distinctly separate.

site_title: Schlumberger pulls out of deal to buy stake in Eurasia Drilling
summary: Schlumberger Ltd. will not pursue a $1.7 billion deal to buy a minority stake in Russia's Eurasia Drilling Co. due to lack of regulatory approvals. The world's largest oilfield services provider will instead focus on other merger and acquisition opportunities. The deal was set to be finalized by September 30, but regulatory hurdles stalled the process.

site_title: Modi to speak to Facebook users in Silicon Valley
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi will speak to Facebook users in Silicon Valley, answering questions from 1.5 billion users at a town hall on Sunday. During his two-day visit, Modi will meet with tech leaders at Facebook and Google headquarters before attending an event at the San Jose Convention Center. Modi has been criticized for his human rights record, but remains popular, with an 87% approval rating in India. He aims to attract technology investments and jobs to India's growing startup scene.

site_title: China's Xi confident of 'healthy' economic growth
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping expressed confidence in a "healthy" economic growth for China, citing a shift from speed-based to quality-based growth. Despite international concerns over a slowdown in the world's second-largest economy, Xi said China's economy would expand at around 7% this year. However, the Asian Development Bank has cut its growth forecast to 6.8% for 2015, citing weak indicators. The Chinese government has implemented measures to shore up growth, including interest rate cuts and reduced bank reserve requirements.

site_title: Latest iteration of Apple versus Samsung
summary: The iPhone 6s and Samsung's Galaxy Note 5 have gone head-to-head in the market, with initial sales figures to be closely watched. The Note 5, with its 5.7-inch screen and metal body, is competing with the iPhone 6s, which boasts a 5.5-inch screen and improved camera capabilities. Despite Samsung's market share decline, the company's sales are being eroded by Chinese brands such as Xiaomi, Huawei, and Lenovo. The Note 5 features Samsung's new design language, a high-resolution Super Amoled screen, and a power-packed octa-core Exynos 7420 chipset. The phone's non-removable battery and limited storage capacity have raised concerns among power users, but Samsung's integration with the Google ecosystem and new mobile payment service, Samsung Pay, may help attract users.

images.alt_text: It remains to be seen if Samsung's Galaxy Note 5 and its running mate the Galaxy S6 Edge+ can halt the decline in phone sales that Samsung has suffered since its heyday in 2013.

site_title: Wall St, Hollywood, tech get seats at table for Xi state dinner
summary: US President Barack Obama and Chinese President Xi Jinping hosted a state dinner at the White House, attended by prominent guests including tech mogul Mark Zuckerberg, Disney CEO Bob Iger, and former US Senator Christopher Dodd. The dinner, part of Xi's two-day visit, focused on issues like climate change, market-access, and military cooperation. Despite some contentious issues, the two leaders agreed to disagree on issues like cybersecurity and human rights. The dinner featured a menu of lobster and lamb, with California wines paired with each course, and concluded with a performance by R&B recording artist Ne-Yo.

site_title: Malaysia shuts schools again amid 'very unhealthy' air
summary: Malaysia has shut schools in the capital and three states due to unhealthy air quality, triggered by thick smoke from Indonesian slash-and-burn farming. The haze, which has plagued the region for weeks, has forced tens of thousands to seek medical treatment and cancelled dozens of flights. Authorities have launched legal action against Indonesian companies blamed for the fires, with Singapore also taking action. The crisis is one of the worst and longest-lasting in years, with the region's air quality remaining hazardous.

site_title: Foxconn said to be nearing deal with Sharp
summary: Foxconn Technology Group has signed a letter of intent to buy a stake in Sharp Corp's LCD business, giving Foxconn management control. The deal would allow Foxconn to expand its presence in the display panel market, a move to diversify its revenue streams. Sharp, under financial pressure, is considering various options for the LCD business. The companies still need to complete price negotiations and due diligence before a final deal can be reached.

site_title: Five banks discuss ways to change gold trading methods in London
summary: Five major banks, including Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley, are discussing the possibility of introducing standardized central clearing and listed derivatives in London's gold trading market, a move that could bring the market in line with global commodity trading practices. This comes as regulators worldwide scrutinize commodities trading and lawmakers push for tighter bank controls. The move could also be driven by the London Metal Exchange's readiness to work with the industry on a clearinghouse for bullion, and the industry's need to modernize the market.

site_title: Is STI on the verge of entering a bear market?
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) has fallen 20% from its 2015 high, prompting concerns it may be entering a bear market. Financial research firm Ideaglobal expects new lows before a recovery, citing periodic crises of confidence. However, some experts believe the worst is over, with the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions and potential rate hikes expected to stabilize markets. The Fed's next meeting is scheduled for October, with a possible rate hike possible, but the exact timing remains uncertain.

site_title: Developer plans ultra-luxury Manhattan condominium tower with US$3,000 psf prices
summary: Sharif El-Gamal's Soho Properties is planning a 667 ft ultra-luxury condominium tower at 45 Park Place in Lower Manhattan, with prices starting at US$3,000 psf. The 15 full-floor units will range from 3,200 to 3,700 sq ft, with the median price expected to be 13% higher than the average for new-development listings in the borough. The project, scheduled for completion in 2017, aims to capitalize on Manhattan's luxury-condo boom and renaissance, despite growing concerns about oversupply.

site_title: Variety adds spice to EE Awards
summary: This year's Emerging Enterprise Awards (EE 2015) recognized 14 diverse SMEs for their entrepreneurial daring and innovative business strategies. Top winners included Hope First Response, GD Group, and ZWEEC Analytics, which took home the Singtel Best Innovation Award. The event, held at the Shangri-La Hotel, featured performances by local jazz singer Dawn Ho and recognized the entrepreneurial achievements of SMEs in various industries, including emergency medical services, food, and water surveillance. The awards were jointly presented by The Business Times and OCBC Bank.

images.alt_text: (From left) Oliver Tan, CEO of ViSenze, Most Promising Startup Award winner; Charles Johnson, founder of Hope First Response, Emerging Enterprise Award winner; Ven Chin, founder and executive director of GD Group, Emerging Enterprise Award winner; Cecilia Chow, executive director of ZWEEC Analytics, Emerging Enterprise Award winner and also Best Innovation Award winner; Lee Yi Shyan, Senior Minister of State, Ministry of Trade & Industry; Linus Goh, head of global commercial banking, OCBC Bank; and Alvin Tay, editor of The Business Times

site_title: Is it ok to ask your opponent what club he just used?
summary: A question in golf etiquette arises: is it acceptable to ask an opponent about the club used in a recent shot. The query was posed in a four-ball match where a caddie intervened, suggesting a 6-iron over a 7-iron. The article does not provide a definitive answer, instead prompting readers to weigh in on the matter.

site_title: Inspired creations that raise the bar
summary: Bacchanalia, a new restaurant, reopened with a focus on food. Thevar 2.0 showcased mod-Indian cuisine, while The Social Kitchen set up shop at Bank of Singapore. CMC Markets partnered with Sophia Women to promote financial literacy for women. The restaurant Bacchanalia is located at 39 Hong Kong Street.

site_title: Hamilton wins Japanese Grand Prix
summary: Lewis Hamilton secured his grip on a third Formula One world title with a dominant victory at the Japanese Grand Prix. The British driver, who now leads Nico Rosberg by 48 points with five races remaining, took the chequered flag 19 seconds ahead of Rosberg. Hamilton's masterclass performance at Suzuka marked his eighth win of the season and allowed him to celebrate a rare emotional moment, matching his boyhood hero Ayrton Senna's 41 victories.

site_title: A tale of two cities
summary: Hong Kong and Singapore, two major financial hubs in Asia, are seen as rivals by each other. Hong Kong's investable market is about five-and-a-half times larger than Singapore's, with the city positioning itself as the gateway to China. Singapore, on the other hand, markets itself as the gateway to Southeast Asia. The comparison of their indices highlights the differing economic focuses of the two cities.

site_title: Volkswagen scandal unnerves markets, threatens economies
summary: Volkswagen's diesel emissions scandal has sent shockwaves through the global automotive industry, with the company facing billions of dollars in fines and legal costs. The scandal has also raised concerns about the lax regulatory environment in Europe, where Volkswagen has been accused of "ducking" emissions rules to keep its polluting cars on the road. The European Parliament has voted to introduce stricter emissions tests, while US officials have charged Volkswagen executives with cheating in diesel emissions tests. The scandal is estimated to have killed tens of thousands of people worldwide each year, and experts warn that the response of European regulators has been "shameful".

site_title: High-end home sales get boost as buyers find reasons to bite
summary: High-end home sales in Singapore have seen a boost, with a 17.7% increase in private homes sold above S$3 million in the first seven months of this year. This growth is attributed to emerging value and currency movements, with Savills Singapore analyzing URA Realis data. Transactions in the landed and non-landed segments have also seen an increase, with 48% of private homes sold above S$3 million being landed properties. Buyers are attracted to the lower prices and completed units, with developers offering more realistic pricing to meet the sales deadline.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Update: Volkswagen scandal spreads trouble from IPOs to credit markets
summary: Volkswagen's emissions scandal has spread to Europe's credit markets, with the Bank of France halting trading of two securities backed by Volkswagen auto loans. The move follows a 28% decline in Volkswagen's stock price after the company admitted to cheating on US emissions tests since 2009. Former CEO Martin Winterkorn resigned, and new CEO Matthias Mueller aims to restore trust with stringent compliance standards. The scandal also affects parts supplier Schaeffler AG, which is planning an initial public offering despite concerns about the impact on Volkswagen car production.

site_title: Civil war puts a hold on creativity of Libyan artists
summary: Libyan artists' creativity has been severely hindered by the ongoing civil war, with many forced to abandon exhibitions and workshops due to power cuts, water cuts, fuel shortages, and the departure of artists with their families. The country's art scene, which had shown great promise after the fall of dictator Muammar Gaddafi in 2011, has been reduced to a single gallery, Dar al-Founoun, which has become a refuge for artists to meet. The Islamist-backed militia coalition's takeover of Tripoli in 2014 has led to a significant decline in artistic expression.

site_title: Thai police say detained man is Bangkok 'bomber' seen on CCTV
summary: Thai police have confirmed that a detained man, Adem Karadag, is the bomber seen on CCTV footage at the Bangkok shrine before a deadly blast on August 17, which killed 20 people. Karadag, a foreigner held in custody, had been denied a confession to the crime by his lawyer, but authorities say CCTV footage and eyewitness accounts confirm his identity. He now faces up to eight charges, including premeditated murder, and is set to undergo a reenactment of his alleged role in the crime.

site_title: Boeing US tanker plane makes first flight
summary: Boeing's KC-46A refueling plane completed a four-hour inaugural flight on September 26, 2015, marking a key milestone for the US$49 billion program. The test pilots performed operational checks on engines, flight controls, and environmental systems before landing at Boeing Field. The flight will pave the way for aerial refueling flights with US Air Force aircraft later this year, potentially leading to a decision in 2016 to move into low-rate production.

site_title: Shop rents tumble on Hong Kong street that was world's priciest
summary: Hong Kong's Russell Street, once the world's most expensive strip for retail rents, has seen a significant drop in shop rents. A 1,000 square feet space currently rented by Jaeger-LeCoultre for over HK$1.4 million per month will be leased to Colourmix for HK$1 million per month, a 43% decrease. This trend is attributed to China's economic slowdown, with Jones Lang LaSalle predicting a 15-20% drop in high-street rents in Hong Kong this year. Similar rent reductions have been seen in other locations, including Central, where Adidas is leasing a space currently occupied by Coach at a 23% cheaper rate.

site_title: Pound's outlook seen brightening as way clear for BOE rate boost
summary: The pound may recover against the euro as the Bank of England is expected to raise interest rates sooner than predicted, according to BNP Paribas analysts. Despite the pound's 1.1% drop in the month, the analysts predict the BOE will increase interest rates by February, potentially reversing the currency's slide against the euro. This is due to the Federal Reserve's confirmation of interest rate hikes in the US and the European Central Bank's possible expansion of quantitative easing. The analysts are shorting euro-sterling, betting on the euro's weakness.

site_title: S'pore leads Asian investors in fleeing Wall Street in Q2
summary: In the second quarter of 2015, Singapore-based investors led Asian investors in fleeing US stocks, dumping a net $14.75 billion worth of US equities, while Europeans, particularly the British, sold a larger amount, $17.69 billion. This was due to concerns over Greece's potential default on debt payments. In contrast, Asian investors bought a net $2.47 billion in US Treasury bonds, reversing their previous quarter's net sales. US investors also increased their quarterly outlay on foreign stocks, reaching $45.65 billion.

site_title: Two Chinese suitors said to be keen on jet lessor AWAS
summary: Chinese suitors ICBC Financial Leasing Co and Aviation Industry Corp of China are exploring a takeover of AWAS Aviation Capital Ltd, a Dublin-based aircraft lessor, in an auction expected to fetch over US$5 billion. Terra Firma Capital Partners, which owns 75% of AWAS, is working with Deutsche Bank and Goldman Sachs on the process. This move could help a Chinese buyer tap into the growing Asian air-travel market and diversify investments as the yuan weakens. AWAS has over 250 commercial planes under its portfolio and more than 100 airline customers worldwide.

site_title: MyRepublic secures S$23m capital funding
summary: MyRepublic, a Singaporean fibre broadband service provider, has secured S$23 million in capital funding, including investments from Brunei's DST. The company aims to build a lean operator that can survive with 8% market share, with plans to trial small cell LTE technology to lower infrastructure costs. DST CEO Suhaimi Hussain sees the investment as an opportunity to expand into the mobile market, while MyRepublic CEO Malcolm Rodrigues aims to achieve this goal without incurring significant costs.

site_title: Global regulators reach agreement on bail-in bonds plan for top banks
summary: Global regulators reached a draft agreement on a rule requiring top banks to hold enough equity capital and bonds to avoid taxpayer bailouts in a crisis. The Total Loss Absorbency Capacity (TLAC) rule, also known as "too big to fail," will apply to nearly 30 globally systemic banks, including Goldman Sachs, Deutsche Bank, and HSBC. The FSB aims to finalize the rule by November's G20 Summit, with the goal of reducing taxpayer risk in financial crises.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs Group Inc. headquarters stand in New York, US, on Monday, Jan 13, 2014. Global regulators reached a draft agreement Friday on a rule on stopping banks being "too big to fail", by requiring them to hold enough equity capital and bonds to avoid taxpayers being called on in a crisis.

site_title: Fed's George: no need to wait for more data before rate hike
summary: Kansas City Fed President Esther George said the Federal Reserve should raise interest rates soon, citing moderate US economic growth and signs of firming inflation. She believes waiting for perfect conditions is unrealistic and that rate hikes are necessary to keep financial markets from taking on too much risk. Despite factors like the strong dollar and drop in oil prices, George remains confident in the US economy's trajectory. She expects monetary policy to remain accommodative even after a rate increase.

site_title: Update: Volkswagen picks company veteran to tackle emissions crisis
summary: Volkswagen has appointed Matthias Mueller as its new CEO amid the company's emissions crisis. Mueller, 62, replaces Martin Winterkorn, who resigned on Wednesday. The scandal involves 2.8 million vehicles in Germany, nearly six times as many as admitted in the US, with regulators and prosecutors worldwide investigating. The company has announced a full investigation, suspended staff, and adopted a more decentralized structure. Mueller has vowed to develop strict compliance and governance standards, but analysts question his ability to lead the company for 10 years. The company faces lawsuits, job cuts, and a potential recall of affected vehicles.

site_title: STI's decline continues on China, US rate concerns
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) declined 13.1 points to 2,832.64 on Friday, resulting in a net loss of 1.6% for the week. Despite a 2-point gain on Monday, the market's daily turnover has been uninspiring, with 1.4 billion units worth S$1.2 billion traded on Friday. The decline is attributed to heavy trading of blue chips, with Singtel and Neptune Orient Lines experiencing significant price movements.

site_title: Buying spread out across several sectors
summary:
Key facts and events from the article include: 
In the week ending September 25, 47 purchases worth S$10.63 million were made by directors, while only one firm made a disposal worth S$0.09 million. 
Thirty companies repurchased shares worth S$77.6 million, with the turnover down from the previous week's S$182.4 million. 
Mencast Holdings, a marine and oil & gas industry services provider, bought back shares for the first time since December 2014. 
Plastoform Holdings, a wireless audio speaker developer and manufacturer, also made its first buyback since October 2014. 
Key insider purchases were recorded by Technics Oil & Gas, Hong Fok Corporation, Bonvests Holdings, Sunningdale Tech, and Ban Leong Technologies.

images.alt_text: The buying rebounded sharply while the selling among directors was very low based on filings on the Exchange during the holiday-shortened week of September 21 to 25.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality goes global on hotel residences
summary: Frasers Hospitality is expanding its hotel-residences brand, Capri by Fraser, in Europe and Asia-Pacific. The company plans to triple the number of Capri by Fraser properties by 2018, from six currently, to 17 with over 3,500 units. This follows the launch of Capri by Fraser in Frankfurt and Barcelona, and upcoming openings in Berlin and Shanghai. Frasers Hospitality sees strong growth potential for the brand, particularly in Europe, where it will add 10 more properties in Asia-Pacific over the next four years.

site_title: Payments startup Square Inc plans 'imminent' IPO filing: source
summary: Square Inc, a payments startup, plans to file for an "imminent" initial public offering, potentially becoming a public company by the end-of-year holiday season. The company, valued at an estimated $6 billion, has pioneered instant payments over smartphones. A spokesman for Square declined comment on the timing, but earlier reports suggested the filing would occur within the next two weeks.

images.alt_text: Square's IPO comes at a critical time for chief executive officer Jack Dorsey, who is also interim CEO of Twitter Inc .

site_title: US House Speaker Boehner to resign
summary: US House Speaker John Boehner announced his resignation at the end of October, citing the need to protect the institution from leadership turmoil amid a government shutdown threat. Boehner's departure follows repeated clashes with conservative Republicans, including a potential shutdown over Planned Parenthood funding. The new fiscal year begins on October 1, and Congress faces a looming government shutdown if a spending plan is not approved, similar to the 2013 shutdown.

images.alt_text: MR BOEHNER: His sudden and surprising resignation threatens to further divide his caucus, as his loyalists lashed out at those in the caucus who had threatened to try to topple Mr Boehner.

site_title: Q2 growth revised upwards on consumer spending, construction
summary: The US economy expanded at a 3.9% annualized rate in the second quarter, beating prior estimates of 3.7%, driven by gains in consumer spending and construction. This growth may help the US weather a global slowdown. The Commerce Department's revised GDP figures offer a boost to the Federal Reserve's confidence in the US economy's resilience. The news comes as the Fed views the US as likely to overcome any fallout from cooling overseas markets.

site_title: August fall in manufacturing output stokes recession fears
summary: Singapore's manufacturing output plummeted 7% year-over-year in August, exceeding expectations and sparking recession fears. Economists debate whether the country is already in a technical recession or how severe it will be. While some, like Citigroup and Nomura, predict a strong services sector will prevent a GDP decline, others, like Bank of America Merrill Lynch, see a deep recession. A technical recession is considered likely if GDP declines for two consecutive quarters, and hopes for a recovery in September's factory output are seen as improbable.

site_title: Security increased at haj site as death toll from tragedy rises to 769
summary: A stampede at the haj site in Mecca, Saudi Arabia, has claimed the lives of 769 people, making it the deadliest tragedy to strike the annual Muslim pilgrimage in a quarter-century. The incident occurred on Thursday as pilgrims converged on Jamarat Bridge, a five-storey structure where they ritually stone the devil. The death toll has raised tensions with regional rival Iran, which has criticized Saudi Arabia's handling of the disaster. An investigation has been ordered, and the kingdom's leaders have vowed to "revision" its organisation to prevent similar incidents in the future.

site_title: Singapore air quality improves as government says haze to stay
summary: Singapore's air quality improved to "moderate" levels after reaching a year's high of 334 due to Indonesian forest fires. Schools and outdoor events were shut, and the government advised healthy individuals to reduce physical activity. The National Environment Agency identified four Indonesian companies that may have contributed to the smoke. The government has served Asia Pulp & Paper with a notice for information on fire suppression measures. Air quality is expected to remain in the "moderate" range over the next 12 hours.

site_title: US: Stocks drop as investors stay edgy
summary: US stocks dropped for the week, despite improving US data, due to concerns over a slowing Chinese economy and the Volkswagen emissions scandal. The Nasdaq Composite Index fell 2.92%, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 dropped 0.43% and 1.37%, respectively. Despite these losses, US stocks have reached fresh records, and investors remain cautious amid tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: HLH brings HDB-style homes to Cambodia
summary: HLH Group, a Singaporean homegrown company, has launched its real estate development brand Camhomes in Cambodia, offering HDB-style homes. The first project, D'Seaview, is an executive condominium near Sokha Beach in Sihanoukville, with 735 units priced from US$33,000. Camhomes will adopt a sale and purchase system similar to Singapore's HDB system, with subsidies for Cambodian citizens up to 50% of the selling price. The company plans to develop 5,000 units in three cities by the end of next year, driven by Cambodia's growing population and rising disposable income.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: PAP group proposes Fort Canning memorial for founders
summary: A People's Action Party (PAP) group has proposed a memorial park in Fort Canning Park to honor Singapore's founders, who transformed the city-state from a struggling port city to a First-World metropolis. The 15-member committee, led by Esplanade chairman Lee Tzu Yang, will gather public views on the proposal. The memorial, which will not feature personalized monuments, will highlight Singapore's 50 years of nation-building. The site, close to the National Museum, will include landscaped gardens, exhibitions, and spaces for children, according to the PAP.SG group, chaired by Speaker of Parliament Halimah Yacob.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Pope Francis sees 2 sides of Washington
summary: Pope Francis visited Washington, DC, where he received a standing ovation from US lawmakers and other VIPs while delivering a speech to Congress. He also had lunch with the homeless at a Catholic Charities facility, where he blessed the food and encouraged guests to enjoy their meal. The pope emphasized the need for action on global issues, including the migrant crisis and climate change, and called for a better life for all people.

site_title: US to host meeting to wrap up TPP deal
summary: The US will host a meeting from September 30 to October 1 to finalize the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) deal, a key part of President Barack Obama's Asia engagement. The 12-nation pact aims to cut trade barriers and set common standards for 40% of the world economy. Key sticking points include dairy trade, biologic drug protection periods, and rules of origin for cars. Officials close to the negotiations say progress has been made, with a final deal expected next week, but some countries, including Mexico and New Zealand, have expressed concerns.

site_title: Living in the era of cheating software
summary: Volkswagen's "clean diesel" scandal highlights the need for better ways to catch cheating software in smart objects. The company's vehicles used software to reduce emissions during testing but exceeded pollution limits when driving. Similar cases have been reported in cars, voting machines, and other devices. To combat this, smart objects must be tested "in the wild" and manufacturers must not be allowed to block research into their systems. Regulatory frameworks and auditable logs can help ensure the integrity of software systems, and industries like slot machines demonstrate the effectiveness of such safeguards.

site_title: China capital outflows hit record in August on yuan weakness
summary: China experienced a record capital outflow of $141.66 billion in August, surpassing the previous record of $124.62 billion in July. The outflow was largely attributed to the yuan's weakness, triggered by the People's Bank of China's devaluation on August 11. Experts warn that the ongoing capital flight could lead to depreciation pressure, but officials claim it's a temporary market reaction. The Chinese government is working to enhance capital controls and balance the need to open its capital account to win reserve status with the International Monetary Fund.

site_title: Japan's economy slips back into deflation
summary: Japan's economy slipped into mild deflation in August, with core consumer prices falling 0.1% from a year earlier, prompting speculation of further monetary stimulus from the Bank of Japan. The move raises concerns of a potential recession and challenges Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's goal to boost the economy by 20% in the next few years. Despite this, Abe claimed the economy is recovering gradually and no additional fiscal stimulus is needed, while BOJ governor Haruhiko Kuroda hinted at possible easing in the coming months.

site_title: US firms quick at cutting deals with activists
summary: US companies are quickly agreeing to activist hedge funds' demands, with Sysco granting board seats to Trian Fund after just six days. This trend is accelerating, with the average number of days to reach a settlement with activists decreasing to 56 days, down from 83 days in 2010. Activists are becoming more influential, backed by powerful institutional investors, and companies are bowing to their demands to avoid proxy fights. Experts warn that this may lead to short-term expediency at the expense of long-term shareholder interests.

site_title: Independent China refiners' clout growing in global oil market
summary: China's independent refiners, known as "teapots," are gaining significant clout in the global oil market as the government widens access for private investment. The country has approved seven teapot operators to import 35.3 million tonnes of overseas crude, and imports are expected to rise to 40 million tonnes by 2016. This expansion is seen as a response to a global oil glut, which has cut benchmark prices by half in the past year, and may help boost imports into the world's second-biggest oil user.

site_title: Celebrating architecture
summary: Archifest, Singapore's annual festival celebrating architecture, returns with the theme "What Future?" amidst the country's 50th year of independence. The event features various activities, including conferences, exhibitions, workshops, and private tours of lesser-known spaces, such as the Civil Service Club and Tokio Marine Centre. The festival aims to inspire Singaporeans to think about their future and the city's growth, with approximately 30,000 visitors expected to participate.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: Abeo Electra bare their teeth
summary: Abeo Electra has emerged as a strong contender in The Business Times Corporate League 2015, with Seagull Gayatri facing pressure due to their initial strong start. Meanwhile, China is urging South-east Asian countries to support openness amidst US tariffs, while Chinese property shares surged on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector. US weekly jobless claims fell unexpectedly, and China unveiled new steps to aid employment amid trade tensions. Reliance Jio has delayed its India IPO beyond this year, and a low-profile property trust is exploring a data centre gambit.

site_title: Tried and Tested
summary: The TaylorMade M1 range of metalwoods, released in 2015, features a multi-material, multi-adjustable, and multi-target audience design. However, the article appears to be unrelated to the M1 range as it contains unrelated news articles about various global topics, including Myanmar's election, China's data centre, US jobless claims, and Reliance Jio's delayed India IPO.

site_title: Gold bears grow weary as ratio of puts to calls hits 3-year low
summary: Gold bears show signs of fatigue as the put-to-call ratio hits a 3-year low, indicating a potential loss of control by bears. The ratio, compiled by Bloomberg, fell to its lowest since 2012, with open interest on puts decreasing since mid-July. Investors are dumping gold in anticipation of monetary tightening, with the Federal Reserve holding off on raising interest rates. Despite this, gold prices have rebounded 7% since slumping to a 5-year low, and some analysts suggest a counter-trend move higher if the rate increase is pushed out to December or next year.

site_title: VW diesel scandal: local car buyers unfazed
summary: Volkswagen's diesel scandal has not deterred Singaporean car buyers, with diesel cars being chosen mainly for their lower price and compliance with Singapore's stricter emission standards. Unlike the US, Singapore's emissions regulations are less stringent, making diesel cars more appealing to buyers. Dealers say the scandal has not affected demand for diesel cars in Singapore.

images.alt_text: The Volkswagen emissions scandal does not seem to have affected Singaporeans' interest in or demand for diesel cars so far, as purchases here are based mainly on financial considerations and because of the lower emission standard here, say dealers.

site_title: Building a S'pore core in maritime workforce
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has launched initiatives to attract and advance Singaporeans through careers in the maritime industry. In partnership with 13 industry bodies, MPA aims to attract over 1,200 Singaporeans as maritime seafarers and port-operations officers, doubling the number of seafarers on board Singapore-flagged ships to 1,000 in the next five years. The initiatives include a career services platform, Maritime Singapore Connect, and funding support from the government's SkillsFuture initiative to encourage lifelong learning.

site_title: Volkswagen pollution scandal may backfire on diesel
summary: Volkswagen's worldwide pollution cheating scandal may ultimately harm the diesel fuel, which is widely used in Europe to reduce carbon emissions. The scandal, which involved software that could switch off emissions controls, has led to a decrease in diesel car sales and a shift towards hybrid and electric technologies. A recent survey found that 59.6% of French drivers do not believe diesel is clean, and 27% of respondents to a separate survey reported a more negative opinion of diesel cars after learning about the scandal.

site_title: Yellen ends speech on inflation abruptly
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen received medical attention after coughing and struggling to finish a speech in Amherst, Massachusetts, on Thursday. Yellen, 69, felt dehydrated and was attended to by emergency medical staff, but was fine afterwards. She had been speaking for nearly an hour about the Fed's decision to delay interest rate hikes, saying the US economy is strong enough to boost employment and inflation remains stable. The speech was her first public comments after explaining the Fed's decision, and her comments suggest the Fed may raise interest rates later this year.

images.alt_text: MS YELLEN: Nearing the end of her speech, she began to slow and then lost her place in reading her notes.

site_title: Global IPOs slump in Q3, but Q4 hopes up
summary: Global initial public offerings (IPOs) declined 55% in the third quarter to 192 deals, raising US$17.9 billion, a 75% drop from the previous quarter. The Asia-Pacific region, particularly China, saw the sharpest slowdown. Despite this, EY expects IPO activity to pick up in developed markets, such as the US, in the fourth quarter, driven by risk-aversion and solid economic fundamentals.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: China Aviation Oil seeks up to 1.1 million barrels of jet fuel for loading in November, consistent with usual volumes. Tung Lok Restaurants faces a civil complaint from China National Decoration seeking a late payment penalty of nine million yuan, with the company planning to vigorously defend the claims. Semiconductor firm Sunright posted a net profit of S$3.15 million for FY2015, up 24% from FY2014, despite flat revenue.

site_title: Bank of Singapore sees pressure on Asia's small wealth firms
summary: Bank of Singapore, the private banking arm of OCBC, expects further consolidation in Asia's wealth management sector as smaller firms struggle to compete with larger banks offering a range of global products. CEO Bahren Shaari notes that firms with less than $20 billion in assets under management may face difficulties sustaining their operations. The industry is already seeing consolidation, with DBS acquiring Societe Generale's Asian wealth management unit and Union Bancaire Privee acquiring Coutts International. Only large banks with significant assets under management are likely to prosper in the sector.

images.alt_text: Bank of Singapore Ltd, the private banking arm of South-east Asia's second-largest lender, Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp (OCBC), sees further consolidation in the Asian wealth management sector, as business gravitates to the larger firms and smaller players find it harder to offer the range of services demanded by the region's rich.

site_title: S'pore confronts four Indonesian firms and APP over haze
summary: The Singapore government has served notices to four Indonesian companies and Asia Pulp & Paper (APP) for allegedly contributing to haze pollution through forest fires in Sumatra. The National Environment Agency (NEA) has requested the companies to extinguish fires and take measures to prevent future occurrences. The government is also reviewing procurement procedures to promote green procurement and apply economic pressure against errant companies, with the goal of supporting sustainable practices in the palm oil and forestry sectors.

site_title: Competition unit seeks feedback on changes to guidelines
summary: The Competition Commission of Singapore is seeking public feedback on proposed changes to its guidelines, aiming to streamline its merger assessment process and whistleblowing procedures. The changes include a fast track procedure for companies under investigation and a clearer process for cartel whistleblowers. The CCS is consulting with law firms, the business community, and government departments to gather feedback on the proposed changes.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality in talks with funds as it eyes Europe assets
summary: Frasers Hospitality, the hospitality arm of Frasers Centrepoint Ltd, is in talks with funds to acquire targeted European assets and has plans to expand its UK-based hotel chain group to Europe and Asia. The company is seeking a distribution platform, with a Japan-based player being considered for a strategic alliance or equity investment. Despite concerns over the euro crisis, Frasers Hospitality believes valuations are attractive, with Ebitda yields of 7% in Europe compared to Asia or China. The company is eyeing opportunities in Munich, Madrid, Milan, and other European cities, with a focus on 30-40% of branded hotels, 30% boutique hotels, and 30% Capri by Fraser.

site_title: ADB bumps up financing for war on climate change
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has doubled its annual climate change financing to $6 billion by 2020, with $4 billion dedicated to mitigation efforts and $2 billion for adaptation projects. The move reflects the bank's strategic priorities and increased financing capacity. Developed nations have pledged $100 billion annually from 2020 to counter climate change in developing countries. The ADB's efforts align with the UN's Sustainable Development Goals, which aim to combat climate change and its impact.

site_title: EU launches new fund to boost investment
summary: The European Union has launched the European Fund for Strategic Investment (EFSI), a new institution to boost investment in the 28-member grouping. The EFSI will invest or guarantee investments of about 20 billion euros annually for three years, catalyzing an additional 250 billion euros of investment from the private sector. The fund aims to support projects with good returns, targeting areas such as energy efficiency, renewables, and small and medium enterprises. Asian investors, including those from Singapore and China, can also participate in EFSI-funded projects.

site_title: Friends with nature
summary: A dedicated Malaysian farmer, Fung Chee Siang, supplies 80% of Singapore's top chefs with organic vegetables, making the locavore concept a reality. Hatiku Agrikultur, his farm in Cameron Highlands, fulfills the romantic notion of farm-to-table, with a focus on working relationships with nature. The farm's unique approach, including companion planting and allowing wildlife to coexist, results in a diverse and pest-free environment. Chefs like Anthony Yeoh and Ivan Brehm praise the farm's commitment to sustainability and the connection it fosters between farmers and chefs, allowing for a more authentic dining experience.

site_title: Nine rules for investors to keep in mind
summary: A writer recounts their experience purchasing a rare Carpenters' CD from Amazon Japan, where it was mistakenly shipped with a new, pristine version, despite being ordered for a second-hand edition. The article is unrelated to the writer's anecdote and appears to be a collection of unrelated news articles about investing, asset diversification, and market trends, including a record high S&P 500, Ant's stablecoin plans, and Amundi's expectations for ETF growth in Asia and Europe.

site_title: Deutsche Bank to face US$190m tax fraud case
summary: A US federal judge has denied Deutsche Bank's request to dismiss a US$190 million tax fraud lawsuit, allowing the government to proceed with its case against the German bank. The lawsuit claims Deutsche Bank used shell companies to avoid capital gains taxes on Bristol-Myers Squibb Co shares acquired in 1999. The bank had argued the transaction was not fraudulent and the lawsuit was filed too late, but the judge found the government's claim to be legally sufficient.

site_title: Swiss start criminal proceedings against Fifa head
summary: Swiss authorities have opened criminal proceedings against FIFA President Joseph "Sepp" Blatter, accusing him of criminal mismanagement and misappropriation. Blatter, 79, is accused of signing an unfavorable contract with Caribbean soccer officials in 2005 and making a "disloyal payment" of 2 million Swiss francs to Michel Platini. The probe follows allegations of corruption and follows US attorney general Loretta Lynch's warning of potential further arrests. The investigation has resulted in the seizure of assets, including apartments in the Swiss Alps, and comes as FIFA prepares for reform efforts.

site_title: Malaysian police arrest three over suspected terror plot
summary: Malaysian authorities have arrested three individuals, including a Syrian and an Indonesian national, on suspicion of planning terror attacks against domestic and foreign targets. The suspects were taken into custody on Thursday after the US and Australian embassies warned citizens to avoid a popular tourist area due to an unspecified security threat. Authorities claim the suspects planned to attack "important national assets, Western assets, and public spots." The arrests come amid concerns over growing hardline Islamic views and the potential for militant activity in the country.

site_title: Cyber ransom emerging as credible threat: Symantec
summary: A recent study by Symantec reveals that cyber ransomware has emerged as a significant threat, with the majority of attacks aimed at making money from victims. The four most prevalent direct revenue-generating risks include misleading apps, fake antivirus scams, locker ransomware, and crypto ransomware. Crypto ransomware, which doesn't necessarily use encryption, is a major concern, with the US and Japan being the top two countries affected. Symantec warns that prevention is key, recommending regular backups and secure storage solutions to shield consumers from these threats.

site_title: Discounts in US Reits setting the stage for buyout spree
summary: US real estate investment trusts (Reits) are trading at a nearly 15% discount to their individual building values, the largest gap in five years, according to Green Street Advisors LLC. This has pushed the odds of Reit buyouts to their highest since 2006, as investors seek better deals. The significant discount sets the stage for a wave of takeovers, potentially leading to a buyout spree.

site_title: Obama, Xi lay out joint vision for global climate agreement
summary: US President Barack Obama and Chinese President Xi Jinping outlined a joint vision for a global climate agreement, aiming to shape a new century through cooperation. China will launch a national carbon cap-and-trade system in 2017, while the US reaffirmed its pledge to channel $3 billion to the UN-backed Green Climate Fund. The two leaders also agreed on enhanced transparency and periodic emission reduction commitments. The joint statement builds on their November 2014 bilateral announcement, with China committing to cap its rising emissions by 2030 and the US pledging to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions 26-28% by 2025.

images.alt_text: CLOSER TO GOALS: The joint presidential statement by Mr Obama and Mr Xi was a highlight of a state visit to Washington by the Chinese president as the two leaders tackled difficult issues such as cyber spying and China's economic policies.

site_title: Japan's Abe signals readiness to offer fiscal stimulus
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe signaled readiness to offer fiscal stimulus to counter economic downturns, despite his cabinet's initial reluctance. Abe emphasized the importance of achieving strong economic growth, but acknowledged Japan's economy is showing weaknesses. Analysts expect the government to provide additional fiscal stimulus to boost growth ahead of next year's upper house elections, despite initial denials by key cabinet ministers.

site_title: Drug's pricing proves a defining moment in modern healthcare
summary: Martin Shkreli, a pharmaceutical executive, raised the price of Daraprim, a critical drug for rare parasitic infections, from $13.50 to $750 per pill, sparking widespread outrage on social media. Shkreli defended the price hike, saying it was a "great business decision" that benefits all stakeholders. Experts, however, criticized the industry's lack of transparency and irrational pricing system, with one physician stating that the system is "rationality-free." Shkreli eventually announced a price reduction, but the incident highlighted the need for greater transparency in healthcare pricing.

site_title: Putting money in water works
summary: US water ventures continue to attract investors despite regulatory obstacles and environmental opposition. Companies like Cadiz and Poseidon Water are investing heavily in water projects, but profits remain elusive. Cadiz has accrued $185 million in losses over the past decade, while Poseidon Water's investors face a long wait for returns. Environmental groups, such as Food and Water Watch, oppose private control of the water supply, citing public trust concerns. Experts believe water will become increasingly valuable, driving investment opportunities, but investors are cautious, focusing on less emotive companies that supply infrastructure to water utilities and industrial users.

site_title: Malaysian firms fear rising ethnic chauvinism
summary: Malaysian firms are concerned about rising ethnic chauvinism, citing the recent escalation in racial rhetoric and the threat of prolonged ethnic strife. Trade Minister Mustapa Mohamed acknowledged the concern, stating that it's time to find solutions to address the issue. The country's racial diversity has long been a strength, but the recent events have given cause for apprehension, with some quarters warning that it could disrupt businesses and the economy. The government faces pressure to address the issue ahead of the 2018 general election, with Prime Minister Najib Razak under scrutiny over the 1MDB scandal.

site_title: Handicap your enthusiasm
summary: Larry David expressed his disdain for the excessive enthusiasm surrounding golf, particularly in Southern California. During a round at Winged Foot, he was interviewed by friend Bill Scheft, where he shared his frustrations with the game's social norms and country-club etiquette. David's passion for golf remained unwavering despite his disdain for the pomp and circumstance surrounding the sport. His comments reflect his signature wit and candor, characteristic of his comedy style.

site_title: GCB site in Cluny Hill area sold for S$21.52m
summary: A 15,097 sq ft vacant freehold site in the Cluny Hill area of Singapore's Good Class Bungalow (GCB) zone has been sold for S$21.52 million (S$1,425 per square foot). The property, being sold by Standard Chemical Corporation, was purchased by Aston Holdings and Realstar Premier Group. The buyer is 90% owned by Tan Koo Chuan, who also controls developer Yi Kai Group. The sale marks a significant transaction in Singapore's GCB market.

images.alt_text: PLUM SITE: It may cost around S$6-8 million to build and fit out a new bungalow with a gross floor area of about 8,000-10,000 sq ft on the site.

site_title: Scout's honour
summary: The Indian Scout motorcycle brand has arrived in Singapore, marking a significant milestone for enthusiasts in the country. The 2015 model, steeped in history and tradition, was first introduced in the 1950s and rode to victory in racing and World War II. The managing director of Mah Pte Ltd, Eugene Mah, announced that the initial shipment of eight Scouts has been sold and delivery is ongoing, with plans to apply for Singapore to be an official chapter of the Indian Motorcycle Riders Group.

site_title: Football: Fifa chief Blatter's offices searched: Swiss authorities
summary: Swiss authorities searched the offices of FIFA President Sepp Blatter as part of a criminal probe into suspected misappropriation of funds. Blatter was questioned on September 25, 2015, and his offices were searched, with data seized. The investigation, led by Switzerland's top prosecutor, is ongoing.

site_title: European stocks rebound as Yellen clarifies Fed rate policy
summary: European stocks rebounded from an eight-month low after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen clarified the Fed's rate policy, indicating a potential rate hike this year. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index rose 2.8% and Germany's DAX Index rebounded 2.8% after Yellen's comments brought clarity to the market. The rebound was also driven by deal news and a relief rally, with stocks such as BMW, Renault, and Adidas gaining ground.

site_title: Serapong sweep
summary: The Golf Digest ranking of golf courses in Singapore has been delayed due to redevelopment at several clubs, including Orchid Country Club, National Service Resort and Country Club, and Sentosa Golf Club's Tanjong Course. The usual biennial rating process has been disrupted, leaving the rankings uncertain. The Golf Digest typically releases its rankings once every two years, but this year's rating process has been affected by the redevelopment projects. The exact impact on the rankings remains unclear.

site_title: A really good Day on the greens
summary: Jason Day and Jordan Spieth have had a remarkable 2015 season, both rising to No. 1 in the world golf rankings. Day, 27, became the youngest Australian world No. 1 at 27 years and 10 months old, while Spieth, 21, won the US Open and Masters, becoming the youngest US Open winner since 1923. Both golfers are strong contenders for the PGA Player of the Year award, with Day having a recent winning streak and Spieth having a superb season. The Tour Championship at East Lake Golf Club will determine the FedEx Cup winner and Day's chance at the $10 million prize.

site_title: Great game will haunt Pettersen
summary: Golfer Suzann Pettersen was left feeling disheartened after a poor display of sportsmanship during the Solheim Cup. The event, which saw Pettersen walk off the course after a dispute, has been described as one of the worst displays of sportsmanship in golf history. Pettersen's actions have been widely criticized, and it remains to be seen how this incident will affect her career. The Solheim Cup was a major golf tournament that showcased the skills of European and US female golfers.

site_title: ADB says to double funds for Asia-Pacific climate mitigation by 2020
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has announced plans to double its climate change mitigation funding to $6 billion annually by 2020. This funding will focus on renewable energy, energy efficiency, and sustainable transport in South Asia and Southeast Asia, where climate change is particularly critical. The ADB warns that if left unchecked, climate change could result in significant economic losses, including a 8.8% loss of GDP in South Asia and a 6.7% loss in Southeast Asia by 2100.

site_title: Making cool reds in the heat
summary: The article discusses the challenges faced by the wine industry due to global warming, which has led to early harvests and higher alcohol levels in wines. To combat this, grape farmers are experimenting with planting techniques, such as reducing sun exposure and selecting cooler spots, while winemakers are using blending rustic and acidic grape varieties to restrain alcohol levels. The article highlights 10 wines from the BT Wine Challenge 2015, including Trinchero Napa Valley Cloud's Nest Cabernet Sauvignon, Ridge Vineyards Cabernet Sauvignon Estate, and Teso La Monja Toro Almirez, which showcase the diversity and skill of vineyard owners and winemakers in creating high-quality wines despite the challenges posed by climate change.

site_title: Play safe
summary: The article discusses various global news topics. Knee injuries from twisting or rotational forces are highlighted as a potential risk. Meanwhile, in politics, ASEAN agrees that Myanmar's election is not a priority, and Malaysia expresses concerns. In business, a low-profile property trust invests in a data center, and Chinese property shares surge due to unverified reports. Additionally, US weekly jobless claims fall unexpectedly, and China announces new steps to aid employment amid trade tensions. Reliance Jio's India IPO is also delayed beyond this year.

site_title: The forbidden dance
summary: Golf pro Miguel Angel Jimenez is known for his pre-round routine, which some consider "risqué" and humorous. However, the article does not provide further information about Jimenez or his dance. The article appears to be a collection of unrelated news headlines, covering topics such as Southeast Asian politics, China's economic efforts, and a US job market update. No conclusions are drawn, and no further analysis is provided.

site_title: US House speaker Boehner to resign next month: lawmaker
summary: US House Speaker John Boehner announced his resignation at a closed-door meeting, citing the end of October as the effective date. His departure will trigger an intense battle for control of the House ahead of the 2016 presidential election.

site_title: Celebrating SG50 in the right spirit
summary: Beam Suntory is hosting a private event "50 Years of Gold" to celebrate Singapore's 50th birthday, featuring a specially crafted cabinet showcasing three 50-year-old single malt whiskies: Bowmore, Auchentoshan, and Yamazaki. The cabinet, designed by Nathan Yong, will be auctioned off on September 30, with proceeds going to The Business Times Budding Artists Fund, supporting disadvantaged young artists. This event highlights Beam Suntory's commitment to commemorating SG50 and giving back to the community.

images.alt_text: PRIZED POSSESSIONS: The single malts are the Bowmore 50 Years Old, the Auchentoshan 50 Years Old, and the Yamazaki 50 Years Old

site_title: Brewing up a storm
summary: Homegrown tea brands in Singapore are gaining popularity, offering specialty teas at affordable prices and catering to the growing demand for healthier and more flavorful drinks. With over 10 new tea brands emerging in the past five years, the local market is experiencing a "cha shakedown." Brands like Collaboration Tea, Allerines Tea, and Pin Tea are creating unique blends and using Asian ingredients to appeal to local tastes.
