Established companies like 1872 Clipper Tea Co and Gryphon Tea Company are also investing in plantations and owning tea factories to maintain quality control and pass on savings to consumers.

site_title: How to deliver economic justice to the deprived lot?
summary: The concept of economic justice has gained significance in 21st-century eco-politics, with governments facing pressure to address income inequality. Metrics like the Gini coefficient show stark disparities in income distribution, with China's 73 ranking far lower than Sweden's 24. The lack of economic justice has led to popular revolutions and protests, with governments being voted out or changed due to perceived inequities. The growing population of young people and social media generation is fueling this dissatisfaction, making it a key factor in electoral outcomes.

site_title: China: Stocks end the week flat as volumes keep sliding
summary: China's main stock indexes ended the week flat, with the CSI300 index falling 1.6% and the Shanghai Composite Index losing 1.6%, amid shrinking trading volume. Analysts say the market is still seeking a bottom as investors digest mixed signs on company performance.

site_title: Apple CEO faces iPhone growth question
summary: Apple's latest iPhone models, released worldwide on Friday, may not match the sales success of previous releases, with demand appearing lower than last year. Analysts at Pacific Crest Securities and Sanford C Bernstein & Co have raised concerns about iPhone growth, citing a 35% average quarterly increase in sales since 2013. The new iPhone 6s and 6s Plus feature 3D Touch, improved cameras, and faster processors, but may not be enough to match last year's 74.6 million units sold, with some analysts suggesting sales may have peaked in China, Apple's largest market outside the US.

site_title: Obama, Xi lay out joint vision for global climate agreement
summary: US President Barack Obama and Chinese President Xi Jinping outlined a joint vision for a global climate agreement, building on their 2014 bilateral announcement. China will launch a national carbon cap-and-trade system in 2017, while the US reaffirmed its pledge to channel $3 billion into a UN-backed Green Climate Fund. The two countries also agreed on enhanced transparency and ramping up national emission reduction commitments periodically, aiming to deliver on their 2014 pledges to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

site_title: US services sector growth in Sept slows to 3-month low, says Markit
summary: US services sector growth slowed to its lowest rate in three months in September, according to a Markit report, with the Purchasing Managers Index (PMI) falling to 55.6 from 56.1 in August. New business expansion weakened for the second month, and the employment component also declined. The data suggests sustained steady expansion of the US economy, but growth may weaken in coming months.

site_title: Civmec eyeing slice of Australian submarine project
summary: Civmec, a Singapore-based heavy engineering firm, is pursuing a contract worth up to A$50 billion to build Australia's next-generation submarine fleet. The company has launched a new defence division and aims to work with the lead contractor, investing up to A$30 million in infrastructure facilities. Civmec's CEO, Pat Tallon, stated that the company's portion of the project would be a percentage of the total value, but the exact amount is unclear. The project, which includes construction and "through-life support" of up to 12 submarines, is expected to be completed by 2025.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Genting Singapore's core Ebitda has bottomed out in Q2 2015, despite regional challenges at Resorts World Sentosa. Analysts UOB-Kay Hian Research and OCBC Investment Research maintain buy and hold recommendations, respectively, with target prices of S$1.01 and S$1.39. In contrast, RHB Research advises a sell rating on SMRT Corporation due to elevated rail maintenance costs and dismal FY2016 growth, with a target price of S$1.05.

site_title: BlackBerry unveils Android phone in new reboot effort
summary: BlackBerry unveiled its new Android-powered smartphone, the "Priv," which combines BlackBerry security and Android's expansive mobile application ecosystem. The device is expected to be available later this year. BlackBerry remains committed to its BB 10 operating system, which it will continue to develop and enhance. The company's quarterly results showed a profit of $51 million, but revenues slumped 46% to $490 million. BlackBerry's smartphone sales were 800,000 units at an average price of $240, a tiny fraction of the global smartphone market.

site_title: Civmec eyes Aussie submarine project
summary: Australian heavy engineering firm Civmec is eyeing a piece of an A$50 billion submarine project in Australia, with plans to work as an in-country builder. Civmec has launched a new defence division and appointed a former Royal Australian Navy Commodore to head it, with the potential to create up to 1,000 jobs in Western Australia. The company owns a fabrication facility in Henderson, south of Perth, and plans to build a dedicated facility for submarines.

site_title: Thai banks suffer biggest default since 1997
summary: Thai banks face the biggest default since the 1997 Asian financial crisis as Sahaviriya Steel Industries pcl defaults on 50 billion baht (S$2 billion) of loans following the failure of its UK venture. The default, triggered by a drop in steel prices and a supply glut, is expected to hit earnings at top creditors Siam Commercial Bank pcl, Krung Thai Bank pcl, and Tisco Financial Group pcl. The move may raise bad loans in the Thai banking system to 2.86% of total advances, the highest since July 2011.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares ended higher on Friday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.84 points to close at 1,615.01. 1.66 billion lots valued at RM1.95 billion were traded, with 355 gainers and 381 losers.

site_title: DPM: Singaporean core key to growth of maritime sector
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean announced a series of initiatives to support Singaporeans in the maritime industry, aiming to attract and groom a strong and skilled Singaporean core. The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore, in partnership with industry bodies, will launch a series of programs, including a one-stop career services platform, to facilitate access to information on maritime careers and education. The initiatives, valued at S$115 million, aim to double the number of seafarers on board Singapore-flagged ships to 1,000 in five years and meet projected demand for port operations staff.

site_title: Sunright's counter jumps on FY15 profit spike
summary: Shares of Sunright, a mainboard-listed semiconductor firm, jumped 24% to S$0.26 on Friday after reporting a significant increase in net profit to S$3.1 million for FY15, despite flat revenue. The profit spike was attributed to lower costs, including raw materials and inventories. The company's directors recommended a 0.4 cent ordinary dividend and special dividend, subject to shareholder approval.

site_title: Primary and secondary schools to reopen on Monday unless haze forecast deteriorates back to hazardous levels
summary: Singapore's primary and secondary schools will reopen on Monday unless the 24-hour Pollutant Standards Index (PSI) forecast indicates a hazardous level of haze. The Ministry of Education will consider closing schools if the PSI forecast is hazardous, and parents will be informed through the schools.

site_title: Consumer sentiment in US fell less than forecast in September
summary: US consumer sentiment fell less than forecast in September, decreasing to 87.2, the lowest level since October. A late-month boost among wealthier Americans helped mitigate the decline, with consumers increasingly attributing stock-market turmoil to international conditions rather than domestic economic issues. Despite a decline in expectations six months from now and current conditions, Americans still expect a 2.8% inflation rate in the next year and a 2.7% rate over the next five to 10 years. This suggests that spending will continue to underpin growth despite recent economic challenges.

images.alt_text: A late-month boost among wealthier Americans kept consumer sentiment from falling as much as forecast in September, indicating some households are starting to look beyond the recent turmoil in financial markets.

site_title: US 2nd-quarter GDP growth revised up on spending, building
summary: US GDP growth in the second quarter was revised up to 3.9% from 3.7%, driven by stronger consumer spending and construction. Consumer spending, accounting for over two-thirds of US economic activity, rose 3.6% due to cheap gasoline prices and higher house prices. Construction spending also expanded 4.1% and inventories contributed less to growth than initially estimated. The revised data supports the case for the US economy to withstand interest rate hikes and could lead to a Federal Reserve rate increase this year.

site_title: A new level of luxury
summary: The Lexus RX has undergone a significant design and dynamic overhaul, improving ride comfort and performance. The fourth-generation RX features a more stylish spindle grille, LED lamps, and a touchless power door. Inside, the cabin boasts a higher level of luxury with natural materials and fine wood trim. The new body is bigger but lighter, thanks to aluminum and high-tensile steel, and the revised platform provides improved body rigidity and responsiveness. The RX now offers three engine options, including a new 2.0L turbocharged engine, and features advanced suspension systems for a smoother ride and better handling.

site_title: US to test all diesel car models after VW scandal
summary: The US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) announced it will test all diesel car models for pollution "defeat devices" after the Volkswagen scandal. The EPA will test cars under actual driving conditions, not just newly produced ones, and partner with Environment Canada to conduct lab and on-road tests. The move is in response to Volkswagen's software that overrides pollution controls on the road. The EPA may impose a potential $18 billion in fines on the German company.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Friday
summary: Singapore's industrial production in August fell 7% from a year ago, largely due to weak electronics and marine output. The housing sector is shifting towards oversupply, according to a BNP report. Meanwhile, Malaysia's May industrial production rose 0.3%, below forecast, and the UK economy contracted for the second month. These economic indicators are raising concerns about policymakers' ability to manage growth.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end higher but Shanghai sinks
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.43% to close at 21,186.32, ending a three-day decline, while Shanghai plummeted 1.60% due to ongoing economic concerns. The Hang Seng Index rebounded after a 3% drop in its previous sessions.

site_title: Gold dips as Yellen says Fed on track to hike rates this year
summary: Gold prices dropped 0.7% to $1,146.15/oz, its lowest in a month, after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen said the US central bank would begin raising rates this year, likely denting demand for non-interest-paying gold. The dollar rallied on Yellen's comments, boosting the metal's value. Despite some support from inflows into gold-backed funds and purchases by central banks, gold remains under pressure. Platinum slid for a fifth session, while palladium rose sharply on expectations of a shift from diesel to gasoline vehicles.

site_title: China launches coal shipping route with North Korea: Xinhua
summary: China has launched a coal shipping route connecting its Longkou port to North Korea's Nampo port, focusing on importing coal and exporting groceries. The route, serviced by seven ships, aims to increase coal imports from North Korea, which have surged 33% to 13.4 million tonnes in the first eight months of the year. This marks North Korea as China's third biggest foreign coal supplier.

site_title: Singapore sends notices to four Indonesian companies over haze
summary: The Singapore government has sent notices to four Indonesian companies for contributing to haze pollution, prompting the National Environment Agency (NEA) to deploy fire-fighting personnel and request the companies to discontinue burning activities. The haze is believed to have originated from fires in lands held under concessions by PT Rimba Hutani Mas, PT Sebangun Bumi Andalas Wood Industries, PT Bumi Sriwijaya Sentosa, and PT Wachyuni Mandira. The Singapore government is also examining economic pressure against errant companies and reviewing procurement to promote green practices.

site_title: US: Stocks rise after Yellen affirms coming rate hike
summary: US stocks rose on Friday after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen reaffirmed plans to raise interest rates in 2015, boosting the Dow Jones Industrial Average by 1.13% to 16,383.82. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also gained, with the S&P 500 rising 0.75% to 1,946.67 and the Nasdaq Composite Index increasing 0.83% to 4,773.62.

site_title: Tung Lok to 'vigorously defend' late payment penalty claims by Beijing firm
summary: Tung Lok's Beijing subsidiary, My Humble House in Beijing (Restaurant) Company Ltd, plans to vigorously defend a late payment penalty claim of nine million yuan (S$446,000) made by China National Decoration (CND) for allegedly failing to obtain a fire safety certificate. Tung Lok disputes the amount due to CND, stating it is 1.55 million yuan, and has filed a counterclaim for breach of terms and conditions of the renovation agreement. The case will be heard in the People's Court of the City of Beijing.

site_title: Eurozone loans to private sector increase slightly: ECB
summary: The European Central Bank reported a 1.0% increase in private sector loans in August, marking a slight pick-up in economic health. This growth, although slow, is a result of the ECB's policy measures, including a massive bond-buying program. However, the overall eurozone money supply grew only 4.8% in August, slower than the 5.3% recorded in July. The ECB's M3 money supply remains a key indicator of future inflation.

site_title: Thai central bank cuts 2015 growth, export forecasts again
summary: Thailand's central bank lowered its 2015 economic growth forecast to 2.7% for the third time this year, citing a decline in exports for the third consecutive year. The bank cut its export growth projection to a 5.0% decline from 1.5% earlier. The military-led government has struggled to boost the economy, with sluggish shipments and domestic demand. This is the weakest growth pace since 2001.

site_title: China central bank says will closely watch capital flows
summary: China's central bank stated it will closely monitor capital flows and utilize monetary tools to maintain liquidity and reasonable growth in credit and social financing. The People's Bank of China reiterated interest rate and exchange rate reforms, aiming to keep the yuan stable while adhering to prudent monetary policy. The central bank noted emerging markets face difficulties, while the US economy shows positive signs, and China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower on continued worries over China slowdown, US rates
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed lower on Friday, dropping 13.10 points to 2,832.64, marking a 1.6% loss for the week. The single gain on Monday was not enough to offset falls on the other days, with daily turnover reaching S$1.2 billion. The market's concerns over a China slowdown and US interest rate hikes continued to weigh on the STI.

site_title: China Securities Association denies rumor IPOs set to resume
summary: The Securities Association of China denied rumors that initial public offerings (IPOs) would resume, following a rumor spread on Wechat. The rumor contributed to the decline of the Chinese stock market, with the Shanghai Composite Index falling 1.6% on Friday. China suspended IPOs in early July to stabilize the market, which has lost $5 trillion in value in three months. Analysts suggest that resuming IPOs is unlikely this year due to the government's aim to stabilize the market.

site_title: China's economic growth will be stable in Q3: stats bureau
summary: China's economic growth is expected to remain stable in the third quarter, with no significant impact from stock market volatility. The country's GDP growth in the first half of the year was 7%, and the first two quarters' growth is considered reliable. This reassurance comes as policymakers face pressure to address slowing growth.

images.alt_text: China's economic growth will not fluctuate much in the third quarter compared with previous quarters as the impact from the stock market volatility was not large, Sheng Laiyun, spokesman of the National Bureau of Statistics, said on Friday.

site_title: Australia: Shares wobble after strong start; down 2.5% for the week
summary: Australian shares fell 0.6% on Friday, led by losses in banks, after US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen hinted at rate hikes later this year. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended the week down 2.5%, its second consecutive weekly decline, and is now 3.2% lower in September.

site_title: French consumer confidence jumps to highest since Oct 2007
summary: French consumer confidence surged to its highest level since October 2007, jumping 3 points to 97 in September, surpassing analyst expectations. The rise in households' confidence is a welcome sign for the Socialist government, following a record increase in job seekers. The indicator remains below its long-term average, but the number of households considering big-ticket purchases rose above its average, suggesting a timid recovery in consumer spending.

images.alt_text: French consumer confidence jumped to its highest level since October 2007 in September, above all analysts' expectations and suggesting the traditional driver of growth in the eurozone's second-biggest economy is beginning to see a timid recovery.

site_title: Indonesian quake injures scores, shakes popular tourist spot
summary: A 6.6-magnitude earthquake struck remote eastern Indonesia, injuring over 60 people, damaging 200 houses, and rattling the popular tourist island chain of Raja Ampat. The quake, which occurred at 1:00 am, left 17 people with serious injuries and 45 with minor injuries. No deaths have been reported, but blackouts were experienced in the coastal city of Sorong. The US Geological Survey confirmed the quake's magnitude, which is part of Indonesia's frequent seismic activity due to its location on the Pacific "Ring of Fire".

images.alt_text: A powerful earthquake in remote eastern Indonesia on Friday injured more than 60 people, left hundreds of houses damaged and rattled an idyllic island chain popular with foreign tourists and divers.

site_title: BI to announce policy package to support rupiah
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, plans to announce a policy package next month to support the rupiah, which has lost 18% against the dollar this year. The package will include relaxing forward dollar selling requirements and tax incentives for exporters to keep their dollars onshore, aiming to increase onshore foreign exchange supply.

site_title: Singapore Aug industrial output down 7.0% y-o-y, weaker than expected
summary: Singapore's industrial production in August fell 7.0% year-over-year, weaker than expected, due to weaknesses in electronics and marine engineering output. Manufacturing output also declined 3.7% month-over-month. This was lower than the median forecasts in a Reuters survey.

images.alt_text: Singapore's industrial production in August fell seven per cent from a year earlier, due to weakness in areas such as electronics and marine and offshore engineering output.

site_title: Yellen's US rate hike views hit Asia FX, weekly losses seen
summary: Emerging Asian currencies slid on Friday, with the Taiwan dollar hitting a six-year low after the island's central bank cut its benchmark interest rate. The move was seen as a response to concerns about a global economic slowdown and the US Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hike in 2015. Other currencies, including Malaysia's ringgit and Indonesia's rupiah, also fell to their lowest levels since the Asian financial crisis in 1998, with losses expected to continue into the next week.

site_title: Competition Commission eyes fast-track enforcement, leniency tweaks
summary: The Competition Commission of Singapore (CCS) is seeking feedback on proposed changes to guidelines and processes, including a fast-track enforcement framework offering a 10% reduction in financial penalties for liable parties. The CCS also plans to expand leniency for whistleblowers, including coercers and initiators of cartel activity, but with more stringent requirements. The changes aim to improve business compliance and encourage cooperation in anti-competitive investigations.

site_title: Japan Post planning measures to boost share prices after IPOs
summary: Japan Post Holdings plans measures to boost its share prices after the planned initial public offerings of the company and its financial units. The IPOs, set to list on November 4, aim to raise up to 1.39 trillion yen (S$16.4 billion) for the government. The company's president, Taizo Nishimuro, aims to avoid the market volatility seen with NTT's IPO three decades ago, and instead focus on supporting and boosting share prices after the listings.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise but still face weekly loss
summary: European shares rose on Friday, despite a weekly loss, due to Volkswagen's emissions test scandal and signs of a slowdown in China. The FTSEurofirst 300 index climbed 2.2% and the Euro STOXX 50 index advanced 2% after Volkswagen's CEO appointment hinted at the company's commitment to tackling emissions issues. Meanwhile, France's consumer confidence index reached its highest level since 2007, boosting the CAC equity index 1.8%.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close higher after Yellen speech
summary: Tokyo shares rose 1.76% on Friday after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen hinted at a US rate hike by the end of 2015. The Nikkei 225 index closed 308.68 points higher at 17,880.51. Despite a weak inflation report, investors remained optimistic due to Yellen's comments.

site_title: China said to plan pollution trade expansion for emissions
summary: China plans to launch a nationwide pollution-trading system to reduce global warming emissions, starting in 2017, and will make a significant financial commitment to help poorer countries transition away from fossil fuels. The system will favor domestically produced electricity with lower pollution levels. The move is aimed at increasing climate action and paving the way for a global agreement on climate change. China, the world's largest greenhouse polluter, aims to derive 20% of its energy from renewables and nuclear by 2030, as part of its efforts to shift away from coal.

site_title: Volkswagen pollution scandal backfires on diesel
summary: Volkswagen's worldwide pollution cheating scandal threatens to backfire on diesel, the fuel that powers most cars in Europe. The scandal involves 11 million diesel cars equipped with software that can switch off pollution controls during official testing. This has raised concerns about the emissions of nitrogen oxides and lung-clogging particles. As a result, diesel's popularity is declining in Europe, with 59.6% of French drivers doubting the fuel's cleanliness. The scandal may lead to a shift towards hybrid and all-electric technologies, potentially harming diesel's prospects.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality tripling hotel residences under 'Capri by Fraser' by 2018
summary: Frasers Hospitality is tripling its "Capri by Fraser" hotel-residences brand by 2018, from six properties to 18, with plans to add 10 more in Asia-Pacific over the next four years. The brand, launched in 2012, offers a hybrid of hotel facilities and serviced residences, catering to mobile business travelers and millennials. The company expects the brand to contribute to its global expansion goal of 30,000 residence units by 2019, with strong demand in Europe and Asia-Pacific.

site_title: Businesses, not govt, to spur consumption in China: Alibaba's Ma
summary: China's slowdown is an opportunity for entrepreneurs to drive consumption, not the government, according to Alibaba Group Holding Ltd Executive Chairman Jack Ma. Ma stated that a "real market economy" will flourish as businesses spur consumption, reducing reliance on government investment and export-led growth. Despite Beijing's efforts to steer the economy toward a consumption-driven model, its stock market slump has raised doubts about its commitment to reforms. Alibaba's gross merchandise volume climbed 34% in the three months through June, driven by healthy and aggressive consumer spending.

site_title: US dollar rises, stocks slip in Asia after Yellen comments
summary: The US dollar rose against emerging currencies, while Asian stocks slipped after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen hinted at a potential interest rate hike by year's end. Yellen's comments provided more clarity on the Fed's monetary policy, but economists believe the prospect of higher borrowing costs will deter investment opportunities, weighing on stocks.

site_title: World leaders set to adopt broad UN goals to tackle global woes
summary: Leaders from nearly 200 nations are set to adopt the 17 Sustainable Development Goals, a 15-year plan to combat poverty, inequality, and climate change. The goals aim to end poverty, promote gender equality, protect the planet, and create conditions for sustainable growth. The adoption follows three years of brainstorming and negotiations, replacing the previous Millennium Development Goals. The UN officials will closely monitor the implementation of the goals, which require trillions of dollars in investment, and review progress using global indicators by March 2016.

site_title: Seoul: Won slips, posts biggest weekly fall in 4 yrs; shares down
summary: The South Korean won fell 0.2% to a near three-week low of 1,194.7 per dollar after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen hinted at rate hikes this year. This marks the biggest weekly loss in 4 years, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) also down 2.7% for the week. Foreigners sold 300.7 billion won of shares, extending a five-day selling streak, amid concerns about the won's sharp fall.

site_title: Pink diamond expected to fetch up to US$28m at Geneva auction
summary: A 16.08-carat pink diamond, classified as a Type IIa diamond and considered "vivid pink" under Gemological Institute of America guidelines, is expected to fetch up to $28 million at Christie's Geneva auction on November 10. The stone is set as a ring and surrounded by white diamonds. This is one of only three "vivid pink" diamonds of over 10 carats to be sold in 250 years, surpassing the world record for a pink diamond sold in 2010 for $46 million.

site_title: Indonesia's Q4 GDP growth seen at above 5%: BI official
summary: Indonesia's economy is expected to grow above 5% in the fourth quarter, according to Bank Indonesia's executive director Juda Agung. This would bring the annual GDP growth pace to 4.9%. The economy rebounded from a 4.67% growth in the second quarter, the lowest pace since 2009. A month-on-month inflation rate of 0.06% is also expected in September.

site_title: Engine defect prompts Cathay flight to divert to Bali
summary: A Cathay Pacific flight carrying 251 passengers from Australia to Hong Kong made an emergency landing in Bali after an engine defect was reported. The plane, an Airbus A330, experienced a loud bang and shook violently before landing safely. Passengers reported seeing flames and sparks on the wing, but no fire was found onboard. All passengers and crew are safe and unharmed. The incident is under investigation by Cathay Pacific, and the aircraft is being repaired at Bali airport.

site_title: Australian Exchange opens Hong Kong office as ties to Asia grow
summary: ASX Ltd, Australia's main equities exchange, is opening an office in Hong Kong to strengthen ties with Asia. The new office will be headed by James Keeley, with direct access to Sydney markets, offering faster and cheaper access. This move aims to deliver a more timely and competitive service to Asian customers, as the region is the world's fastest-growing economic area. ASX has already established connections with Singapore, London, and Chicago, and has started a yuan settlement service with Bank of China.

site_title: Sharp drops to record low after saying it will miss profit goal
summary: Sharp Corp shares plummeted to a record low of 139 yen after the electronics maker said it will miss its first-half operating profit forecast, falling short of 10 billion yen. The company expects a 30 billion yen operating loss for the six months ending Sept 30 and has no plans to change its full-year outlook. Sharp's shares have slumped 45% this year, with the company considering selling a stake in its LCD operation to Foxconn Technology Group.

site_title: Japan sports minister submits resignation over Olympic stadium
summary: Japan's sports minister Hakubun Shimomura has submitted his resignation over the cancellation of plans for the Tokyo 2020 Olympics centrepiece stadium due to a cost blowout. Shimomura, a close ally of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, will return half his pay for six months in atonement. He cited his resignation as a response to the "great worry and trouble" he caused over the national stadium issue. Abe had asked Shimomura to stay on until a cabinet reshuffle planned for next month.

site_title: Starbucks to raise wages for UK employees: FT
summary: Starbucks has announced it will raise the average wage for its UK staff to nearly £8 ($17.4) an hour from November, regardless of age. This move comes after British Finance Minister George Osborne introduced a new National Living Wage of £7.20 per hour for workers aged 25 and above in April. The decision also includes offering interest-free loans to help staff pay housing deposits. This follows Lidl's recent announcement to increase pay for thousands of staff in Britain by at least 12%.

images.alt_text: Starbucks Corp, the world's biggest coffee chain, promised to raise the average wage for its UK staff to just under 8 pounds (S$17.4) an hour from November regardless of age, the Financial Times reported.

site_title: China central banker calls for more reforms now, warns of cost of delay
summary: China's central banker, Sheng Songcheng, has called for more financial reforms to be implemented now, warning that delaying these reforms will increase costs. Songcheng stated that recent market volatility is not due to China's capital account opening, but rather the country remains attractive to long-term foreign capital. China can fully liberalize domestic interest rates, as financial institutions have learned to manage risk. The central banker emphasized that China has leeway to adjust economic policy, including further reform to the foreign exchange market.

images.alt_text: The headquarters of China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, is pictured behind an iron chain in Beijing, in this on June 21, 2013 file photograph. China should continue with financial reform now, a senior Chinese central banker said on Friday, warning that costs will increase if reforms are delayed.

site_title: Australia Post reports first annual loss in 30 years
summary: Australia Post reported its first annual loss in 30 years, with an after-tax loss of US$154 million. The decline in letter volumes, mainly due to the shift to digital communication, contributed to the loss. Despite this, parcels revenue grew 3.6% to A$3.21 billion, accounting for more than half of total income. The company is undergoing reform, investing in digital capabilities, and expects to become a more eCommerce-centric organization.

images.alt_text: Australia Post on Friday delivered its first full-year loss in three decades driven by plunging letter volumes in the struggle to enter the digital era.

site_title: More than 700 pilgrims die in crush in worst haj disaster for 25 years
summary: At least 717 pilgrims from around the world died in a crush outside the Muslim holy city of Mecca, Saudi Arabia, on September 24, 2015, in the worst haj disaster for 25 years. The incident occurred when two large groups of pilgrims arrived together at a crossroads in Mina, resulting in a stampede that also injured over 863 others. Saudi authorities have ordered a review of haj plans and King Salman has offered condolences to the families of the victims.

site_title: Singapore's housing sector shifting towards oversupply: BNP
summary: Singapore's housing market is expected to shift towards oversupply from 2016, driven by record-high supply, tight immigration policies, and rising interest rates. Prices are forecast to bottom out in 2018/19, with excess supply peaking in 2020 before easing. Analysts at BNP Paribas predict a milder oversupply cycle compared to the 1997-2006 period, with proactive supply cuts and a neutral outlook on the property sector. The bank has adjusted its target prices for CapitaLand and City Developments, maintaining a "buy" and "hold" call respectively.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

Singapore's housing market could shift towards oversupply from 2016, with prices bottoming out in 2018/19 due to record-high supply, tight immigration policies and rising interest rates that dampen demand, BNP Paribas said in a report.

site_title: Ringgit headed for worst weekly since 1998 as US probes 1MDB
summary: Malaysia's ringgit is on track for its worst weekly decline since 1998 due to US investigations into 1MDB, exacerbating losses driven by a slowdown in China and tumbling commodity prices. The currency weakened 0.9% to 4.3870 against the US dollar, down 4.2% for the week. The US Federal Bureau of Investigation is probing money laundering, while the US Justice Department is looking into property purchases associated with Prime Minister Najib Razak's family. The FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI Index is set for its worst week in over a month.

site_title: MyRepublic raises S$23 million
summary: MyRepublic, a Singaporean broadband provider, has raised S$23 million in capital, with Brunei's DST as a major investor. The investment supports MyRepublic's expansion plans, including a "mobility trial" for mobile services in October. The company aims to achieve 8% market share and become Singapore's fourth mobile operator. MyRepublic has tripled its subscriber base since launching 1Gbps services in 2014, reaching just under 40,000 subscribers. The funding will help the company achieve its developmental goals and gain exposure to a different market environment.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Friday, down 8.89 points to 1604.15. The market saw a 128-75 loser-to-gainer ratio. Volume reached 73.2 million lots worth RM43.3 million.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks edge up at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose slightly in opening trade on Friday, edging up 0.14% to 21,125.1, following a 0.01% fall the previous day. Shanghai's benchmark composite index slipped 0.38%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index lost 0.53%. The gains were due to profit-taking after a strong rally in previous sessions.

site_title: Hong Kong peg to draw support even as Fed raises, says Greenwood
summary: Hong Kong's currency peg is unlikely to be reevaluated despite US interest rate hikes, according to John Greenwood, chief economist at Invesco Asset Management. The peg, which links the Hong Kong dollar to the US dollar, has been in place since 1983 and is expected to remain stable even if China achieves reserve-currency status or opens up its capital markets. Greenwood notes that a 10-15% correction in the asset market due to a strong US dollar or rising interest rates could even be welcomed by the Hong Kong government, as it would help lower-income people acquire property.

site_title: Seoul: Shares and won fall as Yellen keeps rates hike view
summary: Seoul shares fell 0.7% on Friday due to persistent foreign selling, while the South Korean won slipped 0.3% against the dollar after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen stated the US central bank is still on track to raise interest rates this year. Market analysts attributed the decline to uncertainty around the Fed's monetary policy. Heavyweight Samsung Electronics Co Ltd lost 1.1%, while Hyundai Motor Co Ltd gained 2.9% after its vice chairman bought 500 billion won worth of shares. Foreigners were net sellers for a fifth consecutive session.

site_title: Rupiah set for biggest weekly loss since 2013 on growth outlook
summary: The Indonesian rupiah is on track for its biggest weekly loss since 2013, falling 2.1% to 14,690 a dollar, amid a worsening growth outlook for Indonesia and expectations of US interest rate hikes in 2015. Foreign investors have pulled $104 million from Indonesian shares in the past three days, leading to an 11th consecutive week of outflows. The government's growth estimate for 2016 has been cut to 5.3% from 5.5%, and sovereign bonds have fallen, pushing their yield to a 51-basis-point increase.

images.alt_text: The rupiah headed for its steepest weekly drop in almost two years as foreign funds pulled money from stocks amid a worsening growth outlook for Indonesia and signs the US will raise interest rates in 2015.

site_title: China: Stocks fall at open
summary: China's major stock indexes fell in early trade on Friday, with the CSI300 index down 0.3% and the Shanghai Composite Index losing 0.4%. The Hang Seng index in Hong Kong also declined 0.2%. The decline follows a recent rally in the region, with Singapore stocks notching a 5-day gain ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Weak Japanese data weighs on oil markets
summary: Oil markets remained subdued in early trading in Asia after weak Japanese data reinforced concerns over global economic growth. Japan's core consumer prices fell 0.1% in August, the first year-on-year drop since 2013. Global oversupply of oil, estimated at 2.5 million barrels per day, persists despite a slowing North American market. Oil prices fell 10% since the beginning of September, and Brent futures were down four cents at $48.13 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate futures were up four cents at $44.95 per barrel.

site_title: Emas Offshore names Ezra ex-COO as CEO
summary: EMAS Offshore has appointed Adarash Kumar, former chief operating officer, as its new CEO. Kumar stepped down from his roles at Ezra Holdings, the parent company, to focus on the new position. There will be no change to Ezra's board. As of Wednesday, Emas shares traded at 24 Singapore cents, while Ezra shares ended at 12.1 Singapore cents.

site_title: China capital outflows hit record in August on yuan weakness
summary: China experienced a record capital outflow of $141.66 billion in August, surpassing the previous record of $124.62 billion in July, according to a Bloomberg gauge. The outflow was triggered by the devaluation of the yuan on August 11, which led to a worldwide drop in commodities and emerging-market currencies. The People's Bank of China is working to enhance capital controls, while Chinese investors are seeking to diversify in overseas assets. Experts warn that the capital outflow could lead to depreciation pressure and further economic downward pressure.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise after cbank cuts rate; T$ jumps
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.3% to 8,147.66 on Friday after the central bank cut its benchmark interest rate for the first time since 2009, citing a slowdown in the global economy. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$33.009 per US dollar. The electronics subindex rose 0.25%, while the financials subindex fell 0.5%.

site_title: Branson outlines world powered by wind, solar power
summary: Richard Branson outlined a vision of a world powered by renewable energy, calling for an end to subsidies for dirty fuels and a carbon tax. He expressed concern that the UN climate summit in Paris may not be successful, stating it would be "pretty dreadful" if not. Branson proposed a global carbon tax, with revenue going into a big innovation pot, and predicted a world powered by solar and wind energy by 2050, benefiting hospitals, schools, and the majority of the world. He believes this shift will pull people out of poverty and be a "really exciting world to aim for."

site_title: Nasdaq incubator opens to Silicon Valley startups
summary: The Nasdaq Entrepreneurial Center, a 13,000 square foot facility, has opened in San Francisco to strengthen ties between Silicon Valley startups and the electronic exchange. The center offers free education and training, mentorship programs, and a hub for entrepreneurs to learn and connect with experts. The launch coincides with Nasdaq's 25th anniversary in the Bay Area and aims to help the exchange become the preferred platform for hot startups to go public. The center is part of Nasdaq's efforts to compete with the New York Stock Exchange and regain its reputation after a technical issue in 2012.

site_title: Australia: Shares turn lower as Fed uncertainty, growth woes hurt
summary: Australian shares fell 0.4% on Friday, weighed down by uncertainty over US Federal Reserve interest rate hikes and concerns over China's growth. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,052.1, down 2.3% for the week, after two consecutive weekly gains. Banks and energy-related shares declined, while consumer staples and discretionary shares rose. The decline was led by Commonwealth Bank of Australia and Westpac, which fell over 1% each, and Origin Energy and Karoon Gas, which dropped 1.8% and 2.2% respectively.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open 0.26% higher after Yellen speech
summary: Tokyo shares opened 0.26% higher on Friday after US Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen said she expects to hike interest rates this year, recovering losses from a day earlier. The Nikkei 225 index rose 46.47 points to 17,618.30.

site_title: Netflix set to make more shows of its own, including Handler
summary: Netflix plans to produce more original content in-house, including Chelsea Handler's new talk show, to control global distribution and reduce reliance on external studios. The move may expose the company to new financial risks but could speed up its uniform global service. Netflix has leased a 200,000-square-foot space in Hollywood to design and produce shows, and will continue to partner with studios for larger series. The shift could impact what's available on streaming services, as major media companies like 21st Century Fox and Time Warner reevaluate their relationships with Netflix.

images.alt_text: Netflix plans to make its "Originals" more original by shooting several new shows itself, instead of relying on outside studios.

site_title: China's Xi arrives in Washington for first US state visit
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping arrived in Washington for a state visit, sparking concerns over alleged cyber spying, economic policies, and territorial disputes in the South China Sea. Xi sought to reassure US companies about China's investment climate, while President Barack Obama plans to discuss these issues with him. A private working dinner and full honors, including a 21-gun salute, are planned for Xi's visit. No policy breakthroughs are expected, but modest achievements may be announced, such as climate change commitments and cyber security agreements.

site_title: Deutsche Bank must face US$190m US tax fraud case
summary: A US federal judge has ruled that Deutsche Bank must face a $190 million tax fraud lawsuit, rejecting the bank's request to dismiss the case. The lawsuit, filed in 2014, alleges that Deutsche Bank used shell companies to avoid capital gains taxes on Bristol-Myers Squibb Co shares acquired in 1999. The bank had previously agreed to address the matter with the US Internal Revenue Service in 2009. Deutsche Bank plans to continue defending itself against the allegations.

site_title: Half of UK firms struggle to invest to improve productivity: CIPD
summary: Half of UK firms struggle to invest in staff and new technology to boost productivity, according to the Chartered Institute of Personnel Development. Around 20% of businesses operate in "survival mode" and 29% have failed to balance investment in people or technology. This comes as the government plans to raise the hourly minimum wage to £9 by 2020, which could impact businesses in the hospitality, retail, and social care sectors. The UK's weak productivity performance could also affect worker earnings.

site_title: Obama, Tsipras discuss refugee crisis, economy in phone call
summary: US President Barack Obama and newly re-elected Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras discussed the refugee crisis and Greece's economy in a phone call. The two leaders expressed hope that Greece's economy would stabilize and return to growth. Tsipras, who won a convincing election victory, is set to push through a controversial bailout deal with international creditors. The conversation comes as Greece struggles to cope with a huge influx of migrants and refugees, while Obama also accepted an invitation to meet with Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin to discuss the Syrian conflict.

site_title: US: Wall St ends lower as Caterpillar, health stocks weigh
summary: US stocks closed lower on Thursday due to uncertainty over US monetary policy and global economic growth. Caterpillar cut its sales forecast, leading to a 6.3% decline in its stock price, while healthcare investors fled due to concerns over price gouging by drug companies. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.48%, the S&P 500 lost 0.34%, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.38%. The market is expected to retest its August lows, with investors awaiting a speech by Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen.

site_title: Nike sprints ahead as high-margin products sales rise
summary: Nike reported a 23% increase in net income to $1.18 billion, or $1.34 per share, for its first quarter, beating analyst expectations. The company's gross margins rose 90 basis points to 47.5% due to increased sales of high-margin products and a strong direct-to-consumer channel. Nike's "futures orders" growth, excluding currency changes, rose 17% and 27% in China, surpassing analyst estimates. The company's sales in its largest market, North America, rose 8%, driven by a 9% increase in footwear sales.

images.alt_text: Nike reported a better-than-expected profit for the ninth straight quarter as the world's largest sportswear maker sold more products at higher prices and benefited from increased sales in its owned stores and internet business.

site_title: German government boosts funding to states for refugees
summary: Germany's government has agreed to provide 4 billion euros in funding to its 16 states to help cope with the record influx of refugees. The funding, announced by Chancellor Angela Merkel, includes 670 euros per month for each asylum seeker taken in. This brings the total to around 4 billion euros, including extra payments for social housing and care for unaccompanied young refugees. The funding aims to support the states in caring for 800,000 asylum seekers this year.

site_title: Asian stocks advance after Yellen points to 2015 rate increase
summary: Asian stocks rose after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen hinted at a possible interest rate hike this year, citing a track record of economic growth. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index gained 0.2% as Yellen stated that the Fed would raise rates if the economy surprises them, providing a "reasonably comforting" framework. Japan's Topix index added 1.1%, while New Zealand and Australia also saw gains, despite slower demand from China and a decline in commodity prices.

site_title: Fed chief Yellen treated for 'dehydration'
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen, 69, was treated for dehydration after a lengthy speech at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst. She coughed and stopped herself at times, prompting EMT staff on-site to assess her condition. Yellen felt fine after treatment and continued with her schedule. Despite the interruption, she maintained that the US economy is "solid" and expects interest rate increases in 2015.

images.alt_text: US Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen was treated for dehydration at the end of a lengthy speech on Thursday, but was later able to resume her normal schedule, a bank spokesman said.

site_title: Australia checking if Volkswagen emissions claims misled consumers
summary: Australia's competition regulator is investigating whether Volkswagen misled consumers over emissions claims following the German carmaker's admission of cheating on US pollution tests. The ACCC is looking into how Volkswagen made representations on emissions and considering consumer rights under the Australian Consumer Law. Volkswagen Australia is awaiting guidance from its head office on the matter. The scandal affects 11 million vehicles worldwide fitted with software to reduce apparent emissions from diesel engines.

images.alt_text: Australia's competition regulator said on Friday it was looking into whether Volkswagen had misled consumers over its emissions claims after the German carmaker admitted cheating on US pollution tests.

site_title: TMC fails to get reserve price at auction of Peninsula Plaza lots, to try again in October
summary: TMC Education Corp failed to meet its reserve price in the Sept 22 auction of two Peninsula Plaza lots, which comprise 10 units and have 813 years left on their leases. The lots were valued at S$5.62 million. TMC will hold another auction on Oct 22. The company's shares were last bid at 8.1 Singapore cents.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.7% down
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.7% lower on Friday, with the Straits Times Index down 19.5 points to 2,826.24, amid expectations of a US Federal Reserve rate hike this year. Banks, particularly DBS Group Holdings and OCBC Bank, contributed to the decline. Losers outnumbered gainers 82 to 70, with Medtecs International being a notable exception, jumping 15.1% after 5.9 million shares changed hands.

site_title: Japan's CPI falls as oil rout overpowers Kuroda
summary: Japan's main inflation gauge fell into negative territory for the first time since April 2013, with consumer prices excluding fresh food dropping 0.1% in August from a year earlier. Weak domestic demand and plunging oil prices are hindering the Bank of Japan's reflation campaign led by Governor Haruhiko Kuroda. Economists expect the central bank to add stimulus in October, with a third of economists forecasting a policy change. The yen fell 0.1% to $120.24, while the break-even rate suggests prices will rise 0.84% annually over the next 10 years, down from 1.1% in May.

site_title: Fed still on track for US rate hike this year, Yellen says
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen said she expects the US central bank to raise interest rates later this year if inflation remains stable and the economy is strong enough to boost employment. Yellen stated that recent inflationary weakness is likely transitory and will allow US inflation to rise to a 2% goal over the next few years. She anticipates an initial rate hike later this year, followed by a gradual pace of tightening, citing solid US economic prospects and a preference for a timely and gradual approach to rate hikes.

site_title: Samsung says technology trumps competition in chip market goal
summary: Samsung Electronics aims to expand its logic chip business to increase its market share, prioritizing external customers over internal divisions. The company plans to sell more chips to other companies, with a new 1 million square-foot research-and-design center in California to attract engineering talent. Despite declining sales in its mobile phone business, Samsung's chip division has seen increased sales and profitability, driven by the company's dominance in the memory chip market. This expansion aims to bolster Samsung's position as the world's second-largest chip producer, behind Intel Corp.

site_title: French economy minister says needs to understand UK's EU reforms
summary: French Economy Minister Emmanuel Macron expressed willingness to help the UK seek EU reforms before its 2017 referendum on membership. Macron met with Prime Minister David Cameron and finance minister George Osborne, sharing ideas on cutting red tape and regulation. However, Macron remained unsure about key British proposals, particularly regarding the EU's euro zone and non-euro zone countries. He emphasized the need for a better-integrated single market and a federal euro zone, warning that a Brexit would be "the defeat of solidarity."

site_title: Bank of Singapore sees small Asia wealth managers under pressure
summary: Bank of Singapore, a private banking arm of Southeast Asia's second-largest lender, expects further consolidation in the Asian wealth management sector due to the growing demand for global products from Asia's rich. Only large banks offering a range of services are likely to prosper, according to Bank of Singapore's CEO. Wealth managers with less than $20 billion under management may struggle to sustain their operations, and the industry is also experiencing consolidation in Europe. Bank of Singapore remains open to further acquisitions, with its total assets under management reaching $54 billion in June.

site_title: Highlights of fifth Singapore Construction Productivity Week
summary: The fifth Singapore Construction Productivity Week (SCPW) will be held from October 13 to 16 at the Singapore Expo Max Atria and Hall 3. The event will feature technology solutions to transform the built environment sector and improve productivity, in collaboration with the Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore (IDA). The annual event aims to attract over 6,000 industry practitioners and academics worldwide to share and learn about advanced construction technologies and trends in construction productivity.

site_title: Winners from diverse industries share the same gung-ho spirit
summary: Three companies - Hope First Response, ZWEEC, and GD Group - won top honors at the 2015 Emerging Enterprise Awards (EE 2015) in Singapore. Hope First Response, a provider of emergency medical response services, received the top award for entrepreneurial daring. ZWEEC Analytics took home the Best Innovation Award for its patented surveillance and water security solutions. GD Group, a Penang food restaurant chain, also received top honors for its innovative business practices. The award recognizes young enterprises with annual sales turnover of not more than S$15 million, and the winners each received S$490,000 in prizes.

site_title: US dollar gains as Yellen eyes rate hike by year's end
summary: US dollar gains after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen hints at rate hike by year's end. Yellen stated that the economy's improvements will likely lead to a federal funds rate increase later this year, followed by gradual tightening. The dollar rallied against the euro, yen, Swiss franc, and British pound. This move is seen as a positive sign for the US currency, with some analysts believing it indicates the Fed will raise rates in 2015.

site_title: (No headline) - DTPICK25
summary: The '70s-themed musical 'Saturday Night Fever The Musical' is coming to Singapore for the first time, based on the classic 1977 film. The show features Broadway actor Brandon Rubendall as Tony Manero, a Brooklyn hipster, and promises slick choreography and Bee Gees hits. The musical runs at Mastercard Theatres from September 25 to October 4, with showtimes and ticket prices available.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Commodity super-cycle isn't dead, it's just a correction, says Westpac
summary: Westpac Banking Corp says the commodity super-cycle isn't dead, but rather experiencing a correction. A glut in commodities may take 12-24 months to clear due to lower energy prices, which are reducing costs and shipping rates. This will enable producers to export to China on aggressive terms, paving the way for a rebound in prices.

site_title: Transforming construction through technology
summary: Construction firms in Singapore are adopting technology to improve efficiency and productivity without compromising on quality and safety. A Biometric Authentication System uses facial recognition to track man-hours spent onsite, while a Construction Management System automates data collection and processing. IoT technology is used to monitor construction sites for dust, noise, and water leaks. Additionally, a mobile tool called iSafe automates safety processes, and drone technology is used for site inspections. These solutions aim to boost productivity, reduce costs, and enhance workplace safety.

site_title: Report faults UK govt's land sales scheme
summary: The UK government's land sales scheme has been criticized by the Public Accounts Committee, accusing the government of "wishful thinking" and failing to provide adequate proof that sales have met its housebuilding targets. The committee found that the Department for Communities and Local Government did not record the number of properties built or under construction, or the sale proceeds. The report calls for a more rigorous approach to land disposal and demands better value for taxpayers. The government's failure has been described as "embarrassing" by opposition lawmaker Meg Hillier.

site_title: The weakened Fed is increasingly friendless
summary: The US Federal Reserve faces intense criticism and scrutiny, having become increasingly "friendless" due to its inability to stimulate economic growth. Despite keeping interest rates near zero and pouring $4 trillion into the economy through quantitative easing, the recovery has been slow. Critics, including some economists and politicians, blame the Fed for the sluggish growth, calling for reforms to its policies. However, former Fed chairman Ben Bernanke argues that the Fed's powers are limited and that the economy's problems are more complex than Fed policy can solve, making the Fed's reputation and autonomy increasingly vulnerable.

site_title: Why Americans are spending more on rent
summary: The US affordable housing crisis worsens as nearly half of all renters spend more than 30% of their income on housing, up from less than a quarter in 1960. A new report predicts nearly 15 million households will be "severely cost-burdened" by 2025, up from 11.2 million today. Rents have outpaced inflation for decades, while incomes have stagnated, creating a "perfect storm" that is unsustainable, according to experts.

site_title: Embarking on yet another musical adventure
summary: The Observatory, a veteran local indie band, released its seventh album "Continuum" in July 2015, featuring a unique blend of Balinese rhythms and Western influences. The album was recorded over four years, with founding members Leslie Low and Vivian Wang working on the project before the band's lineup changes. To perform the album live, 11 musicians joined the band, making it a reunion of sorts for some members. The album's release was seen as an ambitious project, with the band continuing to evolve and explore new sounds.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Exploring the moon through songs
summary: Chanticleer, a 38-year-old a cappella ensemble, will perform on October 4 with a new program titled "Over the Moon" featuring songs based on Pierrot Lunaire poems and popular American songs. The group, known for its classy sound and large vocal range, has 12 male members aged 25-48, with a focus on maintaining a youthful sound despite the physical demands of their schedule. Music director William Fred Scott aims to balance the ensemble's vocal demands with a cohesive and beautiful performance.

site_title: Citigroup warns bulls to brace for more losses
summary: Citigroup analysts warn bulls to brace for more losses in commodities due to excess supplies and a sluggish world economy. The bank is bearish on crude oil, aluminium, platinum, iron ore, cocoa, and wheat for the next three to six months. Inventories are climbing while demand growth slows in China, leading to returns near a 16-year low. Other banks, including Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley, also forecast further declines in raw materials, with the Bloomberg Commodity Index tumbling 15% since June 30.

site_title: Artificial intelligence system passes SAT math test with average score
summary: An AI system developed by the Allen Institute for Artificial Intelligence and the University of Washington achieved a 49% accuracy score on the SAT math test, comparable to a high school senior's average score of 513 points. This marks a significant milestone in the development of autonomous, intelligent computers. The AI system's performance demonstrates its potential to approach human-level intelligence in specific areas, such as math.

site_title: Small-scale LNG taking off in Indonesia
summary: Indonesia's state-run utility PLN has shortlisted 11 companies, including Shell, to develop small-scale liquefied natural gas (LNG) projects across the country. The projects aim to supply LNG to power plants planned under President Joko Widodo's 35,000 megawatt electrification program. The 11 shortlisted companies are expected to team up or partner with other players to meet Indonesia's massive LNG demand. The projects are crucial to Indonesia's goal of delivering 35,000 MW of electricity by 2019, with small-scale LNG expected to fuel dozens of power plants.

site_title: Traditional remedies cool China's vitamin fever
summary: China's traditional medicine sector is rapidly growing, expected to reach $40 billion by 2019, surpassing the vitamins market's $20 billion in 2019. Firms like Amway and Pfizer are incorporating traditional ingredients into their products to tap into the market. Traditional remedies are used for various ailments, from low energy to cancer, and are often more expensive than Western-style vitamins, with shoppers willing to pay thousands of yuan for natural ingredients. The industry's growth is driven by rising disposable incomes, health awareness, and supportive government policies.

images.alt_text: Vitamins firms are looking for inspiration from traditional medicine recipes going back thousands of years to succeed in China's increasingly pivotal healthcare market.
Vitamins firms are looking for inspiration from traditional medicine recipes going back thousands of years to succeed in China's increasingly pivotal healthcare market.

site_title: Over 700 pilgrims die in Saudi haj stampede
summary: At least 717 pilgrims died in a stampede at Mina, Saudi Arabia, on Thursday during the annual haj pilgrimage, with over 800 injured. The Saudi health minister blamed undisciplined pilgrims for the tragedy, citing a lack of respect for established timetables. This is the deadliest incident at the haj in nearly a decade, following previous stampedes and disasters in 2006. The government has faced criticism for its handling of safety during the pilgrimage, with efforts to improve crowd control technology and infrastructure in recent years.

site_title: VW needs an outsider to fix it
summary: Volkswagen needs a new chairman to oversee an investigation into the emissions cheating scandal and a reorganisation of the company. Hans Dieter Poetsch, the long-term finance chief, is not a suitable choice due to his ties to the company and lack of experience in crisis management. A more fitting replacement would have a clean record, experience in crisis management, and the ability to deal diplomatically with US regulators and judges. Candidates such as Wolfgang Reitzle, Heinrich Hiesinger, or Matthias Wissmann could be suitable alternatives, offering a fresh start for the company.

site_title: New York builders may have to keep 25% of homes for low-income residents
summary: New York City is set to implement mandatory inclusionary housing, requiring developers to set aside at least 25% of their units for lower-income residents in select areas. The policy, part of Mayor Bill de Blasio's goal to add 80,000 new affordable units by 2024, will first be applied to East New York in Brooklyn. The proposal has sparked both support and opposition, with some residents and advocacy groups expressing concerns about affordability and racial impact. The city plans to give developers several options for meeting the requirement, including setting aside affordable units for households earning 60% or 80% of the area's median income.

site_title: PBOC increases cash injections before holiday as repurchase rate rises
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), increased cash injections by 80 billion yuan (S$18 billion) before the National Day holiday, with the seven-day repurchase rate rising 12 basis points to 2.46%. This move aims to meet increased cash demand before the holiday. The PBOC also lowered its economic expansion target to between 6.5% and 7% for 2016, citing a contracting manufacturing sector.

site_title: China's fake Apple stores thrive ahead of new iPhone launch
summary: In China's Shenzhen, over 30 fake Apple stores have popped up ahead of the new iPhone 6S and 6s Plus release, selling genuine Apple products at double the official price. The stores are operated by individuals buying iPhones from authorized channels and reselling them in China. The fake stores have become a lucrative business, with some vendors even offering services like logos, uniforms, and display shelves to create an authentic Apple experience. Despite Apple's efforts to manage its brand, the proliferation of fake stores poses risks to the company's long-term plans.

site_title: Tencent M&A chief leaving firm, sources say
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd's mergers and acquisitions chief, Richard Peng Zhijian, is leaving the company to start his own investment fund. During his seven-year tenure, Peng drove the company's participation in $19 billion worth of deals, transforming Tencent into a business spanning social media, gaming, and online commerce. He was instrumental in backing companies such as Didi Dache and Riot Games, and helped Tencent become the most acquisitive Chinese company under his leadership. Peng's departure comes at a time when Tencent's shares declined 1.1% in Hong Kong.

site_title: Manhattan oasis, senior housing vie for space
summary: The Elizabeth Street Garden in Manhattan is facing a potential demolition to build subsidized senior housing. The garden, a tranquil oasis in a hard-edge part of the city, has been a source of contention between advocates for open space and those pushing for affordable housing for older adults. The city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development has applied for a $6 million grant to build a seven-story building with 60-75 apartments on the garden's half-acre site. Neighbors and local officials are opposed to the plan, citing the garden's value as a community green space.

images.alt_text: By recruiting volunteers to keep watch at the garden's entrance, Friends of Elizabeth Street Garden has managed to open the space to the public on a regular basis for the first time.

site_title: Ringside seat to view nature's brutal beauty
summary: The article discusses the 1996 ill-fated expedition to conquer Mount Everest, which inspired the film "Everest." The documentary-style film retells the tragic story, focusing on the devastating power of nature and the madness that drives adventurers to climb mountains despite the inherent dangers. The article concludes that the urge to achieve something extraordinary supersedes all else, and the film invites viewers to draw their own conclusions about the tragedy that occurred.

images.alt_text: As the pressure builds, Rob Hall (Jason Clarke) scrambles to maintain control of the climb

site_title: A Singapore moment in New York
summary: Singapore is showcasing its cultural and creative side in New York City, part of a larger effort called Singapore: Inside Out. The exhibition features 20 popular food establishments serving Singapore-inspired dishes, including lobster laksa and chilli prawns, during the Singapore Restaurant Week. The event is accompanied by a showcase of art, design, and fashion, attracting over 20,000 visitors in Beijing and London. The goal is to promote Singapore as a cultural and creative force beyond its financial hub reputation, and to "own" its soft power, according to the Singapore Tourism Board.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: BOE will watch balance of payments risk from EU vote: top official
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) will monitor the potential impact of the UK's European Union membership referendum on its current account deficit. Deputy Governor Ben Broadbent stated that the referendum created uncertainty, which could make it harder for the country to finance its deficit.

site_title: Why the Fed buried monetarism
summary: The US Federal Reserve's decision not to raise interest rates was met with surprise due to Chair Janet Yellen's apparent complacency about inflation risks. The Fed's statement revealed it is unconcerned about inflation and eager to push unemployment below its "natural" rate of 5%. This stance reflects a shift away from the monetarist theory, which posits that inflation accelerates without limit when unemployment falls below a certain level. Instead, the Fed appears to be returning to pre-monetarist views, acknowledging trade-offs between inflation and unemployment are real and can last for many years.

site_title: 3 KLW directors on chopping block at EGM
summary: KLW Holdings, a Singapore-based door maker, is set for a potential boardroom refresh after new controlling shareholder Quek Chek Lan requisitions an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on October 12 to vote on removing three directors and appointing four new ones. The move comes after Quek declared his intention to oust the directors earlier. The EGM will be held to address the company's ongoing struggles.

site_title: VW customers, dealers seek speedy action on emissions scandal
summary: Volkswagen faces pressure to recall and refit models rigged to pass US emissions tests, with the German consumer body urging the company to indemnify affected consumers. The automaker has set aside 6.5 billion euros to cover costs, and 11 million cars worldwide may be affected. Dealers and consumer protection bodies stress the need for swift action to regain customer confidence. The scandal has led to the resignation of CEO Martin Winterkorn, who took responsibility for the emissions cheating scandal.

site_title: ECB faces defiance on bank oversight as Germany hoards powers
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is facing resistance from euro-area governments, particularly Germany, over bank oversight. A German bill would limit the ECB's supervisory powers, allowing the Finance Ministry to issue rules on banks' recovery plans and risk management. The ECB may file a complaint to the European Commission, citing that national regulations divert attention from its main task of ensuring safe and sound European banks. This is the latest challenge to the ECB's authority, with similar issues raised by Italy's Fabio Panetta and ECB head Daniele Nouy.

site_title: Xi vows easier China-US trade at US$3t summit
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping vowed to push ahead with reforms to expand trade ties with the US during a meeting with 30 corporate leaders representing $3 trillion in market value. He assured business leaders that China's economy fundamentals are sound, despite slowing growth and a slumping stock market. Xi also expressed support for a Sino-US digital cooperation plan, following a meeting with US tech companies and a tour of a Boeing factory in Washington. The meeting aimed to bridge differences on two-way investment and ease concerns on disputes such as cybersecurity.

site_title: Abe's doggedness on hawkish new security laws could be his undoing
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has pushed through new security laws, diluting the country's post-war "pacifist" Constitution, despite 60% of the population opposing them. The laws allow Japan's Self-Defense Forces to engage in collective self-defense and provide logistic support for UN-authorised military operations. Abe's determination to pass the legislation has sparked widespread protests, with tens of thousands turning out to rally against the changes. The move has raised concerns about Abe's popularity and potential impact on his re-election bid in 2016, with many fearing the changes could lead to future conflict.

site_title: RBS to axe 100 jobs as part of investment bank revamp
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) plans to eliminate approximately 100 jobs as part of a restructuring of its investment bank, codenamed "Project Brick". Senior figures such as Richard Bartlett and Eric Capp will be departing, while Scott Satriano will lead the reorganized unit. The move is part of RBS CEO Ross McEwan's efforts to reduce the bank's investment bank operations and cut costs, with the goal of making the bank more sustainable.

images.alt_text: RBS's reorganisation, codenamed "Project Brick", is part of the bank's attempts to simplify the structure of its corporate and institutional banking division to better serve its corporate and financial institutional customers.

site_title: Thailand plans measures to help property sector: minister
summary: Thailand plans to finalize measures to help the property sector within two weeks, aiming to boost demand and alleviate the impact of sluggish sales due to economic growth falters. The government will provide loans via its housing bank to home buyers who cannot get mortgage loans from commercial banks, and also finalize property tax this year. The measures are expected to help developers, with one developer planning to launch only six projects this year compared to a target of 10-12 projects. The government hopes to announce the measures quickly to stimulate the property sector.

site_title: Megaships worsening glut in container market
summary: Container shipping lines are set to receive new megaships with capacities over 18,000 TEU, exacerbating the glut in the market. The industry's shift to larger vessels has increased capacity by 90% since 1996, while freight volumes have slowed, creating a massive overhang. The new generation of megaships will further reduce fuel costs and lower emissions, but may contribute to unsustainable overcapacity and impose costs on other businesses. Economies of scale depend on megaships being loaded close to maximum capacity, and the industry is consolidating into an alliance network to ensure efficient operations.

site_title: VW saga may end platinum's edge over palladium
summary: Volkswagen's car emissions scandal threatens to disrupt the platinum market, potentially ending platinum's price dominance over palladium. The US accused the German firm of using software to deceive regulators, leading to a 6-1/2 year low in platinum prices. If the scandal affects European diesel cars, which account for 45% of sales, it could lead to falling demand for platinum, potentially pushing prices to parity with palladium. Platinum prices have fallen to $925.30 an ounce, while palladium trades at $640 an ounce.

site_title: Private memorial service for Lee Kuan Yew in New York
summary: Lee Kuan Yew, Singapore's founding father, held a private memorial service in New York City, where he was unable to attend due to pressing matters in Singapore. The service, titled "A Celebration of His Life and Legacy," was organized by former US Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin and Ray Dalio, and attended by former US Secretary of State Henry Kissinger and former US Ambassador to Singapore Jon Huntsman. In a message read by Singapore's Ambassador to the US, Ashok Kumar Mirpuri, Lee Kuan Yew recalled his first official visit to the US in 1967, where he was warmly received by President Lyndon Johnson and his wife, and later maintained a strong relationship with the US throughout his life.

images.alt_text: The memorial service for the former prime minister and a founding father of Singapore, titled A Celebration of His Life and Legacy, was initiated and organised by former US Treasury secretary Robert Rubin and Ray Dalio, a US hedge fund manager and founder of investment firm Bridgewater Associates.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Hutchison Port Holdings Trust (BT) is recommended to buy with a target price of US$0.62. The article does not provide further details on the company's performance or market trends.

site_title: Companies should have action plans to defend against short-seller attacks
summary: Companies should develop action plans to defend against short-seller attacks, as regulations and disclosure frameworks can only do so much to mitigate the impact. The Singapore Exchange's circuit breakers and mandatory disclosure of short-selling positions can provide some stability. However, intraday short-selling attacks can be difficult to defend against, and companies can only hope to limit the damage. Effective action plans are crucial to protect share prices and maintain investor confidence.

site_title: City buzz
summary: A Relais & Chateaux Evening with Grand Chefs Emmanuel Stroobant and Philippe Vetele will take place at Saint Pierre restaurant in Singapore. The dinner features an eight-course menu with four courses each prepared by the two chefs, with prices ranging from S$188++ to S$398++ per person. Meanwhile, Cook & Brew is hosting Saturday Night Roasts, offering live carving stations and an assortment of side dishes. The $100Gourmet series is also ongoing, featuring a visiting guest chef and a local chef for a three-course meal at S$100++. Additionally, Projek Suitcase showcases eight original Malay theatre monologues, while Saturday Night Fever The Musical brings the '70s to Singapore with a disco-themed show.

site_title: BioMed Realty Trust exploring sale: sources
summary: BioMed Realty Trust, a US-based real estate investment trust, is exploring a potential sale with interest from firms like Blackstone Group LP. The San Diego-based company, valued at $3.9 billion, is working with Morgan Stanley on a deal. BioMed controls $8 billion in laboratory properties, benefiting from the growth of healthcare spending and increasing demand for lab space. The sale would mark a significant move for the company, which has seen its shares decline 6.8% in the year. Talks are ongoing, but no guarantee of a deal exists.

site_title: Modi eyes Silicon Valley on US trip amid fading euphoria
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's trip to Silicon Valley has been marred by stalled deals and slow reforms. Despite being welcomed by tech giants like Apple, Facebook, and Google, Modi's reputation as a man of action has been hurt by setbacks. The US has complained about barriers to trade and disputes over copyrights and patents, and optimism among Indian companies has been dented. Modi will focus on solar power and start-ups, but progress on economic reform remains slow, with a $2.5 billion helicopter deal with Boeing being years in the making.
