summary: A US$2.6 trillion campaign to divest from fossil fuels has gained momentum, with 436 institutions and 2,040 people pledging to abandon the energy source to combat climate change. The divestment movement, led by US activists, has seen a 50-fold increase from last year, with notable pledges from institutions like the University of California System and the Norway Pension Fund. The divestment is expected to impact at least US$78 billion in fossil fuel exposure. Climate experts warn that unchecked global warming will lead to severe disasters, and the shift to cleaner energy is seen as a necessary business choice.

site_title: Weak Aussie dollar lures foreign firms seeking M&A deals
summary: Foreign firms are taking advantage of the weak Australian dollar to acquire Australian companies, with a 23% increase in inbound deals by value in 2015 compared to last year. The average value of these deals is the highest on record at $127 million. Deals include a $1.6 billion bid by US credit agency Equifax for Veda Group and a $6.5 billion acquisition by Japan Post Holdings for Toll Holdings. The decline in the Aussie dollar has made valuations reasonable, with the currency down 13% this year.

site_title: Citi, EZ-Link launch corporate ERP payment solution
summary: CitiBank Singapore has partnered with EZ-Link to offer EZ-Reload Corporate Service, a business-to-business solution that automatically tops up EPS and ERP parking fees for commercial card customers. The service allows up to 1,000 EZ-Link cards to be linked to a Citibank Commercial Card account, eliminating unwarranted spending and providing detailed usage reports for account reconciliation. The administrative fees for top-ups will be waived starting from November 1, 2015, offering greater convenience, cost savings, and ease to companies managing their corporate fleet.

site_title: Volkswagen faces US criminal probe on cheating scandal: source
summary: The US Justice Department's environment and natural resources division is leading a criminal investigation into Volkswagen, following the company's admission of cheating on emissions tests in nearly 500,000 US cars. The investigation is part of a broader probe by the EPA and California Air Resources Board, which could result in fines of up to $18 billion. New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman has also launched an investigation, calling for companies to adhere to environmental laws. A hearing on the emissions scandal is set to be held in Congress.

site_title: Rowsley to turn Iskandar project into healthcare cluster
summary: Rowsley, a real-estate vehicle of billionaire Peter Lim, has decided to turn its delayed mega Vantage Bay project in Johor into a healthcare cluster worth RM5 billion (S$1.82 billion). The project will include a specialist hospital, community hospital, long-term care facilities, and medical suites. The development will be funded through internal funds and bank financing, with potential equity fund-raising also considered. The project's components are split among medical, education, and wellness facilities, with the medical component expected to be ready in 2018.

site_title: Trade body warns of failure to reach EU-US deal on derivatives
summary: The European Union and US regulators are at risk of failing to reach a deal on derivatives rules, which could lead to "catastrophic" attempts by market users to withdraw from American clearing houses. The global derivatives market is worth $630 trillion and would face significant costs and fragmentation if a deal is not reached. Industry officials, including Eric Litvack of the International Swaps and Derivatives Association, have warned that a failure to agree on rules could have severe consequences for the market. Talks are ongoing, but a deal is yet to be finalized.

site_title: Nissan CEO says it would be hard to hide any effort to falsify emissions data
summary: Nissan CEO Carlos Ghosn says it's difficult to hide efforts to falsify vehicle emissions data, citing Volkswagen's recent scandal. Ghosn believes a large number of people within a company would likely know about such an effort, making it hard to conceal. The Volkswagen scandal raises "trust" issues for global automakers, prompting Ghosn to call for the industry to be "extremely open." The incident has sparked questions about whether other automakers may have also tampered with emission equipment, leading to potential price tags and scrutiny from consumers and regulatory bodies.

site_title: 1MDB objects to Zeti's comments, says it is not responsible for ringgit's weakness
summary: Malaysia's central bank governor Zeti Akhtar Aziz has commented on the country's currency woes, stating that resolving issues surrounding 1MDB will help bolster the ringgit. 1MDB has objected to Zeti's comments, claiming it is not responsible for the currency's weakness. The company stated that the ringgit's decline is mainly due to the fall in oil prices, US interest rates, and concerns over emerging markets. The US Justice Department has launched an investigation into allegations of corruption associated with Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak and 1MDB.

site_title: MAS to tighten rules on gold buyback and landbanking schemes
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) plans to regulate investment schemes such as gold buybacks and collective landbanking, starting in 2016. The new rules aim to prevent providers of controversial products from targeting less sophisticated investors. MAS will treat gold buyback schemes as debentures, requiring sellers to register prospectuses, and amend the definition of collective investment schemes to close a loophole used by landbanking programmes. The regulations will restrict the sale of collective investment schemes to retail investors without MAS authorisation and require financial institutions to offer licensed financial advice to accredited investors.

site_title: SEC settles with two ex-Fannie Mae execs
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has settled with two former Fannie Mae executives, Enrico Dallavecchia and Thomas Lund, over their roles in concealing the company's exposure to subprime and low-documentation home loans. They will pay $25,000 and $10,000 respectively to settle charges. The settlement leaves the SEC's "baseless charges" behind, with both men denying wrongdoing and agreeing to cooperate with the SEC in its ongoing case against former Fannie Mae CEO Daniel Mudd.

site_title: Harvard grads make aiding the poor a new business
summary: Harvard graduates Michael Faye and Paul Niehaus have developed a business model that gives cash directly to the poor, proving it to be more efficient and productive than traditional aid distribution methods. Their technology, Segovia, aims to help anti-poverty programs track recipients and provide targeted aid. With initial funding of $13 million, the company is poised to revolutionize the $25 billion humanitarian aid industry, which is currently dominated by in-kind aid distribution. Studies have shown that cash transfers can lead to significant earnings boosts and long-term economic growth, with benefits including increased productivity and asset accumulation.

site_title: A meeting of the two largest economic powers
summary: US President Barack Obama and Chinese President Xi Jinping are meeting at the White House, with hopes of new agreements on trade and atmospheric pollution. China's economic growth has been driven by infrastructure investments and a shift towards a more inward-focused economy, while the US is still experiencing a trade deficit. Germany has a large trade surplus, while China's trade balance is smaller per person. The meeting aims to promote global trade and cooperation, with China expected to make significant investments in high-tech engineering goods to aid Germany's trade balance.

site_title: An uncertain future
summary: Crowdfunding is gaining traction, but uncertainty remains as most firms will raise modest amounts and handle a large number of stakeholders. This can create pressure for results and unwarranted transparency. Policymakers and regulators will have a "headache" keeping up with innovation. The success of crowdfunding is tied to the legal and regulatory framework, which must adapt to constant innovation, allowing small entrepreneurs to access a new source of funding.

site_title: Smaller audit firms urged to improve risk analysis
summary: Audit firms, particularly smaller ones, are urged to improve the quality of their audits, with recurring deficiencies in areas such as revenue recognition and construction contracts found in non-listed companies. The industry regulator, Acra, attributes the deficiencies to incorrect audit risk identification, low involvement of audit partners, and insufficient technical knowledge. Larger firms have shown improvements in audit quality, and Acra plans to step up enforcement actions, including public reporting of inspection outcomes, to address the issue.

images.alt_text: "Some are overstretching themselves by taking on too many clients," said Acra's Kenneth Yap

site_title: China's Greenland ties up with Mizuho
summary: China's Greenland Holdings Corp has partnered with Japanese lender Mizuho Financial Group to secure debt financing and access international capital markets. Mizuho will provide bond-market services, property investment targets in Japan, and asset management services to Greenland. This tie-up marks Greenland's latest international foray, with plans to strengthen its overseas business within the next five years. The partnership may involve yen bond sales, a first for a Chinese developer, and is seen as a significant move to boost Greenland's global presence.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: SATS Ltd is expected to continue its operational improvements, driven by management efforts to increase productivity, despite sluggish performance at Changi Airport. OCBC Investment Research maintains a "Hold" rating with a target price of S$3.78. Dairy Farm is upgraded to "Buy" by DBS Group Research, citing a share price correction that has priced in structural cost challenges. Thai Beverage is recommended to "Add" by CIMB Research, as the company prepares for a re-branding and re-positioning in the market.

site_title: Merged portfolio strategy pays off for Credit Suisse
summary: Credit Suisse's merged portfolio strategy for advisory and discretionary mandates has seen a 200% increase in net new sales and a 50% rise in assets under management (AUM) in the first half of the year. The bank's Asia Pacific AUM rose 16% to $149 billion, driven by global wealth management clients. The merged strategy has helped clients navigate volatility and provide stable long-term performance, with discretionary portfolios generating returns of 5-9% in the first six months. Credit Suisse expects the US Federal Reserve to hike rates in December, but notes that uncertainty over Fed policy has increased.

images.alt_text: Ms Tan attributes business growth to clients' search for solutions to navigate volatility and provide stable long-term performance.
Genevieve Cua

site_title: Fed was dovish as expected. Now, to take profit
summary: The Federal Reserve maintained its dovish stance, delaying interest rate hikes, and the market is now poised to take profit. The technical rebound in equities is expected to run out of steam, with heavy resistance at 2,000-2,100 points. Despite the Fed's cautious approach, the US economy remains in decent shape, and the dollar is likely to rebound. The Fed's decision was seen as a continuation of the expected "risk rally" supported by dovish Fed policies, but with limited upside in equities.

site_title: Launch of cluster heralds exciting new chapter in 3D printing for S'pore
summary: Singapore launches the National Additive Manufacturing Innovation Cluster (Namic), a 3D printing initiative led by Spring Singapore and Nanyang Technological University, to help startups and spinoffs commercialize their intellectual property and access incubators and skilled manpower. The cluster aims to revolutionize the manufacturing industry, particularly in sectors like aerospace, precision engineering, and medical technology, and will establish a joint fund to support translational projects between research institutes and industry practitioners. This move comes after a US-based company invested S$8 million to build a Global Additive Manufacturing Center of Excellence in Singapore.

site_title: Sales growth the key priority in next phase of productivity
summary: The Singapore government has launched the Second Retail Productivity Plan, focusing on driving sales growth and transforming retailers into e-retailers. The 5-year plan aims to support businesses in improving operational efficiency and investing in e-commerce, branding, and concept innovation. With 1,900 retailers benefiting from the first plan, the new plan aims to deepen transformation and bring on board more retailers. The government will provide support for product development, brand-building, and digital advertising to help retailers sell online, with a focus on internationalization.

images.alt_text: As the retail sector moves into its next phase of productivity improvements, businesses must focus not just on operational efficiency but also on driving top-line growth, says Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry and National Development Lee Yi Shyan.

site_title: 1 in 4 female undergrads sexually attacked in US
summary: A recent study by the Association of American Universities found that nearly a quarter of female undergraduate students in the US experience unwanted sexual contact during their college years, with 13.5% reporting penetration or attempted penetration. The survey of 27 leading universities revealed that 27.2% of female college seniors experienced some form of unwanted sexual contact, often due to incapacitation from alcohol or drugs. The study highlights the need for increased awareness and support for victims of sexual assault on college campuses.

images.alt_text: Most of the institutions in the AAU study released their own figures from the survey, and several of the most respected ones - such as Harvard, Yale and the University of Michigan - had some of the highest rates of sexual assault by force or incapacitation for undergraduate women.

site_title: Volkswagen scandal may be tip of iceberg; industry may suffer fallout
summary: Volkswagen's emissions scandal has escalated, with the company facing a potential $18 billion fine in the US and millions of vehicles worldwide potentially affected by software that cheated emissions tests. The scandal has sent shockwaves through the global car industry, causing a 38% share plunge for Volkswagen and a decline in shares of other major car companies and suppliers. Analysts fear that other motor companies may have also understated pollution emissions, and environmental groups warn that millions of cars could be recalled to meet anti-pollution requirements.

site_title: Iran stagnating as shoppers delay purchases
summary: Iran's economy is experiencing stagnation as consumers delay purchases of domestic goods, waiting for international brands to arrive. Despite a nuclear deal that will lift sanctions, manufacturers face challenges competing with foreign goods, leading to a slowdown in consumer spending and warehouses filling with unsold goods. The lack of choice and higher quality of foreign products is prompting a social media campaign urging a boycott of domestic carmakers, with some consumers waiting for prices to drop before making purchases.

site_title: China retailers take the showroom approach
summary: Chinese retailers, including Li Ning Co and Haier Electronics Group, are adopting the showroom approach to reduce inventory costs and improve sales. By directing customers to the internet to make purchases online, these companies aim to boost sales and reverse years of losses. This strategy is expected to help companies manage complex inventory management in China, particularly in smaller cities, and may be beneficial for other areas of retail, such as homeware and personal beauty care.

site_title: China's declining coal trade could help climate push
summary: China's coal trade is declining, which could help the country's climate efforts. However, Beijing must take significant action to capitalize on the drop in demand. Mines in China's coal heartland have fallen silent, with miners' salaries cut by one-fifth. China's shift away from coal could also impact global energy markets. The decline in coal demand could also benefit the environment and align with China's climate goals, but it will require major policy changes from the government.

site_title: US drug company rescinds big price increase on TB drug
summary: US drug company Turing Pharmaceuticals has rescinded a massive price hike of Daraprim, a tuberculosis treatment, and agreed to return the drug to its previous non-profit owner, Purdue Research Foundation. The price increase was met with outrage, with Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders calling for action to control pharmaceutical prices. Rodelis Therapeutics, which acquired the tuberculosis drug cycloserine, has also agreed to return the drug to its former owner, the Purdue Research Foundation, after discovering its strategy.

site_title: Negotiating a delicate balance
summary: Singapore's crowdfunding market needs a balanced regulatory framework to promote innovation and protect investors. Currently, the market is fragmented, with different forms of crowdfunding lacking clear guidelines. The Monetary Authority of Singapore has proposed a regulatory framework, but experts argue that it should be more comprehensive. Some propose a general framework addressing anti-money laundering and due diligence, while others suggest that accredited investors and institutional investors should be prioritized. The market's success depends on finding a balance between protecting investors and promoting entrepreneurship, with some experts warning that overly restrictive rules could hinder innovation.

images.alt_text: "Overly restrictive rules will prevent crowdfunding from delivering its many potential benefits. On the flip side, a laissez faire attitude will most likely damage the market if investors and backers have bad experiences." - Adrian Harkin, chief executive officer, management consulting for KPMG in Asean

"I do think there is a lot of information out there on the Internet and good crowdfunding platforms operating in a country like Singapore will have strong investor protection and transparency to mitigate risks." - Andy Lim, chairman and co-founder of private equity firm Tembusu Partners

"Angel investors and PE firms who have the right risk appetite and business acumen to understand the potential of investing early in growth companies will find the crowdfunding platform useful as an additional avenue for sourcing for deals." - Albert Ho, director of boutique corporate advisory and investment firm Centrum Capital

site_title: Lee Kuan Yew's younger children, government in court over interviews
summary: A court case is underway in Singapore between Lee Wei Ling and Lee Hsien Yang, younger children of Lee Kuan Yew, and the government, over the custody and use of interviews given by the late prime minister in 1981 and 1982. The siblings, as executors of their father's will, have requested copies of the transcripts, citing an agreement made in 1983. The government has disagreed, and a pre-trial conference was held on Tuesday. The case aims to clarify the proper interpretation of the agreement, with the siblings seeking to establish their entitlement to the transcripts.

site_title: Online message board 4chan sold to Japanese Web culture pioneer
summary: 4chan, a popular anonymous online message board, has been sold to Hiroyuki Nishimura, a Japanese web culture pioneer and founder of 2channel, a website that inspired the creation of 4chan. The sale comes after more than a decade under the helm of Christopher Poole, who expanded the site to over 20 million monthly visitors. Poole stepped down, handing over the reins to part-time moderators, and the new owner has expressed his admiration for 4chan's role in internet culture. The sale marks a significant shift for 4chan, which has struggled to scale into a profitable business.

site_title: Brazil's currency hits record low on pessimism over budget
summary: Brazil's currency, the real, hit a record low of 4.0142 per US dollar due to concerns over President Dilma Rousseff's ability to shore up the country's budget and avoid further credit-rating cuts. The real has tumbled 5.7% since Standard & Poor's cut Brazil to junk, with analysts predicting a 2.7% economic contraction this year and 0.8% decline in GDP for 2016. The country's economic situation is worsening, with a 50% chance of further downgrade by Fitch Ratings, and a pessimistic outlook for the economy's recovery.

site_title: Malaysia's forex reserves rise again after months of decline
summary: Malaysia's foreign exchange reserves rose to $95.3 billion in the first two weeks of September, a 1.1% increase, after months of decline. The reserves are sufficient to finance 7.3 months of retained imports and are 1.1 times the short-term external debt. The increase may be attributed to the US Federal Reserve's decision to hold off on hiking interest rates, easing pressure on Malaysia's reserves. The ringgit currency has depreciated 18% against the dollar this year, and Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak announced economic measures to prop up the stock market.

images.alt_text: BNM says currency reserves rose to US$95.3 billion as at Sept 15, from US$94.7 billion on Aug 28, and are 1.1 times the short-term external debt.

site_title: Women workers hold key to boosting Asian growth, says ADB
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has urged the use of women's power to boost economic growth in Asia and the Pacific, suggesting that adopting progressive attitudes towards women at work could lead to a 30% rise in income over a generation. The ADB's report notes that women continue to make less than men in paid employment, with a 20% wage gap globally, and highlights the need to close the gender gap in pay and participation in the labor market to maximize economic efficiency.

site_title: Roller-coaster China stock ride scaring investors away
summary: China's stock market continues to experience extreme volatility, with the Shanghai Composite Index's 30-day price swings reaching 57.7, more than double the global average. Turnover has plummeted 22% and the number of new investors has dropped 82% since May, as foreign money managers have sold billions of Shanghai shares. The government's efforts to stabilize the market have been met with skepticism, with some analysts warning that the market is "bubbly" and at risk of further declines.

site_title: Sells outstrip buys in Singapore stocks
summary: Global mutual funds sold S$1.55 billion in Singapore stocks and S$535.5 million in real estate investment trusts (Reits) in the three months to Sept 16, outpacing net buys of S$879.7 million and S$91.2 million respectively. Fortune Real Estate Investment Trust was the top sell, with net sells of S$206.2 million, while Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust was the top buy, with a volume of S$21.7 million.

site_title: Currencies go wild as Fed leaves traders in limbo
summary: The Federal Reserve's decision not to raise interest rates has left foreign-exchange markets in a state of high volatility, with the US dollar experiencing significant price swings. This uncertainty has led traders to expect further volatility in the market, with Morgan Stanley predicting that currency traders will enter a "new era" of price swings. Policymakers in Europe and Japan are also weighing further stimulus, adding to the uncertainty, while the Fed's focus on global economic data and international circumstances will continue to stir markets.

site_title: Wall Street banks seek to monetise their analysts' reports
summary: Wall Street banks are restricting access to analysts' reports, embedding them on their websites to track readership and tailor products for specific clients. This move aims to monetize analysts' work by limiting free access, a practice that has made it easy for non-paying clients to share reports. Bank of America, Morgan Stanley, and Citigroup are joining in, and more firms are expected to follow, as the approach also enables easier customization of products for different client types.

images.alt_text: "You're not accessing a static PDF, you're going into a website and you are authenticating. That's the whole premise here, that you have a greater ability to control the access coming in when it's a living, breathing environment that we control." - Daire Browne, Bank of America's chief operating officer for global research. The bank is joining rivals Morgan Stanley and Citigroup Inc in limiting access to its analysts' reports

site_title: NYT: US grand jury probing Najib-linked graft allegations
summary: A US federal grand jury is investigating allegations of corruption involving Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak and people close to him, focusing on properties bought by shell companies linked to Najib's stepson and a close family friend. Investigators are also looking at $681 million in payments to Najib's personal bank accounts. The probe is part of a series of international investigations into 1MDB, a state-owned Malaysian company plagued by a massive debt pile and allegations of fraud or mismanagement.

site_title: Indonesia suspends operations of four companies over haze
summary: Indonesia has suspended operations of four companies, including three palm oil plantation firms and one forestry company, for allegedly causing forest fires that sent thick smoke across Southeast Asia. The companies have had their permits frozen or licenses revoked, and the Indonesian government has ordered thousands of security personnel to help fight the fires. The environment ministry has also launched investigations against over 200 companies, amid complaints from neighboring countries.

site_title: US$ nears 2-week high on fresh talk of rate hike
summary: The US dollar reached a two-week high against a basket of major currencies after comments from Federal Reserve officials revived expectations of a rate hike later this year. The dollar has bounced back over 2% since Friday's low, with half of market participants betting on a rate hike in October or December. The euro and yen have been pressured by growing expectations of expansionary stimulus programs from the European Central Bank and Bank of Japan, boosting the dollar. The dollar rose 0.1% against a basket of six major currencies, its strongest level since September 10.

images.alt_text: The dollar touched an almost two-week high against a basket of major currencies on Tuesday after comments from Federal Reserve officials revived expectations that US interest rates will still be hiked later this year.

site_title: STI erases gains in volatile trade
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended the day with a net loss of 13.8 points to 2,868.47, despite an earlier gain of 20 points, due to a sharp dip in Dow futures and a weak Europe opening. Volatility in global markets, including worries over a hard landing in China, led to cautious trading. Turnover was moderate, with most players maintaining a cautious outlook for equities.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: ST Engineering has incorporated three UK-based companies and two Irish companies under the "Keystone" name, forming a holding company for aircraft leasing investments. Lizhong Wheel Group's free float has dropped below 10% after Berkley International launched a conditional cash offer. SWEE Hong has received High Court approval to convene a meeting of creditors to approve a debt restructuring scheme by Oct 19.

site_title: When will the time be ripe to raise rates?
summary: The US Federal Reserve decided to hold interest rates at historic lows despite speculation that a rate hike was imminent. The decision was made after the unemployment rate fell to 5.1% and inflation rose to 0.3%, lower than the 2% threshold that requires action by the central bank. The Fed cited uncertain global economic conditions and the potential for financial turmoil in emerging markets as reasons for not raising rates. However, some Fed policymakers may still advocate for a rate hike in late October or mid-December if the economy improves and inflation rises to 2% under the best-case scenario.

site_title: China can maintain 'medium-high growth': Xi
summary: China's President Xi Jinping stated the nation can maintain "medium-high growth" despite economic weakness, attributing it to sticking with economic reforms and shifting towards an innovation and consumption-driven economy. He defended China's intervention to stem a stock market slide and reiterated the country's commitment to opening its markets. Xi also addressed concerns on cybersecurity and territorial claims in the South China Sea, asserting China's defensive stance and backing by historical and legal evidence.

site_title: Silver Lake co-founder starts new firm to manage his own wealth
summary: James Davidson, co-founder of Silver Lake Management, has launched Paxion Partners, a multi-family office to manage his personal wealth. The firm is structured to eventually manage outside capital, including wealthy clients, and will focus on maximizing after-tax wealth creation. Paxion's investment mandate differs from Silver Lake's, with a focus on income and estate tax optimization. Davidson has briefed Silver Lake investors on his new venture, ensuring that it won't compete with or reduce his time at the firm. The firm plans to hire additional asset managers and invest in areas like affordable housing and venture capital funds.

site_title: Foreign-currency debt looms again as a problem for emerging Asia: ADB
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has warned countries in emerging Asia to limit reliance on foreign debt amid volatile global capital flows and interest-rate uncertainties. The bank's annual Asian Development Outlook report projects 5.8% growth for developing Asia in 2015 and 6% in 2016, down from earlier forecasts. China's slowdown and India's moderating prospects are major contributors to the lower growth. The ADB cautioned that foreign-currency debt poses a risk to Asian companies, particularly those with limited foreign revenues, and urged policymakers to find a balance between stabilizing the financial sector and stimulating domestic demand.

site_title: CAO core jet fuel biz still strong despite slowdown
summary: China Aviation Oil (CAO) CEO Meng Fanqiu says the company's core jet fuel business remains strong despite China's economic slowdown, driven by a growing global civil aviation industry, particularly in Asia. CAO expects to grow with the market, with plans to expand globally and invest in production, logistics, and airport refuelling facilities. The company aims to double its 2012 gross profit by 2020 and is optimistic about China's economic future, citing the country's 7% growth rate as a positive sign.

images.alt_text: Mr Meng said the current slower GDP growth of 7% in the world's second largest economy is natural, considering that China is in a state of transition.

site_title: Via insurance or otherwise, cyber-attack risks must be managed
summary: The risk of cyber attacks is increasing, with devastating consequences for companies and governments. In 2014, JP Morgan Chase and eBay suffered major breaches, and Singapore's government portals and high-ranking officials' websites were also targeted. Cyber security insurance is becoming more popular, with premiums expected to rise from $2.5 billion to $7.5 billion by the end of the decade. However, pricing is a challenge due to limited data on risk assessment, and companies are reluctant to disclose breaches to protect their reputations. Assessing damage is also difficult, with widespread and contentious consequences.

site_title: Dong CEO seeks banks for IPO as Denmark turns to Rothschild
summary: Dong Energy CEO Henrik Poulsen is seeking banks to guide the company's initial public offering (IPO), which may include divesting the oil unit. Denmark, owning 59% of Dong, plans to cut its stake to 51% and hire Rothschild to advise on the process. The IPO, valued at 70 billion kroner (S$14.8 billion), will be the largest in Denmark's history. A strategic review of Dong's Exploration and Production (E&P) business is planned, following a 50% drop in oil prices over the past year.

site_title: Volkswagen models in emissions scandal not sold in Singapore: NEA
summary: Volkswagen models affected by the emissions scandal are not sold in Singapore, according to the National Environment Agency (NEA). The agency stated that the cases reported in the US pertain to Volkswagen diesel models not sold in Singapore. This implies that Singapore is not impacted by the scandal involving Volkswagen diesel models.

site_title: Norway media firm building its digital presence
summary: Norway's media firm Schibsted ASA is expanding its digital presence by developing more personalized products for consumers and advertisers. The company has set up a new development hub in London with 45 employees, focusing on creating targeted audiences for advertisers. Schibsted aims to increase traffic and revenue, with a balance sheet to support its growth. The company has raised 2.7 billion kroner in a private placement and is exploring consolidation opportunities in the online classifieds sphere across Europe, particularly in countries where it already operates.

site_title: Lor Lew Lian housing site triggered for tender
summary: A private housing site in Lorong Lew Lian, near Serangoon MRT Station, has been triggered for release from the Government Land Sales (GLS) Programme after 21 months. The 1.4-hectare site can be developed into a private condo project with approximately 465 units. The minimum bid price is S$553 psf ppr, with analysts predicting six to 12 bids, with the top bid likely to be around S$630-680 psf ppr. The successful bidder is expected to build around 600 units, with an average selling price of S$1,250-1,300 psf.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Fed likely to raise US interest rates in December
summary: The US Federal Reserve is likely to raise interest rates in December, with 60% of economists polled by Reuters predicting the move. Despite the Fed keeping rates steady last week, citing China and global markets, data suggests it may be time for a hike. The decision to hold rates in a range of zero to 0.25% has sparked uncertainty, with some economists warning of asset bubbles and others expressing confidence in the Fed's decision.

site_title: Australia Q2 home prices leap 4.7%, biggest quarterly gain in 5 years
summary: Australia's home prices surged 4.7% in Q2, the largest quarterly gain in 5 years, driven by Sydney's record 8.9% increase. The mean home price in New South Wales reached A$777,400. However, cities in resource-rich states like Western Australia saw declines, highlighting the patchy housing market. Regulatory measures introduced to tighten mortgage lending appear to be taking effect, with the Reserve Bank of Australia governor stating they are working to contain leverage and prevent debt build-up.

site_title: Cybersecurity remains bone of contention for US, China
summary: US and China have taken steps to smooth President Xi Jinping's visit, with China sending a special envoy to address cybersecurity concerns and the US repatriating one of China's most-wanted fugitives. Despite this, the contentious issue is expected to remain a key topic of discussion during their meetings. US President Barack Obama has warned of measures against China over online attacks, which won't be taken before the summit. China's shift in attitude towards the US appears to be driven by the repatriation of Yang Jinjun, a former covert agent.

site_title: Chinese president woos big business as US visit begins
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping began a US state visit in Seattle, aiming to woo American businesses and ease tensions between the two countries. Xi met with corporate leaders, including Boeing and Microsoft, and delivered a keynote speech, focusing on trade and investment. The visit comes amid concerns over China's territorial claims, cyber theft, and unfair business practices. Xi must balance demonstrating China's importance as a global power with addressing US concerns, including the theft of US business secrets and human rights issues.

site_title: Lizhong free float falls below 10% mark
summary: Lizhong Wheel Group's free float has fallen below 10% to 6.83% after Berkley International launched a conditional cash offer for the shares, citing low trading liquidity and compliance costs. The offer price is 50 Singapore cents per share, nearly double the pre-announcement price. The Singapore Exchange may suspend trading of the shares on October 16 due to non-compliance with free float requirements. The takeover is seen as a move to take the company private.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Indonesia's central bank sees rupiah trading at 13,700-13,900 per dollar on average in 2016
summary: Indonesia's central bank governor Agus Martowardojo predicted the rupiah currency would trade at 13,700-13,900 per dollar on average in 2016, recovering after remaining under pressure this year. The currency had dropped to a 17-year low of 14,500 to the dollar and is the worst performing currency in the region this year. Martowardojo attributed the expected recovery to the government's deregulation package and the central bank's stabilisation policy.

site_title: Future shock
summary: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) and Singapore will host a joint conference, Future-Ready Shipping 2015, to discuss improving energy efficiency in ships and facilitating technology transfers. The event aims to support the implementation of a MARPOL Annex VI regulation promoting technical co-operation and technology transfer. Shipping industry leaders, including the International Chamber of Shipping, argue that the industry is committed to reducing CO2 emissions and is already making significant progress. However, the pressure remains to either improve efficiency or adopt new fuels and propulsion systems to meet environmental targets, including a potential carbon levy.

images.alt_text: On Monday and Tuesday next week, a joint IMO-Singapore International Conference on Maritime Technology Transfer and Capacity Building will take place here.

site_title: Industry warns over failure to reach EU-US deal on derivatives
summary: The European Union and US regulators are at an impasse over derivatives rules, with a failure to reach a deal potentially leading to "catastrophic" attempts by market users to withdraw from American clearing houses. The global derivatives market, valued at $630 trillion, could fragment and increase costs if a deal is not reached by the end of December. Industry officials warn that European users of clearing houses, such as Societe Generale, are looking nervously at the situation and would be forced to hold more capital if they were to withdraw from US clearing houses.

site_title: Business schools see broadest increase in applications since the recession
summary: US business schools have seen the strongest increase in applications since the 2009 recession, with 59% of programs reporting a rise in full-time, two-year MBA applications from Americans. Domestic candidates make up 45% of the applicant pool, while the majority of MBA programs globally reported a year-over-year increase in applications, higher than a decade ago. This trend contrasts with declining law school applications, suggesting business schools are a popular destination for career-minded professionals seeking graduate education.

site_title: Singapore industrial Reit sector will be resilient in slowdown: Fitch
summary: Singapore's industrial Reit sector is expected to remain resilient during the economic slowdown due to its robust financial profiles. Rental rates for industrial properties are expected to remain under pressure, with lower-specification properties being more affected. Reits with high proportions of near-term lease renewals and low-specification assets are at higher risk. However, 80% of the sector's debt has fixed rates, providing support to the sector's resilience in a downturn. This narrow mismatch between lease and debt contracts will help mitigate the impact of a potential economic downturn.

site_title: Fed rate decision highlights the need for a global central bank
summary: The US Federal Reserve's decision not to raise interest rates last week highlights the need for a global central bank, according to Fed Chair Janet Yellen's actions. By considering global economic fragility, Yellen acted as if the Fed were a global central bank, despite its limited authority to intervene in global monetary affairs. This decision risks undermining credibility and creating tensions. The Fed's actions illustrate the need for global monetary policy coordination, but the US is reluctant to relinquish its power as the world's reserve currency and lender of last resort.

site_title: Cyber security firm offers $1 million for Apple hack
summary: A US$1 million bounty has been offered by security firm Zerodium to hackers who can breach Apple's iOS 9 mobile operating system. The challenge, which closes on October 31, requires exploiting previously unknown weaknesses to remotely bypass security and install an application. Zerodium rewards independent researchers for discovering vulnerabilities, with up to $1 million paid to up to three successful hackers. Apple's iOS 9 is considered the most secure operating system, but Zerodium argues that "secure does not mean unbreakable."

site_title: Volkswagen says 11m cars worldwide have pollution cheating software
summary: Volkswagen announced that approximately 11 million diesel cars worldwide have been equipped with engine software that could skew emissions data, amid the ongoing pollution cheating scandal. The company is setting aside 6.5 billion euros to cover potential costs and will adjust its profit targets for the current year. This announcement led to a 20% decline in VW shares on the Frankfurt stock exchange.

site_title: Rowsley to convert Vantage Bay to healthcare hub
summary: Rowsley, a real estate firm controlled by billionaire Peter Lim, plans to convert its long-delayed Vantage Bay integrated development in Iskandar into a healthcare cluster. The RM5 billion project, spanning 10 years, will feature a specialist hospital, community hospital, long-term care facilities, and medical suites, with a total of about 850 beds. The conversion aims to capitalize on the region's soft residential market, with the healthcare hub expected to be developed in phases.

site_title: European stocks slide as carmakers post biggest drop since 2008
summary: European stocks slid as Volkswagen's emission-test scandal and concerns about global growth weighed on investor sentiment. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index dropped 3.1% to its lowest since August 24, while Germany's benchmark DAX Index fell 3.8%. Shares in carmakers, including Volkswagen and PSA Peugeot Citroen, plummeted 20% and 8.8% respectively, with Volkswagen setting aside €6.5 billion for the costs. Investors also parsed comments from Federal Reserve officials for signals on interest rates, with a hike in October now at 18% probability.

site_title: US: Stocks drop as Volkswagen weighs on automakers
summary: US stocks fell in opening trade Tuesday, following European markets sharply lower due to the Volkswagen emissions scandal. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 218.55 points (1.32%), the S&P 500 fell 25.71 (1.31%), and the Nasdaq Composite Index declined 68.06 (1.41%). European bourses, including Paris and Frankfurt, were down more than three percent, with shares of major automakers hit by the scandal.

site_title: DBS disrupts national pastime: queuing for food
summary: DBS Bank is launching an app called FasTrack, which allows customers to place food and beverage orders and make payments through their phones at hawker centres and quick-serve restaurants in Singapore. The app aims to reduce cash usage and long queues, increasing productivity for businesses. By December, the service will be available at cost price, with DBS seeking government funding to cover costs. The app has been tested by a beverage seller and is targeted at small payments, with each app customizable to the restaurant's needs.

images.alt_text: DBS's FasTrack app is displayed here by Mr Soo (left) and Old Tea Hut founder Kenny Loy, whose outlet has tested it. The app will be fully available to businesses by December

site_title: Singapore: Plunge in US futures erases earlier gains
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) in Singapore fell 13.8 points to 2,868.47, erasing earlier gains, due to a sharp dip in US futures and weak European market opening. Turnover was low at 1.5 billion units, and the market's advance-decline score was neutral. The decline was attributed to concerns about the outlook for equities and short selling.

site_title: HSBC gets first China approval to sell bonds in interbank market
summary: HSBC Holdings Plc has received the first approval from the People's Bank of China to sell bonds in the country's interbank market. The central bank gave HSBC the green light to sell 1 billion yuan (US$157 million) of bonds, while BOC Hong Kong Holdings Ltd will sell 10 billion yuan of bonds. This approval could signal the opening up of an alternative source of funding for global borrowers, potentially leading to a 13-fold jump in issuance of onshore securities by foreign firms by 2020.

site_title: Singtel least likely to be affected by fourth telco: UOB Kay Hian analyst
summary: Singtel is least likely to be affected by a fourth telco operator in Singapore, according to a UOB Kay Hian analyst. The analyst projects a 2.2% decline in Singtel's net profit in 2019, compared to a 32% decline for M1 and 25.8% for StarHub, two years after the new operator enters the market in 2017. This is due to Singtel's significant revenue coming from outside Singapore.

site_title: Home prices in US rose more than estimated in July, FHFA says
summary: US home prices rose 0.6% in July, exceeding economists' estimates of 0.4%. The median price of an existing single-family home increased 5.8% from last year to $235,500. The job market's improvement and reduced listings nationwide, down 4.7% from last year, contributed to the price gain. Experts say the increased availability of homes should ease price growth in the coming months.

site_title: Singapore Exchange faces test as China-led boom fades
summary: Singapore Exchange Ltd faces pressure as China's economic slowdown affects its derivatives trading, with trading in key futures contracts slumping nearly three-fourths from a record high. The exchange's derivatives business, which contributed 38% of its revenue, is expected to be a challenge for new CEO Loh Boon Chye. Investors are watching for his response to the challenges, but analysts say the market is largely dependent on market participants for growth.

site_title: New CEO for YuuZoo Corporation
summary: YuuZoo Corporation has appointed James Sundram as its new CEO, effective October 1. Sundram brings significant international expertise in online and multimedia industries, having launched successful turnaround and transformation strategies at previous companies. As CEO, he will oversee all operations and manage the company according to established policies and goals. This appointment aims to drive revenue growth for YuuZoo.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: We 'screwed up': Volkswagen US chief
summary: Volkswagen US chief executive Michael Horn apologized for the company's dishonesty in US pollution testing, admitting they "totally screwed up" by cheating with 11 million diesel cars worldwide. The scandal led to a US probe, a criminal investigation, and a halt in US diesel sales, potentially resulting in fines over $18 billion. The company set aside $7.3 billion in provisions to cover costs. VW shares plummeted 40% following the revelation.

site_title: Microsoft begins worldwide release of Office 2016
summary: Microsoft has begun the worldwide rollout of Office 2016, a cloud-based subscription service, as part of its Office 365 platform. The new version includes updated desktop apps for Word, PowerPoint, Excel, Outlook, and Access, allowing for collaboration and teamwork. Available in 40 languages, Office 2016 requires Windows 7 or later versions and can be downloaded by Office 365 subscribers starting Tuesday. This move comes after the launch of Windows 10 in July, aimed at regaining market share in the tablets and mobile arena.

site_title: Volkswagen denies report about CEO ouster
summary: Volkswagen denied a report that CEO Martin Winterkorn was to be replaced amid the company's ongoing emissions scandal. The German automaker faces potential penalties of up to $18 billion in the US and class-action lawsuits. US regulators allege Volkswagen misled buyers for over a year, damaging its reputation. A company spokesman called the report by German Tagesspiegel "nonsense."

site_title: Indonesia vows to stick with ore export curbs as metals sink
summary: Indonesia is sticking to its mineral-ore export ban despite low metal prices, with President Joko Widodo reaffirming his government's full support for the policy. The ban, implemented in 2014, aims to spur investment in processing facilities. Since then, Indonesia has attracted $2.4 billion in metals investments. The country's nickel export price has dropped from $13,900 to $9,100, but the government is not considering relaxing the ban, citing concerns about volatility. Indonesia's smelters need a nickel price of $15,000 to break even.

site_title: Merkel urges 'full transparency' from VW in cheating scandal
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel urges Volkswagen to provide "full transparency" regarding the pollution test cheating scandal, emphasizing the need for clear facts to be revealed. Merkel is in close contact with Transport Minister Alexander Dobrindt, who is working with the company to resolve the matter.

site_title: China grants Aberdeen Asset Management business licence
summary: Aberdeen Asset Management, a British-based fund firm, has been granted a business licence to operate in China, allowing it to set up an office under a pilot free-trade scheme. The licence was issued to a newly-created Aberdeen subsidiary, enabling the firm to bring its fund management expertise to the second-largest economy in the world. British business minister Sajid Javid expressed commitment to building relationships between the two nations, citing the potential for Aberdeen to contribute to China's growth.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) will regulate gold buyback and landbanking schemes as capital markets products, increasing hurdles for wealthy investors. The country also launched a cluster for 3D printing, and DBS will introduce cashless options through a mobile app at F&B outlets. Meanwhile, Lee Wei Ling and Lee Hsien Yang have filed a court case over an interview agreement with their late father, Lee Kuan Yew. The Singapore Stock Index (STI) declined 13.8 points, wiping out earlier gains, amid a slide on Wall Street.

site_title: China's economy still able to achieve this year's growth target: research paper
summary: A research paper by China's top economic planner suggests the country's economy can still achieve its annual growth target of 7% for 2015, despite increasing pressure. Positive growth impulses from the services sector and property market are expected to offset weaknesses in the manufacturing sector and financial services industry. Domestic consumption is expected to remain the main driver of growth, with modest rises in consumer prices and employment. The paper cites these factors as reasons to believe China can meet its growth target, despite a quarter-century low annual rate.

site_title: VW to replace CEO amid emissions scandal: Tagesspiegel
summary: Volkswagen's CEO Martin Winterkorn is set to be replaced amid the emissions scandal, with Porsche's CEO Matthias Mueller taking over. The decision comes after the US Environmental Protection Agency accused Volkswagen of rigging emissions tests, which could result in penalties of up to $18 billion. The supervisory board will make the official announcement on Friday.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen is to oust Chief Executive Martin Winterkorn after US authorities late last week accused the German carmaker of rigging emissions tests, German daily Tagesspiegel reported, citing supervisory board sources.

site_title: Greece's Tsipras may form cabinet without Tsakalotos as finance minister
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is struggling to re-appoint finance minister Euclid Tsakalotos, who is reluctant to take the job again due to concerns over the party's shift towards pragmatism. Alternative candidate George Chouliarakis, a technocrat, is also being considered. Tsipras' cabinet will focus on implementing the 86 billion euro bailout and addressing Greece's refugee crisis. A new finance minister is expected to ensure the bailout does not go off track and handle Greece's economic challenges.

site_title: UK manufacturing stalls in September, outlook weak: CBI
summary: British manufacturing output stagnated in the three months to September for the first time since 2013, according to the Confederation of British Industry. Total orders and export orders declined, with demand from abroad at its lowest level in six months. Economists expect a slowing economy, with the CBI director of economics stating that exports are the "missing link" in the UK recovery, hindered by the strong pound and squeezed margins. This marks the second consecutive month of economic contraction.

site_title: Britain urges closer China ties despite economic risk
summary: Britain's finance minister George Osborne urged closer business ties with China despite economic risks, visiting Shanghai to discuss linking London and Shanghai bourses and yuan-denominated bonds. Osborne agreed with Chinese officials to study these possibilities, aiming to strengthen ties. China's slowing growth has shaken world markets, with the Shanghai stock exchange's benchmark index plummeting nearly 40% since June.

site_title: Malaysia's opposition parties announce new alliance
summary: Malaysia's opposition parties announce a new alliance called Pakatan Harapan, consisting of the Democratic Action Party (DAP), Parti Keadilan Rakyat (PKR), and Parti Amanah Negara (Amanah), replacing Parti Islam SeMalaysia (PAS).

site_title: Boeing 'planning China factory': report
summary: Boeing has submitted plans to build a factory in China's Zhoushan city, a move that would mark a significant shift in the US company's strategy in the country. The proposed factory, which would be part of a new aerospace industrial zone, is expected to be the centrepiece of a major investment by Boeing in China. The move comes as China is set to add 6,330 new aircraft worth $950 billion to its commercial fleet by 2034, and Boeing is exploring options to tap into the growing market.

site_title: China committed to market liberalisation: UK Finance Minister
summary: China's authorities remain committed to market liberalisation, said UK Finance Minister George Osborne. This comes after a series of agreements between Britain and China, including a feasibility study for connecting London and Shanghai stock markets. Osborne expressed support for China's efforts, despite volatility in the country's stock markets. The UK and China also agreed on initiatives such as a currency swap agreement and Chinese investment in a British nuclear power.

site_title: Europe: Shares down, Volkswagen extends losses as probe spreads
summary: Volkswagen shares fell 3.3% after South Korea announced it would investigate three of its diesel models, amid a global probe into emissions cheating. The company's shares had previously slumped 20% on Monday. European equities retreated, with the FTSEurofirst 300 index down 0.3% at 1,407.35 points. The probe's spread to Asia and US lawmakers' plans to hold a hearing further weighed on the market.

site_title: Indonesia acts against timber, palm oil firms over haze
summary: Indonesia has revoked the license of a timber supplier and suspended operations of three palm oil plantation operators over fires causing haze in Southeast Asia. The fires, primarily on Sumatra and Borneo islands, have sent smog to neighboring countries, causing thousands to fall ill and reducing visibility. President Joko Widodo has insisted that law-breakers will be punished, with more companies likely to have their licenses suspended. Police have launched investigations and arrested executives, and over 170 individuals are being probed over the fires.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares ended lower on Tuesday with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index slipping 4.1 points to close at 1,635.37. The trading volume was 1.99 billion lots valued at RM1.95 billion, with 322 losers and 424 gainers.

site_title: Shanghai Futures Exchange moves to levy fees on same-day trading
summary: The Shanghai Futures Exchange has started charging fees for same-day trading in nickel, silver, and bitumen futures to curb speculation. Fees range from 6 yuan per contract for nickel to 0.005% of the trade value for silver. Margin requirements and trading bands will also be raised for nickel and bitumen. The move aims to prevent excessive speculation and strengthen regulations, following China's crackdown on market speculation after an equities rout.

site_title: Lee Wei Ling, Lee Hsien Yang start court action over Lee Kuan Yew interviews
summary: Lee Wei Ling and Lee Hsien Yang, the children of late Singapore Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew, have filed a court case to seek guidance on an interview agreement with the government. The agreement, made before Mr Lee's death in March, relates to the custody and use of interviews given to the Oral History Department. The Attorney General's Chambers will establish the proper interpretation and status of the agreement before the court. The executors and trustees of Mr Lee's will, Dr Lee and Mr Lee Hsien Yang, are leading the case.

site_title: VW CEO's history of sweating the details now haunting him
summary: Volkswagen CEO Martin Winterkorn's meticulous attention to detail, once a strength, is now being scrutinized amid a US criminal probe for emissions test cheating. In 2011, Winterkorn inspected a Tennessee factory where he criticized staff for displaying chrome parts in a way that didn't meet his standards. This focus on details, which has been a hallmark of his career, is now seen as a contributing factor to the company's emissions scandal. The probe has raised questions about whether Winterkorn's relentless pursuit of perfection compromised his judgment.

site_title: Lorong Lew Lian site triggered for release from reserve list: URA
summary: A 1.4-hectare 99-year leasehold private housing site in Lorong Lew Lian has been triggered for release from the reserve list, with a developer committing to bid at a minimum price of S$250 million in a public tender. The site can yield an estimated 465 housing units and has a 3.0 plot ratio. The URA will launch the public tender next month, with a four to six-week tender period. The minimum price works out to S$552.93 per square foot of potential gross floor area. The identity of the developer remains undisclosed.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Oil prices dented by uncertain global outlook
summary: Crude oil prices fell on Tuesday, reversing a rally the previous day, due to uncertainty over global demand and the market's possible stabilization. The International Energy Agency (IEA) issued more bullish forecasts for the market balance next year, citing a loss of US oil production. However, uncertainty remains over demand in top consumers like China and the resilience of the US economy. Oil prices are expected to rise gradually in the coming years, according to Capital Economics.

site_title: Osborne says exit from UK's loose monetary policy is coming
summary: Chancellor of the Exchequer George Osborne stated that the UK's exit from loose monetary policy is imminent, citing rising interest rates and inflation pressures. Bank of England Governor Mark Carney previously indicated that rates may increase in early 2016. Osborne sees this as a sign of economic success, while Carney weighs slow inflation against solid labor-market data. The UK's economy is expected to continue growing robustly, leading to the withdrawal of emergency measures.

site_title: New accounting rules to challenge banking industry: ECB's Nouy
summary: The European Central Bank's supervisory chief, Danièle Nouy, warns that the introduction of the new accounting standard IFRS 9 will pose significant challenges for the banking industry, particularly in modeling for expected losses. The rule, which requires banks to provision for losses at the time of loan origination, is set to take effect in 2018. The rule aims to address the slow response of banks to the financial crisis, where soured loans were not adequately covered. The European Union endorsement process is ongoing, with Britain's top banks already expected to comply by 2018.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end higher after US gains
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.18% to close at 21,796.58 following gains in New York, where top Federal Reserve officials reassured dealers about the US economy after interest rate decisions.

site_title: NOL can't explain high volume, except maybe market talk of Temasek selling stake
summary: Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) saw its shares surge 5.7% to S$0.93, driven by a high trading volume of 17.9 million shares, more than double its average. The unusual trading volume comes amid market speculation that Singapore state investment firm Temasek Holdings may be selling its stake in NOL, which it acquired in 2004. NOL confirmed it has not made any decision on a potential sale and is in compliance with listing rules.

site_title: DBS to introduce cashless options through mobile app to F&B outlets in Singapore
summary: DBS is launching a mobile application, FasTrack, to introduce cashless options at hawker centres and quick-serve restaurants in Singapore. The app allows customers to place orders and make payments through a DBS or POSB card, reducing the need for terminals. The service aims to help F&B businesses with manpower crunches and aligns with Singapore's SmartNation and productivity aims. The application has been tested with one outlet and is expected to be rolled out to more restaurants by December at no cost. This move is expected to disrupt the need for cash payments.

site_title: US businesswoman held in China for 'espionage': supporters
summary: A US businesswoman, Sandy Phan-Gillis, has been held in China for six months on alleged espionage charges, sparking concerns about her treatment and the potential impact on US-China relations. Phan-Gillis, a member of a trade delegation from Houston, was detained while crossing the border to Macau and has been denied access to her family, lawyers, and the outside world. Chinese authorities claim they lack sufficient evidence to file charges, but have not released her. Her case raises questions about the treatment of foreign citizens in China and the potential strain on US-China relations during President Xi Jinping's upcoming visit to the US.

site_title: China's Xi says economy within proper range: WSJ
summary: China's President Xi Jinping stated in an interview with the Wall Street Journal that the country's economy is operating within a proper range despite facing downward pressure. Xi emphasized the importance of developing capital markets and vowed to continue exchange rate reforms, citing no basis for sustained yuan depreciation. His comments come ahead of a visit to the United States, where he aims to address market volatility and reassure investors.

site_title: Seoul: Shares rise as local institutions turn net buyers; won down
summary: Seoul shares rose 0.9% to 1,982.06 points, driven by domestic institutions turning net buyers and foreigners reducing their selling. Hyundai Motor Co Ltd and Hyundai Mobis Co Ltd led gains, while Korea Electric Power Corp rose 4.9%. The South Korean won fell 0.4% to 1,179.2 per dollar due to a stronger US dollar.

site_title: UK has highest August budget deficit since 2012 as tax falls
summary: The UK has recorded its highest August budget deficit since 2012, with a deficit of 12.1 billion pounds, exceeding revenue by 12.1 billion pounds. Tax income fell 0.6% and spending rose 1.6% due to higher day-to-day running costs. The deficit is within the target set by Chancellor George Osborne to cut the deficit to 3.7% of GDP by 2020. Economists had forecast a 9.2 billion-pound shortfall.

images.alt_text: British finance minister George Osborne said on Thursday there will come a point when interest rates rise from record low levels in Britain, and that could be interpreted a sign of economic strength.

site_title: Australia: Shares end slightly firmer, China flash PMI eyed
summary: Australian shares ended 0.7% higher at 5,103.6, rebounding from Monday's 2% slide. Oil and gas producers, such as Woodside Petroleum, were among the best performers. The market remains cautious ahead of China's flash PMI survey on Wednesday, which could impact risk appetite. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.2%.

site_title: MAS to regulate gold buyback, landbanking schemes
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) plans to regulate gold buyback schemes as capital markets products, requiring higher hurdles for wealthier accredited investors. Collectively managed investment schemes will also be regulated, restricted to liquid assets and stable income. The new rules will treat primary residences as part of the net worth assessment, limiting contributions to S$1 million. The changes aim to enhance investor protection and clarity.

site_title: De Beers pushes gift-giving to halt China's diamond slowdown
summary: De Beers, the world's largest diamond producer, is shifting its focus to promoting gift-giving in China to counter the country's slowdown in diamond demand. The company plans to boost marketing efforts in China, targeting young women and buyers in smaller cities. This move comes as Chinese demand for diamonds has shrunk 15% this year due to economic and anti-corruption factors. De Beers aims to reverse this trend by emphasizing occasions like weddings and anniversaries, which are becoming increasingly popular for gift-giving in China.

site_title: Indonesia starts legal action against 4 companies linked to SE Asia haze
summary: Indonesia has ordered four companies to suspend operations for causing forest fires that sent smoke across Southeast Asia, affecting Indonesia, Malaysia, and other countries. The companies, including PT Langgam Inti Hibrindo and PT Provident Agro, had their permits or licenses revoked or frozen. The suspensions will remain in effect until the police finish their criminal proceedings. The haze has caused unhealthy pollution levels, with thick smoke blanketing the region in recent weeks.

site_title: China: Stocks extend rise on signs of market stabilisation
summary: China's stocks rose 0.9% for the second day, stabilizing after a mid-June rout, with the CSI300 index reaching 3,339.03. The volatility index has dropped to 40% from an August peak of 64%. Analysts caution that the rebound may be temporary due to high valuations and an unsteady economy. Chinese President Xi Jinping emphasized that developing capital markets is a key goal of China's reforms, unaffected by current market volatility.

images.alt_text: China stocks ended lower on Monday, with the telecoms sector leading declines and as investors remained cautious ahead of a fresh batch of listings.

site_title: Haze worsens as Singapore, parts of Indonesia covered in smog
summary: Haze from Indonesian forest fires worsened, with pollution indices in parts of Indonesia reaching hazardous levels and blanketing downtown Singapore with smog. The pollution index in Palangkaraya reached 1,990.4, while in Pontianak it was 481.64. Singapore's Environment Minister Vivian Balakrishnan urged enforcement of laws against plantation owners to resolve the haze. Indonesia set deadlines to extinguish fires and detained suspects, with coordinating minister Luhut Panjaitan vowing to take firm action against concession holders involved in forest fires.

images.alt_text: The haze from Indonesian forest fires intensified Tuesday afternoon, driving the pollution gauge in parts of the country to hazardous levels and blanketing downtown Singapore with a layer of smog.

site_title: Europe's airlines spruce up their jet fuel hedges
summary: European airlines are hedging more of their fuel needs due to the collapse in oil prices, with those that kept their powder dry emerging as clear winners. Airlines like Norwegian Air Shuttle have hedged 23% of their fuel needs for the rest of 2015 and 28% for 2016, while others, such as Air Berlin, have been negatively impacted by falling prices due to large hedges at higher rates. Hedging strategies differ, with some airlines opting for options contracts to access lower prices, and industry sources expect carriers to hedge larger amounts of fuel and further out into the future.

images.alt_text: European airlines are exploiting a collapse in oil prices by hedging more of their fuel needs further into the future, but those that kept their powder dry before the rout are emerging as clear winners, industry sources say.

site_title: Indonesia to borrow US$4.2b from World bank, ADB to cover budget deficit: govt official
summary: Indonesia plans to borrow US$4.2 billion from the World Bank and Asian Development Bank to cover its widening budget deficit. The loans will strengthen the country's forex reserves, which fell to US$103 billion, and will also allow Indonesia to issue foreign currency bonds in 2016. The move aims to address market volatility and slow economic growth.

site_title: Seoul summons VW over 'cheating' emissions tests
summary: South Korea summoned Volkswagen representatives to discuss emissions tests after the German auto giant was accused of cheating on US air pollution standards. The US EPA found Volkswagen fitted diesel vehicles with software that turned on pollution controls only during testing, resulting in excessive emissions. About 59,000 affected models are on the road in South Korea, and the government will conduct tests starting next month. Punitive measures against Volkswagen are uncertain until test results are available, with potential fines totaling up to $18 billion.

site_title: Oil price rally reverses as dollar ticks higher
summary: Oil prices fell in Asia, reversing sharp gains from the previous session, due to a strong US dollar and concerns over a global supply glut. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate eased 39 cents to $46.29, while Brent crude for November dipped 37 cents to $48.55. A resurgent US dollar makes dollar-priced oil more expensive for holders of weaker currencies, hurting demand and prices. Analysts believe Monday's price rebound was a technical correction, and traders are monitoring Iran's compliance under a nuclear deal with western powers.

site_title: Asia: Shares rise, dollar firm on Fed, ECB views
summary: Asian shares rose on Tuesday, driven by the US markets' rebound and the European Central Bank's readiness to ease monetary policy. The dollar held steady, while the euro gained 0.1% to US$1.12. Chinese shares extended gains, but economists caution that a weak September factory PMI could derail optimism. Oil prices slipped, and investors await the euro zone's flash manufacturing activity reading on Wednesday.

site_title: Asian currencies retreat as talk of Fed rate hike returns
summary: Asian currencies retreated as US Federal Reserve officials hinted at a potential interest rate hike within the year, sparking concerns of capital outflows from emerging markets. Despite a previous decision to hold off a rate increase last week, Fed comments by officials including Atlanta Fed president Dennis Lockhart and James Bullard injected fresh vigor into the dollar, which rose against major Asian currencies. Markets are now watching the Fed's next two meetings in October and December for a potential decision on a rate hike, which could impact regional currencies and global markets.

site_title: 1MDB objects to Malaysian central bank chief's rebuke on ringgit
summary: Malaysia's 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB) has objected to comments by central bank Governor Zeti Akhtar Aziz, who said the company's issues could help bolster the ringgit currency. 1MDB disputed the claim, stating it's not responsible for the ringgit's weakness, which has been Asia's worst-performer in the past 12 months. The central bank had sought to distance itself from the controversy surrounding 1MDB and allegations against Prime Minister Najib Razak, with the US Justice Department starting an investigation into corruption associated with the premier.

site_title: Australia: Shares stage modest rebound, New Zealand firmer as well
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% to 5,093.2, rebounding from a 2% drop on Monday, as investors trimmed excessive bearishness. The big four banks and oil and gas producers were winners, while the dairy sector saw gains after Synlait Milk reported expected lactoferrin sales to nearly double next year. New Zealand's benchmark NZX 50 index was slightly firmer, but lacked conviction due to diverging interest rate outlooks.

site_title: China govt think tank says economy may grow 6.9% this year: state media
summary: China's economic growth is expected to slow to 6.9% this year, according to a report from the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, citing falling investment and growing debt pressures. The slowdown is attributed to a demographic window where China's working-age population is peaking, leading to a contraction of the labor force. The report urges policymakers to rein in overspending, diversify fiscal revenue, and implement tax cuts to address regional imbalances. This growth forecast is lower than the government's target of 7% and may put pressure on policymakers to address the economic slowdown.

site_title: China's Communist Party sacks assistant chairman of stock regulator
summary: China's Communist Party has sacked the assistant chairman of the country's securities regulator, Zhang Yujun, amid a graft probe. The move comes days after Zhang was announced as the subject of an investigation for "serious violation of discipline." This is the first CSRC official to face investigation amid the country's ongoing stock market turmoil, which began in June.

site_title: Gold retains losses as firmer dollar, stocks dent safe-haven demand
summary: Gold prices steadied below a near three-week high on Tuesday as investors worried about a potential US interest rate hike later this year. The dollar edged higher, and Asian equities rose, reducing demand for safe-haven assets. Spot gold remained at US$1,133.01 an ounce, after a 0.5% drop on Monday. Federal Reserve officials signaled a possible rate hike, citing "a powerful case to be made" for tightening policy, and investors await comments from Fed Chair Janet Yellen on Thursday.

site_title: Australia home prices jump the most in 5 years in Q2, Sydney surges
summary: Australia's home prices surged 4.7% in Q2, the largest quarterly gain in over 5 years, driven by a 8.9% increase in Sydney, the country's fastest growth since 2003. The mean home price in New South Wales rose to A$777,400, the highest in the country. However, cities in resource-rich states like Western Australia experienced declines as the mining boom fades. Regulatory measures introduced to tighten mortgage lending to investors appear to be taking effect, with Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Glenn Stevens stating they are doing their job to contain leverage.

site_title: Recurrent audit deficiencies found in smaller audit firms: Acra
summary: Singapore's Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA) has found recurring audit deficiencies in smaller audit firms auditing non-listed companies. The report, released on Tuesday, noted improvements in larger firms and greater emphasis on audit quality. However, smaller firms were found to have recurring issues with revenue recognition, fair value measurements, and construction contracts. ACRA urged these firms to adopt best practices and increase staff-to-client ratios to maintain audit quality. The regulator plans to step up enforcement actions and explore public reporting of audit findings.

site_title: Citi ties up with EZ-Link on ERP payment solution for corporate clients
summary: Citibank has partnered with EZ-Link to offer a business-to-business payment solution for Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) and Electronic Parking System (EPS) fees. The EZ-Reload Corporate Service allows companies to link their EZ-Link cards to their Citibank commercial card accounts, enabling automatic top-ups and eliminating unwarranted spending. Up to 1,000 EZ-Link cards can be linked, with administrative fees waived starting November 1, 2015. The service provides greater convenience, cost savings, and ease in managing corporate fleets, and offers detailed usage reports for account reconciliation and route tracking purposes.

images.alt_text: Citibank Singapore on Tuesday announced a partnership with EZ-Link to offer a seamless automatic top-up solution for the payment of Electronic Parking System (EPS) parking fees and Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) gantry fees for its commercial card customers.

site_title: LTA awards S$137m rail contract to Japanese-Chinese consortium
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has awarded a contract worth S$136.8 million to a Japanese-Chinese consortium, comprising Kawasaki Heavy Industries and CSR Qingdao Sifang Co, for the purchase of 12 new six-car trains for the North-South and East-West Lines in Singapore. The trains will feature tip-up seats and commuter-centric features, and are expected to arrive in early 2018. This is the final batch of 57 new trains that will be put into service from 2016 to 2019, increasing the overall train fleet size by nearly 50%.

site_title: Australia's major banks pull plug on bitcoin companies
summary: Australia's major banks, including Commonwealth Bank and National Australia Bank, have closed accounts of bitcoin companies, forcing 13 providers out of business due to stricter anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing rules. The move follows Westpac's exit from the remittances business in June. The Australian government has called for clearer regulation of digital currencies, and seven percent of the world's bitcoin worth $5 billion is in circulation in Australia. The affected companies, including BitTrade and Buyabitcoin, are seeking a solution with the banks and government.

site_title: Ringgit adds to declines as new 1MDB probes compound losses
