summary: The Malaysian ringgit declined further after the US Justice Department launched an investigation into alleged corruption associated with Prime Minister Najib Razak and his associates. The probe focuses on US properties linked to Najib's stepson and money in the prime minister's personal bank account, sparking a surge in debt insurance costs. The ringgit has weakened 24% in the past year, reaching a 17-year low this month, amid plunging commodity prices and a looming US interest rate hike.

images.alt_text: The ringgit added to Monday's decline after the New York Times reported the US Justice Department has started an investigation into allegations of corruption associated with Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak and people close to him.

site_title: US tells China cyber espionage is more than an irritant, must stop
summary: US National Security Adviser Susan Rice warned China that state-sponsored cyber espionage must stop, calling it a national security concern and a factor in US-China relations. Rice stated that cyber-enabled espionage undermines long-term economic cooperation and must cease. The warning comes ahead of President Xi Jinping's visit to the White House this week, where the two leaders are expected to have an intense discussion on the issue.

images.alt_text: US national security adviser Susan Rice issued a stern warning to China on Monday before President Xi Jinping's visit that state-sponsored cyber espionage must stop, calling it a national security concern and a critical factor in US-China relations.

site_title: Singapore launches cluster for 3D printing
summary: Singapore has launched the National Additive Manufacturing Innovation Cluster (Namic), a 3D printing cluster aimed at boosting the nation's manufacturing sector. Led by Nanyang Technological University, the cluster will facilitate collaboration between research institutes and industry practitioners, providing access to incubators, intellectual property, and a joint fund to support translational projects. The initiative is part of the S$200 million Innovation Cluster Programme announced in 2013, with additive manufacturing as one of the four key tech areas for development.

site_title: Temasek to invest in new venture capital fund
summary: Temasek Holdings has committed US$65 million to a new US$100 million venture capital fund by Jungle Ventures, which will invest in 20 technology startups. The fund expects to invest US$3-6 million per company. This is part of Jungle Ventures' previous funding round, which saw three exits, including Twitter's acquisition of ZipDial. The fund aims to close in three months with other investors including the National Research Foundation of Singapore and family offices.

site_title: ADB revises down regional growth as China and India slow
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has revised down its regional growth forecast due to weaker growth in China, citing a slowdown in the rest of Asia. China's economic slowdown is attributed to the surprise devaluation of its yuan currency and concerns over its economic management. The ADB also warned central banks to prepare for a potential Federal Reserve interest rate rise, amid capital outflows from Asia to safer US investments.

images.alt_text: Weaker growth in China this year is expected to cause a slowdown in the rest of Asia, the Asian Development Bank said Tuesday as it became the latest major body to revise down its forecasts for the world's number two economy.

site_title: Tsipras to form cabinet, push EU on migration after election win
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras will form a new coalition cabinet to implement economic reforms after his party, Syriza, won a majority in the election. Tsipras called on Europe to help address the nation's migration challenge, stating that "Europe...must share out responsibility among all member states." The EU has pledged support, but also reminded Greece to enforce reforms set out in a rescue package worth up to $136 billion. Tsipras must now prepare for a review of the package in October and finalize economic reforms, including tax hikes and pension changes, to secure a new tranche of aid.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai stocks open higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.17% to 21,794.34 on Tuesday, following a pick-up in Wall Street. Shanghai extended gains, adding 0.15% to 3,161.32. Analysts warn gains may be capped by lingering global economic concerns.

site_title: Seoul: Shares edge up, helped by automakers; won falls
summary: Seoul shares rose 0.3% to 1,970.16 points, driven by gains in automakers Hyundai Motor and Kia Motors, while institutional and foreign selling weighed on the main board. Hyundai Motor rose 3.8%, Kia Motors 3.5%, and Hyundai Glovis 4.4%. The won fell 0.1% against the dollar, but analysts expect limited losses due to exporters' demand for settlements around 1,180.

site_title: China turns to Islamic finance to expand economic clout
summary: China is expanding its economic influence abroad through Islamic finance, strengthening ties with Muslim-majority countries and Chinese companies tapping offshore Islamic funds. China's "One Belt, One Road" strategy aims to build stronger trade ties with Asia and Europe, with Islamic finance playing a key role. Chinese companies, including state-owned enterprises and private firms, are exploring Islamic financing options, including a $150 million deal to buy ships and a potential sukuk issuance by a railway project. However, hurdles remain, including stiff competition from domestic banks and a steep learning curve for Chinese firms in Islamic finance.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares opens lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Tuesday, down 0.4 points to 1639.07. The market saw a volume of 93.4 million lots worth RM36.88 million, with gainers outnumbering losers 135 to 57.

site_title: 27-year-old British national charged with crossing F1 race track on Sunday
summary: A 27-year-old British national, Yogvitam Pravin Dhokia, has been charged with a rash act for crossing the Singapore Airlines Singapore Grand Prix track on Sunday during the F1 race. No plea was taken from Dhokia in court on Tuesday. The incident occurred while the race was in progress.

images.alt_text: Yogvitam Pravin Dhokia, who allegedly committed a rash act on Sept 20 to endanger safety of F1 drivers in the Singapore Grand Prix, was charged on Tuesday.

site_title: Chinese maker of Victoria's Secret bras launches up to US$243m HK IPO
summary: Regina Miracle International, a Chinese lingerie manufacturer, launched a US$243 million Hong Kong IPO to fund increased output and debt reduction. The company, which makes lingerie for Victoria's Secret and Calvin Klein, is offering up to 295 million new shares in an indicative range of HK$5.38 to HK$6.38 each. This would value the company at up to HK$1.88 billion. The IPO aims to support the company's growth and debt repayment.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks up with overseas markets but caution ahead of central bank meeting
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.3% to 8,330.48 on Tuesday, following overseas markets, amid expectations of a rate cut by the central bank's quarterly policy meeting on Thursday. The move was partly driven by bargain hunting after Monday's 1.8% decline, but was capped by uncertainties ahead of the meeting. The data also showed a significant drop in August export orders, which could lead to a contraction in third-quarter GDP, according to economists.

site_title: Most Asian stocks advance as consumer, material companies rally
summary: Asian stocks rose, with consumer and material shares leading gains, as US equities rebounded. The MSCI Asia Pacific Excluding Japan Index was little changed. Japan's markets were closed for a holiday. Interest-rate futures indicate traders remain skeptical of a US rate hike in 2015. China's Shanghai Composite Index gained 1.9% on Monday, extending its advance, amid speculation of increased orders following President Xi Jinping's US visit.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Jasper, Tiger, International Healthway, Magnus, Q&M
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

Several companies made significant announcements on Monday. Jasper Investment was acquired by Triton No 9 Pte Ltd and Polaris Nine LLP, which took a 80.77% stake in the vessel management outfit. Tiger Airways and Cebu Pacific secured approval for a strategic alliance, enhancing connectivity between their networks. International Healthway Corporation announced the acquisition of Healthway Medical Corporation, with IHC shareholders set to receive new shares. Soilbuild Construction won a tender for a 30-year land lease at Airport Road, with plans to invest S$50 million in a construction hub. Magnus Energy and Q&M Dental Group also made notable announcements.

site_title: South Korea to probe VW, Audi diesel car emissions
summary: South Korea will investigate emissions of three VW and Audi diesel cars after Volkswagen admitted rigging emissions tests on US diesel vehicles. The probe will cover 4,000-5,000 vehicles, including Jetta and Golf models and Audi's A3, and may expand to all German diesel imports if problems are found. The investigation may lead to a recall and could hurt demand for VW and Audi cars in South Korea, benefiting local brands like Hyundai and Kia. The US Environmental Protection Agency has already started a probe, with penalties of up to $18 billion possible.

site_title: Indonesia central bank not worried if forex reserves drop below US$100b
summary: Indonesia's central bank governor, Agus Martowardojo, stated he's not concerned if the country's foreign exchange reserves drop below US$100 billion, citing it as a monetary instrument. Reserves had fallen to US$103 billion from US$105.35 billion at the end of last month. The central bank uses reserves to defend the weakening rupiah, which hit a 17-year low earlier this week.

site_title: Australians welcome new PM Turnbull, poll shows
summary: New Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull received widespread approval from voters, with a Newspoll showing 55% of voters rating him as their preferred prime minister. This is the highest rating for a prime minister in over five years. Turnbull's popularity is 18 points above Tony Abbott's, and support for Labor leader Bill Shorten has almost halved. The new government has indicated it will serve out its three-year term, but a possible early election could be brought forward in the coming months.

site_title: Volkswagen crashes 22% after it admits to cheating on emissions tests
summary: Volkswagen's shares plummeted 22% to 126.40 euros after admitting to cheating on US air pollution tests, risking billions in fines and damaging its reputation. The company faces potential fines of $18 billion and may see top management face consequences. CEO Martin Winterkorn apologized and ordered an external investigation, but his leadership is now under threat. The company has halted sales of affected models, which could result in a loss of US sales and a hit to its long-term prospects.

site_title: ANZ's Asia strategy in focus as CEO Smith heads for retirement
summary: ANZ, Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, is shifting its focus from Asia to improved returns, amid speculation the bank may retreat from the region. Despite being the largest single market share of new Australian home loans in August, ANZ ranks 9th in Asia Pacific ex-Japan. CEO Mike Smith, who kick-started the bank's Asia strategy in 2007, will retire within the year. Investors have concerns about the bank's ability to meet its goal to garner 25-30% of profit from outside Australia, citing low margins and high costs in Asia.

site_title: Lew says China should roll out fiscal stimulus to buoy consumers
summary: US Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew has urged China's leadership to implement targeted fiscal stimulus to boost consumption and support economic growth. With China's economy expected to slow, Lew called for fiscal measures to be focused on the consumer, aiming to transform the country's model away from debt-fueled investment. He also emphasized the need for the yuan to be allowed to move freely, driven by upward pressure, to alleviate concerns about competitive devaluation. Lew's comments come ahead of Chinese President Xi Jinping's US visit, highlighting the need for China's policymakers to take action to stabilize the economy.

site_title: Firm commitment to uphold high standards
summary: The Securities Investors Association (Singapore) is hosting the 6th Singapore Corporate Governance Week 2015 from October 12-16. A statement of support for good corporate governance has been signed by 54 companies, including China Aviation Oil, First Reit, Frasers Centrepoint, and Thai Beverage. The statement emphasizes the importance of upholding high standards of corporate governance to enhance shareholder value and contribute to the stability of the financial markets. The week-long programme is endorsed by the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority, the Singapore Accountancy Commission, and the Singapore Exchange.

images.alt_text: Joining the initiative are Meng Fanqiu of China Aviation Oil (Singapore) (above), Ronnie Tan of First Reit, Lim Ee Seng of Frasers Centrepoint, Or Toh Wat of OKP Holdings and Thapana Sirivadhanabhakdi of Thai Beverage

Joining the initiative are Meng Fanqiu of China Aviation Oil (Singapore), Ronnie Tan of First Reit (above), Lim Ee Seng of Frasers Centrepoint, Or Toh Wat of OKP Holdings and Thapana Sirivadhanabhakdi of Thai Beverage

Joining the initiative are Meng Fanqiu of China Aviation Oil (Singapore), Ronnie Tan of First Reit, Lim Ee Seng of Frasers Centrepoint (above), Or Toh Wat of OKP Holdings and Thapana Sirivadhanabhakdi of Thai Beverage

Joining the initiative are Meng Fanqiu of China Aviation Oil (Singapore), Ronnie Tan of First Reit, Lim Ee Seng of Frasers Centrepoint, Or Toh Wat of OKP Holdings (above) and Thapana Sirivadhanabhakdi of Thai Beverage

Joining the initiative are Meng Fanqiu of China Aviation Oil (Singapore), Ronnie Tan of First Reit, Lim Ee Seng of Frasers Centrepoint, Or Toh Wat of OKP Holdings and Thapana Sirivadhanabhakdi of Thai Beverage (above)

site_title: Singapore's Second Retail Productivity Plan will focus on powering sales growth: minister (Amended)
summary: Singapore's Second Retail Productivity Plan aims to drive sales growth by supporting retailers in e-commerce, branding, and concept innovation over the next five years. The plan, launched on September 22, 2015, will focus on operational efficiency improvements through technology adoption, such as self-checkout systems and electronic shelf-labelling. The plan builds on the first five-year plan launched in 2011, with a goal to deepen transformation and bring on board slower-to-adapt retailers, ultimately aiming to maintain the sector's 5% workforce share and 1% GDP contribution.

images.alt_text: Driving sales growth is a key priority in the government's Second Retail Productivity Plan, said Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Lee Yi Shyan on Tuesday morning.

site_title: ADB sees slower growth for Asia, China in 2015, 2016
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has lowered its growth forecast for developing Asia to 5.8% and 6.0% for 2015 and 2016, respectively, due to China's slowing economy. East Asia's growth is expected to be 6.0% this year and next, down from 6.2%. The ADB urges policymakers to strengthen financial-system buffers against external shocks, particularly in the face of potential capital outflows ahead of a US Federal Reserve interest rate hike.

images.alt_text: Growth in developing Asia will likely be slower than previously thought as a slowdown in China's economy hurts demand, the Asian Development Bank said.

site_title: China could dodge Fed bullet, but Malaysia in the firing line
summary: The US Federal Reserve's decision not to raise interest rates may provide temporary relief for China, but Malaysia is at risk of a negative impact on its economy. Malaysia's high debt-to-GDP ratio and significant currency fluctuations make it vulnerable to financial tightening, which could disrupt growth. The country's economy expanded the least in almost two years in the second quarter, and private consumption is expected to moderate due to a new consumption tax and uncertain economic environment.

images.alt_text: When the US Federal Reserve last week opted against its first rate hike in nine years, governments around Asia breathed a sigh of relief.

site_title: Asean firms to face tighter, costlier funding over next two years: S&P
summary: Standard & Poor's (S&P) predicts that ASEAN companies will face tighter and costlier funding over the next 12-24 months due to currency depreciation and rising interest rates. Lending costs are already increasing, and most companies rely on short-term, floating-rate financing. S&P notes that companies' balance sheets have deteriorated, making credit risk and return assessments more challenging. This forecast marks a turn-around from the post-global financial crisis era of abundant and cheap funds. Companies will likely continue to raise funds from bank lending, with bond funding becoming a secondary source.

site_title: Apple revving work on electric car
summary: Apple plans to release an electric car by 2019, according to a Wall Street Journal report. The project, code-named Titan, will have a team of 1,800 people and initially feature a manual driving system. Apple has been hiring talent away from Tesla to boost the effort and has met with the California DMV to discuss self-driving car regulations. The company's interest in autonomous vehicles is not new, with reports of partnerships with Google and traditional auto makers also in the works.

site_title: Foxconn asks Apple to join bid to buy Sharp's LCD ops: report
summary: Taiwanese electronics giant Foxconn has proposed taking over Sharp's display business, with Apple urged to join the deal. Foxconn, an Apple supplier, would take a majority stake in Sharp's LCD operations worth around $3.5 billion, and Apple is considering an investment. Sharp, struggling with deficits and competition, is selling assets and restructuring to cut costs. The proposal aims to give Sharp an opportunity to offload operations with heavy downside risk while avoiding massive layoffs.

site_title: Weary Greeks brace for more economic pain after Tsipras win
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras was sworn in on Monday, taking a mandate to drive through unpopular austerity reforms with international creditors. Tsipras' Syriza party secured a narrow majority, but will have to form a coalition with the nationalist Independent Greeks party. The new government faces a tough economic agenda, including raising taxes and rewriting economic rules. A lenders' review in October will assess whether Greece is abiding by the cash-for-reforms program, with the release of a new aid tranche at stake. Tsipras has pledged to soften the edges of the bailout to help Greece's poorest citizens.

images.alt_text: Weary Greece braced for more painful austerity Monday as Alexis Tsipras was sworn in as prime minister with a mandate to drive through unpopular reforms agreed with the nation's international creditors.

site_title: Dollar gains on rate hike hopes
summary: The US dollar advanced against major currencies on Monday following comments from Federal Reserve officials indicating a potential interest rate hike in 2015. The dollar's gain was driven by hawkish remarks from St. Louis Fed president James Bullard and Richmond president Jeffrey Lacker. Despite the Fed's decision to leave the benchmark federal funds rate at zero, the dollar strengthened against the euro, which fell to $1.1195. Market expectations are now focused on the European Central Bank's potential quantitative easing program, which could impact the euro's value.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Tuesday in Wall St's footsteps
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened higher on Tuesday, rising 11.13 points or 0.39% to 2,893.40, following the Dow and S&P 500's rally on Monday. The Dow Jones Industrial Average surged 125.61 points (0.77%) and the S&P 500 rose 8.94 points (0.46%). Asian markets, including Japan, were closed for a public holiday. Singapore's STI gained due to the inclusion of new stocks, including SATS, UOL, and Yangzijiang, replacing Jardine group stocks.

site_title: UK pledges £2b for Hinkley Point nuclear plant project
summary: The UK has pledged £2 billion (S$4.4 billion) for the Hinkley Point nuclear plant project in England, a consortium led by French energy company EDF, in partnership with Chinese firms China General Nuclear Corporation and China National Nuclear Corporation. The plant, expected to generate 7% of Britain's electricity, aims to meet the country's energy needs as older coal and nuclear plants are retired. The funding pledge was announced by Chancellor George Osborne during a visit to China, with a final decision on investment expected this year, potentially influenced by a visit from Chinese President Xi Jinping next month.

site_title: Indonesia president to visit White House next month
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo is set to visit the White House on October 26, marking his first visit since becoming president last year. The trip aims to strengthen bilateral cooperation between the US and Indonesia, particularly in the South China Sea, where Indonesia plays a crucial role. The visit comes as US President Barack Obama presses Jakarta to take a more prominent role in regional affairs. The meeting will focus on expanding existing areas of cooperation, including economic relationships and addressing concerns about climate change.

site_title: Dollar regains mojo as 2015 Fed hike view stays intact
summary: The US dollar regained its momentum, hovering near a two-week high, as traders regained confidence in a potential interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve later this year. The dollar index rose 2% from its trough on Friday, while the euro and yen fell against the greenback. Analysts attribute the rebound to rising US yields and comments from Fed officials keeping expectations for a rate hike alive. The market now awaits Fed Chair Janet Yellen's speech on Thursday for further clarity on the Fed's decision-making process.

site_title: After delay, Yellen faces questions over Fed message on rate hike
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen faces pressure to clarify the central bank's stance on a potential rate hike amid growing confusion among her colleagues, market analysts, and investors. Despite forecasts showing 13 policymakers expect a rate hike this year, a delay was prompted by market volatility and perceived contradictions in the Fed's communication. Yellen's speech on Thursday may provide insight into her position, and analysts expect her to clarify the Fed's intentions to address market uncertainty and stabilize the global economy.

site_title: Rate hike delayed because risks had "ratcheted up": Fed's Lockhart
summary: The Federal Reserve's decision to delay a rate hike last week was driven by concerns over market volatility and its potential impact on the US economy. Atlanta Fed President Dennis Lockhart said the delay was a "risk management" exercise, and he still expects the Fed to hike rates later this year. Lockhart cited the economy's progress on employment and inflation, but noted that the Fed needs more certainty on global risks. He expects to vote in favor of a rate hike in a "coming" meeting, but emphasized the need for prudent risk management.

site_title: Greece's bonds rise as bailout seen secure after Syriza's win
summary: Greece's 10-year government bonds rose to 8.27% after Alexis Tsipras and Syriza won the election for the second time in eight months, securing a bailout. The outcome is seen as more stable for Greece, but investors still have concerns over how successful reforms can be. The yield on Greece's government notes due in 2017 dropped 36 basis points to 10.45%. The new government will implement austerity measures, including tax reforms, which could impact the economy and daily life for Greeks.

site_title: US: Stocks rise but biotech dents Nasdaq gain
summary: US stocks rose on Monday, with the Dow and S&P 500 rallying 125.61 and 8.94 points respectively, but the Nasdaq Composite Index was limited by biotech shares' decline. Biogen and Gilead Sciences fell 5.6% and 2.5% respectively after Hillary Clinton's pledge to address rising specialty drug prices. Other sectors, such as tech, finance, and semiconductor companies, showed gains.

site_title: Ride-sharing apps vie to replace private car ownership in Vietnam
summary: Ride-sharing apps Uber and GrabTaxi are experiencing double-digit growth in Vietnam due to the country's young, tech-savvy population and limited car ownership. The apps offer affordable and reliable services, with Uber charging 8,000 dong per kilometer compared to taxis' 11,000-15,000 dong. Executives, including Uber's general manager for Vietnam, aim to replace private car ownership, citing the convenience and affordability of ride-sharing services. Local cab firms are also launching smartphone apps to compete, but policymakers are still working out how to regulate the industry.

site_title: India's growth expected to top last year's, minimal China impact seen
summary: India's economy is expected to grow faster this year than last, with minimal impact from China's slowdown. Finance Minister Arun Jaitley attributed the slowdown to global market volatility, which has slowed down the government's privatisation programme. India's economy grew 7.3% last year and aims for 8-10% annual growth. The slowdown in China has led to weaker oil and commodity prices, making India a potential alternative investment destination. Jaitley also announced a draft of India's bankruptcy law is almost ready for submission to parliament.

site_title: Tougher to window-dress STI with Jardine departure
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) removed Jardine Matheson Holdings (JMH) and Jardine Strategic Holdings (JSH) for the first time in nearly two decades due to new liquidity rules. The two stocks, along with Olam International, were replaced by SATS, UOL Group, and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, which performed well on their debut. Analysts believe the change will lead to improved liquidity and potentially encourage the development of more STI-based instruments, making the index more meaningful for fund managers.

site_title: Asia: Short-term bumps on a long-term growth path
summary: Singapore's asset management industry is expected to benefit from the opening of Korea's National Pension Service's (NPS) office in the city-state, marking the third overseas office in Asia after New York and London. This move affirms Asia's long-term growth prospects despite recent market volatility and moderation in growth. The region's economies are expected to continue growing, albeit at a slower pace, driven by favorable demographics, a growing middle class, and ongoing urbanization. Emerging Asia is seen as a key destination for diversified investment portfolios, offering both asset and geographical diversification and potential for higher long-term returns.

site_title: Vale leads Brazil's iron ore expansion with largest project
summary: Brazil's Vale is expanding its iron ore operations with the S11D project, the largest in its history, valued at $17 billion. The 1,000-kilometer project will increase production by 90 million tonnes, making Vale the world's number one iron ore producer. The expanded port will handle 230 million tonnes per year and is on track for completion in the second half of 2026. The project aims to reduce costs in a market where prices have halved since last year, and analysts express concern about the impact on the global market, citing oversupply from Australian rivals.

site_title: Kickstarter makes itself legally bound to pursue public benefit
summary: Kickstarter has reincorporated as a Public Benefit Corporation, legally committing to pursue social values alongside profit. The move follows similar changes by Patagonia and This American Life, requiring companies to prioritize positive societal impact. Founded in 2009, Kickstarter will now be known as Kickstarter PBC and will take a percentage of funds raised for projects. The company aims to join forces with socially responsible businesses and align its goals with those of its investors.

site_title: China rate cuts bypass business heart of economy
summary: China's central bank has cut interest rates to boost economic growth, but the move may bypass the country's struggling small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), which account for 80% of urban employment and 60% of GDP. The financial infrastructure is geared towards state firms, leaving SMEs with limited access to credit. This has exacerbated their struggles, with business conditions worsening despite government efforts to stimulate the economy. The rate cuts are aimed at stimulating investment and consumption, but their impact on SMEs remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: Small and medium enterprises (SMEs) are already the heart of China's economy, providing 80 per cent of urban employment and 60 per cent of GDP. But the country's financial infrastructure is largely geared to state firms.

site_title: Singapore seeds another S$40m to power economic transformation
summary: Singapore has allocated S$40 million for the Early-Stage Venture Fund (ESVF-III), a government initiative to boost the startup ecosystem and facilitate the growth of high-tech innovative companies. The fund will invest in venture-capital (VC) funds investing in early-stage tech startups in Singapore, aiming to develop tech ecosystems around large local enterprises. This move is part of the government's "Smart Nation" initiative to leverage technology for economic and social development, and to create a highly networked ecosystem.

images.alt_text: Dr Vivian Balakrishnan, who was at the opening of Techventure 2015 on Monday, takes in a demonstration of AIT Technologies' DigiQuinTM technology, which enables shoppers to try on clothing digitally through a digital mannequin.

site_title: The rage of the bankers
summary: The US Federal Reserve chose not to raise interest rates last week, and the author argues it was the right decision. The financial industry's reaction, however, suggests a different motive - bankers' profits. The author suggests that low rates are bad for bankers, as their net-interest margin has fallen sharply over the past five years. The author believes that the clamour for higher rates has nothing to do with the public interest, but rather with the influence of bankers and their interests. The Fed's decision was a demonstration of its commitment to the public interest, rather than catering to the financial industry's demands.

site_title: US and India begin high-level commercial talks
summary: US and Indian senior officials began a high-level "strategic and commercial dialog" ahead of US Prime Minister Narendra Modi's visit, aiming to boost trade and inward investment. The two nations' trade reached over $100 billion in 2015, with Modi's administration seeking to multiply this by five. India's rapidly growing economy, driven by services, requires US capital and technology, while the US is interested in Indian market opportunities. The talks aim to establish a framework for cooperation and growth.

site_title: Hong Kong's property market seen defying dire predictions
summary: Hong Kong's property market is defying dire predictions, with experts predicting a slower pace of growth rather than a repeat of the 1997 six-year slump. Healthy borrower finances and domestic demand for housing support this outlook, according to Deutsche Bank's Michael Spencer and other property experts. A major political upheaval in China is the only factor that could disrupt the decade-long property bull market.

site_title: Dollar well above Friday's post-Fed decision low
summary: The US dollar recovered against the yen and euro on Monday, reaching a 4-week high of 95.319 against a basket of six major currencies. This follows the Federal Reserve's decision not to raise interest rates, as investors weigh the possibility of monetary easing by the European Central Bank and Bank of Japan. The euro fell to a 4-week low of $1.1280, while the dollar was 0.3% higher at 120.40 yen. Analysts expect the dollar to continue to rise as traders await potential monetary stimulus from the ECB and BOJ.

site_title: Bank of America's Moynihan faces shareholder vote
summary: Bank of America CEO Brian Moynihan faces a shareholder vote on Tuesday to determine whether he will retain his title as chairman. The decision was made in 2014, despite a 2009 vote requiring the chairman to be an independent director. Analysts expect a narrow win for Moynihan, with institutional investors likely to sway the outcome. Critics argue that the decision creates a conflict of interest, while supporters claim it was necessary for the bank's stability. A narrow win for Moynihan would be a setback for the bank's governance.

site_title: Allegedly underpaid 7-Eleven staff fear to speak out in Australia
summary: Allegations of underpayment and exploitation of 7-Eleven staff in Australia have led to a visa amnesty being required for affected staff to come forward, lawyers said. The independent panel investigating the claims is being hindered by the fear of deportation for staff on student visas, which prohibit working more than 20 hours a week. Nearly 100 complainants have already come forward, with thousands more potentially affected, as the company faces similar accusations in North America.

site_title: Sembcorp Ind eyes S$350m gain from sale of stake in JV
summary: Sembcorp Industries expects to gain S$350 million from the sale of a 40% stake in an Australian waste management joint venture to Suez Environnement Asia. The sale is expected to boost earnings per share and net tangible asset per share. The divestment is set to be completed by Q4 2015, subject to regulatory approvals. The gain will be channeled into high-growth businesses and markets in the energy and water sectors for FY15.

site_title: Swiss home vacancies at 14-year high, cities still 'strained'
summary: Switzerland's home vacancies reached a 14-year high, with 51,172 empty apartments as of June 1, resulting in a 1.19% vacancy rate. This represents a 12% increase from the previous year. The annual census reported by the Federal Statistics Office indicates that cities are still experiencing strain due to the high number of empty apartments.

site_title: Infrastructure spending in Indonesia picks up
summary: Indonesia's infrastructure spending has begun to pick up, driven by the government's efforts to boost capital spending and jump-start the country's largest economy. Cement sales and imports of capital goods have surged, supporting shares of construction firms and other infrastructure-linked companies. The basic industry sector has risen 3.6% in the past month, outperforming the main index. The government's capital spending has increased from 14% to 25% in August, with annual cement sales likely increasing by 15% in the same month. This growth is expected to continue into 2016, with a strong rebound anticipated.

site_title: New investors buying out Jasper Investment (Amended)
summary: Two new investors, Triton No 9 Pte Ltd and Polaris Nine LLP, have acquired over 80% of Jasper Investment, a vessel management and operations outfit, for $1.25 million. The acquisition valued shares at $0.0004 per share. Triton will also extend a $870,000 loan with a 9% annual interest rate to tide over Jasper's working capital requirements. The takeover bid comes after Jasper reported a $26.15 million loss after tax for the first quarter.

site_title: Glencore production cuts fail to boost copper
summary: Glencore, the world's second-largest refined copper producer, has cut copper output by 20% over 18 months in an effort to reduce debt and protect its credit rating. Despite this, copper prices remain near a six-year low due to concerns over China's slowing growth, which accounts for 40% of global demand. Analysts expect further production cuts and potential price increases to copper above $5,700 a tonne by the fourth quarter, driven by supply constraints and improving China's property market.

site_title: Fed held hostage to markets: UBS economist
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen has been criticized for being too responsive to financial markets, which are misreading economic data. Senior UBS economist Paul Donovan says the Fed should raise interest rates in December, not in October, to create stability around expectations. Donovan argues that the US labor market is strong, inflation is approaching the 2% target, and financial markets are overreacting to revised economic data. He believes the Fed has created a "hostage crisis" by tying its decisions to market expectations.

site_title: HKEx CEO gets backing of chairman amid report on 'princeling' hirings
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEx) CEO Charles Li has received backing from chairman Chow Chung-Kong amid a Wall Street Journal report linking Li to hiring practices at his former employer JPMorgan Chase & Co that are being investigated. The report claims Li recommended employing the children and associates of Chinese officials, known as "princelings", while he was chairman of JPMorgan China from 2003 to 2009. Li has denied the allegations, stating that he followed the bank's formal hiring processes and that the report has no bearing on his role at HKEx.

site_title: Global outlook for wheat set to worsen as supplies build up
summary: Hedge funds are predicting a worsening global wheat outlook due to expected record-high world inventories before next year's harvest, driven by increased crops in the US, Russia, and Ukraine. Despite a 29-year low in wheat prices, funds remain bearish for seven consecutive weeks, anticipating further losses.

site_title: Apple cleaning up iOS App Store after first major cyber attack
summary: Apple has removed hundreds of malicious iPhone and iPad apps from its iOS App Store after a large-scale cyber attack. The malicious program, dubbed XcodeGhost, was embedded in apps by convincing developers to use a counterfeit version of Apple's Xcode software. The attack, discovered by cyber security firms, had limited functionality but raised concerns about the App Store's security. Infected apps included popular services like WeChat, Didi Kuaidi, and NetEase. Apple is working with developers to rebuild their apps using the proper version of Xcode.

site_title: Technology gap gives foreign firms the edge in China robot wars
summary: China's robotics industry is experiencing a technology gap with foreign firms, despite government subsidies boosting growth. Only a few Chinese robotics firms have done meaningful research and development, with many relying on imported control systems and struggling to compete on price. Industry insiders predict a market bubble and anticipate foreign firms will weather the temporary demand blip, while domestic firms like Shanghai Siasun Robot & Automation are seen as making advances in robot technology. Experts believe a domestic champion may emerge from unexpected quarters, such as e-commerce giant Alibaba Group Holding.

site_title: It's fine for Fed to keep eye on China; it's what it sees that's troubling
summary: The US Federal Reserve's decision not to raise interest rates after its September meeting has been attributed to a moderation in its outlook for the US economy, citing the global economy, particularly China. The Fed's data suggests a slowing China, which could impact global trade and demand for goods and services. The central bank's projections for 2016 and 2017 GDP growth were reduced, and inflation projections were also cut, indicating a focus on keeping inflation in check. The Fed's decision reflects sound economics, prioritizing fundamentals over market volatility.

site_title: VW to stop US sales of diesel models involved in recall over illegal software
summary: Volkswagen has halted US sales of 2015 and 2016 models equipped with 4-cylinder turbo diesel engines, marketed as "clean diesel", due to a recall related to allegedly installed software to evade smog standards. The company will also stop selling used cars with these engines. This decision follows regulatory accusations against Volkswagen.

site_title: Smaller China banks bingeing on risky debt
summary: Smaller Chinese banks are increasing their exposure to riskier debt to boost capital buffers amid a slowing economy and slumping stocks. They issued 85 billion yuan of Tier 2 securities in the third quarter, the highest two quarters on record, to comply with Basel III rules. This comes as smaller banks face declining profits and rising corporate defaults, with non-performing loans surging 54% for large-scale commercial banks and 69% for rural commercial banks. Authorities have halted initial public offerings to prop up plunging stocks, forcing banks to raise capital through debt markets.

site_title: Focus on Yahoo stake as lockup of US$105b of Alibaba shares ends
summary: Alibaba's 63% stake, valued at US$105 billion, became available after the lockup period ended on September 21, 2015. Yahoo, which holds 15%, is weighing its options, with CEO Marissa Mayer considering a spinoff. Analysts expect SoftBank to hold onto its shares, while Yahoo's uncertainty may create uncertainty around Alibaba's shares. The market slump of US$128.5 billion from Alibaba's peak in November may prompt investors to hold onto the shares, and a delay in Yahoo's plan could help bolster Alibaba's price.

site_title: Homegrown Kim Soon Lee buys Tuas warehouse from ISK
summary: Kim Soon Lee, a Singaporean transportation and logistics group, has acquired a 325,211 sq ft warehouse in Tuas for S$30 million. The purchase will aid the company's expansion of its warehousing business. The facility has a 1.4 plot ratio and a 32-year balance lease. The acquisition will be funded by the group's reserves and a local bank loan. The purchase is part of Kim Soon Lee's plan to strengthen its position as a "one-stop transportation and moving specialist".

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
Mr Joseph Lim (centre) sees good potential in Singapore's transportation and logistics needs; with him are his brothers Gim Hwee (left) and Larry.

site_title: SMEs need help refocusing productivity efforts amid rising costs: SCCCI
summary: A recent survey by the Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SCCCI) found that only 87.9% of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore have adopted productivity measures, down from 90.3% last year. The survey highlights that SMEs need guidance to optimize their business models and undertake higher-value activities. The SCCCI recommends that the government set up a committee to address rising business costs, and that the SkillsFuture program could be a solution to SMEs' manpower challenges.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: London leads UK home prices to all-time high
summary: London home prices reached an all-time high in September, with asking prices rising 2.2% to £620,003, driven by a shortage of properties for sale and strong demand from wealthy buyers. Nationally, prices rose 0.9% to £294,834, with London's districts of Southwark, Kensington, and Richmond on Thames seeing the largest gains. The UK housing market continues to face a shortage of suitable supply, with prices expected to reach £1 million by 2020 if current trends continue.

images.alt_text: In London, the three best performers were the districts of Southwark, Kensington and Chelsea, and Richmond upon Thames, each gaining about 8 per cent on average.

site_title: KKR seeks at least US$1.5b for second US property fund
summary: KKR is seeking at least $1.5 billion for its second US real estate fund, capitalizing on robust investor demand for higher-yielding assets. The firm aims to tap into the market's appetite for commercial property, which is yielding around 6%, compared to 2% for the 10-year Treasury note. This follows the success of KKR's first fund, which made over a dozen investments in North America and Europe, and its property unit's recent sale of a stake in a senior-residence management business for a five-fold gain.

site_title: Toll Brothers sees Manhattan luxury-condo glut
summary: Toll Brothers, a US luxury-home builder, is shifting its focus from ultra-luxury condos to smaller, more affordable units in Manhattan due to a glut of expensive units on the market. The company's latest project, at 55 W 17th St in Chelsea, will have an average asking price per square foot less than at new buildings in the rest of the borough. This move comes as sales of new Manhattan condos slow and prices continue to escalate. Other developers, including HFZ Capital Group and Vornado Realty Trust, are also citing oversupply in the market as a reason to adjust their strategies.

site_title: Quintiles goes purple to mark World Alzheimer's Day
summary: Quintiles, a biopharmaceutical services company, marked World Alzheimer's Day by dressing employees in purple shirts in Singapore. The company has over 300 employees and has provided clinical services for 100 Alzheimer's disease studies involving 18,000 patients across 56 countries since 2010. This event highlights Quintiles' commitment to addressing Alzheimer's disease, a global health concern.

site_title: Syriza records remarkable re-election win
summary: Syriza, a radical left party in Greece, won the most seats in the country's fifth general election in six years, but fell short of an overall majority. The party will form a coalition with the Independent Greeks, and Alexis Tsipras will serve as prime minister for a second time. The new government faces significant challenges, including implementing a tough bailout deal, tackling corruption, and restoring economic confidence. With Greece's financial system still weak, the country's international creditors will closely monitor the new government's progress, and the prospect of Greece leaving the eurozone remains a possibility.

site_title: Win contest to watch Monte Carlo race
summary: UBS, a global partner of the Mercedes AMG Petronas F1 team, is hosting a contest for one winner to attend the 2016 Monaco Grand Prix. To enter, participants must answer three multiple-choice questions correctly, with the grand prize including two round-trip flights, premium tickets, and an authentic Lewis Hamilton replica suit. The contest runs until September 29 and is open to fans worldwide. The contest winner will join 30-year-old Lewis Hamilton, a two-time F1 world champion, and teammate Nico Rosberg, who are both second in the championship standings.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Tsipras needs to get cracking now
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras' electoral victory has given him a mandate to implement the country's 86 billion euro bailout deal. Despite his party's internal divisions, Tsipras has the support of four opposition parties to pass the agreement. Successful implementation could bring relief on Greece's debts, lower borrowing costs, and stimulate economic growth. However, Tsipras faces the risk of being incompetent or dragging his feet, which could lead to disaster, particularly if Greece fails to meet the October deadline for reforms.

site_title: Billionaires seek own India airport as low fares crowd skies
summary: Billionaires in India are seeking their own airport due to onerous rules and regulations that delay private planes, causing the country's business jet fleet to shrink. The Business Aircraft Operators Association is lobbying the government to develop a network of airports exclusively for business planes, citing high fees, taxes, and bureaucracy as major obstacles. The move is seen as a response to India's growing economy and the increasing wealth of its high-net-worth individuals, who are driving demand for private air travel.

site_title: StanChart may face more fines for Iran-related deals: report
summary: Standard Chartered may face additional US fines for its Iran-related deals, according to a report by the Financial Times. The bank was still reviewing its client list in 2013 and identified transactions that could put it at risk of severe penalties. Standard Chartered paid $667 million in 2012 after breaking sanctions and was fined another $300 million in 2014. The bank has cooperated with US investigations and cited legacy obligations as the reason for not pursuing new business with known Iranian entities. The bank's shares dropped 2.4% following the report.

site_title: GCB site off Upper Thomson up for sale
summary: A freehold Good Class Bungalow site off Upper Thomson Road in Singapore has been put up for sale by public tender at S$27 million, or S$1,280 per square foot. The 21,091 sq ft site, built in the 1950s, is now occupied by a bungalow and is part of a landed housing area. This is a rare opportunity for sale in the area, with only 34 GCB plots available. The sale is expected to contribute to the growing activity in the upper-tier landed residential property market, with 20 GCBs transacted at a total value of S$485 million this year.

site_title: 'Edge' set to resume publication as court revokes suspension
summary: A Malaysian High Court has revoked a three-month permit suspension on two publications of the Edge Media Group, citing illegality and lack of procedural fairness. Judge Asmabi Mohamad ruled that Home Minister Zahid Hamidi acted beyond his powers and failed to specify which articles were deemed undesirable for publication. The Edge Media Group, which reported extensively on scandal-ridden state-owned 1MDB, had challenged the suspension in a judicial review, with the court ordering RM15,000 in costs and damages to be ascertained.

site_title: US bonds just got rosier with Fed deciding against rate hike
summary: The Federal Reserve has decided against a rate hike, keeping benchmark borrowing costs near zero. Top investors expect US bonds to remain in demand due to low inflation expectations, with some predicting rates won't rise until 2016. The Fed also cited rising international risks, such as China's slowdown, in its decision. Traders believe policymakers will be cautious in lifting rates to avoid disrupting the economic recovery, supporting the demand for bonds.

site_title: Deluge of new homes may end high property prices in Sydney
summary: A surge in new home starts across Australia, with 213,000 new homes planned, may lead to a supply glut in Sydney, potentially ending the city's record-high property prices. Goldman Sachs warns of a supply glut by 2017, citing slowing population and economic growth. Experts say housing prices have been artificially inflated by low interest rates, and the market is due for a correction. Auction clearance rates in Sydney have dropped to 73%, and investor demand is being choked by tighter lending requirements, suggesting a possible decline in property prices.

site_title: VW steering committee to meet on emissions scandal: sources
summary: Volkswagen's supervisory board has scheduled an emergency meeting to discuss allegations by the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) that the German carmaker rigged emissions tests for diesel VW and Audi branded cars. The EPA claims the company used software to deceive regulators, potentially facing penalties of up to $18 billion. The steering committee meeting, initially set for a regular session, has been rescheduled to address the emissions scandal.

site_title: Cool Washington reception for China's Xi
summary: US Republican presidential candidates have proposed canceling a state dinner for Chinese President Xi Jinping in response to suspected Chinese hacking attacks on the US. Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker suggested this during a CNN debate, but it appears no one in the GOP is actually using the hashtag "#CancelChinesePresidentStateDinner". The Chinese government denies involvement in the attacks and claims it was the victim of similar attacks. The dinner remains scheduled for Friday at the White House.

site_title: Macau casino analysts capitulate on second-half recovery
summary: Macau casino analysts have drastically revised their estimates, forecasting a 32% decline in revenue for the year, with some predicting a US$14 billion loss. The decline is attributed to China's crackdown on graft, a slowing economy, and travel restrictions on Chinese nationals. Analysts have given up on a second-half recovery, with some predicting a 5% growth in 2016. Gross gaming revenue is expected to fall to around US$30 billion, down from US$44 billion in 2014.

site_title: Building economic, cultural and trade ties between UK and Asean
summary: UK Prime Minister visits Singapore and Vietnam to strengthen economic, cultural, and trade ties with Asean. The visit aims to build on the UK's strong relationships with Singapore and other Asean countries, particularly in areas of intellectual property, innovation, and trade. The UK and Singapore have signed a memorandum of understanding to enhance cooperation on intellectual property protection, and the UK has committed to supporting Singapore's efforts to become a regional IP hub. The visit also highlights the UK's commitment to promoting innovation, entrepreneurship, and economic growth in the region.

site_title: CCS approves Tiger-Cebu Pacific alliance
summary: The Competition Commission of Singapore (CCS) has approved a strategic alliance agreement between Tiger Airways and Cebu Pacific, allowing the two budget carriers to work more closely together for the Singapore and Philippine markets. The greenlight enables better connectivity across their networks, more flight options, and potentially better prices. The carriers will work together on sales and schedules for certain routes, combining their resources to provide greater convenience and value to customers.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: STI unmoved by new benchmark entrants
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) struggled to make headway after a wobbly start on Monday, finishing 0.1% higher despite a significant change to its basket. The three new entrants, SATS, UOL, and Yangzijiang, gained ground on their debut, but their tiny weightage had little impact on the overall index. Traders instead focused on small-cap space, with International Healthway Corp (IHC) and Healthway Medical seeing significant trading volumes. IHC fell 68.6% after resuming trading, while Healthway lost 26.3%.

site_title: JetBlue wants Delta to leave 'humanity' alone
summary: JetBlue Airways Corp expressed disappointment after Delta Air Lines Inc claimed its "humanity" slogan, which JetBlue has used for 16 years to restore humanity to flying. JetBlue CEO Robin Hayes and leaders were chagrined by Delta's press releases echoing the exact wording, which is also in JetBlue's Customer Bill of Rights. Despite this, JetBlue has chosen not to take action, instead focusing on making the customer experience "even better".

site_title: More medium-sized companies hedging FX risk: HSBC exec
summary: Medium-sized companies, also known as middle-market enterprises (MMEs), are increasingly hedging their foreign exchange exposure due to the recent renminbi devaluation, according to HSBC regional head of MMEs Tim Evans. MMEs, which generate $176 billion in turnover and provide 400,000 jobs in Singapore, are more vulnerable to currency volatility as they expand globally. Companies should hedge 25-75% of their foreign currency receivables/payables, depending on their profit margin, and consider trade credit insurance to mitigate commercial risks.

images.alt_text: "During periods of extreme volatility, bid-offer spreads could widen to reflect the lack of liquidity in the market. Additionally, at a time when Asian currencies are under pressure, the cost of buying US dollars - as reflected by the forward premium - could increase," said Mr Evans.

site_title: More diversity on show and validation for HBO
summary: The 67th Primetime Emmy Awards honored diverse representation in television, with HBO dominating with 43 awards, including best drama and outstanding comedy series. Viola Davis became the first African-American woman to win an Emmy for best lead actress in a drama series for her role in How to Get Away With Murder. HBO's wins also included Game of Thrones, which won its first Emmy for best supporting actor in a drama, and Transparent, which won for outstanding actor in a comedy series. The awards marked a shift towards increased diversity, with many winners speaking out on issues of representation and inclusion.

site_title: China said to be considering framework for governing ride-booking services
summary: China is considering regulations for ride-booking services like Uber and Didi Kuaidi, which would require commercial registration of cars and drivers and limit permits for city governments. The proposed framework would challenge the companies' current business model and potentially cap growth, as vehicles registered for commercial use have to be scrapped after eight years. The rules may be released for public consultation as early as this month, with local authorities deciding on the number of permits for on-demand vehicles. This could impact Uber and Didi's rapid expansion plans in China.

site_title: Development of local SMEs crucial to success of AEC
summary: ASEAN's single economy is forecast to become the third largest in the world by 2030, driven by the success of the Asean Economic Community (AEC). Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are crucial to this success, accounting for up to 80% of domestic employment and contributing 30-53% to the region's GDP. To grow SMEs, ASEAN needs to create a taskforce to provide access to credit, infrastructure, and business incubators, and foster collaboration among member countries to champion specific industries.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Sembcorp Industries Ltd has signed an agreement to divest its 40% stake in Australian waste management company SembSita Pacific Pte Ltd to Suez Environnement Asia Ltd for A$485 million. This deal is expected to result in an incremental 6-7 cents dividend per share, raising the dividend yield from 4% to 6%. Meanwhile, Ascendas Reit is proposing to acquire A$1.013 billion worth of prime grade logistics properties in Australia, increasing its net gearing and distribution per unit. Additionally, Silverlake Axis is acquiring SunGard Ambit for US$12 million, expected to lift its top line by 15%.

site_title: Jinjiang International buys 81% of Keystone Lodging
summary: Jinjiang International Hotels Development Co. has acquired 81% of Keystone Lodging Holdings Ltd, the owner of Plateno Group, for 8.3 billion yuan (S$1.8 billion). The deal gives Keystone an enterprise value of 10.8 billion yuan and marks a significant expansion step for Jinjiang, with plans to add brands in middle to high-end hotels. The acquisition is funded by cash and loans, increasing Jinjiang's debt-to-asset ratio to 72.9%. Regulatory approval from Chinese authorities is pending.

site_title: Olam ready to deploy US$2b to take advantage of buyer's market
summary: Olam International Ltd is set to deploy US$2 billion for acquisitions in a buyer's market for agricultural commodities, driven by slumping prices and weakening emerging-market currencies. The company, 51% owned by Temasek Holdings, aims to shift its strategy to larger deals, with a focus on the US$100-200 million range, after a recent US$1.3 billion purchase of Archer-Daniels-Midland Co's cocoa business. This move comes after a significant investment from Mitsubishi Corp, which bought a 20% stake in Olam for about US$1 billion.

site_title: Sales of existing homes down more than forecast in August
summary: US existing home sales declined 4.8% in August to a 5.31 million annual rate, missing forecast expectations. Despite a 5.4% year-over-year increase in purchases, the median home price rose 4.7% to $228,700, driven by a tight inventory of available properties. Limited income growth and tougher mortgage qualifications hindered Americans' ability to take advantage of low interest rates and relocate, according to the National Association of Realtors.

site_title: Join the family firm? Only 1 in 5 grads say yes
summary: A global study of over 34,000 next-generation family business members found that only 19.7% are interested in taking over their family firm, with 3.5% wanting to do so immediately after graduation and 4.9% planning to do so five years later. The figures have decreased by 30% from a comparable survey in 2011, with Singapore having the lowest interest rate at 3.8%. The study suggests that family businesses with smaller staff sizes and higher inheritance taxes have lower succession intentions, while those in countries with strong family values and economic growth have higher intentions.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: China party mouthpiece lashes out at tycoon Li Ka-shing
summary: China's Communist Party newspaper has criticized Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka-shing for selling assets in the country, questioning his patriotism and loyalty. Li has been offloading major property investments in China, where growth has slowed, amid speculation he's losing confidence in the region. The People's Daily described Li as having "shared the prosperity" with China but now abandoning it, but downplayed any impact on confidence, citing China's significant role in the global economy.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rebound from two-day drop despite Volkswagen slide
summary: European stocks rebounded 0.9% from a two-day drop, driven by a broad-based rally. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index reversed losses despite Volkswagen's 19% slide, the largest single-day drop in the company's history. Investors are optimistic about European shares, with analysts seeing value in the market after recent declines. The European Central Bank's Mario Draghi is set to make public appearances this week, sparking speculation about potential stimulus measures.

site_title: Feinmetall finds finesse in lean management
summary: Feinmetall, a German company with a local joint venture in Singapore, has successfully implemented lean management to overcome market challenges. The company, which provides testing services for semiconductor chips, has grown from a small team of five employees to a full-service solution provider. Lean management strategies, such as introducing an automated needle-bending machine and minimizing idling, have increased productivity and reduced resource waste. The company has also improved office environment and employee morale through innovative designs, such as a pantry area with a foosball table. Despite facing challenges like rising wages and market volatility, Feinmetall is prepared to adapt and innovate to maintain its success.

site_title: Tigerair, Cebu Pacific get nod for strategic alliance
summary: Singapore's Competition Commission has approved a strategic alliance between Tiger Airways and Cebu Pacific, allowing the two budget carriers to work more closely together for the Singapore and Philippine markets. The agreement will enable better connectivity across both networks, with passengers able to tap into each other's routes, including South-east Asia and India. The two carriers will also be able to work together on sales and schedules, offering more flight options at potentially better prices. The move is seen as a positive development for the carriers, which will leverage on each other's strengths and complementary networks.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: US existing home sales fall more than expected
summary: US existing home sales fell 4.8% in August to 5.31 million units, beating economists' expectations. The decline may be due to rising home prices, which shut out potential buyers, particularly in the South and West. The median home price fell slightly to $228,700, up 4.7% from last year. This marks the lowest year-over-year rate since August 2014. The decline in sales pace supports the view that the US economy is building up steam, potentially leading to interest rate hikes.

site_title: Jet fuel stays at sea as imports overwhelm Europe
summary: Europe's jet fuel market is saturated due to imports from Asia and the Middle East, forcing sellers to store oil on tankers or extend voyages. Record-high storage levels and low profit margins have led traders to opt for longer voyages or sail around Africa to avoid high storage costs. Despite a surge in air traffic, jet fuel demand is outpacing supply, with 2.4 million tonnes booked for October, outstripping the region's average demand.

site_title: Diamond jewellery sales rise to record in 2014: De Beers
summary: De Beers reported a 3% increase in global diamond jewellery sales to a record $80 billion in 2014, driven by strong demand in the US, China, and India. Sales of polished diamonds rose 7% in the US, while demand in China and India grew by 6% and 3% in local currency terms, respectively. However, De Beers warned that 2015 would be a challenging year for the industry due to the strengthening of the US dollar.

site_title: Malaysian opposition parties plan new alliance after implosion
summary: Malaysia's opposition parties, the People's Justice Party and the Democratic Action Party, plan to form a new alliance after the collapse of the Pakatan Rakyat coalition in June. The parties will discuss and negotiate the new alliance, excluding Parti Islam se-Malaysia (PAS). The formation of a new alliance comes as the ruling United Malays National Organisation faces pressure from the economy and public calls for Prime Minister Najib Razak's resignation. The new alliance aims to present a stronger and more harmonious opposition to UMNO and Barisan Nasional.

site_title: Magnus Energy to pay A$1 million for 8m shares in Aussie oil and gas firm
summary: Magnus Energy is investing A$1 million for 8 million shares in Royal, an Australian oil and gas company. The investment will give Magnus Energy a 17.5% stake in Royal. Royal aims to acquire assets nearing production and utilize its management team's expertise. The company plans to raise A$5-10 million in funds, with the capital structure finalized by September 30. This investment will allow Mid-Con, a subsidiary of Magnus Energy, to expand its oil and gas equipment supply business and participate in investment opportunities through Royal.

site_title: Growth in number of people with Internet slows; more than half world's population offline: UN
summary: The United Nations Broadband Commission reported that internet growth is slowing, with the access rate expected to decrease to 8.1% this year. Over 57% of the world's population, or 4 billion people, remain offline, with 90% in the 48 poorest countries lacking access. The milestone of four billion internet users is unlikely to be reached before 2020. The commission attributes the slowdown to high costs of extending last-mile infrastructure and a decline in mobile subscriptions globally, with women in poorer countries being particularly disadvantaged.

site_title: Greece's liabilities towards ECB payment system near their 2012 highs
summary: Greece's liabilities to the eurozone's bank payment system rose to 106.13 billion euros in July, the highest since 2012, according to data from the European Central Bank. This increase is attributed to fears Greece may be forced out of the eurozone, driving money out of the country. Payments by Greek banks to institutions in other eurozone countries exceeded flows in the opposite directions by 106.13 billion euros, highlighting the country's financial instability.

site_title: Morgan Stanley's pioneer of China investing falls on hard times
summary: Morgan Stanley's 9-year-old China A Share Fund has slumped 13% this year, its worst performance since its launch in 2006. The fund, which tracks the Shanghai Composite Index, has a 24% discount, the largest among over 500 closed-end funds. The underperformance is attributed to a 39% decline in the Shanghai Composite Index and the opening up of China's capital markets to cheaper and more efficient products like ETFs. Despite the decline, some investors see the widening discount as a buying opportunity, while others believe the fund's performance will improve in the coming months.

images.alt_text: As bad as the Chinese stock market has been for investors this year, a Morgan Stanley fund has been even worse.

site_title: China investors in rare protest accuse regulators of "ignoring fraud"
summary: Hundreds of Chinese investors protested outside the China Securities Regulatory Commission's headquarters, accusing regulators of ignoring Fanya Metal Exchange's alleged fraud. The exchange, which trades rare metals, has been accused of defrauding investors of billions of yuan as demand for the metals has fallen due to the slowing economy. Protests were dispersed by police, with investors claiming they had invested a total of 45 billion yuan and had not been repaid. The Fanya Metal Exchange denied any problems with cash flow, but the chairman, Shan Jiuliang, was previously apprehended and released by police.

site_title: China, Britain to study London-Shanghai stock link: Osborne
summary: China and Britain plan to study linking the London and Shanghai stock markets, with Finance Minister George Osborne stating it's in their interests to have deeper financial markets globally. This comes as China's stock markets have experienced a debt-fueled rally followed by a significant decline, raising questions about Beijing's economic management. A feasibility study will be carried out on a possible link, with Osborne also calling for closer business and economic ties between the two countries, believing it will benefit both economies.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher after post-Fed losses
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday, recouping losses from the previous week after the Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates near zero. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.48%, the S&P 500 gained 0.42%, and the Nasdaq composite added 0.58%. Despite ongoing global economic concerns, stocks continued their rally, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records.

images.alt_text: US stocks opened lower on Thursday on lingering concerns about global economic growth and ahead of a speech by Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen on inflation.

site_title: English house prices see biggest September jump since 2002: Rightmove
summary: English house prices saw their largest September increase since 2002, rising 0.9% to a record high of £294,834 (US$456,904), according to Rightmove. The jump followed a 0.8% decrease in August. Cheap borrowing and a lack of properties on the market contributed to market "extremes".

site_title: Google launches online IT degrees in India
summary: Google has launched online IT degrees in India in collaboration with Udacity and Tata, offering courses on building apps for Android. The courses cost 9,800 rupees per month and take 6-9 months to complete. Google aims to tap India's 3.6 million developers and create world-class apps. The companies will also offer 1,000 scholarships and a job fair for graduates. The launch coincides with Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's visit to Silicon Valley, where he will seek foreign investment and financial ties with US tech giants.

site_title: ADB says to identify future projects for co-financing with AIIB
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has agreed to identify future projects that can be co-financed with the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB). ADB President Takehiko Nakao and AIIB President-designate Jin Liqun met to discuss co-financing opportunities. The ADB will share its expertise in regional cooperation, sustainable development, and climate change with the AIIB. This collaboration aims to promote sustainable development and regional integration in the region.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Jumbo seafood restaurant group is planning to list on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange, aiming to expand outlets in Singapore and China. International Healthway Corporation is set to acquire Healthway Medical Corporation for S$0.10 per share, with no cash payment. Soilbuild Construction Group has won a land lease for S$26 million to develop an integrated construction hub. Meanwhile, Q&M Dental Group has acquired TP Dental Surgeons, and a subsidiary of Magnus Energy is investing A$1 million in an Australian oil and gas company.

site_title: Volkswagen says to halt sales of VW, Audi diesel cars in US
summary: Volkswagen has halted sales of four-cylinder diesel cars in the US due to a scandal over manipulated emissions data. The company sold nearly 240,000 cars in the US between January and August. The US authorities claim VW equipped 482,000 cars with software that turns off emissions controls during normal driving. VW's CEO Martin Winterkorn has apologized and ordered an external investigation, which could lead to fines of up to $18 billion. The move has caused a 21.8% loss in VW shares on the Frankfurt stock exchange.

site_title: Malaysia court quashes ban on scandal-reporting media group
summary: Malaysia's High Court quashed a publishing ban on The Edge Media Group, a media group that reported on financial irregularities linked to Prime Minister Najib Razak. The group's reports alleged fraud, mismanagement, and misappropriation of funds from state-owned investment company 1MDB. The government had imposed the ban, citing "public order" concerns, but the High Court found the decision to be "tainted with illegality". The Edge Media Group hailed the decision as vindicating its position that the suspension was unfair and without justification.

site_title: European Commission: Greek government has mandate for reforms
summary: The European Commission has confirmed Greece's new government, led by Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, has a mandate to implement reforms agreed upon with international lenders in July. Tsipras' Syriza party secured an unexpected election victory, forming a coalition with the Independent Greeks party. The mandate will allow the new government to carry out the ambitious programme of reforms, following Greece's commitment to these changes.

images.alt_text: More than half of the European Union's 28 nations plan to prohibit the cultivation of a group of genetically modified crops awaiting EU regulatory approval, marking the first use by individual governments of a new right to go their own way on the planting of biotech foods.

site_title: Greek current account surplus widens in July, helped by ECB inflow
summary: Greece's current account surplus widened to 4.25 billion euros in July, a nearly quadrupled increase from the same month last year, driven by a 1.8 billion euro inflow from the European Central Bank. This improvement was partly due to higher tourism revenues, which rose to 2.87 billion euros. The surplus was also influenced by a 7.2 billion euro bridge financing agreement with the European Financial Stability Mechanism.

site_title: GE's Immelt says remains positive on China
summary: GE's Chairman Jeff Immelt expressed optimism about China's growth path, contradicting other pessimistic views. He cited his observations of growth on the ground, despite a string of downbeat economic data and market volatility. This contradicts the concerns over China's 2015 growth target of seven percent, which may be at risk due to slowing GDP growth. Immelt's positive assessment is notable, given the prevailing negative sentiment about China's economy.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Monday
summary: The Singapore government has set aside S$40 million for the third Early Stage Venture Fund (ESVF) to support tech startups. Olam International is considering US$2.72 billion in acquisitions due to agricultural commodity price slumps. Enhanced subsidies for certifiable courses are available to Singapore citizens aged 40 and above, starting from October 1. A freehold GCB site in Singapore is up for sale at S$27 million. Additionally, 25,000 Singapore residents with pre-existing conditions will pay additional premiums under MediShield Life. The Singapore market closed 0.1% higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index advancing 2.68 points.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 29.98 points to close at 1,639.47, ending the day lower. 1.6 billion lots valued at RM1.87 billion were traded, with 274 gains and 526 losses.

site_title: Volkswagen shares drops 15% after admitting cheating on US diesel emissions tests for years
summary: Volkswagen admitted to cheating on US diesel emissions tests for years by installing software that turned on full pollution controls only during official testing. The company's shares dropped 15% after trading opened, with a possible $18 billion in fines and criminal prosecution. The violations affect nearly half a million vehicles, and CEO Martin Winterkorn apologized for breaking public trust. The scandal affects Volkswagen's US sales, which dropped 10% last year, and could lead to a 24% decline in the company's value.

site_title: Oil price gets closer to global benchmark as glut shifts
summary: US oil prices narrowed their discount to international benchmark Brent, trading $2.40 a barrel less, as a North American supply glut abated. US crude production declined for six weeks, while Brent was under pressure from rising shipments from the North Sea and West Africa. The US oil price gained 1.4% to $45.65, while Brent rose 54 cents to $48.01. However, analysts predict the spread between the two grades will not last, as Canadian output recovers and inventories at US crude-storage hubs accumulate.

site_title: Artefacts from Mr Lee Kuan Yew's Oxley Road home now on show at new exhibition
summary: Singaporeans can now view personal artefacts from late former Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew at the National Museum of Singapore. Items from his Oxley Road home, where the People's Action Party was founded, have been donated by his children, Dr Lee Wei Ling and Mr Lee Hsien Yang. The exhibition showcases the contributions of Singapore's founding leaders, providing a unique glimpse into the nation's history.

images.alt_text: Singaporeans will be able to get up close to the personal artefacts of the late Mr Lee Kuan Yew at a new exhibition at the National Museum of Singapore chronicling the contributions of the nation's founding team of leaders.

site_title: Infrastructure spending in Indonesia picking up after long delays but could miss target
summary: Indonesia's infrastructure spending is picking up after long delays, with the government speeding up capital spending, leading to a surge in cement sales and imported materials. This has supported shares of construction firms, including Adhi Karya Tbk and Semen Indonesia. The development is a welcome relief for President Joko Widodo's plan to boost Southeast Asia's largest economy by building new roads, ports, and bridges. However, it remains to be seen whether this will help the country meet its infrastructure spending target.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares fall, pulled down by global market weakness
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.8% on Monday, weighed down by global market weakness, with the Hang Seng index closing at 21,756.93.
