The Business Council of Australia has praised his new approach, highlighting the need for a growth agenda driven by innovation and tax reform. Analysts expect Turnbull's leadership to boost business investment spending and attract private investment in emerging technologies.

site_title: Dollar rebounds after Fed-induced plunge
summary: The US dollar rebounded 1.2% on Friday after the Federal Reserve declined to hike interest rates, reversing its previous day's decline. The dollar strengthened against the euro and pound, while holding flat against the yen. Analysts attributed the rebound to the Fed's emphasis on solid US growth and a potential rate increase by the end of the year. Meanwhile, the euro fell against other currencies due to Greek polls showing a slim lead for the left-wing candidate, which could impact the country's EU bailout program.

site_title: S-Reits rebound after Fed holds rates for now
summary: Singapore's S-Reits rebounded 0.5% after the US Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged, boosting the FTSE ST Reits Index to 694.15. Analysts expect a short-term boost, but warn of risks to earnings and top-line growth, with most anticipating a rate hike in December. Despite a 10% price drop since July, Reits in sectors like data centres, logistics, and healthcare are seen as better positioned to withstand rate hikes. However, smaller Reits may need to consider mergers to stay competitive.

site_title: SHS selling petroleum distribution arm for S$100.3m
summary: SHS Holdings, a Singapore-based engineering and corrosion prevention services group, has agreed to sell its refined petroleum distribution arm to Brenntag for S$100.3 million. The deal is part of SHS's strategic review to streamline businesses, unlock shareholder value, and boost financial flexibility. The disposal will enable SHS to focus on its other strategic business units.

site_title: India to 'Act East', and look to S'pore as launchpad
summary: India is set to adopt a more proactive "Act East" policy, with Singapore serving as a key launchpad for engagement with the region. Finance Minister Arun Jaitley announced the shift, citing the need for greater economic ties with Southeast Asia and the world. This move aims to boost trade and investment between India and Singapore, with the latter's strategic location providing access to the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) and beyond. The "Act East" policy is expected to promote economic growth and strengthen India's position in the region.

site_title: Institutional investors 'need more active management'
summary: Institutional investors are shifting away from market indices as a primary source of returns, as the current market conditions and indices' performance are not generating sufficient gains. According to GIC's president, investors need more skilled active managers to generate returns, particularly in emerging and developed markets. The experts warn that asset managers will have to work harder to generate returns over the next few years, with a focus on finding alternative managers and stock picks. This shift is expected to impact the investment landscape, with a greater emphasis on skill and expertise.

site_title: US$50 tablet leads Amazon's latest gadget offensive
summary: Amazon unveiled a major home electronics push, led by a US$50 tablet computer and other devices aimed at budget-conscious consumers. The low-cost tablet, Fire tablet, will be available starting Sept 30, with an option to buy a "six pack" at US$250. Analysts say Amazon may not make a profit on the US$50 tablet, but will use it to lure consumers into its ecosystem. The company also launched updated Fire TV streaming media devices and a new game controller box, competing with products from Apple and other brands.

site_title: Higher repayments ahead for home loans
summary: Higher interest rates in Singapore are expected to increase monthly home loan repayments, with some borrowers facing hundreds of dollars more in monthly instalments. The 3-month SOR jumped 50% to 1.405% in August, prompting DBS Bank to advise customers to switch to more stable pricing packages. Borrowers with SOR-based loans can expect a 20-year loan to increase by $340.83 per month. DBS Bank is offering refinancing options, including fixed deposit home loan rates and managed mortgage packages, to help borrowers cope with the rising interest rates.

site_title: A-Reit buys Aussie assets for A$1.01b
summary: A-Reit is acquiring a 26-property logistics portfolio in Australia for A$1.01 billion, becoming the eighth largest industrial landlord in the country. The portfolio, mainly in Sydney, Melbourne, and Brisbane, has a total of 24 tenants with 30 triple net leases and an occupancy rate of 94.4%. The acquisition is expected to generate a 6.4% net property income yield and will be funded by A$600 million of Australian onshore loans and perpetual securities. The move is part of A-Reit's plan to have 20-30% of its portfolio in mature developed markets.

site_title: Asiatravel.com shares soar on ZhongHong's takeover bid
summary: Asiatravel.com Holdings has accepted a S$93 million takeover bid from Shenzhen-listed ZhongHong Holdings, with the offer price set at 30 Singapore cents a share. The deal marks a 22% surge in the stock price, reaching an 11-month high of 26.5 Singapore cents. Five substantial shareholders, including the majority owner and former CEO, have agreed to sell their shares to ZhongHong, which holds an 11.4% stake in the company.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Macho, Macho Mien
summary: Steve Tan, 43, an executive with a local data services company, has curated his three-bedroom apartment to embody a "macho mien." The space features dark timber panelling, Mad Men-worthy furniture, and animal skin accents, showcasing a strict adherence to masculine style. The home's design is reflective of Tan's athletic background as a former triathlon competitor, with high-performance engineered furniture pieces that evoke toughness and strength. The result is a space that exudes masculinity and testosterone.

site_title: Fuld's estate in Sun Valley sets record at auction
summary: A Sun Valley, Idaho estate owned by former Lehman Brothers CEO Richard "Dick" Fuld sold for at least $20 million at an auction, setting a record for a US home sold at auction. The 29-hectare property features a main home and adjacent buildings with 11 bedrooms and 10.5 baths. Six bidders competed, with the winner from the Pacific Northwest, and the final value will be disclosed in about 30 days. The sale surpassed the previous disclosed record of $19.25 million for an estate in Jackson Hole, Wyoming.

site_title: US, Europe stocks fall on Fed but some emerging markets rally
summary: The US Federal Reserve decided against raising interest rates, sending major US stocks tumbling 1.61% while emerging markets rose in relief. The decision was seen as a signal that the US economy is not strong enough to support higher rates, prolonging uncertainty and negatively impacting corporate profits. Emerging market currencies, such as the South Korean won and Indian rupee, gained against the US dollar, while the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices fell 3.06% and 2.56%, respectively.

site_title: Bitcoin is officially a commodity, says US regulator
summary: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) has officially designated Bitcoin as a commodity, subject to its regulations. This move asserts the agency's authority to oversee trading of cryptocurrency futures and options, allowing for charges to be brought against those engaging in wrongdoing. Exchanges operating Bitcoin derivatives or futures must now register as swap execution facilities or designated contract markets, similar to the CME Group. The decision aims to clean up US trading and prevent a repeat of the Mt Gox incident, but may also increase costs for businesses operating in the space.

site_title: This Dane's not giving up the fight
summary: Caroline Wozniacki, the 25-year-old Danish tennis star, is facing a tough season despite being ranked sixth in the world. She has struggled with injuries and failed to make the quarter-finals at all four grand slams. Wozniacki is still in contention for the BNP Paribas WTA Finals in Singapore, but trails eighth-placed Carla Suarez-Navarro by 569 points. Despite the setback, Wozniacki remains optimistic, citing past successes and her ability to bounce back from adversity.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Reasons for Fed's rate freeze dent equities
summary: The US Federal Reserve maintained its interest rate at nearly zero percent, postponing a long-promised rate hike due to volatile global and financial conditions. The decision, made despite long-awaited anticipation, has caused consternation among traders and investors. The Fed cited China-inspired volatility and concerns over emerging markets as reasons for the delay, pushing down targeted rates for the next three years. The decision has led to market uncertainty, with some strategists cutting earnings targets for the S&P 500.

images.alt_text: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen speaks at a press conference in Washington, DC, USA Sep 17, 2015.

site_title: Mad about tapas
summary: Tapas, a style of eating food in small portions, continues to gain popularity in Singapore, with the number of newly opened tapas restaurants increasing. However, this trend has sparked debate among Spanish food purists, who argue that tapas should only refer to traditional Spanish cuisine. Some restaurants, like My Little Spanish Place and Cato, have adapted the concept to include non-Spanish dishes, while others, such as Catalunya, stick to authentic Spanish products. Chef Maria Sevillano believes that tapas should be about sharing a variety of small plates, while others, like chef Daniel Chavez, see it as a casual and relaxed dining format.

site_title: Singapore firms' IPO proceeds fall to lowest since 2009
summary: Singapore firms' initial public offerings (IPOs) raised a record-low $91.7 million in the first nine months of 2015, a 95.6% slump from last year. This is the lowest since 2009. Despite market volatility, only a few companies pushed through with their IPOs, including Soo Kee Group, iX Biopharma, and NauticAWT. The Singapore Exchange saw no new listings on its mainboard this year.

site_title: Generous stock options linked to product recalls
summary: A study by University of Notre Dame academics found a correlation between generous stock options for CEOs and the incidence of serious product recalls. The researchers suggest that abundant options may lead CEOs to be more aggressive, resulting in mistakes that affect consumers. This raises concerns about the potential risks of lavish executive compensation packages. The study highlights the need for investors to consider the potential consequences of stock options on company performance and consumer safety.

site_title: Fed's holdback on rate hike buffets Asia markets
summary: The US Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged at historically low levels, sparking mixed Asian markets. The Singapore Straits Times Index (STI) ended 0.56% lower, while the Singapore dollar weakened to S$1.4019 per US dollar. However, other regional markets fared better, including Australia's All Ordinaries and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index. Gold prices rallied 1.65% due to prospects of lower interest rates for longer. Analysts warn against premature exuberance, citing concerns about the global economy and the potential for steeper hikes if rate-normalisation is delayed.

site_title: Engineering expertise still wanted: PM Lee
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for engineering expertise in Singapore's nation-building, stating that universities should focus on developing a "Singaporean character" and providing holistic education. He highlighted the importance of engineering expertise in upgrading infrastructure, overcoming constraints, and achieving the country's vision of a Smart Nation. Lee praised the achievements of the first batch of engineering graduates from the Nanyang Technological Institute, which has played a significant role in building Singapore.

site_title: Deutsche Bank to scale back business in Russia
summary: Deutsche Bank is scaling back its business in Russia, closing its corporate banking and securities operations and relocating its Russian corporate finance and markets businesses to international hubs. The bank plans to cut around 200 jobs in Russia, from a current total of around 1,300, as part of a review of its global structure amid sanctions and investigations.

site_title: More missing funds linked to 1MDB
summary: The Wall Street Journal reports that officials in Abu Dhabi are investigating missing funds linked to 1Malaysia Development Bhd, a Malaysian state investment fund. A further $993 million in payments to the International Petroleum Investment Co appears to be largely missing, following a previously reported $1.4 billion transfer that was not received. The total amount of missing funds now exceeds $2.4 billion, raising questions about the fund's financial dealings.

site_title: Lightspeed
summary: BT, a business news publication, has launched a Telegram channel for daily updates and weekend content. The channel, t.me/BizTimes, aims to provide subscribers with timely information and curated content. Meanwhile, various businesses and organizations, including Thevar 2.0, NCSS, The Social Kitchen, and CMC Markets, are promoting their initiatives and partnerships, focusing on topics such as mod-Indian cuisine, volunteer engagement, financial literacy, and sustainability. These efforts highlight the importance of corporate purpose and community involvement.

site_title: Carmakers seek to diversify China revenues
summary: Car manufacturers like BMW are diversifying their revenue streams in China, where new car sales are slowing down. To offset the decline, they are intensifying training programs for dealers to maximize revenue from after-sales services, such as car repairs, insurance, and financing. The training focuses on teaching dealers how to identify areas for improvement and optimize their business. With 60% of dealerships losing money on each new car sold, manufacturers are building out other revenue streams to ensure survival. After-sales margins in China can be as high as 50% if run efficiently.

site_title: Mad Men, Game of Thrones to battle it out for Emmys glory on Sunday
summary: This year's Emmy Awards ceremony is set to take place on Sunday, with Mad Men and Game of Thrones competing for top television honors. The ceremony could see major surprises, potentially including a history-making win for black women. Millions will tune in to find out who takes home the top awards, with Mad Men and Game of Thrones being major contenders.

site_title: Silverlake Axis acquiring SunGard Ambit (S) for US$12m
summary: Silverlake Axis is acquiring SunGard Ambit (Singapore) for US$12 million to expand its software and services, deepen customer relationships, and increase geographical presence. The acquisition is expected to contribute 15% to Silverlake Axis' revenue and add over 50 new customers. It will also extend the company's reach to Eastern Europe, the Middle East, and South Asia, creating a stronger market leadership in South-east Asia. Cost synergies will be implemented, while revenue synergies will be created through cross-selling of software and services.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: StanChart looks for investment bank head
summary: Standard Chartered is searching for a new head of its corporate and institutional business, a role currently held by Mark Dowie, as part of CEO Bill Winters' management overhaul. The search is being led by an executive search firm and is expected to be completed by year-end. The move comes as the bank faces turmoil in emerging markets and a drop in commodity prices, driving down its share price 23% this year. The bank has also seen several departures in recent months, including heads of financial markets for the Middle East and Europe.

site_title: Apple customers report devices crashing on iOS 9 update
summary: Apple customers are reporting widespread crashes after attempting to upgrade to iOS 9, with some users experiencing issues on older models of iPhones and iPads. IT specialists advise users to wait several days before downloading new updates. Disgruntled customers, including a student, expressed frustration over the inconvenience of not being able to use their devices for a day, citing reliance on apps for school. The issue has raised concerns about the reliability of the new operating system.

site_title: Lower BP may be good for you
summary: A new study suggests that lowering systolic blood pressure to 120 mm Hg may be beneficial for healthy adults over 50 without underlying diabetes, stroke, or kidney disease, reducing heart complications and stroke by almost one-third and death by almost a quarter. However, patients with diabetes, significant heart or brain artery disease, or certain types of kidney disease should exercise caution and not attempt to lower their blood pressure excessively, as it may increase the risk of stroke or other complications. The study's findings do not contradict current blood pressure guidelines, but rather provide an alternative approach for healthy adults.

images.alt_text: FLUCTUATING VALUE: It is not uncommon to find that the blood pressure of a person can be different when comparing the reading at home with the reading in a clinic.

site_title: Desperate 2.3m Indians apply for 368 low-level government jobs
summary: In Uttar Pradesh, India, 2.3 million applicants vied for 368 low-level government jobs, overwhelming officials and raising concerns about the economy's job market. The hiring manager described the volume of applications as "stunned" and estimated it would take over three years to interview candidates. This phenomenon highlights the intense competition for limited job opportunities in Asia's third-largest economy.

site_title: Late selling strikes after initial gains on Fed news
summary: The Singapore stock market experienced late selling after initial gains following the Federal Open Market Committee's decision to keep interest rates unchanged. The Straits Times Index rose 24 points on Friday but ended with a net loss of 16.22 points, with Jardine Matheson Holdings and OCBC among the biggest losers. The late selling was likely due to anticipation of weakness on Wall Street on Friday, resulting in a record-breaking volume of 1.54 billion units. Reactions to the Fed's decision were mixed, with some experts noting that uncertainty over interest rate hikes and international developments will dominate Fed policy.

site_title: China on track to book US$1 trillion in total offshore investment
summary: China is on track to surpass $1 trillion in total offshore investment for the first time in 2015, driven by slowing economic growth and increasing internationalization of Chinese businesses. Outbound direct investment rose 18.2% to $473.4 billion in the first eight months of the year, with non-financial investments reaching $123.12 billion in 2014. The Beijing government has rolled out policies to support global efforts, offering financial incentives and removing administrative controls.

site_title: Weak China growth could affect global monetary policy
summary: A slowing Chinese economy could impact global monetary policy, primarily through its commodity trade, which drives deflationary pressures worldwide. Asia, with the largest export exposure to Chinese domestic demand, will be the most affected. Developed world economies, such as the US and Europe, are expected to be less impacted. China's financial contagion to other equity markets is limited due to its relatively closed capital account, with a correlation of weekly returns averaging 0.26. The global impact is also expected to be minimal from direct investment and financial liabilities.

site_title: Cafe culture
summary: Muji's revamped flagship store in Singapore's Paragon mall features a new in-store deli, mirroring the Japanese model. The cafe, operated under a self-service system, has been popular with customers, with reported 30-minute wait times. The store's design approach, focusing on ordinary, practical, and well-priced products, remains a key factor in Muji's enduring popularity, according to its president. The addition of the cafe aims to further enhance the store's appeal, aligning with Muji's universal and ageless product aesthetic.

images.alt_text: UNDER ONE ROOF: On the menu at Cafe&Meal Muji (above) are two deli sets - either one hot deli and two cold deli dishes with white rice or bread for S$12.90.

The new store includes having higher fixtures for better product display (above), a section that carries a baby and kids clothing line as well as offering customisation services for its furniture and fabric ranges.
Two hot deli and two cold deli dishes with white rice or bread for S$16.90 (above).

'Muji is a known lifestyle brand, so apart from selling daily necessities and clothes, there is also food.'- Satoru Matsuzaki, president and representative director of Ryohin Keikaku Co, the parent company of Muji
Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: A whiter shade of pale
summary: White wine producers have successfully balanced ripeness and acidity in 10 top-rated wines, according to the BT Wine Challenge 2015. Unlike red wines, which rely on tannins, white wines rely on acidity to deliver freshness. Harvesting grapes at the right time is an art, as over-ripeness can lead to loss of aromatic compounds. Aromatic whites, such as Gewurztraminer and Riesling, require careful balance, while neutral whites, like Chardonnay and Vermentino, are ideal for traditional sparkling wines. The top-rated wines showcase the diversity of white wines, from Alsace to New Zealand, and demonstrate the expertise of winemakers in balancing acidity and ripeness.

site_title: US oil output set to plummet as shale producers struggle with debt
summary: US shale oil producers are struggling with debt, with half of the companies in a Bloomberg index facing debt levels of 40% of their enterprise value. If more companies file for bankruptcy, US oil output could plummet by 200,000 to 400,000 barrels per day, impacting states like Oklahoma. Producers face grim choices, including bankruptcy or debt restructuring, as US oil futures have fallen to $46.90, down by half in the past year, and Goldman Sachs predicts a glut of crude may keep prices low for 15 years.

site_title: Time again for Hercules - or why Greece needs a superhero
summary: Greece is set to hold its sixth election in eight years, amid economic and social recovery concerns. The country's needs are likened to those of ancient Greek hero Hercules, who completed 12 labors to atone for past mistakes. A modern-day Hercules would need to tackle societal naivety, tax evasion, wealth flight, bureaucratic stagnation, and corruption. To address these challenges, Greece must become more realistic about healthcare and entitlements, attract investment, and realign its citizens as owners through privatisations and redistributions. The outcome of the election will determine the path forward for Greece, with the hope that leaders will tap into the country's cultural ambition and determination.

site_title: Slowing China comes to oil's rescue
summary: China's plans to build a 500 million barrel strategic oil reserve will prevent a further price crash, analysts say. The country has purchased half a million barrels of crude in excess of its daily needs, cushioning an oversupplied market. China's demand growth is set to slow to 2.3% by the fourth quarter, and its stockpiling helps shield crude against extreme losses, effectively setting a floor of $30 for Brent. The move will prevent crude from falling to $20 a barrel, but still won't be enough to eliminate the surplus of two million barrels a day.

site_title: Honeywell acquires aviation software firm
summary: Honeywell has acquired privately held aviation software firm Aviaso for an undisclosed amount, expanding its presence in Europe and boosting its portfolio. Aviaso's software products help airlines save on fuel consumption, with a single-digit percentage-point improvement translating to tens of millions of dollars in cost savings. The acquisition strengthens Honeywell's leadership in delivering energy-efficient solutions and adds fuel-management services to its growing services portfolio. This move is expected to create opportunities for further expansion in mature and high-growth markets.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Song Seng Wun keeps tabs with bellynomics
summary: Singaporean economist Song Seng Wun, 55, tracks the economy by eating at different establishments daily, comparing costs, tracking rentals, and monitoring hourly wages. He posts his findings on Facebook, where he has gained a following for his unique blend of macroeconomics and gastronomics. Mr. Song uses his observations to confirm official statistics and provide insights on labor force participation, commercial rents, and foreign labor policies, with the intention of becoming a Singapore citizen in the future.

site_title: China's Li says to widen scope for foreign investment
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang announced plans to widen the scope for foreign investment and make it easier, welcoming countries to invest in China as it is closely interconnected with the world. No specific details were provided.

site_title: Sembcorp partners EDB to be Singapore's first industrial 'living lab'
summary: Sembcorp Industries partners with the Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) to be the country's first industrial "living laboratory". The initiative grants technology providers access to Sembcorp's wastewater-treatment and waste-to-energy facilities on Jurong Island to test-bed and co-innovate water and environmental technologies. The partnership will jointly invest up to S$8 million to support research and development projects. Successful applicants will test their technologies in Sembcorp's industrial settings, with potential deployment in global operations, strengthening Singapore's position as a global hydrohub and commercialisation pathway for water research investments.

images.alt_text: MR LIM: Says the 'living lab' initiative will provide another commercialisation pathway for Singapore's water research investments.
Mindy Tan

site_title: Marina One unveils anchor retail tenants
summary: Marina One, a mixed development in Singapore's Marina Bay, has unveiled its anchor retail tenants, including Virgin Active, Cold Storage, and Cookhouse by Koufu. The fitness club will occupy 26,000 sq ft, featuring an indoor lap pool and climbing wall, while the supermarket and food court will offer a variety of local and international options. The development will also have 140,000 sq ft of retail space, 1.88 million sq ft of office space, and 1,042 luxury residential apartments. The retail strategy aims to provide a sophisticated and cosmopolitan lifestyle experience.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: US: Wall St falls as Fed frets about global growth
summary: US stocks fell on Friday, with the Dow Jones down 0.6%, the S&P 500 down 0.6%, and the Nasdaq down 1.34%, following the Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates unchanged due to concerns over global economic growth.

site_title: Singapore moving towards new five Cs
summary: Singapore is shifting its focus from traditional values to a new set of five Cs: creativity, collaboration, contribution, compassion, and confidence. This change was sparked by the death of former Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew in 2015, which brought the nation together and highlighted the importance of its people and values. The new five Cs aim to foster a renewed spirit of optimism and sustainable growth, with a focus on harnessing the potential of Singapore's people, celebrating its achievements, and preparing for its role in the growing creative economy.

site_title: Real-time data sets F1 apart
summary: Formula One teams utilize a sophisticated communication grid and advanced data analytics to gain a competitive edge. Embedded sensors in each car transmit real-time data to teams' pit crews, which then analyze it with sophisticated analytics programs to predict component behavior and optimize car performance. This actionable intelligence enables teams to make informed decisions, such as when to pit and how to adjust the car. The technology backbone has become a vital component of the sport, differentiating it from other racing events and enhancing the spectator experience through real-time data visualizations and analysis.

site_title: Homing instinct
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Singapore's home decor scene is thriving, with new stores and designers gaining popularity. Maissone, an online homeware shop, offers unique and stylish items from around the world, including bedlinen, candles, and accessories. Kuhl Home, a furniture store, offers Scandinavian designs at affordable prices. West of May, an online furniture website, allows customers to buy authentic designer furniture without waiting for long lead times. Functional art is also on display, with PLAYplay and Outofstock launching new collections with Journey East and Scanteak. These stores cater to the growing demand for stylish and affordable home decor in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: China central bank researcher urges Fed to stop guessing games
summary: A Chinese central bank researcher, Yao Yudong, has urged the Federal Reserve to stop playing "guessing games" with interest-rate decisions, suggesting the adoption of a clear pre-determined economic threshold. Yao recommends the Fed should not raise rates until inflation reaches 2.5% or the unemployment rate falls to 4.5%. He also downplayed concerns over China's impact on US policy, stating China has a "no problem" in providing liquidity and its government debt level is low. Yao's proposal is based on the Evans Rule, a past proposal by Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago President Charles Evans.

site_title: Singapore Grand Prix flags off after haze scare
summary: The Singapore Grand Prix practice session began on Friday evening despite concerns over haze, with air quality improving after downpours earlier in the week. The 24-hour Pollutant Standards Index (PSI) reading dropped from unhealthy to moderate, clearing the air for the event. The haze scare was a concern earlier in the week, but it appears the air quality has improved, allowing the practice session to proceed.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: JPMorgan 3rd-qtr trading revenue down like other firms, CEO says
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co's third-quarter markets revenue declined like other firms, with CEO Jamie Dimon stating it was "about the same as everybody else." Dimon attributed the decline to slow trading volume during three volatile weeks in August, but noted that the results were "pretty good" as the bank avoided losses. Dimon did not provide a percentage change, differing from competitors who reported a 5% decline.

site_title: Facebook counters Twitter with tool for journalists
summary: Facebook has unveiled a new tool called Signal, designed to help journalists track breaking and trending news on the social network. Signal allows journalists to surface relevant content, monitor trending topics, and access lists of public figures being mentioned on Facebook. The tool is available for both Facebook and Instagram, and enables users to save content into custom collections for later use. This move aims to challenge Twitter's dominance in the journalism space.

site_title: US Fed likely to raise rates in Dec: BlackRock's Reider
summary: The US Federal Reserve is likely to raise interest rates in December, according to BlackRock's Rick Reider, citing a 42% chance of a rate hike at the December meeting. The Fed's near-zero rate policy decision on Thursday sparked notable inflows into fixed-income funds, but a rate hike in October is seen as less likely, with a 14% chance.

site_title: BT Wine Challenge 2015 Readers' Contest
summary: The Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) is hosting the BT Wine Challenge 2015 Readers' Contest, where wine lovers can enter to win a pair of coveted invitations to an exclusive awards ceremony. To enter, participants must email their favorite wine and reason within 50 words by October 5. Three winners will be selected each week, with 15 readers standing a chance to win in total. Winners will be contacted by October 6, and must be at least 21 years old to attend.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: The Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged, citing economic weakness in China and emerging markets as a reason for holding off a rate hike. US inflation remains below 2%. This move is seen as a response to the ongoing impact of the trade war and economic instability in Asia. The decision also highlights the growing importance of dollar asset diversification in the region.

site_title: Engineering expertise will continue to be needed in next stage of Singapore's development, PM Lee tells alumni
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for engineering expertise in Singapore's next stage of development, citing the success of the pioneer batch of engineering graduates from Nanyang Technological Institute. He noted that such expertise will continue to be essential in nation-building.

site_title: Funds will return when problems are solved, but adjust in the meantime: Zeti
summary: Malaysia's Bank Negara governor Zeti Akhtar Aziz expects the country to recover from its current economic malaise faster than during the 1997-98 Asian financial crisis. However, she advises Malaysians to adjust and live within their means, as the country faces a challenging period with businesses potentially scaling back. Despite a slump in commodity prices and a cooling in consumption, Zeti maintains that Malaysia's economic fundamentals are stronger than in 1997. The government aims to sustain growth, while the US Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hikes may lead to continued capital outflows.

site_title: Payrolls rose in 32 states in August led by California, Florida
summary: US payrolls rose in 32 states in August, with California leading the nation with a 36,200 increase in employment. Florida followed with a 19,600 gain. The jobless rate fell in 29 states, with Nebraska having the lowest unemployment rate at 2.8%. The national jobless rate dropped to 5.1%, the lowest since April 2008. This steady job growth suggests the labour market is supporting US economic growth, potentially leading to higher wages and consumer spending.

site_title: Go on a virtual tour of Ferrari's F1 garage
summary: Shell and Ferrari have partnered to offer a virtual tour of the Ferrari F1 garage and paddock, featuring 360-degree photography and footage captured at the Bahrain Grand Prix. The site provides an immersive experience, allowing fans to explore the garage, watch pit stops, and access videos, data, and trivia about the team. The partnership, which dates back to the 1930s, has resulted in 12 drivers' titles and 10 constructors' championships for both teams. The site can be viewed on laptops, desktops, smartphones, or tablets, offering a unique behind-the-scenes look at F1 racing.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Cosco shares to remain suspended on parent's uncertain transaction
summary: Cosco Corporation's shares remain suspended due to uncertainty surrounding a significant transaction by its parent company, China Ocean Shipping (Group) company. The company is awaiting further study and analysis on the proposed transaction, which may impact its securities. Trading in Cosco's shares was suspended on August 11, and the suspension is expected to continue until material developments are announced. The company aims to ensure fair disclosure of information and protect investor interests.

site_title: Indian central bank chief cautions against growing economy too fast
summary: Reserve Bank of India (RBI) Governor Raghuram Rajan warned against India's economy growing too fast, citing Brazil's recession as a cautionary tale. India's economy is expanding at around 7%, while its BRICS peers face deep problems. Rajan emphasized the need for "sustainable growth" built on low inflation, urging business leaders to focus on effective methods rather than impulsive stimulus. The RBI will maintain its path, despite pressure to cut interest rates, and will review its policy on September 29.

images.alt_text: MR RAJAN: Said "our fellow BRICS all have deep problems" and that "Brazil may have overspent, China may have overinvested".

site_title: Spine-tingling spider
summary: The Ferrari 488 Spider has been revealed, offering an open-top experience with the responsiveness of a track car. The convertible features a 3.9-litre turbocharged V8 engine, producing 670 hp and 760 Nm, with a dry weight of 1,420 kg and a 0-100 km/h time of 3 seconds. The Spider shares the same spaceframe chassis as the GTB, with a wheelbase of 2,650 mm and a width of 1,952 mm. With a price expected to be similar to the 458 Spider, the Ferrari 488 Spider is set to be a thrilling drop-top option.

images.alt_text: Ferrari 488 Spider
AT 2,000 RPM IN THIRD GEAR, FOR EXAMPLE, THE 488 HAS A THROTTLE RESPONSE TIME OF A MERE 0.8 SECOND, WHICH MEANS VIRTUALLY NO TURBO LAG.

site_title: Taiwan says to remove rule that discourages stock short-selling
summary: Taiwan's financial regulator has lifted a rule that discouraged stock short-selling, allowing investors to sell short stocks at prices lower than the prior session's closing prices, effective next Monday. This decision comes as the stock market has stabilized after hitting multi-year lows in August due to concerns about a China-led global economic slowdown. The regulator cited improved stability in foreign and domestic economic development and overseas stock markets. The move is seen as a positive step for investors, with Taiwan's main index ending the day 0.2% higher at 8,462 points, about 14% above its August 24 closing level.

site_title: Europe: Fed rate inaction sends Europe down, emerging markets up
summary: The US Federal Reserve held interest rates steady, contrary to expectations, which sent European shares down and emerging markets up. The decision was made due to concerns about the impact of China's slowing economy on the US economy. This move exposed a global stock gap, with European stocks declining and emerging markets rising.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Cosco Corporation suspended trading in its shares on Friday, citing a significant transaction pending further study and analysis. QT Vascular amended its distribution agreement with Cordis to sell its Chocolate PTA balloon catheter to 88 US healthcare providers. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks rallied for a fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data, and Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss.

site_title: Leading indicators in US increase for fifth month in last six
summary: US leading economic indicators increased for the fifth month in the last six, rising 0.1% in August. The Conference Board's measure, which forecasts economic growth for the next three to six months, was boosted by a stronger housing market and slow, steady growth into 2016. Five of the 10 indicators rose last month, with low interest rates and building permits contributing to the gain. The growth is expected to remain moderate, with little reason to expect a substantial pick-up in growth.

site_title: SHS to sell refined petroleum distribution arm for S$100.3m
summary: SHS Holdings agreed to sell its refined petroleum distribution business to Brenntag for approximately S$100.3 million. The deal includes two wholly owned units, Tat Petroleum and Axxmo International. SHS expects the sale to be completed by Q4 2015 and will use the proceeds for working capital, general corporate purposes, and reducing external borrowings. The move is part of the group's strategic review to streamline businesses and boost financial flexibility.

site_title: Glencore inventory sale could sink world zinc prices further
summary: Glencore, a major zinc producer, plans to sell US$1.5 billion worth of commodity inventories to help pay off debt, potentially releasing substantial amounts of zinc onto the market. This could further sink already falling zinc prices, which have slumped 30% since their eight-month peak in May. The inventory sale, part of Glencore's efforts to slash net debt of US$30 billion, has created a plentiful supply situation, dampening the impact of mine closures and creating negative sentiment around zinc prices.

site_title: Singapore shares close weaker as Fed keeps rates unchanged
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 16.22 points to 2,879.59 on Friday, closing with a net loss of 8 points for the week. The decline followed a late selling session, with a record 1.54 billion units traded worth S$1.9 billion. The reversal was attributed to anticipation of weakness on Wall Street on Friday, following the Federal Open Market Committee's decision to keep interest rates unchanged. Jardine, OCBC, and Global Logistic Properties were among the biggest losers, with Jardine stocks set to be dropped from the index on Monday.

site_title: Pimco sees no Fed rate move until '16 as treasuries extend gains
summary: The Federal Reserve kept interest rates near zero, citing low inflation and uncertain global growth, which led to a second consecutive day of gains for US Treasuries. Pacific Investment Management Co. expects no rate hike until 2016, while JPMorgan Asset Management sees a 2016 increase. Benchmark 10-year note yields fell to 2.16% and two-year note yields rose to 0.69%. Despite the Fed's dovish tone, market-based measures of inflation expectations declined, and traders are pricing in a 46% chance of a rate hike by December.

site_title: Fed's latest rate forecasts still deemed high by traders
summary: The Federal Reserve maintained its benchmark interest rate near zero, signaling policymakers expect inflation to remain below the 2% target amid uncertain global economic growth. Despite officials cutting their median forecast for the funds rate, futures traders anticipate a delay in rate hikes until 2016. Market expectations diverge from Fed projections, with traders expecting a lower effective fed funds rate by year-end. The central bank's long-run rate was lowered to 3.5% from 3.8%.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Friday
summary: Ardian, a French alternative asset manager, agreed to buy US$1 billion of stakes in GIC's private-equity fund. A-Reit is set to acquire 26 logistics properties in Australia for A$1.013 billion. Marina One unveiled anchor tenants, including Virgin Active and Cookhouse by Koufu. SHS Holdings sold its refined petroleum distribution arm to Brenntag for S$100.3 million. Sembcorp Industries partnered with the Singapore Economic Development Board to launch Singapore's first industrial "living laboratory." The Straits Times Index closed weaker, down 16.22 points, after the Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged.

site_title: SE Asia: Stocks mixed after Fed holds rates
summary: Southeast Asian stocks were mixed on Friday after the US Federal Reserve held interest rates steady, sparking relief but also renewed concerns about the global economy. Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.6%, while Malaysia's key index declined 0.7%. Indonesia, the Philippines, and Thailand posted net foreign sales, with the Philippines gaining 3.2% on the week. Despite mixed performances, Malaysia's index remains the best performer in the region.

site_title: London fifth-priciest city in the world but earnings lag behind: UBS
summary: London ranks as the fifth most expensive city in the world, but its wage levels lag behind other major cities. The Swiss Bank UBS report found that while rent costs have increased, wages have risen more slowly than inflation since the 2007/8 financial crisis. Londoners must work 41.2 hours to afford an iPhone 6, compared to 20.6 hours in Zurich. The report attributes the shift in rankings to the Swiss National Bank's decision to abandon its currency cap, which led to a surge in the franc's value.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip on Fed's downbeat economic view
summary: European shares fell on Friday as the US Federal Reserve's downbeat comments on the global economy overshadowed its decision to keep interest rates on hold. The pan-European FTSEurofirst 300 index dropped 1% and the euro zone's Euro STOXX 50 index fell 1.2%. Uncertainty over when the Fed would raise rates weighed on markets, with traders citing the Fed's comments as a major concern.

site_title: HSBC says tech firms may face more regulation on banking services
summary: HSBC's chairman, Douglas Flint, suggests that technology companies offering financial services may face increased regulation, similar to banks. Flint expects most tech firms to partner with banks to avoid compliance costs. He notes that tech companies' handling of customer data and potential risks are major concerns. Flint sees the tech industry as a positive force in modernizing banking, but emphasizes the need for transparency and clarity on data ownership, security, and responsibility.

site_title: McDonald's investor group wants it to drop meat produced with antibiotics
summary: A McDonald's shareholder group, led by the Congregation of Benedictine Sisters, is calling for the fast-food chain to drop meat produced with antibiotics vital to fighting human infections. The move comes amid growing concern over antibiotic-resistant bacteria, with the group citing a "double standard" in McDonald's policy, which only phases out chicken produced with antibiotics. The group wants McDonald's to expand its antibiotic policy to include beef and pork, and take it globally, as 70% of antibiotics sold for human health are used in meat and dairy production.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks higher as Fed holds rates
summary: The Federal Reserve held interest rates at record lows, boosting Asian markets. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 0.30%, while Shanghai's benchmark composite index added 0.38%. Despite a volatile week, Shanghai's index closed at a new high. The US stock market also reached fresh records despite trade uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: China central bank orders banks to tighten supervision of clients' forex deals: sources
summary: China's central bank has ordered banks to tighten supervision of clients' foreign exchange deals and check the authenticity of transactions to prevent cross-border arbitrage. The People's Bank of China also raised trading fees for some banks, up to 0.3%, to settle clients' forex deals in the domestic market. The move aims to curb speculation and stabilize the currency market.

site_title: India's central bank chief warns against chasing economic growth too fast
summary: India's central bank governor, Raghuram Rajan, warns against rapidly pursuing economic growth, citing the need to keep inflation low. Despite growing pressure to cut interest rates, Rajan suggests that monetary policy alone and short-term government incentives may not be enough to fuel sustainable growth. He emphasizes the importance of implementing announced reforms to expand sustainable growth potential, rather than relying on rate cuts or short-term measures.

images.alt_text: India must focus on keeping inflation low and avoid using monetary policy alone and short-term government incentives to fuel short-term economic growth, the country's central bank governor said on Friday.

site_title: China to continue crackdowns on illegal share sales and speculative trading
summary: China's securities regulator will continue its crackdowns on illegal share sales and speculative trading, having recently probed 19 cases. Major shareholders of a company reduced stakes worth 900 million yuan (US$141.45 million) in a bid to reduce selling pressure in the volatile stock market. China has banned major shareholders from reducing stakes for the next six months.

site_title: US moves to open up business with Cuba, ease embargo
summary: The US has issued regulations easing restrictions on American companies seeking to do business in Cuba, further weakening the US trade embargo. The new rules allow US companies to establish a presence in Cuba, open offices, stores, and warehouses, and provide telecommunications and Internet services. They also ease travel restrictions and increase educational opportunities, while lifting the cap on remittances. The move comes as Washington and Havana move towards normal relations, with US Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew stating that the US-Cuba relationship has the potential to create economic opportunities for both Americans and Cubans.

site_title: China: Stocks edge up after Fed holds rates, down for the week
summary: China's stocks rose 0.4% on Friday, ending a volatile week down 2.9% after the US Federal Reserve held off on raising interest rates citing a weak global economy. The CSI300 index closed at 3,251.27, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose to 3,097.92, also down 3.2% for the week. The market has seen extreme fluctuations due to concerns over the economy and efforts to clean up unregulated financing and curb corruption.

site_title: Greece must keep reforming to stay in euro: ECB's Coeure
summary: Greece must continue to implement economic reforms to remain in the eurozone, according to European Central Bank Executive Board member Benoit Coeure. Greece is set to vote in a general election on Sunday, with the winner needing to oversee reforms required for an 86 billion euro bailout, bank recapitalization, and the unwinding of capital controls. Coeure emphasized the need for Greece to continue reforming to stay in the eurozone, highlighting the importance of meeting these conditions to avoid economic instability.

site_title: Asia-Europe container freight rates drop 22.4%: source
summary: Shipping freight rates for transporting containers on the world's busiest route have dropped by 22.4% to US$456 from Asia to Northern Europe, the lowest level since July 24. This marks the second consecutive week of decline. Despite an initial increase in 8 weeks this year, freight rates have now fallen in 28 weeks. The drop is attributed to a decrease in demand and increased competition in the market.

site_title: Update: Fed rate decision lifts Asia markets, emerging currencies
summary: The US Federal Reserve decided to hold interest rates steady, alleviating concerns about emerging market currencies and most Asian markets. The decision was made despite warnings of a "perfect storm" in financial markets and a slowdown in the global economy. Emerging market currencies rose, with the South Korean won and Malaysian ringgit gaining 0.27% and 0.50% respectively. The decision gave central bankers in emerging markets "breathing room" to be more accommodative, and analysts expect the uncertainty of when rates will rise to be as damaging as an actual rate hike.

site_title: QT Vascular revises deal with Cordis to sell its product in US
summary: QT Vascular has signed an amendment to its distribution agreement with Cordis Corporation, allowing the company to sell its Chocolate PTA balloon catheter to a select group of 88 US healthcare providers with immediate effect. This revised deal supports QT Vascular's goal of increasing adoption and use of the product in the US. Prior to the amendment, Cordis was the sole distributor of the balloon catheter in the US.

site_title: Asiatravel.com up 22% on news of cash offer
summary: Asiatravel.com Holdings shares surged 22% after the company announced a cash offer from its substantial shareholder, ZhongHong Holding, at 30 Singapore cents per share. ZhongHong owns 11.4% of Asiatravel.com. The counter resumed trading after a trading halt, gaining five Singapore cents to 28 Singapore cents.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Seoul: Shares, won rise on relief from Fed decision
summary: South Korean shares rose 1.0% to 1,995.95 points, while the won gained 0.3% to 1,162.8 per dollar, as relief from the US Federal Reserve's decision to hold off on raising interest rates offset global market concerns. This marks the won's 1.9% gain against the dollar since the week began, its fastest increase since December 2011.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 12.09 points to close at 1,669.45 on Friday, with 2.03 billion lots valued at RM2.63 billion traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 482 to 384. The decline was attributed to the lower stock market performance, with no specific news or events mentioned.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: Creative Technology has warned that its H2 revenue may be below target, with an operating loss similar to that in the first half of the year. The company's earnings were not the main focus of the news, however. The article actually focused on other news stories including US stocks opening lower due to Trump's tariffs on Canada, a potential £10 billion upgrade at Heathrow airport with higher fees, and Singapore's economic news, such as MAS and PBOC deepening cooperation in green finance.

site_title: Marina One unveils anchor tenants
summary: Marina One, a Singapore development, has secured anchor retail and food & beverage tenants including Virgin Active, Cold Storage, and Cookhouse by Koufu. The development, expected to receive its temporary occupation permit in 2017, aims to be a premium destination for living, working, and playing. Other notable tenants include Teppei Syokudo, Jewel coffee house, and 4 Fingers Crispy Chicken. This lineup reinforces Marina One's vision to cater to a sophisticated and cosmopolitan audience, with a focus on introducing new lifestyle and retail experiences.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

Artist's impression of Marina One.Marina One announced on Friday that it had secured a strong line-up of anchor retail and food & beverage (F&B) brands that include Virgin Active, Cold Storage and Cookhouse by Koufu, ahead of the Singapore development's expected issuance of its temporary occupation permit in 2017.

site_title: Apple to launch online payment in China: report
summary: Apple plans to launch an online payment service in China, following a similar move in the Shanghai Free Trade Zone. The company, led by CEO Tim Cook, aims to expand in its largest market outside the US, despite fierce competition from local rivals like Alibaba's Alipay. Apple Pay is expected to be set up in China "as quickly as possible," with the goal of surpassing the US as Apple's largest market.

site_title: Sembcorp partners EDB to launch Singapore's first industrial living lab
summary: Sembcorp Industries has partnered with the Singapore Economic Development Board to launch Singapore's first industrial "living laboratory". The lab will grant technology providers access to Sembcorp's wastewater treatment and waste-to-energy facilities for testing and co-innovation of water and environmental technologies. The partnership will jointly invest up to $8 million in R&D projects, with successful applicants having the potential to be deployed globally. The initiative aims to raise Singapore's profile as a hub for applied R&D and support the growth of the water and energy sectors.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Asia: Fed rate decision lifts markets, Singdollar and emerging currencies; STI up 0.6%
summary: The US Federal Reserve decided to hold off hiking interest rates, lifting Asian markets and emerging currencies. The Straits Times Index rose 0.63% as investors became more optimistic about the global economy. The decision eased concerns over a cash outflow from emerging markets, which had been declining due to a slowdown. The Singapore dollar strengthened 0.15% and other emerging currencies, such as the South Korea won and Malaysian ringgit, also gained. The decision was seen as giving emerging market central bankers more room to be accommodative without being offset by a tighter Fed.

site_title: Snapchatters have 24 hours to see Burberry's new collection
summary: Burberry's new spring-summer collection will be showcased on Snapchat for 24 hours starting September 20, allowing the luxury brand to reach its 100 million active users. The collection will be available on the brand's Snapchat channel until the following afternoon, when it will disappear. This initiative aims to generate buzz and excitement for the collection, which will be introduced at a catwalk show during London fashion week.

images.alt_text: Burberry Group's new spring-summer collection will vanish after only a day - on the Snapchat messaging application.

site_title: EU could lose 3.5m jobs if cuts trade defences against China: report
summary: The European Union may lose up to 3.5 million jobs if it removes trade defenses against China, according to a study. EU imports of manufactured goods are expected to rise 25-50% over the next three years, with Chinese export prices potentially decreasing by 30%. If granted "market economy status" by the World Trade Organization, China's artificially low prices could strip 1-2 percentage points from the EU's GDP, resulting in job losses in sectors such as automotive parts, steel, and ceramics.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks defy Asia rally after Fed holds fire
summary: Tokyo shares fell almost 2% on Friday, defying a rally across Asian stocks, after the US Federal Reserve held interest rate hikes. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 1.96% to 18,070.21, as the yen strengthened against the dollar. This move countered a regional rally, where Singapore stocks rose 5 days in a row ahead of GDP data and US stocks reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore's NEA tenders to explore e-waste collection, recycling and management
summary: The National Environment Agency (NEA) in Singapore has tendered for a study on e-waste collection, recycling, and management as part of the country's efforts to become a Zero Waste Nation. The study aims to identify a system for collecting and recycling e-waste, including a survey of the entire e-waste value chain. The findings will help the agency minimize public health concerns and environmental impact from e-waste, which may contain valuable and hazardous materials. The study is part of Singapore's broader efforts to safeguard public health and reduce waste.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: France backs yuan inclusion in IMF's currency basket: finance minister Sapin
summary: France backs China's efforts to include the yuan in the IMF's currency basket, supporting Beijing's bid to strengthen the yuan's position in global trade. French Finance Minister Michel Sapin stated this at the China-France High-Level Economic and Financial Dialogue. China aims to push financial reforms to make the yuan more convertible and has pledged to work with France to boost the role of the yuan and euro in the international monetary system.

site_title: Fed decision likely reflected voice of emerging economies: Japan finance minister
summary: US Federal Reserve keeps interest rates steady, likely influenced by emerging economies' concerns about rapid rate hikes damaging their economies. Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso said the decision reflected lobbying by countries such as Brazil, Russia, and India at the recent G20 meeting, where they voiced worries about capital flight and currency depreciation. The Fed left room for a modest policy tightening later this year, amid global economic concerns and sluggish inflation.

site_title: Oil prices weak on economic concerns, Opec target on market share
summary: Oil prices declined on Friday due to economic concerns and Opec's focus on market share. US WTI crude futures fell to $46.72 per barrel, while Brent prices rose to $49.12 per barrel. Kuwait stated that the oil market will balance itself, but this process will take time, supporting Opec's policy of defending market share despite falling prices. The US kept interest rates at historic lows, further contributing to the weak oil prices.

site_title: Another US$1b payment from 1MDB to Abu Dhabi fund is missing: Wall Street Journal
summary: Malaysia's state investor 1MDB allegedly made a US$1 billion payment to Abu Dhabi's International Petroleum Investment Co (IPIC) but the funds are missing, according to a Wall Street Journal report. This is the latest in a series of discrepancies, following a previously reported US$1.4 billion transfer that was not received. The missing payment is part of a larger issue of unaccounted funds from 1MDB, raising concerns about the financial dealings of the Malaysian government. An investigation is ongoing.

images.alt_text: Another US$1 billion (S$1.4 billion) in payment from Malaysia's state investor 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB) to Abu Dhabi's International Petroleum Investment Co (IPIC) is allegedly missing, the Wall Street Journal (WSJ) said.

site_title: Indonesia sees pressure on rupiah continuing as US delays rate hike
summary: Indonesia's rupiah continues to face pressure due to the US Federal Reserve's delay in raising interest rates, according to the country's chief economics minister. The rupiah weakened 0.07% to 14,465 per dollar, touching a 17-year low of 14,470. The Fed's decision left open the possibility of a modest policy tightening later this year, which could ease pressures on the rupiah.

site_title: Australia: Shares close higher, up strongly on week
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% on Friday, closing at 5,170.5, to reach a 2% weekly gain. The rally was driven by a reassuring assessment of the economy by RBA Governor Glenn Stevens, which countered a cautious tone from the Federal Reserve. The big four banks, including Westpac, also closed higher, with Westpac up 1.3%. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.3%. The gains followed a mixed session on Wall Street.

site_title: Australia: Stocks slip after US keeps rates on hold
summary: Australian stocks fell 0.28% at the open on Friday after the US Federal Reserve left interest rates near zero, with the S&P/ASX200 index dropping 14.32 points to 5,132.5. This move follows mixed signals from the Fed, which sparked uncertainty among investors. The US stock market, however, continued to rise, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records.

site_title: Gold dips as Fed move to hold US rates adds to uncertainty
summary: Gold prices dropped 0.3% to $1,127.80 an ounce, reversing gains from the last two days, amid uncertainty over the US Federal Reserve's decision to hold interest rates steady. The Fed maintained its bias towards a rate hike this year, despite global economic concerns. Gold was on track to end a three-week losing streak with a near 2% gain. The decision added to market uncertainty, which has been fueled by Trump's tariff moves.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks drop slightly after Fed holds rates steady
summary: Taiwan's stocks dropped slightly on Friday, trailing regional markets, after the US Federal Reserve held interest rates steady. The TAIEX index fell 0.2% to 8,425.94, amid worries over global economic growth and subdued domestic inflation. The electronics subindex declined 0.2%, while the financials subindex lost 0.8%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$32.404 per US dollar.

site_title: BOJ members agreed emerging economies will pick up longer term: minutes
summary: Bank of Japan policymakers agree emerging economies, such as China, will experience weak growth but are likely to improve from a longer-term perspective. However, they must remain vigilant to the risk of a decline in exports due to a prolonged slowdown in these economies. The BOJ has kept monetary policy steady, but its forecast that inflation will reach 2% by September next year is under threat due to weakening emerging market demand and a decline in exports.

site_title: Seoul: Shares rise, won holds steady after Fed decision
summary: Seoul shares rose to a one-month high, driven by non-cyclical shares such as cosmetics and pharmaceuticals. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) increased 0.6% to 1,988.12, with pharmaceutical shares up 4.6% and cosmetics makers rising 4-4.7%. The US Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged, citing global economic concerns, but left room for potential policy tightening later this year. Foreigners sold 23.1 billion won of shares, while South Korean bond prices rose amid a growing possibility of a rate cut.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.34 points to 1680.58 on Friday, with 98 gainers outnumbering 47 losers. The market saw a higher opening, with 29.7 million lots traded worth RM13.5 million.

site_title: Ringgit poised to snap longest run of weekly declines since 1971
summary: Malaysia's ringgit is poised to snap its longest run of weekly declines in over 40 years, after the US Federal Reserve held interest rates near zero and Brent crude prices improved. The ringgit strengthened 1.7% to 4.2467 a dollar, its first weekly advance in three months, and pared its loss this year to 18%. The delay in US interest rate hikes reduces the risk of outflows from Malaysian debt and stocks, and improved oil prices are also contributing to the ringgit's rebound.

site_title: Singapore keeps Asia-Pac's top spot on Global Innovation Index
summary: Singapore has maintained its top spot in the Asia-Pacific region on the Global Innovation Index (GII) 2015, ranking seventh globally. The US, UK, Japan, Germany, and Switzerland lead in innovation quality, while China, Brazil, and India excel in middle-income economies. The GII, co-published by Cornell University, Insead, and WIPO, surveys 141 economies using 79 indicators to gauge innovative capabilities and results. Singapore's position remains stable, with Ireland entering the top 10 and the Czech Republic entering the top 25.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Wall Street banks now eye December for Fed rate liftoff: Reuters poll
summary: Wall Street banks now expect the US Federal Reserve to raise interest rates in December, according to a Reuters poll. This comes after the Fed left interest rates unchanged on September 17, with 12 of 17 primary dealers forecasting a rate hike in December, and two in October and three in March 2016. The Fed maintained its bias toward a rate hike this year, with policy meetings in October and December. The expectation of a December rate hike is a tactical delay, with economists predicting four hikes in 2016 and 2017.

site_title: Malaysia August inflation seen at 3.0%, below July pace
summary: Malaysia's inflation in August is expected to be 3.0%, lower than July's 3.3%, due to lower fuel prices and the post-Eid al-Fitr celebrations. The country's economic growth slowed in the second quarter, but inflation has risen steadily since the implementation of a 6% Goods and Services Tax in April. This marks a slight cooling of inflation, which had previously risen above expectations in July.

site_title: Singapore shares open marginally lower
summary: Singapore shares dropped 3.54 points or 0.12% to 2,892.27 in early trading following the US Federal Reserve's decision not to raise interest rates due to concerns about the global economy. The Dow Jones Industrial Average slipped 36.25 points, while the US dollar sank after the Fed statement. Losers outnumbered gainers 53 to 51.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Most Asian stocks fall as Fed holds rates; Japanese shares slide
summary: Asian stocks fell as the Federal Reserve held interest rates steady, sparking concerns about the global economy. Most Asian stocks dropped, with Japan's Topix index retreating 0.9% and China's Shanghai Composite Index slipping 2.1%. The Fed's decision showed reluctance to end record monetary stimulus amid uncertainty over China and other developing nations. Odds of a US interest rate hike this year have fallen below 50%, with Fed Chair Janet Yellen citing the recent turmoil as a restraint on the US economy.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on RBA governor's upbeat assessment of economy
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% on Friday following RBA Governor Glenn Stevens' upbeat assessment of the economy, with the S&P/ASX 200 index reaching 5,175.0. Stevens expressed satisfaction with monetary policy and comfort with the Australian dollar, citing a lack of risk in raising interest rates. The strong rally was tempered by global growth concerns, with the US Federal Reserve leaving rates unchanged. The index is on track for its second straight week of gains, with analysts citing a cautious market response to the Fed's decision.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks fall 0.85% after US holds fire on rate rise
summary: Tokyo shares fell 0.85% on Friday after the US Federal Reserve decided to leave interest rates unchanged near zero due to global economic concerns. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 156.79 points to 18,275.48. This decision followed mixed Fed views and uncertainty over US-China trade tensions.

site_title: China home prices up 0.3% in August, rise for 4th month
summary: China's average new home prices rose 0.3% in August, marking the fourth consecutive month of growth, according to the National Bureau of Statistics. Prices are down 2.3% from last year, with Shanghai seeing a 5.6% increase and Beijing a 3.0% rise. Analysts say a full-blown property recovery is unlikely due to a large oversupply of homes, but government support measures have helped home sales and prices gradually improve.

site_title: Fed gifts emerging markets a lifeline at expense of euro, yen
summary: The Federal Reserve kept interest rates near zero, providing emerging markets with a reprieve from currency slumps and outflows. This move stems from concerns about slowing global growth, particularly in China, and avoids destabilizing global markets. As a result, emerging-market currencies rose 0.8% from their lowest point, while the euro and yen strengthened against the US dollar, creating challenges for European and Japanese central bankers seeking to weaken their currencies. The Fed's decision allows emerging markets to maintain accommodative policies, while ECB and BOJ officials face uphill struggles to achieve their goals.

site_title: A-Reit to acquire logistics portfolio in Australia for A$1.013b
summary: A-Reit is set to acquire a logistics portfolio in Australia for A$1.013 billion from GIC and Frasers Property Australia. The 26 properties in Sydney, Melbourne, and Brisbane will be A-Reit's first Australian acquisition, establishing it as the eighth largest industrial landlord in the country. The portfolio has a 6.4% net property income yield and a weighted average lease expiry of 6.1 years. The acquisition is expected to be completed in the fourth quarter of 2015, further diversifying A-Reit's portfolio geographically and enhancing its customer base with high-calibre end-users and multinational tenants.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Taiwan central bank may cut discount rate for first time since 2009
summary: Taiwan's central bank may cut its policy interest rate for the first time since 2009, citing concerns over the global economy and slowing tech exports. Following the Federal Reserve's decision to hold off on raising interest rates, SinoPac Securities predicts a 1.75% discount rate cut. The move aims to ease policy as Taiwan's economic growth has dropped to a six-year low, and demand for tech shipments is faltering.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians walk past stores in the shopping district of Ximending in Taipei, Taiwan, on Monday, on Dec 8, 2014. Taiwan's central bank may cut its policy interest rate for the first time since 2009 next week, as China's slowdown and weak global demand dampen the island's tech exports and economic growth outlook.

site_title: Hong Kong, China: Stocks open up as Fed holds rates
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.10% on Friday, following the US Federal Reserve's decision to hold interest rates. The Hang Seng Index increased 21.50 points to 21,876.13, while Shanghai's composite index gained 0.46% and the Shenzhen Composite Index added 0.60%. The moves were seen as a positive response to the Fed's decision, which was expected to be neutral. The regional market advance was also influenced by other factors, including the ongoing US-EU trade talks and the US stock market's edge to fresh records.

site_title: Fed rate delay lifts Singdollar, emerging market currencies but stocks fall
summary: The US Federal Reserve held off hiking interest rates, causing the US dollar to retreat and emerging market currencies to rise. The decision, attributed to concerns about the global economy, particularly China, gave emerging market central bankers "breathing room" to be more accommodative. However, the news spooked investors, leading to a decline in regional stock markets, including Tokyo, Sydney, and Seoul. Economists warn that a rate hike is still likely, with some predicting a "perfect storm" in financial markets.

site_title: Ardian said to buy US$1 billion of GIC private-equity fund stakes
summary: Ardian, a French alternative asset manager, agreed to buy a portfolio of private-equity fund stakes worth about US$1 billion from Singapore's GIC Pte. The deal was made at a premium to book value, avoiding an auction. This follows Ardian's recent US$9 billion fund raise to invest in secondary deals. The stakes become more valuable as buyout firms sell more assets.

site_title: 'Mad Men', 'Game of Thrones' to battle for Emmys glory
summary: The 67th Primetime Emmy Awards will be held on Sunday, with "Game of Thrones" and "Mad Men" competing for top honors. "Game of Thrones" has earned 24 nominations, while "Mad Men" has won the coveted outstanding drama trophy four times but has yet to win for its lead actor, Jon Hamm. The ceremony may see a history-making win for black women, with Viola Davis and Taraji P. Henson in contention for lead actress in a drama category. Other contenders include "Transparent" and "Veep," which may dethrone "Modern Family" for best comedy series.

site_title: Quick takes: Here's what Wall Street is saying about the Fed's decision to keep rates unchanged
summary: The Federal Reserve has kept interest rates unchanged, following a statement that highlighted recent global economic and financial developments that may restrain economic activity. Analysts and economists across Wall Street have mixed reactions, with some seeing the decision as prudent given the current economic climate and others expressing concerns about the potential for a policy mistake. Despite the uncertainty, most expect the Fed to raise rates this year, with some predicting a single move in December. The decision has sparked debate about the timing of future rate hikes, with some warning of a paralyzing discussion about when the Fed will eventually raise rates.

site_title: Silverlake Axis buys SunGard Ambit for US$12m
summary: Silverlake Axis acquired SunGard Ambit for US$12 million to expand its software and services, deepen customer relationships, and broaden geographical presence. The acquisition is expected to contribute 15% to the enlarged group's revenue and create revenue synergies through cross-selling. CEO Raymond Kwong stated the deal will position Silverlake Axis as a leading player in digital financial technology adoption and innovation.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Bitcoin is officially a commodity, according to US regulator
summary: The US Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) has officially designated Bitcoin as a commodity, subject to its regulations. This move asserts the agency's authority to oversee trading of cryptocurrency futures and options, and allows it to bring charges against bad actors. The decision has significant implications for the cryptocurrency market, potentially leading to increased oversight and regulation. The CFTC's action follows a settlement with a Bitcoin exchange that facilitated trading of option contracts.

site_title: Dollar nurses losses after Fed refrains from rate hike
summary: The US dollar recouped some losses against the euro and other currencies after the Federal Reserve held interest rates steady and cut its long-term US growth outlook. The dollar index rose 0.1% to 94.632, while the euro hit a three-week high of $1.1441. The Fed's decision to refrain from a rate hike left the door open for a potential policy tightening later this year, but 13 of 17 policymakers still expect a rate hike in 2015, down from 15 at the previous meeting.

site_title: Oil prices dip as Fed holds rate at zero
summary: Oil prices dropped on Thursday as traders reacted to the Federal Reserve's decision to keep its benchmark interest rate at zero, citing concerns about global growth. US West Texas Intermediate oil fell 25 cents to $46.90 a barrel, while European Brent oil lost 67 cents to $49.08 a barrel. The rate decision weighed on oil prices, despite other market factors, such as Trump's tariffs and China's solar industry.

images.alt_text: World oil prices dipped Thursday as traders weighed a Federal Reserve decision to keep its benchmark interest rate at zero, citing worries about global growth.

site_title: South Korea August producer prices fall at fastest rate in 16-1/2 years
summary: South Korea's producer prices fell 4.4% in August, the fastest annual decline in 16-1/2 years, driven by low energy prices and weak demand. This marks the 13th consecutive month of year-on-year declines, indicating benign consumer inflation. Global raw material costs were lower, and demand remained weak, easing price pressure across major categories.

images.alt_text: South Korea's producer prices fell in August at their sharpest annual pace in 16-and-a-half years on low energy prices and weak demand, central bank data showed on Friday, indicating benign consumer inflation ahead.

site_title: US: Wall St ends down after choppy session; Fed holds rates
summary: US stocks ended lower on Thursday after the Federal Reserve held interest rates steady, citing concerns about global economic growth and financial market volatility. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite rose, but the Dow Jones industrial average fell. Investors are now expecting interest rates to remain low for longer, with the next Fed meeting on October 27-28 expected to be closely watched for a potential rate increase.

site_title: Apple wins patent ruling against Samsung in US appeals court
summary: A US appeals court ruled in favor of Apple, stating that the lower court abused its discretion when denying Apple an injunction against Samsung for infringing three of its patents. The court ruled that Apple's proposed injunction is narrow and does not ban Samsung's devices from the marketplace. The case, which involved Apple patents for iPhone features, was sent back to a federal district court in California to reconsider the injunction. Apple has won every round in the ongoing patent dispute with Samsung, but its impact may be limited as Samsung has likely designed around the features or abandoned them.

site_title: China's game makers target US$6.8b Japanese 'treasure chest'
summary: Chinese smartphone game makers are targeting a US$6.8 billion share of Japan's mobile gaming market, with over 480 vendors attending the Tokyo Game Show, a record attendance.
