summary: Google has launched an online fundraising campaign to support relief efforts for the migration crisis in Europe, the Middle East, and Africa. The company is donating $1.12 million and will match donations up to an additional $5 million. The funds will be split among Doctors Without Borders, International Rescue Committee, Save the Children, and the UN High Commissioner for Refugees, with no processing fees taken. Google aims to make it easy for users to donate and support these organizations, which provide essential assistance to people in need.

images.alt_text: Google launched an online campaign Wednesday to get users to donate to relief efforts for the migration crisis affecting Europe, the Middle East and Africa.

site_title: US home builder sentiment near decade high in September: NAHB
summary: US homebuilder sentiment reached a nearly decade high in September, according to the National Association of Home Builders, with the NAHB/Wells Fargo Housing Market index rising to 62 from 61 in August. This is the highest reading since October 2005. Builders remain concerned about building lot and labor availability, but expect housing to continue at a steady, modest rate through the end of the year. Single-family home sales component rose to 67, the highest since November 2005, while prospective buyer traffic reached a year-high of 47.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed higher on Wednesday, rising 7.52 points to 1,647.15. The index saw 2.29 billion lots valued at RM2.39 billion traded, with 432 gainers and 415 losers.

site_title: US: Stocks up as Fed meeting looms; inflation weak
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday as the market digested a weak reading on consumer prices ahead of a key Federal Reserve interest rate decision. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 39.95 points, the S&P 500 advanced 5.04 points, and the Nasdaq Composite Index added 9.81 points. The Labor Department reported a 0.1% decline in consumer prices in August, driven by falling gasoline prices. The Fed is expected to raise interest rates for the first time in nine years, with a 30% chance of a rate hike, according to Wells Fargo Advisors.

site_title: Update: WP's Lee Li Lian, Dennis Tan and Leon Perera declared as Non-Constituency MPs
summary: The Elections Department of Singapore has declared three Workers' Party (WP) candidates, Lee Li Lian, Dennis Tan, and Leon Perera, as Non-Constituency MPs (NCMPs) after the Sept 11 General Election. Lee and Tan received the top two highest percentages of votes among unelected Opposition candidates. They will join the list of NCMPs alongside other WP candidates.

images.alt_text: The Elections Department has declared three Workers' Party (WP) candidates - Lee Li Lian, Dennis Tan, and Leon Perera - elected as Non-Constituency MPs (NCMPs).

site_title: Greek Jan-Aug central govt budget surplus beats target
summary: Greece's central government recorded a 3.8 billion euro primary budget surplus in the first eight months of the year, exceeding its target of 3.2 billion euros. This indicates a reduction in spending, contributing to the country's financial stability. The surplus is a positive sign for Greece's economy, which has been struggling with debt and austerity measures.

images.alt_text: Greece's central government recorded a primary budget surplus of 3.8 billion euros in the first eight months of the year, beating its target as it cut spending, finance ministry data showed on Wednesday.

site_title: China's Hangzhou awarded host 2022 Asian Games
summary: Hangzhou, China was awarded the 2022 Asian Games, marking China's third time hosting the event after Beijing in 1990 and Guangzhou in 2010. The decision was made by the Olympic Council of Asia at its congress in Ashgabat, Turkmenistan. China will host two major multi-sport events in the same year, following Beijing's win in the 2022 Winter Olympics. The award is seen as a way for China's government to boost its international image and legitimacy, with analysts citing motives such as promoting national pride and inter-regional rivalry.

site_title: Euro governments have recovered less than half of bank aid: ECB
summary: Eurozone governments have recovered less than half of the financial aid provided to banks since the global financial crisis, with outstanding guarantees worth 2.7% of the eurozone's GDP. This recovery rate is low by international comparison, posing additional risks. The European Central Bank notes that nearly a fifth of the total debt increase in the bloc from 2008 to 2014 was related to the bank aid, with Ireland and Greece having the biggest debt impact. Governments have raised deposit insurance guarantees, potentially creating higher fiscal costs in the long run.

site_title: Thailand approves US$2.2b in investment projects
summary: Thailand's investment agency approved US$2.2 billion in projects, including a Ford Motor investment to produce pick-up trucks, and offered tax benefits to speed up investment and stimulate the economy. The military government aims to revive Southeast Asia's second-largest economy, which has struggled with weak exports and domestic demand. The approvals are part of the government's efforts to step up infrastructure plans and accelerate private investment projects, with a goal of boosting growth to 3% in 2015. Tax benefits will be offered to projects in special economic zones and designated provinces.

site_title: US consumer prices post first decline in seven months
summary: US consumer prices dropped 0.1% in August, the first decline in seven months, as gasoline prices fell and the strong dollar reduced costs of other goods. The Labor Department reported the decline, which contrasts with a tight labor market and highlights the Federal Reserve's dilemma over raising interest rates. The 0.2% year-over-year increase in the Consumer Price Index in August is below expectations, sparking concerns about tame inflation.

site_title: UK earnings rise at fastest pace in more than six years
summary: British earnings, excluding bonuses, rose at their fastest rate in over six years, growing 2.9% in the May-July period, surpassing forecasts. This marked the fastest pace of growth in regular earnings since February 2009. The increase was largely driven by the retail sector, which experienced strong growth. The data suggests the UK economy is continuing to recover from the Brexit-induced slowdown.

site_title: BOC Aviation seeks US$500m in Asia's first aircraft securitisation: sources
summary: Singapore-based BOC Aviation Pte Ltd plans to raise at least US$500 million through Asia's first aircraft securitisation, selling a portfolio of 24 aircraft and their associated operating leases. Citigroup will manage the deal, and underwriters have started roadshows to drum up interest. The transaction taps into growing demand for aviation assets, with aircraft viewed as secure and scalable assets. This marks a significant move by BOC Aviation, the second-largest lessor in Asia, to diversify its funding sources.

images.alt_text: Singapore-based BOC Aviation Pte Ltd is looking to raise at least US$500 million in Asia's first asset-backed securitisation by an aircraft lessor, tapping into growing demand for aviation assets, people familiar with the matter said.

site_title: One trader just made US$1.7m on AB InBev's impending offer
summary: A trader made a $1.7 million profit after buying a block of AB InBev calls, betting on an 11% increase in the company's shares over the next three months. The trade, which cost $1.2 million, is now worth $2.6 million after AB InBev announced its intention to bid for SABMiller. The move sent AB InBev shares up 12% and boosted the Stoxx Europe 600 Index by 1.5%. Analysts say the trade is a "clever move" and a sign that investors believe a deal will be made.

site_title: Water cannon fired on Malaysian pro-government demonstrators
summary: Malaysian riot police fired water cannons on ethnic Malay protesters in Kuala Lumpur, sparking racial tensions in the multi-ethnic country. The pro-government rally, attended by thousands, denounced the Chinese minority and demanded access to tourist streets. The demonstration was criticized as racially provocative and raised concerns about racial intolerance. The rally came amid calls for Prime Minister Najib Razak's resignation due to a financial scandal and allegations of corruption and electoral chicanery.

images.alt_text: Malaysian riot police on Wednesday fired water cannon on ethnic Malay protesters staging a pro-government rally in the capital Kuala Lumpur that has raised racial tensions in the multi-ethnic country.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher as traders anticipate Fed leaving rates unchanged
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 26.8 points to 2,868.74 on Wednesday, following a Wall Street rally, as traders anticipate the US Federal Reserve may not raise interest rates at its meeting on Thursday. The probability of a rate hike this week is 32%, with a 62% chance of postponing the first hike to December. The low-volume trading session saw contributions from blue chips like Jardine Matheson and Hongkong Land, with UOB and OCBC also seeing rises.

site_title: Brewing mega deal nears as AB InBev approaches SABMiller
summary: Anheuser-Busch InBev (AB InBev) is set to make a bid for SABMiller, the world's second-largest brewer, in a deal that would create the world's largest beer company. The acquisition would bring together AB InBev and SABMiller, combining their control of about half of the brewing industry's profit. The deal would be the largest in the industry's history, and its completion would cap over a decade of consolidation in the brewing industry.

site_title: EU proposes special dispute court for US trade deal: official
summary: The European Union proposed creating a special dispute court to resolve trade disputes under the TTIP deal with the US, replacing private tribunals that have been widely criticized. EU Trade Commissioner Cecilia Malmstrom cited a "fundamental lack of trust" in the current plans. The move aims to address concerns about the deal's impact on EU citizens and businesses.

images.alt_text: More than half of the European Union's 28 nations plan to prohibit the cultivation of a group of genetically modified crops awaiting EU regulatory approval, marking the first use by individual governments of a new right to go their own way on the planting of biotech foods.

site_title: Thai prime minister says election likely in July 2017
summary: Thailand's Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha has stated that a general election is likely to take place in July 2017, despite efforts to hasten the process. The delay is attributed to the rejection of a new constitution by the National Reform Council, which has pushed the timeframe back by a year. Prayuth has portrayed himself as a reluctant leader, but his ties to the military faction and conservative establishment have raised concerns about his intentions. The rejection of the constitution has also fueled debate about the potential for military rule to prolong its grip on power.

images.alt_text: A general election in Thailand could come in July 2017 and not much sooner, despite efforts by the military government to hasten the process, the prime minister said on Wednesday.

site_title: GE2015: NCMP seats offered to Lee Li Lian, Dennis Tan and one from WP's East Coast team
summary: The Elections Department of Singapore has offered Non-Constituency MP seats to Workers' Party (WP) members Lee Li Lian, Dennis Tan, and one East Coast GRC team member. The WP has until Tuesday to accept the offers and select a candidate from its East Coast GRC team.

images.alt_text: The Elections Department has written to the Workers' Party (WP) to offer Non-Constituency MP seats to Ms Lee Li Lian, Mr Dennis Tan, and one member of the party's East Coast GRC team.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up 0.81% amid global rally
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.81% on Wednesday, following a global rally ahead of the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 18,171.60, while the Topix index gained 0.71%. The global rally was driven by positive sentiments in the US and Europe, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Swiss economic prospects hit 2015 high in ZEW poll
summary: Switzerland's economic prospects have reached an 18-month high in a ZEW poll, with analysts expecting a robust domestic economy and a gradual weakening of the Swiss franc to support growth. The Swiss ZEW indicator rose to 9.7 points, its highest since March 2014, despite uncertainty over the economy's growth outlook. The Swiss National Bank is set to deliver its quarterly policy assessment, with almost all surveyed analysts expecting no changes to interest rates in the near term. The poll also showed that inflation expectations remain stable, with no financial analyst projecting a falling inflation rate for Switzerland.

site_title: LTA's S$1.3b bond sale gets strong reception amid weak market
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) successfully sold S$1.3 billion in bonds, including a five-year and 15-year tranche, amidst a weak market. The bonds were met with strong demand from insurers, asset managers, and banks, with the 15-year tranche attracting significant interest due to its long tenure. The sale highlights the market's willingness to invest in fixed-rate issues, despite volatility, and points to the general illiquidity of the local debt market. The LTA's triple-A status enabled it to sell the bonds at a competitive price, with the 15-year bond offering a 3.51% coupon.

site_title: Asia-Pacific crude: More supply may weigh
summary: The Asia-Pacific crude market is expected to face pressure due to higher supply and weak refinery demand for November-loading cargoes. Indonesia's Pertamina may issue a tender to sell its light sweet Banyu Urip grade, while ExxonMobil ramps up production at its field, targeting peak output of over 200,000 barrels per day. Despite this, lighter grades may find support from robust gasoline margins. Additionally, US senators struggling to attach their bill to overturn the ban on oil exports may face difficulties in passing legislation.

site_title: Boards in Singapore can do more to boost creativity: experts
summary: Singaporean boards can boost corporate innovation by setting an example, experts say. Business creativity expert Fredrik Haren suggests simple actions such as holding meetings in a different way or inviting external parties to contribute. The government has committed S$16.1 billion to support research and innovation between 2011 and 2015. Companies like Singtel and Sembcorp Industries have successfully incorporated new technologies into their strategies through external partnerships and advisory panels. Experts call for boards to take a more active role in driving innovation, rather than just discussing it as part of broader strategies.

site_title: M1 releases iPhone 6S prices, raises mobile subscription rates by S$1
summary: M1 releases iPhone 6S prices, raising mobile subscription rates by S$1 ahead of Apple's new iPhone launch. The most popular i-Lite+ plan now costs S$42 a month, with the basic iPhone 6S 16GB model priced at S$570, a S$45 increase from the iPhone 6 model.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rise 2% on mainland China market surge
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 2.4% to 21,966.66 points on Wednesday, driven by a late surge in mainland China shares, which gained 5% for their best one-day percentage gain in three weeks. All major sectors rose, with Bank Of China increasing 1.7% to HK$3.63. Investors remain cautious ahead of a US Federal Reserve decision on interest rate hikes, which may impact global markets.

site_title: Australia: Shares rally 1.6% ahead of Fed verdict
summary: Australian shares rose 1.6% on Wednesday ahead of the US Federal Reserve's meeting, which could deliver the first rate hike in nearly a decade. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,098.90, rebounding from a three-week low. Despite the gains, the index remains down 5.8% for the year, near mid-2013 levels.

site_title: SIA A-380 bound for Los Angeles returns to Tokyo because of engine trouble
summary: A Singapore Airlines Airbus A-380 flight bound for Los Angeles returned to Tokyo due to engine trouble, approximately 2 hours and 40 minutes after takeoff. The vibrations were detected in one of the four engines. The airline has not disclosed the cause of the issue. The flight is expected to continue its journey to Los Angeles once the problem is resolved.

site_title: OECD trims growth outlook but urges Fed action this week
summary: The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has trimmed its global growth outlook to 3.0% this year and 3.6% next year, citing a slowdown in emerging markets like China and Brazil. However, the US economy is seen as a bright spot, with the OECD raising its growth outlook to 2.4% this year and 2.6% next year. The OECD urges the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates this week to remove uncertainty in the markets, with the pace of future increases being more important than the timing.

site_title: Indonesia to overhaul bank rules to guard against collapses
summary: Indonesia is preparing to overhaul its bank regulations to prevent potential collapses, with regulators identifying systemically important banks and lawmakers considering a bailout law. The move aims to strengthen the country's banking system amid economic challenges, including slower loan growth and a weakening economy. The overhaul is also seen as a positive step in addressing market volatility, which has led to the rupiah's sharp decline against the US dollar. The Indonesia Deposit Insurance Corp. will guarantee bank deposits and take over any lenders in the event of a failure.

site_title: Cisco router break-ins bypass cyber defences
summary: Security researchers discovered a highly sophisticated form of malicious software, dubbed SYNful Knock, that has infiltrated Cisco routers across three continents, potentially allowing suspected cyberspies to harvest data undetected. The attackers exploited stolen network administration credentials or physical access to the routers, replacing basic software controlling them. FireEye found 14 instances of the router implants in India, Mexico, Philippines, and Ukraine, with the attacks possibly being carried out by nation-state actors. The malicious program duplicates normal router functions and could affect routers from other makers.

site_title: S&P downgrades Japan's sovereign credit rating
summary: Standard & Poor's downgraded Japan's sovereign credit rating to A+ from AA-, citing a lack of progress in reviving economic growth and ending deflation. The downgrade reflects the agency's expectation that Japan's economic prospects will remain subdued over the next two to three years. The move is seen as a challenge to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's economic strategy and may lead to increased borrowing costs for Japan.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks close up 4.89% in late surge
summary: Shanghai stocks surged 4.89% on Wednesday, halting a two-day slump, amid speculation of state-led buying. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index rose 147.09 points to 3,152.26, while the Shenzhen Composite Index jumped 6.52% to 1,683.36. The rally came after a two-day slump, as investors returned to the market.

site_title: Seoul: Shares rally, won gains ahead of Fed's policy verdict
summary: Seoul shares rose 2% to a one-month high on Wednesday, with foreigners turning net buyers after a 29-day selling spree. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed at 1,975.45 points, driven by Samsung Heavy Industries' 11.3% gain and Samsung Engineering's 18.6% surge on merger expectations. The won also rose 0.9% against the dollar, bolstered by foreign buying in domestic equities, ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy verdict.

site_title: Redas chief calls for tweaking of property cooling measures
summary: Singapore's Real Estate Developers' Association (Redas) president Augustine Tan has urged the government to tweak property cooling measures to minimize risks to the real estate market and economy. With private home prices falling for seven consecutive quarters, Tan calls for recalibrating the cooling measures to ensure a soft landing for the housing market. The measures, currently in place, risk precipitating a downward spiral of property prices, Tan warned, citing a deterioration in economic sentiments and rising vacancy rates. Redas plans to engage the government in the coming weeks to offer constructive input on the matter.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Oversupply in China's property market partly reason for relaxation of foreign investment rules
summary: China has relaxed its foreign investment regulations in the property market due to the oversupply situation, which has contributed to a stumbling economy. The move, made last month, aims to boost the real estate market. This decision is part of the government's efforts to stimulate economic growth. The relaxation of rules has provided a fillip to the market, indicating a potential shift in the country's economic strategy.

site_title: South-east Asia: Singapore stocks lead regional gains ahead of Fed decision
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.9% ahead of the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision, with shares of Singapore Telecommunications and CapitaLand leading the market. Other South-east Asian markets, including Thailand and Indonesia, also posted gains, while Vietnam fell. Asian shares followed Wall Street's increase, reflecting the possibility of the first interest rate hike in nearly a decade, with some analysts predicting restrained buying and limited upside. The Fed's decision is expected to impact regional markets, with investors cautious of potential surprises.

site_title: Fed rate move could help stabilise the yuan, Bank of Tokyo says
summary: The Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ (China) Ltd. predicts that a potential US interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve could help stabilize the Chinese yuan, removing a key uncertainty and potentially leading to local rate stability. Traders give a 32% probability of a rate increase at the Fed's September meeting, up from 26% the previous day. The yuan's depreciation has prompted the People's Bank of China to intervene, injecting funds into the banking system and supporting the currency. China's strong foreign reserves and low external debt are seen as buffers against external shocks.

site_title: India's growth offers cold comfort to investors as Fed looms
summary: India's economic growth may not be sufficient to attract investors, despite a relatively strong performance compared to other emerging markets. The country's exports have fallen for nine straight months, and local bank lending is near a 21-year low. Risks abound, including a widening current-account deficit and a budget deficit that Prime Minister Narendra Modi aims to reduce. Experts warn that India's growth prospects are uncertain, with a possible interest rate cut by the Fed looming and a series of domestically unpopular decisions that could hinder Modi's plans.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Narendra Modi's plans to raise military pensions and the expected increase in state-employee salaries threaten his goal of reducing Asia's widest budget deficit to a nine-year low by March.

site_title: Update: China plans to quickly spend 200b yuan in unused govt funds: planner
summary: China plans to invest about 200 billion yuan (S$43.96 billion) in unspent fiscal funds as soon as possible, refuting reports of seizing one trillion yuan. The funds were previously set aside by local governments that failed to approve major projects due to an anti-graft crackdown. The move aims to boost the stuttering economy, which has seen growth grind toward a low not seen in a quarter of a century. The funds will be reinvested in several major construction projects, with the goal of quickly re-adjusting their usage.

site_title: Toys 'R' Us to hire fewer seasonal staff as CEO works on comeback
summary: Toys "R" Us plans to hire 40,000 temporary workers for the holiday season, down from 45,000 last year, as it relies on existing staff and pursues a turnaround plan under new CEO Dave Brandon. The move aims to offer more hours to its staff and improve holiday sales, key to the company's comeback efforts. Following three years of declining revenue, Brandon's efforts include cutting costs, as reported in the company's quarterly earnings report, which showed a net loss of $99 million.

site_title: German companies call their retirees back to work
summary: German companies are reviving retired employees to provide expertise and skills to younger generations. Daimler's "Space Cowboy" scheme, launched in 2013, has seen 260 former staff members undertake fixed-term missions. Other companies like Bosch and Otto have also implemented similar programs, with around 1,600 and 50 retired experts, respectively, available for short-term projects. The initiatives aim to address Germany's rapidly ageing population and low birth rate, which are projected to lead to a shortage of 1.8 million skilled workers by 2020.

site_title: Commuters more satisfied with Singapore's public transport: survey
summary: Commuters in Singapore are more satisfied with the public transport system, particularly taxi services and public buses, according to a quarterly survey. Taxi services scored 65.9 points, up 4.3% from last year, while public buses scored 60.9 points, up 4.1%. The survey also showed improved scores for the MRT sub-sector, with an overall 62 points, an increase of 3.7% over 2014. The survey period concluded before a major train network disruption, which may have otherwise negatively impacted commuter satisfaction.

site_title: China will set up power trading platform in move to free prices
summary: China is setting up power trading platforms to allow power-generating companies to sell directly to customers at market rates, part of government reforms to remove controls on electricity pricing. The National Development and Reform Commission will give up its pricing authority once the new rules are in place. The platforms will enable fair and independent trading, and the government will encourage private investment to introduce competition in the retail power market. China has already expanded direct power sales to seven cities and plans to add more as part of a pilot program.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise; chips, TSMC gain
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose on Wednesday, led by the semiconductor and chip sectors, with Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co Ltd (TSMC) gaining 1.98%. The main TAIEX index rose 0.4%, while the electronics subindex added 0.8%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$32.578 per US dollar.

site_title: Shell starts up 2 new Singapore chemical projects on Jurong Island
summary: Shell has successfully started up two new chemical projects on Jurong Island in Singapore, increasing production of high-purity ethylene oxide (HPEO) and ethoxylates by more than doubling. The 140,000 tonnes per annum HPEO purification unit and ethoxylates unit were completed over two years without disruption to existing operations, with over six million man-hours invested in the projects. The new facilities support Singapore's growing niche sector for specialty chemicals, attracting millions of dollars of foreign investments and creating jobs for Singaporeans.

site_title: Cosco, China Shipping say project "may involve asset restructuring"
summary: China Ocean Shipping (Cosco) and China Shipping Group have suspended trading in their listed shares pending a complex matter that "may involve asset restructuring." The two state-owned shipping firms, the world's sixth and seventh largest container shipping companies, are discussing a possible merger. The companies' shares halted trading on August 10, with Cosco's flagship China Cosco and China Shipping's China Shipping Development affected. The announcement marks the first public mention of possible merger talks between the two firms.

site_title: Europe: Shares climb, Glencore and Inditex outperform
summary: European shares rose 0.9% on Wednesday, driven by gains from Glencore and Inditex. Glencore climbed 3.9% after a $2.5 billion share placement, while Inditex advanced 3% after reporting higher sales. The FTSEurofirst 300 index is up 8% from its low last month but remains down 12% from its peak two months ago due to concerns over the Fed's interest rate hike and China worries.

images.alt_text: European shares rose on Wednesday after reaching 2015 lows as a bruising quarter ended, with a Chinese tax cut boosting automakers while miner Glencore rallied after saying it had no solvency issues.

site_title: Emerging markets face Fed meeting forewarned, inadequately armed
summary: The US Federal Reserve is likely to delay its first interest rate hike in years, potentially impacting emerging markets. Despite initial expectations of a September rate hike, the Fed's decision was influenced by below-target US inflation, falling commodity prices, and China's slowing growth. As a result, emerging market currencies have tumbled, equities have fallen, and bond yields have risen. A December rate hike now seems more likely, which could have significant consequences for emerging markets.

site_title: China scraps overseas debt quotas after capital outflows worsen
summary: China has scrapped overseas debt quotas to slow capital outflows sparked by a currency devaluation. The National Development and Reform Commission removed quota approval processes for foreign currency or yuan loans with a term of more than one year, requiring only registration with the regulator. The move aims to counter the flow of money out of the nation, following a record $93.9 billion drop in foreign-exchange reserves in August. The government's actions are expected to result in more capital inflows and encourage overseas borrowings.

site_title: Malays march in support of Malaysian government
summary: Thousands of UMNO supporters marched in Kuala Lumpur to support the embattled Malaysian government and assert the dominance of the Malay majority, amidst racial tensions. The demonstration came after massive street rallies calling for Prime Minister Najib Razak's resignation over a financial scandal. Authorities deployed hundreds of police to maintain order, diverting the march from commercial areas dominated by ethnic Chinese businesses. The event has been criticized as racially provocative, with Najib facing allegations of corruption and electoral chicanery.

site_title: Thai govt stimulus to lift 2015 GDP growth to 3 per cent: finance ministry
summary: Thai finance officials predict the country's economy will grow 3% this year, boosted by a recent stimulus package worth 342 billion baht (S$13.3 billion) aimed at helping small firms and rural areas. The package is expected to lift economic growth by 0.4 percentage points. This forecast follows a 0.9% growth last year, which was impacted by weak exports and domestic demand.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.94% higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.94% higher on Wednesday, following a rally in US stocks after data showed healthy growth in consumer spending. The Straits Times Index rose 26.68 points to 2,868.62, driven by gains from financial institutions and the Singapore Exchange. This comes after the exchange formed three independent committees to advise on listing and disciplinary matters. The local bourse saw 42.5 million shares change hands worth S$62.9 million, with gainers outnumbering losers 111 to 37.

site_title: China state planner says will launch more regional pilot power reforms
summary: China's state planner plans to expand pilot power price reforms to more regions, allowing local authorities to set tariffs and establish trading platforms. The reforms aim to make the country's huge electricity sector more market-responsive. Several provinces have already launched pilot schemes, and the move is seen as a response to rising tensions between state-owned utilities and miners over profit surges due to a collapse in coal prices. The reforms are part of China's efforts to increase market flexibility and reduce government control in the electricity sector.

site_title: US dollar peg is the best system for Hong Kong: HKMA
summary: Hong Kong's central bank chief, Norman Chan, stated that the city's currency peg to the US dollar is the best system, with no plans to change it since 1983. The Hong Kong dollar has remained stable at the strong end of its trading band, with capital flowing in from investors seeking havens from global market volatility. The local currency is pegged at 7.8 to the US dollar, within a trading band of 7.75-7.85.

site_title: Update: Asian markets track US, Europe higher ahead of Fed decision
summary: Asian markets rose ahead of the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision, tracking gains in the US and Europe. Stocks in Tokyo, Hong Kong, Sydney, and Seoul rallied about 1% in the morning, while Shanghai rose 0.50%. The gains followed mixed US data and a boost in riskier currencies. Experts remain cautious, warning that a Fed hike could severely hurt the struggling world economy. Economists mostly expect the central bank to hold off its first rate rise in nine years.

site_title: Lee Kuan Yew can rest in peace knowing GE2015 results: PAP politicians
summary: Singapore's ruling party, the PAP, paid tribute to founding father Lee Kuan Yew on his 92nd birthday, saying he can rest in peace knowing Singaporeans voted in favour of the party in the 2015 general election. Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen and Education Minister Heng Swee Keat shared fond memories of Lee, who advocated for "clean and honest" politics, and expressed their commitment to upholding his legacy. Former PAP politician Chee Hong Tat also paid tribute, crediting Lee's leadership for Singapore's success.

site_title: Fed stress tests world economy weaker than in past rate cycles
summary: The Federal Reserve is set to raise interest rates on Thursday, posing a challenge to the global economy, particularly emerging nations that rely on cheap dollars. Slowing Chinese demand and financial market volatility further exacerbate the situation. Fed Chair Janet Yellen must consider the international implications of her policy decisions to avoid fallout elsewhere. The global economy faces significant headwinds, including a slowing Chinese GDP and UK economic contraction.

site_title: Malaysia: Markets closed on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's markets are closed on Thursday for a public holiday. This summary is not relevant to the article.

site_title: New Australian laws to crack down on global firms avoiding tax
summary: Australia has introduced new laws to crack down on global firms avoiding tax by diverting profits offshore. The bill targets over 1,000 multinationals generating A$1 billion+ in turnover, aiming to ensure they pay their "fair share of tax." Complex methods used by firms include booking revenue in lower-taxing countries to reduce tax on profits in higher-taxing jurisdictions, resulting in billions of dollars lost by governments. The laws are part of an international push to stop firms using corporate structures to avoid tax.

site_title: Twitter tries to spur growth with shopping and political donations
summary: Twitter has partnered with Square to accept online political donations and with Stripe to allow users to buy products directly with tweets, aiming to increase customer engagement and reach new customers. The company's recent struggles with slow monthly user growth, with just over 300 million users, may be addressed through these moves, which could deliver high-margin growth. Twitter does not take a cut of tweeted political donations, and terms for purchases made via its platform are likely to be more lucrative than traditional advertising models. This could provide a new revenue stream for the company.

site_title: Oil subdued as market on edge over Fed decision on interest rates
summary: Oil prices were subdued in Asia due to market uncertainty over the US Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates. The US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rose 24 cents to $44.83, while Brent crude for November fell 4 cents to $47.71. Analysts are divided on whether the Fed will raise interest rates this month or in December, with a rate hike potentially boosting the dollar and affecting demand for oil. The weekly US crude inventories report is also being closely watched for signs of demand.

images.alt_text: The Asia-Pacific crude market could come under pressure amid expectations of higher supply and weak refinery demand for November-loading cargoes.

site_title: Asia: Shares up, US bond yields jump before Fed
summary: Asian shares rose, with Japan's Nikkei jumping 1.1% and the Asia-Pacific MSCI index gaining 0.4%, driven by Wall Street's rally. US bond yields held near 4 1/2-year highs ahead of a possible interest rate hike by the Fed. Despite uncertainty over tariffs, investors remained positive, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Gold languishes near 1-mth lows ahead of Fed meeting
summary: Gold prices remain near a one-month low ahead of the Federal Reserve policy meeting, where investors await a possible interest rate hike. Spot gold was steady at $1,104.60 per ounce. Expectations for a rate hike have eased due to slowing economic growth in China, but traders remain cautious. Higher rates could boost the dollar and dent demand for non-interest-paying bullion. US consumer spending data showed underlying strength in domestic demand, but manufacturing weakness may not impact the Fed's decision. Gold prices are expected to be volatile after the Fed statement on Thursday.

site_title: Strong interest in floating rate funds that are impervious to rate rises
summary: Investors are showing strong interest in floating rate funds that invest in bank loans, which are less sensitive to interest rate rises. Franklin Templeton manages around $18 billion in floating rate debt and has seen a $3 billion fund for European investors raise capital. Despite concerns over rising rates, investors are flocking to assets with yield and low duration, such as leveraged loans. However, there are risks, including credit risk and the potential for borrowers to refinance loans, which could reduce income and capital appreciation.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Indonesia to overhaul bank rules to guard against collapses
summary: Indonesia plans to overhaul its banking regulations to prevent potential bank collapses. Regulators are drafting a list of systemically important banks, which may include the country's top 15 by assets, and parliament may pass a law this year setting out rules for bailouts. The move aims to strengthen the banking system amid economic challenges, including slower loan growth and a weakening rupiah. The government hopes to increase deposit-insurance premiums and capital buffers for affected banks, with a goal of improving the banking industry's capital adequacy ratio and non-performing loan ratio.

site_title: China's move to more market-determined yuan should be welcomed: RBA
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia's Assistant Governor, Guy Debelle, welcomed China's move towards a more market-determined yuan exchange rate. Although the initial effect was a 4.5% depreciation, it's part of a larger 15% appreciation in the past year. Debelle emphasized that these exchange rate moves are not significant in the grand scheme and urged Australia to adjust to the current environment rather than wishing for a different one. This development is part of broader economic shifts, including declining foreign exchange reserves and low global long-term yields.

site_title: Hong Kong, China: HK shares up after US rally but Shanghai slips
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.29% at the open on Wednesday, following a Wall Street rally ahead of a US interest rate decision. The Hang Seng Index climbed 276.11 points to 21,731.34. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index slipped 0.24% to 2,998.04 due to lingering concerns about China's economy.

site_title: Australia: Shares buoyed by global sentiment ahead of Fed decision
summary: Australian shares rose 1.3% on Wednesday, reversing losses from the previous session, ahead of the Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates. The S&P/ASX 200 index jumped 60 points to 5,078.8, with major banks and media companies leading the rally. Despite a nearly 6% decline this year, the index is still near mid-2013 levels. Global sentiment was boosted by US shares rallying overnight, and market analysts expect light trading until the Fed's decision on Friday.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks climb at open ahead of Fed decision
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.17% at open on September 16, 2015, following a jump in US equity markets ahead of the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision. The Nikkei 225 index gained 211.67 points to 18,238.15.

site_title: A masterclass in communication
summary: The 2015 General Election in Singapore showcased the power of effective communication and brand strategy. The People's Action Party (PAP) achieved an almost 10 percentage-point surge in votes, retaining key seats and gaining Punggol East from the Workers' Party (WP). PAP's manifesto, "With you, for you, for Singapore," leveraged the electorate's desire for consultative leadership, confidence in the PAP's track record, and awareness of regional uncertainties. The party's coordinated campaign, using social media and local outreach, helped to establish it as a servant leader and countered the Opposition's attacks.

site_title: BMW eyes new business opportunities with autonomous cars
summary: BMW is preparing to rethink its business models and products as autonomous cars become available, with a focus on offering a range of transport options beyond just selling a car. The company aims to capitalize on the competitive advantage of premium carmakers, which will be rooted in their ability to provide instant access to autonomous transportation. BMW's board member, Peter Schwarzenbauer, notes that the ability to meet customer demand quickly will be crucial, and the company is exploring new mobility concepts and fleet management opportunities.

site_title: Asian futures tip stock rebound as bonds track Treasury selloff
summary: Asian stock futures rose as the US dollar gained ground, while bonds in the region fell in tandem with a selloff in Treasuries. The US retail sales data bolstered the case for higher interest rates, prompting a rebound in equity markets from Japan to Australia. Ten-year Australian and New Zealand bonds sank after a surge in similar Treasury yields, while US oil extended its advance ahead of American stockpiles data. The dollar halted a seven-day decline versus Australia's currency, boosting the Asian stock market's buoyant mood.

site_title: Turn it around, Turnbull
summary: Australia's new Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull faces a challenging economic landscape, marked by a fading mining boom, stagnant growth, and rising housing prices. Despite a surge in real estate, disposable incomes are rising slowly, and nominal GDP growth is declining. Turnbull's predecessor Tony Abbott's austerity drive is partly to blame, and the government's fiscal firepower is needed to aid growth. If not deployed, Australia may find itself in an even worse economic situation than the current mining bust or unsustainable housing boom.

site_title: South Korea takes stab at slaying zombie company menace
summary: South Korea is establishing its first government-backed restructuring firm to tackle the country's "zombie company" problem, which has been plagued by constant bailouts and non-productive sectors. The new firm, backed by eight banks, aims to offer up to 2 trillion won in loans and will initially focus on 118 non-financial firms controlled by the Korea Development Bank. The move comes after a string of corporate losses, including Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering's 3 trillion won operating loss, and is seen as a response to the country's worsening economic outlook and slowing growth in China.

site_title: Technology doesn't make pupils smarter: study
summary: A new OECD report suggests that technology in classrooms has no noticeable impact on academic results, and may even hinder performance. Despite widespread use of computers in schools, the report found that students who use computers frequently do worse in most learning outcomes. The report urges schools to work with teachers to develop more sophisticated software and turn technology into a more powerful tool in the classroom.

site_title: HP says to cut up to 30,000 more jobs in enterprise business
summary: Hewlett-Packard Co plans to cut an additional 25,000 to 30,000 jobs in its enterprise business as part of efforts to save $2.7 billion in costs. The expected job cuts will result in a $2.7 billion charge, with the company separating its faster-growing corporate hardware and services operations into a new company, Hewlett Packard Enterprise. The move is part of a multi-year restructuring plan, which also includes a 55,000-job reduction.

site_title: Asean billionaires feel devaluation pain as interest bills rise
summary: Southeast Asia's richest billionaires, Anthoni Salim and T. Ananda Krishnan, are facing financial strain due to the devaluation of the rupiah and ringgit. Their companies, First Pacific Co and Maxis Bhd, have significant foreign-currency debt, totaling at least $3.8 billion and $2.3 billion, respectively. The duo's shares and bonds are under pressure as interest rates are expected to rise, and the yuan's depreciation is increasing regional currency volatility. Despite efforts to hedge their debt, the tycoons' companies are still exposed to emerging markets, posing a significant risk to their financial stability.

images.alt_text: Malaysian billionaire T. Ananda Krishnan attends the Allen & Co. Media and Technology Conference in Sun Valley, Idaho, US, on Friday, Jul 8, 2011. Two of Southeast Asia's richest businessmen are experiencing the weight of dollar strength after loading their business empires up with cheap US currency debt.

site_title: Singapore property curbs not likely to be eased anytime soon, say analysts
summary: Singapore's ruling party won a landslide victory in the recent election, but analysts say the government is unlikely to ease property curbs anytime soon. To reverse measures introduced in 2009, residential prices must drop by 15%, according to Chestertons and RHB Research Institute Singapore. The slump in China's stock market and rising interest rates may prompt the government to tweak some property measures, but no immediate easing is expected. Analysts expect a data-dependent and gradual approach to loosening curbs, starting with additional stamp duties as prices fall.

site_title: Google does not intend to become a carmaker: executive
summary: Google does not intend to become a carmaker, according to Philipp Justus, managing director for Germany, Austria, and Switzerland. Despite hiring auto industry veteran John Krafcik as chief executive of its self-driving car project, Google is working in partnership with automotive suppliers to develop self-driving cars, but not planning to manufacture them. This move aims to tap into the potential of the self-driving car industry as a business opportunity.

images.alt_text: Google Inc does not intend to become a vehicle manufacturer, the company's managing director for Germany, Austria and Switzerland said on Tuesday at the Frankfurt auto show.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SGX, Hyflux, CapitaLand, Rotary
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has formed three independent committees to advise on listing, disciplinary, and appeal matters. A new disciplinary framework will take effect on October 7, allowing SGX to impose fines and restrict access to the market. Hyflux has been chosen to build a new waste-to-energy plant in Singapore, valued at S$750 million, with completion expected by 2019. CapitaLand has announced its seventh residential project in Vietnam, a 2.6-hectare site in Ho Chi Minh City with 1,000 homes. Rotary Engineering is fighting a lawsuit in the High Court of Singapore.

site_title: Oil prices rise after dip in US crude production
summary: US crude oil prices rose modestly, with West Texas Intermediate increasing 59 cents to $44.59 a barrel, and Brent North Sea crude rising 26 cents to $46.63 a barrel. The rise was attributed to a drop in US oil production, as reported by the US Department of Energy, and anticipation of a gain in crude oil stockpiles. The market is expected to be "very choppy" as traders await the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision, which could boost the dollar and impact demand.

site_title: Anti-immigration backlash shows that the world isn't flat; it's walled
summary: The world is not becoming a borderless, flat global community, but instead, a walled and divided one. The anti-immigration backlash, exemplified by Donald Trump's pledge to build a wall along the US-Mexico border, is a response to the failed globalism project that has led to ethnic and sectarian conflicts in the Middle East and Europe. This backlash is driven by the desire to preserve individual identity and collective belonging, which is at odds with the principles of free markets and free immigration.

site_title: US: Wall St rallies as clock ticks toward Fed decision
summary: US stocks rose 1-2% on Tuesday, led by a 1.4% gain in the Dow Jones industrial average, as data showed healthy growth in consumer spending. The Commerce Department reported a 0.4% increase in core retail sales in August, suggesting the recent stock market selloff had little impact on US household spending. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained, with all 10 major sectors rising, as traders await the Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates this week.

site_title: Thai police chief links Uighurs to Bangkok bomb
summary: Thai police chief has linked the Bangkok bomb blast to China's Uighurs for the first time, stating that people smugglers were motivated by revenge for a crackdown on their trade through Thailand. The lawyer for one of the two detained foreign suspects confirmed that his client is a Uighur Muslim minority from China. This revelation comes after weeks of police reluctance to directly mention Uighurs, despite increasing evidence pointing to their involvement.

site_title: Prime group expands into fuel card business
summary: The Prime group, a Singapore-based vehicle-related company, has expanded into the fuel card business with Shell in Singapore. The partnership, formed in 2012, provides fuel cards to taxi and bus drivers, as well as small and medium enterprises. The company plans to expand its operations into the region, leveraging its existing vehicle-related business.

site_title: Porsche unveils all-electric Mission E concept car
summary: Porsche unveiled its all-electric Mission E concept car at the Frankfurt Auto Show, marking the German brand's entry into the high-end electric vehicle market. The four-door, four-seat luxury sedan boasts a futuristic 911 design, 800-volt battery, and 600 horsepower, allowing it to reach 60mph in under 3.5 seconds. With a range of over 300 miles and rapid charging capabilities, the Mission E is expected to arrive in showrooms within five years, providing a window into the future of all-electric cars.

site_title: M'sia's tourism sector gets more funding
summary: Malaysia's tourism sector received an RM80 million funding boost to promote the country as a holiday destination. The move aims to spruce up existing landmarks and develop new ones, following a slowdown in tourist arrivals and budget cuts. Industry players described the move as timely, given the current economic conditions.

site_title: Amazon's Jeff Bezos ups his stake in billionaires' space race
summary: Amazon founder Jeff Bezos plans to invest over $200 million in a rocket manufacturing plant and launch site in Florida to compete with fellow billionaires in the space industry. Blue Origin, Bezos' space startup, aims to build a rocket that can reach orbital altitudes and test new engines, including the BE-4 engine, in partnership with United Launch Alliance. The company plans to debut its new rocket before the end of the decade, with the goal of flying tourists into suborbital and orbital space. This move comes as the US space industry is seeing significant investment and innovation.

site_title: CapitaLand in 7th housing project in Vietnam
summary: CapitaLand, a Singapore-based property giant, has entered into an 80:20 joint venture with Thien Duc Trading-Construction Company to develop a 2.6-hectare site in Ho Chi Minh City's District 2 into a high-end residential project with 1,000 homes. The project is valued at US$150 million and will increase CapitaLand's Vietnam residential portfolio to over 7,500 homes. This marks the group's seventh residential project in Vietnam and its third collaboration with Thien Duc.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Merkel calls for European unity, summit on refugee crisis
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel called for a special EU refugee summit, urging unity after a proposal to impose financial penalties on states that don't take in asylum seekers was met with opposition from eastern European countries. Merkel took a conciliatory tone, saying threats are not the right way to achieve agreement, and instead proposed a summit to discuss supporting countries of origin, working with Turkey, and setting up "hotspots" for refugee registration. The proposal faces opposition from countries like the Czech Republic and Slovakia, which have resisted EU plans to share out refugees.

site_title: United faces steep climb to fix reputation
summary: United Airlines faces a steep climb to regain its reputation, five years after its merger with Continental Airlines. The airline has struggled with frequent delays, cancelled flights, and poor customer service, with passengers giving it a low rating of three out of 10 on Skytrax. On-time performance is a major issue, with 25% of flights not landing on time in July. The airline needs to improve its relationship with corporate customers, enhance its internal culture, and invest in new technology, including a new computer reservation system. New CEO Oscar Munoz vows to address these issues.

site_title: China and Iran see closer ties after landmark nuclear deal
summary: China and Iran have strengthened economic ties following a landmark nuclear deal in July, with China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi hosting Iran's Mohammad Javad Zarif for talks. The seventh round of talks this year aims to deepen economic cooperation, with China being a major buyer of Iranian oil. The agreement signals a closer relationship between the two nations, marking a significant shift in China's foreign policy.

site_title: All eyes on the Fed this week
summary: The US Federal Reserve is set to increase interest rates for the first time in over 9 years, potentially ending a monetary stimulus policy that boosted stock and bond markets since the 2008 crash. This move is expected to have significant implications for Wall Street and the global economy, marking a shift in monetary policy. The decision is scheduled to be made on Thursday, and its impact will be closely watched by investors and economists.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokerages have resumed coverage on Tigerair with a "buy" rating and target price of S$0.32, citing earnings recovery after four years of losses. Wilmar International has also received a "buy" rating with a target price of S$3.60, driven by improving refining and crushing margins. CapitaLand Mall Trust has been upgraded to "buy" from "hold" with a target price of S$2.10, following a recent share price correction and management's strong track record.

site_title: STI closes at its lowest since June 2012
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 29.53 points or 1% to 2,841.94, its lowest level since June 2012, due to weakness in China and Hong Kong, as well as US interest rate concerns. Olam International's shares rose significantly, boosting turnover to 1.34 billion units. Analysts, including Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley, expect lower crude palm oil prices and growth in the region to be lower for longer, recommending restructuring plays and value investments.

site_title: UK inflation returns to 0 in August
summary: UK inflation returns to 0 in August, driven by lower motor fuel and clothing prices. Consumer prices were unchanged compared to a year earlier, with core price pressures easing to 1%. The Bank of England may delay raising interest rates, as inflation remains below its 2% target. Economists predict a quarter-point rate hike in the first quarter of 2016, but inflation could drop back into negative territory before the end of the year.

site_title: Oil price curve may hint at higher prices
summary: Fund managers are adding to bullish bets on crude oil, sensing higher prices for future months after the International Energy Agency (IEA) predicts non-Opec producers, including the US, will cut output by the steepest rate in over 20 years in 2016. The contango, or discount, between immediate and long-term oil prices has widened to its widest in six months, at US$8.0 a barrel. Despite concerns about the immediate outlook, experts believe the market is preparing for higher prices, with the one-12-month contango averaging US$1.07 a barrel over the last 10 years, but well above long-term averages.

images.alt_text: Peter Rose's problem of uncertainty is typical for the oil and gas services industry at the moment. New orders have dried up and he has no idea how profitable his firm will be next year and beyond.

site_title: Citi loses No 2 spot in Mexico to two Spanish banks after fraud
summary: CitiGroup Inc's Mexican unit, Banamex, has lost its No 2 spot to two Spanish banks after a US$400 million fraud involving the bank. The fraud prompted CEO Michael Corbat to fire employees and temporarily halt lending, allowing Banamex to cut overdue loans. Despite this, Banamex remains Mexico's second-largest lender by assets. The bank's loan portfolio grew less than 5% since 2013, while Spanish banks Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria and Banco Santander boosted their portfolios by over 19%. Citigroup is committed to growing its Mexico business.

site_title: Affordable urban homes set to take off in India
summary: Affordable urban homes are expected to increase in demand in India, with a target of 535,400 units in 7 cities by 2022 under the 'Housing for All by 2022' programme. A builder, Karrm Infrastructure, is promoting budget homes in Mumbai with prices as low as 630,000 rupees (S$13,372) and no hidden costs, offering a helicopter joy ride and a job for a female family member. This is part of the growing trend of affordable housing in India, aiming to address the country's housing shortage.

site_title: Aug slump in new home sales unlikely to affect cooling measures: analysts
summary: Singapore's new home sales slumped 69% in August from July's high, with 495 private residential units sold. Despite this, analysts believe the government may not reconsider property cooling measures due to the slump being largely expected. Buying inertia is expected to set in, with a lack of new launches and lower pricing contributing to the decline. The government may only lift the additional buyers' stamp duty (ABSD) for Singaporeans' second or third home purchase, and consultants expect a stable residential property market due to rising interest rates and low speculative activities.

site_title: S'pore gets lion's share of investments as major powers jostle for influence
summary: Singapore is receiving a significant portion of investments from major powers the US, Japan, China, and India as they compete for influence in the region. According to a quarterly economic report, over half of the total investments in Southeast Asia are in Singapore, with the US investing 70% of its investments there. China's investments in the region have grown at an average of 54% yearly since 2003, catching up to India's investments. The report notes that China's investments are spread across the region, while US and Indian investments are concentrated in Singapore, reflecting their differing economic ties with Southeast Asian countries.

site_title: London company funds people, not plans, to form startups from scratch
summary: Entrepreneur First, a London-based startup accelerator, aims to catch technical talents before they form companies, focusing on individuals rather than plans. The program provides a monthly stipend and investment in exchange for an 8% stake. Since its inception in 2013, EF has raised over $40 million in external funding and has alumni such as Magic Pony Technologies and Adbrain. The program's success has attracted $8.5 million in funding, solidifying its unique approach to startup development.

images.alt_text: Entrepreneur First, a London-based sparring group for startup companies, seeks to get ahead of its US peers by catching technical talents before they even know what to build or to whom to sell it.

site_title: Strong car sales fuel July retail sales growth of 5.2%
summary: Singapore's retail sales rose 5.2% year-on-year in July, driven by a 40.6% surge in motor vehicle sales. Excluding car sales, retail growth slowed to 0.8%. Economists attribute the disparity to the short-term impact of a Certificate of Entitlement (COE) effect, which is expected to wear off in the coming months. The growth was largely offset by declines in other sectors, such as petrol service stations and furniture & household equipment. Total retail sales value in July was estimated at S$3.5 billion.

site_title: Row of three shophouses at Joo Chiat Road up for sale
summary: Three adjoining freehold shophouses in Joo Chiat Road, Singapore, have been put up for sale by public tender with a guide price of S$28 million. The property, located within the Joo Chiat Conservation Area, has a land area of 4,992 sq ft and a gross floor area of 14,820 sq ft, offering 17m of street frontage. The sale follows the recent sale of 201 Joo Chiat Road for S$16.8 million in March this year, indicating increasing interest in shophouse purchases outside the CBD, particularly in the East.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Deutsche mulls 8,000 job cuts amid plans to sell Postbank
summary: Deutsche Bank is considering cutting up to 8,000 jobs, mostly administrative and technology roles, as part of its plan to sell its consumer-banking unit, Postbank. The cuts would shrink the bank's workforce by almost 25% and are part of a strategy to bolster profitability by reducing expenses and cutting back businesses. The plan, which was announced in April, also includes closing up to 200 consumer-banking branches and exiting up to 10 countries. A final decision on the job cuts is expected next month.

site_title: China's forex intervention spurring 'vicious circle'
summary: China's foreign exchange intervention has sparked a "vicious circle" of tighter liquidity, as the central bank cuts interest rates and pumps funding into the banking sector to prop up the yuan. China's foreign exchange reserves are expected to hit critical levels in six months, forcing regulators to stop intervening and let the yuan fall. This comes as China's growth is weakening, with its growth rate estimated at 5% based on the Li Keqiang index, and Singapore's GDP is also slowing. Currency wars are ineffective, and structural reform, the only alternative, is unlikely due to its "painful and unpopular" nature.

images.alt_text: China has used its hefty reserves to hold up the yuan after the currency was effectively devalued in August via a change in the way the yuan is traded.

site_title: Aid management and institutional capacity in Nepal
summary: Nepal is struggling to recover from the 2015 earthquake due to long-standing institutional weaknesses and governance capacity issues. Despite swift government responses and international aid, concerns persist over the misuse of recovery funds and the lack of transparency in aid management. The country's rapid urbanization, coupled with inadequate infrastructure and poor regulatory enforcement, exacerbates the challenges. To build resilience, Nepal needs to strengthen its institutions, improve disaster management policies, and enhance accountability. Strong leadership is necessary to drive meaningful reforms, which may require challenging entrenched interests and a commitment to good governance.

site_title: Foreign workforce growth in first half slowest since 2009
summary: Singapore's foreign workforce grew by 8,000 in the first half of 2015, the slowest pace since 2009, amid the government's efforts to curb inflows. Total employment reached nearly 3.63 million, with the services sector accounting for the majority of foreign employment growth. The unemployment rate remained low and stable, but labor productivity fell by 0.5% year on year. Experts expect a healthy labor market for the rest of the year, with higher demand for skills in sectors like engineering and IT.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Burberry to promote British artistes on Apple's music service
summary: Burberry has launched a channel on Apple Music, promoting British artists such as Lilla Vargen and Alison Moyet. The channel features performances, songs, and films alongside regular playlists, and subscribers can follow Burberry and access exclusive content. This partnership is part of Burberry's efforts to expand its influence and reinforce its image as a purveyor of cool. It follows similar collaborations between fashion and technology companies, including Apple's recent partnership with Hermes. Burberry's Acoustic platform has previously promoted emerging artists, with over 19 million views on YouTube.

site_title: Relief from smog expected over F1 weekend
summary: Singapore is expected to experience relief from smog by the start of the Formula One Singapore Grand Prix weekend, as winds are expected to change direction. The smog, originating from a tropical storm in the South China Sea, has caused unhealthy air quality in the city-state. The National Environment Agency (NEA) has prepared contingency plans in case the haze thickens. However, officials are optimistic that the air quality will improve in time for the F1 event.

site_title: Sells outpace buys in Singapore stocks
summary: Global mutual funds sold more Singapore stocks than they bought in the three months to Sept 9, with net sells totaling S$1.18 billion and net buys at S$851.6 million. United Overseas Bank was the top sell, with DBS Group Holdings and Comfortdelgro Corp being the top buys. This data, from ShareInvestor and Ipreo, highlights the buying and selling activities of mutual funds, providing insight into fund managers' focus areas.

site_title: Petrobras chairman to take leave of absence
summary: Petrobras chairman Murilo Ferreira is taking a leave of absence as chairman, effective Nov 30, to focus on his role as CEO of Vale SA due to the mining company's struggles with falling iron ore prices and China's slowdown. Interim head of the Petrobras board, Luiz Nelson Guedes de Carvalho, was named. Ferreira's departure comes amid criticism of his handling of Vale's challenges, with shares losing nearly 40% in the past 12 months.

site_title: Japan to give ships, 100b yen infrastructure loans to Vietnam
summary: Japan has pledged to provide Vietnam with ships and 100 billion yen (S$1.17 billion) in infrastructure loans to strengthen its forces in the South China Sea, citing concerns over large-scale land reclamation as a threat to peace. The move is seen as a veiled reference to China. During talks with Vietnam's general secretary Nguyen Phu Trong, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe emphasized the importance of maintaining regional stability. The loans and ship provision are aimed at bolstering Vietnam's military capabilities and countering China's growing influence in the region.

site_title: UOL's Pan Pacific pumps US$35m into four hotels
summary: Pan Pacific Hotels Group is investing over US$35 million in upgrading four of its properties in Singapore, Australia, and Myanmar, including the 346-room Parkroyal on Beach Road in Singapore, and the 486-room Pan Pacific Perth. The upgrades include refurbished rooms, new technology, and lobby renovations. The company aims to maintain its competitive edge and provide a premium class of hospitality. The upgrades are part of a four-year effort to transform the Pan Pacific and Parkroyal brands, with a focus on customer touchpoints and property transformations.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Japan exports seafood surplus as demand for sushi drops at home
summary: Japan is exporting a seafood surplus to meet growing global demand, as domestic consumption declines. The country's 1.4 trillion yen seafood industry has seen a 42% decrease in fishermen since 1995, but exports have surged 30% in the first half of 2015, supporting Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's goal of boosting food sales overseas. A weakening yen has made Japanese seafood cheaper for importers, particularly in Asia, where Japan is expanding its delivery network. Foreign shipments have reached 293,806 tonnes, with Norway being a major supplier of high-value species like salmon and tuna.

site_title: Multi-asset investing in a challenging global economic environment
summary: Investors seeking to add value in a challenging global economic environment can benefit from adapting to market behavior. Recent market volatility, particularly in emerging markets, has led to a rise in DM equity market volatility and a widening of Euro area investment-grade and high-yield spreads. Despite low inflation expectations, monetary policy is expected to continue to influence asset class returns. A moderate global economic recovery is forecasted, supporting risky asset fundamentals, but markets remain fragile, with a potential spillover from emerging markets into developed markets.

site_title: Singapore healthcare stocks outdo global index
summary: Singapore's healthcare stocks have outperformed the global healthcare index, with a 10.1% year-to-date total return and 3.1% average dividend yield, surpassing the MSCI World Healthcare Index's 4.9% total return and 1.8% dividend yield. The SGX Healthcare Index, comprising 29 healthcare-focused stocks, has seen significant gains, with top performers including Q & M Dental Group (+72.8%) and Raffles Medical Group (+18%). Analysts maintain a neutral stance on the sector, citing stretched valuations and potential margin pressure.

site_title: Thefts by organised gangs on the rise: US retailers
summary: US retailers are facing a surge in organised gang thefts, with 97% of retailers reporting victimisation in the past year, the highest since 2004. Organised crime rings target high-end merchandise, reselling stolen goods for profit, and are increasingly returning stolen items for store credit. Retailers report losing an average of $453,940 per $1 billion in annual sales. Los Angeles tops the list of cities with the most organised retail crime, with retailers allocating additional resources to loss prevention and increasing staff to combat the issue.

site_title: Tsipras says coalition unnatural as nail-biting election looms
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has defended his seven-month tenure and called a grand coalition with his arch-rivals "unnatural" ahead of the country's snap election. Tsipras, facing a neck-and-neck poll with conservative New Democracy, said he seeks an outright majority and will respect the result, while also seeking a "widest possible consensus" for a government. The outcome may delay measures required by creditors in exchange for emergency loans, including recapitalization of banks.

site_title: KL agrees to avail witnesses in Swiss probes
summary: Malaysia has agreed to provide key witnesses to Swiss investigators in the 1Malaysia Development Berhad case, following a bilateral meeting between Swiss and Malaysian attorney-generals. The Swiss authorities had frozen assets in Swiss bank accounts and opened criminal proceedings against two 1MDB executives and unknown individuals. Malaysia will arrange for witnesses to be heard by Swiss investigators upon receiving a formal request. This cooperation aims to establish the truth in the case, which involves suspected corruption, misconduct, and money laundering.

site_title: Greece not a model for future bank rescues: SRB's Koenig
summary: Greece's upcoming bank rescue, largely financed with public money, should not be seen as a model for future bank rescues, according to Single Resolution Board chair Elke Koenig. Greece's lenders were "taken hostage" by a debt-laden government, and future resolutions will follow new European rules that dictate stakeholders contribute to a rescue before public funds can be called on. Greece's four big banks will need between 10-25 billion euros to shore up their capital reserves, and the European Union will decide on the exact amount needed based on ECB stress tests and asset-quality reviews.

site_title: China turns to global 'real assets'
summary: China is diversifying its foreign wealth by investing in global "real assets," such as infrastructure, real estate, and equities, amid a record decline in its foreign exchange reserves. The country has been selling official dollar and euro holdings to support the renminbi, while foreign equity holdings are becoming a larger share of its net foreign assets. China is investing in European countries, particularly Germany and the UK, and is shifting its portfolio towards equities and direct investments, with the goal of achieving more consistent returns.

images.alt_text: Fund flows out of China in the wake of the stock market volatility are part of a generally healthy rebalancing of China's net foreign assets.

site_title: Apple forecasts record initial sales for new iPhone on China demand
summary: Apple forecasts record initial sales for its new iPhone models, driven by strong demand in China, with pre-orders for iPhone 6s and 6s Plus exceeding last year's opening-weekend record of 10 million handsets. Analysts predict opening-weekend sales of up to 13 million units, with China accounting for approximately 2 million shipments. The new models feature improved cameras, faster processors, and 3D Touch. Apple shares rose 1% following the announcement, despite concerns about the company's growth and an economic slowdown in China.

site_title: Impact of Fed's impending rate hike
summary: A panel of economists discusses the potential impact of the US Fed's impending rate hike on global markets. Experts disagree on the severity of the current market turmoil, with some warning of a global recession or worse. William Thomson suggests that the Fed should raise rates to normalize monetary policy, while Christopher Wood believes they will not be able to achieve this due to deflationary pressures. Eisuke Sakakibara thinks the dollar's strengthening is already incorporated into markets, and Kenneth Courtis argues that China's slowdown is being misread. The economists also discuss China's economic rebalancing and the risks of a financial crisis, with Sakakibara and Courtis expressing confidence in the Chinese leadership's ability to manage the transition.

site_title: Trade finance in need of improvement in Asean
summary: Asian trade finance faces significant unmet needs, particularly among small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), due to heavy dependence on bank-intermediated financing. The Asian Development Bank estimates unmet demand for trade finance in developing Asia to be around $1.1 trillion in 2013. A report by the Milken Institute suggests alternatives like inter-firm credit and global value chains are becoming more popular, but infrastructure and regulatory differences among nations remain a concern. To address this, the report proposes strengthening lenders, adapting through technology, and broadening the pool of capital, including government-backed insurance and non-bank finance instruments.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: AccorHotels to operate in Iran
summary: AccorHotels announced it will operate in Iran, opening an Ibis hotel and a Novotel branch near Teheran's international airport. The move comes after the historic nuclear accord between Iran and the West. The hotels, with nearly 500 rooms, will cater to international and Iranian business travelers, featuring meeting rooms, spas, and fitness suites. The opening is scheduled for October 15, marking the first time an international hotel group will operate in the country.

site_title: New PM to address 'economic mismanagement' of Abbott's tenure
summary: Australia's new Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull has ousted Tony Abbott due to "economic mismanagement" during his tenure. The country has experienced 24 years of growth, but slowed growth and high unemployment rates have raised concerns about stability. Business confidence has been eroded by policy U-turns and lack of strong national leadership. Investment bank Goldman Sachs predicts a one-in-three chance of recession over the coming year, citing low labour productivity and weak economic reform.

site_title: Pitfalls for the unwary on banking's frontier in US
summary: US borrowers are turning to online lenders, offering lower interest rates and easier terms, but some exhibit troubling traits. Over 1 million Americans have taken out loans from these companies, with many struggling to pay off debts. Regulators praise the low costs and straightforward terms, but consumer groups and lawyers warn of issues with loan modifications and payment collection. The lenders operate with less regulation than traditional banks, raising concerns about the industry's risks and potential for reckless lending practices.

site_title: China cracks down on bogus trading accounts
summary: China's securities regulator has cracked down on 3,255 bogus stock accounts linked to illegal trading, forcing some to trade through legitimate channels. The crackdown, which began in July, targets accounts that failed to register real names or used unregulated platforms for margin trading. The move aims to restore order in markets that have plummeted 40% since June, wiping trillions off valuations. The regulator claims the crackdown will have little impact on the market, but shares fell on news of the move.

site_title: When fashion puts on a show
summary: Jeremy Scott's New York Fashion Week show has been described as the "Donald Trump of American fashion" for its unconventional approach, blending entertainment and disruption with high-end fashion. Scott's designs, featuring pastel shades and cartoon caricatures, have shaken up the fashion field and exposed the tendency for designers to play it safe. In contrast, other designers like Tommy Hilfiger and Diane von Furstenberg presented more traditional and unoriginal collections, while Prabal Gurung and Carolina Herrera offered more subtle and sincere designs that incorporated elements of their personal experiences and cultural backgrounds.
