images.alt_text: Jeremy Scott with a model backstage at his show at Skylight at Moynihan Station during New York Fashion Week on Monday. The show was costumey, down to the plastic disc dresses and zap gun prints, but it also had a good humoured energy of its own that has effectively shaken up the fashion field.

site_title: A long history of client-focused solutions
summary: NN Investment Partners, asset manager of NN Group NV, manages $206 billion in assets worldwide for institutions and individual investors. The company has a 170-year history and employs over 1,100 staff in 16 countries. Following a name change from ING Investment Management, NN Investment Partners will continue to partner clients to solve their investment needs without changes to people, services, or products. The company remains a multi-boutique asset manager with a wide product range.

site_title: North Korea threatens nuclear attack, reaffirms reactor restart
summary: North Korea has threatened a nuclear attack against the US, reaffirming its main nuclear facility is fully operational, allowing for improved nuclear weapons. The statement comes ahead of the 70th anniversary of the ruling Workers' Party, as the country seeks economic and political concessions from South Korea and the US. China is pushing to get six-nation disarmament talks back on track, while North Korea's military analysts have documented signs of uranium enrichment at its nuclear complex.

site_title: Hyflux, Mitsubishi to build new waste-to-energy plant in Tuas
summary: A consortium led by Hyflux and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries has won a tender to build a new waste-to-energy plant in Tuas, Singapore, valued at S$750 million. The project, expected to be completed by 2019, will provide 3,600 tonnes of incineration capacity per day and generate 2,880MWh of electricity daily. Hyflux will hold 75% of the shares, while Mitsubishi will have 25%. The plant is part of Singapore's long-term plan to meet future waste management needs and will be its largest and most energy-efficient.

site_title: German investor confidence index slumps in September
summary: German investor confidence index fell 12.9 points in September to 12.1 points, its lowest level in almost a year, due to concerns over slowing growth in emerging markets affecting the country's export sector. This marks the sixth consecutive monthly decline. Despite this, analysts note that the German economy remains strong, driven by low oil prices, a weak euro, and a robust labor market, with growth in Europe and the US potentially compensating for weakness in demand from China.

site_title: SGX sets up independent listing panels to uphold market quality
summary: SGX establishes three independent committees to advise on listing, disciplinary, and appeal matters. The Listings Advisory Committee, led by Gautam Banerjee, will review listing applications, while the Disciplinary Committee, co-chaired by Eddie Tan and Eric Ang, will handle serious breaches. The Appeals Committee, led by Francis Xavier, will provide an avenue for parties to appeal against disciplinary actions. The new framework, set to take effect on October 7, will give SGX the power to impose fines and restrict access to the market for issuers' office-holders and issue managers.

site_title: GE launches digital unit to boost software and analytics business
summary: GE launches a digital division to boost its software and analytics business, focusing on its core industrial businesses. The new GE Digital will be led by chief digital officer Bill Ruh, harnessing the company's digital capabilities to propel it into the top ranks of the software industry. This move aims to shed financial assets and focus on core industrial businesses, marking a shift in GE's strategy.

site_title: Singapore market offers deep value, says Morgan Stanley
summary: Morgan Stanley has upgraded Singapore's equity market to "most preferred market" due to its deep value, citing a trailing price-to-book (P/B) ratio of about 5% below the SARS trough in 2003. The market's P/B multiple is 32% lower than periods of growth uncertainty, making it an attractive investment opportunity. The brokerage also highlights the market's dividend income, which provides downside protection, and its relatively low correlation to external factors.

site_title: Sri Lanka hopes to draft economic pact with India this year
summary: Sri Lanka aims to draft an economic pact with India by the end of this year, aiming to strengthen ties and reduce dependence on Chinese investment. The move follows a general election win for Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe, who sought a mandate for trade and investment with India. Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi expressed support for deeper economic engagement and a balanced trade, with bilateral trade reaching $3.64 billion in 2013. The goal is to have a framework agreement in place by mid-2016, with final agreements to follow.

site_title: US business inventories edge up in July; sales weak
summary: US business inventories rose 0.1% in July, the smallest increase since March, suggesting a potential slowdown in inventory accumulation. This could pressure the struggling manufacturing sector, which has been undermined by a strong dollar, weak global demand, and lower crude oil prices. Retail inventories excluding autos rose 0.2%, while sales increased 0.1% after a 0.3% rise in June. An inventory drawdown could weigh on manufacturing, which would take 1.36 months to clear shelves at current sales pace.

site_title: US CEOs cautious on economy, spending: survey
summary: US CEOs are cautious about the economy's near-term prospects, expecting a 2.4% growth in US GDP this year, down from a 2.5% projection earlier. Nearly a third of CEOs anticipate US employment to fall, while nearly two-thirds expect US sales to increase. The Business Roundtable CEO Economic Outlook Index slipped to 74.1, reflecting reasonable caution regarding modest US growth. CEOs also expect to trim capital spending over the next six months, with 20% anticipating a decrease. This downward trend reflects cautious expectations for near-term US growth.

site_title: A roving, bounding symbol of Taiwan
summary: Taiwan's Cloud Gate Dance Theater, the island's first professional dance company, is set to open its annual Next Wave Festival in New York with the US premiere of its 2013 work, Rice. Founded in 1973 by artistic director and chief choreographer Lin Hwai-Min, the company promotes Taiwan's image abroad and has become a symbol of the island's culture. Lin, 68, is seen as a cultural ambassador for Taiwan due to the country's disputed status with mainland China. The company's performances combine Western classical dance techniques with Eastern "rounded" movements, drawing on martial arts and tai chi.

site_title: Europe: Stocks gain as US data disappoints
summary: European stocks rose on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index gaining 0.87% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 adding 0.56%, as disappointing US data on retail sales and industrial production data raised doubts about a Federal Reserve interest rate hike. The US data was seen as a signal that the Fed may delay raising rates, with investors also concerned about Chinese growth and global economic weaknesses. The euro slid to $1.1267, while Asian markets were mixed, with Tokyo rising 0.34% and Shanghai and Hong Kong falling.

site_title: Minority shareholders caught in Nobel Design saga
summary: Minority shareholders of furniture supplier Nobel Design are caught in the middle of a bitter dispute between the company's largest shareholder, Bert Choong, and the board of directors. Choong, who holds a 25% stake, has been critical of the board and has threatened to exit his stake unless they step down. The company's stock price has fallen 18% since the dispute began, and experts say helping Choong exit at a fair price may be difficult due to the large size of his stake. The dispute has raised questions about corporate governance and whether shareholders have a responsibility to act constructively, rather than aggressively.

site_title: Life on board a professionally run ship
summary: A recent cruise to Alaska on Norwegian Cruise Lines' Norwegian Jewel was described as a "slick, professional operation" with a focus on safety and customer satisfaction. The ship's crew, particularly hotel staff, were praised for their efforts to keep passengers happy, safe, and well. The cruise line's revenue streams included food, entertainment, shore excursions, and gambling, with passengers enjoying unlimited amenities. However, questions about crew pay and welfare raised concerns, and the ship's environmental record was also scrutinized. Overall, the cruise demonstrated high operating standards, with the ship's management prioritizing safety and proper procedures.

site_title: Expectations of Fed lift-off delay behind Sing dollar's rise: analysts
summary: The Singapore dollar has strengthened against the US dollar, rising 2% in the past week, due to market expectations that the US Federal Reserve will delay its first interest-rate hike until after September. Analysts attribute this to a flight to safety amid the greenback's weakness. However, they caution that this appreciation is unlikely to last, as the focus will soon shift to the Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) October policy meeting, which may lead to a potential easing of the Sing dollar.

images.alt_text: The Sing dollar has strengthened from around 1.43 to the US dollar last Wednesday to 1.40 on Tuesday, its strongest since Aug 27.

site_title: Yen gains as BOJ refrains from more stimulus
summary: The Bank of Japan held off on expanding its stimulus programme, with Governor Haruhiko Kuroda maintaining optimism about Japan's economic outlook. The yen rose as a result, despite weak economic data. Kuroda stated that Japan's economy continues to recover moderately and expects exports to rise gradually. He gave no hints about further easing, maintaining his stance on moderate recovery.

site_title: Singapore's special Formula for Grand Prix success
summary: Singapore's Formula 1 Grand Prix has been a success due to its unique combination of a city-centre venue, carnival atmosphere, affordable ticket prices, and high-profile performances. The event, which has been running since 2008, has attracted a large following and has helped to establish Singapore as a major F1 destination. The city-state's success in hosting the event has led to Azerbaijan joining the F1 circuit in 2017 with a similar street circuit designed by Hermann Tilke. This has highlighted the appeal of hosting high-profile events in urban areas.

site_title: Arguments for Germany leaving the euro are all flawed
summary: A recent article argues that Germany's departure from the eurozone would be economically flawed, impractical, and shortsighted. The author contends that proponents of a German exit rely on flawed assumptions, such as that a weaker currency would boost growth, and that competitiveness depends solely on exchange rates. In reality, productivity, education, and the tax system are more important factors. The article concludes that the eurozone, despite its flaws, is good enough to last, and that all member countries must work together to remain competitive and achieve sustainable economic growth.

site_title: China takes aim at automated trading in commodities futures
summary: China is extending its control of onshore commodities markets, aiming to regulate automated trading, amid concerns that speculators have shifted from volatile stock markets to commodities futures. The country's top exchanges have been asked to draft rules on program trading, with proposed measures including stricter controls on automated trading and increased regulatory oversight for traders. The move follows new regulations aimed at curbing "malicious" trading in stock futures, which has led to hedge funds shifting their order flow into commodities.

site_title: China filling warehousing gap with purchase of 220-year-old firm
summary: China's CMST Development Co is acquiring a majority stake in 220-year-old Henry Bath & Son Ltd, a London Metal Exchange warehousing business, for $60 million. This marks China's first major foray into metals warehousing as Western companies retreat. The deal shifts the balance of power in global metals markets from Europe to Asia, with Henry Bath operating 50 LME warehouses globally. The management of the company is expected to remain in place, and the deal is subject to regulatory approvals.

site_title: US factory output declines on sharp drop in auto production
summary: US factory output declined 0.5% in August, driven by a 6.4% drop in auto production, reversing July's gains. The decline was also attributed to a stronger dollar affecting exports. Capacity utilization in the factory sector fell to 77.6% from 78.0%. The drop may moderate economic growth in the third quarter, although domestic auto sales have provided a reassuring sign for the outlook.

images.alt_text: US manufacturing output contracted more than expected in August, dragged down by a sharp fall in auto production that could moderate economic growth in the third quarter.

site_title: US, China exchange new investment treaty offers ahead of Xi visit
summary: The US and China have exchanged revised offers for a proposed investment treaty ahead of Chinese President Xi Jinping's visit to the White House in September. The US Trade Representative's office said revised negative list offers were exchanged at talks in Washington last week, with business groups hoping for news on the bilateral investment treaty (BIT) during Xi's visit. The US continues to review China's revised negative list and assess next steps in negotiations, with both sides needing to agree on a high-standard treaty text and a limited Chinese negative list to conclude the BIT negotiations successfully.

site_title: BOJ awaits outcome of key Fed meeting
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its monetary easing stance amid the US Federal Reserve's upcoming rate-setting Open Markets Committee meeting. Analysts expect the Fed's decision to influence BOJ policy, potentially leading to adjustments if the Fed raises interest rates. Currency and stock markets may need to adapt to a "new reality" if the Fed begins raising rates, with implications for the global economy and other central banks.

site_title: Floating object spotted near where MH370 debris found
summary: An Air France pilot spotted a white object floating in the water near Reunion island, where a wing part of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 was found in July. The object was seen at an altitude of 3,000 meters and was reported 70 kilometers off the island. Local authorities have ordered a ship to investigate, but so far, no debris has been found. This is the latest in a series of sporadic reports of possible plane parts, which have failed to yield conclusive evidence of the missing Boeing 777.

site_title: Productivity slump: A scarcity of economic growth
summary: The US economy experienced a 0.5% increase in productivity in 2014, significantly lower than the 2% average annual gain since the late 1940s. This slowdown is attributed to unclear causes, including undercounted internet benefits, lagging technology and innovation, and weak business investment after the Great Recession. The "dead weight losses" created by special interest groups, as argued by economist Mancur Olson, may also be a contributing factor. As a result, gains in productivity are being siphoned off in government benefits and higher health costs, leaving room for only a rebound in productivity or redistribution of income and wealth.

site_title: Commercial property prices to rise in Japan, US on demand: JLL CEO
summary: Commercial property prices in Japan and the US are expected to continue rising due to strong office demand and attractive returns amid low interest rates. According to JLL CEO Colin Dyer, the commercial property cycle has two more years to go, with prices in major cities extending gains. Low interest rates and government bond yields have prompted investors to seek higher returns, driving up property prices globally. Sales of office, warehouse, and retail space may reach a new high this year, with prices in Tokyo gaining 21% in the second quarter.

site_title: Malaysia to help arrange for Swiss to interview witnesses in 1MDB probe
summary: Switzerland's federal prosecutor, Michael Lauber, met with Malaysian counterpart Tan Sri Dato Sri Mohamed Apandi Ali to discuss cooperation in the 1MDB probe. Malaysia agreed to arrange for Swiss investigators to interview witnesses. The Swiss have already frozen assets and opened criminal proceedings against 1MDB officials. The probe is based on two suspicious transactions flagged by Switzerland's anti-money laundering agency. The Swiss regard Malaysian cooperation as crucial to their ongoing inquiry.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Singapore Airlines' system-wide passenger carriage increased 0.8% year-on-year in August, despite a 2.1% capacity reduction, boosting passenger load factor to 85.6%. Regional wing SilkAir saw a 16.7% year-on-year expansion in passenger carriage. TECHNICS Oil & Gas secured a S$70.5 million contract to build a liftboat. Rotary Engineering is fighting a lawsuit in the High Court of Singapore, claiming damages for alleged contract breaches.

site_title: GE2015 has assured Singapore's future beyond SG50: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said the 2015 General Election has assured the country's future beyond SG50, citing a strong result that gives leadership renewal a chance to succeed. The election reinforced and rejuvenated the governing team, according to Lee. This is a key development in Singapore's preparations for the SG50 celebrations in 2015, marking 50 years of independence.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher after retail data
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday after data showed retail sales continued to rise in August, despite caution ahead of the Federal Reserve meeting. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 55.78 points, or 0.34%, to 16,426.74, while the S&P 500 gained 6.85 points, or 0.35%, to 1,959.88. The gains were capped by uncertainty surrounding the Fed meeting, which could impact market sentiment.

site_title: Fragmented rules prevent ECB from acting early on weak banks
summary: The European Central Bank's supervisory chief, Danielle Nouy, stated that fragmented national rules hinder the bank's ability to act early on struggling banks. The European directive on banking resolution allows for "early intervention measures" but its implementation varies across the eurozone, setting a high bar for intervention. Nouy expressed satisfaction with the current situation, citing a lack of solidarity among EU member states in implementing banking union measures, including a single deposit guarantee. The ECB is set to introduce capital requirements for its supervised banks, but a single guarantee scheme is still in the works.

site_title: India's exports shrink for ninth straight month, fall 20.7% y/y in Aug
summary: India's merchandise exports contracted for the ninth consecutive month in August, falling 20.66% year-over-year due to weak global demand. The trade deficit narrowed to $12.5 billion, while imports dropped 9.95% to $33.74 billion and exports stood at $21.27 billion. This marks the longest stretch of contraction in India's export growth.

site_title: Gauge of US consumer spending rises in August
summary: US consumer spending rose 0.4% in August, beating expectations and indicating solid domestic demand. This growth suggests the Federal Reserve may hike interest rates on Thursday, as the economy shows signs of sustained strength. Core retail sales, excluding autos and gas, increased 0.4% after a 0.6% rise in July, with increases in sales at online retailers, restaurants, and sporting goods stores. The recent stock market sell-off appears to have had little impact on consumer spending, fueling concerns the Fed may raise interest rates to combat labor market tightness and low inflation.

site_title: China state firm to lease private tanks for oil reserves: sources
summary: China's CEFC Energy has entered a preliminary agreement with an undisclosed state energy firm to lease private tanks for oil reserves, totaling 12.6 million barrels, to be built in Yangpu port on Hainan island. The 17.6 million barrel capacity tanks are expected to open at the end of 2015, leased for a maximum of six years.

site_title: Singapore Grand Prix to go on as planned despite haze: Organisers
summary: Singapore's Singapore Grand Prix will proceed as planned despite haze, according to event organizers. The event, set for September 18-20, will display PSI levels and health advisories on its website and screens at the circuit site. Organizers will also broadcast this information on in-circuit radio and at entrances.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Grand Prix this weekend willgo ahead as planned for now, despite the haze, its organisers said on Tuesday. "Based on the current PSI levels, there are no plans to amend the published racing and entertainment programme," Singapore GP said in a statement. It added that it will work with the relevant authorities to get the best possible forecast of the PSI levels over the three-day event, which takes place from Sept 18 to 20.

site_title: New York State factory activity declines for second month: NY Fed
summary: New York State's manufacturing activity declined for the second consecutive month in September, with the Empire State general business conditions index falling to -14.7, its lowest since April 2009. Employment in the sector dropped for the first time in over two-and-a-half years, while new orders and shipments also decreased. Economists had expected a reading of -0.75, with the August and September levels marking the first back-to-back contractions since 2012-2013.

site_title: World Bank economists warn Fed hikes may be bumpy for emerging markets
summary: World Bank economists warn that US interest rate hikes may have a bumpy impact on emerging markets, potentially cutting capital inflows by 45%. A 1 percentage point rise in US and European yields could reduce capital flows by 2.2 percentage points of emerging economies' combined output within a year. The Fed's potential rate hike has sparked concerns among investors, with some predicting a more aggressive tightening cycle. The World Bank advises emerging markets to prepare for a potentially volatile ride.

site_title: CapitaLand announces US$150m residential project in Ho Chi Minh City
summary: CapitaLand has announced a US$150 million residential project in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. The 2.6-hectare site in District 2 will feature about 1,000 homes. This marks the group's seventh residential project in Vietnam, increasing its portfolio to over 7,500 units. CapitaLand aims to solidify its presence in the country's growing real estate market.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Singapore Wrap Tuesday
summary: Singapore's total employment grew 9,700 workers to 3.63 million in Q2 2015, a 2.2% increase from last year. This brings the year-on-year growth in total employment to 2.7% in March 2015. Singapore remains the top ASEAN investment pick for the big four economies.

site_title: Jaguar Land Rover sales will rise in 2015 despite China drop: CEO
summary: Jaguar Land Rover expects to exceed 2014 sales this year, despite a 1% decline in sales so far due to a 29% fall in China. The Chinese market's economic slowdown, stock market slump, and currency devaluation have reduced demand for cars. However, CEO Ralf Speth notes that Britain, Europe, and the US will compensate for the decline, leading to a rise in overall sales this year compared to 2014.

site_title: Greece not a model for future bank rescues: SRB's Koenig
summary: Greece's upcoming bank rescue, largely financed by public money, should not be a model for future bank rescues, according to Elke Koenig, head of the Single Resolution Board. The rescue, part of a bailout package, will follow new European rules that require stakeholders to contribute to a rescue before public funds are called on. The current Greek rescue, which includes 25 billion euros for bank capital gaps, is seen as an exception due to the government's debt-laden situation, in which lenders were taken "hostage".

site_title: Emerging market stock allocations at all-time low: BAML poll
summary: Investors have cut emerging market stock allocations to an all-time low, raising cash balances to 5.5% and increasing bond allocations. A Bank of America Merrill Lynch survey found 75% of respondents identified a recession in China or emerging markets debt crisis as the biggest tail risks, leading to a 34% underweight to emerging market equities. This has resulted in $58 billion pulled from emerging market equity funds in the year to date, with only 25% expecting the US Federal Reserve to raise interest rates this week.

site_title: Rules for 'dark pool' trading need strengthening: report
summary: US regulators need to strengthen rules for "dark pool" trading platforms to protect investors from poor trade execution and conflicts of interest, according to a new report. The Health Markets Association urges the Securities and Exchange Commission to improve disclosures, mitigate conflicts, and update rules for efficient trade execution. The report criticizes settlements for dark pool violations, stating that they failed to consider the true harm inflicted on investors. The SEC has filed cases against six dark pools since 2011, but the report is not optimistic about swift regulatory reforms.

site_title: Bentley to sell fewer cars this year as China cools
summary: Bentley's global sales for 2015 are expected to fall by "a few hundred cars" due to a drop in demand in China, where the economy is cooling and the stock market is experiencing a slump. Despite a 9% rise in global sales, Bentley's first-half sales fell 11.7% to 4,639 vehicles, the largest decline among Volkswagen's brands. The brand's sales chief attributed the decline to China's slowdown, which is affecting several carmakers.

site_title: Even after rout, less than 10% of investors consider EM cheap: survey
summary: Global investors believe emerging market assets remain expensive, with fewer than 10% considering them cheap after a steep decline. A Barclays survey of 716 investors found 45% think the August selloff is part of an ongoing correction, while 30% believe it marks the start of a wider malaise. 40% cited weak growth in China and emerging markets as the biggest risk to global financial markets over the next 12 months. The survey also found that 75% of investors now view deflation as a greater risk than inflation.

site_title: GM has sufficient scale to go it alone, CEO says
summary: General Motors CEO Mary Barra stated that the company has sufficient scale to pursue investments in new technologies without a merger with Fiat Chrysler. Despite Fiat Chrysler CEO Sergio Marchionne's efforts to woo GM, the US carmaker's board rejected a merger proposal earlier this year. Barra emphasized that GM's focus is on delivering a strong return to shareholders through investments in connectivity, forward-looking technologies, and propulsion systems. She also noted that investors have not expressed interest in a potential tie-up with Fiat Chrysler.

site_title: Brent oil contango is widest in three months as surplus piles up
summary: Brent oil futures traded at their widest discount to later-dated contracts in three months, signaling a growing global oil surplus. The contango spread widened to $1.17 a barrel, with immediate supplies exceeding demand. The surplus is attributed to increasing supplies from Opec members, including Iraq, and is expected to persist, with Goldman Sachs predicting crude prices could fall as low as $20 a barrel. US crude inventory data is also expected to show a significant increase, with stockpiles projected to be 100 million barrels above the seasonal norm.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures traded at their deepest discount to later-dated contracts since June, signaling the global oil surplus is growing more severe.

site_title: OECD head says sees further cut to global growth forecasts
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) plans to cut its global growth forecasts, with significant cuts to some regions, according to Secretary-General Angel Gurria. This follows the June cut of 0.6 percentage points to 3.1% from the previous forecast of 3.7% in November. The OECD is set to release new forecasts on Tuesday.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 7.52 points to close at 1,647.15, driven by gains of 432 stocks while 415 lost value. The index saw trading of 2.29 billion lots worth RM2.39 billion.

site_title: SGX forms listing, disciplinary and appeals committees
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has formed three committees to advise on listing, disciplinary, and appeals matters ahead of a new disciplinary framework set to take effect on October 7. The committees include a 15-member Listings Advisory Committee, a 14-member Disciplinary Committee chaired by Citibank and DBS Bank executives, and a 7-member Appeals Committee led by Senior Counsel Francis Xavier. The new framework allows SGX to impose fines and restrict access to the market for issuers' office-holders and issue managers, aiming to improve market quality and processes.

site_title: Yuan volatility drops as stability seen before Xi visits US
summary: China's yuan volatility dropped for a sixth day, falling 14 basis points to 5.32% as speculation grows that the central bank will intervene to maintain currency stability ahead of President Xi Jinping's US visit. The yuan's one-month implied volatility has declined 95 basis points in six days, reaching a three-week low. China's foreign-exchange reserves tumbled by $93.9 billion in August, and yuan positions have fallen to record lows. Analysts expect the yuan to remain stable in the coming weeks, reducing pressure on the currency.

site_title: Rainy Singapore gets break from haze as F1 nears
summary: Rainy Singapore experienced a brief respite from haze caused by regional forest fires, but air pollution indices remained in the "unhealthy" range. Organizers of the upcoming Formula One race are monitoring pollution levels, with contingency measures in place in case of severe deterioration. Despite concerns, many attendees, including graphic designer Sivanandan Karunanandan, plan to attend the event, citing the threat of cancellation. International performances, including Bon Jovi and Maroon 5, will proceed as scheduled, with few pedestrians wearing anti-pollution masks in the central business district.

site_title: China vows to loosen market access "negative list"
summary: China's President Xi Jinping has vowed to loosen market access restrictions, citing the need for the country to fuel national growth. The "negative list" regulating foreign market access will be gradually relaxed, with the goal of improving inefficient state-owned firms. China's economy, the world's second-largest, is expected to experience its slowest expansion in 25 years in 2015. The move aims to attract foreign investment and technology, and establish a commercial environment based on rule of law.

site_title: Hyflux, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries to build new waste-to-energy plant in Tuas
summary: Hyflux and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries have won a tender to build Singapore's sixth waste-to-energy (WTE) plant in Tuas. The plant, to be operational from 2019 to 2044, will have a capacity of 3,600 tonnes per day and produce 2,880MWh of electricity daily, meeting 2-3% of Singapore's electricity needs. At a first-year cost of S$55.19 per tonne, it is the most competitive offer, surpassing the other five bids. The new plant will be Singapore's largest and most energy-efficient, with a 4.8-hectare site and a processing capacity of 750 tonnes per day per hectare.

site_title: UK inflation slips back to zero in August as oil weighs
summary: UK inflation slipped back to zero in August, with consumer prices rising 0.2% on the month but remaining unchanged from a year earlier. A decline in oil prices, particularly petrol, and lower clothing prices contributed to the slowdown. Factory gate prices recorded an annual fall of 1.8%, while core inflation rose 1.0% year-over-year. The Bank of England expects price pressures to remain low, with interest rates unlikely to be raised in the near future, although some policymakers predict a potential rebound in inflation over the next couple of years.

site_title: Cargo losses from China port explosions to be at least US$1.5b: trade body
summary: Explosions at China's Tianjin port in August have led to estimated cargo losses of at least US$1.5 billion, potentially rising to US$6 billion, according to trade body estimates. The incident is having a significant impact on the marine insurance sector, prompting a "substantial wake-up call" for cargo insurers. Reinsurance broker Guy Carpenter estimated total losses could reach US$3.3 billion, while Credit Suisse initially estimated losses between US$1 billion and US$1.5 billion. The incident is expected to have long-term effects on the marine insurance sector.

site_title: Indonesia fin min says rupiah won't move much from 14,000 per dollar for rest of the year
summary: Indonesia's finance minister, Bambang Brodjonegoro, expects the rupiah to remain around 14,000 per dollar for the rest of 2015, following its current value of 14,405 per dollar. The currency has lost 14% of its value this year due to a slowing economy and rising US dollar.

site_title: India's central bank might limit size of lender consortiums
summary: India's central bank is considering a proposal to limit the number of participants in a single lenders' consortium to encourage banks to carry out independent credit checks and chase rogue borrowers. The move aims to tackle US$50 billion of bad debt, which is slowing credit growth and hindering the economic recovery. The proposal, which has come from various quarters, would require banks to have serious independent credit appraisals and credit mindsets. The Reserve Bank of India Deputy Governor R Gandhi said the proposal could have drawbacks but is a step towards reducing stressed assets on banks' balance sheets.

images.alt_text: India's central bank is considering a proposal that would limit the number of participants in a single lenders' consortium, in a bid to encourage banks to carry out better independent credit checks and do more to chase rogue borrowers.

site_title: Startups from scratch as London group funds people, not plans
summary: Entrepreneur First, a London-based startup accelerator, is focusing on recruiting technical talent rather than pre-existing business ideas. The program provides funding and mentorship to individuals with strong engineering skills, with the goal of forming companies that can be defensible and patentable. Since its inception, the program has seen significant success, with alumni raising over $40 million in external funding. The program's unique approach sets it apart from US-based accelerators, which often focus on pre-validated business ideas.

site_title: China: Shanghai shares close down 3.52%
summary: China's benchmark Shanghai Composite Index plummeted 3.52% on Wednesday, falling below the 3,000 level due to a crackdown on illegal trading by Chinese authorities. The Shanghai index dropped 109.63 points to close at 3,005.17, while the Shenzhen Composite Index plummeted 4.97%. Analysts attribute the decline to concerns over weakening growth in China and yuan depreciation, leading to downward pressure on yuan-denominated assets. The market is considered weak, with some predicting a market bottom.

site_title: BOJ stands pat on policy but says slowing emerging markets adding to pain
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its current policy stance, citing moderate economic recovery despite slowing emerging markets and weak exports. BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda expressed optimism on Japan's economic outlook, despite a slowdown in emerging economies affecting exports and output. The BOJ will continue to increase base money at an annual pace of 80 trillion yen, but analysts now expect a feeble economic rebound in the current quarter.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit 3-week low as prime minister change falls flat
summary: Australian shares fell to a three-week low on Tuesday, down 1.5% or 78.1 points to 5,018.4, following the emergence of Malcolm Turnbull as prime minister elect, which failed to inspire investors. Falling commodity prices and heavy trading in futures contracts also contributed to the decline. The S&P/ASX 200 index is down 11% since the start of August, its lowest finish since August 24.

site_title: Australian businesses wants political merry-go-round to stop
summary: Australian businesses are calling for stability after the nation's fifth prime minister in five years, Malcolm Turnbull, took office following Tony Abbott's ouster. The business community is concerned about the lack of strong national leadership, reform, and economic narrative, which has led to slowing economic growth and rising unemployment. The economy has notched 24 years of growth, but growth has slowed below potential, and business confidence is structurally weaker due to the lack of stability.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower on China, US interest-rate concerns
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 29.53 points, or 1%, to 2,841.94, its lowest level since June 2012, due to weakness in China and Hong Kong, as well as US market concerns over interest-rate hikes. The US Federal Reserve's upcoming meeting has unnerved markets. Olam International's shares rose after the company announced a deal with Mitsubishi Corp, boosting turnover to 1.34 billion units worth S$1.5 billion.

site_title: Maserati to arrive late to crowded luxury SUV party
summary: Maserati's long-awaited luxury SUV, the Levante, is expected to debut in early 2016, potentially at the Geneva auto show. The vehicle is crucial for the Italian brand, aiming to reverse falling sales and emulate Porsche's success with its own unique Italian design and Ferrari-engineered engines. Analysts predict the Levante will perform reasonably well, but struggle to meet its sales goal of nearly 75,000 vehicles between 2013-18, with some predicting it may only contribute around 17,200 vehicles at peak.

images.alt_text: As competitors gear up to put on display new luxury sport utility vehicles at the Frankfurt auto show, Maserati keeps its fans waiting a little longer as it makes final tweaks to a model meant to reverse falling sales of the Italian brand.

site_title: Seoul: Won eases on North Korea jitters; stocks see modest gain
summary: The South Korean won eased 0.3% to 1,186.7 to the dollar after North Korea stated it was improving its nuclear weapons. Meanwhile, South Korean shares rose 0.3% to 1,973.56 points, despite foreigners selling a net 5.8 trillion won worth of shares for a 29th consecutive session. The US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision later in the week remains a concern, capping gains in the market.

site_title: Three adjoining shophouses on Joo Chiat Road put up for tender
summary: Three adjoining freehold shophouses on Joo Chiat Road in Singapore have been put up for sale by public tender. The properties, located within the Joo Chiat Conservation Area, have a land area of 4,992 sq ft and a gross floor area of 14,820 sq ft. The site is zoned for commercial use with a 3.0 plot ratio and has a guide price of S$28 million. The tender will close on November 4, 2015.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Eurozone house-price recovery sustainable but subdued: ECB
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) states that eurozone house prices have shown a sustainable but subdued recovery, correcting income and property price mismatches. The ECB notes that past cycles have seen stronger recoveries, but the current growth is on more solid footing following sharp price declines in 2009 and 2012-2013. The bank's economic bulletin warns that the eventual normalization of interest rates poses some risks to the recovery.

site_title: Europe: Shares edge higher, focus on Fed decision
summary: European shares edged higher in early trading on Tuesday, awaiting the US Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates. The pan-European FTSEurofirst 300 index rose 0.3% at 1,398.06 points. Investors are also watching German energy companies E.ON and RWE, which fell 2% after a report revealed they were short of funds for nuclear waste disposal. The Fed's interest rate decision is scheduled for Thursday, with a potential first rate increase since 2006.

site_title: Indonesia's trade surplus narrows in August
summary: Indonesia posted a trade surplus of $433 million in August, narrowing from a forecast of $630 million and July's revised surplus of $1.38 billion. August exports fell 12.28% to $12.70 billion, while imports decreased 17.06% to $12.27 billion. This marks a significant decrease from the previous month.

site_title: Developers' sales plunge 69% in August
summary: Developers in Singapore sold 495 private residential units in August, a 69% decline from July. This includes 961 units, including public-private hybrid ECs, down from 2,106 units in July. The top-selling projects were MCL Land's Sol Acres and Chip Eng Seng's High Park Residences, with median prices ranging from S$787 to S$933 per square foot. The decline in sales marks a significant drop in the market, with suburban areas being the primary focus for buyers.

site_title: BMW halts Frankfurt press briefing after CEO Krueger faints
summary: BMW halted a press conference at the Frankfurt International Motor Show after CEO Harald Krueger, 49, collapsed on stage due to a "moment of dizziness." Krueger was escorted offstage and is being treated by a doctor, with his condition described as stable. This incident occurred shortly after Krueger began his first appearance as BMW's CEO, who took the top post in May. The revamped 7-Series sedan was the focus of the briefing.

site_title: Singapore remains top Asean investment pick for big four economies
summary: Singapore remains the top Asean investment pick for big four economies, including China, India, Japan, and the US, according to the Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales' Economic Insight report. Over 50% of foreign investments from these economies are destined for Singapore, with India allocating the highest proportion at 97%. China's investment pattern differs, with significant allocations to Myanmar, Laos, and Cambodia. The report suggests that competition between China and other major economies will benefit Asean by unlocking Chinese-led capital and creating cross-border networks.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: China: Stocks post biggest two-day loss in three weeks on economy
summary: China's stocks fell 2.6% on the Shanghai Composite Index, marking the steepest two-day loss in three weeks, amid concerns of a deepening economic slowdown. The decline follows a 44% drop in mainland equity funds last month and US$15 million in withdrawals from a major US exchange-traded fund. The yuan position at the central bank and financial institutions fell by the most on record in August, indicating policy makers stepped up intervention to support the currency.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares fall, track sliding mainland shares
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 0.5% to 21,455.23, tracking a decline in mainland Chinese stocks. Investor sentiment was subdued due to concerns over China's economy and the Federal Reserve's policy decision. Tech stocks were the only sector to rise, with ICBC gaining 0.2%. Trading volume was low, with 1.4 billion shares changing hands. The decline follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and comes amid ongoing US-EU trade talks and uncertainty over the Fed's interest rate decision.

site_title: China cracks down on 'illegal' stock trading accounts
summary: China's securities regulator, the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC), has cracked down on thousands of "illegal" stock trading accounts, targeting 3,255 accounts linked to illicit activities such as unregistered names and unauthorized margin trading. The crackdown aims to restore order to markets that have plummeted by 40% since June, wiping trillions off valuations. The regulator has fined companies and detained officials, but analysts say the impact on the market will be limited. The CSRC claims the crackdown will not have an obvious impact on the market, amid ongoing efforts to stabilize the market.

site_title: Hong Kong, China: Stocks extended losses at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks extended losses on Tuesday, following disappointing data from Beijing. The Shanghai Composite Index dropped 2.28%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 2.79%. The Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong declined 0.16%. Investors are concerned about the Chinese economy, contributing to the losses.

site_title: Oil prices up in Asia
summary: Oil prices rose in Asia, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate increasing 24 cents to $44.24 and Brent crude rising one cent to $46.31. However, prices remain suppressed due to weak demand and excess supplies. Analysts expect US crude stockpiles to expand for a third week, hindering price gains. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) also slashed its 2016 demand forecast, citing slower economic growth in Latin America and China. A potential interest rate hike by the US central bank could further dampen demand and push dollar-priced oil higher.

images.alt_text: Oil was up in Asia Tuesday but prices remain hobbled by weak demand and excess supplies.

site_title: Deutsche Bank said to weigh cutting jobs on top of Postbank sale
summary: Deutsche Bank is considering cutting up to 8,000 jobs, in addition to selling its consumer-banking unit Postbank, which would shrink the workforce by almost 25%. The cuts would mainly affect administrative and technology jobs, with some client-facing positions also at risk. The plan is part of the bank's strategy to bolster profitability by reducing expenses and cutting back businesses. A final decision is expected next month, with analysts suggesting that deeper cuts are needed to show the bank is serious about reducing costs.

site_title: Update: Air quality in Singapore remains unhealthy on Tuesday; 24-hour PSI at 1pm: 129-152
summary: Singapore's air quality remains unhealthy on Tuesday, with a 24-hour Pollutant Standards Index (PSI) between 129 and 152. This is the second consecutive day with unhealthy air quality. The three-hour PSI was 114 at 8am, surpassing the 200-mark on Monday night.

site_title: Australia to swear in new prime minister Turnbull
summary: Malcolm Turnbull, a former banker, was sworn in as Australia's Prime Minister on Tuesday, succeeding Tony Abbott in a sudden coup. Turnbull has pledged a consultative government, promising a smarter style of leadership and advocating for advocacy over slogans. He aims to shake up the cabinet and bring in younger blood and more women, while ruling out an early national election. Despite criticism of his climate policy, Turnbull vowed to maintain the current targets, which have been deemed inadequate by the Climate Change Authority.

images.alt_text: Multi-millionaire former banker Malcolm Turnbull is to be sworn in as Prime Minister of Australia on Tuesday, just hours after masterminding a coup against conservative leader Tony Abbott and pledging a new style of leadership.

site_title: Singapore retail sales up 5.2% in July on surge in car sales
summary: Singapore's retail sales rose 5.2% year-on-year in July, driven by a surge in car sales, which increased 40.6%. Excluding car sales, retail sales would have risen 0.8%. Watches & jewellery sales also experienced double-digit growth, while medical goods & toiletries and telecommunications apparatus & computers saw 9.9% and 6.4% increases, respectively. This helped offset declines in other areas, such as petrol service stations and optical goods & books. On a seasonally-adjusted basis, retail sales decreased 2.2% in July.

site_title: Aussie slips from 2-week high after RBA minutes douse rally
summary: The Australian dollar slipped to US$0.7130 after the Reserve Bank of Australia's September policy meeting minutes failed to provide incentives for a rally. The currency had risen to a two-week high earlier in the day following the ousting of unpopular Prime Minister Tony Abbott. The focus now shifts to the Bank of Japan's policy meeting, where investors expect the central bank to maintain its current pace of monetary easing. The yen traded at 120.45 yen, up 0.2% on the day.

site_title: Indonesia sends troops to fight fires as haze cloaks South-east Asia
summary: Indonesia has deployed 1,600 military personnel to fight forest and agricultural fires in Sumatra and Borneo, producing thick haze that has closed schools in Malaysia and worsened air quality in Singapore. The fires, fueled by palm oil and pulp and paper plantations, have intensified in the past two weeks, causing health issues and disrupting air travel. President Joko Widodo has ordered law enforcement agencies to take firm action against those responsible, with over 100 people and 15 companies being investigated.

images.alt_text: Indonesia on Tuesday deployed an extra 1,600 military personnel to fight forest and agricultural fires producing thick haze, as the smog closed schools in Malaysia and worsened air quality in Singapore.

site_title: China clouds European optimism as IAA auto show opens
summary: The International Automobile Exhibition (IAA) in Frankfurt has opened, featuring 210 world premieres and innovations from 1,100 exhibitors from 39 countries. The European automobile industry is recovering, with demand increasing by 8.2% in the first six months of the year, driven by double-digit growth in southern Europe. However, China's economic slowdown is expected to impact the sector, with demand projected at just 3% this year, a significant decline from previous years. Despite this, industry experts expect China's market penetration to remain low, allowing for continued growth in the medium term.

site_title: Australia: Shares slump as futures changeover dims new leader's glow
summary: Australian shares plummeted 1.0% or 52.4 points to 5044.1, despite Malcolm Turnbull's emergence as prime minister, as the S&P/ASX 200 index fell to its lowest point since August. The decline was fueled by falling commodity prices, heavy trading in futures contracts, and investor distraction from the transition. Key sectors, including banks, miners, and energy stocks, led the decline, while free-to-air television broadcaster Seven West Media rose 8% after announcing a share buyback.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.61% lower
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.61% lower, 17.57 points down, at 2,853.9, with 96.7 million shares worth S$79.4 million changing hands. Losers outnumbered gainers 73 to 63. The decline follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Total employment in Singapore grows 9,700 to 3.63m workers in Q2: MOM
summary: Singapore's total employment grew 9,700 to 3.63 million workers in Q2, a 2.2% increase from last year. This year-on-year growth was 2.7% in March. However, local employment declined by 8,900 in the first half of 2015, largely due to young casual workers exiting the workforce. The Ministry of Manpower attributed this decline to the exit of young casual workers and continued growth in older local workers.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Tuesday, rising 11.33 points to 1,650.96. The index saw 73.65 million lots traded, worth RM33.5 million, with 129 gainers outnumbering 53 losers.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close higher as BoJ holds fire on stimulus
summary: Tokyo shares closed higher for the first time in four days after the Bank of Japan (BoJ) refrained from unleashing fresh monetary stimulus. The Nikkei 225 index rose 60.78 points to 18,026.48, while the Topix index edged down 0.17 points to 1,462.24. The decision was seen as a sign of confidence in the economy, which has been growing steadily. The move follows a similar stance by the BoJ in August, and analysts expect the Bank to maintain its policy in the near future.

site_title: Indonesia orders action against land burning as haze chokes
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has called for strong action against those responsible for forest fires in Sumatra and Kalimantan, which have caused severe haze affecting neighboring countries, including Malaysia and Singapore. Air quality has reached "unhealthy levels" in Malaysia and Singapore, leading to school closures and flight disruptions. The fires have been exacerbated by El Nino and a prolonged dry season. Indonesian authorities have named over 100 people as suspects, and the government has vowed to take strict legal action, including revoking land permits.

site_title: US fast-food meat still mostly raised on antibiotics: consumer groups
summary: US fast-food chains continue to serve meat from farm animals raised on antibiotics, despite growing concerns over antibiotic-resistant bacteria. Consumer groups graded major chains such as Subway, Starbucks, and KFC as "F" for their antibiotic policies, citing lack of plans to curb the practice. Only Chipotle and Panera Bread received "A" grades for their strict limits on antibiotic use. The US CDC estimates 2 million people are infected with antibiotic-resistant bacteria annually, with 23,000 deaths.

images.alt_text: Subway, Starbucks, KFC and Domino's Pizza were among the industry leaders graded "F" for their antibiotic policies in the report from consumer and health groups, titled Chain Reaction, released on Tuesday.

site_title: Emerging economies plea for end to US interest rates agony
summary: Emerging economies, including Peru, India, and Indonesia, are urging the US Federal Reserve to raise interest rates as soon as possible to alleviate the uncertainty and turmoil caused by the impending rate hike. The slowdown in Chinese growth and commodities price collapse have battered these economies, with investors dumping equities and the dollar rising. The International Monetary Fund has warned against a "premature" increase in US interest rates, but some central bankers prefer an early move to avoid prolonged uncertainty. A decision by the Fed is expected on Thursday, with mixed economic data and Chinese growth uncertainty potentially delaying the move.

site_title: Malaysia closes schools as Indonesia smoke haze worsens
summary: Malaysia has closed schools in Kuala Lumpur and neighboring states due to worsening haze from Indonesian forest and agricultural fires. The haze has deteriorated air quality, with more than half of the country's 52 monitoring stations registering "unhealthy" air. Indonesia has declared a state of emergency in Sumatra's Riau province, where tens of thousands of people have fallen ill. Authorities have distributed free face masks and advised citizens to limit outdoor activity. This is an annual problem in Indonesia, with joint regional efforts failing to find a lasting solution.

site_title: Australia's ousted leader Abbott slams 'revolving door' of PMs
summary: Australia's ousted Prime Minister Tony Abbott criticized the country's politics, calling it a "revolving door" that can't be good for the nation. Abbott, who lost the top job to Malcolm Turnbull, said poll-driven panic and a febrile media culture have led to character assassination and treachery. He vowed to make the leadership transition "as easy as I can" and promised not to engage in leaks or undermining. Abbott highlighted the achievements of his two-year Liberal-National coalition government, including policy successes such as removing mining and carbon taxes and stopping asylum-seeker boats.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open 0.65% higher
summary: Tokyo shares opened 0.65% higher on Tuesday, rebounding from losses ahead of the Bank of Japan meeting and the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision. The Nikkei 225 index rose 117.02 points to 18,082.72.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks down; China, Fed in focus
summary: Taiwan's main stock index fell 0.3% to 8,280.49 due to weak Chinese markets and uncertainty over the US Federal Reserve's rate meeting. China's Shanghai Composite Index dropped 1.74% amid further market reforms. The US dollar strengthened against the Taiwanese dollar, closing at T$32.560 per US dollar. The Fed's decision on rate hikes this week kept markets in check, while regional markets largely followed suit, with Singapore's STI up 0.4% despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Asia: China woes weigh on Asia but Tokyo up ahead of bank decision
summary: Asian shares retreated as China's economic woes continued to weigh on investors ahead of a US interest rate decision. Despite Tokyo's Nikkei index rising 1.33% due to hopes for fresh measures to shore up Japan's economy, Shanghai fell 1.47% and Hong Kong remained flat. The Australian dollar surged after Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull replaced Tony Abbott, while the yen weakened against the dollar and euro. The Bank of Japan is set to announce its plans for further stimulus, with analysts predicting a widening of the country's stimulus package.

site_title: Thailand's reluctant leader prolongs his grip on power
summary: Thailand's Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha is on track to become the country's longest-ruling strongman since the 1970s, with a prolonged grip on power despite presenting himself as a reluctant leader. His military seized power in 2014 to "rescue" the nation, and the scuttling of a draft constitution has further cemented his rule. This move casts doubt on his professed allergy to high office, raising concerns about his intentions and the future of democracy in Thailand.

site_title: Seoul: Shares rise modestly, won holds steady ahead of Fed meeting
summary: Seoul shares rose modestly, 0.2% at 1,934.81 points, as the won held steady ahead of the US Federal Reserve's rate-setting meeting. Foreigners bought 7.4 billion won of shares by midday, ending a 28-session selling streak. If the won holds steady, it would mark a significant change. Markets are adopting a wait-and-see posture, with analysts expecting a possible first rate hike in nearly a decade.

site_title: China Aug fiscal spending jumps 25.9% as Beijing looks to spark economy
summary: China's fiscal spending surged 25.9% in August, the largest increase since April, as Beijing seeks to re-energize the flagging economy. The increase, combined with a 14.8% rise in fiscal expenditure for the first eight months, aims to combat deflationary pressures and short-term growth. However, the clunky budget process and corruption issues may hinder the effectiveness of the stimulus. China's economic growth is expected to slow to 7% in 2015, with domestic and global demand, a wobbly housing market, and cooling investment contributing to the decline.

site_title: Auto industry veteran hired to rev up Google car
summary: Google has hired auto industry veteran John Krafcik to head its self-driving car project, aiming to expand road tests for autonomous vehicles. Krafcik, formerly of TrueCar and Hyundai Motor America, will join the company as CEO later this month. He believes self-driving cars can save thousands of lives and provide greater mobility for millions. Google has been testing its vehicles for 10,000 miles a week and plans pilot programs with prototypes. The self-driving car project is part of Google X-Lab and may become an independent entity under Alphabet.

site_title: Complex programme rights and high costs slow down Apple TV
summary: Apple's new Apple TV device lacks a bundle of television programs due to complexity and high costs in securing digital rights. Negotiating deals with multiple parties, including networks and local affiliates, is a major hurdle. The digital rights to a single show are often held by multiple parties, making it difficult for Apple to secure content. Analysts estimate that securing TV shows would be extremely costly, potentially rivaling the record deals made by Apple in the music industry.

site_title: China investigates senior labour ministry official for graft
summary: China's Central Commission for Discipline Inspection has launched an investigation into senior labour ministry official Zuo Chunwen, 58, for suspected corruption. Zuo, head of the unemployment insurance division, is accused of "serious breaches in discipline" and has been under scrutiny since President Xi Jinping's anti-graft campaign began in 2012. This is the latest in a series of high-profile officials caught up in the campaign, including former domestic security chief Zhou Yongkang, who was jailed for life in June. No further details have been released about the investigation.

images.alt_text: President Xi Jinping has launched a sweeping campaign against graft since assuming the party leadership in 2012 and presidency in 2013.

site_title: Update: Hot stock: Olam sees heavy trading
summary: Olam International shares fell 3 cents to S$1.955 after issuing 332.7 million shares to Japan's Mitsubishi Corp at S$2.75 apiece. This deal will dilute Temasek Holdings' stake in Olam to 51.4% from 58%, making Mitsubishi its second-largest shareholder with a 20% stake. The agri-business will also be dropped from the Straits Times Index due to new liquidity rules.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan
Shares of Olam International fell 3 cents to S$1.955 as at 9.46am on Tuesday with some 222.1 million shares changing hands.

site_title: Higher UK minimum wage to hit hospitality hardest: report
summary: A planned UK minimum wage increase to 9 pounds by 2020 is expected to significantly impact the hospitality sector, potentially leading to lower hiring, profits, and higher prices. The Resolution Foundation estimates 60,000 fewer jobs and a 1% increase in business costs. The new minimum wage will directly affect around a quarter of British workers, resulting in a 0.6% rise in employers' wage bill and higher social security and pension contributions.

images.alt_text: British businesses in the hospitality, retail and social care sectors are likely to be challenged by a planned rise in the minimum wage and will need to find ways to boost productivity, an economic think tank said on Tuesday.

site_title: Asia: Shares tread water as Fed meeting looms
summary: Asian shares remained stable on Tuesday as investors awaited the US Federal Reserve's policy decision, with the MSCI Asia-Pacific index rising 0.1%. The dollar edged up against the yen, while the euro decreased 0.1%. Investors expect the Fed to hold off on raising interest rates due to slowing global momentum and volatile markets, with a Reuters poll showing a slight majority expecting no rate hike. Commodities, including oil and gold, also saw gains.

site_title: China signals that it may allow weaker automakers to merge as sales slow
summary: China's auto industry regulators have signaled that they may refrain from implementing large-scale stimulus measures, instead encouraging weaker automakers to merge or be acquired as sales slow. The slowdown exposes problematic overcapacity, with vehicle sales predicted to grow at the slowest pace in four years. Regulators are citing "severe structural problems" within the industry and encouraging local carmakers to expand overseas. Some state-owned carmakers, such as Changan Automobile Group and Dongfeng Motor Corp, support this approach, arguing that one-off stimulus measures have not led to good results in the past.

site_title: Apple says sales of new iPhones are off to strong start
summary: Apple reports strong sales of its new iPhones, with advance orders surpassing 10 million units, beating analyst expectations. The sales are attributed to the inclusion of sales from China, where the phones debuted earlier than last year. Apple shares rise 0.7% in afternoon trading, with analysts expressing cautious optimism about the company's ability to sustain momentum. The iPhone 6S and 6S Plus feature modest updates, but analysts see room for growth, particularly in the Chinese market.

site_title: Japan set for historic defence shift, but still not "normal nation"
summary: Japan is set to enact defence legislation this week, allowing it to start planning for a possible conflict with China, but Japan will not send troops to support US-led operations against Islamic State. The changes include loosening the country's pacifist constitution and expanding logistics support for US and other countries' militaries. Despite public protests, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has welcomed the shift, but critics argue it violates the constitution and opens Japan to entanglement in US-led conflicts, leaving the country still short of being a "normal nation" by global security standards.

site_title: Crisis-hit Brazil announces spending cuts, tax hikes
summary: Brazil's government announced a 64.9 billion reais (S$23.9 billion) austerity package to address the country's deepening economic crisis. The package includes spending cuts, tax hikes, and job reductions, including freezing public sector salary raises and eliminating 10 ministries. The measures were announced after a downgrade of Brazil's credit rating and amid a huge corruption scandal and plummeting commodity prices. The package aims to balance the books and prevent an exit of foreign capital, with the government scrambling to address the economic crisis.

site_title: Japan business mood sinks on China worry, weak demand: Reuters Tankan
summary: Japan's manufacturers' confidence slumped to an eight-month low in September, falling to 9 from 17 in August, due to fears of a China-led global economic slowdown. Domestic demand also appears fragile, with service companies reporting weak sentiment and predicting further deterioration. The Reuters Tankan sentiment index is forecast to worsen further to 7 in December, adding pressure on policymakers to offer fresh stimulus to rev up Japan's growth.

site_title: China building third airstrip on disputed South China Sea islets: expert
summary: China appears to be building a third airstrip on Mischief Reef in the South China Sea, according to satellite photographs taken last week. The 3,000-meter-long airstrip, similar to two others on Subi and Fiery Cross reefs, would allow China to threaten all air traffic over the disputed features. US experts warn this would escalate tensions and reduce diplomatic solutions, particularly for the Philippines, which claims Reed Bank near Mischief Reef. China claims "indisputable sovereignty" over the Spratly Islands and has been criticized for its aggressive land reclamation efforts.

site_title: Economists fearing shallow recovery see Draghi enlarging QE
summary: Economists predict Mario Draghi will expand the European Central Bank's (ECB) quantitative easing (QE) program, with 68% of surveyed economists expecting an increase. Most, 87%, predict a commitment to more stimulus by March 2016. The ECB's QE program, which began in 2015, aims to stimulate the euro-area economy, which economists fear may not be sustainable. A slowdown in global trade and China's economic downturn are seen as major concerns, leading to concerns about the fragility of the euro-area recovery.

site_title: EU ministers fail to reach refugee quotas deal: official
summary: EU interior ministers failed to reach a unanimous agreement on binding quotas to relocate 120,000 refugees, with Luxembourg minister Jean Asselborn stating that "not everyone is on board" but a "large majority" is in favor of the redistribution. The ministers will return to the issue in October.

site_title: Australian PM-elect Turnbull says to focus on the economy
summary: Australian Prime Minister-elect Malcolm Turnbull vowed to focus on improving the country's faltering economy, which has struggled since the end of a mining boom. Turnbull, a former tech entrepreneur, ousted Tony Abbott in a secret ballot, becoming the fourth leader in two years. He is expected to overhaul his cabinet, replacing key ministers including Treasurer Joe Hockey and Defence Minister Kevin Andrews. Turnbull's popularity with the public is high, but his support for certain policies has made him unpopular with the conservative Liberal Party's right wing.

site_title: EU parliament to present new proposals to push bill against benchmark-rigging
summary: The European Union's parliament is set to present new proposals to push forward a bill aimed at deterring manipulation of financial benchmarks, with a key point of divergence being the definition of critical benchmarks. The bill, which aims to curb conflicts of interest at banks and other companies, has been stalled in talks with member states since 2013. The EU's lead negotiator, Cora van Nieuwenhuizen, plans to put new initiatives on the table during the next round of negotiations on September 22.

site_title: BlackRock to Pimco find bond sweet spots as Fed decision looms
summary: Major bond investors, including BlackRock, Pacific Investment Management Co, and Fidelity Investments, are betting that the Federal Reserve will keep interest rates low due to dormant inflation levels and uneven economic growth. Despite an imminent rate hike, investors are buying US Treasury bonds, with foreign central banks and mutual funds purchasing a record portion at the $13 billion 30-year bond auction. Experts believe the Fed will prioritize caution to avoid economic slowdowns, with some predicting a slower pace of rate normalization than policymakers anticipate.

site_title: Corbyn opposition fails to halt British strike bill
summary: The British parliament has cleared its first hurdle on a strike bill, with lawmakers voting 317-284 in favour of the proposal. The bill, proposed by the Conservative government, aims to curb strike action by imposing a minimum 50% turnout in strike ballots, requiring unions to give more notice before strikes, and allowing employees to use agency workers to replace striking staff. Labour opposition, led by new leader Jeremy Corbyn, criticized the bill as a "partisan attack" on trade unions, but it will now advance to in-depth debate.

site_title: China sells record net 723.8b yuan of forex in August
summary: China's central bank and commercial banks sold a record net 723.8 billion yuan (S$160 billion) of foreign exchange in August, amid concerns about the economy and US interest rate hikes. This is the largest outflow on record, following the yuan's 3% devaluation in August. The central bank aims to stabilize the onshore rate, while traders expect purchases to fall from September due to market uncertainties. The yuan remains volatile, with the offshore rate still discounting the onshore rate, suggesting expectations of a potential fall.

site_title: Opec cuts 2016 oil forecast as emerging markets fizzle
summary: OPEC has cut its forecast for global oil demand growth in 2016 to 1.29 million barrels per day, citing slower economic momentum in emerging markets, particularly China and Latin America. The cartel trimmed its forecast for world oil demand growth this year to 1.46 million barrels per day due to lower oil prices. Low oil prices are also expected to impact production, with OPEC predicting a marginal increase in US oil production to 13.97 million barrels per day next year.

site_title: Oil extends losses as Opec cuts demand growth forecast
summary: Oil prices continued to decline, with US West Texas Intermediate dropping 63 cents to $44.00 a barrel and Brent North Sea crude falling to $46.37 a barrel. Opec lowered its demand growth forecast for 2016 to 1.29 million barrels per day, citing slowing growth in emerging markets. The cartel's revised forecast is 50,000 barrels less than its previous estimate. The market is also watching the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision, with speculation over a potential rate hike that could further dampen demand and push dollar-priced oil higher.

site_title: Tumbling prices in India boost expectations of more rate cuts
summary: India's wholesale prices tumbled 4.95% in August, driven by falling fuel costs, and are expected to lead to a rate cut by the Reserve Bank of India at its next policy review on September 29. This marks the 10th consecutive month of declining prices, which has bolstered expectations of further interest rate cuts to spur economic growth. Retail inflation is forecast to ease to 3.6% in August, fueling calls for a rate cut.

site_title: Dollar snaps six-day skid against euro ahead of Fed
summary: The US dollar snapped a six-day losing streak against the euro ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy decision later this week. Analysts predict various outcomes, including a potential interest rate hike, which could impact the dollar's value. A rate hike could lead to a sharp spike in the cost of buying US dollars, while a "one and done" policy could result in dollar weakness. Trading is uncertain, with possible scenarios including a decline in the dollar if the Fed doesn't hike or a rally if a rate hike is announced.

site_title: More mergers, IPOs seen as China boosts reform of state-owned firms
summary: China has unveiled guidelines to boost state-owned enterprise (SOE) reforms, aiming to make SOEs more globally competitive and transparent by 2020. The reforms include classifying SOEs into public service-oriented and commercial-oriented entities, introducing mixed ownership, and increasing decision-making powers for SOE boards. This may lead to more mergers and acquisitions (M&As) and initial public offerings (IPOs), particularly in competitive sectors. Analysts expect consolidation in industries such as resources, exploration, and telecommunication, with non-state firms potentially joining the process through various means.

site_title: Big pharma turns to wearables to track participants in clinical trials
summary: Pharmaceutical companies are using wearable technology, such as Fitbits, to track participants in clinical trials, aiming to streamline trials and gather more accurate data. At least 299 trials are currently using wearables, with companies like GlaxoSmithKline and the US Department of Veterans Affairs utilizing the technology to monitor patients with conditions like ALS and back pain. Wearables offer a more accurate alternative to subjective questionnaires, and tech companies are developing more discreet devices, such as adhesive "biostamps", to make the technology more user-friendly.

site_title: US: Stocks drop as market eyes Federal Reserve
summary: US stocks declined on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 62.13 points (0.38%) to 16,370.96, the S&P 500 dropping 8.02 (0.41%) to 1,953.03, and the Nasdaq Composite Index sliding 16.58 (0.34%) to 4,805.76. Traders anticipate a potential interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve, which could be the first in over nine years, sparking market uncertainty.

site_title: DBS's Islamic Bank of Asia 'to progressively wind down'
summary: DBS Group Holdings announced the progressive winding down of its Islamic banking unit, The Islamic Bank of Asia Limited (IB Asia), due to inability to achieve economies of scale. IB Asia, with 33 staff, is financially viable but required its own board and management, hindering cost advantages. DBS will continue to develop and distribute Shariah-compliant products within its main operations, absorbing staff and absorbing most of IB Asia's operations. The bank's 50% stake in IB Asia is owned by prominent investors from the Gulf Cooperation Council countries.

site_title: Sixteen local business leaders named Entrepreneurs of the Year
summary: Sixteen local business leaders have been named Entrepreneurs of the Year in Singapore, with nine in the Established Entrepreneur category and seven in the New Entrepreneur category. The 27th annual award, co-organized by the Association of Small and Medium Enterprises and the Rotary Club of Singapore, recognizes over 250 business owners. Returning participants include Cheah Bee Chew and Regina Lee Rong Xian, who attribute their return to the award's rigorous judging process and its ability to encourage entrepreneurs to re-examine their business models.

site_title: US industrial giant GE launches digital division
summary: US industrial giant General Electric launched a digital division on Monday, aiming to propel the company into the top ranks of the software industry. Led by chief digital officer Bill Ruh, GE Digital will focus on harnessing the company's digital capabilities. As GE sheds financial assets to focus on its core industrial businesses, the new division will build the playbook for the "new digital industrial world." This move is part of GE's strategy to adapt to the changing industry landscape.

images.alt_text: General Electric launched a digital division Monday that it hopes will propel the US industrial conglomerate into the top ranks of the software industry.

site_title: Turnbull topples Abbott to be Australia's new PM
summary: Malcolm Turnbull won a secret Liberal Party vote by 54 to 44, ousting Tony Abbott as Australia's prime minister. This marks the country's fifth prime minister in eight years. Turnbull, a former tech entrepreneur, is set to become Australia's new prime minister, following months of infighting and declining voter support.

site_title: Industrial sector seen as first AEC beneficiary
summary: CBRE predicts the industrial sector will be the first beneficiary of the Asean Economic Community (AEC), driven by reduced costs and investment. Manufacturers are expected to set up in the region as member countries implement initiatives to facilitate trade and improve infrastructure. The AEC aims to integrate 10 member economies by the end of 2015, with positive spillover effects on the office and retail markets. However, obstacles such as a shortage of skilled labor and restrictions on foreign real estate investment may hinder success.

site_title: Aussie bank stocks are crashing but retail investors are bullish
summary: Aussie bank stocks have tumbled 13% in August, the largest decline in over two years, yet individual investors have net bought financial shares to the highest level on record. Despite a post-mining boom economy and new regulations, retail investors are drawn to banks' high dividend yields and cheapest valuations in almost three years. The average dividend yield for Australia's four biggest lenders is 6.2%, the highest since 2012, with forecasted payouts to boost by 3% over the next three years.

images.alt_text: Analysts say retail investors like the dividend story. The big four lenders - Commonwealth Bank, Westpac, NAB and ANZ Group - trade with an average dividend yield of 6.2 per cent, the highest level since 2012.

site_title: VRM completes the cycle from waste to food
summary: VRM BioLogik, a Singapore-based company, has developed a patented technology that converts organic waste into quality soil enhancers, known as HumiSoil and XLR8, which promote soil health and plant growth. The company's microbes break down waste, fight germs, and sequester carbon, producing nutrients and water for plants and animals.
