This move comes as worries about fund outflows rise, although the exact details of the controls are not specified.

site_title: China market-rescue effort hurts brokerages more than it helps
summary: China's market-rescue effort is hurting Hong Kong-listed brokerage firms, with shares of Citic Securities Co, Haitong Securities Co, and China Galaxy Securities Co tumbling twice as fast as benchmark indexes since July. The firms are being forced to pay part of the rescue bill and are also experiencing a plunge in trading volumes due to restricted speculative trading. Policymakers' efforts to shore up the market are instead driving investors away from the brokerage industry, highlighting the unintended consequences of the rescue efforts.

site_title: 'Women still barred from economic activity'
summary: A new World Bank report reveals that women face job restrictions in 100 out of 173 economies worldwide, limiting their access to credit and leaving them unprotected against violence. The report, titled "Women, Business and the Law 2016," found that women are barred from certain jobs, such as factory work and night shifts, and are often required to obtain their husbands' permission to work. The World Bank argues that empowering women is "an economic no-brainer," as it can boost economic growth and benefits extend beyond women to children, communities, and entire economies.

site_title: Another day of market gyrations unnerves investors
summary: Japan's Nikkei 225 index plummeted 2.5% on Thursday, following a 7.7% surge the previous day, amidst ongoing market volatility. Asian currencies, including the yen, lost ground, while the yen held steady at 120 to the dollar. Japan's finance minister Taro Aso warned of further economic risks, while Bank of Japan governor Haruhiko Kuroda expressed optimism about achieving a 2% inflation target. Core machinery orders in Japan fell unexpectedly, fueling speculation about potential monetary policy easing.

site_title: Hijack suspected as M'sian ship goes missing in South China Sea
summary: A Malaysian cargo ship, MV Sah Lian, carrying a mixed cargo of iron products, piping, and food, went missing in the South China Sea last Thursday. Authorities suspect hijacking, with the ship believed to be in Indonesian waters near the Natuna islands. The 14-man crew, consisting of Malaysian, Indonesian, Myanmar, and Indian nationals, has not been in contact since the vessel lost communication while traveling from Kuching to Limbang. Malaysian and Indonesian authorities, along with the International Maritime Bureau, are searching for the ship and investigating the incident.

site_title: The Internet of Way Too Many Things
summary: The Internet of Things (IoT) has been touted as a game-changer for consumers, but a recent exhibition in San Francisco's Target store reveals a more nuanced reality. Many IoT products on display are unnecessary, overpriced, and lack functionality, instead prioritizing marketing and data collection. Experts emphasize the need for improved integration, usability, sustainability, and privacy and security in IoT design. With an estimated 50 billion IoT objects expected by 2020, it's crucial to focus on making "smart" a whole lot smarter, prioritizing the needs of consumers and the environment over corporate interests.

images.alt_text: DISCONNECTED: Technology is integrated not because it is necessary, but because the technology exists to integrate it - and because it will enable companies to sell you stuff you never knew you were missing. .

site_title: Singapore votes, with 2.46 million at the polls
summary: Singaporeans cast their votes for the 89 members of the 13th Parliament, with 2.46 million voters participating at 832 polling centres. After nine days of campaigning and a 24-hour cooling-off period, citizens head to the polls to elect their representatives. This marks the end of the campaign period, and the results will determine the composition of the new Parliament.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Hotel room workspaces in US go casual
summary: US hotels are shifting away from traditional in-room workspaces, catering to younger travelers who prefer flexible and minimalist spaces. New workspaces feature laptop trays, electrical outlets, and adaptable furniture, allowing guests to work from anywhere. This trend reflects the growing trend of remote work and the need for more flexible accommodations. As a result, traditional stationery and traditional desk setups are becoming less common in hotel rooms.

site_title: Nuanced killer with a conscience
summary: Taiwanese auteur Hou Hsiao-Hsien's wuxia film "The Assassin" is notable for its quiet elegance and attention to detail, despite its slow pace. Set during the Tang Dynasty, the film follows a female warrior on a mission to murder a man she was once betrothed to. With a restrained, naturalistic approach to storytelling and stunning visuals, "The Assassin" is a great candidate for the year's most beautiful film, showcasing Hou's mastery of arthouse cinema. The film's intricate and intriguing tale makes it a standout in the wuxia genre.

site_title: Interest-paying e-wallets a challenge for Indian banks
summary: Indian banks face competition from interest-paying digital wallets, with 11 entities licensed by the central bank to operate like PayPal. Startups and telecom operators are promoting digital wallets for ease of transactions, security, and potential interest earnings. Consumers are considering switching from traditional bank accounts to digital wallets, with some even seeking discounts or offers to make the switch.

site_title: SGX wins awards for derivatives exchange, clearing
summary: SGX retains its title as Derivatives Exchange of the Year and Central Counterparty of the Year by Asia Risk magazine for the second consecutive year. The exchange's derivatives business saw a 41.7% operating revenue increase to S$295.7 million in 2015, contributing 38% of total operating revenue. SGX's CEO, Loh Boon Chye, attributed the success to risk management and customer support, while also highlighting the company's commitment to innovation and infrastructure development.

site_title: Australia jobless rate falls to 6.2% in August
summary: Australia's unemployment rate fell to 6.2% in August, with 17,400 new jobs added to the economy, exceeding forecasts of a 5,000 increase. The improved reading contrasts with a slower-than-expected 0.2% GDP growth rate in April-June. Analysts attribute the jobs boost to companies feeling more confident to hire, signaling a potential pick-up in non-mining capital expenditure. The Australian dollar strengthened on the back of the news, reaching 69.70 US cents.

site_title: In ageing Germany, refugees are seen as tomorrow's skilled workers
summary: Germany is seeking to utilize its record influx of refugees to address its skills shortage, which the country expects to worsen by 2030 due to a shrinking working-age population. The government aims to quickly train and employ the 800,000 expected asylum seekers this year. Local businesses, such as a flooring company, have already begun hiring refugees, who are filling over two-thirds of new jobs created in the country over the past five years. The initiative is seen as a way to maintain Germany's economic strength, with Economy Minister Sigmar Gabriel stating that trained refugees can solve the country's biggest economic problem.

site_title: Greek bailout review in October to pave way for debt talks
summary: International creditors expect Greece's first review of reforms under its latest bailout to start in October, paving the way for debt rescheduling talks. Eurozone finance ministers will discuss preparations for the review, which will likely involve negotiations with the new Greek government. Changes to the memorandum of understanding may be necessary due to evolving economic data and forecasts. Debt restructuring discussions will focus on extending loan maturities and additional grace periods to lower debt servicing costs, with no principal write-off expected.

site_title: European stocks retreat after rally
summary: European stocks declined on Thursday, halting a recent rally, amid concerns over China's economy and potential US interest rate hikes. The FTSE 100 index dropped 1.18%, while the CAC 40 and DAX 30 also fell, with the Bank of England cutting its growth forecast for Britain. The euro edged up to $1.1266, while Asian markets retreated, with China's inflation data sparking uncertainty. US stocks were slightly higher, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 adding to their gains.

site_title: Everyone can play a part in fund-raising
summary: Paralympian William Tan, a Stage 4 leukaemia survivor, completed a 50-hour hand-pedaling challenge to raise S$50,000 for needy children. Tan, who consumed only liquids and took short breaks, was accompanied by a fundraiser who reached out to contacts to meet the target. The funds will support The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund, Rotary Club of Bugis Junction's Children in Need Fund, and Care Corner Orphanage Foundation in Thailand. The challenge highlights the value of giving, regardless of the amount raised, and the importance of empathy in fund-raising efforts.

site_title: Greece lifts temporary ban on re-export of medicines
summary: Greece has lifted a temporary ban on the re-export of certain medicines, which was imposed in July due to concerns about possible shortages. The ban, affecting 25 types of drugs, was lifted by the National Medicines Agency after officials found "abuses" by some market players. The agency will continue to monitor the situation and take further action if needed. Pharmaceutical manufacturers have promised to keep supply lines open despite facing large unpaid bills in Greece.

site_title: Volvo to unveil luxury sedan next year to boost sales
summary: Volvo plans to unveil a new luxury sedan, the S90, in January 2016 to boost sales and compete with BMW, Mercedes-Benz, and Audi. The S90 targets buyers of the 5-Series, E-Class, and A6, with a station wagon version, the V90, also planned. Volvo aims to reach annual sales of 800,000 vehicles by 2020, a 60% increase from current levels. The company is investing $11 billion globally to improve profitability, following a $1.8 billion acquisition by Chinese billionaire Li Shufu's Zhejiang Geely Holding Group in 2010.

site_title: Market observes its own cooling-off day
summary: The Singapore stock market experienced a cooling-off day on September 10, 2015, with the Straits Times Index (STI) sliding 1.4% to 2,888.03 due to external factors such as investor jitters over US interest rate hikes and a mixed reading on China's inflation. The STI finished the week with a non-committal 0.85% gain above last Friday's close, despite hopes for a pre-election pick-up in local shares. Trading volume dropped, with losers outnumbering gainers 303 to 129.

site_title: Citi made US$35m ahead of client's M&A deal, former FX trader tells court
summary: A former Citigroup foreign exchange trader claims the bank made millions ahead of a major M&A deal in 2010 by "front running" on insider information, directly violating its code of conduct. The trader, Perry Stimpson, alleges US$35 million in profits were made by buying cash and options that pushed the sterling rate higher. Citigroup denies the allegations, stating they were investigated and found unsubstantiated, with key staff members leaving the bank for personal reasons unrelated to the FX investigation.

site_title: ECB to extend QE beyond Sept 2016 to battle low inflation: Reuters poll
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is set to extend its quantitative easing (QE) program beyond September 2016 in an effort to boost inflation and stimulate economic growth in the eurozone. The program, which has so far failed to achieve its inflationary goals, may be increased in size or duration. The ECB faces challenges, including low inflation, a weak economy, and global economic uncertainty, which may impact the effectiveness of the program. Economists predict the ECB will act within the next six months to address these issues.

site_title: Madame Mao's memories
summary: A play called "Revolutional Model Play 2.0" is being performed at the Singapore International Festival of Arts, exploring the role of Madame Mao in China's Cultural Revolution. The play, directed by Wang Chong and written by Zhao Binghao, features young actors playing complex characters, including Jiang Qing, the actress-wife of Mao Zedong. The production uses a Brechtian style to distance the audience from the story, but the young cast's performances are sometimes uneven, resulting in a tedious experience. The play raises important questions about the impact of the Cultural Revolution on the Chinese people.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Japan must boost consumption to counter China slowdown: panel
summary: Japan's top economic advisory panel recommends boosting domestic demand to counter China's economic slowdown. The panel suggests increasing consumption to 70% of gross domestic product from about 60% now. This move aims to cushion the impact of China's weaker economic movements and uncertainty. The panel's proposals will be presented to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe on Friday.

site_title: Fifa compliance head's report pressures soccer body to change
summary: Fifa's head of compliance, Domenico Scala, has published a report calling for changes to the soccer governing body to restore its credibility. Scala's proposals include splitting the executive committee's functions, term limits for senior officials, and curtailing the executive board's power. The report, shared with the organization's board, puts pressure on a separate reform committee to come up with substantive changes. Scala's goal is to increase transparency and build credibility, as the organization faces unprecedented crisis following the arrests of seven Fifa officials.

site_title: US House panel passes bill to repeal oil export ban
summary: The US House of Representatives subcommittee has passed a bill to repeal the 40-year-old ban on oil exports, providing momentum for its potential passage in the full House. The bill, sponsored by Representative Joe Barton, aims to provide jobs and help allies diversify their oil supplies. Despite having 123 co-sponsors, the measure faces an uphill battle in the Senate, where it needs support from at least six Democrats to reach the 60 needed to pass.

site_title: GE2015: ELD reminds candidates who posted on social media of Cooling Off Day rules
summary: The Elections Department (ELD) in Singapore reminded candidates who posted election advertisements on social media on Cooling Off Day of the ban in place on electioneering. Several candidates and parties were found to have made such posts on Twitter and Facebook during the early hours of Cooling Off Day.

site_title: US wholesale inventories fall for first time since 2013
summary: US wholesale inventories fell 0.1% in July, the first decline since 2013, as a drop in oil prices reduced petroleum stock values. This marks a tentative sign that businesses are reducing their stockpiles, which could impact production and economic growth. Wholesale inventories rose 0.7% in June, and sales at wholesalers fell 0.3% in July, leaving shelves at a 1.30-month pace. A high inventory-to-sales ratio suggests an unwanted inventory build-up, which could weigh on manufacturing and economic growth.

site_title: Singdollar stabilises, interest rates ease
summary: The Singapore dollar (SGD) has stabilised, recovering from its year-low, and short-term interest rates have eased. The 3-month swap offer rate (SOR) eased to 1.46209% on Wednesday, after rallying to S$1.4155. China's economic transformation is seen as a source of strength for global growth, despite Premier Li Keqiang's warning of difficulties ahead. The SGD has fallen 7% against the US dollar year-to-date, making it the fifth-worst among Asian units.

images.alt_text: The Singapore dollar (SGD) has stabilised somewhat, recovering from the year's low on Tuesday and, with that, short-term interest rates have also eased.

site_title: Extraordinary music
summary: Singer Matthias Goerne's dark and haunting interpretation of Schubert's Winterreise at the Singapore International Festival of Arts is a masterful performance. Accompanied by pianist Markus Hinterhauser, Goerne brings out the shifts in tones and tempo through his baritone voice and intense body gestures. The production incorporates artist William Kentridge's hand-drawn animations, reflecting South African social and economic inequities, which sometimes strain to connect with the music, but yield profound effects when a connection is made. The performance breathes new life into Schubert's 1827 song cycle, conveying a deep existential longing.

images.alt_text: MASTER OF THE LIEDER: Matthias Goerne's delivery of Winterreise is dark and haunting, with some well-judged moments of lightness.
Helmi Yusof

site_title: US outlines new policy for investigating corporate executives
summary: The US Department of Justice has outlined a new policy to focus on investigating corporate executives, rather than corporations alone, in cases of wrongdoing. Deputy Attorney General Sally Quillian Yates announced the change, which includes requiring companies to disclose all relevant facts about individuals involved in suspected wrongdoing. The policy shift aims to address criticism that the government has not investigated individual executives vigorously enough in the lead-up to the 2008-09 financial meltdown and housing crisis. The new approach will prioritize individual accountability over corporate leniency.

site_title: US crude stocks rise more than expected as refinery runs fall: EIA
summary: US crude stocks rose by 2.6 million barrels in the last week, exceeding analysts' expectations. Refinery crude runs fell by 279,000 barrels per day, while crude imports declined by 396,000 barrels per day. Gasoline stocks increased by 384,000 barrels, and distillate stockpiles rose by 1 million barrels. The refinery utilization rate fell by 1.9 percentage points. These changes suggest a shift in the US oil market, with a decrease in refinery production and an increase in gasoline and distillate inventories.

site_title: China deflation fears grow on biggest producer price dip in 6 years
summary: China's producer price index (PPI) fell 5.9% in August, its 42nd consecutive month of decline, signaling deflation risks in the economy. This is the biggest drop since the global financial crisis in 2009. Despite a 2% rise in the consumer price index (CPI) due to soaring food prices, economists warn of ongoing deflation and weak aggregate demand, leading to expectations of further stimulus measures. China's economic growth is under pressure, with many economists predicting a weaker-than-expected 7% growth target for this year.

site_title: 3-hour PSI reading hits 138 at 4pm, highest so far this year
summary: A 3-hour PSI reading of 138 was recorded in Singapore on September 10, 2015, the highest so far this year, according to the National Environment Agency. The haze worsened throughout the day, breaching the 100 mark at 2am. This is the first time the PSI has exceeded 100 in 2015.

site_title: US import prices post biggest drop in seven months
summary: US import prices dropped 1.8% in August, the largest decline in seven months, due to a strong dollar and soft global demand. This marks the 12th consecutive month of decline, with prices falling 11.4% over the past 12 months. Economists had forecast a 1.6% drop. The decline in import prices poses a challenge for the Federal Reserve as it considers raising interest rates for the first time in nearly a decade.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines signs lease agreement with Air Lease Corp for four Airbus planes
summary: Malaysia Airlines has signed a lease agreement with Air Lease Corp for four Airbus A350-900s and two A330-900neo aircrafts. The A350-900s are expected to be delivered between 2017 and 2018, with an option to lease two more A350-900s and two A330-900neo aircrafts. This long-term agreement aims to improve passenger comfort and efficiency, following the airline's recent air tragedies and financial restructuring.

site_title: Bank of England keeps rates steady, sees greater overseas risks
summary: The Bank of England kept interest rates steady at a record-low 0.5% as policymakers deemed it too soon to raise rates due to overseas turmoil. Despite sharp falls in global stock markets and signs of weakness in Britain's economy, the central bank expects healthy growth and maintained its inflation target. The decision comes as economists forecast interest rate hikes in early 2016, with some policymakers seeing a risk of inflation rising more quickly than forecast.

site_title: Global shale output decline will stabilise oil market: Russia
summary: Russia's energy minister, Alexander Novak, expects a stabilization of the oil market due to a decline in global shale oil production. US shale output is expected to expand by 650,000 barrels per day in 2015 and then shrink by 400,000 barrels in 2016, following a three-year growth of over 1 million barrels per day annually. Novak believes this decline will help stabilize oil prices, which have more than halved since June 2014, and expects prices to be between $50 and $60 per barrel on average this year.

site_title: Consumer comfort stalls as Americans see mixed economic picture
summary: US consumer attitudes remained steady at 41.4, with the buying climate gauge dropping to a five-week low and personal finances reaching a seven-month high. The mixed economic picture, despite job market momentum, has not deterred consumers, who are awaiting wage growth. Stable consumer attitudes are expected to support consumer spending, the largest contributor to the US economy.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index closed 1.4% lower on Thursday, with investors anxious over potential US interest rate hikes. Meanwhile, CapitaLand and Keppel Corp maintained their positions on the Dow Jones Sustainability Indices Asia Pacific Index. The Malaysian ringgit fell below 3.07 to the Singdollar amid concerns of capital outflow from emerging markets.

site_title: Opec, non-Opec countries study Venezuela's oil summit proposal: Qatar
summary: OPEC and non-OPEC countries are studying a Venezuelan proposal for an emergency heads-of-state summit to address low oil prices, which have fallen below $48 a barrel. Venezuela's President Nicolas Maduro suggested the meeting, which could include Russia, to address the market. A lukewarm response was received from one OPEC source, who expressed concerns that a meeting without a concrete outcome would not be beneficial. The proposal comes after OPEC's 2014 policy change to defend market share, and non-Gulf members have been pushing for OPEC to take action.

site_title: China seen delaying Shenzhen stock link until 2016 amid turmoil
summary: China is likely to delay the start of a Shenzhen stock-exchange link until 2016 due to market turmoil, according to analysts in a Bloomberg survey. The link was initially set to begin in 2015 but authorities are focusing on stabilizing mainland share prices, which have lost over 40% since June. China's weak economic outlook and efforts to combat a $5 trillion selloff are also contributing to the delay, with some predicting it may start after the second quarter of 2016.

site_title: CapitaLand, Keppel to stay on Dow Jones' sustainability indices
summary: CapitaLand and Keppel Corp will remain on the Dow Jones Sustainability Indices (DJSI) Asia Pacific Index, marking the seventh straight year for CapitaLand and the third straight year for Keppel. The companies are among the top fifth of 600 largest Asia-Pacific companies deemed leaders in sustainability. This inclusion represents a seventh consecutive year for CapitaLand and a third consecutive year for Keppel on the index.

site_title: Mercedes beats Audi to take second place in luxury-car sales
summary: Mercedes-Benz surpassed Audi in luxury-car sales for the first time in 5 years, delivering 1.19 million vehicles in the 8-month period through August. This surpasses Audi's 1.18 million and marks Mercedes' second-place position globally. Mercedes' sales growth in China, driven by its C-Class and GLA models, contributed to the outcome. Analysts predict Mercedes will continue to lead Audi in sales, with a possible overtaking this year.

site_title: China's yuan jumps offshore in suspected intervention
summary: China's yuan surged 1% in offshore markets on suspected intervention by state banks, marking its largest daily gain on record. The intervention aimed to dampen expectations of further yuan depreciation, following its devaluation in August. The move narrowed the gap between onshore and offshore rates, and dollar currency forwards dropped. Analysts say the central bank's efforts to control the currency are costly, with a record drop in foreign exchange reserves in August of nearly $100 billion. The intervention was seen as a bold gesture to shake out speculators and maintain market stability.

site_title: China auto sales down 2.98% in August: industry group
summary: China's auto sales declined 2.98% in August, with 1.66 million vehicles sold, marking the fifth straight month of decline. Production also fell 8.44% to 1.57 million units. Despite month-on-month sales rising 10.74%, concerns over China's slowing economy and recent events such as the Tianjin explosion and car plate restrictions are affecting demand. The country's overall auto sales reached 23.49 million vehicles last year, falling short of the industry's growth target.

images.alt_text: Car sales in China fell 2.98 per cent in August from a year ago, an industry group said Thursday, as concerns rise over slowing growth in the Chinese economy.

site_title: Middle East crude: Dubai, Oman stay in wide discounts
summary: Middle East crude benchmarks Dubai and DME Oman remained in deep discounts of about US$2 a barrel to Dubai swaps on Thursday, with Dubai staying in the discount as BP repeated its offer for 300,000 barrels of Das crude. Saudi Arabia has increased production and maintained its market share in 2015, but long-term trends may reduce its global crude oil market share. Iran reduced its quarterly price for its flagship crude to the lowest in three years to lure Asian buyers.

site_title: Asian currencies slide as Fed, China concerns deter risk taking
summary: Asian currencies, including Indonesia's rupiah and South Korea's won, fell as concerns over China's economic slowdown and the prospect of higher US interest rates deterred risk taking. The US jobs data boosted the case for the Federal Reserve to raise borrowing costs, while Standard & Poor's cut Brazil's sovereign rating to junk. China's producer prices tumbled, and the yuan closed little changed after Premier Li Keqiang's comments on avoiding a currency war. The Fed's Sept 16-17 meeting adds to the uncertainty, with odds of rate hikes at 28% and 58.7% in December.

site_title: Sing dollar stabilises, interest rates ease as markets remain volatile
summary: The Singapore dollar (SGD) has stabilised, recovering from its year-low, and short-term interest rates have eased. The SGD rallied to S$1.4155 against the US dollar (USD), while the three-month swap offer rate (SOR) eased to 1.46209 per cent. Volatility in Asian currencies persists due to China worries and US Federal Reserve interest-rate normalisation. Chinese Premier Li Keqiang reassured international investors that China's economic transformation is a natural process and will not pose a risk to the world economy.

site_title: US jobless claims fall, point to firming labour market
summary: US jobless claims fell to 275,000 for the week ended Sept 5, marking the 27th straight week below the 300,000 threshold, indicating a moderation in job growth. This suggests the labour market may have rebounded from an August slowdown. Economists had forecast claims to fall to 275,000 last week, and the prior week's claims were revised down by 1,000. The decline in claims points to a firming labour market.

site_title: SGX wins awards for derivatives exchange, clearinghouse
summary: SGX retained its title as Derivatives Exchange of the Year and Central Counterparty of the Year by Asia Risk magazine for the second consecutive year. The market operator cited its diverse offerings as a key factor in the award. CEO Loh Boon Chye attributed the win to the growing importance of risk management in capital markets, with SGX committed to innovating and strengthening its infrastructure.

site_title: Chinese hedge funds set sights on commodities as stock volumes dry up
summary: Chinese hedge funds are shifting their focus to commodities as Beijing's restrictions on stock trading have led to a decline in equity market activity. The measures, which raised margin requirements and capped trading volumes, have diminished the appeal of stock futures. As a result, funds are moving to commodities, including petrochemical products, iron ore, and metals, with iron ore volumes surging to record highs. The change in sentiment is driven by weak commodity prices and a slowing economy, prompting funds to seek trading opportunities in commodities, particularly iron ore.

site_title: Apple accused over US$71 million in Chinese taxes
summary: Apple's Chinese subsidiary has paid US$100.5 million in back taxes, including late fees, after failing to pay 452 million yuan in taxes due at the end of 2013. The audit found the company under-reported revenue by 8.79 billion yuan and overstated profit by 5.35 billion yuan. Apple had previously paid the taxes, along with 65 million yuan in late fees, and the company's products remain popular in China, with iPhone sales surging 85% in the region.

site_title: Online lending tech firm Orchard Platform raises US$30m
summary: Orchard Platform, a US-based online lending tech firm, has raised US$30 million in funding led by Thrive Capital and including former Goldman Sachs president Jon Winkelried. The company's total investment now stands at US$44.7 million. Orchard's CEO, Matt Burton, notes that marketplace lending has been validated as the future of credit extension, with investors embracing the space. This round of funding follows similar investments in LendingClub Corp and On Deck Capital, and comes as the number of online lenders to consumers and small businesses expands rapidly.

site_title: Shanghai gold exchange to allow physical gold as collateral
summary: The Shanghai Gold Exchange announced that it will allow physical gold to be used as collateral on futures contracts starting September 29, with a maximum usage of 80% of margin value. This move aims to increase market participation and liquidity.

site_title: Google won't have easy ride back into China
summary: Google's efforts to re-enter China's app market through Google Play may face significant challenges. Despite CEO Sundar Pichai's desire to bring Google Play back into China, the company has lost ground in major services such as search and video streaming to local players like Baidu, Tencent, and Alibaba. China's mobile gaming market is expected to surpass $6 billion this year, with Google Play reaching only 21 million of an estimated 800 million Chinese mobile users. Regulatory hurdles and the dominance of local app stores and handset manufacturers also pose obstacles to Google's plans.

site_title: German econ minister: 1.8% growth this year and next realistic
summary: German economy minister Sigmar Gabriel predicts 1.8% growth for this year and next, citing higher tax receipts from economic expansion. The influx of refugees poses a significant challenge, described as the "biggest national, European challenge since reunification" in 1990.

site_title: Europe: Shares retreat on China concerns, E.ON down sharply
summary: European shares retreated 1.1% on Thursday, following sharp losses on Wall Street and in Asia, amid concerns over China's deflation risk. China's producer price index fell 5.9% in August, its 42nd consecutive month of decline. The FTSEurofirst 300 index closed at 1,419.63 points.

site_title: Australia's jobless rate falls to 6.2%
summary: Australia's unemployment rate fell to 6.2% in August, with 17,400 new jobs created, exceeding forecasts. The Australian dollar strengthened to 69.70 US cents after the news. Economists say the jobs growth signals a pick-up in non-mining capital expenditure, contrasting with a slower-than-expected GDP growth rate of 0.2% in April-June. The improved reading suggests companies are feeling more confident, but the economy remains vulnerable to tumbling commodity prices and concern over China's slowing growth.

site_title: Philippine credit rating at risk if levies cut, tax chief says
summary: The Philippines risks credit rating downgrades if the government grants more levy cuts, according to Tax Commissioner Kim Henares. The country's tax revenue has been declining, and Henares has proposed measures to improve collection, such as removing deposit secrecy laws. The government's single-term President Benigno Aquino aims to double internal revenue collection, but Henares warns that cutting levies without compensating measures could undo his fiscal gains.

site_title: Tokyo exchange approves Japan Post's huge IPO
summary: The Tokyo Stock Exchange has approved Japan Post's initial public offering (IPO) planned for November 4, with the government-owned company aiming to raise around $11.6 billion. The IPO will see shares listed for the company, insurance, and banking units, with prices set at 1,350 yen, 1,400 yen, and 2,150 yen per share, respectively. The majority of the offering will be sold to domestic investors, with the remaining portion earmarked for foreign buyers. The mail-delivery unit will remain untouched amid social and political pressure to maintain its status quo.

images.alt_text: The Tokyo Stock Exchange on Thursday approved Japan Post's plans for an initial public offering later this year, setting up a whopping share sale that could top US$11 billion.

site_title: Singapore shares close 1.4% lower on Thursday
summary: The Singapore market ended 1.4% lower on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index shedding 40.15 points to 2,888.03, due to investors' concerns over a potential US interest-rate hike. Local banks and Singtel contributed to the decline. The US Federal Reserve will hold a policy meeting on September 16-17, which may impact emerging markets.

site_title: China tightens capital controls after devalution: FT
summary: China is tightening capital controls amid concerns about fund outflows following the yuan's devaluation. The State Administration of Foreign Exchange ordered financial institutions to increase checks and controls on foreign exchange transactions, particularly over-invoicing of exports. This move comes after the yuan dropped nearly 5% in a week as part of broader economic reforms aimed at shifting towards a more flexible exchange rate. The measures aim to prevent capital outflows and stabilize the currency.

site_title: Shanghai, Hong Kong: Stocks tumble after two-day rise
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks plummeted on Thursday, reversing a two-day rally, due to mixed inflation data from China and concerns over the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes. The Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong fell 2.57% and Shanghai's benchmark composite index dropped 1.39%. The declines were attributed to uncertainty surrounding the Fed's plans and ongoing trade tensions.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks ended barely changed on Thursday, as most Asian markets stabilised after jitters over Turkey's downing of a Russian fighter jet abated.

site_title: Update: Chinese Premier Li sees 'painful and treacherous' economic transition
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang described the country's economic transition as "painful and treacherous," but assured the global economy that China is not a source of risk. The country's GDP growth is expected to slow, with a target of 7% this year, but Li stressed that China's economy is a "source of strength for global growth." Despite acknowledging difficulties, Li said China has the capability to deal with economic challenges and will not head for a hard landing. China's GDP now stands at over $10 trillion, with growth of 7% representing a significant figure.

site_title: Australia: Shares post biggest drop in three weeks
summary: Australian shares plummeted 2.4% on Thursday, marking the largest decline in three weeks, amid concerns of deflation in China. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 125.13 points to 5,095, with banks and miners experiencing the biggest losses. Despite this, the index remains up 1% for the week, following a 4.2% drop the previous week.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks edge down from 1-mth highs; Apple suppliers lose ground
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.4% on Thursday, reversing a one-month high, due to weaker overseas markets and a decline in Apple shares. Apple's new TV set top box and iPhones underwhelmed investors, with Hon Hai Precision and Pegatron, Apple's main suppliers, also losing ground. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$32.606 per US dollar.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close 2.51% lower on China, US rate fears
summary: Tokyo stocks plummeted 2.51% on Thursday, driven by concerns over China and a possible US interest rate hike. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 470.89 points to 18,299.62, while the Topix index fell 1.85% to 1,479.52. The decline came a day after the index's largest one-day jump in seven years. The market's volatility was attributed to uncertainty surrounding China's economic outlook and the US Federal Reserve's potential rate hike, which may impact global trade and investment.

site_title: Seoul: Shares reverse early losses to close at 3-week high; won falls
summary: Seoul shares rose 1.4% to a three-week high, closing at 1,962.11, driven by gains in shipbuilders such as Samsung Heavy Industries and Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering. Foreigners continued to sell, marking a 26th consecutive session, but domestic shares outperformed. The won fell 0.4% to 1,194.4 per dollar. Analysts attributed the shipbuilders' gains to expectations of restructuring normalisation.

site_title: World food commodity prices plunge to lowest in seven years: FAO
summary: The Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) reported that international food commodity prices plummeted in August to their lowest level in nearly seven years. The FAO Food Price Index dropped due to ample supplies, a slump in energy prices, and concerns over China's economic slowdown. Meat prices remained unchanged, but overall prices are down 18% from August 2014.

site_title: China: Stocks correct on profit-taking, joining regional markets
summary: China stocks fell 1.2-1.5% on Thursday, following a 5% gain in the previous two days, as investors took profits and deleveraged. The CSI300 index declined to 3,357.56, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell to 3,197.89 points. Regional markets, including Japan's Nikkei and Taiwan's market, also declined. Despite a warning from Premier Li Keqiang, inflation data showed persistent weakness in producer prices in August with little impact on the market.

site_title: China Jan-Aug FDI rises 9.2% y/y, up 22% in Aug: ministry
summary: China attracted 525.3 billion yuan ($85.3 billion) in foreign direct investment (FDI) in the first eight months of 2015, a 9.2% year-over-year increase. FDI inflows in August rose 22% to 54.2 billion yuan ($8.71 billion).

images.alt_text: China plans to invest about 200 billion yuan (S$43.96 billion) in unspent fiscal funds as soon as possible, an official from the state planner said, adding it was not accurate that authorities had seized untapped local government allocations totalling one trillion yuan.

site_title: China exports to see positive growth this year: ministry
summary: China's exports are expected to see positive growth this year, with the decline in imports easing, according to the commerce ministry. Exports in August dropped 5.5% from a year earlier, slightly less than forecast, while imports fell for the 10th straight month, easing concerns about China's economy slowing down. The ministry attributed the fundamentals of China's foreign trade to remain unchanged.

site_title: Dell says to invest US$125b in China over five years
summary: Dell Inc plans to invest US$125 billion in China over five years, according to CEO Michael Dell. This investment is expected to contribute US$175 billion to imports and exports, sustaining over one million jobs in China. The company aims to integrate its strategies with national policies and expand its research and development team in China. This investment marks a significant expansion for Dell in China, which is the company's second-largest market outside the United States.

site_title: Lufthansa flights return to normal after strike
summary: Lufthansa flights returned to normal after a two-day strike by pilots over cost cuts and pay. A German court ruled that the strike was not only over pay and retirement benefits but also over low-cost expansion plans, which were not part of the union's mandate. The ruling came too late to restore normal flight schedules on Wednesday, but flights resumed on Thursday without cancellations, according to a Lufthansa spokeswoman.

site_title: China to launch new crude oil benchmark
summary: China plans to launch a new yuan-denominated international benchmark for crude oil futures this year, aimed at the Asian market. The contract, traded at the Shanghai International Energy Exchange, will be a price reference for medium sour crude, a variety favored by Asian players. The contract will have a higher sulfur content than existing benchmarks and will be traded in lots of 100 barrels, allowing retail investors to participate. The launch is expected to boost volumes and provide a better hedge for players in the region, potentially affecting existing benchmarks like WTI and Brent.

site_title: Apple said to market euro bonds adding to US$53b debt binge
summary: Apple plans to sell euro bonds, adding to its $53 billion debt since 2013, to raise funds for share buybacks and lock in low borrowing costs. The 12-year euro bonds will be sold at a 95 basis point premium to benchmark rates, compared to a 45 basis point premium in November. This is part of Apple's efforts to diversify funding and return $200 billion to investors by March 2017, as it expands its global retail network.

site_title: Gold holds near 4-week low as fund outflows, US data weigh
summary: Gold prices fell near a four-week low on Thursday, losing 1.4% as strong US economic data and outflows from bullion-backed exchange traded funds reduced investor interest. Spot gold was at $1,106.65 an ounce, its lowest since August 11. The US gold market rose 0.4% despite a 1.7% drop overnight. The decline in gold prices is attributed to the recent strong US economic data and fund outflows.

site_title: Hong Kong watchdog says Moody's broke code of conduct with 'red flags' report
summary: Hong Kong's Moody's unit is accused of breaching the regulator's code of conduct with a 2011 report on Chinese companies, which raised concerns about corporate governance. The report was fined US$3 million, with Moody's claiming the regulator overstepped its mark. The Hong Kong unit is appealing the decision, arguing the report was not a credit rating and therefore not subject to the regulator's code. The outcome of the appeal is yet to be determined.

images.alt_text: An advertising board (left) showing a Chinese stone lion is pictured near an entrance to the headquarters (right) of China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC), in Beijing, China, on Sep 7, 2015.

site_title: Apple aims to conquer living room with new Apple TV
summary: Apple has unveiled a revamped Apple TV, aiming to conquer the living room with a full-fledged App Store, integration with Siri, and a new touch-sensitive remote control. The device, priced at $149, will go on sale in October and will offer a content-driven model, with revenue from programming and services expected to be key. Apple faces competition from firms like Amazon and Roku, but analysts say its edge lies in its open platform for developers and its loyal user base. The new Apple TV will also focus on games, targeting casual players, but will need to convince consumers to buy the device based on available apps.

site_title: Malaysia's July industrial output up 6.1% year on year, well above forecast
summary: Malaysia's July industrial output surged 6.1% year-over-year, exceeding market expectations, driven by growth in manufacturing and mining sectors. Exports rose 3.5% in July, primarily due to increased demand for electrical and electronic goods. However, Malaysia's manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index for August fell to its lowest reading in nearly three years, indicating declining production and purchasing activity. This marks a contrast to the previous month's 4.3% growth in June industrial output.

site_title: China consumer inflation rises to 2.0% in August: govt
summary: China's consumer inflation rose to 2.0% in August, the highest level in a year, as deflation receded. This is the strongest CPI reading since August last year. However, producer prices fell 5.9% in August, marking the 42nd consecutive monthly drop. Moderate inflation can boost consumption, but falling prices can hurt economic growth, which is already slowing due to declining commodity prices.

site_title: Marvel adds Native American, Korean superheroes
summary: Marvel has added two new superheroes, Red Wolf, a Native American character, and Amadeus Cho, a Korean-American teenager, to its roster. Red Wolf will debut in December, while Amadeus Cho will replace Bruce Banner as the new Hulk. These additions aim to diversify the Marvel Universe, following the 2018 film Black Panther, which features a black superhero. The move is seen as a step towards breaking down racial boundaries and highlighting heroes beyond their cultural backgrounds, as artist Jeffrey Veregge stated, "It's about them being a hero."

site_title: EU unveils 'bold' plan to take 160,000 refugees
summary: The European Union has unveiled a plan to take 160,000 refugees from overstretched border states, aiming to ease the pressure from the worst migration crisis since World War II. The US has agreed to accept more Syrians to alleviate the issue. European Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker urged the continent to take decisive action, citing the need to ignore populist parties and draw on its history. Germany pushed for long-term binding quotas with no limits on numbers to address the surge in asylum-seekers.

site_title: Dollar little changed as investors await Fed rate call
summary: The US dollar remained largely unchanged against other major currencies as investors awaited the Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates next week. Analysts expect the Fed to leave interest rates unchanged, citing market turmoil and concerns about growth and inflation. The greenback firmed against the Japanese yen, but the outlook for a rate hike remains uncertain. A delay in a rate hike could lead to a "big bounce" for the dollar. The Federal Open Market Committee will make its decision on September 16.

site_title: Asian markets retreat as China, Fed feed caution
summary: Asian markets retreated on Thursday, following a two-day rally, due to concerns over a potential US interest rate hike and mixed Chinese inflation data. China's consumer price index rose 2% last month, while the producer price index fell at its fastest rate in six years. Despite Chinese Premier Li Keqiang's efforts to reassure investors, markets were volatile, with Shanghai, Hong Kong, and Tokyo experiencing losses. The US jobs market data also sparked speculation about a potential rate hike, adding to market unease.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks ended barely changed on Thursday, as most Asian markets stabilised after jitters over Turkey's downing of a Russian fighter jet abated.

site_title: Seoul: Shares edge down on profit-taking; won falls
summary: Seoul shares declined 0.1% on Thursday, reversing the previous day's 3% gain, amid profit-taking. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed at 1,932.98. Analysts attribute the decline to a contraction in risk appetite, following overnight falls in Wall Street. Prior gainers in growth stocks are retreating, while undervalued stocks in chemicals and shipbuilders are seen leading the market's gains.

site_title: Asia: Stocks stumble as gloomy China, Japan data add to growth worries
summary: Asian stocks fell on Thursday after China's consumer inflation edged up and Japan's capital spending unexpectedly fell, highlighting concerns about slackening global growth. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand cut its benchmark rate by 25 basis points, but economists revised down their global growth forecasts to 3.5% for 2016 and 2017. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.6% and other regional indices also declined, with Tokyo's Nikkei falling 2.9% and Australian shares falling 2.2%.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 11.6 points to 1592.16, with losers outnumbering gainers 162 to 56. Volume reached 37.4 million lots worth RM14.9 million.

site_title: China says senior official visited Interpol to push graft fight
summary: China's Deputy Head of the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection, Zhao Hongzhu, visited Interpol in France to push for greater international cooperation in combating corruption. The visit came as China's "Sky Net" initiative aims to return corrupt officials and assets from abroad. Only about 10 people from a list of 100 suspected corrupt individuals have been returned to China so far. The move is part of President Xi Jinping's anti-graft campaign, which has been hindered by difficulty in getting corrupt officials and assets back from overseas.

images.alt_text: President Xi Jinping has launched a sweeping campaign against graft since assuming power in late 2012, but has been hampered to an extent by difficulty in getting corrupt officials and assets back from overseas.

site_title: Tax concerns on Yahoo's Alibaba stake spinoff prompt target cuts
summary: Yahoo's planned tax-free spinoff of its Alibaba stake has hit a roadblock, with the US Internal Revenue Service denying a private letter ruling request. This move prompted at least nine brokerages to cut their price targets on the stock, citing a diminished likelihood of a positive tax outcome. Despite this, analysts remain largely positive on Yahoo's value, with its stake in Alibaba and Yahoo Japan Corp. driving much of its worth. The company will weigh its options, including proceeding with the spinoff or exploring alternative alternatives.

site_title: South Korea's Hyundai Motor union votes for strike
summary: South Korea's Hyundai Motor union has voted to strike unless a wage dispute deal is reached. The union, representing 48,585 workers, voted 78% in favor of strike action, with 89% participation. The union is demanding a 7.84% wage hike, job security until age 65, and 30% of net profit for bonus payments. The strike would be the fourth consecutive year of industrial action at the automaker, which reported a 23.8% plunge in second-quarter net profit due to a strong won and increased competition. Negotiations will resume later Thursday.

site_title: AirAsia's Indonesian affiliate plans debt-to-equity conversion
summary: Indonesia AirAsia, the Indonesian affiliate of AirAsia, plans to convert debt into preference shares to meet Indonesia's new "positive equity" rule. The move is pending approval from the Indonesia investment coordinating board. The conversion aims to improve the airline's equity position, which had previously been considered "negative equity". This decision follows a government extension of the deadline, allowing airlines until September 30 to meet the new requirement.

site_title: Forget social media, friends and family drive purchases: study
summary: A study by Boston Consulting Group found that direct word-of-mouth recommendations from friends and family are the top driver of purchasing decisions, being about four or five times more influential than traditional and social media in making purchases.

site_title: Oil prices remain low as Japan data hints at weaker Asia economy
summary: Crude oil prices slipped as Japan's machinery orders fell 3.6% in July, fuelling concerns about a weaker Asia economy. This data follows a 7.9% decline in June and a further slowdown in China's economic growth. Oil prices have dropped over 50% since June 2014 due to conflicting global output and slowing economies. The weakening in Asia's economies also led to a downgrade of Brazil's credit rating to junk-grade.

site_title: Standard and Poor's cuts Brazil sovereign credit rating to junk
summary: Standard & Poor's cut Brazil's sovereign credit rating to junk, citing struggles with growing debt and political turmoil under President Dilma Rousseff's government. The 'BB+' and 'BBB-' ratings are a blow to the foundering economy, potentially driving off investors. The junk rating is the latest in a series of challenges, including a corruption scandal at state-owned oil giant Petrobras and a recession that could extend into 2016. Analysts warn of further downgrades due to the government's inability to submit a budget to Congress, and potential policy reversals amidst fluid political dynamics.

site_title: Ringgit falls below 3.07 to Singdollar
summary: Malaysia's ringgit currency fell below 3.07 to the Singapore dollar, reaching a new 1998 low against the US dollar at 4.3770 per US dollar. The decline is attributed to concerns of capital flowing out of emerging markets due to the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike and other market downturns. Analysts predict a risk-off trading environment, leading to a drop in Asian currencies.

site_title: Li says China still has policy tools as growth faces pressures
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang stated that China's economy is still within a reasonable growth range despite facing downward pressure and difficulties. He vowed to press ahead with reforms and gradually open the nation's capital account. Li's 7% growth target for this year is at risk due to a stock market rout and sluggish global demand, with exports falling 5.5% in August. The country's official factory gauge has also reached a three-year low, increasing pressure on policymakers.

site_title: HNA plans China's first Islamic finance deal
summary: HNA Group, a Chinese conglomerate, plans to raise up to $150 million in Islamic loans in October to finance ship purchases, marking the first Islamic financing deal by a mainland Chinese company. The financing arm will issue a large offshore sukuk, likely over $500 million, with a mix of global and Gulf-based banks involved. This move aims to address China's scarce and costly domestic loan market, as private firms seek funding overseas. The deal is expected to be a precursor to more Chinese companies entering Islamic finance, a growing area in global financial centers.

images.alt_text: Renminbi banknotes are placed on a bank staff's table in a bank.

site_title: Vallianz says plans to penetrate Egypt, Iran in very early stage
summary: Vallianz Holdings is in the preliminary stages of submitting for pre-qualification in Egypt and assessing the potential of the Iranian market. The offshore vessel owner hopes to be ready for tender opportunities in Egypt by the first half of 2016, but faces uncertainty regarding qualification and approval. Vallianz shares rose 2% in early trade following the announcement, amid a clarification of earlier comments on its expansion plans.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
Mr Ling Yong Wah, CEO of Vallianz Holdings.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks fall more than 3% at opening
summary: Tokyo shares plummeted more than 3% at the opening on Thursday, marking their biggest one-day drop since 2008. The Nikkei-225 index fell 3.21% to 18,167.65. The decline follows a previous one-day jump of 3.44% on Wednesday.

site_title: Hijack suspected as Malaysian cargo ship goes missing
summary: Malaysian authorities are searching for a cargo ship, MV Sah Lian, that has been missing for a week and is suspected to be hijacked in the South China Sea. The ship, carrying a mixed cargo and 14 crew members from Malaysia, Indonesia, Myanmar, and India, lost contact last Thursday while traveling from Kuching to Limbang. The Malaysian coast guard is leading the search operation, with concerns over piracy in the area.

site_title: International Healthway requests trading halt
summary: International Healthway Corp (IHC) has requested a trading halt pending an announcement. The Singapore Exchange warned investors to exercise caution after reviewing trades in IHC shares, which showed 60% were conducted by a small group of connected individuals. IHC proposed acquiring Healthway Medical Corp by issuing new shares.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

A view of Singapore Exchange building (SGX) at the financial district in Singapore on Aug 25, 2015. On Wednesday, the Singapore Exchange advised investors to exercise caution when trading shares of IHC.

site_title: Hong Kong, China: Stocks open lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 2.36% on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index dropping to 21,609.27, following a strong two-day rally and China's inflation data showing a 2% rate for August. Shanghai and Shenzhen composite indexes also declined, with Shanghai's composite index falling 1.66% to 3,190.55. The declines came after China released the inflation data, which was seen as a positive sign for the economy.

site_title: Singapore shares open sharply lower on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares opened 1% lower on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index slipping 40.6 points to 2,887.6, amid global market downturns. The benchmark index had previously seen a 5-day rally. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 fell 1.5% and 1.4% respectively, driven by rate hike fears and falling crude oil prices. Despite this, investors remained positive, with the STI closing 0.4% higher on Thursday.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Japan teams up with CME to develop LNG index, break oil-link
summary: CME Group partners with RIM Intelligence to develop a Japanese liquefied natural gas (LNG) index contract, aiming to break Japan's decade-long reliance on oil-linked pricing. Japan, the world's largest LNG importer, seeks to cut fuel costs and gain control over prices after the Fukushima disaster. The new contract will allow importers to hedge risks as Japan prepares to liberalize its power market. It will be available for submission to clearing via the Japan OTC Exchange and over-the-counter brokers, potentially kickstarting spot trading of the world's fastest-growing energy source.

images.alt_text: The Middle East crude benchmarks Dubai and DME Oman remained mired in deep discounts of about US$2 a barrel to Dubai swaps on Thursday.

site_title: UK's state-owned finance sprawl needs better management: watchdog
summary: The UK's National Audit Office (NAO) has warned that the country's state-owned financial institutions, now totaling 54, need better management. These institutions, including nationalized banks and loan management bodies, represent a £222 billion asset value on the government's balance sheet. The NAO recommends a portfolio approach to managing these institutions, as it is difficult to distinguish between temporary and permanent bodies. The government's poor track record in selling shares and managing debt risks losing taxpayers more than £200 million over the next five years.

site_title: Japan's July core machinery orders down 3.6% month on month
summary: Japan's core machinery orders fell 3.6% in July from the previous month, marking a second consecutive decline and casting doubt on capital expenditures. This was lower than the expected 3.7% increase. Core orders, excluding ship and electric power utilities, rose 2.8% compared to the same period last year. The data suggests a slowdown in Japan's economy and raises concerns about the strength of capital spending in the coming months.

site_title: Bread-and-butter issues drive PAP's Tin Pei Ling
summary: Tin Pei Ling, a PAP candidate, held her first and only rally speech in MacPherson, defending her seat in a three-cornered contest. She discussed her plans to improve infrastructure, support low-income families, and provide childcare services. She also criticized opposition party policy proposals, suggesting they would burden the next generation. Tin Pei Ling emphasized the importance of bread-and-butter issues and her vision for Singapore, including a world-class education system and a conducive environment for young families.

site_title: Memstar converts trading halt to suspension pending RTO revision talks
summary: Memstar Technology has converted its trading halt to a voluntary suspension pending negotiations on revising terms of its proposed reverse takeover of Longmen Group. The deal, valued at US$420 million, was initially proposed last December. Memstar has signed three supplemental agreements since February, but discussions are still preliminary. There is no certainty that the parties will reach an agreement, and shareholders are advised to exercise caution.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Apple presses deeper with new iPhones and more
summary: Apple unveiled new iPhones, the iPhone 6S and 6S Plus, at a media event in San Francisco. The devices feature the same overall dimensions as the previous model, but with new technologies under the hood. Additionally, Apple introduced an upgraded streaming TV box and an iPad Pro aimed at revitalizing the tablet market, moving into the living room and expanding its product line.

site_title: Business sentiments of Singapore SMEs fall to three-year low
summary: Singapore small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) reported a three-year low in business sentiments, with the SBF-DP SME Index dropping to 51.9 in the final quarter of 2015. All sectors experienced a decline in turnover and profitability expectations, with the construction/engineering sector reporting the largest drop. The decline is attributed to weakening residential property prices and limited opportunities in the commercial and industrial property sectors, potentially leading to lower hiring expectations and a further slowdown in job creation.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: S'pore creatives take a bite of the Big Apple
summary: A group of Singaporean artists, chefs, architects, and designers will showcase their works in Manhattan from September 23 to 27 as part of the Singapore Tourism Board's "Singapore: Inside Out" event. The showcase features 20 New York restaurants serving Singapore-inspired dishes, and a window display at Bergdorf Goodman featuring local artist John Clang's work. The event aims to refresh perceptions of Singapore globally, celebrating its vibrant creative scene and cultural diversity. This is the third stop in the "Singapore: Inside Out" tour, following Beijing and London.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: UK surveyors report fastest prices rises since May 2014
summary: The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) reported the fastest house price rises in the UK since May 2014, with a 6% increase expected this year, up from an earlier forecast of 3%. A shortage of homes on the market contributed to a +53 RICS monthly house price balance in August, the highest level since 2014. RICS chief economist Simon Rubinsohn said the trend is likely to be sustained into next year, despite making it uncomfortable for those entering the market.

site_title: Wall Street selloff cuts short global market rally
summary: A late Wall Street selloff cut short a global market rally on Wednesday, as concerns over the Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hike next week took hold. Despite a strong start, US stocks fell 1.39% and 1.45% for the S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average, respectively. Global markets also declined, with China's Shanghai Exchange and Japan's Tokyo market experiencing gains, but ultimately failing to sustain the rally. Economists say the Labor Department's jobs report, which showed rising job vacancies, may raise the odds of a Fed rate hike.

site_title: China Sky requests resumption of trading after long suspension
summary: China Sky Chemical Fibre, whose share trading was suspended since November 2011, has requested trading resumption from Thursday, citing compliance with conditions imposed by the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The company had previously agreed to a civil settlement with the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) involving former CEO Huang Zhong Xuan, who admitted to breaking capital markets laws and agreed to pay a civil penalty. Trading is expected to resume on or after September 10, barring unforeseen circumstances.

site_title: Vallianz eyes entry into Egypt and Iran
summary: Vallianz Holdings, an offshore vessel owner, is expanding its fleet to support its ventures in Egypt and Iran, a joint-venture with Rawabi Holdings. The companies are seeking to pre-qualify for offshore tenders in Egypt by mid-2016, following a giant gas discovery in the country. Vallianz also aims to break into Iran's offshore market, with 50 projects valued at US$185 million planned for development. The joint venture partners are looking to secure long-term charters to finance the vessels and reduce debt.

site_title: US: Stocks sink as Apple drops after products launch
summary: US stocks plummeted on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 239.11 points (1.45%) to 16,253.57. The S&P 500 dropped 27.37 (1.39%) to 1,942.04, and the Nasdaq Composite Index lost 55.40 (1.15%) to 4,756.53. The decline came after Apple's shares sank following the unveiling of its upgraded products. The tech-heavy Nasdaq was the biggest loser, with many investors selling off shares amid concerns about the products' pricing and demand.

site_title: Firms in Europe boost long-dated debt this year
summary: European companies have increased long-term debt by 225 billion euros this year, with bonds maturing in a decade or more accounting for 36% of all investment-grade notes sold. Companies such as Allianz and Bayer took advantage of low borrowing costs, while investors sought riskier assets due to suppressed European Central Bank yields. This trend may be narrowing as the region's growing economy increases inflationary pressure and the Federal Reserve prepares to lift interest rates, forcing investors to seek alternative assets.

site_title: Tokyo's dramatic stock market surge signals more volatility ahead: analysts
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index surged 7.7% or 1,343 points to 18,770.51 on Wednesday, its most dramatic move since the 2008 global financial crisis. The rally came after Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's virtual certainty of three more years in power and the continuation of "Abenomics" policies. Analysts suggest the surge was partly a "relief rally" over apparent stabilisation of markets in China and a modest "price-keeping operation" by Japanese public pension funds. Further volatility is expected ahead, with markets worldwide showing see-sawing movements.

site_title: Yahoo may have to pay taxes on US$23b Alibaba spinoff
summary: Yahoo may have to pay taxes on the planned $23 billion spinoff of its Alibaba stake, despite the US Internal Revenue Service (IRS) denying a request for a private letter ruling on tax-free status. The IRS has not concluded the transaction would be taxable, but Yahoo will weigh its options, including proceeding with the spinoff. The decision puts pressure on CEO Marissa Mayer's turnaround strategy, which has yet to revive Yahoo's core online advertising business. The value of the stake has nearly halved since January's announcement.

site_title: Asia: Stocks follow US lower as jobs data fuel rate-rise bets
summary: Asian stocks declined, following a surge in the regional benchmark index the previous day, as data on US job openings fueled rate-rise bets. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index dropped 1.2% to 127.87, while the Standard & Poor's 500 Index slid 1.4%. Investors weighed the implications of the employment data for the Federal Reserve meeting, with futures traders seeing a 28% chance of a rate hike in September. Markets are expected to remain volatile until the Fed meeting next week.

site_title: Oil prices skid lower as oversupply worries weigh
summary: Oil prices declined on Wednesday due to concerns about global oversupply, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate falling $1.79 to $44.15 a barrel and Brent North Sea crude closing at $47.58 a barrel. The drop was attributed to expectations of another increase in US inventories, further exacerbating worries about the global oversupply.

site_title: Lufthansa fails to block escalation of pilot strike
summary: A Frankfurt labour court ruled that Lufthansa's attempt to block the escalation of the pilot strike was dismissed, allowing the strike to proceed. The strike, which has already canceled over 1,000 flights, will continue and is deemed not disproportionate. Lufthansa has appealed the decision and will adopt a tougher stance, including a hiring freeze and limiting labour talks. The strike is over Lufthansa's plan to create a European low-cost carrier, which the pilot union argues affects its collective bargaining accords.

site_title: Microsoft shares Apple event stage in tech world twist
summary: Microsoft made a surprise appearance on the stage of an Apple event, showcasing software tailored for a new iPad Pro. Apple CEO Tim Cook welcomed Microsoft, saying "Who knows more about productivity than Microsoft?" The move marked a significant shift in the long-standing rivalry between the two tech giants. Microsoft's executive Kirk Koenigsbauer presented Office work software designed for the iPad Pro, while Adobe demonstrated a new application, Photoshop Fix, also for the device. The unexpected appearance has sparked debate among fans, with some seeing it as a sign of Microsoft's defeat and others as a potential alliance to push iPads into the business world.

site_title: US$1.4b collateral payment to Abu Dhabi firm by 1MDB possibly not received: WSJ
summary: Malaysia's state-owned 1MDB reportedly failed to receive a $1.4 billion collateral payment from Abu Dhabi partner International Petroleum Investment Co (IPIC) for its $3.5 billion bond issue in 2012. 1MDB denied the claim, stating the payment was made and IPIC continues to guarantee the principal and interest. The Wall Street Journal's article has raised concerns about 1MDB's transparency and the potential for further impropriety under Prime Minister Najib Razak. The lack of clarity has damaged public confidence in the government and economy.

site_title: Indonesia unveils stimulus to bolster economy, currency
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo unveiled a stimulus package to boost the economy and currency, which has weakened to 17-year lows. The package includes streamlining trade and industry regulations, simplifying permission processes, and easing foreign currency rules. The government also plans to provide more rice for the poor and find cheaper foreign beef to combat inflation. A second installment of the package is expected to be announced by month-end, but experts warn that infrastructure issues remain a major challenge. The package aims to stimulate the real economy and attract investment, but its impact will be limited without addressing entrenched problems.

images.alt_text: A teller preparing Indonesian rupiah for a customer at a money changer in Jakarta on Wednesday. The rupiah touched a fresh 17-year low on Tuesday.

site_title: Leveraged loan market shows signs of life in US after weak August
summary: The US leveraged loan market is showing signs of revival after its weakest August since 2011. At least four companies, including Berry Plastics Group and Beacon Roofing Supply, are meeting with lenders to discuss loan issuances for acquisitions. The market is expected to continue its recovery, with issuers marketing debt for various deals.

site_title: Seeking relevance in a shrinking asset management sandbox
summary: The asset management industry faces challenges as regulatory scrutiny increases, traditional sources of alpha become elusive, and disruptive technology encroaches on its business. Despite being a significant sector of the global economy, managing over $70 trillion in assets, the industry is shrinking and seeking relevance. Clients will require transparency, compliance, and innovative investment platforms, akin to the "Uber-nisation" of the industry. To survive, asset managers must adapt and evolve to meet changing client demands and technological advancements.

site_title: Luxury homes unsold after a year shows glut in south London
summary: A year after its launch, the £12 billion Nine Elms district in south London has seen nearly 30% of new properties remain unsold, with luxury homes languishing on the market. High prices, increased sales tax, and currency turmoil in emerging markets have deterred international investors, who once accounted for half of all new homes in central London. Local buyers are unlikely to fill the gap, with interest-rate increases expected in the near future.

site_title: New Zealand further reduces interest rates
summary: New Zealand's central bank reduced interest rates by 0.25 percentage points to 2.25% for the third time this year, citing a slowing economy and lower export commodity prices. The economy is growing at 2.0% annually, driven by tourism, strong immigration, and construction activity. Bank governor Graeme Wheeler expects further easing in interest rates, citing the need to keep inflation near the 2.0% target midpoint. The move aims to support growth and alleviate the impact of the decline in export prices.

images.alt_text: New Zealand snipped a further 0.25 percentage points off interest rates on Thursday, the third reduction this year, and with the central bank suggesting further easing was likely in coming months.

site_title: China plans to step up fiscal incentives to boost growth
summary: China plans to increase fiscal incentives to boost its economy, following turmoil in domestic and overseas markets. The government will accelerate major construction projects, allow more small companies to benefit from tax cuts, and encourage private capital to invest in key areas. This move aims to support China's 7% growth target and stabilize growth, following a 40% slump in the Shanghai Composite Index since mid-June. The government has already spent 96% of its annual infrastructure investment budget by the end of August.

images.alt_text: The Chinese government will accelerate major construction projects, allow more small companies to benefit from tax cuts, and encourage private capital to invest in key areas, among other steps.

site_title: East Coast team main architects of WP manifesto: Low
summary: Singapore's Workers' Party (WP) team in East Coast GRC, led by Low Thia Khiang, were key architects of the party's 2015 general election manifesto. Low Thia Khiang stated that the team is highly qualified to debate policies in Parliament. He urged voters in the affluent East Coast area to support the WP to have a significant presence in Parliament, allowing the party to effectively play a role in shaping policies.

site_title: Managing risk in a globalised world
summary: Globalisation has increased risk in the financial system, with interconnected supply chains and markets creating complex risk management challenges. To address these challenges, a more scientific approach to risk management is needed, involving international standards and coordinated action across levels of resolution. The "system of systems" approach requires multiple tools to manage risks at individual, national, and global levels. The Integrated Reporting framework can help identify and manage non-financial risks, and Singapore's capital markets infrastructure is well-positioned to support risk management in the region.

site_title: IEA seeks China's cooperation on oil stockpile use
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) has called for China's cooperation in using its oil stockpiles in the event of a global energy crisis. China's growing buffer, estimated at 49 million barrels, is separate from the IEA's emergency inventory system. IEA Executive Director Fatih Birol said China should become a "full participant" in the organization's work to secure supplies. The IEA plans to hold a joint emergency-response exercise with China next year to coordinate the release of oil reserves. This cooperation aims to mitigate the impact of a global supply disruption on oil prices.

site_title: 83% committed occupancy at CapitaGreen
summary: CapitaGreen, a 40-storey Grade A office tower in Singapore, has reached 83% committed occupancy, with 30 multinational companies from diverse industries occupying the building. The 703,000 sqft building received the Green Mark Platinum Award and has been leased to tenants including Lloyds Banking Group, Schroders Investment Management, and South32. With half of the $1.4 billion development cost attributed to differential premium and land-related costs, CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) has a call option to buy the remaining partners' stakes within three years, subject to market valuation.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: South African gold industry fading as margin squeeze erodes output
summary: South Africa's gold mining industry is struggling due to a margin squeeze, with the four largest producers losing money on 35% of production. Higher costs, including electricity bills that have risen to a record, are cutting into profits. Workers are demanding wage increases, with some threatening strikes if salaries aren't doubled. The industry has declined significantly, with output halving to 145 tonnes last year, and prices have slumped 40% from their 2011 record. Companies face pressure from workers and investors, with some warning that the future of South African gold mining is heading towards a declining trend.

site_title: Yen fall continues as global stocks rally
summary: The yen fell for the third consecutive day due to a global stock market rally, weakening as safe-haven assets lost demand. Japan's Nikkei surged 7.7% and European stocks are expected to rise, while the euro also declined. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's comments on fiscal stimulus contributed to the market optimism. The yen's decline contrasts with the US stock market, which is set to open lower amid a fresh tariff salvo by Donald Trump on Canada.

site_title: Lacking travellers, Berlin's 'phantom' airport draws tourists
summary: Berlin's troubled international airport project, five years behind schedule, has become a tourist attraction with over 1 million visitors since guided tours began in 2007. The tours, offering a behind-the-scenes look at the construction site, have become an unexpected hit with locals and tourists alike. Despite the site's financial woes, with a budget of over 5 billion euros, the tours provide a minimal source of income. Visitors can also participate in guided bicycle rides and a half-marathon across the runways, with the official opening date now slated for late 2017.
