site_title: Dennis Yeo joins CBRE as regional head of industrial and logistics services
summary: Dennis Yeo has joined CBRE as regional head of industrial and logistics services in Asia, effective September 8. Yeo brings over 20 years of experience in handling industrial transactions for multinational clients in the region. He aims to tap Asia's growth, particularly in India and China, and expand CBRE's services to industrial manufacturing and services companies, warehousing and storage firms, and data centers. The move comes after five industrial brokers from Colliers Singapore defected to CBRE in June, bolstering the firm's industrial expertise in the region.

site_title: Party united despite talk of rift over 1MDB scandal: Najib
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak said his party, Umno, is united despite concerns over the 1MDB scandal, which has led to criticism from senior ministers. Najib dismissed talk of a rift and welcomed the involvement of former deputy prime minister Muhyiddin Yassin, who had been critical of his leadership. The party meeting came after a Cabinet reshuffle in July, which saw Muhyiddin and other senior ministers removed. Najib faces a major crisis following media reports of a large transfer of funds into his account, which he denies any wrongdoing over.

site_title: 'Don't leave international financial flows to the market'
summary: The US economy's recovery from the 2008 Global Financial Crisis is causing emerging markets to destabilize. Despite the US economy's role in the crisis, emerging markets, which heavily rely on US exports, are suffering. This is seen as unfair, as the US economy was the cause of the crisis. International forums, including the G20, have coordinated economic policies to support the US economy's recovery, leaving emerging markets vulnerable to the consequences. This phenomenon challenges the traditional notion of international financial flows being tied to the US economy.

site_title: UK factory output slumps in July, BOE seen wary on rates
summary: The UK manufacturing sector experienced its first year-on-year decline in nearly two years in July, with factory output falling 0.8% and exports dropping 9% due to weaker global demand. The trade deficit widened to £11.08 billion, four times its level in June. The Bank of England is expected to maintain interest rates at record lows, with a possible decision in early 2016, as the slowdown in the global economy may prompt caution.

images.alt_text: Exports of goods dropped by more than 9 per cent, the biggest fall since July 2006, the ONS said.

site_title: Blackstone buys Strategic Hotels and Resorts for US$6b
summary: Blackstone Group has agreed to acquire Strategic Hotels and Resorts for approximately $6 billion, including debt. The deal includes high-end properties such as Four Seasons hotels, Fairmont and Intercontinental hotels, and JW Marriott Essex House Hotel. The transaction is expected to close in the first quarter, pending shareholder approval. This acquisition represents a 13% premium to Strategic Hotels' unaffected intraday trading price.

site_title: Aug condo rents fall 0.4%, lease transactions slide 1.6%
summary: Singapore's private condominium and apartment rents dropped 0.4% in August, according to SRX Property data. This decline was worsened by a rise in private home completions. Meanwhile, HDB rents fell 0.6%. The weaker leasing market is attributed to the increase in private home completions.

images.alt_text: Residential rents in the suburbs fell 1.3 per cent, compared to the city centre's 0.7 per cent decrease, and the city fringe's 0.8 per cent increase.

site_title: Tencent pips Alibaba as Asia's biggest Internet company
summary: Alibaba Group Holding has lost its title as Asia's largest Internet company to Tencent Holdings, with its market value plummeting by US$140.7 billion over the past 10 months. Alibaba's shares fell 4.7% to US$60.91, while Tencent's value surpassed US$153 billion. Tencent's growth is attributed to its expansion into Hollywood content, cloud computing, and on-demand mobile services, as well as its e-commerce alliance with JD.com. The decline in Alibaba's market capitalization is equivalent to the entire value of Samsung Electronics Co.

site_title: Pavilion Energy to offer small-scale LNG solutions in S-E Asia
summary: Pavilion Energy plans to offer small-scale liquefied natural gas (LNG) solutions in South-east Asia, targeting islands with high power demands. The company has already discussed partnerships with Indonesian and Philippine markets, and will use vessels of 10,000 cubic metres to deliver LNG. This move aims to increase flexibility in terminal operations and make LNG available to users not connected to pipeline networks. Pavilion Energy believes small-scale LNG solutions will promote LNG penetration in previously unreachable markets and increase demand for natural gas.

site_title: Risk-protecting strategies seen adding to wild market swings
summary: Investors in risk-parity funds and exchange-traded funds (ETFs) have seen their strategies contribute to market volatility, despite promising to insulate investors from risk. The massive sums of money invested in these strategies, estimated at around $4 trillion, have led to a more volatile market. As returns on these investments continue to suffer, a wave of investor selling is expected to start a wider market rout, with managers struggling to unload high-yield bonds and equities. Experts warn that the current low-volatility environment is coming to an end, and investors must adapt to more frequent and unpredictable market swings.

images.alt_text: An explosion in investments aimed at avoiding market pratfalls has become an investment rage in recent years as global central banks pumped trillions of dollars into asset markets to spur economic growth .

site_title: Central bank officials set 2016 interim deadline for new forex code
summary: Central bank officials have set a 2016 interim deadline to publish a new global code for currency markets, aiming to eradicate misconduct and remove excuses for breaches. The code will replace existing guidelines and address issues of clarity and enforcement. A "reasonable chunk" of the new guide will be published by May 2016, with completion expected in 2017. Enforcement remains a challenge, with officials considering incentives and less-severe penalties to promote adherence through industry-wide efforts.

site_title: Tharman debunks myths on the surplus, reserves and CPF
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam addressed opposition claims that the Singapore government is "squirrelling away" savings into reserves and denying citizens benefits. He explained that the government's prudent long-term budgeting results in increased investment returns, which in turn allow for higher government spending benefiting current and future generations. Tharman also clarified that excess returns on Central Provident Fund (CPF) investments, which some claim are being kept by the state-owned investment firm GIC, are actually reinvested into the budget, benefiting the public.

images.alt_text: Tharman greets supporters.

site_title: Will China crash?
summary: China's economy is weakening, with growth likely below the government's target of 7% and recent manufacturing index at its lowest point in three years. Despite this, economists argue that China's economy is not near collapse, citing rising retail sales, smartphone sales, and a strong job market. However, housing over-investment and a stock market plunge remain major concerns. The slowdown has had global consequences, including a commodities bubble bursting and impacting commodity producers worldwide. China's leaders may need to adapt to a new economic model, but the country's strong job market and rising consumer spending suggest they feel relatively safe.

site_title: BP must face investors' US$2.5b spill-loss claims, rules court
summary: A federal appeals court ruled that BP must face investors' US$2.5 billion claims for market losses caused by the 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill. The court upheld a decision allowing institutional investors who bought shares after the spill to sue as a group for losses. Those who bought shares before the spill are blocked from seeking damages due to alleged deception by company promises. The shareholder class action is set to go before a Houston federal jury in January.

site_title: China's premier downplays slowdown at World Economic Forum, reassures investors
summary: China's Prime Minister Li Keqiang reassured global investors at the World Economic Forum that the country's economy is operating within a reasonable range despite slowing growth. The economy grew 7% in the first two quarters, its slowest rate in over 25 years, but Li said China can maintain mid- to high-speed growth as long as employment remains stable and incomes grow in tandem with output. The government has taken steps to stabilize growth, including cutting interest rates and devaluing the yuan, but Li said there is no basis for further devaluation and no intention of sparking a currency war.

site_title: Vote for us to work for you and make PAP work harder: SDP
summary: The Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) unveiled its "alternative vision" for Singapore, promising to prioritize Singaporeans in job offers, implement a minimum wage that keeps up with inflation, and make public housing flats "truly affordable." The party's leader, Chee Soon Juan, called on voters to cast away their fear and vote for the SDP's 11 candidates to represent their interests in Parliament. The SDP claims the ruling People's Action Party's policies have led to unhappiness among Singaporeans, and the party aims to undo these issues, including high costs of living, job insecurity, and neglect of the elderly.

site_title: United's ousted CEO was in a nosedive even before graft probe
summary: United Airlines' ousted CEO Jeff Smisek struggled with a poorly integrated merger, labor disputes, and technology issues before a US probe into a flight from Newark to South Carolina. Smisek departed on Tuesday amidst these troubles. The airline faced criticism over its merger integration and technology glitches. His departure comes as the company faces additional scrutiny.

site_title: Fast food, fast jobs: Chipotle to hire 4,000 in one go
summary: Chipotle is hiring 4,000 new staff in one go, with each restaurant interviewing up to 60 applicants. The company aims to keep its pace of growth, having opened 100 new restaurants in the first half of the year, taking its total to 1,850. The entry-level jobs offer $10 an hour with health insurance and paid time off. This move comes as the company continues its expansion plans, with revenues rising 17% to $2.29 billion for the first six months of the year.

site_title: The dos and don'ts for Cooling-off Day and Polling day
summary: The Elections Department of Singapore has issued reminders on the dos and don'ts for Cooling-off Day and Polling Day. On these days, campaigning, canvassing, and displaying political propaganda are prohibited. Election advertising is also restricted, except for reports, Party Political Broadcasts, approved posters, and certain online ads. Voters are advised to bring their NRIC/passport and poll card to the polling station and to mark their choice with a cross on the ballot paper. No camera, video, or photographic equipment is allowed in the polling station, and voters are encouraged to avoid the morning peak period.

site_title: BA plane catches fire at Las Vegas airport, several injured
summary: A British Airways plane caught fire at Las Vegas' McCarran International Airport on Tuesday, prompting an emergency evacuation. The Boeing BA plane was preparing for takeoff when flames broke out, injuring several passengers. There were 159 passengers and 13 crew members on board. The cause of the fire is unknown and an investigation is underway.

site_title: Woodside faces long trek for Oil Search bid
summary: Woodside Petroleum is pursuing its A$11.65 billion takeover bid for Oil Search, but faces significant challenges. The bid requires support from both Papua New Guinea and Abu Dhabi, with the latter's backing seen as crucial for the deal's success. The deal would be the largest energy takeover in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Costco sold counterfeit Tiffany engagement rings, rules US judge
summary: A US judge ruled that Costco Wholesale Corp willfully infringed on Tiffany & Co's trademarks by selling counterfeit diamond engagement rings bearing the luxury retailer's name. The judge rejected Costco's claim that Tiffany's trademarks were invalid because they sought to prevent others from using the word "Tiffany" as a generic description of a ring setting. Costco must face a jury trial to assess damages.

site_title: Think of the future, as you evaluate track records
summary: Singapore voters are reflecting on the future as they cast their ballots in the country's general election. While the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) has a strong track record, voters are also considering the future, including threats to their well-being and the impact of technology on jobs. The PAP has made efforts to address concerns, such as curbing the foreigner inflow and introducing new policies for the elderly. However, opposition parties, including the Singapore Democratic Party and the Workers' Party, are also vying for votes, with some criticizing the PAP's sometimes harsh attitude towards dissent.

site_title: Microsoft buys cloud computing security startup Adallom
summary: Microsoft has acquired cloud computing security startup Adallom for an estimated $250 million. The acquisition aims to enhance Microsoft's offerings for the enterprise, particularly in defending programs and content in the cloud. Adallom's technology will be integrated into other Microsoft products, such as Enterprise Mobility Suite and Advanced Threat Analytics. This move follows Microsoft's shift towards cloud-based computing and its expansion of the Surface Pro tablet for businesses.

site_title: Centara eyes major cities, new markets
summary: Centara Hotels and Resorts, a Thai hotel chain, aims to expand globally and establish a presence in major cities and emerging markets. To achieve this, the company plans to purchase properties in strategic locations to boost its reputation. Suparat Chirathivat, Centara's vice-president for development, stated that the chain will focus on gateway cities and emerging markets to become an international hotel chain. This expansion strategy aims to increase the company's global presence and reputation.

site_title: Singtel teams up with telcos to boost startup ecosystems
summary: Singtel Innov8, a venture capital arm of Singapore Telecommunications, has teamed up with other telcos to boost startup ecosystems across South-east Asia, Africa, Europe, Latin America, and the Middle East. The partnership aims to create a unified startup ecosystem, with Singtel Innov8 providing $250 million in funding. The collaboration will also promote innovation and entrepreneurship in the region, with Singtel Innov8 offices in Singapore, Silicon Valley, Tel Aviv, and Beijing.

site_title: Surfwear chain Quiksilver files for bankruptcy
summary: Quiksilver, a California-based surfwear chain, filed for bankruptcy, seeking a $175 million financing plan from Oaktree Capital Management LP to restructure. The company aims to retain its stores and has already begun discussing a management-led buyout. Quiksilver's sales declined 13% last year, and it listed $826 million in total debts and $337 million in assets. The bankruptcy plan requires court approval and will allow the chain to abandon costly leases, while its European and Asian operations remain unaffected.

site_title: Cisco Investments invests US$10m in S'pore venture capital firm Monk's Hill Ventures
summary: Cisco Investments has invested US$10 million in Singapore-based venture capital firm Monk's Hill Ventures, aiming to foster startups and drive innovation in the Asia-Pacific region, particularly in the areas of Internet of Everything, data analytics, and connected mobility. This investment will support local companies in innovating and generating economic growth, with Cisco also seeking to share technology and expertise with its investee companies.

site_title: Continuity is key in Potong Pasir: Sitoh
summary: PAP incumbent Sitoh Yih Pin emphasized the importance of continuity in Potong Pasir, saying he has no intention to replace or replicate the 27-year legacy of former MP Chiam See Tong. Sitoh outlined his 2015 manifesto, which includes 22 new projects and enhancements to amenities, such as expanded gyms and CCTV installations. He also highlighted his efforts to maintain the kampung spirit and community character of the estate through community events and initiatives. Sitoh clarified that while he received government funding, he also raised substantial sums of money on his own and had over 500 meetings with agencies to get things done.

images.alt_text: Mr Sitoh says he only asks pertinent and relevant questions in Parliament, focusing on issues that directly affect the lives of his Potong Pasir residents.

site_title: Default next move for oil is downwards, and here's why
summary: Oil prices are expected to drop, driven by factors such as overreaction to news and fear, rather than fundamental influences. The benchmark US oil, West Texas Intermediate (WTI), has formed a new range, with prices currently in the high US$40s. Traders are favoring short positions due to a closer, logical stop loss level and psychological factors, such as the desire to re-test and break through significant levels. While a significant shift in fundamentals could reverse the trend, the current market suggests a bias towards a short position, with prices potentially heading down to the US$30s.

site_title: Americans troubled by China ties, economy tops list: poll
summary: A recent Pew Research Center poll found that Americans are highly concerned about China's economic ties, with 89% viewing the US debt held by China as a very serious problem, and 86% concerned about the trade deficit. Other issues, such as cyberattacks and human rights, also received high levels of concern. Republican supporters expressed more worry about China than Democrats, particularly regarding the debt and trade deficit. The poll's findings come as US President Barack Obama prepares to receive Chinese President Xi Jinping for his first state visit.

site_title: Rallies in Japan, Dow futures boost STI
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) surged 1.5% on Wednesday, adding 42.86 points to finish at 2,928.18, following a 7.7% jump in Japan's Nikkei Average and a 4% rise in Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index. Dow futures also rose 180 points, boosting the index's two-day recovery to 76 points or 2.7%. The rally was driven by announcements from the Chinese Ministry of Finance and the World Bank, which warned against a US Federal Reserve rate hike in September.

images.alt_text: A 7.7 per cent jump in Japan's Nikkei Average after announcement of a cut in corporate tax, a 4 per cent jump in Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index and a 180-point rise in the Dow futures on Wednesday helped the Straits Times Index (STI) extend its rebound into a second consecutive day, this time adding 42.86 points or 1.5 per cent to finish at 2,928.18.

site_title: Companies need to innovate to disrupt tech disruption
summary: Disruptive technologies, such as the Internet of Things and analytics, are expected to reshape business models and operations, challenging traditional business models. Companies must innovate to disrupt themselves and survive. Experts predict that industries will shift from product-driven to service-driven, adopting disruptive innovation approaches and consuming services from each other. To capitalize on disruptions, companies are focusing on digital strategies, leveraging non-traditional disciplines, and developing proprietary initiatives. Successful companies will have a methodical approach to innovation, focusing on hunger to succeed, creativity, and quick learning.

site_title: ESM Goh urges cool heads before vote, national unity after
summary: Emeritus Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong urged Singaporeans to "cool heads" before the vote, focusing on national unity after the polls. He emphasized the importance of choosing the next leaders and maintaining unity. This comes as the country prepares for its election.

site_title: The longer she reigns, the less wealthy Queen Elizabeth II looks
summary: Queen Elizabeth II became the longest-reigning monarch in British history on September 9, 2015, but her wealth has diminished over the years. At the time of her ascension in 1952, she inherited one of the richest thrones, but the emergence of billionaire financiers, entrepreneurs, and oil-rich sheikhs has left her wealth relatively modest. Despite ruling over a period of unprecedented wealth creation, Queen Elizabeth II's personal wealth has decreased, with her now possessing palaces, stables, and an expensive stamp collection.

site_title: Instagram opens up to advertisers worldwide
summary: Instagram has opened its platform to most advertisers worldwide, allowing ads to debut in over 20 countries including Italy, Spain, and India. The move aims to increase ad revenue, which is projected to reach $1.5 billion in 2016 and nearly double by 2017. With 300 million monthly active users, Instagram's vast consumer data allows for targeted advertising, giving it an advantage over rivals like Snapchat. Users may rebel against the change, but advertisers see the platform as a key opportunity to tap its user base.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore banks are well-positioned for a rate environment of 26-28% upside, according to Morgan Stanley. The banks' net interest margins and lower credit risk compared to global peers make them attractive investments. DBS Group Holdings benefits from rising rates, while OCBC Bank's success in its wealth strategy could drive more upside. However, OCBC Bank and UOB face similar near-term risks. The report places Singapore banks in a global context, highlighting their relative advantages in a "Goldilocks scenario" where rates are not too high or too low.

site_title: Latest selldown could be buying point for Reits, say analysts
summary: Singapore-listed Reits and stapled trusts averaged a 5.9% negative total return in the year-to-date, underperforming the global benchmark. Despite this, their average price-to-book ratio of 0.9 suggests undervaluation. Analysts, including Deutsche Bank and UOB Kay Hian, have upgraded several Reits to "buy" or "overweight" after the latest selldown, citing strong yield support and undemanding valuation. They expect Reits to offer an attractive risk-reward proposition, even as growth slows.

site_title: PM eggs opposition on to show its report card too
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong urged the opposition to present its report card to the public, similar to the ruling People's Action Party (PAP), which has showcased its achievements in the last term. The PAP presented its report card, highlighting its progress in tackling difficult issues, and called for a fresh mandate. The PM questioned the Workers' Party's (WP) ability to govern, citing discrepancies between their campaign rhetoric and parliamentary actions. The WP responded by criticizing the PAP's economic policy and accusing it of ignoring the people.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Amazon takes over from Apple as biggest price prop on S&P
summary: Amazon has surpassed Apple as the largest price prop on the S&P 500 Index, contributing 67% to the index's gains this year. The online retailer's ascent is driven by its perceived haven status and lower exposure to global growth concerns. Amazon's stock has surged 24% following its surprise quarterly profit in July, while Apple's stock has tumbled amid concerns over iPhone demand in China. Despite this, over 80% of analysts have a buy rating for Amazon, with earnings projected to triple this year.

site_title: Indian minister reassures investors over tax concerns
summary: India's Finance Minister Arun Jaitley reassured investors on Wednesday about resolving tax concerns, promising to implement a Goods and Services Tax (GST) by next April 1. The government is pushing for investment to kickstart the sluggish economy, which has been affected by China's slowdown and global market turbulence. Jaitley also hinted at changing the composition of the Upper House, potentially tilting the balance of power in favor of the government, and vowed to resolve pending tax disputes.

site_title: US services data suggests 2nd-qtr GDP may be revised up
summary: US economic growth for the second quarter may be revised slightly higher after data showed a faster pace of consumer spending than previously estimated. The Commerce Department's quarterly services survey indicated a 3.6% annual rate, up at least 0.5 percentage points from the government's second estimate. This could lead to a revised GDP growth rate, potentially boosting the economy.

site_title: Car COE premiums largely flat as buyers stay away
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums for passenger cars remained flat in Wednesday's bidding exercise, with Category A falling S$352 to S$57,089 and Cat B slipping S$40 to S$62,101. Buyers stayed away due to the Hungry Ghost festival and believe premiums should be lower. Showroom traffic has been slow, and dealers speculate that the recent increase in COE premiums and the open bidding system are contributing to the stagnation. Buyers are waiting for a big drop, but it's unlikely in the short run, according to distributors.

images.alt_text: Crowds thronging Toyota's car showroom.

site_title: EIA leaves 2016 US crude output forecast unchanged, lowers 2015
summary: The US Energy Information Administration (EIA) left its 2016 US crude oil production forecast unchanged at 8.82 million barrels per day, but lowered its 2015 forecast to 500,000 bpd growth. The 2016 oil demand growth forecast was also lowered to 130,000 bpd. The EIA attributed the unchanged 2016 forecast to continued production declines in the US, despite a slight increase in production in the second quarter. The agency attributed the lowered 2015 forecast to slower production growth.

site_title: Job openings in US increased to 5.75 million in July
summary: US job openings surged to 5.75 million in July, a 430,000 increase from June, according to a Labor Department report. This marks a cooling in hiring pace. The July figure surpasses the previous record of 5.67 million set in June.

site_title: Europe: Stocks finish higher for third straight day
summary: Europe's main stock markets closed higher for a third consecutive day, with the FTSE 100 index rising 1.35% to 6,229.01 points. The eurozone's Frankfurt DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 also saw gains, rising 0.31% and 1.44% respectively. The rally was driven by gains in mining and healthcare stocks, with US-EU trade talks also in focus.

site_title: Soccer: Prince Ali says will stand again for Fifa presidency
summary: Prince Ali Bin Al Hussein of Jordan has announced his candidacy for FIFA president for the second time, four months after losing the May vote to Sepp Blatter. He is the third heavyweight to declare, following UEFA chief Michel Platini and former Asia vice-president Chung Mong-joon. Prince Ali, 39, plans to run again for the top job at world soccer's governing body.

site_title: Bank of England to raise rates in Q1 2016, following US Fed: Reuters poll
summary: The Bank of England is expected to raise interest rates in Q1 2016, likely following the US Federal Reserve's move, according to a Reuters poll. The central bank is predicted to increase the bank rate by 25 basis points to 0.75% before April. Economists believe the UK economy will grow at a rate of 0.6% per quarter until mid-2016, then dip to 0.5% for the last two quarters. Inflation is expected to pick up but not reach the 2% target until 2017, with wage growth expected to outstrip price rises.

site_title: Citi banker used M&A deal to manipulate market, former FX trader tells court
summary: A former Citigroup FX trader, Perry Stimpson, testified in a London court that senior investment bankers prioritized the bank's interests over clients, engaging in "front running" before a major 2010 M&A deal. Stimpson claimed the deal involved foreign currency trading handled by Jeff Feig, contravening the bank's code of conduct. Stimpson is representing himself in an employment tribunal, alleging unfair dismissal.

site_title: GE2015: PAP's Tin Pei Ling spells out hopes for ward and country
summary: Tin Pei Ling, a People's Action Party (PAP) candidate, delivered her speech in the MacPherson SMC, outlining plans to support young families, improve the education system, and provide support for low-income families and children. She also criticized opposition party proposals, suggesting they prioritize spending without considering the burden on future generations. Her opponents include Bernard Chen from the Workers' Party and Cheo Chai Chen from the National Solidarity Party.

site_title: Malaysia ruling party closes ranks behind Najib after meeting
summary: Malaysia's ruling party, the United Malays National Organisation (UMNO), has closed ranks behind Prime Minister Najib Razak after a meeting of its supreme council. Former deputy premier Muhyiddin Yassin pledged loyalty to Najib amid a funding scandal surrounding 1Malaysia Development Bhd. Najib has denied receiving billions of ringgit linked to 1MDB in his private accounts. The move aims to unite the party and ensure a victory in the next national election for the broader Barisan Nasional coalition.

site_title: Low oil price could force 140 North Sea oil fields to close
summary: A report by Wood Mackenzie warns that low oil prices could force the closure of around 140 North Sea oil fields in the next five years, making them economically unviable even at $85 per barrel. The current price of around $50 per barrel has highlighted the unsustainable nature of maintaining these fields. The consultancy also predicts that 38 new North Sea fields expected to open in the next five years may be postponed or cancelled due to the high costs of recovering oil from the extreme depth of the North Sea deposits.

site_title: China Kunda scraps collaboration MOU with COO's nephew
summary: China Kunda Technology Holdings scrapped a non-binding agreement for strategic collaboration with Yang Jincheng, the nephew of its COO, after four months. The deal aimed to collaborate on business and investment projects, with China Kunda holding majority stakes. The company will continue to assess new opportunities and potential acquisitions. The move comes after China Kunda's original two-year deadline to achieve profitability was extended to September 1, 2016.

site_title: Lufthansa Aug traffic up 4.5%
summary: Lufthansa reported a 4.5% increase in August sales, with revenue seat kilometres rising by the same amount and load factor increasing 1.2 percentage points to 87.6%. However, pricing remained under pressure, and Lufthansa Cargo saw a 4.4% drop in volumes. The airline's positive summer trading echoes other carriers' comments, suggesting a strong summer season for the industry.

site_title: S&P follows Moody's in cutting Asian forecasts on China fears
summary: Standard & Poor's cut its growth forecasts for Asian economies, citing "abysmal" trade data and fears about China's market stability. The region is now expected to grow 5.4% in 2015, down from 5.5% previously, with Indonesia, the Philippines, Singapore, Taiwan, and Thailand being the hardest hit. The downgrade also predicts currency weakness and "slower growth, higher volatility, and more risks" in the region.

site_title: UK growth slowed in three months to August: NIESR
summary: The UK economy likely slowed in the three months to August, with growth estimated at 0.5% compared to 0.6% in the previous quarter. Industrial output contracted in July, mainly due to a summer shutdown of auto plants. The National Institute of Economic and Social Research (NIESR) stated that growth remains close to the economy's long-run potential but below the average rate of 0.7% per quarter since 2013. This marks a fresh blow to the UK economy under Prime Minister Starmer.

site_title: Lufthansa mulls further damages claim over pilot strikes
summary: Lufthansa is considering expanding its damages claim against pilots' union Vereinigung Cockpit, following a labour court ruling that ordered the pilots to stop striking. The airline initially claimed 60 million euros in costs from a strike in April 2014, targeting its Cargo unit, which had a valid pay agreement. The court's ruling strengthened Lufthansa's position, but the airline is now examining whether to expand its claim further.

site_title: Amid the hustings, an urgent call to renew Singapore's leadership
summary: In Singapore's election campaign, the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) has emphasized that voters are choosing not only the party's leaders but also the leaders who will govern for the next 15-20 years. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that every vote for the 89 PAP candidates is also a vote for him. This approach aims to build a long-term relationship between the government and its people, with the party's leaders working together for the country's future.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: CDLHT makes first hotel acquisition in UK
summary: CDL Hospitality Trust (CDLHT) has acquired Cambridge City Hotel in the UK for £61.5 million, marking its maiden entry into Europe. The acquisition is part of the trust's strategy to invest in markets with growth potential. The hotel offers 198 rooms and a prime location in the city centre, with CDLHT expecting constrained supply and new demand growth drivers to support the property's medium-term prospects. The acquisition is expected to be fully funded by British pound-denominated debt and will strengthen CDLHT's portfolio and income.

images.alt_text: An executive suite and meeting room of the Cambridge City Hotel. The newly-refurbished upscale hotel offers 198 rooms and a comprehensive suite of facilities. It enjoys a prime location in the city centre, adjacent to Grand Arcade Shopping Centre - the principal shopping mall in Cambridge.

An executive suite and meeting room of the Cambridge City Hotel. The newly-refurbished upscale hotel offers 198 rooms and a comprehensive suite of facilities. It enjoys a prime location in the city centre, adjacent to Grand Arcade Shopping Centre - the principal shopping mall in Cambridge.

site_title: China Sky seeks to resume trading on Thursday after 4-year suspension
summary: China Sky Chemical Fibre Co, a maker of fibres, is seeking to resume trading on the Singapore Exchange after a four-year suspension. The company has met the conditions set by the regulator, including the appointment of a compliance officer and internal auditor. The suspension was imposed in 2011 amid investigations into major transactions, including a botched land purchase in China. Former CEO Huang Zhong Xuan has been fined S$2.5 million for misleading statements. Trading is expected to resume on Thursday.

site_title: US: Wall St adds to gains after Nikkei surge
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 142.28 points (0.86%) to 16,634.96, the S&P 500 gaining 15.34 (0.78%) to 1,984.75, and the Nasdaq Composite Index rising 45.60 (0.95%) to 4,857.53. The gains followed a 7.7% surge in Japan's Nikkei index. Despite ongoing US-China trade tensions, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records, with investors seemingly brushing off recent Trump threats.

site_title: Sensory indulgence
summary: A Singapore-themed showcase, "Inside Out," is taking place in Madison Square Park, featuring edible art installations, live music, and performances. Pastry chef Janice Wong will create a ceiling full of lollipops, while restaurants like The Meatball Shop and Shake Shack will serve Singapore-inspired dishes. The event also includes sound installations, live painting, and a dance performance. Additionally, the La Mama Experimental Theatre Club will stage a few plays as part of the Something To Write Home About arts festival. The event runs from September 18 to 27.

images.alt_text: Pastry chef Janice Wong's edible art installation at the "Singapore: Inside Out" will feature a ceiling full of lollipops, gumdrop walls and chocolate-coated poles
In the art segment at the Manhattan event, Jason Lim will carry out a durational performance over five days in a work about time and memory

site_title: Lufthansa wins court ruling to halt pilot strike in pay dispute
summary: A German court has ruled in favor of Lufthansa, halting a planned pilot strike over a pay dispute. The strike, which was set to affect over 1,000 flights, has been canceled due to the court's injunction. The Vereinigung Cockpit pilots' union had argued that the airline's decision to create a low-cost unit was a disproportionate protest, but the court rejected this claim. The ruling reverses an initial decision, allowing Lufthansa to maintain its services and operations.

site_title: China Premier says economic prospects positive, to maintain policy direction
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang stated that China's economy remains on a "reasonable track" despite downward pressure, with over 7 million new urban jobs created and an unemployment rate of 5.1%. The economy grew 7% in the first half of 2015, meeting the government's target. Li pledged to maintain basic policy direction while making pre-emptive adjustments, focusing on structural reforms and targeted regulatory measures.

site_title: WP stacks its credibility, renewal against PAP
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) is fielding 28 candidates in the Singapore General Election, positioning itself as the de facto leader of the Opposition. The WP faces a close contest in the East Coast GRC, with the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) also contesting the area. The WP's credibility is under scrutiny due to financial issues at the Aljunied-Hougang-Punggol East Town Council, which was highlighted in an Auditor-General's report. The WP aims to prove its ability to provide rational alternatives to PAP policies and manage public monies effectively.

site_title: GE2015: Reform Party cancels one of its two rallies on last day of campaigning
summary: The Reform Party in Singapore cancelled one of its election rallies on the last day of campaigning due to police intervention, citing concerns about public safety. The cancelled rally was scheduled to take place at Delta Hockey Pitch on September 9, 2015.

images.alt_text: The Reform Party has cancelled one of its two scheduled election rallies on the last day of campaigning.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Wednesday
summary: Singapore's COE prices remained flat in September's bidding exercise due to buyer expectations of lower premiums. Private condo and apartment rents fell 0.4% in August, while the outlook for small and medium-sized enterprises in Singapore reached a three-year low. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 1.5% higher, rebounding from recent losses, after Japan's Nikkei Average surged 7.7% and Dow futures jumped 180 points. Meanwhile, Malaysia's May industrial production rose 0.3%, below forecast, and the country's agency is set to seize about RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets.

site_title: Central banks to create full global FX code by May 2017
summary: A committee of major central banks aims to complete the first full global code of conduct for the foreign exchange market by May 2017. The code will address issues such as time-stamping, stop loss orders, and market-making practices. The task is seen as a significant rebuilding of confidence in the market, which has been marred by scandals. The Bank for International Settlements' Markets Committee will devise a way to enforce the code, with Deputy Governor Guy Debelle stating that the goal is to build on existing systems rather than reinventing them.

site_title: French PM says labour law to be revamped, simplified
summary: French Prime Minister Manuel Valls announced plans to simplify the country's complex labour laws, aiming to promote collective bargaining at a sectoral level. Draft legislation will be proposed by year-end, with the goal of reducing the number of sectors where negotiations apply from 750 to 100. The reform will not alter the 35-hour workweek, but will aim to slim down unwieldy laws and give more room for collective bargaining. The proposal is expected to be adopted by parliament by summer 2016.

site_title: 'Handful' of individuals behind bulk of IHC trading since April: SGX
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) revealed that a "handful" of individuals connected to one another have dominated over 60% of International Healthway Corp (IHC) trades since April 2015. The SGX is working with regulatory agencies and urged investors to exercise caution. IHC shares have remained steady, closing at 31.5 Singapore cents, while Healthway Medical Corp shares closed at 5.6 Singapore cents after IHC announced a share swap to acquire HMC.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 16.24 points to close at 1,603.36, driven by 666 gains and 228 losses. The index saw 2.56 billion lots traded, valued at RM2.42 billion.

site_title: China, Pakistan set to sign economic zone deal: officials
summary: China and Pakistan are set to sign a 40-year lease agreement with a Chinese company to develop a special economic zone in Gwadar, Pakistan. The 923-hectare land will be leased to China Overseas Port Holding Company for infrastructure, energy, and transport projects as part of the $46 billion China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC) plan. The contract is expected to be signed in September or October, according to Pakistani officials.

site_title: India govt retreats on parliament plan for vital tax measure
summary: India's government has abandoned plans to reconvene parliament to pass a common goods and services tax, citing a lack of political support. The decision comes despite Prime Minister Narendra Modi's assurances that the economy can withstand global market turbulence. The tax reform, which aims to replace multiple levies and boost economic growth, now faces uncertainty, with economists warning of potential losses to India's GDP. The government had set a deadline of April 2016 for the tax measure, but it will now have to reassess its timeline.

site_title: Apple to show off new iPhones, Apple TV on Wednesday
summary: Apple is set to unveil new iPhones, an updated Apple TV, and a larger iPad at an event in San Francisco on Wednesday. The new iPhones are expected to feature improved cameras and Force Touch, with no significant size change. Analysts predict Apple TV will be upgraded with a new user interface and a focus on streaming media, while the iPad may appeal to professionals with a larger screen. Despite potential upgrades, some investors and consumers may be underwhelmed by the changes, which may not be enough to offset declining interest in the iPad.

images.alt_text: Apple Inc is selling bonds in euros for the second time, extending a $53 billion debt binge since 2013, as it raises funds to buy back shares and locks in borrowing costs near record lows.

site_title: Malaysia's 1MDB slams WSJ's use of confidential documents
summary: Malaysia's 1MDB has criticized the Wall Street Journal for using confidential documents from a parliamentary committee probe into the company. 1MDB claims the WSJ reviewed a transcript from the Public Accounts Committee hearings, which is not allowed under Malaysian Parliament's Standing Orders. 1MDB stated that the publication of such information is a breach of confidentiality.

site_title: China to step up fiscal incentives to boost growth
summary: China plans to adopt stronger fiscal policies to boost growth amid concerns about its economy, following turmoil in domestic and overseas markets. The government will accelerate major construction projects, expand tax cuts for small companies, and encourage private investment in key areas. This move aims to soothe fears about China's slowing growth, which has been a key driver of global expansion. The measures are expected to provide relief to global markets, which have been impacted by China's economic concerns.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher after rallies in Japan, China and Dow futures
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.5% to 2,928.18 after Japan's Nikkei Average jumped 7.7% on a corporate tax cut, and Dow futures surged 180 points. This marks the second consecutive day of recovery, adding 76 points to its two-day total. Volume reached 1.33 billion units worth S$1.24 billion.

site_title: Greek deflation slows in August, prices fall for 30th month
summary: Greece's EU-harmonised deflation rate eased in August, with prices falling 0.4% compared to a 1.3% drop in July. The headline consumer price index fell 1.5% year-on-year, slowing deflation from the previous month. This marks the 30th consecutive month of deflation in Greece, largely due to wage and pension cuts and a deep recession.

site_title: Asian currencies rebound as global stocks rally boosts sentiment
summary: Asian currencies, including the Malaysian ringgit and Indonesia's rupiah, rebounded from 17-year lows as global stocks rallied, boosting sentiment. China's shares recovered, and central bank Governor Zhou Xiaochuan's comments indicated a rout in the nation's stocks is almost over. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index dropped 0.4%, and the MSCI Asia-Pacific Index rose 4.4%, its biggest gain since 2009. This led to a 1% rise in South Korea's won and a 0.2% advance in the ringgit and India's rupee.

site_title: CDL Hospitality Trust acquires UK hotel for £62.5m
summary: CDL Hospitality Trust has acquired the Cambridge City Hotel in the UK for £62.5 million, marking its maiden entry into Europe. The hotel will be renamed CDL HBT Cambridge City Hotel (UK) Ltd and continue to operate under the same ownership. The acquisition is part of the trust's expansion plans, with the consideration including £61.5 million for the property and £1 million for the target company's net working capital and cash.

site_title: Greece must respect bailout, or EU reaction will be "different": Juncker
summary: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker warned Greece's new government that respecting the bailout agreement is crucial, or the EU's stance on keeping Greece in the single currency bloc could change. Juncker stated that Grexit is not an option and emphasized the importance of respecting the agreed-upon program. If the rules are not respected, the EU's reaction will be "different."

site_title: Indonesia president unveils economic stimulus moves
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo unveiled a stimulus package to support the rupiah and boost growth, aiming to restore investor confidence. The package includes extending a rice subsidy for the poor and simplifying 89 regulations. The government plans to complete deregulation steps by October. The measures are part of efforts to stabilize the economy, which has been affected by a weak rupiah and declining investor confidence.

site_title: Singtel partners top telcos to ramp up startup ecosystem
summary: Singtel's startup arm, Innov8, partnered with top telcos Orange, Deutsche Telekom, and Telefónica to create a unified startup ecosystem across South-east Asia, Africa, Europe, Latin America, and the Middle East. The partnership aims to support eligible startups by providing market insights, networking opportunities, and access to the collective mobile customer base of over 1 billion people. Innov8, with a US$250 million fund, will facilitate the growth of selected startups beyond their home markets, leveraging the resources and networks of the four leading communications companies.

site_title: EU squeezed US$7.8b Greek bridge loan via ESM loophole
summary: The European Union (EU) used a loophole in the European Stability Mechanism (ESM) to provide a $7.8 billion bridge loan to Greece in July 2015. The ESM, which was barred from lending directly to Greece, financed the loan through a private placement, with Greece paying it back in August after receiving its bailout approval. This unconventional arrangement allowed the EU to keep the transaction quiet and avoid breaking rules shielding taxpayers from losses. The ESM's investment strategy focuses on capital preservation and only invests in high-quality assets, making the transaction fully compliant with its guidelines.

site_title: Gold holds near 3-week low as stocks gain, India taps idle metal
summary: Gold prices held near a three-week low as global stocks rose, reducing demand for a safe-haven metal. Indian authorities approved a plan to tap the country's bullion reserves to reduce imports. The Asian stock market surge, particularly in Japan, is seen as bad news for gold, with investors cutting holdings in gold-backed funds.

site_title: Companies in Europe boost long-dated debt to lock in low rates
summary: Companies in Europe have increased long-term debt to 225 billion euros, the most in annualized data since 1999, as they seek to lock in low borrowing costs. This year's bond sales account for 36% of all investment-grade notes, with insurance companies leading purchases. The growing economy and increasing inflationary pressure may narrow the window of opportunity for borrowers, but many companies are taking advantage of cheap financing costs, with some selling bonds due in as much as 60 years.

site_title: Hong Kong dollar peg shows strain caught between Fed and PBOC
summary: Hong Kong's 32-year-old currency peg is under strain due to the US Federal Reserve's tightening monetary policy and China's economic slowdown. The linked exchange rate, pegged to the US dollar, forces Hong Kong to follow the US in raising interest rates, despite the city's economic challenges. The peg's resilience has been tested by China's slowest growth since 1990, which is fueling public discontent and weakening the city's competitiveness. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has pledged to maintain the stability of the local currency, but economists warn that the peg may become unsustainable if the US raises interest rates.

site_title: Singapore's key short-term interest rate hits 7-year high
summary: Singapore's key short-term interest rate rose to 1.07508% on Wednesday, its highest level since 2008. The Singapore dollar hit a six-year low against the US dollar earlier in the week, sparking concerns of a possible rise in US interest rates. Investors are seeking higher yields as compensation for holding the weakening currency. The central bank's monetary policy focuses on managing the exchange rate, rather than interest rates, due to the city-state's trade-reliant economy. A possible recession and further central bank easing are also seen as potential headwinds for the Singapore dollar.

site_title: Car COE premiums flat
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums for passenger cars remained flat in Wednesday's bidding exercise, with Category A prices dropping to S$57,089 and Category B prices falling to S$62,101. The Hungry Ghost month and expectations of lower premiums contributed to the flat COE prices. Category C, D, and E saw price increases, with Cat C rising S$300 to S$46,801 and Cat D climbing S$400 to S$6,512.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares have biggest one-day gain since December 2011
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose sharply on Wednesday, posting their biggest one-day percentage gain in nearly four years, with the Hang Seng index rising 4.1% to 22,131.31. This followed a second consecutive day of gains, driven by low valuations and signs that China's efforts to stem mainland stock slides are paying off. Analysts attribute the rebound to short-sellers covering positions and investor sentiment. The rebound also saw Hong Kong-based companies such as Cheung Kong Infrastructure Holdings and Power Assets Holdings surge.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks ended barely changed on Thursday, as most Asian markets stabilised after jitters over Turkey's downing of a Russian fighter jet abated.

site_title: Seoul: Shares post best day in nearly 4 years; won gains
summary: South Korean shares experienced their largest daily gain in nearly four years, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) rising 3% to 1,934.19 points. The gain followed a three-day decline and came as risk appetites recovered following sharp rises in Wall Street and Europe. Foreigners initially bought shares but then turned to selling for a 25th consecutive session, contributing to the market's rally.

site_title: Maersk Oil cuts US$1b from investment budget as prices fall
summary: Maersk Oil cuts its annual investment budget by $1 billion due to a 50% drop in crude prices over the past year. The company now forecasts capital expenditures of $2-4 billion per year, with a focus on acquisitions in 2015 and 2016 to replace reserves. Maersk Oil has also reduced unit costs by 33% and completed 600 job cuts. The company expects oil prices to remain stable in the short term before rising due to Chinese demand and OPEC responses. This move follows the industry's trend of cutting jobs and investments.

images.alt_text: AP Moeller-Maersk A/S's oil unit cut US$1 billion off its annual budget for capital expenditure after petroleum prices plunged.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise, lifted by Ryanair after profit forecast hike
summary: European shares rose on Wednesday, driven by a 10% surge in Ryanair's shares after the airline lifted its full-year profit forecast by 25%. Ryanair's summer performance was boosted by bad weather in northern Europe and the strength of the British pound. The FTSEurofirst 300 index rose 2.1% to 1,444.61 points, marking its third consecutive session of gains.

site_title: Singapore remains top meeting and convention city in 2014
summary: Singapore remains the top international meeting city in the Union of International Associations 2014 rankings for the eighth consecutive year. It was also third in the top international meeting countries category and the only Asia-Pacific city to make the top 10 of the International Congress and Convention Association's rankings. The Singapore Tourism Board will continue to enhance the country's Meetings, Incentive Travel, Conventions and Exhibitions (MICE) ecosystem to drive its development in the coming years.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: UK factory output unexpectedly drops while exports slump
summary: The UK's factory output unexpectedly declined 0.4% in July, with exports falling 9.2% - the largest drop in nine years. Manufacturing output dropped 0.8%, and the goods trade deficit widened to £11.1 billion, exceeding forecasts. The decline in industrial output was attributed to summer shutdowns at auto factories and a drop in weapons manufacturing. The data may reinforce expectations that the Bank of England will keep interest rates at a record low.

site_title: China changes GDP data calculation method to improve accuracy
summary: China's National Bureau of Statistics has changed its method for calculating quarterly GDP data to improve accuracy, adopting international standards. The move aims to address concerns over the reliability of Chinese economic data, particularly in relation to growth rates. The new methodology, set to be implemented starting with third-quarter data, will provide more accurate measures of seasonal economic activity and short-term fluctuations. This change is expected to pave the way for China to adopt the International Monetary Fund's Special Data Dissemination Standard for calculating GDP.

site_title: Tech world waits for iPhone news and hopes for magic
summary: The tech world is awaiting Apple's upcoming media event in San Francisco, where new iPhone versions and an updated Apple TV are expected. Analysts predict Apple will unveil innovative features, possibly pushing into the online television streaming sector. The company's silence has fueled speculation, with some hoping for unexpected innovations. The event is seen as a significant moment for the tech industry, with many eyes on Apple's potential moves.

site_title: Dennis Yeo joins CBRE as regional head of industrial and logistic services in Asia
summary: Dennis Yeo, a property veteran, has joined CBRE as regional head of industrial and logistics services in Asia, effective September 8. He resigned from Colliers International, where he was managing director for Singapore, to take on the senior regional position. Based in Singapore, Yeo will work closely with CBRE's industrial and logistics teams across the region, aiming to build the property consultancy's industrial and logistics platform.

site_title: EU unveils 'bold' migrant crisis plan
summary: EU Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker unveiled a 'bold' plan to address the continent's worst refugee crisis in 70 years, sharing 120,000 refugees across the bloc from swamped border states. The plan includes binding quotas and a more permanent system. Australia has also pledged to take more refugees, responding to Europe's calls for international help. The crisis is expected to last for years, with officials seeking a long-term solution.

site_title: Singapore's SME outlook hits three-year low: survey
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) face a three-year low outlook due to weaker sales and profit forecasts, according to a survey. The SBF-DP SME Index, measuring business sentiment for the next six months, has fallen to its lowest level since 2013. The three key sectors of commerce and trading, construction and engineering, and manufacturing recorded significant declines in business outlooks. The weak outlook could lead to lower job creation and impact the Singapore economy, particularly SMEs, which contribute 70% of jobs. The decline is attributed to global demand, commodity prices, and the strong Singapore dollar.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: India finance minister reassures investors with promise to end tax battles
summary: India's finance minister, Arun Jaitley, has reassured investors that the government will resolve tax disputes and implement a Goods and Services Tax (GST) by next April, aiming to boost economic growth. Jaitley also expressed urgency to kickstart the sluggish economy, which has been affected by global market turbulence and China's slowdown. The government has been pushing for trade protection and lower interest rates to stimulate growth, but investors have been demanding action on these issues. Jaitley's comments come as India's economy remains sluggish despite official growth figures.

site_title: EU looks to October talks to advance bid for US trade dea
summary: The European Union and US are set to meet in October as part of negotiations for a Trans-Atlantic Trade and Investment Partnership, with a goal of completing the deal by the end of 2016. EU chief negotiator Ignacio Garcia Bercero expressed optimism that the deal can be brought forward to a political conclusion by the end of next year, prioritizing market access in key areas such as tariffs, procurement, services, and agriculture. Two additional rounds of talks are planned, one in December or January.

site_title: Update: Netflix sets sights on Hong Kong, three other Asian markets
summary: Netflix plans to expand into Hong Kong, Taiwan, Singapore, and South Korea early next year, following its recent entry into Japan. The company will initially stream popular TV shows, movies, and kid-friendly content with local subtitles. This move aims to complete its global rollout by the end of next year, as it seeks to diversify revenue sources beyond the US market. Netflix faces competition from local streaming services in these markets, including Tencent Holdings' Tmall Box Office in China.

site_title: GE2015: WP team, if elected, hopes to retain East Coast Town Council's managing agent, says Gerald Giam
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) team contesting the East Coast Group Representation Council (GRC) in Singapore's 2015 general election plans to retain the East Coast Town Council's managing agent if elected. If the existing agent, EM Services, decides not to continue, the WP will seek a smooth handover or consider direct management to prevent disruptions. Team leader Gerald Giam emphasized the importance of continuity in services to residents.

site_title: Alibaba gets in the game with new sports company
summary: Chinese online giant Alibaba has established Alibaba Sports Group, a new company focused on professional sports, leveraging its e-commerce ecosystem to participate in sports media, events, and ticketing. The venture aims to "transform the China sports industry" and bring better products and services to consumers and sports fans. Alibaba CEO Daniel Zhang will be chairman of the new company, with partners including Yunfeng Capital and Sina, operator of Weibo. This move expands Alibaba's foray into sports, following its earlier investment in Chinese football club Guangzhou Evergrande.

site_title: Netflix to launch in Singapore early 2016
summary: Netflix announced its plans to launch services in Singapore early 2016, with the office serving as the hub for its expanding operations in Asia. The streaming service will offer a curated selection of popular TV shows and movies in high-definition or Ultra HD 4K on various devices, including smart TVs, tablets, and smartphones. Younger viewers will also have access to a wide range of kid-friendly programming. The launch is part of Netflix's global rollout, which is expected to be completed by end-2016.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Launch of ICE's Singapore platform set for Nov 17
summary: ICE is set to launch its Singapore platform, ICE Futures Singapore and ICE Clear Singapore, on November 17, subject to final approval by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). The platform will offer five new contracts, including mini Brent and gasoil futures, kilo gold futures, and renminbi futures. ICE Futures Singapore will provide efficient trading and clearing services, while ICE Trade Vault, LLC has submitted a foreign trade repository application to MAS to support market participants' compliance with regulatory reform.

site_title: Mahathir returns to Malaysia ready for probe over anti-Najib comments
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad returned home on Wednesday, stating he would cooperate with any police investigation into his anti-Najib Razak comments at an anti-government rally. Mahathir led calls for Najib's resignation over alleged mismanagement and corruption at 1MDB, sparking concerns of a party split and investor uncertainty. The 90-year-old leader joined a two-day rally in Kuala Lumpur, calling Najib a corrupt leader, and warned he would comply with any investigation, despite fears of arrest. Najib faces a major crisis amid media reports of a mysterious $600 million transfer into his account.

site_title: Instagram steps up advertising effort, adds 30 markets
summary: Instagram expands its advertising efforts, opening up global marketing campaigns to large and small advertisers. The platform will allow for video ads of up to 30 seconds in 30 new markets, including Italy, Spain, and South Korea. This expansion aims to increase revenue and follows the launch of new formats, such as portrait and landscape images, which have opened up new possibilities for advertisers. The move could help Instagram generate 14% of mobile ad revenue for Facebook by 2017, with projected earnings of $2.8 billion.

site_title: Lufthansa pilots strike for second day, 1,000 flights cancelled
summary: Lufthansa pilots went on strike for a second day, cancelling around 1,000 flights and affecting 140,000 passengers. The strike is over cost cutting, retirement benefits, and pay, with the pilots demanding a halt to expansion of low-cost operations. Courts ruled in favor of the pilots' union, and management has refused to improve its offer. The strike could continue if no new offer is made, with the pilots warning of further strikes without notice.

site_title: IEA seeks China's cooperation on emergency oil stockpile use
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) has sought cooperation from China to use its emergency oil stockpiles in the event of a global crisis. IEA Executive Director Fatih Birol stated that China, as the largest player in the global energy market, should be a full participant in securing supplies. China has accumulated 49 million barrels of crude and plans to expand its stockpiles to 50 million barrels. The IEA aims to coordinate with China for a joint emergency response exercise and to make room for China under the IEA umbrella to effectively manage global supply disruptions.

site_title: GE2015: ESM Goh urges country to vote carefully, rebuild consensus after polls
summary: Emeritus Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong urged Singaporeans to vote carefully and rebuild national consensus after the upcoming General Election. He emphasized the importance of maintaining unity and getting people to focus on the day after the polls. Goh shared his experience on past elections, comparing the voting community to a piece of fabric that different parties tug at. He stressed the need to tone down conflicts after the polls and rebuild consensus, which typically takes about a year.

images.alt_text: Emeritus Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong put on the elder statesman hat on the last day of electoral campaigning on Wednesday as he reflected on the importance of choosing the next set of leaders and on maintaining unity after the polls.

site_title: Greece to look at recapitalising banks after election
summary: Greece plans to set up a working group with its "troika" creditors to explore ways of supporting its fragile banking system. The group will include experts and representatives from the EU, ECB, and IMF. The goal is to establish a framework for bank recapitalization by September 20, allowing the new government to make informed decisions. Greece has set aside 25 billion euros under the latest aid plan for bank recapitalization, although this amount could change depending on stress tests carried out by the ECB this month.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei soars 7.71% in biggest one-day jump since 2008 financial crisis
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei-225 index surged 7.71% to 18,770.51, its largest one-day jump since 2008, amid an Asian equities rally. The Nikkei-225 gained 1,343.43 points, while the broader Topix index rose 6.40%. The rally follows a global equities rally, with US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: ABN Amro raises financial targets, awaits IPO green light
summary: ABN Amro has raised its financial targets for 2017, citing a recovering economy and its desire to return to private hands. The bank aims to achieve a Tier 1 capital adequacy ratio of at least 11.5%, a cost-income ratio of less than 60%, and a return on equity of at least 10%. These targets are more reflective of reality than ambition, as the bank has already surpassed many of these measures in previous quarters. The bank's efforts are part of its efforts to prepare for an initial public offering (IPO) as soon as possible.

site_title: Australia: Shares gain the most in over 2 weeks
summary: Australian shares rose 2.07% to 5,221.1, the largest daily gain in over two weeks, with banks and miners leading the way. This follows a 1.7% gain on Tuesday. New Zealand's benchmark NZX 50 index also rose 1.09%. The gains were attributed to investors' hopes that Beijing's efforts to stabilize its stock markets are paying off.

images.alt_text: Australian shares posted solid gains for the second straight day on Wednesday, with banks and miners leading the way as investors hoped Beijing's efforts to stabilise its ailing stock markets were starting to pay off.

site_title: Asian currencies rebound as global stocks rally boosts sentiment
summary: Global stocks rallied, boosting sentiment and driving demand for Asian currencies. The Malaysian ringgit and Indonesia's rupiah rose from 17-year lows, while the Malaysian won advanced from a five-year low and the Thai baht rallied. A rebound in Chinese shares and comments from Chinese central bank Governor Zhou Xiaochuan helped reduce appetite for the dollar, leading to a 0.4% drop in the Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index. The Bloomberg Commodity Index rose 1.4% as Brent crude extended its rebound.

site_title: Seoul: Shares gain 2 per cent; tracking Wall Street, Europe rallies
summary: Seoul shares rose 2% on Wednesday, tracking Wall Street and European rallies, as risk sentiment improved. China's import data showed a larger-than-expected decline, while exports fell less than expected, sparking hopes for additional stimulus. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index gained 2% to 1,916.52 points, with winners outnumbering losers 8 to 1, breaking a three-day losing streak.

site_title: CapitaGreen hits 83 per cent occupancy
summary: CapitaGreen, a 40-storey Grade A office tower in Singapore, has reached 83% occupancy with 30 multinational companies occupying the building. The tenants include Bordier & Cie, Cargill, and Lloyds Banking Group, among others. The building's sustainable design principles have attracted tenants who are also committed to environmental sustainability. Developed by CapitaLand, CapitaLand Commercial Trust, and Mitsubishi Estate Asia, CapitaGreen was granted a Temporary Occupation Permit in December 2014.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Facebook business pages closer to becoming online shops
summary: Facebook has introduced features to its business pages, making them closer to online shops. The changes include customized layouts, mobile-friendly designs, and sections for showcasing merchandise or services. Business pages can now feature a services menu, products, and allow customers to book appointments or browse. The updates aim to make it easier for businesses to highlight information and reach their goals, as well as facilitate exchanges with customers. The new features are intended to simplify online shopping experiences on Facebook.

site_title: China yuan shock threatens triple whammy for Asian exporters
summary: China's yuan devaluation has worsened the outlook for Asian exporters, particularly those with high exposure to the Chinese market. The devaluation has eliminated the dollar link that had kept the yuan strong, making it harder for Asian countries to compete with China. Taiwan, South Korea, and Malaysia are among the most vulnerable economies, with exports to China plummeting 14.8%, 14.7%, and 13.8% respectively in August. The shift by China to higher-value-added industries also increases the risk of increased competition and deflationary pressures for Asian exporters.

site_title: Pavilion Energy to start small-scale LNG business in South-east Asia
summary: Pavilion Energy plans to launch a small-scale liquefied natural gas (LNG) business in South-east Asia, targeting markets in Indonesia and the Philippines. The company's CEO, Seah Moon Ming, cited a trend towards small-scale LNG solutions, with 65% of recent contracts signed for volumes below one million tonnes per year. Pavilion Energy will use small vessels to deliver LNG to remote islands, and has previously secured LNG supply from the US and signed portfolio LNG supply contracts. The move aims to provide power solutions to islands in the region.

site_title: Dubai property developers upbeat despite falling prices
summary: Dubai property developers remain optimistic despite falling property prices, with forecasts predicting a 15% decline this year. Despite this, developers are unveiling large-scale projects, including a new indoor ski slope and skyscrapers. Analysts attribute the decline to global economic factors, such as falling oil prices and the Chinese economy's slowdown. Regulations, including mortgage caps, have helped stabilize the market, and developers expect a rebound in mid-2016. Over 40,000 units have been announced this year, with 20,000 expected to be delivered by 2017.

site_title: Oil markets rise as Asian stock markets catch a tailwind
summary: Crude oil prices rose 23 cents to $49.75 per barrel, driven by a strong performance in US and European markets. Asian shares gained after upbeat German economic data, influencing oil markets. Despite gains, concerns remain about global oversupply and slowing demand, particularly in the US. Opec production remains near record highs, with Indonesia set to rejoin the group, adding 3% to Opec's output. Oil prices have fallen 60% since June 2014 due to a global supply glut.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally after open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.66% on Wednesday, following a strong lead from Wall Street, as investor fears over China eased. The Hang Seng Index climbed to 21,612.6, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.38%. This is the second consecutive day of gains, reflecting a regional advance.

site_title: Bangkok suspect handed device to shrine bomber: police
summary: A Thai suspect, Yusufu Mieraili, has confessed to playing a central role in the August 17 Bangkok blast that killed 20 people, mostly ethnic Chinese tourists. Mieraili, 25, handed a backpack bomb to a man in a yellow T-shirt, who later placed it at a shrine, moments before the blast. The suspect's motive remains unclear, but he has been charged with involvement in the deadly attack.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Wednesday, rising 12.17 points to 1597.90. The index saw 164 gainers and 26 losers, with a trading volume of 35.8 million lots worth RM15.7 million.

site_title: Alibaba US$141b slide boosts Tencent to Asia's biggest
summary: Alibaba Group's market value slid to US$153 billion after falling 4.7% in New York, capping a 10-month decline that wiped US$140.7 billion from its value. Tencent Holdings, which has been gaining ground, surpassed Alibaba as Asia's largest Internet company. Tencent's value surpassed Alibaba's for the first time since 2014, with shares rising 17% this year in Hong Kong trading. The decline in Alibaba's market capitalization is equivalent to the entire value of Samsung Electronics Co.

site_title: Stock rebound goes global as Asia rallies on easing China angst
summary: Asian stocks surged, led by a 4% gain in Japan's Topix index, as investors became optimistic about China's ability to stabilize its financial markets. Emerging-market currencies strengthened, and commodity-producer currencies rebounded, while the yen traded near its weakest level. China's stocks opened higher after a late-afternoon recovery in Shanghai, with investors taking it as a sign that regulators can calm volatile markets. The Federal Reserve's next meeting is expected to be less likely to raise interest rates in December, amid recent market volatility.

site_title: Abe pledges 2016 corporate tax cut as investment stays sluggish
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe pledged to lower the effective corporate tax rate by at least 3.3 percentage points to 35.4% next year, aiming to reduce it to the twenties over several years. This follows a sluggish domestic investment, as businesses reduced investment despite record cash holdings and surge in profits. The move aims to boost Japan's economy, which contracted 1.2% in the second quarter. Abe's administration plans to continue lowering the levy over five years to under 30%. The move is seen as a response to the government's need for more companies to become profitable.

site_title: Condo, apartment rents down 0.4% in August: SRX
summary: Singapore condominium and apartment rents declined 0.4% in August, following a 0.3% drop in July, according to SRX Property. Rents in the city centre and suburbs fell 0.7% and 1.3% respectively, while city fringe rents rose 0.8%. Year-over-year, rents were down 5.7% from August 2014 and 12.9% from their peak in January 2013. HDB rents also declined 0.6% in August, with year-over-year drops of 3.6% and 6.6% from August 2014 and August 2013, respectively.

images.alt_text: Private condominium and apartment rents in Singapore dipped 0.4 per cent in August, after falling 0.3 per cent in July, according to data released by SRX Property on Wednesday.

site_title: Prices on UK high streets fall again, food prices edge up
summary: UK shop prices fell 1.4% in August, matching July's decline, due to intense competition among retailers and falling commodity prices. Food prices rose 0.2% year-on-year, a marginal increase, likely a temporary fluctuation. Non-food goods prices fell 2.4%, a sharper decrease. The Bank of England expects inflation to pick up next year, while wages are being closely monitored for signs of inflationary pressures.

images.alt_text: British shop prices fell as sharply in August as in July but the price of food edged up for a second month in a row, the British Retail Consortium said on Wednesday.

site_title: Halcyon Agri in discussions over 'potential strategic transaction'
summary: Halcyon Agri Corporation Limited is in confidential discussions with "certain parties" regarding a potential strategic transaction. The company has not reached an agreement and cannot assure a deal will be concluded. As a result, Halcyon Agri's share price gained 9.1% to 66 Singapore cents in trading on Wednesday.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks up on bargain hunting, tech sector strong
summary: Taiwan's main TAIEX index rose 2.2% to 8,176.63 points on Wednesday, driven by broad-based gains and bargain hunting in the tech sector. Chipmaker TSMC led the gains, with shares up 3.3%, while Hon Hai Precision, the main assembler for Apple's iPhones, rose 1.8%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$0.375 to T$32.628 per US dollar.

site_title: China finance minister targets fiscal policy, infrastructure to support economy
summary: China's finance minister announced plans to strengthen fiscal policy, boost infrastructure spending, and speed up tax reform to support the country's slowing economy. The Ministry of Finance will accelerate major construction projects, utilize public-private partnerships, standardize local government debt, and reform taxes. This move follows other efforts by authorities to revive the economy, which has been growing at its slowest pace in decades. The government aims to support stable growth and promote continued healthy economic development.

site_title: Australia July unemployment rate unchanged after re-benchmarking
summary: Australia's unemployment rate remained unchanged at 6.3% in July, following a re-benchmarking of employment figures by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS). Employment numbers rose by 37,900, but were revised from the initial 38,500. The revised figures were released to ensure the use of the latest population estimates.

images.alt_text: The Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) on Wednesday published revised employment figures using the latest population estimates.

site_title: AIIB to grow to 70 members soon, sees first projects early 2016
summary: The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) is expected to grow to 70 members soon, with Jin Liqun, its president-designate, stating that more than 70 countries are waiting to join.
