images.alt_text: The bulk of the shortfall is likely to be faced by Raiffeisen Bank, Credit Agricole SA, UniCredit Spa, Societe Generale, Banco Santander and Natixis, JP Morgan said.

site_title: M&S slows foreign expansion amid China, Russia turmoil
summary: Marks & Spencer is slowing its foreign expansion drive due to economic turbulence in China and Russia, according to its international boss. The retailer had set targets to open 250 new stores overseas in three years, but now considers those targets unobtainable. M&S remains committed to China and Russia, but will re-think its expansion pace in the short term amid tough markets at home and economic challenges in its priority markets.

site_title: Rebounding China stocks support Asia FX
summary: Asian currencies rose as China's stocks rebounded, reducing risk aversion. Most emerging currencies gained, except Malaysia's ringgit, which hit a 17-year low due to low oil prices and concerns about exports. Indonesia's rupiah also slumped to its weakest since 1998. Despite the gains, concerns about China's economy, with imports contracting 13.8% in August, limited gains.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close 2.43% lower on China worries
summary: Tokyo shares declined 2.43% on September 8, 2015, due to concerns over China's economy. Despite better-than-expected revised Japanese GDP figures, the Nikkei 225 index fell 433.39 points to 17,427.08, while the Topix index dropped 2.00% to 1,416.71.

site_title: Indonesia said to be on course to rejoin Opec in December
summary: Indonesia is on track to rejoin the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) in December, after a nearly seven-year suspension. The move, subject to final approval, comes as the country pumps 852,000 barrels of oil daily, nearly half the amount it consumes. Indonesia's suspension was triggered in 2008, and the nation's request for reinstatement has been supported by Opec's 12 members. The decision will be made at Opec's ministerial meeting on December 4.

site_title: China economic planner approves 70b yuan worth of railway projects
summary: China's National Development and Reform Commission approved 70 billion yuan worth of railway projects, including a 51.6 billion yuan railway in southwestern Yunnan province and an 18.1 billion yuan high-speed railway linking Hebei and Shanxi. This move aims to boost growth in China's economy, following the approval of 77 billion yuan worth of highway and bridge projects on Monday.

site_title: Japan MOF seeks tax rebate on food and drinks when tax rises in 2017: sources
summary: Japan's Ministry of Finance plans to propose tax rebates on food and non-alcoholic drinks when the national sales tax rises to 10% in 2017. The rebates, which would apply to low-income earners, would effectively exempt them from the tax hike while maintaining a single nominal rate. The proposal aims to reduce burdens on low-income people and ease the impact of the tax increase, which is expected to hit households hard and contribute to a recession. The plan would use a national identity number system for tax administration.

site_title: Japan service sector sentiment worsens in August
summary: Japan's service sector sentiment index fell to 49.3 in August, the lowest level since January, due to declining confidence about current economic conditions. The index, which measures workers' confidence in future conditions, slipped to 48.2. This marks the first time the index has fallen in two months. The decline is attributed to worsening economic conditions, which may put pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Seoul: Won erases loss and closes up; shares fall for a 3rd day
summary: The South Korean won reversed an early loss, closing up 0.2% to 1,200.9 per dollar, as traders suspected foreign exchange intervention to curb its sharp fall to a five-year low. The won had slipped to 1,208.8 earlier, with local exporters' demand settlements also supporting its rise. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) ended down 0.2% for a third consecutive session, with foreigners selling shares for a 24th day in a row, the longest such streak since 2008.

site_title: South Korea plans record 2016 budget as Park seeks growth
summary: South Korea plans a record $456 billion budget for 2016, aiming to boost the economy amid slowing growth in China. The proposed budget is 2 trillion won more than this year's, with increased government expenditure on welfare programs, education, and defense. The government expects a budget deficit of 2.3% of GDP in 2016, with debt reaching a record 40.1% of the country's GDP. Despite the increased spending, economists say the budget plan prioritizes fiscal soundness over growth support.

site_title: Air quality crosses into the unhealthy range on Tuesday morning
summary: Air quality in Singapore reached unhealthy levels on Tuesday morning, with a 24-hour Pollutant Standards Index (PSI) of 88-101. The elderly, pregnant women, and children are advised to minimize outdoor activities, while those with chronic lung or heart disease should avoid strenuous activities when the PSI exceeds 100.

site_title: Metro joins Alibaba in Chinese e-commerce partnership
summary: Metro AG, Germany's largest retailer, is partnering with Alibaba Group to develop e-commerce on the Chinese online retailer's website. Metro will sell private-label products to Chinese consumers through Alibaba's site, and the companies will explore data sourcing and cooperation. This partnership aims to help European consumer brands expand into the Chinese market. Metro has been expanding in Asia and recently acquired a Singapore-based gourmet products supplier. The alliance was announced by Alibaba's CEO Daniel Zhang, who stated that the partnership will help European brands establish fast-track solutions for entering the Chinese market.

site_title: GE2015: A vote for your PAP candidate is a vote for me, my team, my programme, says PM Lee
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong urged Singaporeans to vote for the People's Action Party (PAP) candidates, stating that their vote would be a vote for him, his team, and his programme. He made this appeal during a PAP rally in Singapore, emphasizing the party's unity and shared vision.

site_title: GE2015: Vote for the right people who can put Singapore on the right path, says PM Lee Hsien Loong
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong urged Singaporeans to vote for the right people who can implement policies effectively and guide the country on the right path. He reiterated the People's Action Party's (PAP) ability to take Singapore forward in the long term. The statement was made during a rally in Singapore, ahead of the 2015 general election.

site_title: China's August yuan-denominated exports fall 6.1 per cent on year: media
summary: China's yuan-denominated exports fell 6.1% in August from the previous year, while imports dropped 14.3% in yuan terms, resulting in a trade surplus of 368 billion yuan. This follows weak global commodity prices and soft domestic demand. Exports in dollar terms were expected to drop 6.0% in August, while imports likely shrank for a 10th consecutive month.

site_title: Australia: Shares bounce on M&A deal
summary: Australian shares rose 1.7% on Tuesday, the largest daily gain in two weeks, as US index futures firmed and a US$8 billion Woodside Petroleum takeover approach for Oil Search boosted confidence in energy stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,115.2, up 84.8 points. The rally followed a two-week decline, with investors seeking gains as US trade talks and tariffs continued to dominate markets.

site_title: Australian PM Abbott slams 'xenophobic' opposition to China trade deal
summary: Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott criticized opposition to a China trade deal, labeling it "xenophobic." The deal, signed last year, aims to expand ties between Australia and China, opening Chinese markets to Australian exports and easing investment curbs. Despite the benefits, opposition remains, citing labor provisions as weaknesses. Abbott's government considers the deal the best ever signed between China and a Western country.

site_title: Modi asks billionaires if China's pain can be India's gain
summary: Prime Minister Narendra Modi held a meeting with billionaires and bankers to discuss ways to manage global economic turbulence and capitalize on opportunities in China's market. India's economy has improved since 2013, with lower inflation and a growth rate of 7% in the June quarter. However, investors and corporates express concerns that Modi has not moved fast enough to attract foreign investment. ASSOCHAM called for interest rate cuts and new duties to stop dumping of Chinese products, predicting an 8% or more growth rate in 2015/16, despite slow private investment and high lending rates.

site_title: Update: China August exports fall less than forecast
summary: Chinese exports fell in August, but the decline was less than forecast, indicating a slowdown in the world's second-largest economy. The drop is attributed to weak demand in major markets, exacerbating concerns about China's growth slowdown. Beijing is trying to rebalance the economy towards domestic consumer demand, but the transition is proving challenging.

site_title: South Korea police launch sports fixing, gambling probe
summary: South Korean police launched a formal investigation into match-fixing and illegal gambling involving over 20 sportsmen, mostly basketball and judo players. The probe began after a February incident where a basketball player, Kim, allegedly helped throw a match by missing baskets at a fellow gambler's request. Police suspect involvement of 28-year-old judo player and others, with the investigation focusing on potential game-rigging and betting schemes. The probe aims to address widespread corruption in South Korean sports.

site_title: Aussie advances as business bounce outweighs China trade slump
summary: The Australian dollar strengthened for a second day, advancing against 16 major peers, following improved business conditions data that outweighed a report of a China trade slump. The kiwi currency also rose, driven by a relief rally and expectations of monetary policy review by the New Zealand central bank. China's imports slumped, but stocks swung between gains and losses. The Aussie's gains were attributed to better-than-expected data from National Australia Bank, with senior currency strategist Emma Lawson citing a relief rally and improved business conditions.

site_title: Oil prices mixed after weak Chinese trade data
summary: Oil prices were mixed in Asia, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate falling $1.34 to $44.71 and Brent crude gaining 44 cents to $48.07, following weak Chinese trade data. China's overseas shipments in August fell 6.1% from a year earlier, and imports dropped 14.3%. Analysts say the data reinforces concerns about the Chinese economy's slowdown, which could curb demand for commodities and keep oil prices under pressure.

site_title: GE2015: PAP candidates say a vote for the PAP is a vote for Singapore's continued success
summary: In a rally for the upcoming Singapore General Election, candidates from the People's Action Party (PAP) emphasized that a vote for the party is a vote for Singapore's continued success and prosperity. Thousands attended the event. Meanwhile, globally, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. In other news, Citigroup forecasts a 1,150 target for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026 and Malaysia's industrial production rose 0.3% in May, below forecast.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise at open; FTSE up 0.76%
summary: Europe's stock markets rose in opening deals on Tuesday, with the FTSE 100 index up 0.76% to 6,120.48 points, and the DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices adding 0.89% and 0.70%, respectively. This follows a five-day rally in Singapore stocks and a record-breaking close for the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq. US-EU trade talks and the impact of new Trump threats on the market are being closely watched.

site_title: Robust Plan withdraws offer for Cordlife's CCBC shares, notes
summary: Robust Plan has withdrawn its unsolicited offer for Cordlife's shares and convertible notes in US-listed China Cord Blood Corp (CCBC) due to concerns over CCBC's potential sale of its China business to Nanjing Xinjiekou Department Store. The withdrawal comes after CCBC's board announced it will review and evaluate NXDS's offer, which could lead to CCBC losing its core China business and becoming "no longer commercially relevant" to Robust Plan.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Uber to enter 100 new Chinese cities in next 12 months: CEO
summary: Uber's China unit plans to enter 100 new cities in the next 12 months, a rapid expansion from its previous goal of 50 cities. This was announced by CEO Travis Kalanick during an event in Beijing. Uber China has also raised $1.2 billion in funding as part of an ongoing fundraising round. This move aims to further establish the company's presence in China's rapidly growing ride-hailing market.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index up 0.58 points to 1584.20. Losers outnumbered gainers 89 to 72, and trading volume reached 33.89 million lots worth RM8.9 million.

site_title: GE2015: AHPETC hits back at statements from DPM Teo, Charles Chong
summary: The Aljunied-Hougang-Punggol East Town Council (AHPETC) responded to PAP candidate Charles Chong's claim of a S$1 million surplus in Punggol East SMC accounts, stating there is no evidence to support the claim. The AHPETC described Chong's statement as "misleading" and "obliged to set the record straight".

images.alt_text: The Aljunied-Hougang-Punggol East town council at Rivervale Crescent in Sengkang.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on firmer US futures, Woodside Oil Search bid
summary: Australian shares rose 1.1% on Tuesday, led by a 17% surge in Oil Search after Woodside Petroleum made a $8 billion takeover approach. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached its biggest percentage gain since August 27. Other energy majors, including Santos and BHP Billiton, also gained. The gains followed higher US index futures, suggesting a Wall Street rise when trading resumes. The rally also boosted confidence in the sector, with banks and telecommunications shares also rising.

site_title: Asia: Markets tread water ahead of China trade release
summary: Asian markets remained steady on Tuesday as investors awaited China's trade data release, fearing another weak reading would fuel market volatility. Analysts noted recent turmoil in international markets due to China and US interest rate uncertainty, leading to cautious trading. News of Japan's less-than-expected economic contraction failed to boost Tokyo's Nikkei, despite speculation of potential monetary easing measures.

site_title: Resale prices of non-landed private homes inch up 0.2% in Aug: SRX
summary: Singapore's resale prices of non-landed private homes rose 0.2% in August, according to SRX Property's flash estimate. Prices increased 1.8% in the city fringe or rest of central region, while slipping 0.5% in core central region and 0.2% in outside central region. Compared to last year, resale prices eased 1.7%, with a 6.5% decline from the peak in January 2014. Resale volume decreased 16.8% to 466 units in August, with a year-on-year increase of nearly 16%.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: GE2015: Immigration policy U-turn has hurt businesses, says WP's Gerald Giam
summary: Singaporean Workers' Party candidate Gerald Giam says the government's U-turn on immigration policy has hurt businesses, as the party proposes curbs on foreign manpower growth. Giam questions the government's planning for population growth, suggesting they should have had a target in mind. The sudden policy change, he claims, is the main reason businesses were affected. Despite this, Giam says the team has seen "a lot of support" from ground sentiment, indicating a possible shift in public opinion.

images.alt_text: The U-turn in the Government's immigration policy has hurt businesses, said Workers' Party candidate Gerald Giam on Tuesday as he defended the opposition party's proposed curbs on foreign manpower growth.

site_title: China outrage after officials say blast relatives 'calm'
summary: Chinese officials sparked outrage after stating that the relatives of those killed in a chemical plant explosion in Shandong province were "calm" despite the death toll rising to 13. The statement, later deleted, was deemed "cold-blooded" by China's state news agency Xinhua. Internet users expressed outrage, criticizing officials for prioritizing stability over the emotional well-being of the victims' families. The incident raises concerns about corruption and the government's handling of disaster reporting, particularly in the wake of last month's Tianjin explosions that killed 161 people.

site_title: China: Shanghai shares down before China data, Hong Kong rises
summary: Shanghai shares fell 0.84% ahead of Chinese trade data, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 0.52%. The decline in Shanghai was attributed to expectations of another weak reading, potentially fueling market volatility. In contrast, Hong Kong's market reacted positively to the data release.

site_title: Malaysia's 1MDB shortlists four parties for its power unit
summary: Malaysia's state fund 1Malaysia Development Bhd has shortlisted four parties for the final bidding stage in the sale of its power unit, Edra Global Energy Bhd. The fund also plans to shortlist preferred bidders for its Bandar Malaysia property project by the end of the week. The move comes amid controversy over 1MDB's US$11 billion debt and ongoing investigations into financial mismanagement.

site_title: Singapore shares open marginally higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore shares opened 7.08 points higher to 2,859.49, narrowing to a 1.76 point gain at 9:16am. Gainers outpaced losers 76-64. Market strategist Bernard Aw expects cautious trading due to European indices' higher close and focus on China. Despite US markets reopening after a weekend, interest remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Seoul: Won falls to 5-year low after corporate deal; shares down
summary: The South Korean won fell to a five-year low against the US dollar, trading at 1,205.9 per dollar, following Tesco's sale of its largest overseas unit, Homeplus, in South Korea. Dollar demand is expected to rise, putting pressure on the won. Foreign exchange authorities may intervene to curb the won's sharp fall, limiting losses. Seoul shares also declined, with the KOSPI index down 0.2%, as foreigners continued to sell local shares and exporters bolstered the market on a weak won.

site_title: Samsung to cut 10% of headquarters staff, says newspaper
summary: Samsung Electronics plans to cut 10% of its headquarters staff, primarily in human resources, public relations, and finance departments, amid declining sales and market share. The move comes after the company's new Galaxy smartphones failed to impress consumers, resulting in a loss of US$40 billion in market value since April. Samsung's sales are estimated to decline to 200.2 trillion won this year, down from 206.2 trillion won last year.

site_title: Update: Tepid Japan GDP stirs central bank easing speculation
summary: Japan's economy contracted by 0.3% in the April-June quarter, beating initial estimates of a 0.4% decline but sparking concerns over inventory buildup and declining capital spending. The revised GDP data rekindled speculation about the central bank easing stimulus, as Prime Minister Shinzo Abe faces public opposition over unpopular legislation. Economists predict a 0.3% expansion in the next two quarters, but warn that a failure to recover domestic demand could lead to an extraordinary budget.

site_title: EU businesses warn China over 'slow' reforms
summary: European Union businesses in China have expressed concern over the slow implementation of market reforms, warning that stagnation is a risk for the country's economy. The EU Chamber of Commerce said unequal restrictions on investment remain, and the need for meaningful reforms to state-owned enterprises is pressing. China's GDP growth figure for last year was lowered to 7.3%, the lowest in a quarter of a century, amid global market turmoil. Authorities are urged to use the crisis as a catalyst for reform rather than panic, with the EU Chamber calling for a streamlined approach to foreign investment.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rally with Aussie on Japan boost before China trade
summary: Asian stocks rose with US index futures and Australia's dollar as Japan's smaller-than-expected economic contraction boosted optimism over the global outlook. Japan's Nikkei 225 Stock Average climbed 0.1%, while Australia's S&P/ASX 200 Index rose 0.9%. Chinese index futures signaled gains, despite uncertainty over the country's economic outlook, with the Shanghai Composite Index falling 2.5% on Monday. The Asian-Pacific benchmark is on its second advance in seven days, driven by a weaker emerging market backdrop and dovish central bank rhetoric.

site_title: Gold holds near 2-1/2-week low as US rate outlook weighs
summary: Gold prices stabilized near a 2-1/2-week low on Tuesday, as the US dollar eased amid uncertainty over a potential interest rate hike. Spot gold rose 0.2% to $1,121.16 an ounce, while US gold remained unchanged at $1,120.70. The dollar index fell 0.3%, contributing to the gold price stability. Despite the slight increase, gold is still struggling to find direction amid the looming interest rate hike uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Gold held near a three-week low as gains in global stocks cut demand for a haven and India approved a plan to tap the country's bullion to reduce imports of the metal.

site_title: Amazon plans to sell US$50 tablet
summary: Amazon plans to release a $50 tablet for the holiday season, featuring a 6-inch screen and mono speaker. The company also plans to release 8-inch and 10-inch tablets. Unlike other Amazon Fire tablets, which display ads as screen savers, it's unclear if the new 6-inch tablet's cost includes ads.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks up but gains tentative on domestic economy concerns
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose on Tuesday but with caution, due to concerns over the domestic economic outlook and global market uncertainty. The consumer price index fell for the eighth straight month in August, while exports dropped at their sharpest pace in two and a half years. The gains were tentative, with traders worried about the island's export-driven economy entering a traditionally strong second half of the year.

site_title: Australia business conditions improve in Aug but confidence falters on China: survey
summary: Australian business conditions improved in August, with the National Australia Bank's index rising 5 points to +11, driven by growth in trading and profitability. However, business confidence fell to +1, its lowest since mid-2013, amid concerns over China's economy. The survey also showed a jump in sales and profitability, but forward orders and employment remained negative. The results are seen as a positive sign for the Reserve Bank of Australia, which is expecting a pick-up in non-mining business investment.

images.alt_text: National Australia Bank's monthly survey of more than 500 firms showed its index of business conditions rose 5 points to +11 in August. In contrast, its measure of business confidence dipped 3 points to +1 - its lowest since mid-2013.

site_title: Japan trims April-June GDP contraction estimate to 0.3%
summary: Japan's economy contracted 0.3% during the April-June quarter, beating market expectations for a 0.5% contraction. The revised estimate, slightly better than the original 0.4% contraction, was largely due to a larger contribution from stock building. Despite this, concerns remain, with analysts citing recent data on exports and industrial production suggesting a rapid recovery is unlikely.

site_title: Ringgit falls for fifth day on lower oil, China growth concern
summary: Malaysia's ringgit fell for the fifth consecutive day, with a 0.9% decline to 4.3672 a dollar, due to lower oil prices and concerns over China's economic slowdown. Brent crude slumped 4% on Monday, contributing to the ringgit's 20% depreciation this year. China's exports contracted for a second month in August, further dampening demand for the oil-exporting nation's assets. Market participants expect the ringgit and oil prices to stabilize, but global funds reduced holdings of Malaysian government bonds by 4.3% in August.

site_title: Cameron suffers defeat in Commons vote on EU referendum bill
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron suffered a defeat in the House of Commons over the EU referendum bill, with 312 to 285 votes against weakening purdah rules. The defeat highlights the struggle for eurosceptics within Cameron's Conservative party to secure deeper reforms before the 2017 vote. The bill will now proceed to the House of Lords for further debate, with Cameron aiming to secure cosmetic changes to Britain's relationship with Europe.

site_title: Moody's trims Asia-Pac growth forecasts
summary: Moody's has trimmed growth forecasts for many Asia-Pacific countries due to subdued global growth, weak demand from China, and a commodities slump. Despite this, the agency notes that sovereign credit profiles of Asia-Pacific countries remain resilient, with most credit indicators in line with assumptions. Domestic demand is unlikely to offset slower global growth, and households are saving more income gains from lower energy costs. The risk of deflation is minimal, and lower oil prices have supported current account and fiscal positions in many Asian countries. Exchange rates and reserves are expected to continue to face pressure.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Weak economic outlook and oversupply weigh on oil markets
summary: US oil prices fell around 3% on Tuesday, with Brent futures down $1.24 from their opening value, amid a weak global economic outlook and oversupply. Japan's economy shrank 1.2% in April-June, and Asian shares are expected to struggle as investors seek stability in China's slowing economy. Oil prices have fallen 60% since June 2014 due to a global supply glut, with Opec producing near record volumes to squeeze out competition. A Russian cut to oil production is unlikely, further weighing on oil prices.

site_title: YuuZoo, Sweden-based firm in mobile games tie-up
summary: YuuZoo Corp, a Singapore-listed firm, has partnered with Sweden-based Circle of Champions Inc to distribute and market mobile games Powershot Challenge and Striker Challenge. The games are created for 11 top football clubs, including FC Barcelona and Real Madrid, and will be available through virtual "clubhouses" where fans can download and purchase games, merchandise, and interact with each other and club representatives. Revenues will be shared between CoC and YuuZoo, with the games to be marketed to YuuZoo's 31 million mobile gamers user-base in China and Asia.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: South Korea won slips to 5-year low after corporate merger deal
summary: South Korea's won dropped to a five-year low against the dollar, falling to 1,028.8 per dollar, following Tesco's sale of its largest overseas unit, Homeplus, in South Korea for $6.1 billion. The sale is expected to increase dollar demand, weighing on the won. The currency was down 0.4% at 1,208.6 per dollar as of 0100 GMT.

site_title: EU regulators to approve GE-Alstom deal: source
summary: The European Union is set to approve a US$12 billion deal where General Electric will acquire Alstom's energy business, following concessions made by GE to address concerns over market concentration. The deal, initially met with resistance, had been approved by both companies and the French government, but regulators expressed concerns over potential distortions in the gas-turbine market. The EU's Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager will announce the approval at a press conference.

site_title: Move over Exxon, Russian drillers are oil world's top performers
summary: Russian oil companies, including Rosneft and Lukoil, are outperforming their Western counterparts amidst a global oil price slump. Despite a 50% decline in crude prices, Russian producers are managing cash flow and profit margins better than Shell, BP, and Exxon Mobil. Russian tax rates automatically adjust to lower prices, providing a buffer against the price drop. Rosneft's shares have gained 2.9% and Gazprom Neft's shares have added 0.3%, while Shell's and BP's shares have fallen 28% and 18%, respectively.

site_title: UK retail spending stagnates in August: BRC
summary: UK retail spending stagnated in August, rising just 0.1% from a year earlier, the smallest increase since April, according to the British Retail Consortium. The late August bank holiday and muggy weather hurt sales, particularly for back-to-school clothing and winter fashion collections. Adjusted for high-street price changes, sales were up 1.4%. Retailers hope to recoup the sales deficit in September and benefit from higher real wages. This marks a gloomier picture than recent official data, but follows a recent study showing the biggest drop in retail sales since the 2008 financial crisis.

site_title: In dealing with Europe's migrant crisis, Germany sets an example
summary: Germany is setting an example in dealing with Europe's migrant crisis by accepting considerable numbers of refugees. In contrast, other European countries, such as Britain and France, have been criticized for their handling of the crisis. The EU's own figures show that there are 1.5 million recognized refugees living in EU member states, but only 350,000 have arrived this year. Germany's Chancellor Angela Merkel has shown leadership by committing to accept a significant number of refugees, and Austria and Sweden have also set an example.

site_title: Egypt minister arrested after quitting in graft probe
summary: Egypt's agriculture minister, Salah Helal, was arrested after resigning amid an investigation into corruption at his ministry. He was detained following a meeting with the prime minister, where he was accused of requesting and receiving bribes from a businessman to legalize a state property purchase. The arrest comes as part of a larger effort to combat corruption in Egypt, which has plagued the country since the 2011 uprising that ousted President Hosni Mubarak.

site_title: Diamond cuts: India's global hub fears more job losses as China slows
summary: India's diamond polishing hub, Surat, faces significant job losses as Chinese consumers pull back from luxury purchases, leaving thousands of workers without employment. Over 5,000 jobs have been lost since June, with nearly half a dozen large diamond companies closing down. The industry, which employs nearly a million people in India, is struggling to adapt to the slowdown in demand. China, which accounts for a significant portion of India's diamond exports, has seen its growth rate decline, leading to a 50% drop in exports of cut and polished diamonds.

site_title: Oil prices slide at start of week
summary: Oil prices slid on Monday, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate dropping $1.44 to $44.61 a barrel and Brent North Sea crude falling $1.64 to $47.97 a barrel. Market volatility was driven by uncertainty over US interest rates, with a potential rate hike expected to strengthen the greenback and hurt demand and prices. Analysts await global economic data for clues on crude demand, citing concerns about the Chinese slowdown, which has led to declining oil consumption.

site_title: China to cut dividend taxes for long-term shareholders
summary: China announced plans to cut dividend taxes for long-term shareholders to encourage longer-term investment in equities. The government will remove personal income tax on dividends for those holding stocks for over a year, halve the tax for those holding shares between a month and a year, and require full tax payment for those holding shares for less than a month. The changes take effect on Tuesday, amid efforts to stabilize the Chinese market, which has been affected by global investors' concerns about the country's economy.

site_title: Britain, France join Germany in showing solidarity with migrants
summary: European leaders, including Germany, France, and Britain, have pledged to accept tens of thousands of refugees fleeing war and misery, with Germany committing billions more in funding to house asylum-seekers. The European Union is scrambling to address the record influx of migrants, with warnings that Greece's Lesbos island is "on the verge of explosion" due to overcrowding. The EU is also preparing fresh quotas to relocate 120,000 refugees, with Germany, France, and Spain to take nearly half of the total.

site_title: Aeroflot-Transaero deal, bigger but not better: analysts
summary: Russia's largest airline Aeroflot has acquired 75% plus one of Transaero's shares for 1 rouble, citing Transaero's "extremely difficult financial position". The deal, backed by the Russian government, increases Aeroflot's fleet size to over 300 aircraft and gives it control of more than half of the country's air traffic. However, analysts warn that Aeroflot faces an additional debt burden and will have to restructure Transaero's massive 65 billion rouble debt, which could be a costly and lengthy process.

site_title: Worsening housing shortage challenge for Sweden's central bank
summary: Sweden's central bank is facing a worsening housing shortage in Stockholm, with half a million people in line for apartments. Record immigration and surging house prices have exacerbated the issue, raising concerns about deeper financial instability. The bank warned that the combination of high household debt and negative interest rates may be costly for the economy.

site_title: Coffee bears rewarded as Brazil currency drop sees price slide
summary: Brazil and Colombia, the world's largest suppliers of arabica coffee, see their currency values decline due to stagnating growth and oil price collapse. As exporters increase shipments to dollar buyers, coffee prices plummet to their lowest since January 2014, benefiting coffee bears.

site_title: Campaign begins for Myanmar election set to decide scope of democratic change
summary: Myanmar opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy (NLD) is set to win the historic general election on November 8, marking a major shift in the country's political landscape. Suu Kyi will campaign against President Thein Sein's closest allies, including powerful Minister of the President's Office Soe Thein. The NLD is expected to gain a majority, giving democratic activists a platform to push for reforms and constitutional changes, despite the military holding a quarter of the seats. The election's outcome will determine the country's future direction, with Suu Kyi's party focusing on issues such as national reconciliation and a peace process with ethnic minority guerrillas.

site_title: Glencore plans to sell assets, shares to trim its US$30b debt by a third
summary: Glencore, a commodity producer and trader, plans to sell assets and shares worth $2.5 billion to reduce its $30 billion debt by about a third. The company will also suspend dividend payments until further notice. In response, Glencore shares rose 13%, a record intraday gain, and the company aims to cut its net debt to the "low $20s billion" by the end of next year. The move is seen as a step to strengthen the balance sheet and improve its investment grade rating, allowing it to weather potential downcycles in the commodity market.

site_title: Rocket Internet unit to power up new ventures in the Asia-Pacific
summary: Rocket Internet's Asia-Pacific Internet Group (APACIG) plans to launch a new venture in the region every quarter, starting with online beauty marketplace Vaniday in Australia. APACIG, a joint venture with Ooredoo, aims to develop online solutions for diverse markets across 15 countries. The group already runs 14 ventures across the region, offering e-commerce platforms and setting up infrastructure. This move is expected to increase competition for startups in the region, but also drive growth and maturity in the market.

site_title: SGX can and should do more to refine MTP scheme
summary: SGX's Minimum Trading Price (MTP) scheme, introduced to boost the local bourse, has not refined its requirements enough. Most listed companies have consolidated, but MTPs remain low, with some counters trading as low as 1 cent. To align with US markets, an MTP of at least $1 is suggested. Additionally, SGX should consider introducing one-share trading, which has increased daily transactions activity, encouraging more retail investors to trade in larger cap stocks and ETFs. This would help the local bourse move closer to US exchanges.

site_title: Don't be persuaded by sweet promises, warns Grace Fu
summary: Singapore's ruling People Action Party (PAP) candidate Grace Fu criticized the opposition Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) for using emotional and populist policies to sway voters, warning against "spend, spend and spend" policies. Fu emphasized the PAP's core values of meritocracy, multi-racialism, and honesty, which she believes are essential for Singapore's long-term success. She urged voters not to be swayed by "sweet promises" and to instead examine the SDP's policies, warning that they could lead Singapore down a "slippery road" with no return.

site_title: Nobel Design dispute drags on
summary: Nobel Design, a Singapore-based furniture company, is facing a bitter dispute between its founder and single largest shareholder, Bert Choong, and the board. A fractious EGM was held, prompting speculation that the company may need to make a buy-out offer to Choong. Choong owns a 25% stake and was voted out of the board in April. The dispute is ongoing, and it remains to be seen if a buy-out offer will be made to resolve the situation.

site_title: Analysts trim Japan's GDP forecast for H2, see feeble Q3 rebound
summary: Japan's GDP forecast for the second half of 2015 has been downgraded due to weak economic data, with analysts trimming their growth expectations. The Bank of Japan's confidence in underlying economic growth is wavering, and recent weakness in industrial output and exports weighs on a rebound. Economists now expect the economy to grow 1.67% in the current quarter, down from 2.48% previously, and core consumer prices are forecast to fall 0.14% in the next quarter. The Bank of Japan may lower its assessment on exports at its next rate review.

site_title: India's oldest coal-fired plants ordered to help solar farms
summary: India's government has ordered some of the country's oldest coal-fired power plants to sell cheaper coal power along with more expensive solar energy to make solar farms more competitive. The move aims to lower the price distribution companies pay for solar power, forcing them to buy more of the cleaner energy. The programme, set to be implemented by state-run NTPC, will help achieve India's goal of having 100 gigawatts of solar capacity by 2022. The plants involved will sell their power along with solar energy, potentially reducing the wholesale price of solar power and supporting the government's clean energy initiatives.

site_title: Japan's MS&AD Insurance in talks to buy UK insurer Amlin
summary: Japan's MS&AD Insurance Group Holdings Inc is in talks to acquire UK insurer Amlin for more than 500 billion yen (S$6 billion), according to a Nikkei business daily report. Amlin, with a stock market value of US$3.8 billion, specializes in property, casualty, marine, and aviation insurance. The deal, if successful, would be the latest multi-billion dollar acquisition by aggressive Japanese companies. However, an MS&AD spokesman confirmed that no decision has been made at this point.

images.alt_text: The Mitsui Sumitomo Insurance Group Holdings Inc. headquarters stand in Tokyo, Japan.

site_title: Sun S'pore combines market-oriented focus with R&D on road to success
summary: Sun Singapore Systems, a technology-based firm, has become the largest supplier of automated car parking systems in Singapore, with over 750 systems in various locations. Starting from a research and development subsidiary of Sun Japan Corporation in 1993, the company transformed its business model to focus on market-oriented development and adapted to changing technology, such as cashless parking systems and Electronic Parking Systems. With a two-pronged approach of R&D and market focus, Sun Singapore has reversed its losses and achieved year-on-year profits since 2000, and has expanded into other areas like parking guidance systems and airport taxi systems.

site_title: Apple to unveil its upgraded TV on Wednesday
summary: Apple is set to unveil its upgraded Apple TV at an event in San Francisco on Wednesday, expanding the device's uses in gaming and introducing support for apps and games made by independent software developers. The revamped device, priced at $149, will also feature a redesigned remote control with a touch pad and will share the spotlight with the iPhone. The move aims to transform the Apple TV into a multipurpose entertainment product for homes, competing with other devices like Xbox and PlayStation.

site_title: Iceland's Landsbankinn to refinance 200b kronur in debt
summary: Iceland's Landsbankinn plans to refinance up to 200 billion kronur (S$2.2 billion) in debt issued to its failed predecessor Landsbanki Islands, aiming to lift capital restrictions and reduce financing costs. The bank's CEO, Steinthor Palsson, said the upgrade in credit rating has led to more favorable interest rates, making refinancing mutually beneficial. Landsbankinn will likely prepay 10 bonds to LBI and refinance in steps, with a focus on completing settlements with priority claimants and paying back the debt in a few years.

site_title: PAP's Vivian flags larger challenges looming ahead for Singapore
summary: Singapore Minister for the Environment and Water Resources Vivian Balakrishnan warned of fundamental challenges ahead for the country, citing climate change, global competition, and disruptive technologies. He disputed opposition party proposals, saying a social welfare system would be unsustainable and could lead to bankruptcy. In contrast, the PAP model prioritizes personal and family responsibility, ensuring targeted subsidies and reserves are not raided. The party also argued that Singapore's healthcare system, with Medishield Life, offers a balance of quality, cost, and access, and is not to be dismantled.

site_title: Steve Jobs movie wows reviewers and raises Oscar hopes
summary: A biopic about Apple co-founder Steve Jobs, starring Michael Fassbender, has received high praise from reviewers, with some suggesting Fassbender is an Oscar contender. The film, directed by Danny Boyle and written by Aaron Sorkin, has been described as a "terrific actors' showcase" and an "incorrigibly entertaining ride." Industry experts, including Apple co-founder Steve Wozniak, have praised the film's accuracy and authenticity. The movie is set to be released on October 9 and is expected to be a contender in the Oscar race.

site_title: Indonesian rupiah rout swells cost of US$304 billion foreign debt
summary: Indonesia's rupiah has plummeted to its lowest level since the Asian financial crisis, with a 13.2% decline this year, due to concerns over the country's record $304 billion foreign debt. The currency's decline has raised fears of a debt crisis, with companies facing higher debt servicing costs, falling earnings, and slumping asset prices. While some experts argue that the rupiah's plunge may favor economic growth in the long run, others warn of a self-fulfilling prophecy, citing the country's vulnerability to capital flight and outflows.

site_title: BlackRock sees new opportunity in China real estate
summary: BlackRock is increasing its China real estate portfolio exposure due to weak economy and credit environment, targeting mass-affluent shopping malls and grade "A" and "B" offices in first-tier and selective second-tier cities. The fund's head, John Saunders, sees opportunities in these areas, citing compressed yields and relatively stable capital values despite weakening capital values. Saunders also sees potential in distressed residential projects and currency depreciation, which can make real estate investment favorable.

images.alt_text: Yields in Chinese retail real estate investment markets have compressed to around 6 per cent in H1, according to Colliers.

site_title: Rise in luxury London home prices slows over higher taxes
summary: London luxury home prices rose 1.7% in the year through August, the least in over five years, due to higher taxes and a decline in Chinese buyers following the yuan's devaluation. Sales fell 30% in the three months through July, with prices dropping 2.4% in Knightsbridge and 4.6% in Notting Hill. The increased stamp duty tax for homes over £937,000 (£2 million) is also curbing demand, according to Knight Frank LLP.

site_title: Temasek 'joins Savola in bid for Americana'
summary: Temasek Holdings and Saudi Arabia's Savola Group are teaming up to bid for Middle Eastern fast-food operator Americana, with a deal potentially valued at US$4-5 billion. Talks between the three parties are ongoing, and a deal could be reached before the end of the year. This follows Savola's previous bid to acquire Americana in December 2014. Americana, founded in 1964, operates restaurants such as KFC and Pizza Hut in the Middle East and North Africa, and has a market value of about US$8.5 billion.

site_title: Sept eurozone investor sentiment slumps to low on fears of slowdown
summary: Eurozone investor sentiment plummeted to 13.6 in September, the lowest reading since February, due to concerns about a slowdown in China and its impact on the eurozone economy, particularly Germany. A Sentix survey found a sharp decline in economic expectations, with Germany's index falling to 20.6 and the expectations component collapsing to 4.4. The decline is attributed to Germany's significant trade exposure to China and industrial orders falling more than expected in July. The slowdown in China weighs heavily on the eurozone's economic outlook, sparking uncertainty among investors.

site_title: Indonesia mulls issue of first-ever dim sum bond as it diversifies funding
summary: Indonesia is considering its first-ever dim sum bond, a move to diversify funding as the offshore renminbi market remains reeling from China's currency revaluation and a crashing onshore stock market. The issue is not expected soon due to market volatility, with Indonesian officials saying it's unlikely to be issued in the fourth quarter of 2015. The move would mark Indonesia's entry into the yuan-denominated market, where non-Chinese issuers have seen slightly better performance in secondary markets.

site_title: MediShield Life's deductibles too high: SDP's Prof Tambyah
summary: SDP candidate Prof Tambyah criticized the high deductibles in Singapore's MediShield Life scheme, saying they would burden future generations with out-of-pocket costs. He also argued that the subsidies for senior citizens would expire, making the system unsustainable. The SDP proposed raising taxes on the top one percent to fund healthcare programs, contrasting with Deputy Prime Minister Tharman's stance on the issue. Meanwhile, SDP candidate Dr. Chee highlighted the country's low healthcare spending and questionable investments by Temasek Holdings, calling for more opposition in Parliament to scrutinize the PAP's decisions.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Lessons from China's summer of instability
summary: China's summer of instability, marked by a swooning stock market, has raised concerns about the country's economy and its impact on global markets. However, experts argue that China's stock market is not a reliable indicator of its economic health due to its unique, state-controlled nature. China's economy, the world's second-largest, is a developing economy that defies traditional economic theories and responds to standard analysis in unpredictable ways. The country's currency and trade policies also pose paradoxes, making it challenging for the West to accurately assess its economic situation.

site_title: Queen Elizabeth goes low-key for record reign landmark
summary: Queen Elizabeth II will mark her record-breaking 63 years on the throne by inaugurating a new railway line in Scotland and hosting a dinner at Balmoral Castle. The 89-year-old monarch will ride a steam train to commemorate the occasion, which will surpass her great-great-grandmother Queen Victoria's record. Buckingham Palace will display a photo exhibition of her reign, and the Royal Mint has released a new £20 coin featuring five official portraits since her accession in 1952.

site_title: Pool of bankrupt Malaysians under 35 double that in 2005
summary: Malaysia's number of young people under 35 declared bankrupt has more than doubled since 2005, reaching 5,547 last year. The country aims to achieve "high-income status" by 2020, but rising household debt and financial difficulties among young people pose a threat to its economy. With the highest personal debt rate among 14 Asian economies, Malaysia's growth rate could be impacted if private consumption continues to slow. Experts attribute the rise in bankruptcies to a combination of factors, including low interest rates, easy lending policies, and a lack of financial literacy among young Malaysians.

site_title: StanChart Singapore names Judy Hsu its new CEO
summary: Standard Chartered Bank Singapore has appointed Judy Hsu as its new CEO, effective October 1, 2015. She will replace Neeraj Swaroop, who is leaving the bank to pursue other opportunities. Hsu, a Singapore permanent resident, has lived and worked in Singapore for 25 years and is currently group head of wealth management. The appointment is part of top-level changes made by group CEO Bill Winters, who is trying to reverse falling profits and cut costs, including 4,000 staff cuts.

site_title: China stocks slide despite calming words from policymakers
summary: China's stocks slid 3.4% and 2.5% in Shanghai and Shenzhen, respectively, despite efforts by policymakers to calm markets. The securities regulator is considering a circuit breaker system to halt trading in extreme price moves. China's Central Bank Governor Zhou Xiochuan said the country's equity markets had almost completed their correction, while Finance Minister Lou Jiwei announced a 10% increase in central government spending. The economy is expected to slow, with some analysts predicting a 7% growth rate, down from previous forecasts.

site_title: Gold is likely to lose some more of its lustre
summary: Gold prices are likely to fall further due to decreased demand and increased supply. Investors who still hold gold should reduce their exposure, as the reasons for holding gold, such as inflation insurance and a weaker US dollar, have lost significance. With inflation unlikely to return and the US dollar expected to strengthen, gold prices could drop another 20% to around $700 per ounce, according to median production costs and inflation-adjusted prices.

site_title: Rally watch
summary: Key developments include a low-profile property trust investing in a data centre, US weekly jobless claims falling unexpectedly, and China urging Southeast Asian nations to support openness amid US tariffs. Chinese property shares surged on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector, while Reliance Jio has delayed its India IPO. China also unveiled new steps to aid employment amid trade tensions.

site_title: Toshiba posts 2014 loss, restates profits for previous 6 years
summary: Toshiba posted a 2014 annual loss of 37.8 billion yen, restating profits for the previous six years due to an accounting scandal that led to the ouster of its president and two predecessors. The company has revamped its board and appointed a special committee to regain trust, but investors remain uncertain about its long-term recovery. Toshiba has already sold assets and will hold an extraordinary general meeting on September 30 to address the issues. The company's restatements total 155.2 billion yen in writedowns, with the largest being a 64 billion yen reduction in profit for 2013.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore's Transport Minister announced a potential 1.9% reduction in bus and train fares by end-FY15, which may negatively impact ComfortDelGro Corp's near-term growth due to its 75% exposure in SBS Transit. However, the company's diversified revenue stream will mitigate the impact. OCBC Investment Research maintains a "hold" rating, reducing its FY16 forecast profit by 2% and lowering its fair value to S$2.99. The oil glut has led to increased storage demand, with investment groups acquiring facilities, and the sector is expected to see order momentum.

site_title: Boeing 717: Once a sales flop, now the world's hottest used jetliner
summary: The Boeing 717, a 100-seat jetliner once considered a sales flop, has become the world's most sought-after used aircraft due to cheap fuel and Delta's decision to replace small regional jets with the model. Valuations have risen 17% to $7.5-$10.5 million, and lease rates have soared 22% as airlines such as Delta, Qantas, and Volotea compete for the few available planes. Boeing's investment and spare-part support have contributed to the aircraft's resurgence, with Delta citing its performance and layout as reasons for its popularity.

site_title: Greek crisis prompts rethink on food waste
summary: In Greece, a movement to combat food waste has emerged, with locals donating unsold food from shops and restaurants to charities, providing an average of 2,500 meals daily. Founded by Xenia Papastavrou, the organization Boroume ("We Can") matches donated food with charities, challenging traditional attitudes to food waste. As Greece struggles with economic hardship, this initiative is helping to shift habits and reduce waste, with cooperatives and charities working together to provide affordable food options.

site_title: Singapore property may face ageing threat
summary: A study by the National University of Singapore's Institute of Real Estate Studies predicts Singapore home prices could fall by 30% by 2040 due to an ageing population and rising old-age dependency ratio. However, economists argue that investment and immigration flows will mitigate this effect, offsetting the housing demand lost from an aged population. The study forecasts similar trends in other Asian economies, but notes that Singapore's growing population will have a stabilizing impact, preventing prices from plummeting as much as in other countries.

site_title: QE dispenses unwanted results to Europe stock buyers
summary: The European Central Bank's quantitative easing program has failed to boost European stock markets, with the Euro Stoxx 50 Index falling 9.2% in August and 13% in the last four weeks. Despite economic data showing progress, including a 1.5% GDP growth and 12% profit increase, investor confidence remains low due to financial stress and global economic concerns. Analysts predict stock prices will catch up with earnings once confidence returns, but the ECB's inability to hold up the recovery is a troubling sign for bulls.

site_title: YuuZoo secures S$30m funding facility
summary: YuuZoo Corp has secured a S$30 million funding facility from New York-based GEM Global Yield Fund for the next three years. The facility allows YuuZoo to draw down funds at a 10% discount of its shares' closing price. The agreement includes a one-off commitment fee of S$450,000 and warrants for GEM Global to subscribe for new YuuZoo shares. The funding will enable YuuZoo to continue its expansion plans, with its executive chairman stating the company has no obligation to draw on the funds.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Giving the furniture sector a sexy vibe
summary: The Singapore furniture industry has transformed its image from traditional to modern and sexy, shifting focus from succession planning to design and branding. Ernie Koh, president of the Singapore Furniture Industries Council, notes this change has helped the industry address succession planning concerns.

images.alt_text: Mr Koh, president of the Singapore Furniture Industries Council, is encouraging members to embrace the softer aspects of the business, such as branding.
Mindy Tan

site_title: Nissan may repeat recall over passenger airbags
summary: Nissan may repeat its 2014 recall of almost 1 million vehicles due to a malfunctioning passenger airbag that could deploy incorrectly and cause serious injuries. Despite a software reprogram, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has received over 1,300 complaints from owners whose vehicles still display a warning light indicating the airbag is off, even when an adult is in the seat. The agency is intensifying its investigation and may pressure Nissan for a new recall to correct the issue.

site_title: China's slowdown could be just a blip, if 1960s Japan is a guide
summary: China's economic slowdown and market crash may be a temporary blip, similar to Japan's 1960s experience, according to experts. Both economies experienced rapid growth, leading to soaring real estate prices and stock market bubbles, which eventually ended in a hard landing. However, China's situation is more complex, with a shrinking labor force and an open economy making it vulnerable to capital outflows. Despite these differences, China's current troubles may be a mere blip on the path to prosperity, with the country still at a middling stage of economic development and significant room for growth.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: QT Vascular announced CE mark clearance for its Chocolate Touch peripheral drug-coated balloon catheter in Europe. The company expects a commercial launch in countries accepting the CE mark later this year.

site_title: M'sian traders scorn govt's order to cut prices as ringgit dives
summary: Malaysia's government has ordered traders and restaurant operators to reduce prices following a 10 sen drop in fuel prices, but the move is seen as futile due to the country's struggling currency, the ringgit, which has lost 35% of its value against the US dollar in the past year. Businesses have scorned the order, citing increased costs and the need for suppliers to lower prices. Analysts attribute the ringgit's weakness to external factors, including China's yuan depreciation and a widening trust deficit in Prime Minister Najib Razak.

site_title: S'pore, M'sia gaming outlook stable but headwinds persist: Fitch
summary: Fitch Ratings has stated that the gaming industry in Singapore and Malaysia remains stable despite declining tourist arrivals, shrinking VIP business, and lower win rates. The integrated resorts in Singapore, operated by Genting Singapore and Marina Bay Sands, are expected to withstand the current "macro sluggishness" but may decline in share if the weak backdrop persists. Singapore's gross gaming revenue has been declining, with a 44% drop in the VIP segment, while Genting Malaysia's receivables have increased to 44 days. The rating firm expects Genting Berhad's expansion plans to not adversely affect its credit profile.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Finding a way to put global economy back on track
summary: The global economy is experiencing uncertainty and volatility, with markets fluctuating wildly and economic data contradicting each other. The G-20 finance ministers' meeting in Turkey highlighted the need for growth-oriented policies, but there was little conviction in implementing them. China's slowdown is being blamed for the global economic woes, but its role in the 2007-2008 global financial crisis and the US Federal Reserve's decision to raise interest rates suggest that the issue is more complex. The article concludes that the world's major economies have tried monetary stimulus and now face the option of a recession, but there may be a way to unlock new economic growth potential through cross-border cooperation and political vision.

site_title: Govt can raise usage of reserves: SingFirst
summary: Singaporeans First (SingFirst) secretary-general Tan Jee Say criticized Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam's claim that the government is "maxing out" on its investment income from reserves. Tan argued that excess returns from Central Provident Fund (CPF) investments, such as 6% annual returns, are being kept by the government and could be used for social programs. SingFirst proposed a S$6 billion social safety net and an S$8 billion social investment program, citing the government's S$16 billion returns each year.

site_title: Turkish Airlines CEO sees potential for closer ties with Lufthansa
summary: Turkish Airlines CEO Temel Kotil expressed potential for closer ties with Lufthansa, citing the airlines' complementary strengths in northern and southern Europe. The two carriers are already linked through the Star Alliance and charter venture SunExpress. Kotil hinted at further cooperation, stating that Turkish Airlines needs partnerships to expand its global presence, particularly in the face of growing rivals in the Persian Gulf. Lufthansa shares rose 6.6% following the comments, while Turkish Airlines shares rose 0.5%.

site_title: Too early to say yuan devalued to boost exports: OECD
summary: A senior OECD official, Rintaro Tamaki, stated that it's too early to interpret China's recent yuan devaluations as an attempt to boost exports and drive economic growth. Tamaki believes the devaluations are too small to have a significant impact, and a weaker yuan could offset any benefits from increased exports due to China's economic structure. The OECD deputy secretary-general emphasized the need for China to carry out structural reforms to achieve stable and sustainable economic growth, rather than relying on currency manipulation.

site_title: Indonesia more exposed to capital flight than Malaysia: S&P
summary: Indonesia's economy is more exposed to capital flight than Malaysia's, according to Standard & Poor's (S&P). Indonesia's foreign-exchange reserves have fallen 9% in six months, and its rupiah has weakened 5.1% since July, while Malaysia's ringgit has declined 12%. S&P warns that Indonesia's reliance on foreign capital makes it vulnerable to shifts in outflows and inflows. The country's benchmark stock gauge has lost 16% over the past three months, compared to Malaysia's 9.3%.

site_title: Ringgit falls to new 1998 low as Asia sell-off sends KLCI lower
summary: The Malaysian ringgit fell to a new 1998 low, weakening 1.7% to 4.3300 a dollar, amid a sell-off in Asia and concerns over slowing Chinese growth and US interest-rate hikes. The FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI index lost 0.4% as the country's trade surplus narrowed to RM2.38 billion in July. The central bank is expected to keep interest rates steady, with 18 economists predicting no change, but some predict a 25 basis-point increase.

site_title: China's transition: Risks and opportunities for S-E Asia
summary: China's economic transition poses both risks and opportunities for Southeast Asia. The country's shift from an investment-driven to a consumption-driven growth model may lead to a weaker export sector, hurting regional firms. However, rising wages in China could create a window of opportunity for Southeast Asian countries to capture a greater share of global manufacturing, particularly from multinationals seeking lower labor costs. Additionally, China's investment flows and growing consumer market could support infrastructure development and tourism in the region.

images.alt_text: China's switch to a consumption-driven growth model could create opportunities for Asean, both in terms of creating attractive export markets and increased tourism in the region.

site_title: YouTube to provide viewability data to advertisers: FT
summary: YouTube plans to provide viewability data to advertisers, responding to complaints from clients like Unilever and Kellogg Co. The move, expected to start by the end of the year, will allow third-party verification groups to insert code on the platform to collect data on ad position and context. This aims to address concerns over viewability, which YouTube says it's committed to meeting through product innovation and industry partnerships. Verification companies including ComScore, DoubleVerify, and Integral Ad Science are likely to be involved in the verification process.

site_title: Pilots' union calls strike at Lufthansa for Tuesday
summary: German pilots' union Vereinigung Cockpit (VC) has called an all-day strike at Lufthansa's long-haul and cargo flights on Tuesday, increasing pressure on management over pay, retirement benefits, and cost cuts. The 13th strike in 18 months will affect all long-haul passenger flights and cargo flights out of Germany. Lufthansa, facing market share losses to budget rivals, has proposed concessions, but the union wants the airline to halt hiring staff on non-German contracts for its budget Eurowings division.

site_title: Architect Hadid in Olympic stadium re-design
summary: Architect Zaha Hadid will re-design Tokyo's 2020 Olympics stadium after its initial proposal was scrapped due to its high price tag of $2 billion. The new design, developed with partner Nikken Sekkei, aims to reduce construction costs by 40% to $1.85 billion. The revised stadium could be ready for the 2019 rugby World Cup and meets the International Olympic Committee's deadline of January 2020.

site_title: Duo's hawker fare with a twist
summary: GD Group, a Singapore-based restaurant chain, has expanded its business with modern processes, offering Penang hawker fare with a twist. Co-founders Ven Chin and Ricky Shawn Lim developed the concept, which was initially met with positive reviews, and has since grown to seven outlets across the island. Revenue is expected to grow 37% this year to S$14.5 million. The company has diversified its offerings with three other brands and focuses on kitchen processes, staff empowerment, and halal certification to maintain consistency and quality. GD Group aims to expand overseas with possible joint ventures or franchises in Indonesia, Hong Kong, and China.

site_title: Dollar firmer against yen, Swiss franc as stocks stabilise
summary: The dollar strengthened against the yen and Swiss franc, regaining some stability after a week of volatility. The euro remained steady at $1.1145. Investors remain cautious ahead of China's monthly economic update and the release of August global trade data. The dollar's rise was attributed to a relatively constructive US jobs report, but the euro's value is expected to be impacted by China's falling reserves.

site_title: UAE property crisis fears overblown: HSBC
summary: HSBC Holdings plc has downplayed fears of a crisis in the UAE real estate market, stating that the impact of weaker currencies and slowdown in transaction numbers is lower than reported. Transactions fell 15% in the UAE through August, with sales prices down 9% in Dubai. Foreign buyers, particularly Indians and Britons, remain unaffected by currency fluctuations. The possible removal of sanctions on Iranian buyers could boost demand for Dubai real estate. Contrary to reports of a 50% decline in transactions, the actual decline is around 20%.

site_title: GE2015: NSP's Kevryn Lim makes emotional call for benefits for single parents
summary: NSP candidate Kevryn Lim, a single mother herself, urged the government to provide benefits for single parents and maternity leave for single mothers, citing her personal experiences and those of others. Lim's emotional speech highlighted the need for equality and justice for single parents, who are also Singaporean citizens.

site_title: US: Markets closed for Labour Day
summary: US stock markets are closed on Monday for Labour Day and will resume trading on Tuesday. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks have continued their 5-day rally, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday. The rally is attributed to positive investor sentiment despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Redrawing boundaries costs town councils money: Sylvia Lim
summary: Singaporean Workers' Party (WP) chairman Sylvia Lim criticized the government's electoral boundary changes, which she claims cost residents money and favor the ruling People's Action Party (PAP). Lim singled out former PM Goh Chok Tong's policies, including pegging ministerial salaries to the private sector and increasing GRC sizes. She also targeted Minister Tan Chuan-Jin, suggesting his talents could still benefit Singapore even if he's not elected. The WP is contesting the Marine Parade GRC, where they aim to counter the PAP's strong presence.

site_title: Michael Dell sees consolidation among PC makers in next few years
summary: Michael Dell predicts that the top three global PC makers - Lenovo, Hewlett-Packard, and Dell - will consolidate to corner about 80% of the market in the next 5-7 years. This comes as personal computer sales decline. Dell attributes the trend to the shift towards mobile devices and cloud computing. The three companies are expected to raise their market shares through strategic partnerships and acquisitions.

site_title: Ringgit falls to new 1998 low as Asia selloff sends KLCI lower
summary: Malaysia's ringgit fell to a new 1998 low of 4.3300 against the US dollar, weakening 1.7% in Kuala Lumpur, amid a decline in Brent crude and narrowing trade surplus. The currency's decline was fueled by concerns over US interest-rate hikes and China's slowing economy. The FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI index also lost 0.4% as the country's foreign-exchange reserves fell to US$94.7 billion. The central bank is expected to keep interest rates unchanged at 3.25% when it meets later this week.

site_title: China to cut dividend taxes for long-term shareholders
summary: China has announced plans to cut dividend taxes for long-term shareholders. The new measures will exempt personal income tax on dividends for shareholders who hold shares for longer than a year. For those holding shares for less than a year but longer than a month, the tax will be reduced by 50%. The changes will take effect on September 8.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rebound from weekly drop as miners lead gains
summary: European stocks rebounded 0.5% to 354.81, reversing a weekly loss, after mixed US jobs data sparked concerns about a potential Federal Reserve rate increase. The market's focus shifted from China growth to the Fed's next move, with sentiment playing a key role. Analysts say nothing fundamentally changed, and volatility is expected to continue.

site_title: GE2015: 12 rallies on Tuesday, Sept 8, including lunchtime rally by PAP
summary: Singapore: On September 8, 2015, 12 rallies were permitted by the police, including a lunchtime rally by the People's Action Party (PAP) at the promenade plaza. The PAP secured the slot after losing out to the Singapore Democratic Party in the previous day's rally ballot.

site_title: HK property prices may correct next year: JPMorgan
summary: Hong Kong property prices may correct by 5-10% annually starting in 2016, according to JPMorgan Chase & Co. The economic slowdown in China and Hong Kong will weigh on real estate, with shrinking retail markets and rising unemployment affecting property sales. Residential prices of new homes will rise by 5% in 2015, while existing housing prices will increase by 10%. The economic health of Asia's financial capital has been weakened by a sharp contraction in the private sector and the weakest home sales in 17 months.

site_title: China exchanges plan circuit-breaker to "stabilise market"
summary: China's Shanghai and Shenzhen Stock Exchanges plan to introduce a 'circuit breaker' on the CSI300 index to stabilize the market. A 5% rise or fall in the index from the previous day's close before 2:30 pm will trigger a 30-minute suspension, while a 5% move after 2:30 pm will prompt a suspension until the market close. A 7% move will trigger a trade suspension for the rest of the day. The exchanges are seeking comments from market participants by September 21.

site_title: Germany pledges extra 6b euros for refugees as France vows to take 24,000
summary: Germany pledged an additional 6 billion euros (S$9.6 billion) to help refugees, with France vowing to take in 24,000 over the next two years. Chancellor Angela Merkel said the scenes of solidarity from Germans greeting refugees were "breathtaking." Under pressure from Paris and Berlin, the European Union is preparing fresh quotas, with Germany to take 31,443 and France 24,031 refugees, to relieve the burden on Greece, Italy, and Hungary.

site_title: Lizhong bidder's stake now at 86.98%
summary: Berkley International, owned by the Zang family, has acquired an 86.98% stake in Lizhong Wheel Group, nearing the 90% threshold to make the bid unconditional. The offer price is 50 Singapore cents per share, with shareholders having until October 2, 2015, to decide. The bid's effective ownership level surpasses the 90% trigger, indicating a likely takeover of the aluminium alloy wheel maker.

site_title: Geo Energy says no known explanation for shares' sharp drop
summary: Geo Energy Resources reported a 15.3% drop in its share price, with 8.45 million shares changing hands on Monday. The company was unaware of any undisclosed reasons for the sharp decline. The stock closed at 16 Singapore cents, down 2.9 Singapore cents from the previous day.

site_title: Palm oil prices to remain flat until year end: MPOC Chairman
summary: Palm oil prices are expected to remain flat until the end of 2015, according to Malaysian Palm Oil Council Chairman Lee Yeow Chor. The industry has faced a tough period this year, with prices hovering between RM2,300 and RM2,000 (US$531.48-US$462.16) due to a drop in financial markets. The prices hit a near three-week high on Monday due to exports and a weaker ringgit, but are still down 15% this year.

site_title: Hollande promises French voters 2b euros in tax relief
summary: French President Francois Hollande has pledged a new round of tax cuts worth 2 billion euros (US$2.23 billion) in 2016 to combat high unemployment and win back voters ahead of the 2017 presidential election. The cuts will benefit 16 million households, including the poorest and those already receiving tax relief. Hollande aims to cut unemployment, currently over 10%, and has set a durable turnaround as a condition for seeking a second mandate. The tax relief is expected to be financed by squeezing savings from the budget to meet EU deficit targets.

site_title: GE2015: Yee Jenn Jong says WP will directly manage Marine Parade Town Council if elected
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) has announced that if elected in the Marine Parade GRC, it will directly manage the Marine Parade Town Council. Team leader Yee Jenn Jong stated that the party's MPs and staff have town council operating experience, providing them with expertise to effectively manage the council.

site_title: Football: Prince says Fifa leaders knew about corruption
summary: Prince Ali bin al Hussein, a former Fifa vice president, claims that Fifa leaders knew about the corruption that has rocked the governing body. The prince, who led a challenge against current president Sepp Blatter, says the Fifa brand is "extremely damaged" and its leaders should take responsibility for the scandal. Prince Ali may still run for the Fifa presidency in February, despite Frenchman Michel Platini being the current favorite, and believes he can win if he stands.

site_title: French 2015 growth may top 1%, not strong enough: Hollande
summary: French President Francois Hollande stated that the country's economic growth may reach 1% in 2015, surpassing the official forecast, but is not strong enough to address high unemployment. Hollande also announced plans for a 2 billion euro tax cut in the 2016 budget, which would be funded by savings in other budget areas.

site_title: Seoul seen as Asia's new fashion showcase
summary: Seoul is emerging as Asia's new fashion showcase, with luxury firms seeking to capitalize on the region's trend-setting popularity of South Korean pop culture, known as the Hallyu. Fast-growing Asia, particularly China, drives the global luxury industry, accounting for one-third of global sales. The shift is attributed to Seoul's growing influence and consumer spending power, making it a key market for luxury firms.

images.alt_text: Leading global fashion houses have upped their game in South Korea in a bid to reach those well-heeled Asians who take their fashion cues from popular Korean TV and pop stars.

site_title: Will GOP again lose Asian-American vote?
summary: The article questions whether the GOP will lose the Asian-American vote again in future elections, citing the party's potentially less tolerant stance on racial minorities. In the 2012 US presidential election, President Barack Obama received 73% of the Asian-American vote, surpassing the 62% he received in 2008. This trend may be a concern for the GOP, as it suggests that the party's rhetoric could alienate Asian-American voters.

site_title: Apple ups hiring, but faces obstacles to making phones smarter
summary: Apple is ramping up its hiring of artificial intelligence experts, particularly in machine learning, to challenge Google's dominance in smartphone features. The company is recruiting PhDs and posting dozens of job listings, but experts say its strict stance on user privacy may hinder its ability to compete. Machine learning relies on vast data to provide personalized services, but Apple's approach of analyzing user data on individual devices rather than the cloud limits its capabilities. The company's strategy will be revealed on September 9, when it is expected to release new iPhones and mobile operating system iOS 9, which will include intelligent reminders and features.

site_title: Russia central bank to introduce new liquidity requirement for big banks from Jan 1
summary: Russia's central bank has decided to introduce new liquidity rules for systemically important banks, starting from January 1, 2019, with a minimum liquidity coverage ratio (LCR) of 70%. The LCR will increase by 10 percentage points each year, reaching 100% by 2019. This move aims to strengthen the banking system in line with the Basel III regulatory framework.

images.alt_text: Russia's central bank said on Monday it had formally decided to introduce new liquidity rules for systemically important banks related to the Basel III regulatory framework.

site_title: China lowers 2014's economic growth figure to 7.3%
summary: China's 2014 economic growth figure was lowered to 7.3% from 7.4%, marking the lowest since 1990. The country's stock exchanges are stabilizing after "bubbles" and painful corrections, with the National Bureau of Statistics citing a transition to domestic consumer demand-driven growth. Finance Minister Lou Jiwei stated that growth is expected to remain around 7% for four to five years. Despite a 40% decline in Chinese stocks since mid-June, authorities believe the market is nearing an end to its correction.
