site_title: Thailand's investment budget disbursements seen below target in fiscal year 2015
summary: Thailand's investment budget disbursements for fiscal year 2015 are expected to fall short of target, with only about 60% disbursed as of September. The total budget for 2015 is 2.575 trillion baht, with the investment portion at 451 billion baht. The finance ministry has eased rules on budget approvals for small-scale projects to boost disbursements in the next fiscal year. This slowdown in spending is attributed to the military government's efforts to drive growth through speedy government spending, but big infrastructure projects have stalled.

site_title: Raffles Medical Group to open first medical centre in Japan
summary: RAFFLES Medical Group (RMG) is opening its first medical centre in Japan, a 5,400-square-foot facility in Osaka's central business district. The centre will offer various medical services, including family medicine, travel medicine, and traditional Chinese medicine. RMG subsidiary Raffles Japanese Clinic will operate the facility in collaboration with Socion Healthcare Management. The announcement follows a 0.9% drop in RMG's shares on Monday.

site_title: ECB asset buying slows to weakest under QE in summer lull
summary: The European Central Bank's asset purchases in August slowed to the weakest since quantitative easing began in March, rising by 51.6 billion euros. This marks a decrease from July's 61 billion euros and June's 63 billion euros. The ECB aims to buy 60 billion euros of debt per month through September 2016 to revive euro-area inflation, with purchases potentially being frontloaded before December to maintain momentum.

images.alt_text: The European Central Bank will officially extend its asset purchase programme beyond September 2016 in yet another attempt to drive up inflation and rekindle growth, a Reuters poll found.

site_title: Indonesia's forex reserves fall to US$105.35b by end-August
summary: Indonesia's foreign exchange reserves dropped to $105.35 billion by end-August, down from $107.55 billion in July. The reserves, equivalent to 7.1 months of imports, were used to defend the fragile rupiah, which is Asia's second-worst performing currency. The decline was partially offset by government inflows from a samurai bond issue.

site_title: Commodity finance slump threatens global trading, report says
summary: A report by Clyde & Co finds that global trade finance has declined by half since 2008, with banks now accounting for only 50% of financing for commodities trading. Small and mid-sized traders are being squeezed, relying on alternative financing options such as private equity and trade-finance funds. The majority of respondents want to see a return to traditional "relationship" banking structures and more creativity in lending options, citing increased regulatory scrutiny and lending rules as a major factor.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed at 1,582.85, down 6.31 points, with 1.69 billion lots valued at RM1.53 billion traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 330 to 401.

site_title: BlackRock secures US$400m China investment quota boost
summary: BlackRock Inc, the world's largest asset manager, secured a US$400 million quota boost to invest in Chinese markets, taking its total QFII quota to US$1.25 billion. This move comes amid China's stock market volatility, with the government stepping in to revive investor confidence. The quota boost is one of the largest one-time approvals granted by Chinese authorities.

site_title: GE2015: People's Action Party "doing as it pleases" without effective opposition like the SDP: Chee Soon Juan
summary: Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) chief Chee Soon Juan claims the People's Action Party (PAP) "does as it pleases" without effective opposition in Parliament, citing failed investments such as a $2.5 billion loss on debt-ridden commodities trader Olam International. Chee criticizes the PAP's lack of accountability, particularly on healthcare spending, which the government announced as an additional $4 billion earlier this year. He argues that without opposition, the PAP makes "dangerous, wrong decisions" without proper scrutiny.

site_title: Global copper market to see shortage in 2-3 years: Rio Tinto
summary: Global copper markets are expected to experience a structural shortage within 2-3 years due to increasing demand from power stations, according to Rio Tinto's CEO Jean-Sebastien Jacques. Currently, copper prices are at a six-year low, but Jacques predicts tighter supply will help drive prices up. Despite an oversupply forecast this year and next, Rio Tinto plans to produce over 500 million tonnes of copper this year, driven primarily by the power sector's growing demand for the metal.

site_title: Baidu to boost spending on India, Indonesia as mobile sales boom
summary: Baidu plans to boost investments in India and Indonesia as the company seeks to expand its presence in the smartphone market. The move comes as China's largest web search provider faces competition from Alibaba and Tencent. Baidu's spending will focus on minority stakes and full acquisitions, with an interest in the local education and medical sectors. The company aims to capture 30% of an online educational loans market valued at 10 billion yuan annually, and has already issued 100 million yuan in loans since launching its lending program.

site_title: Singapore shares close weaker as China weakness overshadows Dow futures' rise
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 11.4 points to 2,852.41, its fifth decline in six sessions, due to China's stock market weakness. The index was influenced by China's volatile session and Dow Jones futures rising 100 points, suggesting a Wall Street rebound. The STI's only rise in the past six sessions was last Thursday. Trading volumes were low at 840 million units worth S$834 million.

site_title: Indonesia more exposed to capital flight than Malaysia, S&P says
summary: Indonesia is more exposed to capital flight than Malaysia, according to Standard & Poor's. Indonesia's foreign-exchange reserves have fallen 9% in six months, while its benchmark stock gauge has lost 16% over the past three months. In contrast, Malaysia's economy is considered sounder, with a current-account surplus and a positive net international investment position. The rupiah has weakened 5.1% since the end of July, less than half the 12% slide in the ringgit. Analysts warn that Indonesia's reliance on foreign funding makes it vulnerable to shifts in outflows and inflows, and that its credit rating remains at BB+.

site_title: China's offshore yuan slides after record-high drop in forex reserves
summary: China's offshore yuan slid to around 6.49 per dollar after the country's foreign exchange reserves dropped by a record $93.9 billion in August, trading at its deepest discount to the onshore rate since 2011. The central bank stepped up intervention to stabilize the yuan after a surprise devaluation last month, amid concerns about its economic slowdown and interest rate hike by the US Federal Reserve. The offshore yuan's discount to the onshore rate widened to 1.89%, indicating further depreciation is expected.

site_title: China said to group state firms as commercial or not for profit
summary: China has issued new guidelines for state-owned enterprises, dividing them into two groups: commercially orientated enterprises that will sell equity stakes and seek stock listings, and those focused on not-for-profit operations that will remain in state control. The reform guidelines aim to map out detailed plans for tens of thousands of companies with estimated assets of $16 trillion, potentially affecting urban employment and the stock market. The move is part of China's largest overhaul of its bloated businesses since the late 1990s, with current supervisors shifting to state capital management and leadership enhancements for the communist party.

site_title: StanChart Singapore names group wealth management head as CEO
summary: Standard Chartered Bank Singapore has appointed Judy Hsu as its new CEO, replacing Neeraj Swaroop, who will leave the bank to pursue other opportunities. Hsu, who joined the bank in 2009 and is currently group head of wealth management, will report to Ajay Kanwal, regional CEO of Asean and South Asia. The appointment comes as the bank faces declining profits and is reorganizing its operations, with 4,000 staff cuts already implemented. Hsu will be responsible for developing and executing the bank's strategy in Singapore.

site_title: QT Vascular earns CE mark nod for drug-coated balloon catheter
summary: QT Vascular has received CE mark clearance in Europe for its Chocolate Touch peripheral drug-coated balloon catheter. The medical device maker will begin commercial sales in European countries accepting the CE mark. The news led to a 7.5% decline in QT Vascular's shares, closing at 8.6 Singapore cents on Monday. The CE mark clearance marks a significant milestone for QT Vascular, paving the way for its entry into European markets.

site_title: Blumont slashes rights offering price from 0.675 cent to 0.2 cent
summary: Blumont Group has reduced the price of its rights offering from 0.675 Singapore cent to 0.2 Singapore cent per rights share due to recent market conditions. The company is offering one rights share for every two existing shares held, resulting in a net proceeds raise of S$2.76 million instead of the initial S$9.57 million. The use of proceeds remains unchanged, with 70% allocated to repaying a loan and 30% for working capital.

site_title: HKMA sells HK$3.1b to keep Hong Kong dollar in trading band
summary: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) intervened in the currency market, selling HK$3.1 billion (US$400 million) to keep the Hong Kong dollar within its trading range. The move comes as the local currency hit the strong end of its band, pegged at 7.8 to the US dollar. The HKMA aims to maintain the band's integrity, which requires intervention when the currency reaches 7.75 or 7.85. The sale will lift the aggregate balance to HK$326.932 billion by September 9.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Monday
summary: Standard Chartered Bank Singapore has appointed Judy Hsu as its new CEO, effective October 1, 2015. Goh Eng Wah, a renowned entrepreneur and cinema industry pioneer, passed away at 92. Temasek Holdings has partnered with Saudi Arabia's Savola Group to bid for Kuwait Food Co., a Middle Eastern fast-food operator, in a potential US$4-5 billion deal. Meanwhile, Singapore shares closed weaker, with the STI losing 11.4 points, as China's economic slowdown overshadowed Dow futures' rise.

images.alt_text: Standard Chartered is among three lenders that China's central bank last week suspended from conducting some foreign exchange business until the end of March, two sources with direct knowledge told Reuters on Wednesday.

site_title: ESM's Regling says confident IMF will participate in Greek programme
summary: The head of the European Stability Mechanism, Klaus Regling, expressed confidence that the International Monetary Fund (IMF) will participate in Greece's third aid program, despite previous debates over debt burden. Regling stated that although the IMF's share in Greece's aid is declining, it will continue to play a role in helping EU states. He also argued that a full fiscal union is not necessary for the eurozone to function effectively, suggesting that monetary union can work well without it.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks end lower as data eyed
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stock markets ended lower on Monday as investors await fresh Chinese economic data, fearing weak figures will spark more turmoil. In Hong Kong, the Hang Seng Index fell 1.23%, while in Shanghai, the benchmark index declined 2.52%. The Shenzhen Composite Index edged up 0.20%. Dealers are cautious ahead of the data release, which is expected to impact the markets.

site_title: China freezes outbound investment quotas as outflows hurt yuan
summary: China has frozen outbound investment quotas for a fifth month, the longest halt in six years, as authorities seek to curb the yuan's weakness and stem outflows. The State Administration of Foreign Exchange has not granted new allocations since March, with quotas rising to US$140.3 billion. This move aims to prevent further depreciation pressure and maintain the yuan's reserve status with the International Monetary Fund. The freeze is also seen as a response to China's economic slowdown and the exodus of funds from the country's stock market, which has tumbled 40% since this year's peak.

site_title: ECB sets capital requirements for eurozone's top lenders
summary: The European Central Bank's supervisory arm has set capital requirements for the eurozone's top lenders, covering most of the 123 banks under supervision. The decisions were made during a supervisory board meeting and will be communicated to the banks within two weeks. The move aims to strengthen the financial stability of the eurozone's largest lenders, but no specific details on the capital levels were disclosed.

site_title: Emerging currencies drop as ambiguity on Fed timing hurts stocks
summary: Emerging-market currencies declined, with Malaysia's ringgit hitting a 17-year low and Turkey's lira plummeting to a record, amid uncertainty over the Federal Reserve's interest-rate timing. Stocks fell to a two-week low as investors shifted risk-averse assets following China's devaluation and weakening global trade outlook. The 20-developing nation currency gauge dropped 0.3% for a fifth consecutive day, with other currencies such as the Malaysian ringgit and Turkish lira also experiencing significant declines.

site_title: Au Optronics makes tender offer to repurchase convertible bonds
summary: Au Optronics Corp has issued a tender offer to repurchase its US$287.5 million zero coupon convertible bonds due 2015 from bondholders. The purchase price is US$115,840 per US$100,000 principal amount. The tender offer starts on September 7 and ends on September 21. This move is part of the company's efforts to actively manage its balance sheet.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: German industrial production rises in July
summary: German industrial production rose 0.7% in July, exceeding the 0.3% month-on-month increase, but fell short of analysts' 1.1% expectations. Energy output surged 1.9% and construction output rose 3.2%. However, industrial orders declined 1.4% due to weak demand outside the euro area.

site_title: Aussie climbs as Chinese officials signal confidence in economy
summary: Australia's dollar rose 0.4% to 69.35 US cents after Chinese officials signaled confidence in their economy, citing stabilizing stocks and the yuan. The move came after People's Bank of China Governor Zhou Xiaochuan stated that the stock market correction was almost done. The Aussie dollar advanced against all 16 major counterparts, while the yen weakened for the first time in three days. The Shanghai Composite Index closed 2.5% lower, and Europe's Stoxx 600 Index climbed 0.7%. The relief in markets was seen as a response to China's efforts to soothe concerns over its economy.

site_title: Taiwan dollar volatility jumps to 2011 high on rate uncertainty
summary: Taiwan's dollar volatility surged to its highest in almost four years, reaching 9.60% on September 7, amid uncertainty over interest-rate decisions by the Federal Reserve and the island's central bank. US mixed jobs data added to the uncertainty, with fewer jobs added than forecast, fueling speculation of a potential rate cut by Taiwan's central bank. Economists predict a rate cut by year-end, with eight of 21 surveyed economists predicting a lower policy rate. This move could lead to excessive outflows if the US tightens policy.

site_title: Goldman-led group buys 1.6 bln stg of UK loans from Barclays
summary: Barclays Plc has sold a 1.6 billion pound portfolio of UK loans to a group led by Goldman Sachs Group Inc. as part of its efforts to reduce non-core assets to 20 billion pounds by 2017. The sale is part of the bank's strategy to shed unwanted assets and focus on core operations. This move follows Barclays' previous reduction of non-core assets to 57 billion pounds by the end of June.

site_title: China FX reserves fall record US$93.9b in Aug as central bank supports yuan
summary: China's foreign exchange reserves fell by a record US$93.9 billion in August to US$3.557 trillion, amid efforts to stabilize the yuan currency after a surprise devaluation. The People's Bank of China intervened to support the yuan. Meanwhile, China's gold reserves rose to US$61.8 billion. The drop in foreign exchange reserves was expected and marks the largest monthly fall on record.

site_title: OECD says too early to see yuan devaluation as attempt to boost exports
summary: A senior OECD official stated it's too early to conclude China's recent yuan devaluations are aimed at boosting exports, citing the devaluations' small scope. The official emphasized the need for China to implement structural reforms for stable and sustainable economic growth.

images.alt_text: A senior official at the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development said on Monday that it was too early to interpret China's recent yuan devaluations as an attempt to boost its exports.

site_title: China grants five non-major refiners quotas for imported crude oil
summary: China has granted five non-major refiners nearly 400,000 barrels per day in quotas for imported crude oil as part of reforms to increase competition in the sector. The refiners, four in Shandong and one in Ningxia, must meet environmental conditions to receive the quotas. The government aims to open up the crude import market, allowing refiners to import crude directly without using state traders. This move follows previous approvals for two other refiners, who also received licenses to handle their own shipments. The reforms are part of China's efforts to increase competition and reduce state control.

site_title: Australia: Shares slip but find some support from Qantas, utilities
summary: Australian shares slipped 0.2% on Monday, with gains in healthcare and utilities offsetting losses in banks and miners. Qantas Airways rose 1.7% after CEO Alan Joyce's comments on a trade pact, while the S&P/ASX 200 index fell 10.2 points to 5,030.4. New Zealand's benchmark NZX 50 index gained 0.5%. The decline follows a 0.25% rise on Friday.

site_title: China: Stocks tumble after volatile day
summary: China's stocks plummeted 3.4% on Monday, closing at 3,250.49, after a volatile day following a four-day market holiday. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 2.5% to 3,080.42 points. Key losers included ICBC (-8.9%), Agricultural Bank Of China (-7.4%), and China Shipbuilding (-5.6%). Total trading volume in Shanghai was 29.6 billion shares, while Shenzhen saw 22.8 billion shares.

site_title: Tensions at Nobel Design shareholder meeting over long-standing governance claims
summary: The board members of Singapore-listed furniture and property company Nobel Design faced criticism at its extraordinary general meeting over its revised 2014 financial statements. Shareholders questioned the accuracy of the original statements, despite the resolution passing. The revision was seen as proof of inaccuracy by some attendees. The meeting was held to seek shareholder approval for the revised financial statements.

site_title: Update: Asia markets on edge ahead of China data
summary: Asian markets were on edge on Monday as Shanghai led most markets lower due to a revised China growth figure and upcoming economic data. The US jobs report reduced interest rate hike chances, supporting the Australian dollar. G20 finance ministers pledged to support economic growth and avoid a currency war. China's economy grew at 7.3% last year, slower than initially thought, and more soft readings could fan selling fears of a "hard landing." Markets await China's release of more data this week to gauge the economy's state.

site_title: Uber's China rival said to raise US$3b in latest financing
summary: Didi Kuaidi, a Chinese car-booking business, is reportedly raising $3 billion in its latest financing round, valuing the company at $16.5 billion. This comes as the company competes with Uber in the Chinese market, where both companies are offering incentives to attract drivers and riders. Didi Kuaidi plans to spend $1 billion in China this year, while Uber also plans to invest $1 billion in the country. The companies are part of a growing transportation services market in China, estimated to be worth $1 trillion annually.

images.alt_text: Didi Kuaidi, the Chinese car-booking business competing with Uber Technologies Inc, is close to raising about US$3 billion as it completes its latest round of financing, according to people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Eurozone Sentix index slumps to 7-month low in September
summary: The Eurozone Sentix index, tracking investor and analyst morale, plummeted to a 7-month low of 13.6 in September, down from 18.4 in August. The index, which measures economic expectations, fell to 12.3, its lowest level since December 2014. China's slowdown, particularly in Germany, which has significant trade exposure to China, contributed to the decline. Sentix cited concerns over the eurozone's economy, which cannot be compensated by domestic growth or the US economy, as the primary factor. This weakened economic outlook raises uncertainty for the eurozone.

images.alt_text: French Prime Minister Manuel Valls warned on Thursday that it would be a "very bad thing" if Britain left the EU, but warned that British demands cannot be met at any price.

site_title: GM posts fourth China sales drop in five months as slump deepens
summary: General Motors reported its fourth consecutive month of declining sales in China, with 248,815 vehicles sold in August, a 4.8% drop from last year. The company attributed the decline to "softness in the overall vehicle market." This slump deepens GM's exposure to the slowdown in China's car sales, contributing to its stock hitting a nearly 2 1/2 year low. GM had previously cut its outlook for annual industrywide sales growth in China to the low single-digit range.

site_title: Hot stocks: Ezra, YuuZoo among most actively traded on Monday
summary: Ezra Holdings' stock was among the most actively traded on the Singapore bourse, with 44 million shares changing hands worth S$5.7 million. The company announced a contract with BHP Billiton for the Angostura phase 3 development project in offshore Trinidad and Tobago. Its subsea services division EMAS AMC will provide the services. The stock remained unchanged at 13 Singapore cents.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Europe: Shares rebound, Glencore surges on plans to cut debt
summary: European shares rose 1.1% on Monday after a 2.5% decline the previous session, driven by a 10% surge in Glencore shares. The mining and commodities firm announced plans to cut its debt by a third to $20 billion by the end of next year, including suspending dividends, selling assets, and raising $2.5 billion in a new share issue. Glencore's shares surged as copper and coal prices hit six-year lows, putting pressure on the company to reduce its debt.

site_title: Indonesia migrant boat death toll rises to 61
summary: A boat carrying Indonesian migrant workers sank off Malaysia, resulting in 61 deaths. The vessel was overloaded and capsized due to bad weather, with only 20 survivors. Most of the victims were men, including one toddler, and were on their way home for the Eid al-Adha holiday. The incident occurred amid a larger migrant crisis in Southeast Asia, with thousands of people left stranded at sea.

site_title: Western sanctions sting Russian oil firms: Lukoil head
summary: Western sanctions imposed on Russia have negatively impacted domestic oil producers, particularly Lukoil, the country's largest independent oil producer. Lukoil president Vagit Alekperov stated that the sanctions have reduced access to foreign financial markets and increased borrowing costs, making it difficult to form consortia with foreign companies for complex projects. As a result, Russia has turned to Asia, especially China, for commercial ties, seeking alternative markets and investment opportunities.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices may begin drop in 2016: JPMorgan
summary: Hong Kong's property prices may correct next year, with residential prices potentially falling 5-10% annually starting in 2016, according to JPMorgan Chase & Co. The economic slowdown in China and Hong Kong will weigh on real estate, driven by a shrinking retail market and rising unemployment. Despite strong demand, prices of new homes will rise 5% in 2015 and existing housing will increase 10%. The outlook is influenced by global concerns over China's growth and US interest rates.

site_title: GE2015: SBS Transit to extend operating hours for rail lines and selected bus services
summary: SBS Transit will extend operating hours for its North East, Downtown, Sengkang, and Punggol rail lines on the eve of Polling Day (Sept 10), with train services extended by about 30 minutes. This move aims to accommodate voters.

site_title: Beijing admits stock bubbles, says routs almost over
summary: China's central bank governor and market regulator have acknowledged that stock market bubbles existed in the country, with a 70% increase in the Shanghai Composite Index in March-June 2015. The market has since plummeted 40% due to government interventions, but is now showing signs of recovery. The government has spent hundreds of billions of dollars to prop up stock prices, but investors worry about the cost and limited impact on the real economy. The regulator has reassured traders that it will take decisive measures to stabilize the market.

site_title: Seoul: Won reaches weakest intraday level in nearly 4 yrs; shares slip
summary: The South Korean won reached its weakest intraday level in nearly four years, closing down 0.9% to 1,203.7 per dollar, amid dollar demand linked to Tesco's planned sale of its Homeplus unit. Foreigners continued to sell South Korean shares, marking the 23rd consecutive session, with a net 4.69 trillion won (S$5.6 billion) sold. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) also edged down 0.2% to 1,883.22 points.

site_title: US: Stock markets closed on Monday for holiday
summary: US stock markets closed on Monday for the Labour Day holiday, reopening on Tuesday with a normal schedule. In other markets, Singapore stocks extended a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while traders brushed off new Trump threats to extend stocks rally in Asia. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records in the US, despite tariff uncertainty, and the STI rose 0.4% on Thursday. Airalo raised $220 million in new funding, lifting its valuation past $1 billion.

site_title: Japan's Abe unlikely to tackle hard reforms in next term: economists
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is likely to win a second consecutive term, but economists predict he won't push through hard reforms such as labour market changes. Instead, Abe will focus on government spending and monetary easing to boost growth, with 15 economists polled by Reuters saying regulatory reform of the labour market and repairing the social security system are priorities. Abe's government will likely increase the budget and consider more monetary easing, but economists expect these measures to be insufficient to address Japan's stagnant economy.

images.alt_text: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe looks set to win a rare second consecutive term but economists predict he won't use that victory to push through bold reforms such as labour market changes that are considered vital for long-term growth.

site_title: Temasek teams up with Saudi partner in bid for fast-food firm: report
summary: Singapore's Temasek Holdings has teamed up with Saudi Arabia's Savola Group to bid for Kuwait Food Co., a Middle Eastern fast-food operator, in a deal potentially valued at $4-5 billion. The bid comes after Savola previously attempted to acquire Americana, Kuwait Food's parent company, in 2014. Talks between the three companies are ongoing, with JPMorgan Chase advising Savola on the talks. Temasek seeks to broaden its investments in consumer companies, while Savola aims to expand its market value, which stands at around $8.5 billion.

site_title: To lure Chinese shoppers, luxury brands up their game in Seoul
summary: Luxury brands are shifting their focus to Seoul as a key market in Asia, capitalizing on the region's trend-setting popularity of South Korean pop culture. With Chinese consumers accounting for one-third of global luxury sales, brands are increasingly targeting this demographic. Seoul is emerging as a major fashion showcase, with top luxury firms such as Adidas and Puma eyeing the city for their next big move. The city's influence on global fashion is expected to continue growing, making it an attractive destination for luxury brands looking to tap into the Asian market.

site_title: Lufthansa hit by new pilots' strike on long-haul, freight services
summary: Pilots at Lufthansa will stage a new strike on Tuesday, affecting long-haul passenger services and freight operations, in their dispute over early retirement provisions. This is the 13th strike in 18 months. The strike, which will last from 0600 to 2200 GMT, only affects Lufthansa and not its other airlines within the group. The dispute began in April 2014.

images.alt_text: Pilots at German airline Lufthansa said Monday they will stage new walkouts on freight and long-haul passenger services on Tuesday in their long-running dispute with management over early retirement provisions.

site_title: StanChart said to name Hsu to replace Swaroop as Singapore CEO
summary: Standard Chartered Plc is set to appoint Judy Hsu, its global wealth management head, as Singapore CEO, replacing Neeraj Swaroop, who has resigned after turning down the offer to oversee India. The move is part of CEO Bill Winters' plan to reverse a two-year profit slide, including merging regional jobs and reducing senior banking positions. Hsu, who joined in 2009, will take over from Swaroop, who had previously led the bank's India and South Asia operations.

site_title: Tesco sells South Korean unit for more than 4b pounds
summary: Tesco has agreed to sell its South Korean unit, Homeplus, to a consortium led by MBK Partners for more than £4 billion (S$8.6 billion). The sale comes as Tesco seeks to overhaul its business after reporting its biggest annual loss in nearly 100 years. The deal is part of Tesco's efforts to cut costs and focus on its core UK business.

site_title: Greek opposition leader says would join coalition with Tsipras
summary: Greek opposition leader Evangelos Meimarakis announced he would invite rival Alexis Tsipras to form a coalition to safeguard Greece's eurozone membership, regardless of election results. With polls indicating a close outcome between Syriza and New Democracy, coalition talks may be necessary to implement the country's third bailout. Meimarakis criticized Tsipras for seeking a bailout and holding snap elections, and expressed confidence in his own party's ability to pass needed reforms.

site_title: Entrepreneur Goh Eng Wah dies at 92
summary: Entrepreneur Goh Eng Wah, founder of Eng Wah Global, died on September 5 at 92. He pioneered Singapore's cinema industry and was the executive chairman and founder of Eng Wah Global, spanning entertainment, property, hospitality, and lifestyle sectors. Goh's 70-year entertainment empire included iconic businesses like Happy Theatre and Silver World Theatre. He was described as an "illustrious entrepreneur" who contributed to Singapore's post-war entertainment industry.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Seoul: Won slips to almost 4-yr low on Fed uncertainty; shares choppy
summary: The South Korean won slipped to nearly four years low against the US dollar, down 0.4% at 1,198.5 per dollar, due to uncertainty over the Federal Reserve's first rate hike in a decade. A mixed US jobs report provided mixed signals, but an improvement in wages bolstered market consensus of a rate hike in September. Seoul shares were choppy, with Samsung Electronics losing 1.6% and Hyundai Motor gaining 1.7%. The won is expected to breach 1,200 per dollar and touch 1,210 for the week.

site_title: Greek crisis prompts a rethink on food waste
summary: In response to Greece's economic crisis, a grassroots movement is reducing food waste by redistributing unsold food to charities, providing an average of 2,500 meals daily. Founded by Xenia Papastavrou, Boroume ("We Can") matches donated food with those in need, challenging traditional attitudes of food waste. The movement is also promoting affordable, locally-sourced food through cooperatives, with prices 10-15% lower than supermarkets. As the country faces poverty and unemployment, this initiative aims to foster a sense of community and shared responsibility in addressing the crisis.

site_title: Queen Elizabeth II goes low-key for record reign landmark
summary: Queen Elizabeth II will mark her record 63 years, seven months, and two days on the throne by riding a steam train in Scotland and hosting a dinner at Balmoral Castle with Prince William and Kate. This event will surpass her great-great-grandmother Queen Victoria's 63-year reign. The ceremony is a low-key celebration, following the public interest in the historic date.

site_title: China's banks getting less strict on bad loans, Moody's says
summary: China's banks are becoming less strict in recognizing bad loans, according to Moody's Investors Service. Despite a 77 basis point increase in 90-day delinquencies, the overall bad-loan numbers remain understated. This may drag on Chinese lenders' shares, as investors worry about the true extent of bad debts. Moody's suggests that Chinese banks' profits will deteriorate further in the second half due to bad loans and declining net interest margins and fee income.

site_title: Indonesia to not relax mineral export ban in new stimulus policy package
summary: Indonesia will not relax its mineral export ban in its upcoming economic stimulus policy package, according to Mining Minister Sudirman Said. The ban, which was previously proposed to allow nickel and bauxite shipments to spur smelter developments, has been cancelled due to concerns over legal and environmental risks. This decision comes as Indonesia works on a stimulus package to spur economic growth.

site_title: Asia: Markets on edge ahead of China data
summary: Asian markets opened cautiously on Monday, September 7, 2015, amid China's revised 2014 growth figure and upcoming economic data releases. The US jobs report showed weaker-than-expected numbers, reducing the likelihood of an interest rate hike and supporting the Australian dollar. G20 finance ministers pledged to boost economic growth and avoid a currency war.

site_title: China cuts 2014 GDP growth from 7.4% to 7.3%: govt
summary: China's National Bureau of Statistics lowered its 2014 GDP growth figure from 7.4% to 7.3%, the lowest since 1990. The decrease comes amid concerns over slowing growth in the world's second-largest economy. China's economy has been struggling with a rebalancing from an investment- and export-led model to a domestic consumer-driven model. The move has sparked global market concerns, with investors worried about a potential "hard landing" for China's economy.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks open lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Monday, following a mixed US jobs report. The Hang Seng Index eased 0.75% to 20,683.31, while Shanghai's benchmark composite index retreated 0.34% to 3,149.38. The Shenzhen Composite Index, however, gained 0.91%. The mixed market reaction was attributed to the extended holiday weekend in China.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks up on Chinese gains; tech components up
summary: Taiwan's main stock index rose 0.4% to 8,032.66 points on Monday, following a calm session in Chinese markets. The electronics subindex rose 0.5%, while the financials subindex increased 0.3%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$32.651 per US dollar. The gains were attributed to a senior Chinese regulator's statement that markets were more stable and risks associated with high leverage had eased.

site_title: China: Stocks rise at market open as regulators calm investors
summary: China's major stock indexes rose in early trading on Monday as regulators calmed investors with a statement that markets are more stable and leverage risks have eased. The CSI300 index gained 0.6% to 3,385.40 points, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.9% to 3,188.58 points. The Hang Seng index in Hong Kong also increased 0.8% to 21,016.56 points. The move follows a period of high volatility in the Chinese market.

site_title: Update: China Essence requests trading halt
summary: China Essence Group's counter was halted as it sought more time to provide additional information to shareholders. The halt came after a UK consultant's preliminary search found "unauthorised transactions" in at least two subsidiaries by the firm's former executive chairman and CEO, Zhao Libin. Zhao admitted to the transactions, which were not reported in the company's first quarter results, and attributed them to "long-standing debts" owed to farmers. The company's new directors have no prior knowledge of the transactions.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Monday, down 11.88 points to 1578.5. Volume reached 33.37 million lots worth RM13.4 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 118 to 58.

site_title: "Thaksinomics" return as Thai junta rethinks revival strategy
summary: The Thai junta has shifted its economic revival strategy to employ populist measures, known as "Thaksinomics," to boost rural spending and stimulate growth. The 136 billion baht stimulus package includes village microloans, sub-district spending, and small projects to revive the economy, which has been stagnant due to weak exports and factory output. Deputy Prime Minister Somkid Jatusripitak, architect of "Thaksinomics," has promised to relaunch the One Tambon One Product initiative and is not concerned about a backlash, believing that grassroots economic growth is crucial for the country's survival.

site_title: Asian stocks extend retreat with oil as Chinese markets resume
summary: Asian stocks continued their retreat, with the Asia-Pacific benchmark set for its lowest close since November 2012. Futures pointed to a decline in Chinese equities following a holiday break, with copper and nickel slipping. Oil fell 1.5% to $45.37 a barrel, while the yen maintained gains after posting its biggest advance of 2015. China's yuan climbed 0.2% in offshore trading, and officials predicted stabilisation in the currency and stock markets. The US added fewer workers than expected in Friday's nonfarm payrolls report, fueling bets on a rate hike in September.

images.alt_text: The slump in stocks and commodities continued into Asian trading, with futures pointing to a selloff in Chinese equities following a holiday break.

site_title: Steve Jobs movie starring Michael Fassbender wins critical praise, Oscar buzz
summary: A biopic about Apple co-founder Steve Jobs, starring Michael Fassbender, has received critical praise and Oscar buzz. The film, directed by Danny Boyle and written by Aaron Sorkin, has been described as a "terrific actors' showcase" and an "incorrigibly entertaining ride". Fassbender's performance has been singled out as a "no-brainer best actor Oscar contender". The movie is expected to be a must-see attraction in the fall season, with a potential Oscar run.

site_title: GE2015: 18 designated assembly centres for Polling Day
summary: The Singapore Police released a list of 18 designated assembly centres for Polling Day on September 11, 2015. Candidates, supporters, and the public can gather at these centres to await results after polls close at 8pm. The assembly centres can be applied for permits at the Police Elections Permit Office between September 9-10.

site_title: Gaming outlook in Singapore, Malaysia stable: Fitch
summary: Rating firm Fitch Ratings has stated that the gaming sector in Singapore and Malaysia remains stable despite declining visitor arrivals and lower win rates. The robust earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA) numbers of integrated resorts in both countries support this conclusion. Genting Malaysia and Genting Singapore, both in a net cash position, have high days receivable but plan to fund expansion through a combination of debt and cash. Fitch expects these measures to maintain the companies' credit profiles.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Ringgit falls to new low since 1998 after US jobs data, oil price drop
summary: The ringgit currency has fallen to a new 1998 low after the US jobless rate reached a seven-year low and oil prices continued to decline. The drop was attributed to risk-off in financial markets due to concerns over slowing Chinese economic growth and the Federal Reserve's plan to raise interest rates. The ringgit weakened 1% to 4.3030 a dollar, with analysts predicting no change in the benchmark interest rate from 3.25% but a possible 25 basis-point increase.

site_title: China Essence reports unauthorised transactions in 2 units
summary: China Essence Group announced that a UK consultant discovered "unauthorised transactions" in at least two subsidiaries, attributed to its former executive chairman and CEO, Zhao Libin. The transactions involved transferring shares to the local government to settle debts owed by the subsidiaries to farmers, who had rioted at a factory. The company's new directors and non-executive chairman have no prior knowledge of the transactions, and the board will take action after seeking advice from authorities and legal advisers.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Straightforward French fare
summary: A new Balzac Brasserie, a French restaurant, has been opened in Cox Terrace. The restaurant, created by Jean-Charles Dubois, recreates French classics to good effect. The exact location and address of the restaurant are provided, along with a call for feedback on BT's products and services.

site_title: Oil prices down in Asian trade
summary: Oil prices declined in Asian trade on Monday, dropping 35 US cents to US$45.70 for West Texas Intermediate and 38 US cents to US$49.23 for Brent crude. The move comes as dealers await the US Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates following a mixed August jobs report. The US Labor Department reported fewer than estimated 173,000 jobs added in August. The decline is attributed to a bearish outlook due to US President Trump's tariff policies.

images.alt_text: AP Moeller-Maersk A/S's oil unit cut US$1 billion off its annual budget for capital expenditure after petroleum prices plunged.

site_title: Ezra's subsea arm awarded project in offshore Trinidad
summary: EZRA Holdings' subsea services division EMAS AMC has finalized a contract with BHP Billiton for the Angostura phase 3 development project in offshore Trinidad and Tobago. The contract involves project management, fabrication, construction, and installation of subsea structures, with offshore execution scheduled for mid-2016. EMAS AMC's Houston office is currently working on engineering and procurement, with fabrication and installation to take place in Texas and offshore, respectively. No contract value was disclosed.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Asset-backed debt losses mount as Draghi support proves feeble
summary: European asset-backed debt losses are mounting, with the market poised for its first annual decline since 2011. Despite Mario Draghi's endorsement of the debt last year, investors have seen losses of an average 0.5% through September 3. The European Central Bank's attempts to encourage lending have underwhelmed investors, with some securities experiencing a reversal of gains after initial rallies. The Greek debt crisis and Chinese equity market turmoil have also contributed to losses, with the market's spread widening to an average of 96 basis points.

site_title: With an eye on safe tech solutions
summary: Zweec Analytics, a Singapore-based company specializing in video and data analytics, has deployed its technology in various settings across the island to ensure safety. The company's early warning management system, AquaTEC, has been used to monitor water quality and detect abnormal fish behavior, enabling faster response times. Zweec has expanded its applications beyond water safety, implementing its smart surveillance system in pools to detect distress and prevent drowning fatalities, as well as in public spaces to detect suspicious behavior. The company is also venturing into providing safe drinking water through its "bring your own bottle" concept, IONI Water, which is expected to generate more than half of its total revenue in the next three years.

site_title: YuuZoo secures S$30m funding from GEM Global
summary: YuuZoo Corp has secured a S$30 million funding facility for three years from GEM Global Yield Fund. The facility will be drawn down at a 10% discount of YuuZoo shares' closing price. The agreement also includes the issuance of 55 million warrants and a one-off commitment fee of S$450,000. YuuZoo will control the timing and maximum drawdown, with GEM Global's holding limit set at 19.9% of YuuZoo shares. The agreement was signed on September 4, with shareholder approval required for the warrant issuance.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Dollar nurses losses after US jobs offer little clarity on Fed move
summary: The US dollar experienced losses on Monday following mixed employment data that failed to provide clarity on the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike. Nonfarm payrolls rose 173,000, but the unemployment rate dropped to a 7-1/2-year low, with wages accelerating. The dollar added 0.1% against the yen, while the euro gained 0.1% against the US dollar, amid concerns about global equities and China's slowing economy. Speculators cut back on bullish bets on the US dollar, with the dollar index remaining nearly flat.

site_title: China freezes outbound investment quotas as outflows hurt yuan
summary: China has frozen outbound investment quotas for the fifth consecutive month in August, as authorities seek to curb yuan depreciation and stem capital outflows. The decision, made by the State Administration of Foreign Exchange, comes amid a slowdown in China's economy and a weakening yuan, which has traded 1.4% weaker outside of China than inside the country. The move is part of China's efforts to stabilize the currency and prevent further outflows of funds, while also trying to open up its capital account to gain reserve status from the International Monetary Fund.

site_title: China stocks regulator says to deepen reforms, markets more stable
summary: China's stocks regulator plans to deepen market reforms and bolster supervision, aiming to stabilize the market and reduce risks associated with high leverage. Following a 40% decline in China's stock markets since mid-June, the regulator says it will implement measures to halt trading in response to substantial drops, such as a "circuit breaker" system. The move aims to restore market stability and prevent government intervention, which the regulator believes is not necessary in normal market conditions.

site_title: Singapore shares open 27 points lower on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 27.22 points to 2,836.59 on Monday, as the benchmark opened 48 million shares worth S$89 million. The decline follows US stock indices falling last Friday due to a mixed August jobs report. The US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision remains uncertain, and Wall Street will be closed on Monday for the Labor Day long weekend.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: New runway at Heathrow 'will fail on every level', says London mayor
summary: London Mayor Boris Johnson has criticized the Airports Commission's proposal to build a third runway at Heathrow Airport, calling it "doomed to fail" and stating it would not solve capacity issues. The report found that the expansion would lead to decline, rather than growth. Johnson has instead suggested building a new airport in the Thames Estuary, known as "Boris Island". The decision is expected to be made by Prime Minister David Cameron, who has ruled out serving a third term and has pledged not to allow a third runway at Heathrow.

site_title: YouTube to provide viewability of ads to advertisers: Financial Times
summary: YouTube plans to provide advertisers with viewability data on its ads by the end of this year, in response to complaints from advertisers including Unilever and Kellogg Co. The data will be collected through third-party verification groups that will insert code on YouTube's website to track ad position and context. This move is expected to attract companies like ComScore, DoubleVerify, and Integral Ad Science, which will help advertisers measure the effectiveness of their ads.

site_title: Toshiba slumps to annual loss on accounting scandal writedowns
summary: Toshiba Corp posted a net loss of 37.8 billion yen (S$452.8 million) for the 12 months ended March, after taking writedowns in an accounting scandal that led to the ouster of its president and two predecessors. The company issued revised earnings for three earlier fiscal years and scrapped dividend forecasts for the current year. Shares rose 3.6% to 359 yen as the company works to regain investor confidence. Toshiba has revamped its board and appointed a special committee to prevent further irregularities.

site_title: Mobius to Beijing: Quit fighting the market and let stocks fall
summary: Renowned forecasters Mark Mobius, Tom DeMark, and George Magnus agree that Chinese shares have further to drop, predicting a 18% decline in the Shanghai Composite Index to 2,590 before prices bottom out. Despite the government's two-month rescue effort, authorities may be reducing intervention, with analysts predicting a sustained decline. Foreign money managers have sold Shanghai equities, and valuation gaps between dual-listed shares are at their widest levels since 2009.

site_title: Walter to pay US$29.63m in reverse mortgage settlement
summary: Walter Investment Management Corp agreed to pay US$29.63 million to settle allegations of submitting false claims to the US Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) regarding its servicing of reverse mortgages. The allegations, made by a former executive in a 2013 lawsuit, claimed that Walter submitted claims for interest payments and reimbursement of referral fees without entitlement. The settlement resolves claims made by Matthew McDonald, a former executive, who will receive US$5.15 million. The agreement resolves claims under the federal False Claims Act.

site_title: Apple to launch Apple TV with gaming focus
summary: Apple is expected to unveil a new Apple TV product with a focus on gaming, priced around $150, featuring improved graphics, a new remote that doubles as a controller, and an app store for buying games. The product is expected to target casual gamers rather than high-end console fans, who see little chance of Apple winning over fans of Xbox One and PlayStation 4. The Apple TV is set to be unveiled at an event on September 9, 2015.

site_title: Brazil graft probe targets two in president's inner circle
summary: Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff's former campaign treasurer, Edinho Silva, and her chief of staff, Aloizio Mercadante, have been placed under investigation in the Petrobras corruption scandal. This marks the first time top members of Rousseff's administration have been directly targeted in the investigation. The Supreme Court has authorized investigations into Silva and Mercadante, who were previously implicated in the massive graft at the state-owned oil giant. The move raises concerns about Rousseff's inner circle and potential ties to corruption.

site_title: Corruption-weary Guatemalans choose new president
summary: Guatemalans voted in general elections amid widespread outrage over corruption, following the resignation and jailing of President Otto Perez on corruption charges. Caretaker President Alejandro Maldonado called on voters to punish deceptive candidates, and turnout was deemed "acceptable enough" despite fears of violence. Comedian Jimmy Morales, a political novice, leads in the final opinion poll, with a runoff election scheduled for October 25 if no candidate wins more than 50%. The corruption accusations have fueled protests and anger among Guatemalans, who are choosing a new president and Congress.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open 0.80% lower on weak Wall St, China worries
summary: Tokyo shares opened 0.80% lower on Monday, tracking a weak Wall Street performance and concerns over the Chinese economy. The Nikkei index fell 141.88 points to 17,650.28, while the Topix index slipped 0.99% to 1,430.23. The US jobs data, released on Friday, showed a slower-than-expected job gain, but the unemployment rate fell to 5.1%. Global caution over China's economy, ahead of a G20 meeting, contributed to the market volatility.

site_title: Ramba Energy to farm out 25% of Lemang project to strategic investor
summary: Ramba Energy has agreed to farm out 25% of its Lemang project to a strategic investor through a US$128.25 million deal. The deal includes an upfront cash payment of US$18.75 million, with the remaining amount payable upon achieving certain milestones. The definitive agreements are expected to be executed by September 25. The investor's identity will be disclosed in a separate announcement once the agreements are signed.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: UK manufacturers halve 2015 growth forecast as export orders slump
summary: British manufacturers' growth forecast has been halved to 0.7% for this year, down from 1.5%, due to a slump in export orders, the lowest since the financial crisis. The EEF manufacturers'organisation cited uncertainty over China's economic slowdown and the US-China trade tensions as key factors. This marks a reversal of the 3.1% growth seen in 2015, with recruiters attributing the slowdown to skills shortages leading to higher wages and slower job growth.

site_title: IMF chief says 'extremely encouraged' by Ukraine reforms
summary: IMF chief Christine Lagarde expressed "extreme encouragement" over Ukraine's reform efforts, praising the country's progress in restructuring its debt burden. A deal was reached with commercial lenders to restructure $14.1 billion of debt, providing immediate relief and extending repayment by four years. The agreement keeps global credit markets open to Ukraine and is part of a $40 billion rescue program. The IMF will send an assessment mission to monitor compliance with the program, with President Petro Poroshenko stating that reforms are a process that has just begun.

site_title: New Zealand wholesale sales slip in Q2
summary: New Zealand's wholesale sales declined 0.1% seasonally adjusted in Q2, primarily due to lower sales of basic materials and machinery/equipment. The total value of wholesale stocks reached NZ$9.78 billion for the quarter. This data is one of the final components of the country's gross domestic product (GDP) data, set to be released on September 17.

site_title: Sweden plans forced mortgage payments
summary: Sweden's government has agreed with opposition parties to force home owners to pay off some of the principal on new mortgage loans to cool the country's housing market. Around 70% of Swedish home owners have interest-only mortgages, with a household loan-to-disposable income ratio of over 170%, one of the highest in Europe. The Financial Supervisory Authority will have a legal mandate to require home owners to pay down principal on new mortgages, aiming to rein in consumer borrowing and prevent a potential crash.

site_title: Germany to beat export record despite China worries: trade body
summary: Germany is set to break its export record this year despite concerns over China's economic slowdown. China is Germany's fourth-largest export market, accounting for 6.6% of its exports. The country's economy is export-centric, making it vulnerable to China's economic woes. However, experts believe Germany's diversified economy will help it achieve its export record. This is a positive sign for Germany's economy, which has the greatest exposure to China among all 28 EU member states.

site_title: A ride through S'pore's property market
summary: Evia Real Estate, a Singapore-based developer and fund manager, has shifted its focus from industrial sites to the residential sector, including executive condo (EC) projects. Co-founders Vincent Ong and Leslie Lim have successfully triggered the release of multiple EC sites, securing several development projects. The company has also ventured into South Korea, acquiring a portfolio of industrial and commercial properties. Evia's fund management arm has raised five funds, with stakes in several EC projects and a private housing site in Toa Payoh. The company is now exploring opportunities in the Singapore commercial property market, with plans to acquire assets through a new fund.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: CIMB seeks bids for S-E Asia bancassurance deals
summary: CIMB Group Holdings has invited bids from insurers to distribute their general insurance products in four South-east Asian markets, with a potential deal worth around US$400 million. The bancassurance agreement, which is expected to draw interest from major insurers such as QBE, AXA, and Generali, will give CIMB access to the growing middle class in emerging markets. The deal is expected to draw interest from companies looking to capitalize on the lucrative bancassurance model, which pays hefty fees for access to lenders' branch networks and exposure to emerging markets.

site_title: Power companies benefit from Californian drought
summary: California's record drought is benefiting power companies, as growers increasingly rely on underground water supplies, boosting electricity demand. Farmers in the Central Valley are pumping 60% more water than usual, resulting in a 77% increase in power bills. This has led to new transmission lines and substations being built to handle the additional electricity. The increased usage could reach a record this year, with 2 trillion gallons of water potentially pumped, enough to fill 3.1 million Olympic swimming pools.

site_title: UK's North Sea loses 5,500 jobs in oil market downturn: regulator
summary: The UK's North Sea oil and gas sector has experienced significant job losses due to a year-long decline in oil prices, with over 5,500 jobs shed since late 2014. The decline in Brent crude prices has led to increased operating costs for North Sea operators, resulting in staff cuts. This trend has raised concerns about an emerging skills gap in the industry.

site_title: Refugees get hero's welcome in Germany as UN raps Europe
summary: Thousands of exhausted migrants, mostly from Syria, arrived in Germany, receiving a hero's welcome and aid from well-wishers. The UN criticized Europe's disparate efforts to help, with Turkey accusing "Christian fortress Europe" of being too restrictive. The crisis is seen as manageable if European countries unite and agree on a common approach, with the UN's refugee chief stating that a joint action plan could solve the issue. Meanwhile, Pope Francis urged a different approach, calling on European parishes to take in refugee families.

site_title: India targets tax evaders who hide 'black money' at home and abroad
summary: India has introduced measures to crack down on "black money," with a Sept 30 tax payment deadline for those who have stashed cash in foreign accounts. The government aims to formalize the informal economy and curb a culture of tax evasion, with penalties of up to 10 years in jail. Despite efforts, the rich are finding new ways to skirt the law, including using shell companies and tax havens. Only one wealthy individual has reported black money holdings and paid the tax and penalty, fueling speculation that the deadline may be extended.

site_title: Buying falls for first time in four weeks, with figures down sharply
summary: Singapore's buying activity fell for the first time in four weeks, with 68 purchases worth S$2.76 million recorded between August 31 and September 4. This was a significant drop from the previous week's 50 companies and 122 purchases worth US$19.4 million. Buyback activity also declined, with 30 companies posting 110 repurchases worth US$91.3 million. Notable purchases included BRC Asia Limited, Centurion Corporation, and Trek 2000 International, which were made following a decline in share prices.

site_title: China-focused hedge funds cede top spot to Japan peers
summary: China-focused hedge funds suffered their worst-ever 17.9% loss in June to August, overtaken by Japan-themed peers who posted a 6.3% gain during the same period. The losses eroded funds' earlier year-to-date gains of 3.6%, prompting investors to reconsider their China strategy and potentially leading to a surge in redemptions.

site_title: Avoiding online ads and the blockers
summary: Allrecipes has revamped its website, allowing users to follow other cooks and share recipes on Facebook. The site aims to become a social network for food lovers, with brands creating profile pages to "be part of the conversation." This move is also intended to make the site more appealing to advertisers, who can create native ads that won't be filtered by ad blockers. According to Adobe and PageFair, ad blocking could lead to $22 billion in lost revenue for advertisers this year, driving publishers and advertisers to rethink their strategies.

site_title: China woes outweigh US interest rate concerns
summary: China's unpredictable stock market and economic slowdown are overshadowing US interest rate concerns, with traders prioritizing China's moves ahead of the upcoming Federal Open Markets Committee meeting. Despite some experts urging the Fed to keep rates low, the article suggests that the US market is shifting towards a "good news is good for stocks" mentality, driven by concerns about China's economic woes. The Fed's decision on interest rates is uncertain, but the article concludes that raising rates is necessary to address artificially depressed markets and the consequences of easy money policies.

site_title: Brooks faces fights on all fronts back at Murdoch's London HQ
summary: Rebekah Brooks, Rupert Murdoch's former protegee and cleared of phone hacking charges, returns to lead News UK's British newspapers, including The Sun and The Times. She faces a tough challenge to rebuild circulation, move advertisers online, and repair relationships with staff and politicians. With sales of The Sun down 34% and the company's reputation tarnished, Brooks must navigate a changing media landscape and potential corporate charges against News UK. Her return is seen as a comeback for someone who once worked her way up from the newsroom ladder to become one of Britain's most powerful women.

site_title: Keppel Reit buys retail units in Melbourne
summary: Keppel Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, has acquired three retail units in Melbourne, Australia, from Cerberos for A$8.6 million. The acquisition will give Keppel Reit strategic control over a 35-storey office building and all five units, with the three new units occupying around 5,500 square feet. The units are fully leased to established food and beverage outlets for ten years, with options for another 30 years. The deal is expected to be completed in the fourth quarter of 2015 and will be funded by a combination of working capital and Australian-dollar debt.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Alfred Taubman's record US$500m art trove lands at Sotheby's
summary: Alfred Taubman's record $500 million art collection is set to be sold at Sotheby's. The collection, once held by the late billionaire and former Sotheby's chairman, is expected to be a major event in the art world. The sale comes after Taubman's death in April at 91, with details of his collection previously unknown. The auction is likely to attract significant attention and interest from art enthusiasts and collectors.

site_title: A good nominating committee can save a company
summary: The Toshiba scandal in Japan highlights the importance of a well-functioning nominating committee in appointing good directors to the board. The committee's role is to identify individuals with the right skills, talents, and attributes to challenge management and ensure the board's independence. A good board should have a balance of skills, experience, and diversity, with a continual renewal of directors. The launch of the Nominating Committee Guide by Singapore's Minister Grace Fu aims to provide a framework for effective governance and director appointment.

site_title: Picking stocks by watching debt paydowns
summary: Sandy Rufenacht, co-manager of the Aquila Three Peaks Opportunity Growth Fund, has developed a unique approach to picking stocks by analyzing debt paydowns. He focuses on companies with high-yield bonds that plan to pay down debt, generating free cash flow and improving their credit profiles. This enables them to refinance and take on more attractive financing options, such as buying back stock or increasing dividends. The fund's track record shows it has outperformed 97-99% of peer funds over various time periods, with the institutional share class gaining 8.4% in the last 12 months and 22.1% annually for three years.

site_title: Hamilton's masterly win in Italian GP under tyre scrutiny
summary: Lewis Hamilton secured a flawless victory in the Italian Grand Prix, extending his lead in the drivers' world championship to 53 points. Nico Rosberg retired with a blown engine, allowing Hamilton to capitalize on the situation. However, the win was marred by controversy surrounding alleged tyre pressure irregularities, which are currently under investigation. Despite this, Hamilton's win marked a significant milestone in the championship.

site_title: Gazprom seals major gas deals in Europe despite Ukraine crisis
summary: Russia's Gazprom has sealed two major gas deals in Europe despite ongoing tensions with Moscow over the Ukraine crisis. The deals include an asset swap with BASF, allowing Russia greater access to gas trading and storage in Germany, and a deal to double the capacity of the Nord Stream pipeline to deliver gas to Europe. The German government warned that the deals should not be seen as a sign of improving relations with Russia. Gazprom's chairman, Alexei Miller, hailed the deal as significant for securing reliable gas supply to European consumers.

site_title: Former head of vast hedge fund tries a third act
summary: Philip Falcone, former head of a $26 billion hedge fund, is launching a new investment platform, HC2 Holdings, with $800 million in assets. The company has made two midsize business acquisitions. Falcone aims to make smart acquisitions and hit home runs with smaller ventures, similar to his past success buying distressed bonds.

site_title: US payrolls data hits gold prices; copper also slumps
summary: US payrolls data showed a slowdown in job growth, with non-farm payrolls rising 173,000 in August, below July's upwardly revised gain of 245,000. The unemployment rate fell to a near 7-1/2-year low, and wages accelerated, keeping alive prospects of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike later this month. Gold prices fell 0.4% to $1,120.80 an ounce, while copper slumped 1.9% to $5,145 a tonne, amid caution over interest rate hikes and economic uncertainty.

site_title: Female empowerment can bring dramatic economic gains, says Lagarde
summary: IMF managing director Christine Lagarde declared female empowerment as an "economic no-brainer" during a speech in Ankara, highlighting its potential to boost GDP in countries like the US (5%), Japan (9%), and India (27%). She emphasized the need for decisive action to empower women, citing the potential to create 100 million new jobs and reduce poverty. The W20, an offshoot of the G20, aims to push for gender-inclusive economic growth, with its first summit set to take place in Istanbul next month.

site_title: Ups and downs
summary: Singapore's economy heavily relies on international trade, making currency volatility a significant issue. The recent fall in regional currencies, particularly the yuan's devaluation, has increased complexity for businesses. Companies must manage foreign exchange exposures, raw material costs, and robust cash flow controls to navigate turbulent times. Experts warn of potential risks, including capital outflows, debtor defaults, and economic nationalism. Despite the challenges, most businesses expect the situation to be short-lived and see opportunities for growth in the long term, with some companies even benefiting from the weaker yuan.

site_title: Saudi Arabia trimming expenses, slowing some projects: minister
summary: Saudi Arabia is cutting unnecessary expenses and delaying some projects due to low oil prices, with Finance Minister Ibrahim Alassaf stating the country is well-prepared to cope with the decline. The government will focus on main development projects and human resource building, while cutting expenses in areas deemed non-essential. The country may run a huge budget deficit of $120 billion or more this year, but its financial reserves are sufficient to cover several years. The government plans to issue sovereign bonds and Islamic bonds to finance specific projects, and will maintain its currency peg as long as oil remains dominant in the economy.

site_title: In Cambodia, China feels extent, and limits, of its growing power
summary: China's growing influence in Cambodia is evident in its $800 million Lower Sesan 2 Dam project, which will displace nearly 5,000 people and impact 40,000 along the Sesan and Srepok rivers. The dam is part of China's "great rejuvenation" plan to restore its historic place in Asia, countering the US's "rebalance" policy. China is investing heavily in infrastructure in the region, with no conditions attached, and has already made new friends and enemies. The project's impact on local communities, including the loss of fisheries resources, has raised concerns about increased malnutrition and poverty in Cambodia.

site_title: Textbook defensive stocks outpaced
summary: Smaller Singapore stocks outperformed larger counterparts amid market turmoil, defying expectations of institutional investors. The top performers included dry bulk shipping firm Mercator Lines, Chinese underwear company Great Group, and commodities trader Olam International. Analysts attribute the surge to index fund outflows and corporate announcements, which boosted prices. However, the resilience of these smaller stocks remains uncertain, as many are illiquid and lack institutional interest, making it difficult to separate true performance from market support.

site_title: Prepper Pinterest makes prepping look normal
summary: Prepper Pinterest, a branch of the prepper movement, has gone mainstream with a focus on basic emergency readiness. The platform has seen a 87% increase in prepper pins and repins over the past year, with popular boards on DIY skills, self-sufficiency, and preparedness. Unlike the media's portrayal of preppers as extreme and conspiracy-minded, this branch of preppers prioritizes practical and moderate measures for everyday emergencies, such as job loss or natural disasters. Experts say this shift is part of a broader cultural trend, where mainstream culture has become more hospitable to the prepper ethic, thanks in part to the "Pinterest effect."

site_title: Female truck drivers are outperforming their male counterparts in US
summary: Female truck drivers in the US are outperforming their male counterparts in various categories, including accidents, inspections, and compliance issues. Companies such as Werner Enterprises and Covenant Transportation Group are actively recruiting and retaining female drivers, citing factors like updated fleets, increased salaries, and cleaner terminals. The industry expects women to make up around 10% of drivers by year's end, nearly twice the national average. This shift is attributed to changes in the industry, including the introduction of modern conveniences and a growing recognition of women's capabilities.

site_title: Carmakers, Google take different roads to automation
summary: Carmakers and Google are taking different approaches to autonomous vehicle technology. Google's Chris Urmson believes that fully automated vehicles, requiring no human input, are safer and could be ready for production by 2020. In contrast, carmakers like General Motors and Volkswagen are planning to bring automated driving to the market in stages, starting as early as this year. Experts warn that drivers may not respond well to cars that let them surrender control for long stretches, and regulators are working to clarify their position on partial automation technology.

site_title: Political parties go into overdrive during busy weekend
summary: Singapore's nine-day election campaign intensified over the weekend, with thousands attending rallies by seven parties. The Workers' Party (WP) dominated debates, criticizing the People's Action Party (PAP) over the Punggol East town council saga. WP chief Low Thia Khiang claimed the PAP had handed over the town council with a $282,000 deficit, while Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean revealed the council had given the WP-run Aljunied-Hougang-Punggol East Town Council $22.5 million in cash. The PAP and opposition parties clashed over issues like immigration, employment, and economic growth, with some calling for a citizens-first employment policy and others defending the government's handling of foreign workers.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Ghana's mortgage holders feel the pain as US dollar climbs
summary: Ghanaian mortgage holders are facing financial strain due to the strengthening US dollar, which has more than doubled the cost of repayments on US dollar-denominated loans. The country's cedi currency has lost 25% of its value since January, increasing monthly mortgage payments for homeowners like Isaac Buame, who saw his repayment jump from 1,200 cedis to 2,620 cedis. This is hindering the growth of the mortgage market and deterring private investors from funding the government's goal of building 1.7 million new homes in the next 10 years.

site_title: Slump in commodity prices may be good news for much of the world
summary: A global slump in commodity prices, largely driven by China's slowdown, has prompted concerns about the impact on economies, particularly for oil exporters and producers. However, analysts believe the net effect will be positive for Western countries and industrializing emerging markets, which will benefit from cheaper oil and raw material inputs. The decline in commodity prices has already shifted $900 billion to $1.4 trillion in purchasing power from producers to consumers, with countries like Germany and India expected to benefit.

site_title: Fed must be sure of data before rate raise: IMF
summary: The IMF's managing director, Christine Lagarde, emphasized the need for the US Federal Reserve to be certain about the job market and inflation before raising interest rates. Lagarde stated that the Fed should not "give it a try and then have to come back" and instead should wait for confirmed data to justify a rate increase. The IMF's comments come as traders and investors are uncertain about when the Fed will raise interest rates, with some speculating it may happen on September 16-17.

site_title: S'pore Children's Society walkathon raises S$800K
summary: Singapore Children's Society raised S$800,000 at its annual Walk for Our Children 2015 event, exceeding its initial target of 500. The three-kilometre walkathon and carnival attracted 6,000 participants and 700 volunteers, making it the largest event to date. Minister for Trade and Industry Lim Hng Kiang was the guest-of-honour, while Hong Leong Foundation presented the walkathon. The funds raised will benefit the society's beneficiaries.

site_title: The impact of a weak Malaysian ringgit
summary: The Malaysian ringgit has depreciated above 4.0 against the US dollar, its highest level since the 1998 Asian Financial Crisis, due to concerns over the country's political stability. Despite a healthy 4.9% GDP growth rate, the weak currency affects Malaysia's major trade partners, including Singapore. A weakened ringgit could prompt Singapore's Monetary Authority to adjust its exchange rate, potentially weakening the Singapore dollar. This could lead to a strengthening of the Chinese yuan and Indonesian rupiah against the Singapore dollar, offering investment opportunities through non-deliverable forwards.

site_title: SDP defends policy proposals, pans YOG overspending
summary: The Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) defended its economic policy proposals at a rally, criticizing the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) for overspending on the 2010 Youth Olympic Games. SDP secretary-general Chee Soon Juan argued that high land prices drive rising costs, putting small businesses at a disadvantage, while candidate Paul Tambyah proposed a minimum wage for foreign workers to benefit Singaporeans. The SDP countered the PAP's claims that its policies would bankrupt Singapore, citing the PAP's own overspending on the YOG.

site_title: German businesses welcome refugees
summary: Germany's business leaders are calling for the integration of refugees into the workforce, citing a shortage of skilled labor and a rapidly aging population. The country expects to receive 800,000 asylum seekers this year, with many having "really good qualifications." Businesses are seeking simplified access to jobs, language training, and recognition of professional qualifications. The government has relaxed some conditions, but resistance from Chancellor Merkel's conservatives remains, with concerns about asylum seekers using work as an insurance policy to stay in the country.

images.alt_text: A volunteer preparing a toy for a migrant child after refugees arrived at the main railway station in Munich on Sunday. Businesses want the government to ease the rules on migrants' access to jobs

site_title: WP seeks support for younger candidates for renewal of the party
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) in Singapore is urging voters to support its younger candidates to sustain checks against the ruling party, the People's Action Party (PAP). At a rally, WP chairman Sylvia Lim emphasized the need for renewal, citing the party's age and the PAP's long tenure. WP leaders, including Low Thia Khiang and Gerald Giam, argued that the PAP's immigration policy has led to economic inequality and squeezed out Singaporeans, prompting a re-examination of the policy. The party seeks to promote equitable growth and stability through political diversity.

site_title: Draft constitution rejected in Thailand; polls delayed
