The four-week moving average of claims fell to 275,500, marking the 23rd straight week below the 300,000 threshold. Despite the increase, the labor market trend remains strong, with nonfarm payrolls likely increasing by 220,000 in August, according to a Reuters survey. The employment report, released before the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision on Sept 16-17, may influence expectations for a potential rate hike.

site_title: Oceanus proposes move to Catalist
summary: Oceanus Group, a Singapore-based abalone producer, has proposed moving from the mainboard to the Catalist board, citing a more suitable platform for listing and trading shares. The move requires bourse and shareholder approval and is subject to application to the Singapore Exchange. The company has also completed restructuring of S$64.4 million of loans and warrants, and is in talks with Stamford Corporate Services to be its Catalist sponsor.

site_title: PACC Offshore Services hit with legal suit for S$7.1m of damages and deposit
summary: PACC Offshore Services Holdings (POSH) has been served with a lawsuit by Kensteel Engineering for S$7.1 million in damages and a deposit paid for a property purchase. The dispute arose after Jurong Town Corporation (JTC) rejected Kensteel's application for approval, leading to a failed sale. POSH is defending the claim and taking legal advice. The total claim, including damages and deposit, amounts to 9.4% of POSH's 2014 net profit after tax.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Thursday
summary: Singapore's fourth desalination plant at Marina East will be built through a tender process announced by the national water agency PUB. The Nikkei Singapore PMI showed a slight improvement in business conditions in August, while Singapore Airlines faces delays in its premium economy rollout on the A380 fleet. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed higher due to relief from Hong Kong and China's public holiday closures. Meanwhile, UOL, Yangzijiang, and SATS will join the STI from September 21, replacing Jardine Matheson, Jardine Strategic, and Olam International.

site_title: ECB leaves rates unchanged as expected
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) held interest rates unchanged at record lows, maintaining the main refinancing rate at 0.05% and the marginal lending facility at 0.30%. The decision was in line with expectations after the ECB cut rates to rock-bottom levels a year ago. Markets will focus on ECB President Mario Draghi's news conference, where he will unveil new inflation and GDP growth forecasts.

images.alt_text: European Central Bank president Mario Draghi said Thursday that inflation in the euro could turn negative in the coming months, even if only temporarily.

site_title: HSBC says to rebrand British retail arm 'HSBC UK'
summary: HSBC Holdings is rebranding its British retail arm as 'HSBC UK' after a months-long review, keeping the HSBC brand and adding 'UK' to distinguish it from riskier parts of the business. The decision comes after consulting with staff and customers, with the new brand to be used from 2018, a year before the separation of the business is set to take place. The 'HSBC UK' bank will be headquartered in Birmingham.

site_title: UOL, Yangzijiang, SATS to join STI from Sept 21
summary: UOL Group, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, and SATS will replace Jardine Matheson, Jardine Strategic, and Olam International as constituents of the Straits Times Index (STI) starting September 21. The decision comes after a semi-annual review and a consultation showing strong market demand for an enhanced liquidity rule. The reserve list of companies that may replace ineligible constituents includes CapitaLand Commercial Trust, Singapore Post, and others, and will be reviewed again in December. The STI is a widely followed benchmark for the Singapore market and used for various financial products.

site_title: Indonesia lowers price floor for domestic economy flights
summary: Indonesia's transport ministry has lowered the price floor for domestic economy flights to 30% of the ceiling price, effective Sept 26, to keep fares affordable amid rising unemployment. This change comes just eight months after raising the floor to 40% in December 2014. The move aims to increase profit margins and encourage airlines to invest in safety measures. Unemployment in Indonesia stands at 5.81%, with reports of heavy layoffs painting a bleaker picture of the economy. The change is part of the ministry's efforts to support the airline industry during the economic slowdown.

site_title: Global economic losses from drought to top US$8b: report
summary: Global economic losses from drought are expected to reach over US$8 billion in the next few months due to the intensifying El Nino weather pattern. In the US, agricultural damage in California is projected to cause at least US$3 billion in losses. As El Nino strengthens, more drought-related impacts are expected worldwide, according to a report by reinsurance broker Aon Benfield.

site_title: UK wage pressure signal seen in increase in staff poaching
summary: The UK's labor market is showing signs of rising wage pressure as companies struggle to hire skilled workers, leading to an increase in staff poaching. The unemployment rate has dropped to 5.6% and job-to-job moves have risen, suggesting a labor market tightness. This trend may lead to greater pressure on wage inflation, making it more challenging for the Bank of England to adjust interest rates. The shift in employment patterns, including an increase in self-employed workers, may also be contributing to upward wage pressure.

images.alt_text: British finance minister George Osborne said on Thursday there will come a point when interest rates rise from record low levels in Britain, and that could be interpreted a sign of economic strength.

site_title: Market volatility alone not reason to voice concern on yuan: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) does not see China's recent market volatility as a reason to voice concern about including the yuan in its Special Drawing Rights (SDR) basket. The IMF is on track to complete its review by the end of the year, despite Beijing's push for yuan inclusion. The IMF attributes the recent volatility to market reactions to China's adoption of a more flexible exchange rate.

site_title: Samsung joins the smart home sensor battle with Apple, Google
summary: Samsung launches Smart Things, a connected home system that uses sensors and a central hub to control appliances, lighting, and security. The system, available in the UK and US by September 10, is an open platform that allows developers to create new devices. It can be controlled through a smartphone app, which also offers features like automated routines and remote access. Samsung's move increases competition with Apple's Home Kit and Google's Nest, and the company has secured partnerships with major brands like Philips and Honeywell.

site_title: Japan govt FY2016/17 budget request hit record US$852b: sources
summary: Japan's government has requested a record $852.14 billion for its annual budget for the 2016/17 fiscal year, the largest ever. The budget includes $30.67 billion for social security and $3.85 billion for pro-growth policies, while debt-servicing costs account for $26.05 billion. The Ministry of Finance will review and trim the budget before drafting an annual budget in December, as Japan aims to balance its primary budget by 2021 to reduce its public debt, which is already twice the size of its economy.

site_title: Del Monte narrows Q1 loss to US$12m
summary: Del Monte Pacific reported a net loss of US$12 million for Q1 2015, down from a loss of US$21.9 million in the same period last year. Revenue rose 6.1% to US$472.8 million. The loss was attributed to a weak first quarter for its US subsidiary and expenses from implementing SAP software. Despite this, the company expects its financial performance to improve as it unlocks growth potential and expands into new markets.

site_title: MAS to print 6 million more folders for SG50 commemorative notes due to overwhelming demand
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is printing an additional 6 million folders for the SG50 commemorative notes due to overwhelming demand. Starting from mid-November, two folders will be available to every Singaporean household without needing to obtain the notes at banks. This move aims to meet the high demand for the commemorative notes, which was initially expected but has exceeded initial projections.

site_title: G20 seeks to smooth economic shock waves from China
summary: World finance ministers and central bankers meet in Turkey to address economic shock waves from slowing China's growth, which has panicked stock markets, depressed commodity prices, and affected emerging economies. The expected US interest rate hike in September is now uncertain, raising concerns about a potential new cycle of rate hikes. The Group of 20 meeting aims to smooth the economic impact of China's slowdown and stabilize global markets.

site_title: French unemployment stable at 10% in second quarter: Insee
summary: French unemployment remained stable at 10% in the second quarter, unchanged from the previous three months, according to official data. The unemployment rate among the working population, including overseas territories, was 10.3% and affected approximately 2.9 million people. This data comes as the EU's second-largest economy continues to struggle with a stagnant economy.

site_title: Noble Group hires senior traders to expand Singapore oil team
summary: Noble Group, a Singapore-based commodity merchant, is expanding its oil team to capitalize on growing regional demand despite a price rout. The company has hired three middle distillates traders from BP and added three crude traders to trade physical cargoes in Asia. Noble aims to capture local opportunities as oil demand shifts east, driven by economies opening up their oil industries.

site_title: Asia-Europe container freight rates jump 29%
summary: Container freight rates from Asia to Northern Europe jumped 29% to $763 per 20-foot container, the second consecutive week of increases, according to the Shanghai Shipping Exchange. The rate is still short of the $1,000 announced by major shipping companies earlier. The rates have been affected by overcapacity and sluggish demand, with average rates for 2015 at $666 per TEU, down from $1,172 last year. Maersk Line, the global market leader, controls around one-fifth of transported containers from Asia to Europe.

site_title: US trade deficit smallest in five months
summary: The US trade deficit narrowed to its lowest level in five months in July, falling 7.4% to $41.9 billion. Exports rose 0.4% to $188.5 billion, driven by increases in food, industrial supplies, and capital goods. Imports fell 1.1% to $230.4 billion, with automobile imports reaching a record high. The smaller deficit suggests a modest contribution to the economy's 3.7% annualized growth rate in the second quarter. The US-China trade deficit remains a concern, with exports to China falling 1.9% and imports from the country dipping 0.2%.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher as STI tracks Dow futures; HK and China closed
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 28.3 points or 1% to 2,906.43 on Thursday, rebounding from a 79-point drop between Monday and Wednesday. The index benefited from the closure of Hong Kong and China markets for a public holiday, as well as a 70-point rise in Dow Jones futures. Poor volume and mixed split Fed views also contributed to the rebound.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close 0.48% higher
summary: Tokyo shares rose 0.48% on Thursday, driven by Wall Street's rebound on optimism over the US economy. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 18,182.39, while the Topix index gained 0.61%. Volatile Chinese markets were closed for a long weekend, allowing investors to focus on US economic data and trade talks. Despite tariff uncertainty, investors remained positive, pushing the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: GE2015: SPP releases eight-point manifesto for Bishan-Toa Payoh GRC
summary: The Singapore People's Party released an eight-point manifesto for the Bishan-Toa Payoh GRC, outlining plans for national issues. The team's proposals focus on the GRC, with no mention of local issues. The manifesto was released on September 3, 2015.

site_title: Switzerland freezes assets of troubled Malaysia fund
summary: Swiss authorities have frozen tens of millions of dollars in assets of Malaysia's 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB) as part of an investigation into the state investment fund. The move comes amid allegations that huge sums have vanished in deals with heavily-indebted 1MDB, which was launched by Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak in 2009. Criminal proceedings have been opened against two 1MDB executives. The investigation has sparked mounting anger over Najib's tenure, with the fund at the center of the controversy.

site_title: Seoul: Shares close flat, hurt by foreign selling; won down
summary: Seoul shares closed flat on Thursday, erasing early gains, as foreigners continued their 21-day net selling streak, the longest in over seven years. Tech shares led the market, with Samsung and LG Display rising 2.9% and 5.3%, respectively. Foreigners sold 4.38 trillion won worth of shares in the main board during the 21 days, while the South Korean won closed down 0.8% to 1,190.3 per dollar.

site_title: Update: PUB calls tender to build Singapore's fourth desalination plant
summary: PUB, Singapore's national water agency, announced plans to build the country's fourth desalination plant at Marina East, with a capacity of 30 million imperial gallons per day. The plant will help meet future water demand and strengthen drought resilience. Located near water demand zones, it will also treat freshwater from Marina Reservoir. The project is part of Singapore's "Four National Taps" strategy, which includes rainwater, imported water, and reused wastewater. The desalination plant will produce 25% of current water demand, with NEWater expected to meet up to 55% by 2060.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: GE2015: WP has not explained 'important questions' on clawback from FMSS: Khaw
summary: Minister for National Development Khaw Boon Wan stated that the Workers' Party (WP) has not addressed key questions regarding the clawback of funds from Aljunied-Hougang-Punggol East Town Council (AHPETC). The financial accounts remain qualified, receiving a disclaimer of opinion from independent auditors, and are considered a red flag in the corporate world.

site_title: Low inflation back in focus at ECB policy meeting
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is unlikely to announce new policy measures to prevent deflation at its meeting on Thursday, despite concerns over falling inflation and commodity prices. Analysts expect ECB chief Mario Draghi to remain dovish, potentially opening the door for stepping up quantitative easing (QE) to boost inflation. The ECB's growth and inflation forecasts are expected to be downgraded, with inflation still below the 2% target, and the euro's strengthening could exert downward pressure on prices.

site_title: Europe: Stocks shoot higher at opening bell
summary: European stocks rose at the opening bell, driven by a Wall Street rally and volatile Chinese markets closed for a long weekend. The FTSE 100 jumped 1.17%, the CAC 40 climbed 1.03%, and the DAX 30 advanced 1.13%. The rally was attributed to gains in mining and healthcare sectors, with US-EU trade talks also in focus.

site_title: Asia-Pacific crude: Indonesian grades sink into wide discounts
summary: The Asia-Pacific crude market remained depressed due to unsold supply from previous months. Indonesian crude grades, such as Indonesia Duri, sank into deep discounts, with a discount of about $6.50 to ICE Brent. Chevron offered 100,000 barrels of Indonesia Duri for October loading at $8 a barrel, widening the discount. The discounts were attributed to traders' concerns about market oversupply and a bearish outlook due to the Trump tariff outlook.

site_title: GE2015: SPP's Ravi Philemon pledges to hold three MPS weekly, lobby for bus services
summary: In the 2015 Singapore General Election, candidate Ravi Philemon of the Singapore People's Party (SPP) pledged to hold three Meet the People sessions (MPS) weekly if elected. He also vowed to be a full-time Member of Parliament. This promise was part of his election manifesto unveiled on September 3, 2015.

site_title: Japan eyes tourist boost with Google-style street view... for cats
summary: Japan's western Hiroshima prefecture has launched a Google-style street view for cats, exploring the streets of Onomichi from a feline perspective. The map, featuring a cartoon cat named Lala, allows viewers to see the city from a low-level vantage point. The initiative aims to attract more feline-loving tourists, capitalizing on the city's reputation for having many cats. This is not Japan's first feline-focused tourism bid, with a previous example in Wakayama prefecture where a cat served as stationmaster for a regional train station.

site_title: GE2015: Face of political party's leader can be used in posters for candidates, says Elections Department
summary: The Elections Department of Singapore has clarified that using the face of a political party's leader in posters for candidates from that party, even if they are not contesting the election, is not against the law. This practice has been followed in past elections, allowing voters to identify the party leader with the party. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's face appeared on posters across the island, not just in his designated constituency.

site_title: UK bank lending to small firms rises in second quarter: BoE data
summary: The Bank of England reported a 490 million pounds increase in net lending to small businesses by banks and building societies in the second quarter of 2015, compared to 400 million pounds in the same period last year. This rise is attributed to improving economic conditions, encouraging smaller firms to borrow and banks to make loans.

site_title: Hazy conditions possible over next 1-2 days: NEA
summary: Singapore may experience hazy conditions over the next 1-2 days due to smoke from Sumatra and dry weather, according to the National Environment Agency (NEA). The 24-hour PSI was in the "moderate" range at 2pm on Thursday, expected to move into the "unhealthy" range if wind speeds don't pick up. NEA chief Ronnie Tay expressed concerns to his Indonesian counterpart and urged an update on the situation. Conditions could improve with increased wind speeds, but worsen if winds shift to the south or south-west.

site_title: Gold slips on firmer dollar; US jobs data eyed for cues
summary: Gold prices slipped 0.1% to $1,132.30 an ounce due to a stronger US dollar and anticipation of a potential Federal Reserve rate hike. Investors await the US jobs report, which could influence the Fed's decision. Low interest rates reduce the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion, while Chinese buyers are absent due to public holidays. Analysts predict a bearish market for gold as long as it trades below $1,170.

images.alt_text: US Federal Reserve building in Washington, DC.

site_title: Xi says China no threat, announces military cuts at parade
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping announced the country's commitment to peace and announced significant military cuts, reducing the army by 300,000 personnel, the largest reduction since 1997. The cuts are part of a broader overhaul of the military, moving it closer to a US-style joint command structure. Xi's message of peace was presented at a parade commemorating the end of World War II, but its impact may not resonate in neighboring countries. The cuts aim to soften the perceived power display and make the military more combat effective.

site_title: Australian PM says IS militants worse than Nazis
summary: Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott sparked controversy by comparing Islamic State militants to Nazis, stating they "boast about their evil" and act with "medieval barbarity". Jewish groups criticized his remarks, arguing IS's crimes cannot be compared to the systematic genocide of the Holocaust. Abbott defended his comments, saying IS's boastful nature sets them apart from previous evil-doers. The Australian government has raised its terror threat alert level and introduced new national security laws in response to the growing threat of IS.

site_title: Investment bank income seen down 19% in Q3 from rocky markets
summary: Investment banks' revenue is expected to drop 19% in Q3 due to volatile market conditions, according to JPMorgan analyst Kian Abouhossein. This decline is attributed to decreased equities trading, fixed income, currencies, and commodities revenues, as well as advisory and investment banking fees. Market volatility, particularly concerns over China's economy, may further impact deal completion and client activity. The analyst also lowered earnings per share forecasts for 2015-17 by 2-3%.

site_title: GE2015: WP calls for minimum wage starting at S$1,000
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) in Singapore has proposed a national minimum wage starting at S$1,000 per month, to be increased gradually over a few years to S$1,250. The proposal aims to ensure jobs creation and prevent net job destruction, as the current progressive wage model imposes more burden on employers. The party believes that a minimum wage will give employers more flexibility to improve productivity and match wage levels. The proposal is part of the WP's manifesto for the 2015 General Elections.

site_title: Japan Display CEO hints at strong Apple orders ahead of new iPhone launch
summary: Japan Display Inc. CEO Mitsuru Homma revealed that Apple is increasing orders ahead of the new iPhone launch, despite weakness in China's smartphone market. Homma stated that Apple is seeking more screens from Japan Display, citing no impact from the economic slowdown in China. This news comes after Apple CEO Tim Cook reassured shareholders about the Chinese market's strength. Japan Display has been recovering due to strong Apple orders since its formation in 2012.

site_title: Malaysia's economy in stronger position to meet any incoming storms: Najib
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak stated that the country's economy is in a stronger position to withstand potential economic storms, citing improved balance sheets and governance among local companies, as well as structural reforms to the financial sector. Najib also expressed confidence that Malaysia is on track to achieve its goal of becoming a high-income nation by 2020.

site_title: S&P cuts Glencore outlook to negative on weak commodities
summary: Standard & Poor's cut its outlook for Glencore Plc to 'negative' due to a 29% slump in first-half earnings and slashing its price forecasts for metals amid uncertainties about China's economic outlook. The mining firm cited tough market conditions, weak credit metrics, and volatile commodity prices as factors contributing to the downgrade. This move reflects S&P's concerns about Glencore's ability to withstand additional pressure on operations, credit measures, and free cash flow.

site_title: G20 will seek to smooth economic shock waves from China
summary: World finance ministers gather in Turkey to address economic shockwaves from China's slowing growth, tanking emerging economies, and global stock market panic. The G20 is expected to convey a more subdued tone, acknowledging the impact of China's slowdown on global growth. Policymakers will discuss ways to manage the situation, including China's efforts to ease its economy from reliance on state investment and exports to domestic consumer spending. The meeting comes as the US prepares to raise interest rates, which could further slow emerging economies.

site_title: SIA faces delay in premium economy roll-out on A380 fleet
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has delayed the roll-out of premium economy on its Airbus A380 fleet due to installation programme delays. Affected flights include Shanghai, Beijing, Tokyo, and Mumbai. SIA is working to complete the installation programme as quickly as possible and will contact customers with ticketed bookings to offer alternative travel arrangements. The airline apologizes for the inconvenience caused and provides a full list of affected flights on its website.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly higher as China marks holiday
summary: Asian markets rose on Thursday, driven by a public holiday in China and upbeat US data, which helped push riskier assets higher. The International Monetary Fund warned that China's crisis is having a broader impact on the global economy. Despite US President Trump's new threats, traders are brushing off the uncertainty to extend their rally. The Singapore stock market, in particular, notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: BOJ's Kiuchi warns Japan won't hit inflation goal for another 2-1/2 yrs
summary: Bank of Japan board member Takahide Kiuchi warned that Japan is unlikely to hit its 2% inflation target for another 2.5 years due to weak consumer spending and China's slowdown hurting exports. Kiuchi also expressed concerns that Asian economies may see significant growth slowdowns and that the BOJ's monetary efforts should be accompanied by structural reforms to boost productivity. He proposed tapering the bank's asset purchases to allow more time to hit the target, contradicting BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda's confidence in meeting the target.

site_title: PUB calls tender to build Singapore's fourth desalination plant
summary: PUB announced plans to build Singapore's fourth desalination plant at Marina East with a capacity of 30 million imperial gallons per day. The plant aims to meet future water demand and strengthen drought resilience. Located near water demand zones, it will also treat freshwater from Marina Reservoir. The tender includes engineering design under a Design-Build-Own-Operate arrangement.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 7.26 points to 1597.51. The index saw a gain of 107 to 36 gainers-to-losers ratio. Volume was 34.9 million lots worth RM15.8 million.

site_title: Oceanus completes restructuring of loans, warrants
summary: Oceanus Group, an abalone producer, completed the restructuring of S$64.4 million of loans and nearly three billion warrants on September 2, 2015. This move is seen as a key achievement for the loss-making company, which has faced going-concern questions from its auditors. The company expressed gratitude to shareholders for their support in completing the restructuring.

site_title: Australian retail sales unexpectedly fall as economy slows
summary: Australian retail sales unexpectedly fell 0.1% in July, the first drop since May 2014, due to highly-indebted consumers reducing spending. This drop aligns with a rise in household savings and suggests the economy is not improving. The weaker sales may prompt the central bank to lower interest rates further, adding to the case for rate cuts. Key sectors affected include household goods, which dropped 1.9%, and clothing, footwear, and personal accessories, which rose 2.9%.

site_title: Oil dips in Asia after mixed US report
summary: Oil prices fell in Asia after a mixed US petroleum report, with West Texas Intermediate for October delivery dropping 45 cents to $45.80 and Brent crude for October slipping 38 cents to $50.12. The report showed an increase in US crude stocks to 455.4 million barrels, but a decline in production to 9.22 million barrels. Analysts believe the global supply-demand imbalance remains, despite hopes that an uptick in US demand could reduce global supplies. Market sentiment was also influenced by worries of a potential US Federal Reserve rate hike, which could boost the dollar and hurt demand.

images.alt_text: A driver after refueling at a Dijon's gas station. Oil prices in New York sagged to a new six and a half year low on August 19, 2015.

site_title: Ringgit falls on concern data to show further reserve depletion
summary: The Malaysian ringgit fell 0.5% to 4.2325 a dollar, adding to Wednesday's 1.1% decline, amid concerns over the erosion of foreign-exchange reserves and slowing exports. The country's reserve holdings have fallen 19% this year to US$94.5 billion, and data may show further central bank purchases to prop up the currency. A looming US interest-rate increase and global volatility are also contributing to investor sentiment, with the 10-year government bond yield rising one basis point to 4.28%.

images.alt_text: The ringgit extended the week's losses on concern the erosion of Malaysia's foreign-exchange reserves will further hurt investor sentiment in an economy reeling from falling oil prices and a political scandal.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares opened nearly unchanged at 9:05 am on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index rising 0.74 points to 2,878.87 following an overnight US market rally. The index saw significant support from Singapore Telecommunications, while Ezra Holdings led gains with 11.5 million shares changing hands. Gainers outnumbered losers 105 to 47, with investors staying positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks rise amid global calm
summary: Japanese stocks rose 1.4% to 1,486.33 on Thursday, driven by energy explorers, as global markets calmed following China's two-day holiday. The Nikkei 225 Stock Average also gained 1.4% to 18,345.71. The rout in global equities last month, sparked by China's currency devaluation, erased over $5.7 trillion in global share value. Traders now price in a 32% chance of a US interest rate hike this month amid concerns over China's slowdown.

site_title: Nikkei Singapore PMI shows Aug business conditions up slightly
summary: The Nikkei Singapore PMI showed a slight improvement in August business conditions, with a headline reading of 50.8, above the 50-point mark. Output growth eased to a four-month low, but remained solid overall. New product developments and improving client demand contributed to the higher output. However, total new orders remained unchanged, and economists expressed concerns about a slowdown in the economy, citing weaker global growth and muted demand. The PMI also showed a contraction in manufacturing and electronics sectors.

images.alt_text: Singapore firms posted only a marginal improvement in overall operating conditions in August, according to the Nikkei Singapore purchasing managers' index (PMI) released on Thursday.

site_title: Low inflation back in focus at ECB policy meeting
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is unlikely to introduce new policy measures to combat deflation at its meeting, despite rising concerns. Analysts attribute the decision to the ECB's desire for an "ordinary and dull meeting," but market turmoil and plummeting commodity prices have reignited the deflation debate. The ECB's governing council will reassess its stance on inflation, potentially leading to fresh policy discussions in the future.

site_title: Seoul: Shares rise, helped by tech shares; won falls
summary: Seoul shares rose 0.4% to 1,922.58 points, driven by gains in tech shares, with Samsung Electronics up 2.4% and LG Display up 3.5%. Investors are cautious ahead of the US Federal Reserve's September meeting, but analysts see it as a favorable time to invest based on earnings and valuations. Foreigners, however, remain net sellers for the 21st straight session, offloading 71.7 billion won worth of shares.

site_title: Indonesia plans almost US$1.37b in Islamic bonds for infrastructure projects to kickstart economy
summary: Indonesia plans to issue almost US$1.37 billion in Islamic bonds for infrastructure projects, aiming to kickstart its slowing economy. The country will double its sales of project Islamic bonds, with 13.7 trillion rupiah (S$1.37 billion) of Shariah-compliant sovereign debt to be offered, primarily for building roads, ports, and power plants.

site_title: HDB resale prices up 0.3% in August: SRX
summary: HDB resale prices rose 0.3% in August, led by four-room and five-room flats, according to SRX Property. This marks a 3% drop from a year ago and an 11.3% decline from the SRX's index peak in April 2013. Resale transaction volumes decreased by 6.8% to 1,447 flats sold, a 9% improvement from a year ago.

site_title: Selfie madness: too many dying to get the picture
summary: The rise of selfie photography has led to a string of gruesome deaths worldwide due to risk-taking behavior. In some of the world's most beautiful and dangerous places, people are taking selfies, often disregarding safety and decorum. The trend has been fueled by celebrities, including Queen Elizabeth II and US President Barack Obama. Interventions are being implemented to combat the negative consequences of selfie madness, but the issue remains a concern, highlighting the need for greater awareness and responsibility among selfie enthusiasts.

site_title: China holiday brings respite as stocks rally, havens backtrack
summary: Asian stocks rose for the first time this week as China's two-day holiday brought relief from market volatility. The yen led a pullback in safe-haven assets, while US and European equities rebounded. The Shanghai Composite Index recovered into the close on Wednesday, boosting sentiment and igniting a global stock rebound. With the spotlight off China, attention shifts to the US interest rate outlook, particularly the payrolls report on Friday.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks mixed; techs up, banks down
summary: Taiwan's stocks experienced a mixed session, with technology companies rising and banks falling. The main index dropped 0.1% to 8025.84 points, while the electronics subindex increased 0.3% and the financial subindex decreased 0.2%. Notable gains included Hon Hai Precision, a major iPhone assembler, which rose 1.3%. The Taiwan dollar also strengthened 0.72% to T$32.526 against the US dollar.

site_title: KLW resumes trading after change in major shareholder
summary: KLW Holdings shares resume trading after managing director Lee Boon Teck sold 980.4 million shares to businessman Quek Chek Lan, reducing his stake to 0.1% and increasing Quek's stake to 19.4%. Quek is described as KLW's "new controlling shareholder", despite his stake being below the 30% trigger for a mandatory general offer. Lee will remain managing director and ensure the completion of an ongoing special audit, while Quek plans to restructure the board composition.

site_title: GE2015: Singaporeans overseas to vote at 10 designated polling stations
summary: Singapore citizens overseas will be able to vote at 10 designated overseas polling stations for the 2015 General Election. The Singapore Consulate-General in Dubai was added as a polling station this year. This marks the first time Singaporean overseas voters can cast their ballots in a General Election.

site_title: Toshiba to post annual net loss of US$83m
summary: Toshiba is expected to post a net loss of approximately US$83 million in its 2014/15 financial report, amid a probe into improper accounting. An independent probe found the company overstated its profits by US$1.2 billion over several years. Toshiba postponed its annual results for a second time due to new accounting errors, but aims to announce the earnings by September 7. This marks Japan's largest accounting scandal since 2011, following Olympus Corp's US$1.7 billion scheme to conceal investment losses.

site_title: Kim Kardashian takes Instagram crown with record 45m followers
summary: Reality TV star Kim Kardashian holds the record for most Instagram followers with 45 million, surpassing other popular users like Taylor Swift and Beyoncé. Kardashian's self-promotion strategy on the visually-driven platform has contributed to her success. She still lags behind in other social media platforms like Twitter, where Katy Perry leads with 74.8 million followers. Kardashian's milestone comes after her wedding photo was the most-liked photo on Instagram before being surpassed by a photo of her sister Kendall Jenner.

site_title: September or not, market says Fed's one-and-done until late
summary: The Federal Reserve is likely to wait at least six months before raising interest rates again, with market measures indicating a possible wait of twice that long. The odds of a rate hike in September have fallen to 32% from 40% in July, and December's probability is 58%. The Fed's decision is influenced by China's economic slowdown and global market turmoil, with China's central bank buying yuan and selling dollar assets to support the exchange rate.

site_title: Draghi seen sharpening language as ECB fights fading inflation
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi is set to announce his decision on interest rates, with economists expecting a downgrade of inflation forecasts due to weaker commodity prices and slowing trade. Despite the uncertainty, Draghi is likely to reassure investors with words rather than action, emphasizing the ECB's readiness to respond if conditions deteriorate. The ECB's quantitative-easing program, worth 1.1 trillion euros, may be expanded, but policy action is seen as unlikely for now.

site_title: China, Hong Kong: Markets closed
summary: China's and Hong Kong's financial markets are closed on Thursday for a public holiday. There is no relevant information about the markets in the provided articles.

site_title: Fed's Beige Book says US economy expanded across most regions
summary: The US economy expanded across most regions and industries in July and August, according to the Federal Reserve's Beige Book. Six of 12 Fed districts reported "moderate" growth, while five others reported "modest" expansion. The report suggests that tighter labor markets boosted wages for some workers. This data is being considered by the Federal Reserve as it weighs lifting interest rates, despite market volatility and slowing growth in China.

site_title: Shell reopens two key Nigeria pipelines shut over leaks, sabotage
summary: Shell has reopened two key pipelines in Nigeria, the Trans Niger Pipeline and Nembe Creek Trunkline, after a force majeure was declared due to leaks and sabotage. The pipelines were shut last week, resulting in a halt to crude oil exports. The company lifted the force majeure on September 2, allowing for the resumption of Bonny Light exports. The repairs were completed after a week-long shutdown, enabling the company to resume operations.

site_title: Otto Marine bags US$25.2m charter contracts
summary: OTTO Marine has secured two long-term charter contracts worth US$25.2 million for two 16,000 brake horsepower AHTS vessels. The contracts with a large oil and gas company are expected to positively impact the company's per-share net tangible assets and earnings for the current financial year. This order is seen as a positive development for Otto Marine, with the company's shares trading at 28 Singapore cents following the announcement. The contracts are expected to generate revenue and contribute to the company's growth.

site_title: Obama hails ties with Japan on 70th anniversary of end of WWII
summary: US President Barack Obama honored the 70th anniversary of the end of World War II in the Pacific by praising the US-Japan partnership, which he described as "unimaginable" 70 years ago. Obama saluted the US war dead and honored their sacrifice, while also praising Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe for his role in deepening the relationship between the two countries. The US-Japan partnership is seen as a model of reconciliation, with Obama expressing confidence that it will continue to deepen in the decades to come.

site_title: Broken lavatories force Malaysia Airlines jet to land
summary: Malaysia Airlines flight MH19 made an unscheduled landing in Chennai, India, due to broken lavatories on a scheduled flight from Amsterdam to Kuala Lumpur. The incident occurred on Thursday, following a similar route as MH17, which was shot down over Ukraine last year. The plane landed safely and the cause of the lavatory issue is under investigation. No injuries or fatalities were reported.

site_title: IMF: Impact of China slowdown larger than expected
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned that China's economic slowdown is having a broader impact on the global economy than expected, particularly on emerging markets. The slowdown, which is expected to be in line with forecasts, is causing weakening commodity prices, stock prices, and increasing risks to economic growth worldwide. The IMF recommends that advanced countries maintain loose monetary policies and implement growth-friendly fiscal policies, while emerging economies need to strike a balance between fostering growth and managing vulnerabilities.

images.alt_text: China's economic slowdown is having a broader impact on the global economy than originally expected, especially on emerging markets, the International Monetary Fund said late on Wednesday.

site_title: Oil stages modest rebound after mixed US petroleum data
summary: Oil prices experienced a modest rebound on Wednesday, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rising 84 cents to $46.25 a barrel, and Brent North Sea crude gaining 94 cents to $50.50 a barrel. The rebound came after a mixed US petroleum report showed an increase in crude inventories and a decline in production. Rising supplies and lackluster demand growth have spurred oil's decline since mid-2014, with analysts warning that the market's extreme volatility makes reliable predictions difficult.

site_title: German financial watchdog sees higher bank capital buffers
summary: German financial watchdog Bafin's President Felix Hufeld expects German banks to face higher capital buffers due to a supervisory review process. The review, carried out by the ECB and national banking supervisors, uses a broader methodology to assess risks, which may lead to higher capital demands on lenders. The probe into possible foreign currency market manipulation, focusing on Deutsche Bank, is also nearing a conclusion. Bafin has uncovered bank behavior that would have been previously thought unlikely, leading to an evaluation process and discussions with the banks involved.

site_title: South Korea revised Q2 GDP up 0.3% q-o-q, same as estimate
summary: South Korea's economy grew 0.3% seasonally adjusted in Q2, unchanged from its earlier estimate, marking the worst quarterly growth in over six years. This growth rate is also less than half of the 0.8% expansion in Q1. The revised GDP growth rate is the same as the estimate released earlier, which was also 0.3% q-o-q.

site_title: Greek opposition conservatives nudge ahead of Syriza: poll
summary: Greek opposition party New Democracy has taken a slender lead over the ruling Syriza party, with 25.3% support ahead of snap elections on September 15. The lead comes 18 days before the vote, after Syriza leader Alexis Tsipras quit due to a major rebellion over his decision to sign Greece up for a third bailout. This marks a significant shift in Greek politics, as Syriza had previously dominated the opposition. The poll result suggests that conservative voters may be turning away from Syriza, potentially paving the way for a New Democracy victory.

site_title: DreamWorks to split from Disney: industry source
summary: DreamWorks film studio, co-founded by Steven Spielberg, plans to part ways with Disney when their distribution tie-up ends in August 2016. The studio feels out of step with Disney's focus on big, tentpole films, and Spielberg is negotiating a new partnership with more favorable terms. Universal is tipped as Spielberg's likely new home, following the success of "Jurassic World." The last movie to be distributed under the Disney deal, "The BFG," is expected to be released next year. A sequel to "Jurassic World" is also in the works, with Spielberg as executive producer.

site_title: Rousseff says Brazil will try to get out of first budget deficit
summary: Brazil's President Dilma Rousseff announced her government's plan to work towards eliminating its first-ever budget deficit, which amounts to 0.5% of GDP. The primary budget deficit, valued at 30.5 billion reais, marks the first time Brazil's government has spent more than it has received in revenue. Rousseff aims to reduce the deficit, which has been exacerbated by the country's worst recession since 1931 and high inflation. The move comes as Rousseff's popularity plummets amid economic woes and corruption scandals.

site_title: Stock volatility, ETF rise drive rethink of post-flash crash US rules
summary: US regulators are re-examining rules designed to ensure orderly trading in equities after a near-unprecedented bout of volatility on August 24, triggered by panic over the Chinese economy. Over 1,250 trading halts were triggered in 455 stocks and ETFs, leading to confusion among investors. The US Securities and Exchange Commission is reviewing the rules, including the Limit Up Limit Down rule, to address issues with ETF pricing and potential delays in opening halted stocks. The SEC aims to adjust the rules to reduce volatility and prevent similar disruptions in the future.

site_title: Prime office rents seen softening further
summary: Office rents in Singapore's Central Business District (CBD) softened by 2.6% in Q2, following a 0.6% increase in Q1. The weakening trend is attributed to tenants opting for cheaper decentralised offices and financial institutions consolidating amid an uncertain economic outlook. Key projects such as Asia Square and CapitaGreen weighed down office rents in the Raffles Place and Marina Bay areas.

site_title: Argentina makes proposal to cenbank amid tax evasion probe
summary: HSBC Argentina's general manager, Andrés Hammar Aldatz, has been allowed to continue carrying out executive functions despite a probe into tax evasion and money laundering charges. The country's central bank had ordered the bank to name a new president and vice president within 24 hours, but HSBC maintained that its operations continue normally. The bank is accused of helping over 4,000 clients evade taxes by stashing money in secret Swiss bank accounts.

site_title: China to flex military muscle in WWII parade
summary: China held a large military parade in Tiananmen Square to commemorate the 70th anniversary of Japan's WWII defeat, featuring 12,000 soldiers, 500 pieces of hardware, and 200 aircraft. Major Western leaders, including US President Barack Obama, German Chancellor Angela Merkel, and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, were absent due to concerns over China's growing military assertiveness. China's President Xi Jinping oversaw the event, which comes as Beijing takes a more assertive diplomatic stance, engaging in high-profile maritime disputes with neighbors in the South China Sea.

site_title: Swiss freeze millions amid investigations of Malaysian fund
summary: Swiss authorities have frozen millions of dollars in funds from Malaysia's 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB) amid investigations into corruption and money laundering. Swiss and Malaysian authorities are conducting inquiries, with the Swiss Office of the Attorney General analyzing evidence and cooperating with Malaysia. 1MDB has denied reports of frozen accounts, while Malaysia's attorney general has denied reports of a new task force investigating the company. The Swiss financial regulator FINMA is checking with Swiss banks on 1MDB business dealings. International cooperation is likely to be necessary to establish the facts.

site_title: Hong Kong's August home sales hit 17-month low
summary: Hong Kong's August home sales hit a 17-month low, with 3,896 residential units sold, a 33% decrease from last year, and sales value dropping 26% to HK$31.1 billion. The decline is attributed to a deepening stock market rout in China, affecting homebuyers' sentiment, and a 12% drop in the Hang Seng Index in August. Despite a 10% year-over-year price increase, cautious buyers led to a slower market, with Aspen Crest selling just over half of its units on the first day of sales.

site_title: Tesla to produce 'economical' Model 3 in two years
summary: Tesla plans to produce its "economical" Model 3 in two years, with production dependent on the opening of its new Gigafactory battery plant in Nevada. The Model 3, priced at an estimated $35,000, will be unveiled in March 2016 and begin taking preorders. Tesla currently only sells the Model S and is set to release the Model X SUV at the end of this month. The company's latest success, the high-performance P85D, has received a 100/100 rating from Consumer Reports, breaking the previous record.

site_title: Wall St rebounds amid more wild swings in global markets
summary: US stocks rebounded on Wednesday, with major indexes gaining ground, despite ongoing global market volatility. China's economic concerns weighed on markets, with Shanghai and Tokyo experiencing losses, but European markets bounced back. Analysts attributed the US rebound to buying of blue-chip stocks and tech shares, including a 4.29% gain for Apple. Beijing is believed to have intervened to support the market, with the Chinese government transferring funds to a government-supported fund. The US Federal Reserve's Beige Book survey also provided a boost, indicating modest growth and no signs of inflationary pressures.

site_title: Luxury home sales soar in Toronto, Vancouver
summary: Luxury home sales in Toronto and Vancouver have seen significant growth, with Toronto's sales of homes worth at least C$3 million increasing 119% to 379 units in the first seven months of the year. Vancouver's sales rose 72% to 572 units. Foreign buyers, primarily Chinese families, are driving demand, attracted by Canada's stable economy and high quality of life.

site_title: What's your pants size? Hugged or held-in?
summary: Lululemon is revamping its women's workout pants, introducing a new categorization system based on "engineered sensations" or compression levels. The update includes categories such as relaxed, naked, held-in, hugged, and tight, with the held-in and hugged designs promising a secure fit. The new system aims to address customer concerns about sizing and comfort, with a new fabric called Nulu allowing for a looser fit without requiring a larger size. The move comes as the retailer seeks to reconnect with customers after a 2013 recall and compete with rising athleisure brands.

site_title: It's not the driverless car's fault - it's the other drivers': Google
summary: Google's self-driving cars are being hindered by human drivers who don't follow the rules. In a recent incident, a Google car was hit from behind while slowing down to let a pedestrian cross, despite the car being programmed to follow the law. Researchers say the main challenge is blending autonomous vehicles into a world where humans don't always follow traffic rules. Google's fleet has been involved in 16 crashes, mostly fender-benders, with human drivers at fault in every case. The company is working to improve its software to better interact with humans and avoid similar incidents.

site_title: Chinese economy still on steady growth path, says ADB chief
summary: Asian Development Bank (ADB) president Takehiko Nakao backs China's yuan devaluation, saying it has reached its "real market value." Despite concerns over China's slowing economy, Nakao believes the country will continue expanding steadily, driven by a shift to a consumption-driven model. Chinese stock prices have fallen, but remain above pre-devaluation levels, and the ADB president is optimistic about the economy's outlook.

site_title: Wikipedia blocks accounts linked to paid edits
summary: Wikipedia has blocked over 300 accounts linked to paid edits, where individuals took money to promote outside interests without disclosing their involvement. The blocked accounts, known as "sockpuppets," were used from April to August and created or altered articles with biased or skewed information. The Wikimedia Foundation stated that undisclosed paid advocacy editing may compromise the quality of content on Wikipedia, emphasizing the importance of neutrality. The blocked accounts also led to the deletion of 210 articles deemed promotional in nature.

site_title: A theory of stagnation
summary: The "secular stagnation" hypothesis, which suggests the global economy is stuck in a semi-permanent rut, has gained momentum amid China's economic woes. Proponents argue that ageing populations, globalization, and automation have depressed wages, leading to a deficient demand for new investment. If correct, this could result in a drawn-out slump and unsustainable speculative bubbles. A recent yuan devaluation by the People's Bank of China has sparked a spike in US real interest rates, sparking debate about the validity of the theory and the potential for a global economic slowdown.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: CEFC International has received an in-principle approval from the Singapore Exchange for a S$246.9 million share placement, with 705.5 million shares to be issued. The approval does not indicate the merits of the subscription or the company.

site_title: Reshaping the CFO and finance function
summary: Southeast Asia's economic integration through the Asean Economic Community (AEC) will reshape the role of CFOs, requiring them to become more effective business partners to CEOs. CFOs must upskill in areas such as technology, leadership, and cultural navigation to drive business growth and manage profitability. The AEC's increased talent mobility will also require CFOs to adapt to a more diverse finance workforce. To succeed, CFOs will need to develop skills in areas such as strategic planning, data analysis, and change management, and will increasingly be required to take on more diverse roles as "co-pilots" to the CEO.

site_title: GIC and DLF tie up to build two Delhi projects
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC and Indian real estate developer DLF Home Developers have formed a joint venture to invest in two upcoming projects in Delhi. GIC will invest approximately 1,990 crore rupees (S$422.4 million) in integrated developments with commercial, residential, and retail components. The projects are expected to be built in the Moti Nagar area of West Delhi, leveraging India's long-term growth potential and real estate sector opportunities. This investment aims to unlock embedded value in DLF's projects and may mark the start of a new partnership between the two entities.

site_title: Shunfu Ville up for sale
summary: Shunfu Ville, a 358-unit residential development in Singapore, has launched a collective sale by tender with a minimum price of S$688 million, exceeding expectations. The site, zoned for residential use with a gross plot ratio of 2.8, could yield around 1,100 units. The sale price translates to a land rate of S$791 psf and an estimated breakeven cost of S$1,250 psf for the successful purchaser. The tender closes on October 27.

site_title: Germany plans to ease banking access for refugees
summary: Germany plans to make it easier for the 800,000 refugees granted asylum this year to open bank accounts, while maintaining anti-money laundering measures. The changes aim to simplify documentation and procedures for refugees. The move follows a collaboration between the German finance ministry and financial watchdog Bafin.

site_title: 'Heart age' exceeds real age of most Americans, says CDC
summary: The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) reports that three out of four Americans' hearts are older than their chronological age, increasing the risk of heart disease, stroke, and premature death. The CDC has developed an online tool to determine an individual's "heart age" based on factors like weight, smoking, diabetes, and high blood pressure. This tool can help people assess their risk and take preventive measures to reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease.

site_title: Factory orders up for second straight month in July
summary: US factory orders rose 0.4% in July, a second consecutive month, driven by strong demand for vehicles and machinery. This increase follows a 2.2% rise in June. A strong dollar and softening global demand have hindered manufacturing, but vehicle orders are expected to remain strong after August's surge. The dollar's 16.8% gain against US trading partners since June 2014 has undercut export growth and weighed on multinationals.

site_title: Chosen shares fly on takeover news
summary: Chosen Holdings shares surged 21.2% after private equity firm Shaw Kwei & Partners announced a voluntary cash offer of 24 cents per share. The offer, which includes a 50.99% stake, has received irrevocable undertakings from five shareholders. Trading resumed after a halt on Tuesday and Wednesday morning, with shares closing at the offer price. Shaw Kwei plans to delist Chosen if it gathers enough acceptances.

site_title: Sleeker smartwatches to shine at mega gadget fair
summary: Tech giants, including Huawei and Samsung, will showcase sleek smartwatches at the IFA show in Berlin, as wearable technology is expected to dominate the event. Analysts predict 40 million smartwatches will be sold this year, with innovations in power consumption, data accuracy, and form factors being highlighted. Watchmakers like Fossil will also launch their own smartwatches, while exhibitors are expected to showcase various innovations, including chips implanted in humans and virtual reality headsets.

site_title: Former Apple Music executive moves to LVMH
summary: Former Apple Music executive Ian Rogers, 43, has joined LVMH as its chief digital officer. Rogers, who left Apple in September 2015, previously worked at Yahoo and Topspin before joining Beats, which Apple acquired for $3 billion. He cited a desire for a new challenge and more to learn and contribute, marking a significant shift in the intersection of luxury and technology industries. This move follows other high-profile personnel changes between the two sectors, highlighting their increasing collaboration and competition.

site_title: Impact of global market turmoil
summary: China's economic restructuring has led to global market turmoil, with the yuan's devaluation and stock market decline causing a 1,000-point drop in the Dow Jones Industrials. The IMF warned of a slowdown in China's GDP growth, which could impact commodity-producing countries like Australia and Brazil. However, experts argue that China's new economic model, focusing on infrastructure investment and domestic consumption, is not a cause for panic, and the government has instruments in place to deal with the situation. China's economy will still grow, albeit at a slower rate, and the country will shift its trade patterns, with a greater emphasis on investment goods and consumption.

site_title: The Ascott bags 4 Asia deals
summary: The Ascott, a serviced residence arm of CapitaLand, has secured four contracts to manage over 850 units in Asia. The contracts include the 149-unit Citadines Han River Seoul in South Korea, the 308-unit Citadines Punaka Yogyakarta in Indonesia, the 200-unit Somerset Arcadia Miri in Malaysia, and the 200-unit Citadines Central Binh Duong in Vietnam. The contracts are expected to start in the first quarter of 2016 and demonstrate the company's expansion into new markets. This growth is seen as a significant milestone for The Ascott, with the company adding 4,700 units to its global network.

site_title: Pace of US vehicle sales picks up in August
summary: US auto sales rose at a solid pace in August, boosted by demand for sport utility vehicles and pickups, with lightweight vehicle sales totaling 1.58 million. The sales pace was the strongest since July 2005 and the highest for August since 2003. General Motors reported a 6% gain in sales, with the Silverado pickup truck being its biggest seller. Ford Motor also saw a 5% increase in sales, while Fiat Chrysler Automobiles's US unit reported its best August sales in 13 years.

site_title: GE 2015 will be a keen battle for minds (and hearts) of Singaporeans
summary: Singapore's 2015 General Election (GE) is a battle for the minds and hearts of Singaporeans, with the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) and opposition framing issues differently. The PAP focuses on securing the country's future, emphasizing the need for strong leadership and policies to address restructuring and an ageing population. The party also acknowledges the importance of diversity in Parliament. With the election set for September 11, the remaining seven days of campaigning will be crucial in winning over voters, particularly those on the fence.

site_title: BCA unveils rotatable lab and a revised Green Mark 2015
summary: The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) in Singapore unveiled the world's first rotatable laboratory, the BCA SkyLab, which allows for green building research at any orientation. The lab is part of a revised Green Mark 2015 scheme, which credits building owners for driving green technology. This marks a significant step towards sustainable building practices in the tropics.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Britain's ASOS founder steps down as CEO
summary: Nick Robertson, founder of British online fashion retailer ASOS, has stepped down as CEO after 15 years, transforming the company into a retail powerhouse. He will remain a non-executive director. Nick Beighton, current COO, will take over as CEO with immediate effect. Robertson's departure comes after ASOS issued three profit warnings due to currency swings and higher investment needs, but the company has recovered, with shares rising 16% in 2015. Robertson's vision and passion have built ASOS into a world-class company, according to chairman Brian McBride.

site_title: Temasek-backed rig operator amends bond covenants again
summary: Integradora de Servicios Petroleros Oro Negro, a Mexican oil-rig operator backed by Temasek Holdings, has amended its bond covenants for the second time this year. Noteholders agreed to changes to the company's US$175 million securities due in December, following Oro Negro's failure to revalue its newest rig by an August deadline. The company is trying to lease the asset to state-owned Petroleos Mexicanos by year-end. The 11% 2015 notes have dropped to 75.38 US cents on the dollar.

site_title: The impact of smart cities
summary: The impact of smart cities on the real estate industry is significant, with opportunities for greater efficiency, transparency, and accountability. As urban populations grow, smart cities will require dynamic and flexible use of space, making traditional buildings obsolete. Real estate professionals will need to adapt to new valuation metrics and certifications, and collaborate with the tech sector to create new value chains. Smart buildings will put humans back at the center of cities, but challenges such as data privacy and security will arise. Ultimately, the real estate industry will need to evolve to become the necessary enabler of the human experience in smart cities, creating value and profits while prioritizing human well-being.

site_title: Fear the talking Fed
summary: US Federal Reserve officials' public comments have created market volatility, with recent statements from New York Federal Reserve President William Dudley and Federal Reserve Vice-Chair Stanley Fischer sparking uncertainty about the Fed's plans for interest rate hikes. Dudley suggested that the rationale for raising rates in September is "less compelling," while Fischer hinted at a possible September liftoff. The conflicting views have added to investor confusion, with market participants struggling to make sense of the economic data and Fed officials' comments. The Fed's increased transparency has contributed to the uncertainty, raising concerns about the potential consequences of monetary policy changes.

site_title: 3-month SOR jumps to 1.54% on China economic weakness
summary: Singapore's 3-month swap offer rate (SOR) has jumped to 1.54% due to China's economic weakness, a 10% increase from a week ago and a triple from its January 19th level. The three-month Sibor remains unchanged at 1.07%, but the Singdollar weakened further to S$1.4142 against the US dollar. Experts attribute the upward pressure to weaker currency expectations, higher US interest rate expectations, and exacerbated capital outflow fears. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is likely to shift its policy to neutral in October, and the SGD is expected to decline towards 1.46 against the US dollar later this year.

site_title: RHB cautious on office and hospitality Reits
summary: RHB has downgraded the Singapore Reit sector to "underweight" and specifically warned on office and hospitality Reits. The bank cites unfavourable supply-demand dynamics, slowing rental growth rates, and declining occupancy levels in the hospitality sector, as well as a surplus of office space. RHB expects Reit prices to continue falling, with the sector's dividend yield spiking to 7.3%, and prices potentially falling further until resistance at 8.6% is reached.

site_title: Candidates must have heart in right place: PM
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of a candidate's heart in the right place over their intellect or credentials during the PAP's first election rally. He stated that the party looks beyond a person's IQ and CV to assess their character and caring nature towards people. The PAP will support candidates who demonstrate strong values and a willingness to serve the country, and will not tolerate those with "flawed characters" who prioritize personal gain over public service. The party aims to maintain its high standards in politics and secure voter support to continue its work in key areas such as housing and healthcare.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Olam, CEFC: 2 trading cases needing scrutiny
summary: Olam International and CEFC International have sparked regulatory scrutiny in Singapore's stock market due to unusual trading activity prior to significant announcements. Olam's share price surged 11% on Thursday and 2% on Friday before suspension, with many questions raised about who bought the stock ahead of the announcement. CEFC International's shares also experienced a significant spike, with the exchange issuing a warning and finding concentrated buying in offshore accounts. The regulators will likely examine these trades to ensure a level playing field and prevent potential wrongdoing.

site_title: Producers of wind power at mercy of weather
summary: Wind power producers, such as NextEra Energy and Duke Energy, are experiencing reduced sales due to a lack of sufficiently windy days, despite investments of billions in turbines. This unpredictability is attributed to El Nino, a warming of the equatorial Pacific Ocean, which changes global weather patterns. The phenomenon is correlated with below-average continental wind resources. Despite tax incentives and state clean energy standards, the industry faces challenges in predicting wind patterns, which may impact future growth and profitability.

site_title: Welcome to the world of 'quantitative tightening'
summary: The world is experiencing a global monetary tightening, led by central banks, not the Federal Reserve. The recent loss of liquidity in financial markets partly explains August's trading volatility. Meanwhile, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Economies such as the UK's and South Korea's are facing challenges, including a shrinking economy and trade talks with the US. In other news, Malaysia is seizing assets worth RM3 billion, and Singapore's economy is showing signs of growth. These events highlight the complexities of the current economic landscape.

site_title: Hot summer fuels dangerous glacier melting in Central Asia
summary: Glacier melting in Central Asia is intensifying due to the hot summer, posing a threat to villages like Barssem in Tajikistan. Villagers reported hearing a low rumbling noise and witnessing mudflows destroy homes and cars. The incident highlights the alarming effects of climate change in the region, with shrinking glaciers causing widespread damage.

site_title: Oil price slump spurs tankers to make longer voyages
summary: Oil prices have plummeted by 50% since August last year, triggering "contango" and making longer voyages for tankers viable. At least five tankers are expected to sail around South Africa instead of using the Suez Canal to deliver refined products to European ports. This trend is expected to intensify if prices slide further, increasing demand for long-range product carriers and benefiting tanker owners. Rates for hauling fuels are surging, with long-range tankers earning up to $28,375 per day.

site_title: Australia economy expands at slowest pace in over 2 years
summary: Australia's economy expanded at its slowest quarterly pace in over 2 years, with a 0.2% growth in April-June, taking the annual rate to 2.0%. The expansion was driven by household spending and government expenditure, but was hindered by a 3.0% decline in mining production and weaker exports due to China's slowing growth. The Australian dollar briefly fell below 70 US cents before recovering. Despite this, the economy is expected to continue growing, with analysts suggesting that a recession is unlikely unless an unexpected shock occurs.

site_title: IMF's Lagarde hopes China's economic transition will be orderly
summary: IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde expressed hope that China's economic transition to a more market-determined economy will be managed in an "orderly fashion". The transition aims to shift growth from investment and exports to domestic demand. Lagarde noted that Asian economies are doing "pretty well" despite China's slowdown and global market volatility. To tackle future disruptions, she suggested policymakers rein in excessive credit growth and maintain adequate foreign exchange reserves. The IMF chief also downgraded its world growth estimates, citing slower expansion in Asia.

site_title: US court grants Uber drivers class action status in employment lawsuit
summary: A US court has granted Uber drivers class action status in an employment lawsuit, allowing them to sue as a group over whether they are independent contractors or employees. The ruling, made by Judge Edward Chen in San Francisco, means Uber drivers who have worked since May 2014 must opt out of an arbitration agreement to sue the company. The decision could reshape the sharing economy, potentially forcing Uber to pay Social Security and workers' compensation. Uber plans to appeal, but drivers' lawyers say the ruling is a major victory for Uber drivers.

site_title: Market turmoil not driven by worsening fundamentals
summary: Global equity markets experienced violent moves over the past two weeks, with share prices declining around 20% in six trading days. Despite a rebound after China cut interest rates, experts argue that the turmoil is not driven by worsening economic fundamentals. Instead, they point to post-crisis reforms to financial markets, such as the Volcker Rule, which have reduced the stabilizing role of banks and led to decreased liquidity and increased volatility. The reforms have also resulted in lower equity trading volumes and transaction sizes, contributing to the market's unpredictability.

site_title: Current-account surpluses back in favour as currency traders search for safe havens
summary: Currency traders are shifting focus to countries with current-account surpluses, as investors seek safe havens amid global market turmoil. The five major currencies to have strengthened against the dollar in the past month, including the euro, yen, krona, krone, and franc, all have a surplus in their current accounts. Analysts say this trend is reminiscent of the late 1990s and early 2000s, when countries with strong balance of payments were seen as safe havens. Investors are prioritizing countries with strong current-account dynamics to minimize the risk of shocks to the system.

site_title: Jokowi vows 'massive deregulation' to win investment
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo vowed to implement "massive deregulation" to attract investment, aiming to boost investor sentiment in Southeast Asia's largest economy, which has been affected by slowing domestic consumption and global downturns. This move follows recent concerns over the country's economic outlook.

site_title: Early indicative vote counts to be announced on Polling Day
summary: The Elections Department of Singapore will announce "sample count" results for each of the 29 constituencies shortly after polling closes on September 11, providing an early indication of the final results. A total of 100 ballot papers from each of the 832 polling stations will be randomly chosen and counted, with the sample count results shown as a percentage of valid votes garnered by each candidate. The sample count has a 95% confidence level and will be announced and published on the ELD's website, but the official results will be announced later by the returning officer.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Money markets passing on rate cuts: Reserve Bank of India
summary: Reserve Bank of India Governor Raghuram Rajan hailed a 72 basis point drop in one-year commercial paper rates, the lowest since 2010, as evidence his interest-rate cuts can revive the economy. Despite this, the nation's largest lender, State Bank of India, only cut its base rate 30 basis points. The total amount of commercial paper outstanding increased 30% to 2.71 trillion rupees at the end of June. This suggests banks are not fully responding to the rate cuts, leaving the central bank to drive economic growth.

site_title: Billions at stake from pandemics and natural disasters: study
summary: A new global study, commissioned by Lloyd's, estimates that billions of dollars in economic output from Southeast Asia's largest cities are at risk from threats such as pandemics and market crashes. The Lloyd's City Risk Index found that emerging economies will bear two-thirds of risk-related financial losses, with Southeast Asia's 15 largest cities facing a total of $300 billion in risk, equivalent to 17.7% of projected average annual GDP. This includes a high risk in Singapore, with $50 billion at stake from market crashes and oil price shocks.

site_title: Prospex owner selling whole building instead of strata sales
summary: The Prospex, a nine-storey commercial building in Singapore's Bugis area, is being sold as a whole by private firm Pamfleet Group for S$80 million, or S$1,913 per square foot. This move comes after sluggish office strata launches in the market. Unlike the original plan to sell strata units, the entire building is being put up for sale through an expression of interest (EOI).

images.alt_text: The nine-storey commercial building has two levels of retail podium and is located at the intersection of Victoria Street and Middle Road, hence boasts high visibility and proximity to the Bugis MRT station

site_title: China may launch new crude benchmark: sources
summary: China is reportedly set to launch a new global crude oil futures contract as early as October, potentially rivaling the London Brent and US WTI benchmarks. This move aims to increase the use of the yuan in international oil trading and better reflect China's growing influence in setting crude prices. The launch follows reforms to open up China's oil markets, despite concerns about volatile global trading conditions and China's recent market interference.

images.alt_text: China may launch a global crude oil futures contract as early as October to compete with the existing London Brent and the US WTI benchmarks, three sources said, as it pushes ahead with reforms to open up its oil markets.

site_title: ConocoPhillips axes workforce by 10%
summary: ConocoPhillips, the fourth largest US oil company, plans to reduce its workforce by 10% due to a dramatic downturn in the energy industry. The job cuts will affect around 1,800 positions, with most coming from North America, including over 500 in Houston. This move follows a trend of energy companies laying off over 120,000 workers and reducing spending by more than $114 billion since oil prices plummeted by over half.

site_title: Few take a bite at ice cream with image of executed Japanese war criminal
summary: An ice cream chain in Shanghai is selling ice cream bars with the likeness of Hideki Tojo, the former Japanese prime minister and war criminal executed in 1948, to mark the 70th anniversary of the end of World War II. The "10,000 people together eat the Japanese war criminal" campaign has sparked controversy and outrage, with many calling for the product to be removed. The ice cream chain has defended the move, stating that the product is meant to serve as a reminder of the atrocities committed during the war.

site_title: Japan Post Bank Co seen as the next whale big enough to move markets
summary: Japan Post Bank Co, the world's second-largest pension fund, is seen as a potential candidate to move markets as it plans to increase investments in assets aside from Japanese government bonds (JGBs) by 30% to 60 trillion yen in the fiscal year ending March 2018. The bank's move could help the Bank of Japan meet its annual goal of boosting money supply, and investors are watching its actions closely as the US$1.2 trillion Government Pension Investment Fund (GPIF) nears the end of its shift from JGBs to stocks.

images.alt_text: Japan Post Bank has been diversifying its investments and will continue to do so.

site_title: Economists cut 2015 Singapore growth forecast to 2.2%
summary: Singapore's forecasters have cut their 2015 growth forecast to 2.2%, citing a manufacturing sector drag and concerns about a possible technical recession in the third quarter. Private-sector economists now expect the manufacturing sector to contract 2.7% this year, down from an earlier projection of 0.5% growth. The construction and finance & insurance sectors have also seen their growth forecasts cut. Despite this, the wholesale & retail trade sector is expected to grow 4.8% in 2015, within the government's forecast of 2-2.5% expansion.

images.alt_text: Exterior of the Monetary Authority of Singapore building 18, Aug 2015

site_title: SAP unveils software for Spark
summary: SAP has released Hana Vora, a software that combines business data with information from industrial sensors and other sources using open-source data-sifting software Spark. This move aims to expand SAP's reach beyond its traditional strongholds, particularly in the database market, where Hana has a 6.3% share. By integrating Spark, SAP seeks to improve its Hana product's competitiveness, joining other major tech companies like IBM, Microsoft, and Oracle in supporting the open-source technology.

site_title: Fortnum & Mason replaces brasserie with new restaurant
summary: Fortnum & Mason has closed its 60-year-old Fountain brasserie at 45 Jermyn Street in London and plans to replace it with a new restaurant.
